as the civic temper rises , the more naive citizens begin to play soldier -- but the guns are real .	145.29968
soon they will begin to hunt down the traitors they are assured are in our midst .	295.45276
all false gods resemble moloch , at least in the early phases of their careers , so it would be unreasonable to expect any form of idol-worship to become widespread without the accompaniment of human sacrifice .	92.07206
but there is reason in all things , and in this country the heathenish cult of the motor-car is exceeding all bounds in its demands .	144.4628
the annual butchery of 40 , 000 american men , women and children to satiate its blood-lust is excessive	134.7102
a quota of 25 , 000 a year would be more than sufficient .	70.656906
no other popular idol is accorded even that much grace .	140.08258
if the railroads , for example , regularly slaughtered 25 , 000 passengers each year , the high priests of the cult would have cause to tremble for their personal safety , for such a holocaust would excite demands for the hanging of every railroad president in the united states .	96.662094
but by comparison with the railroad , the motor car is a relatively new object of popular worship , so it is too much to hope that it may be brought within the bounds of civilized usage quickly and easily .	83.92588
yet it is plainly time to make a start , and to be effective the first move should be highly dramatic , without being fanatical .	161.3319
here , then , is what swift would have called a modest proposal by way of a beginning .	62.73547
from next new year ' s day let us keep careful account of each successive fatality on the highways , publicizing it on all media of communication .	123.00334
to avoid suspicion of bigotry , let the hand of vengeance be stayed until the meat-wagon has picked up the twenty-five thousandth corpse	281.18286
but let the twenty-five thousand and first butchery be the signal for the arrest of the 50 state highway commissioners .	100.66789
then let the whole lot be hanged in a public mass execution on july 4 , 1963 .	91.67
the scene , of course , should be nine miles northwest of centralia , illinois , the geographical center of population according to the census .	147.58107
a special grandstand , protected by awnings from the midsummer sun of illinois , should be erected for occupancy by honored guests , who should include the ambassadors of all those new african nations as yet not quite convinced that the united states is thoroughly civilized .	82.94934
the band should play the rogues ' march as a processional , switching to `` hail columbia , happy land ' ' ! !	86.324684
independence day is the appropriate date as a symbolical reminder of the american article of faith that governments are instituted among men to secure to them certain inalienable rights , the first of which is life , and when any government becomes subversive of that end , it is the right of the people to alter or abolish it .	98.20551
the highway system is an agency of government , and when it grinds up 40 , 000 americans every year the government is destroying its own taxpayers , which is obviously a silly thing for any government to do .	73.82541
hanging the responsible officials would not abolish the government , but would emphasize its accountability for the lives of its individual citizens , which would certainly alter it , and definitely for the better .	79.733986
moreover , the salubrious effects would not be exclusively political , but at least partially , and perhaps primarily social .	281.8965
it would challenge sharply not the cult of the motor car itself but some of its ancillary beliefs and practices -- for instance , the doctrine that the fulfillment of life consists in proceeding from hither to yon , not for any advantage to be gained by arrival but merely to avoid the cardinal sin of stasis , or , as it is generally termed , staying put .	133.79463
true , the adherents of staying put are now reduced to a minor , even a miniscule sect , and their credo , `` home-keeping hearts are happiest ' ' , is as disreputable as socinianism .	141.84438
nonetheless , although few in number they are a stubborn crew , as tenacious of life as the hardshell baptists , which suggests that there is some kind of vital principle embodied in their faith .	116.66437
perhaps there is more truth than we are wont to admit in the conviction of that ornament of tarheelia , robert ruark ' s grandfather , who was persuaded that the great curse of the modern world is `` all this gallivantin ' ' ' .	68.966324
in any event , the yearly sacrifice of 40 , 000 victims is a hecatomb too large to be justified by the most ardent faith .	185.93384
somehow our contemporary moloch must be induced to see reason .	311.0621
since appeals to morality , to humanity , and to sanity have had such small effect , perhaps our last recourse is the deterrent example .	191.85632
if we make it established custom that whenever butchery on the highways grows excessive , say beyond 25 , 000 per annum , then somebody is going to hang , it follows that the more eminent the victim , the more impressive the lesson .	193.76672
to hang 50 governors might be preferable except that they are not directly related to the highways	74.160774
so , all things considered , the highway commissioners would seem to be elected .	20.431555
as the new clouds of radioactive fallout spread silently and invisibly around the earth , the soviet union stands guilty of a monstrous crime against the human race .	36.141098
but the guilt is shared by the united states , britain and france , the other members of the atomic club .	41.45997
until moscow resumed nuclear testing last september 1 , the us and uk had released more than twice as much radiation into the atmosphere as the russians , and the fallout from the earlier blasts is still coming down .	100.74511
as it descends , the concentration of radioactivity builds up in the human body	54.503468
for a dose of radiation is not like a flu virus which causes temporary discomfort and then dies .	114.53101
the effect of radiation is cumulative over the years -- and on to succeeding generations .	105.62317
so , while we properly inveigh against the new poisoning , history is not likely to justify the pose of righteousness which some in the west were so quick to assume when mr . khrushchev made his cynical and irresponsible threat .	121.16999
shock , dismay and foreboding for future generations were legitimate reactions	790.07715
on october 19 , after the soviets had detonated at least 20 nuclear devices , ambassador stevenson warned the un general assembly that this country , in `` self protection ' ' , might have to resume above-ground tests .	85.05518
more recently , the chairman of the atomic energy commission , dr . glenn t . seaborg , `` admitted ' ' to a news conference in las vegas , nevada , that the us might fall behind russia ( he apparently meant in weapons development ) if the soviets continue to test in the atmosphere while we abstain .	104.98071
all of which makes it more imperative than ever that the biological and genetic effects of fallout be understood .	137.17598
but for the average citizen , unfortunately , this is one of science ' s worst-marked channels , full of tricky currents and unknown depths .	90.63312
the scientists , in and out of government , do not agree on some of the most vital points , at least publicly .	62.042492
on the one hand , the public health service declared as recently as october 26 that present radiation levels resulting from the soviet shots `` do not warrant undue public concern ' ' or any action to limit the intake of radioactive substances by individuals or large population groups anywhere in the aj .	204.69543
but the phs conceded that the new radioactive particles `` will add to the risk of genetic effects in succeeding generations , and possibly to the risk of health damage to some people in the united states ' ' .	58.3501
then it added `` it is not possible to determine how extensive these ill effects will be -- nor how many people will be affected ' ' .	109.03464
having hedged its bets in this way , phs apparently decided it would be possible to make some sort of determination after all `` at present radiation levels , and even at somewhat higher levels , the additional risk is slight and very few people will be affected ' ' .	117.00465
then , to conclude on an indeterminate note `` nevertheless , if fallout increased substantially , or remained high for a long time , it would become far more important as a potential health hazard in this country and throughout the world ' ' .	87.528366
dr . linus pauling , a nobel prize winner in chemistry , has been less ambiguous , whether you choose to agree with him or not .	76.77196
after declaring , in an article last month in frontier magazine , that the russian testing `` carries with it the possibility of the most tragic consequences of any action in the history of the world ' ' , he gave this estimate of the biologic and genetic consequences if the new soviet shots totaled 200 megatons	72.03616
the damage to human germ plasm would be such that in the next few generations 160 , 000 children around the world would be born with gross physical or mental defects .	81.06635
long-lived carbon-14 from the fusion process would cause four million embryonic , neonatal or childhood deaths and stillbirths over the next 20 generations , and between 200 , 000 and one million human beings now living would have their lives cut short by radiation-produced diseases such as leukemia .	254.83978
most of these would be in the northern hemisphere , where the fallout is concentrating .	33.46166
pauling ' s estimate of 200 megatons yield from the present series of russian tests will probably turn out to be too high , but a total of 100 megatons is a distinct possibility .	59.932575
the lack of scientific unanimity on the effects of radiation is due in part to insufficient data covering large population groups , from which agreed-on generalizations could be drawn .	159.5066
but more than one conscientious researcher has been inhibited from completely frank discussion of the available evidence by the less excusable fact that fallout has been made a political issue as well as a scientific problem .	137.25494
its dangerous effects have been downgraded to the public by some who believe national security requires further testing .	450.91635
an illustration of this attitude is found in john a . mccone ' s letter to dr . thomas lauritsen , reported in a note elsewhere in this issue of the new republic .	116.49221
to this day the atomic energy commission shies away from discussing the health aspects of fallout .	161.35536
a recent study on radiation exposure by the aec ' s division of biology and medicine stated `` the question of the biological effect of ( radiation ) doses is not considered ' ' herein .	128.29001
of course , the aec is in a bind now .	225.60088
if it comes down too hard on the potential dangers of fallout , it will box the president on resuming atmospheric tests .	74.6265
so the commission ' s announcements of the new soviet shots have been confined to one or two bleak sentences , with the fission yield usually left vague .	73.33474
now , of course , that the russians are the nuclear villains , radiation is a nastier word than it was in the mid , when the us was testing in the atmosphere .	73.96072
the prevailing official attitude then seemed to be that fallout , if not exactly good for you , might not be much worse than a bad cold .	107.72829
after a nuclear blast , one bureaucrat suggested in those halcyon days , about all you had to do was haul out the broom and sweep off your sidewalks and roof .	102.12449
yet if washington gets too indignant about soviet fallout , it will have to do a lot of fast footwork if america decides it too must start pushing up the radiation count .	134.51474
as of october 25 , the aec had reported 24 shots in the new soviet series , 12 of them in a megaton range , including a super bomb with a yield of 30 to 50 megatons ( the equivalent of 30 million to 50 million tons of tnt )	72.7545
and president kennedy indicated there were one or two more than those reported .	97.41108
assuming the lower figure for the big blast and one shot estimated by the japanese at 10 megatons , a conservative computation is that the 24 announced tests produced a total yield of at least 60 megatons .	208.9685
some government scientists say privately that the figure probably is closer to 80 megatons , and that the full 50-megaton bomb that khrushchev mentioned may still be detonated .	113.42091
if the new soviet series has followed the general pattern of previous russian tests , the shots were roughly half fission and half fusion , meaning a fission yield of 30 to 40 megatons thus far .	105.26422
to this must be added the 90 to 92 megatons of fission yield produced between the dawn of the atomic age in 1945 and the informal three-power test moratorium that began in november , 1958 .	60.615597
one of the inescapable realities of the cold war is that it has thrust upon the west a wholly new and historically unique set of moral dilemmas .	114.87198
the first dilemma was the morality of nuclear warfare itself .	37.7423
that dilemma is as much with us as ever .	116.04524
the second great dilemma has been the morality of nuclear testing , a dilemma which has suddenly become acute because of the present series of soviet tests .	67.47027
when this second dilemma first became obvious -- during the mid to late ' 50 ' s -- the united states appeared to have three choices .	121.53223
it could have unilaterally abandoned further testing on the grounds of the radiation hazard to future generations .	58.09078
it could have continued testing to the full on the grounds that the radiation danger was far less than the danger of communist world domination .	84.34528
or it could have chosen to find -- by negotiation -- some way of stopping the tests without loss to national security .	229.32674
with the resumption of soviet testing and their intransigence at the geneva talks , however , the hope that this third choice would prove viable has been shaken .	103.89781
once again , the united states must choose .	202.0598
and once again , the choices are much the same .	33.323593
only this time around the conditions are different and the choice is far harder .	71.26624
the first choice , abandoning tests entirely , would not only be unpopular domestically , but would surely be exploited by the russians .	79.23378
the second choice , full testing , has become even more risky just because the current soviet tests have already dangerously contaminated the atmosphere .	152.67322
the third choice , negotiation , presupposes , as russian behavior demonstrates , a great deal of wishful thinking to make it appear reasonable .	59.122482
we take the position , however , that the third choice still remains the only sane one open to us .	134.1708
it is by no stretch of the imagination a happy choice and the arguments against it as a practical strategy are formidable .	186.95009
its primary advantage is that it is a moral choice	864.9469
one which , should it fail , will not have contaminated the conscience .	107.28389
leaving aside the choice of unilateral cessation of tests as neither sane nor clearly moral , the question must arise as to why resumption of atmospheric tests on our part would not be a good choice .	91.21874
for that is the one an increasingly large number of prominent americans are now proposing .	128.52647
in particular , governor nelson rockefeller has expressed as cogently and clearly as anyone the case for a resumption of atmospheric tests .	73.29125
speaking recently in miami , governor rockefeller said that `` to assure the sufficiency of our own weapons in the face of the recent soviet tests , we are now clearly compelled to conduct our own nuclear tests ' ' .	47.289955
taking account of the fact that such a move on our part would be unpopular in world opinion , he argued that the responsibility of the united states is `` to do , confidently and firmly , not what is popular , but what is right ' ' .	71.65944
what was missing in the governor ' s argument , as in so many similar arguments , was a premise which would enable one to make the ethical leap from what might be militarily desirable to what is right .	139.07341
the possibility , as he asserted , that the russians may get ahead of us or come closer to us because of their tests does not supply the needed ethical premise -- unless , of course , we have unwittingly become so brutalized that nuclear superiority is now taken as a moral demand .	155.19318
besides the lack of an adequate ethical dimension to the governor ' s case , one can ask seriously whether our lead over the russians in quality and quantity of nuclear weapons is so slight as to make the tests absolutely necessary .	99.255775
recent statements by the president and defense department spokesmen have , to the contrary , assured us that our lead is very great .	152.20103
unless the administration and the defense department have been deceiving us , the facts do not support the assertion that we are `` compelled ' ' to resume atmospheric testing .	61.96852
it is perfectly conceivable that a resumption of atmospheric tests may , at some point in the future , be necessary and even justifiable .	64.269
but a resumption does not seem justifiable now .	9.083395
what we need to realize is that the increasingly great contamination of the atmosphere by the soviet tests had radically increased our own moral obligations .	108.82926
we now have to think not only of our national security but also of the future generations who will suffer from any tests we might undertake .	147.57367
this is an ethical demand which cannot be evaded or glossed over by talking exclusively of weapon superiority or even of the evil of communism .	86.3701
too often in the past russian tactics have been used to justify like tactics on our part .	83.9951
there ought to be a point beyond which we will not allow ourselves to go regardless of what russia does .	111.119225
the refusal to resume atmospheric testing would be a good start .	57.001957
when his holiness pope john 23 , first called for an ecumenical council , and at the same time voiced his yearning for christian unity , the enthusiasm among catholic and protestant ecumenicists was immediate .	119.09041
with good reason it appeared that a new day was upon divided christendom .	299.65417
but as the more concrete plans for the work of the council gradually became known , there was a rather sharp and abrupt disappointment on all sides .	80.94993
the council we now know will concern itself directly only with the internal affairs of the church .	59.909863
as it has turned out , however , the excessive enthusiasm in the first instance and the loss of hope in the second were both wrong responses .	81.20757
two things have happened in recent months to bring the council into perspective each provides a basis for renewed hope and joy .	222.05457
first of all , it is now known that pope john sees the renewal and purification of the church as an absolutely necessary step toward christian unity .	96.14087
far from being irrelevant to the ecumenical task , the pontiff believes that a revivified church is required in order that the whole world may see catholicism in the best possible light .	180.05925
equally significant , pope john has said that catholics themselves bear some responsibility for christian disunity .	541.7461
a major aim of the council will be to remove as far as possible whatever in the church today stands in the way of unity .	71.69314
secondly , a whole series of addresses and actions by the pope and by others show that concern for christian unity is still very much alive and growing within the church .	113.640755
the establishment , by the holy father , of a permanent secretariat for christian unity in 1960 was the most dramatic mark of this concern .	113.165924
the designation of five catholic theologians to attend the world council of churches assembly in new delhi as `` official ' ' observers reverses the church ' s earlier stand .	112.12529
the public appeal by the new vatican secretary of state , cardinal cicognani , for renewed efforts toward eastern and western reunion was still another remarkable act .	145.6504
nor can one forget pope john ' s unprecedented meeting with the archbishop of canterbury .	46.92604
augustin cardinal bea , the director of the secretariate for christian unity , has expressed as directly as anyone the new spirit that pervades the church ' s stance toward the protestant and orthodox churches .	122.15838
noting all the difficulties that stand in the way of reunion , he has said that they ought not to discourage anyone .	60.198948
for discouragement , or the temptation to abandon our efforts , `` would show that one placed excessive trust in purely human means without thinking of the omnipotence of god , the irresistible efficacy of prayer , the action of christ or the power of the divine spirit ' ' .	79.955956
can any christian fail to respond to these words ? ?	12.985756
the administration ' s official budget review , which estimates a 6 . 9 billion dollar deficit for the current fiscal year , isn ' t making anyone happy .	50.6202
certainly it isn ' t making the president happy , and he has been doing his apologetic best to explain how the budget got into its unbalanced condition , how he intends to economize wherever he can and how he hopes to do better next year .	131.97401
we sympathize with mr . kennedy , but we feel bound to say that his budget review doesn ' t please us either , although for very different reasons .	119.44994
furthermore , we find his defense of the unbalanced budget more dismaying than reassuring .	253.2663
in the first place , a large part of the discrepancy between president eisenhower ' s estimate of a 1 . 5 billion dollar surplus for the same period and the new estimate of an almost seven billion dollar deficit is the result of the outgoing president ' s farewell gift of a political booby-trap to his successor .	54.11632
the eisenhower budget was simultaneously inadequate in its provisions and yet extravagant in its projections of revenue to be received .	169.10855
the rest of the deficit is also easily understood .	14.023603
four billion dollars of the spending increase is for defense , an expenditure necessitated by the penny-wise policies of the eisenhhower administration , quite apart from the recent crises in berlin and elsewhere .	122.17434
four hundred million dollars of the increase is for the expanded space program , a responsibility similarly neglected by mr . eisenhower .	91.667816
the farm program will cost an additional 1 . 5 billion , because of unusual weather factors , the food for peace program and other new measures .	132.26836
anti-recession programs -- aid for the unemployed , their children and for depressed areas -- account for only 900 million of the 6 . 9 billion dollar deficit .	84.1624
our complaint is that in many crucial areas the kennedy programs are not too large but too small , most seriously in regard to the conventional arms build-up and in aid and welfare measures .	200.62009
and yet mr . kennedy persists in trying to mollify the intransigents of the right with apologies and promises of `` tightening up ' ' and `` economizing ' ' .	55.824352
we wish the president would remember that `` fiscal responsibility ' ' was the battle-cry of the party that lost the election .	130.89287
the party that won used to say something about a new frontier .	39.434513
introduction of the `` dialogue ' ' principle proved strikingly effective at the thirty-fourth annual meeting of the catholic association for international peace in washington the last weekend in october .	79.29951
two of the principal addresses were delivered by prominent protestants , and when the speaker was a catholic , one `` discussant ' ' on the dais tended to be of another religious persuasion .	110.08396
sessions devoted to `` ethics and foreign policy trends ' ' , `` moral principle and political judgment ' ' , `` christian ethics in the cold war ' ' and related subjects proved to be much livelier under this procedure than if catholics were merely talking to themselves .	138.93163
usually questions from the floor were directed to the non-catholic speaker or discussion leader .	82.004814
in the earlier sessions there was plentiful discussion on the natural law , which dr . william v . o ' brien of georgetown university , advanced as the basis for widely acceptable ethical judgments on foreign policy .	71.99527
that aristotelean-thomistic principle experienced a thorough going-over from a number of the participants , but in the end the concept came to reassert itself .	67.836
speakers declared that protestants often make use of it , if , perhaps , by some other name .	113.08641
a lebanese moslem told about its existence and application in the islamic tradition as the `` divine law ' ' , while a c . a . i . p . member who has been working in close association with delegates of the new u . n . nations told of its widespread recognition on the african continent .	85.23065
the impression was unmistakable that , whatever one may choose to call it , natural law is a functioning generality with a certain objective existence .	102.3771
another question that arose was the nature of the dialogue itself .	83.745705
the stimulus from the confrontation of philosophical systems involving certain differences was undeniable .	68.600815
it was expected that the comparison of different approaches to ethics would produce a better grasp of each other ' s positions and better comprehension of one ' s own .	95.58735
but a realization that each group has much of substance to learn from the other also developed , and a strong conviction grew that each had insights and dimensions to contribute to ethically acceptable solutions of urgent political issues .	280.2102
one effect of the spirited give-and-take of these discussions was to focus attention on practical applications and the necessity of being armed with the facts knowledge of the destructive force of even the tiniest `` tactical ' ' atomic weapon would have a bearing on judgments as to the advisability of its use -- to defend berlin , for example	92.019485
the pervasive influence of ideology on our political judgments needs to be recognized and taken into due account	307.1603
it is necessary to perceive the extent of foreign aid demanded by the christian imperative .	183.06831
everywhere i went in formosa i asked the same question .	115.072136
i was searching for an accent of self-delusion or , even , of hypocrisy .	107.585625
i never found it among any of the chinese with whom i spoke , though granted they were , almost all , members of the official family who , presumably , harbor official thoughts .	277.80576
but i questioned , also , professional soldiers , who would not easily be hypnotized by a septuagenarian ' s dreamy irredentism .	39.462776
their answer was it can be done , and we will do it .	34.201847
and then i put the question as pointedly as i could directly to chiang kai-shek `` in america ' ' , i said , `` practically no one believes that you subjectively intend to re-enter the mainland .	40.102577
what evidence is there of an objective kind that in fact your government proposes to do just that , and that it can be done ' ' ? ?	38.518322
( he always smiles -- at least at visitors , i gather .	176.13686
he smiled also at a british bloke seated next to me , who asked the most asinine questions .	169.3588
i recalled sympathetically the duke ' s complaint in browning ' s `` my last duchess ' ' .	28.324978
) he smiled , and said a word or two to the interpreter , who turned to me , `` the president wonders where you are going after you leave taipei ' ' ? ?	83.928474
that , i smarted , is a royal rebuff if ever there was one .	107.73973
i answered the routine question about my itinerary , rather coolly .	81.823494
chiang spoke again , this time at greater length .	28.215694
`` the president says ' ' , the translator came in , `` that the reason he asked you where you were going is because he hoped you would be visiting other areas in southeast asia , and that everywhere you went , you would seek the answer to your question .	137.04274
he says that if he were to express to you , once again , his own profound determination to go to the mainland , and his faith that that return is feasible , he would merely sound redundant .	79.88557
so you yourself must seek these objective data , and come to your own conclusions .	85.28306
any information we have here in taiwan is at your disposal ' ' .	17.385456
for every person on taiwan , there are sixty in mainland china .	169.72128
if the raw population figures are crucially relevant , then it is idle to think of liberation , as idle as to suppose that poland might liberate russia .	138.89883
less than 60-1 , but at least 6-1 .	6.841947
the estimates vary widely on the strength of the chinese army .	28.255459
the armed forces of taiwan are at a working strength of about 450 , 000 , though a reserve potential twice that high is contemplated .	264.24786
it is generally conceded that the formosan air force is the best by far in asia , and the army the best trained .	110.75988
even so , it adds up to impossible odds , except that the question arises , on whose side would the mainland chinese army fight ? ?	114.28362
the miserable people of china , the largest cast ever conscripted to enact an ideological passion play , cannot themselves resist overtly .	474.43094
they think , perforce , of physical survival everything else is secondary .	137.50894
but the army which mao continues to feed well , where are its sympathies ? ?	111.49909
the psychological strategists in taiwan stress the great sense of family , cultivated in china over thousands of years .	108.90812
it has not been extirpated by ten years of communist depersonalization .	143.45892
every soldier in the army has , somewhere , relatives who are close to starvation .	82.77431
the soldiers themselves cannot stage a successful rebellion , it is assumed but will their discontent spread to the officer class ? ?	225.87515
the immediate families of the generals and the admirals are well fed a despot does not economize on his generals .	308.11807
but there are the cousins and aunts and nephews .	160.48996
to whom will the generals stay loyal ? ?	1.1928084
there is little doubt if they had a secret ballot , they would vote for food for their family , in place of ideological purity out on the farm .	149.16777
it is another question whether `` they ' ' -- or a single general , off in a corner of china , secure for a few ( galvanizing ? ?	94.59286
) days at least from instant retaliation -- will defy the party .	84.29635
but the disposition to rebel is most definitely there .	42.827724
the military in taiwan believe that the communists have made two mistakes , which , together , may prove fatal .	77.59355
the first was the commune program , which will ensure agricultural poverty for years .	225.43636
and where it is not , it is left with no residue , and the social meaning of this is enormous .	139.004
for it is the family that , in china , has always provided social security for the indigent , the sick , the down-and-out members of the clan .	148.90709
but the government is left with no reserve granary , under the agricultural system it has ordained .	117.37547
thus the government simultaneously undertook the vast burden of social security which had traditionally been privately discharged , and created a national scarcity which has engendered calamitous problems of social security .	150.26546
tibet has historically served china as a buffer state .	121.969154
a friendly state , sometimes only semi-independent , but never hostile .	454.1557
china never tried to integrate tibet by extirpating the people ' s religion and institutions .	105.29159
red china is trying to do this , and she is not likely ever to succeed .	67.67704
tibet is too vast , the terrain is too difficult .	169.75706
tibet may bleed china as algeria is bleeding france .	97.37903
these continuing pressures , social , economic and military , are doing much to keep china in a heightening state of tension .	191.13841
the imposition of yet another pressure , a strong one , from the outside , might cause it to snap .	133.55286
the planners in taiwan struck me as realistic men .	97.85558
they know that they must depend heavily on factors outside their own control .	186.24832
first and foremost , they depend on the inhuman idiocies of the communist regime .	58.460106
secondly , they depend on america ' s `` moral cooperation ' ' when the crucial moment arrives .	162.88155
they hope that if history vouchsafes the west another budapest , we will receive the opportunity gladly .	130.69566
i remarked jocularly to the president that the future of china would be far more certain if he would invite a planeload of selected american liberals to quemoy on an odd day .	139.95786
he affected ( most properly ) not to understand my point .	175.68423
but he -- and all of china -- wears the scars of american indecisiveness , and he knows what an uncertain ally we are .	89.17426
we have been grand to formosa itself -- lots of aid , and , most of the time , a policy of support for the offshore islands .	87.3812
but our outlook has been , and continues to be , defensive .	179.14032
a great deal depends on the crystallization of mr . kennedy ' s views on the world struggle .	28.425835
the free chinese know that the situation on the mainland is in flux , and are poised to strike .	52.066914
there is not anywhere on the frontiers of freedom a more highly mobilized force for liberation .	144.72113
the moment of truth is the moment of crisis .	24.093641
during the slow buildup , the essence of a policy or a man is concealed under embroidered details , fine words , strutting gestures .	159.3118
there the truth is , open to eyes that are willing to look .	57.409344
new self-deceiving rags are hurriedly tossed on the too-naked bones .	297.1811
a truth-revealing crisis erupted in katanga for a couple of days this month , to be quickly smothered by the high pressure verbal fog that is kept on tap for such emergencies .	97.94237
before memory , too , clouds over , let us make a note or two of what could be seen .	98.96673
the measure was instantly taken , as always in such cases , of public men at many levels .	191.94635
one knows better , now , who has bone and who has jelly in his spine .	182.74403
but i am here concerned more with policy than with men .	124.821686
public men come and go but great issues of policy remain .	118.55135
now , everyone knows -- or knew in the week of december 10 -- that something had gone shockingly wrong with american foreign policy .	163.37894
the united states was engaged in a military attack on a peaceful , orderly people governed by a regime that had proved itself the most pro-western and anti-communist within any of the new nations -- the only place in africa , moreover , where a productive relationship between whites and blacks had apparently been achieved .	100.69035
of course the fighting was officially under the auspices of the united nations .	15.451236
but in the moment of truth everyone could see that the u . s . was in reality the principal .	47.090748
the moment simultaneously revealed that in the crisis our policy ran counter to that of all our nato allies , to the entire western community .	92.9343
by our policy the west was -- is -- split .	80.26771
the controlling pattern was first displayed in the hungary-suez crisis of november 1956 .	568.04126
it reappears , in whole or part , whenever a new crisis exposes the reality in cuba last spring ( with which the dominican events of last month should be paired )	190.9615
at the peaks of the nuclear test and the berlin cycles	174.21494
in relation to laos , algeria , south africa	3.7496824
right now , with almost cartoon emphasis , in the temporally linked complex of tshombe-gizenga-goa-ghana .	188.97212
this prime element of the truth may be stated as follows under prevailing policy , the u . s . can take the initiative against the right , but cannot take the initiative against the left .	45.165897
it makes no difference what part of the world is involved , what form of regime , what particular issue .	274.38782
the u . s . cannot take the initiative against the left .	81.89832
there is even some question whether the u . s . can any longer defend itself against an initiative by the left .	112.34857
we can attack tshombe , but not gigenza .	18.309143
no matter that gizenga is moscow ' s man in the congo .	104.66726
no matter that it is his troops who rape western women and eat western men .	311.20886
no matter that the katanga operation is strategically insane in terms of western interests in africa .	65.25635
( even granted that the congo should be unified , you don ' t protect western security by first removing the pro-western weight from the power equilibrium .	162.45648
we can force britain and france out of the suez , but we cannot so much as try to force the russian tanks back from budapest .	109.20822
we can mass our fleet against the trujillos , but not against the castros .	62.998127
we can vote in the un against south african apartheid or portuguese rule in angola , but we cannot even introduce a motion on the berlin wall -- much less , give the simple order to push the wall down .	123.83123
we officially receive the anti-french , moscow-allied algerian fln , but we denounce the pro-europe , anti-communist oas as criminal .	82.696465
in the very week of our war against katanga , we make a $133 million grant to kwame nkrumah , who has just declared his solidarity with the communist bloc , and is busily turning his own country into a totalitarian dictatorship .	81.74343
as our planes land the war materiel that kills pro-western katangans , we stand supinely bleating while nehru ' s troops smash into a five-hundred-year-old district of our nato ally , portugal .	160.39609
it is the consequence of the system of ideas that constitutes the frame of our international -- and in some degree our domestic -- policy .	208.8933
the suez-hungary crisis proves that this system was not invented by the new administration , but only made more consistent and more active .	124.435104
most immediately relevant to these episodes in goa , katanga and ghana , as to the suez-hungary crisis before them , is the belief that the main theater of the world drama is the underdeveloped region of asia , africa and latin america .	68.23861
from this belief is derived the practical orientation of our policy on the `` uncommitted ' ' ( `` neutralist ' ' , `` contested ' ' ) nations , especially on those whose leaders make the most noise -- nehru , tito , nkrumah , sukarno , betancourt , etc . .	45.890118
our chief aim becomes that of finding favor in neutralist eyes .	142.46548
if we grasp this orientation as a key , our national conduct in all of the events here mentioned becomes intelligible .	110.3025
and it becomes clear why in general we cannot take the initiative against the left .	70.647
to write a play , the dramatist once needed an idea plus the imagination , the knowledge of life and the craft to develop it .	93.56449
nowadays , more and more , all he needs is someone else ' s book .	79.2408
to get started , he does not scan the world about him	399.04785
he and his prospective producer just read the bestseller lists .	133.3357
so far this season , broadway ' s premieres have included twice as many adaptations and imports as original american stage plays .	444.48517
of straight dramas , there are all the way home , which owes much of its poetic power to the james agee novel , a death in the family	106.96009
the wall , awkwardly based on the john hersey novel	40.240936
advise and consent , lively but shallow theater drawn from the mountainously detailed bestseller	197.72781
face of a hero ( closed ) , based on a pierre boulle novel .	96.4607
the only original works attempting to reach any stature tennessee williams ' disappointing domestic comedy , period of adjustment , and arthur laurents ' clever but empty invitation to a march .	206.07504
clearly the most provocative plays are all imported originals -- a taste of honey , by britain ' s young ( 19 when she wrote it ) shelagh delaney	218.89397
the hostage ( closed ) , by ireland ' s brendan behan .	127.798256
among the musicals , camelot came from t . h . white ' s the once and future king , and novels were the sources of the less than momentous tenderloin and do re mi .	98.13132
wildcat and the unsinkable molly brown were originals , but pretty bad , leaving top honors again to an import -- the jaunty and charmingly french irma la douce .	252.38501
the only other works at least technically original were dreary farces -- send me no flowers ( closed ) , under the yum-yum tree , critic ' s choice .	125.289604
in the forthcoming the conquering hero and carnival , broadway is not even adapting books , but reconverting old movies ( hail the conquering hero and lili ) .	241.07323
originals are not necessarily good and adaptations are not necessarily bad .	26.63054
some memorable plays have been drawn from books , notably life with father and diary of anne frank .	136.38438
and particularly in the musical field , adaptations have long been the rule , from die fledermaus and the merry widow to oklahoma ! and my fair lady .	209.06996
as critic walter kerr points out `` adaptations , so long as they are good , still qualify as creative ' ' .	94.335754
and other defenders invariably argue that , after all , shakespeare and moliere were adapters too .	126.70127
the difference is that the masters took the bare frame of a plot and filled it with their own world	142.62073
most modern adapters totally accept the world of a book , squeeze it dry of life , and add only one contribution of their own stage technique .	127.71571
the most frequent excuse for the prevalence of unoriginals and tested imports is increasing production expense -- producers cannot afford to take chances .	290.6146
off-broadway , where production is still comparatively cheap , is proving itself only slightly more original .	239.19821
laudably enough , it is offering classics and off-beat imports , but last week only one u . s . original was on the boards , robert d . hock ' s stunning civil war work , borak .	112.23751
the real trouble seems to be the failing imagination of u . s . playwrights .	44.67871
he `` come with me to the casbah ' ' .	2.604811
she `` by subway or cab ' ' ? ?	8.564167
that exchange was not only possible but commonplace last week in manhattan , as more and more new yorkers were discovering 29th street and eighth avenue , where half a dozen small nightclubs with names like arabian nights , grecian palace and egyptian gardens are the american inpost of belly dancing .	81.0262
their burgeoning popularity may be a result of the closing of the 52nd street burlesque joints , but curiously enough their atmosphere is almost always familial -- neighborhood saloons with a bit of epidermis .	130.22139
the belly boites , with their papier-mache palm trees or hand-painted ionic columns , heretofore existed mainly on the patronage of greek and turkish families .	57.491833
between performances , enthusiastic young men from the audience will take the floor to demonstrate their own amateur graces .	80.39392
except for the odd uptown sex maniac or an overeager greek sailor , the people watch in calm absorption .	78.772224
small , shirt-sleeved orchestras play in 2/4 or 4/4 time , using guitars , violins , and more alien instruments with names that would open sesame the oud , grandfather of the lute	138.10454
the darbuka , a small drum with the treelike shape of a roemer glass	321.44278
the girls sit quietly with the musicians , wearing prim dresses or plain , secretarial shifts , until it is time to go off to a back room and reappear in the spare uniform of the harem .	108.87722
if a dancer is good , she suggests purely and superbly the fundamental mechanics of ancestry and progeny -- the continuum of mankind .	90.21863
but a great many of what variety calls the `` cooch terpers ' ' are considerably less cosmic than that .	87.70065
each dancer follows the ancient oriental pattern -- she glides sideways with shoulders motionless while her stomach migrates , and , through breathing and muscle control , she sends ripples across her body to the fingertips and away to the far end of the room .	133.83197
this is done at varying speeds , ranging from the slow and fast shifte telli ( a musical term meaning double strings ) to the fastest , ecstatic karshilama ( meaning greetings or welcome ) .	205.6554
the new york dancers are highly eclectic , varying the pattern with all kinds of personal improvisations , back bends or floor crawls .	100.079285
the belly dance leaves more to the imagination .	18.294212
when a dancer does well , she provokes a quiet bombardment of dollar bills -- although the manhattan clubs prohibit the more cosmopolitan practice of slipping the tips into the dancers ' costumes .	166.24965
with tips , the girls average between $150 and $200 a week , depending on basic salary .	112.86683
although they are forbidden to sit with the customers , the dancers are sometimes proffered drinks , and most of them can bolt one down in mid-shimmy .	99.747505
all over the country , belly clubs have never been bigger , especially in detroit , boston and chicago , and even in small towns	68.32219
one of the best dancers , a turkish girl named semra , works at a roadhouse outside bristol , conn . .	116.22367
the girls are kept booked and moving by several agents , notably voluble , black-bearded murat somay , a manhattan turk who is the sol hurok of the central abdomen .	120.32064
he can offer nine turkish girls , plans to import at least 15 more .	260.74573
but a great many of the dancers are more or less native .	132.84064
sometimes they get their initial experience in church haflis , conducted by lebanese and syrians in the u . s . , where they dance with just as few veils across their bodies as in nightclubs .	68.84803
as the girls come to belly dancing from this and other origins , the melting pot has never bubbled more intriguingly .	99.52806
jemela ( surname gerby ) , 23 , seems hong kong oriental but has a spanish father and an indian mother , was born in america and educated at holy cross academy and textile high school , says she learned belly dancing at family picnics .	153.49844
serene ( mrs . wilson ) , 23 , was born in budapest and raised in manhattan .	83.973076
daughter of a gypsy mother who taught her to dance , she is one of the few really beautiful girls in the new york casbah , with dark eyes and dark , waist-length hair , the face of an adolescent patrician and a lithe , glimmering body .	110.896324
many belly dancers are married , but serene is one of the few who will admit it .	58.04706
marlene ( surname adamo ) , 25 , a brazilian divorcee who learned the dance from arabic friends in paris , now lives on manhattan ' s west side , is about the best belly dancer working the casbah , loves it so much that she dances on her day off .	163.10509
she has the small , highly developed body of a prime athlete , and holds in contempt the `` girls who just move sex ' ' .	149.44977
leila ( malia phillips ) , 25 , is a greenwich village painter of persianesque miniatures who has red hair that cascades almost to her ankles .	254.3725
a graduate of hollywood high school , she likes to imagine herself , as she takes the floor , `` a village girl coming in to a festival ' ' .	118.06868
gloria ( surname ziraldo ) , circa 30 , who was born in italy and once did `` chorus work ' ' in toronto , has been around longer than most of the others , wistfully remembers the old days when `` we used to get the seamen from the ships , you know , with big turtleneck sweaters and handkerchiefs and all .	95.09857
but the ships are very slow now , and we don ' t get so many sailors any more ' ' .	76.15603
the uptown crowd has moved in , and what girl worth her seventh veil would trade a turtleneck sweater for a button-down collar ? ?	365.9485
of the handful of painters that austria has produced in the 20th century , only one , oskar kokoschka , is widely known in the u . s . .	34.9951
this state of unawareness may not last much longer .	23.285448
for ten years a small group of european and u . s . critics has been calling attention to the half-forgotten austrian expressionist egon schiele , who died 42 years ago at the age of 28 .	60.09575
the critics ' campaign finally inspired the first major u . s . exhibit of schiele ' s works .	22.373207
the show has been to boston and manhattan , will in time reach pittsburgh and minneapolis .	125.75862
last week it opened at the j . b . speed museum in louisville , at the very moment that a second schiele exhibit was being made ready at the felix landau gallery in los angeles .	92.91551
schiele ' s paintings are anything but pleasant .	19.872887
his people ( see color ) are angular and knobby-knuckled , sometimes painfully stretched , sometimes grotesquely foreshortened .	81.0873
his colors are dark and murky , and his landscapes and cityscapes seem swallowed in gloom .	212.9846
but he painted some of the boldest and most original pictures of his time , and even after nearly half a century , the tense , tormented world he put on canvas has lost none of its fascination .	148.73274
the son of a railway stationmaster , schiele lived most of his childhood in the drowsy danubian town of tulln , 14 miles northwest of vienna .	176.81908
he was an emotional , lonely boy who spent so much time turning out drawings that he did scarcely any schoolwork .	150.2742
when he was 15 , his parents finally allowed him to attend classes at the academy of fine arts in vienna .	49.342422
even there he did not last for long .	6.766221
cried one professor after a few months of student schiele ' s tantrums and rebellion `` the devil himself must have defecated you into my classroom ' ' ! !	184.50063
for a while his work was influenced deeply by the french impressionists , and by the patterned , mosaic-like paintings of gustav klimt , then the dean of austrian art .	83.402664
gradually schiele evolved a somber style of his own -- and he had few inhibitions about his subject matter .	131.08586
his pictures were roundly denounced as `` the most disgusting things one has ever seen in vienna ' ' .	63.336563
he himself was once convicted of painting erotica and jailed for 24 days -- the first three of which he spent desperately trying to make paintings on the wall with his own spittle .	121.951645
for years he wore hand-me-down suits and homemade paper collars , was even driven to scrounging for cigarette butts in vienna ' s gutters .	166.78322
drafted into the austrian army , he rebelliously rejected discipline , wangled a vienna billet , went on painting .	147.90654
it was not until the last year of his life that he had his first moneymaking show .	75.86125
the unabashed sexuality of so many of his paintings was not the only thing that kept the public at bay his view of the world was one of almost unrelieved tragedy , and it was too much even for morbid-minded vienna .	158.91098
he was obsessed by disease and poverty , by the melancholy of old age and the tyranny of lust .	85.97854
the children he painted were almost always in rags , his portraits were often ruthless to the point of ugliness , and his nudes -- including several self-portraits -- were stringy , contorted and strangely pathetic .	146.71677
the subject he liked most was the female body , which he painted in every state -- naked , half-dressed , muffled to the ears , sitting primly in a chair , lying tauntingly on a bed or locked in an embrace .	80.66079
the most surprising thing about the twenty-second congress of the soviet communist party is that it is surprising -- perhaps quite as much , in its own way , as the twentieth congress of 1956 , which ended with that famous `` secret ' ' report on stalin .	59.348534
the publication last july of the party ' s draft program -- that blueprint for the `` transition to communism ' ' -- had led the uninitiated to suppose that this twenty-second congress would be a sort of apotheosis of the khrushchev regime , a solemn consecration of ideas which had , in fact , been current over the last three or four years ( i . e . , since the defeat of the `` anti-party group ' ' ) in all theoretical party journals .	83.337395
these never ceased to suggest that if , in the eyes of marx and lenin `` full communism ' ' was still a very distant ideal , the establishment of a communist society had now , under khrushchev , become an `` immediate and tangible reality ' ' .	126.75469
it seems that khrushchev himself took a very special pride in having made a world-shaking contribution to marxist doctrine with his draft program ( a large part of his twelve-hour speech at the recent congress was , in fact , very largely a rehash of that interminable document ) .	227.87914
he and other soviet leaders responsible for the document were proud of having brought forward some new formulas , such as the early replacement of the dictatorship of the proletariat by an `` all people ' s state ' ' , and also of having laid down the lines for a much greater `` democratization ' ' of the whole hierarchy of soviets , starting with the supreme soviet itself .	105.53759
their plan for rotation of leaders promised a salutary blow at `` bureaucracy ' ' and would enable `` the people ' ' to take a more direct and active part in running the country .	63.240654
there might even be two or more candidates for voters to choose from .	125.41572
no doubt , there was still a lot in the draft program -- and in khrushchev ' s speech -- which left many points obscure .	149.27762
was it the party ' s intention , for example , to abolish gradually the kolkhoz system and replace it by uniformly wage-earning kolkhozes , i . e . , state farms ( which were , moreover , to be progressively `` urbanized ' ' ) ? ?	115.71365
as we know , the soviet peasant today still very largely thrives on being able to sell the produce grown on his private plot	108.73196
and it is still very far from certain how valid the party ' s claim is that in `` a growing number of kolkhozes ' ' the peasants are finding it more profitable , to surrender their private plots to the kolkhoz and to let the latter be turned into something increasingly like a state farm .	173.25322
if one follows the reports of the congress , one finds that there still seems considerable uncertainty in the minds of the leaders themselves about what exactly to do in this matter .	101.262665
the draft program was interesting in other respects , too .	59.10974
it contained , for example , a number of curious admissions about the peasants , who enjoy no sickness benefits , no old-age pensions , no paid holidays	182.72916
they still benefit far less than the `` other ' ' 50 per cent of the nation from that `` welfare state ' ' which the soviet union so greatly prides itself on being .	116.735374
over all these fairly awkward problems khrushchev was to skate rather lightly	601.1295
and , though he repeated , over and over again , the spectacular figures of industrial and agricultural production in 1980 , the `` ordinary ' ' people in russia are still a little uncertain as to how `` communism ' ' is really going to work in practice , especially in respect of food .	80.29156
would agriculture progress as rapidly as industry ? ?	1.1117502
this was something on which k . himself seemed to have some doubts	53.038486
for he kept on threatening that he would `` pull the ears ' ' of those responsible for agricultural production .	73.08402
and , as we know , the virgin lands are not producing as much as khrushchev had hoped .	160.14595
one cannot but wonder whether these doubts about the success of khrushchev ' s agricultural policy have not at least something to do with one of the big surprises provided by this congress -- the obsessive harping on the crimes and misdeeds of the `` anti-party group ' ' -- molotov , malenkov , kaganovich and others -- including the eighty-year-old marshal voroshilov .	86.55654
molotov , in particular , is being charged with all kinds of sins -- especially with wanting to cut down free public services , to increase rents and fares	199.65155
in fact , with having been against all the more popular features of the khrushchev `` welfare state ' ' .	92.474525
the trouble with all these doctrinal quarrels is that we hear only one side of the story what , in the secret councils of the kremlin , molotov had really proposed , we just don ' t know , and he has had no chance to reply .	77.27682
but one cannot escape the suspicion that all this non-stop harping on the misdeeds of the long liquidated `` anti-party ' ' group would be totally unnecessary if there were not , inside the party , some secret but genuine opposition to khrushchev on vital doctrinal grounds , on the actual methods to be employed in the `` transition to communism ' ' and , last but not least , on foreign policy .	95.99012
the whole problem of `` peaceful coexistence and peaceful competition ' ' with the capitalist world is in the very center of this congress .	101.83078
`` molotov altogether rejects the line of peaceful coexistence , reducing this concept merely to the state of peace or rather , the absence of war at a given moment , and to a denial of the possibility of averting a world war .	65.592674
his views , in fact , coincide with those of foreign enemies of peaceful coexistence , who look upon it merely as a variant of the `` cold war ' ' or of an `` armed peace ' ' .	61.96163
one cannot help wondering whether molotov and the rest of the `` anti-party group ' ' are not being used as china ' s whipping-boys by khrushchev and his faithful followers .	74.808205
for something , clearly , has gone very , very seriously wrong in soviet-chinese relations , which were never easy , and have now deteriorated .	179.29758
the effect of chou en-lai ' s clash with khrushchev , together with the everlasting attacks on molotov & co . , has shifted the whole attention of the world , including that of the soviet people , from the `` epoch-making ' ' twenty-year program to the present soviet-chinese conflict .	101.03342
not only , as we know , did chou en-lai publicly treat khrushchev ' s attack on albania as `` something that we cannot consider as a serious marxist-leninist approach ' ' to the problem ( i . e . , as something thoroughly dictatorial and `` undemocratic ' ' ) , but the albanian leaders went out of their way to be openly abusive to khrushchev , calling him a liar , a bully , and so on .	101.41284
it is extremely doubtful that the handful of albanians who call themselves communists could have done this without the direct approval of their chinese friends .	236.9298
the big question is whether , in the name of a restored chinese-soviet solidarity , the chinese will choose to persuade the albanians to present their humble apologies to khrushchev -- or get rid of enver hoxa .	135.88824
these seem about the only two ways in which the `` unhappy incident ' ' can now be closed .	92.94374
but albania is merely a symptom of a real malaise between china and russia .	75.16971
khrushchev , for all his bombastic prophecies about the inevitable decay of capitalism , is genuinely favorable to `` peaceful coexistence ' ' and would like , above all , the berlin and german problems to be settled peacefully	89.99361
he knows that he was never more popular than at the time of the russo-american `` honeymoon ' ' of 1959 .	56.03055
but it seems that pressures against him are coming from somewhere -- in the first place from china , but perhaps also from that `` china lobby ' ' which , i was assured in moscow nearly two years ago , exists on the quiet inside the party .	128.57072
to these people , solidarity and unity with china should be the real basis of russia ' s future policy .	159.93213
and the chinese , as the albanian incident shows , have strong suspicions that khrushchev is anxious to secure a `` shameful ' ' peace with the west .	89.07898
the fact that china ( which is obsessed by formosa -- to khrushchev a very small matter ) should be supported by north korea and north vietnam is highly indicative .	148.68062
and one cannot but wonder whether marshal malinovsky , who was blowing hot and cold , exalting peace but also almost openly considering the possibility of preventive war against the west , wasn ' t trying to keep the chinese quiet .	125.77518
and this brings us inevitably to the 30- or 50-megaton bomb .	300.9966
was not this dropped primarily in order to `` appease ' ' the chinese -- especially after `` khrushchev ' s `` humiliating ' ' surrender to the west in canceling the german peace-treaty deadline of december 31 ? ?	84.68336
what does it all add up to ? ?	1.0407935
indications are that khrushchev ( and , with him , the bulk of the soviet people ) favor peaceful coexistence and ( with the exception of berlin ) the maintenance of the status quo in the world .	64.06568
the chinese , north vietnamese and north koreans , on the other hand , feel that , militarily , russia is strong enough to support them in the `` just wars of liberation ' ' they would like to embark on before long with china attacking formosa and the north koreans and north vietnamese liberating the southern half of their respective countries .	78.748146
perhaps khrushchev is in a more difficult position than any since 1957 , when the `` anti-party group ' ' nearly liquidated him .	70.31388
he seems strong enough inside the party to cope with any internal opposition	243.34534
but if he is up against china ' s crusading spirit in world affairs , he is going to be faced with the most agonizing choice in his life .	77.00062
he may support china ( but he won ' t )	24.866777
he may break with china ( which would be infernally difficult and perhaps disastrous ) , or he may succeed , by all kinds of dangerous concessions , in persuading china to be patient .	181.08482
the next days may show where things stand .	13.213143
on a misty sunday morning last month , a small band of militant anti-communists called the minutemen held maneuvers in a foggy field about fifteen miles east of here .	116.442505
eleven men , a woman and a teen-age boy tramped over cold , damp , fog-enshrouded ground during a two-hour field drill in the problems of guerrilla warfare .	111.771904
to the average american , this must sound like an incredible tale from a saturday night tv movie .	126.43989
but to the minutemen , this is a serious business .	162.63391
they feel that the united states is engaged in a life-and-death struggle with communism for survival and world supremacy .	116.78041
they feel that world war 3 , has already begun , and they are setting themselves up as a `` last line of defense ' ' against the communist advance .	140.65633
their national leader , robert bolivar depugh of norborne , mo . , says the minutemen believe that guerrilla tactics are best suited to defeat the red onslaught .	103.42516
in their maneuvers last month , they wore world war 2 , camouflage garb and helmets , and carried unloaded m-1 rifles .	52.891098
the maneuvers were held `` in secret ' ' after a regional seminar for the minutemen , held in nearby shiloh , ill . , had been broken up the previous day by deputy sheriffs , who had arrested regional leader richard lauchli of collinsville , ill . , and seized four operative weapons , including a browning machine gun , two browning automatic rifles and an m-4 rifle .	79.761215
undismayed by this contretemps , a small band of the faithful gathered at lauchli ' s home at 6 30 a . m . the next day , put on their uniforms , and headed for a farm several miles away .	66.86718
a 60 mm . mortar and a 57 mm . recoilless rifle owned by lauchli were brought along .	111.25447
the mortar was equipped with dummy shells and the recoilless rifle was deactivated .	53.064938
after a tortuous drive in an open truck and a world war 2 , army jeep down soggy trails , the band arrived at a small clearing squeezed between a long , low ridge and a creek-filled gully .	108.89721
here the two leaders , depugh and lauchli , hastened to put the group through its paces .	275.77704
the minutemen were instructed in the use of terrain for concealment .	123.52063
they were shown how to advance against an enemy outpost atop a cleared ridge .	19.178766
they practiced movement behind a smoke screen laid by smoke grenades	108.83647
and they attempted a skirmish line of advance against a camouflaged enemy encampment .	24.83251
eleven dummy rounds were fired by lauchli in a demonstration of rapid-fire mortar shooting .	165.73508
mrs . depugh , the mother of five children and an active member of her husband ' s organization , participated in all the exercises .	62.313778
there were no `` casualties ' ' , but the `` guerrillas ' ' admitted to being `` a little tired ' ' when the leaders called a halt at 9 a . m . to enable out-of-town members to catch a plane .	99.19588
i would like to add one more practical reform to those mentioned by russell kirk ( dec . 16 ) .	87.81264
it has to do with teachers ' salaries and tenure .	16.47015
next september , after receiving a degree from yale ' s master of arts in teaching program , i will be teaching somewhere -- that much is guaranteed by the present shortage of mathematics teachers .	99.48293
the amazing thing is that this too is caused by the dearth of teachers .	130.51189
as a result buyers , the public , must be satisfied with second-rate teachers .	62.12894
the rub arises from the fact that teachers are usually paid on the basis of time served rather than quality .	136.02129
hence all teachers , good and bad , who have been teaching for a given number of years are paid the same salary .	66.2647
i am firmly convinced that considering the average quality of teachers in this country , the profession is grossly overpaid .	41.39336
it follows that teachers as a group cannot expect any marked salary increases	831.2325
there is a limit to how much the public will pay for shoddy performance .	155.44897
the only hope which good teachers have for being paid their due is to stop dragging the dead weight of poor teachers up the economic ladder with them .	261.04144
the only hope which the public has for getting good teachers is to pay teachers on the basis of merit rather than tenure .	118.85367
here , as in all sectors of the economy , quality and justice are both dependent on the right of the individual to deal directly with his employer if he so chooses .	127.93014
on the eve of the `` great debate ' ' on the proposal to give the president broad powers to make across-the-board tariff concessions which could practically bring us into the atlantic community , we should face the alternatives on this proposition .	85.03876
what we will be sacrificing in any such arrangement will be our power to be selective which is contained in the reciprocal trade principle under which we now operate .	168.44043
without this power we lay open any american industry which the europeans may find it economically profitable to destroy to the will of others .	121.55112
it is this loss of initiative in how we conduct our economy which may lead to the loss of initiative in how we conduct our political affairs .	44.975567
i disagree with mr . burnham ' s position on the common market ( nov . 18 ) as a desirable organization for us to join .	58.818348
for him to ignore the political consequences involved in an atlantic union of this kind is difficult to understand .	72.96935
the pressure for our entry to the common market is mounting and we will proceed towards this amalgamated trade union by way of a purely `` economic thoroughfare ' ' , or garden path , with the political ramifications kept neatly in the background .	147.15285
the appeal is going to be to the pocketbook and may be very convincing to those who do not see its relation to political and legal , as well as economic , self-rule .	86.006424
in entering this union we will be surrendering most , if not all , of our economic autonomy to international bodies such as the atlantic institute ( recently set up ) or the o . e . c . d . , i . m . f . and others .	83.81007
to think that we can merely relinquish our economic autonomy without giving up our political or legal autonomy is wishful thinking .	105.84794
if it is not enough that all of our internationalist one worlders are advocating that we join this market , i refer you to an article in the new york times ' magazine section ( nov . 12 , 1961 ) , by mr . eric johnston , entitled `` we must join the common market ' ' .	121.779236
he says `` it has swept aside petty nationalisms , age-old rivalries , and worn-out customs ' ' .	85.567986
referring to britain , he says , `` we see a nation that traditionally values sovereignty above all else willing to give up its economy , placing this authority in continental hands ' ' .	351.72787
since the goal of our international planners is a world government , this atlantic community would mark a giant step in that direction for , once american economic autonomy is absorbed , a larger grouping is a question of time .	201.13245
frankly , it is being very cleverly done for , in a sense , they have us over a barrel .	126.06188
listen to what mr . johnston has to say `` consider the savage wounds that isolationism would inflict .	106.72141
we would lose our export markets and deny ourselves the imports we need .	103.15363
we would be crippled by reduced output , industrial decline , widespread unemployment ' ' .	66.87515
but the solution to this dilemma is not the incorporation of the united states into an atlantic community or `` economic empire ' ' , but merely what libertarians like henry hazlitt and ludwig von mises have been arguing for years an end to government regulations , an end to government competition in industry , and a realistic depreciation allowance for industry .	72.12429
create a free market here , give us a sound , debt-free money system , and we ' ll compete with anyone , europe and asia combined .	185.83694
in short , get this governmental monstrosity off our backs and we won ' t have to worry about european competition or communism either .	112.02482
if we want to preserve our sovereignty , this is the way to do it	26.221943
if we go into this common market , we might just as well stop talking about constitutional guarantees , connally amendments or , for that matter , conservatism in general .	152.37125
we welcome this able brief for the negative as part of a many-sided discussion of the atlantic common market which jnr will be continuing in our pages .	68.47025
the peiping chinese were the only major silver seller in the world markets who stopped selling the metal on monday morning , november 27 , anticipating by two days the announcement of the u . s . treasury that the pegged offering price will be removed .	83.66704
in 1954 i was drafted and after serving two years honorably on active duty i was not required to participate in any further army reserve activities .	136.33276
now , more than five years later , i cannot in any realistic sense be called a trained soldier .	316.1092
but , in spite of this , i , at present a man 31 years of age and a college professor , have been recalled `` by direction of the president ' ' to report on november 25th to fort devens , massachusetts , for another twelve months of active duty as an sp 4 ( the equivalent of a pfc ) .	104.95393
today , seven years after the date of my initial induction as a draftee , i am assistant professor of philosophy and science at st . michael ' s college .	85.635544
for , after leaving the army in 1956 , i spent five years in graduate school first at boston college and then at the university of toronto .	74.48391
this time , added to that which i had already spent in school prior to my induction in 1954 , makes a total of twenty-two ( 22 ) years of education .	160.07419
the possibility of recall into the army is part of the price that a modern american has to pay for the enviable heritage of liberty which he enjoys .	95.087555
however , it seems axiomatic that the government has an obligation `` to exercise its mandate reasonably , equitably and with full regard for the disruptions which it inevitably causes ' ' .	211.35878
in my own case , i submit that such reasonable and fair exercise is woefully lacking .	220.1634
taken back into the army now as an sp 4 , i am leaving 110 college students whose teacher i am .	238.59708
( a wry sidelight on this is that most of my students have deferments from the draft in order to attend my classes .	139.6114
) at this late date , it is impossible for st . michael ' s college to find a suitable replacement for me .	42.620213
even apart from the fact that now at the age of 31 my personal life is being totally disrupted for the second time for no very compelling reason -- i cannot help looking around at the black leather jacket brigades standing idly on the street corners and in the taverns of every american city and asking myself if our society has gone mad .	136.46336
in news broadcasts i consistently hear the foreign volunteers fighting in the katanga army referred to as mercenaries .	44.493435
if the hessian troops sent here willy-nilly by the hessian government to fight for england in the 1770 ' s were mercenaries , what shall we call the un troops sent to the congo willy-nilly by their governments to fight for the united nations ? ?	76.71468
if the un troops are not mercenaries then the hessians were not mercenaries either .	115.05342
and if the foreigners fighting in the katanga army are mercenaries then lafayette and von steuben were mercenaries too , as were also the members of the lafayette escadrille in the early part of world war 1 , and of chennault ' s flying tigers in the early days of world war 2 .	55.03314
it doesn ' t take a gore vidal to tell you what ' s wrong with cherokee textile ' s slogan ( pitney-bowes objects ' ' , july 1 ) .	103.33491
it ' s an eighteenth-century negative , man ! !	58.10776

the current stereotype of straight news reporting was probably invaluable in protecting the press and its readers from pollution by that combination of doctored fact , fancy , and personal opinion called yellow journalism which flourished in this country more than a generation ago .	160.40869
we don ' t need this type of protection any more .	1049.7356
the public is now armed with sophistication and numerous competing media .	277.16046
besides , there are no longer enough corruptible journalists about .	96.76622
the accepted method of writing news has two major liabilities .	107.75649
a reporter restricted to the competing propaganda statements of both sides in a major labor dispute , for instance , is unable to tell his readers half of what he knows about the causes of the dispute .	69.464584
second , it subjects the news to distortion by the unscrupulous .	54.83594
the charges by the late junior senator from wisconsin not only destroyed innocent people but misled the nation .	379.05045
yet the press was powerless to put these charges in perspective in its news columns .	161.12186
despite several years of front-page stories , the average citizen was unable to get a complete picture of mccarthy until he saw on the television screen what the reporters had been seeing all along but had no effective way of communicating .	101.50084
the senator had boxed them in with their own restrictions .	207.32274
it seems to me the time has come for the american press to start experimenting with ways of reporting the news that will do a better job of communicating and will be less subject to abuse by those who have learned how to manipulate the present stereotype to serve their own ends .	105.33201
the objective should be to provide a method of getting into print a higher percentage than is now possible of the relevant information in the possession of reporters and editors .	60.619267
i would like to see you devote some space in an early issue to the news blackout concerning president kennedy ' s activities , so far as southern california is concerned .	99.77424
you have on more than one occasion praised the idea of a televised press conference and the chance it gives the people to form intelligent opinions .	139.37766
to begin with , the all-powerful los angeles times does not publish a transcript of these press conferences .	71.67082
i am sure that they did when eisenhower was president .	40.414513
next , because of the time differential , the conferences come on the networks during the middle of the day .	49.392666

even then , a few of the `` less interesting ' ' questions are edited out and glibly summarized by a commentator .	115.65447
however , last night the tapes were not run at all during the evening hours and all we got on tv were a few snatches which douglas edwards and huntley and brinkley could squeeze into their programs .	164.74686
this is no criticism of them , as they obviously cannot get a half-hour program into a fifteen-minute news summary .	356.31458
the radio stations did run `` transcripts ' ' ( i thought ) during the evening hours .	61.11024
however , by comparing the tv snatches , two different radio station re-runs , and the censored los angeles times version , i found that the radio stations had edited out questions ( abc removed the one regarding laos ) or even a paragraph out of the middle of the president ' s answer .	129.20203
