can you bring the networks ' attention to this ? ?	105.03915
i was interested in james webb young ' s madison avenue column in which he raised the question `` do we need a college of propaganda ' ' ? ?	56.24542
and the sad part of it is that we had one , which was rounding into excellent shape , and we let it disintegrate and die .	120.53432
during the war , we set up schools for the teaching of psychological warfare , which included the teaching of propaganda , both black and white and the various shades of grey in between .	98.11887
we had a couple of schools in this country , the principal one being on the marshall field estate out in lloyd ' s neck .	60.82876
there were also a couple in canada , and several in england .	165.76639
the english schools preceded ours , and by the time we got into it they had learned a lot about the techniques of propaganda and its teaching .	107.84423
four of us here in the united states attended , first as students , then as instructors , almost every one of these schools , in england , canada , and the united states .	102.624954
we set up the lloyd ' s neck school , worked out its curriculum , and taught there .	270.89255
toward the end of the war , we really felt that we had learned something about propaganda and how to teach it .	133.55211
when the end did come , and the schools were disbanded and abandoned , we felt and hoped that the machinery of psychological warfare would not be allowed to rust .	117.07352
we hoped that its practitioners and teachers might be put on some sort of reserve list and called back for refresher courses each year or so .	276.5995
there apparently is no school of propaganda or psychological warfare .	36.841843
a study at the pentagon and at the service academies revealed that nothing was being done there .	181.23106
and not one of the four men who attended all the schools has ever been called on to apply any of his knowledge in any way .	77.99596

it is not news that nathan milstein is a wizard of the violin .	39.6675
certainly not in orchestra hall where he has played countless recitals , and where thursday night he celebrated his 20th season with the chicago symphony orchestra , playing the brahms concerto with his own slashing , demon-ridden cadenza melting into the high , pale , pure and lovely song with which a violinist unlocks the heart of the music , or forever finds it closed .	73.52764
there was about that song something incandescent , for this brahms was milstein at white heat .	356.99942
not the noblest performance we have heard him play , or the most spacious , or even the most eloquent .	131.82704
those would be reserved for the orchestra ' s great nights when the soloist can surpass himself .	96.712944

but he had in walter hendl a willing conductor able only up to a point .	157.47063
that is , when mr . milstein thrust straight to the core of the music , sparks flying , bow shredding , violin singing , glittering and sometimes spitting , mr . hendl could go along .	93.796875
but mr . hendl does not go straight to any point .	55.17747

h e . bates has scribbled a farce called `` hark , hark , the lark ' ' ! !	42.17579
it is one of the most entertaining and irresponsible novels of the season .	65.95241

perhaps the lesson we should take from these pages is that the welfare state in england still allows wild scope for all kinds of rugged eccentrics .	93.54857
anyway , a number of them meet here in devastating collisions .	409.02753
one is an imperial london stockbroker called jerebohm .	3.1383877
another is a wily countryman called larkin , whose blandly boisterous progress has been chronicled , i believe , in earlier volumes of mr . bates ' comedie humaine .	205.64902
well , jerebohm and his wife pinkie have reached the stage of affluence that stirs a longing for the more atrociously expensive rustic simplicities .	71.60988
they want to own a junior-grade castle , or a manor house , or some modest little place where shakespeare might once have staged a pageant for great elizabeth and all her bearded courtiers .	135.35622
they are willing to settle , however , in anything that offers pheasants to shoot at and peasants to work at .	127.51946
and of course larkin has just the thing they want .	47.39171
the name of it is gore court , and it is surrounded by a wasteland that would impress t . s . eliot .	143.08665

he conjures herds of deer , and wild birds crowding the air .	77.53681
he suggests that gore court embodies all the glories of tudor splendor .	31.769327
the stained-glass windows may have developed unpremeditated patinas , the paneling may be no more durable than the planks in a political platform .	68.100426
the vast , dungeon kitchens may seem hardly worth using except on occasions when one is faced with a thousand unexpected guests for lunch .	175.0816
the spaciousness of the tudor cooking areas , for example , will provide needed space for the extra television sets required by modern butlers , cooks and maids .	160.06601

he doesn ' t really need the immense sum of money ( probably converted from american gold on the london exchange ) he makes them pay .	237.29375
for larkin is already wonderfully contented with his lot .	281.24814

when he needs money to buy something like , say , the rolls-royce he keeps near his vegetable patch , he takes a flyer in the sale of surplus army supplies .	166.85466
one of those capital-gains ventures , in fact , has saddled him with gore court .	384.6295
he is willing to sell it just to get it off his hands .	30.863794
and the jerebohms are more than willing to buy it .	30.454689
they plan to become county people who know the proper way to terminate a fox ' s life on earth .	42.06768
if , in larkin ' s eyes , they are nothing but piccadilly farmers , he has as much to learn about them as they have to learn about the ways of truly rural living .	149.78508
mr . bates shows us how this mutual education spreads its inevitable havoc .	1011.2022
oneupmanship is practiced by both sides in a total war .	381.31177
first the larkins are ahead , then the jerebohms .	315.8865
after larkin has been persuaded to restock his tangled acres with pheasants , he poaches only what he needs for the nourishment of his family and local callers .	137.76811
one of the local callers , a retired brigadier apparently left over from kipling ' s tales of india , does not approve of the way larkin gets his birds .	233.95062
he doesn ' t think that potting them from a deck chair on the south side of the house with a quart glass of beer for sustenance is entirely sporting .	57.77528
but the brigadier dines on the birds with relish .	49.32774
it is truly odd and ironic that the most handsome and impressive film yet made from miguel de cervantes ' `` don quixote ' ' is the brilliant russian spectacle , done in wide screen and color , which opened yesterday at the fifty-fifth street and sixty-eighth street playhouses .	109.85198
more than a beautiful visualization of the illustrious adventures and escapades of the tragi-comic knight-errant and his squire , sancho panza , in seventeenth-century spain , this inevitably abbreviated rendering of the classic satire on chivalry is an affectingly warm and human exposition of character .	89.18838
nikolai cherkasov , the russian actor who has played such heroic roles as alexander nevsky and ivan the terrible , performs the lanky don quixote , and does so with a simple dignity that bridges the inner nobility and the surface absurdity of this poignant man .	112.97318
his addle-brained knight-errant , self-appointed to the ridiculous position in an age when armor had already been relegated to museums and the chivalrous code of knight-errantry had become a joke , is , as cervantes no doubt intended , a gaunt but gracious symbol of good , moving soberly and sincerely in a world of cynics , hypocrites and rogues .	203.45813
cherkasov does not caricature him , as some actors have been inclined to do .	57.218998
he treats this deep-eyed , bearded , bony crackpot with tangible affection and respect .	54.586914
directed by grigory kozintsev in a tempo that is studiously slow , he develops a sense of a high tradition shining brightly and passing gravely through an impious world .	141.79941
the complexities of communication have been considerably abetted in this case by appropriately stilted english language that has been excellently dubbed in place of the russian dialogue .	72.500336
the voices of all the characters , including that of cherkasov , have richness , roughness or color to conform with the personalities .	103.05796
and the subtleties of the dialogue are most helpfully conveyed .	203.03256
since russian was being spoken instead of spanish , there is no violation of artistry or logic here .	112.791565
splendid , too , is the performance of yuri tolubeyev , one of russia ' s leading comedians , as sancho panza , the fat , grotesque `` squire ' ' .	34.15935
though his character is broader and more comically rounded than the don , he gives it a firmness and toughness -- a sort of peasant dignity -- too .	102.1768
it is really as though the russians have seen in this character the oftentimes underlying vitality and courage of supposed buffoons .	151.82628
the episode in which sancho panza concludes the joke that is played on him when he is facetiously put in command of an `` island ' ' is one of the best in the film .	94.40167
true , the pattern and flow of the drama have strong literary qualities that are a bit wearisome in the first half , before don quixote goes to the duke ' s court .	88.17222
but strength and poignancy develop thenceforth , and the windmill and deathbed episodes gather the threads of realization of the wonderfulness of the old boy .	80.16761
there are other good representations of peasants and people of the court by actors who are finely costumed and magnificently photographed in this last of the russian films to reach this country in the program of joint cultural exchange .	59.510487
also on the bill at the fifty-fifth street is a nice ten-minute color film called `` sunday in greenwich village ' ' , a tour of the haunts and joints .	55.613445
television has yet to work out a living arrangement with jazz , which comes to the medium more as an uneasy guest than as a relaxed member of the family .	79.05079
there seems to be an unfortunate assumption that an hour of chicago-style jazz in prime evening time , for example , could not be justified without the trimmings of a portentous documentary .	141.65208
at least this seemed to be the working hypothesis for `` chicago and all that jazz ' ' , presented on nbc-tv nov . 26 .	72.98198
the program came out of the nbc special projects department , and was slotted in the du pont show of the week series .	115.73099
perhaps special projects necessarily thinks along documentary lines .	6.825643
if so , it might be worth while to assign a future jazz show to a different department -- one with enough confidence in the musical material to cut down on the number of performers and give them a little room to display their talents .	98.46514
as a matter of fact , this latter approach has already been tried , and with pleasing results .	50.904045
a few years ago a `` timex all-star jazz show ' ' offered a broad range of styles , ranging from lionel hampton ' s big band to the free-wheeling dukes of dixieland .	51.611618
an enthusiastic audience confirmed the `` live ' ' character of the hour , and provided the interaction between musician and hearer which almost always seems to improve the quality of performance .	122.04525
about that same time john crosby ' s tv series on the popular arts proved again that giving jazz ample breathing space is one of the most sensible things a producer can do .	187.03282
in an hour remembered for its almost rudderless movement , a score of jazz luminaries went before the cameras for lengthy periods .	43.46314
the program had been arranged to permit the establishment of a mood of intense concentration on the music .	63.753708
cameras stared at soloists ' faces in extreme closeups , then considerately pulled back for full views of ensemble work .	108.093
`` chicago and all that jazz ' ' could not be faulted on the choice of artists .	55.432407
some of the in-person performers were jack teagarden , gene krupa , bud freeman , pee wee russell , johnny st . cyr , joe sullivan , red allen , lil armstrong , blossom seeley .	63.8644
the jazz buff could hardly ask for more .	38.593937
furthermore , garry moore makes an ideal master of ceremonies .	250.41437
( he played host at the timex show already mentioned .	77.12967
one of the script ' s big problems was how to blend pictures and music of the past with live performances by musicians of today .	190.32524
nbc had gathered a lot of historical material which it was eager to share .	37.09319
for example , there was sheet music with the word `` jazz ' ' in the title , to illustrate how a word of uncertain origin took hold .	136.68425
samples zoomed into closeup range in regular succession , like telephone poles passing on the highway , while representative music reinforced the mood of the late teens and 1920 ' s .	150.5924
however well chosen and cleverly arranged , such memorabilia unfortunately amounted to more of an interruption than an auxiliary to the evening ' s main business , which ( considering the talent at hand ) should probably have been the gathering of fresh samples of the chicago style .	156.92747
another source of nbc pride was its rare film clip of bix beiderbecke , but this view of the great trumpeter flew by so fast that a prolonged wink would have blotted out the entire glimpse .	161.56561
similarly , in presenting still photographs of early jazz groups , the program allowed no time for a close perusal .	109.851715
`` chicago and all that jazz ' ' may have wound up satisfying neither the confirmed fan nor the inquisitive newcomer .	610.74384
by trying to be both a serious survey of a bygone era and a showcase for today ' s artists , the program turned out to be a not-quite-perfect example of either .	91.33512
still , the network ' s willingness to experiment in this musical field is to be commended , and future essays happily anticipated .	171.66634
even joan sutherland may not have anticipated the tremendous reception she received from the metropolitan opera audience attending her debut as lucia in donizetti ' s `` lucia di lammermoor ' ' sunday night .	67.77254
the crowd staged its own mad scene in salvos of cheers and applause and finally a standing ovation as miss sutherland took curtain call after curtain call following a fantastic `` mad scene ' ' created on her own and with the help of the composer and the other performers .	102.57407
her entrance in scene 2 , act 1 , brought some disconcerting applause even before she had sung a note .	107.85802
thereafter the audience waxed applause-happy , but discriminating operagoers reserved judgment as her singing showed signs of strain , her musicianship some questionable procedure and her acting uncomfortable stylization .	162.54297
as she gained composure during the second act , her technical resourcefulness emerged stronger , though she had already revealed a trill almost unprecedented in years of performances of `` lucia ' ' .	116.8091
each high note had the crowd in ecstasy so that it stopped the show midway in the `` mad scene ' ' , but the real reason was a realization of the extraordinary performance unfolding at the moment .	56.03934
miss sutherland appeared almost as another person in this scene a much more girlish lucia , a sensational coloratura who ran across stage while singing , and an actress immersed in her role .	156.1567
what followed the outburst brought almost breathless silence as miss sutherland revealed her mastery of a voice probably unique among sopranos today .	140.14572
this big , flexible voice with uncommon range has been superbly disciplined .	59.898434
nervousness at the start must have caused the blemishes of her first scene , or she may warm up slowly .	161.1761
in the fullness of her vocal splendor , however , she could sing the famous scene magnificently .	95.84755
technically it was fascinating , aurally spell-binding , and dramatically quite realistic .	77.76253
many years have passed since a metropolitan audience heard anything comparable .	695.92
her debut over , perhaps the earlier scenes will emerge equally fine .	257.1076
the performance also marked the debut of a most promising young conductor , silvio varviso .	49.73806
he injected more vitality into the score than it has revealed in many years .	86.905
he may respect too much the italian tradition of letting singers hold on to their notes , but to restrain them in a singers ' opera may be quite difficult .	154.5983
his bel canto style gave the performance a special distinction .	320.03555
the remainder of the cast fulfilled its assignments no more than satisfactorily just as the old production and limited stage direction proved only serviceable .	250.52843
miss sutherland first sang lucia at covent garden in 1959 .	105.57438
( the first metropolitan opera broadcast on dec . 9 will introduce her as lucia .	79.5123
) she has since turned to bellini , whose opera `` beatrice di tenda ' ' in a concert version with the american opera society introduced her to new york last season .	113.30982
she will sing `` la sonambula ' ' with it here next week .	172.12329
it ' s really quite fun -- as long as you like games .	322.7675
you will need a stereo music system , with speakers preferably placed at least seven or eight feet apart , and one or more of the new london `` phase 4 ' ' records .	145.29712
there are 12 of these to choose from , all of them of popular music except for the star release , pass in review ( sp-44001 ) .	134.47191
this features the marching songs of several nations , recorded as though the various national bands were marching by your reviewing stand .	168.31558
complete with crowd effects , interruptions by jet planes , and sundry other touches of realism , this disc displays london ' s new technique to the best effect .	200.71846
all of the jackets carry a fairly technical and detailed explanation of this new recording program .	138.1465
no reference is made to the possibility of recording other than popular music in this manner , and it would not seem to lend itself well to serious music .	162.00325
but when the sounds of the two speakers are allowed to mix , there is excellent depth and dimension to the music .	86.523895
you definitely hear some of the instruments close up and others farther back , with the difference in placement apparently more distinct than would result from the nearer instruments merely being louder than the ones farther back .	225.79955
this is a characteristic of good stereo recording and one of its tremendous advantages over monaural sound .	163.32603
london explains that the very distinct directional effect in the phase 4 series is due in large part to their novel methods of microphoning and recording the music on a number of separate tape channels .	198.6985
these are then mixed by their sound engineers with the active co-operation of the musical staff and combined into the final two channels which are impressed on the record .	101.01059
in some of the numbers the instrumental parts have even been recorded at different times and then later combined on the master tape to produce special effects .	163.3385
some clue to the character of london ' s approach in these discs may be gained immediately from the fact that ten of the 12 titles include the word `` percussion ' ' or `` percussive ' ' .	78.59075
drums , xylophones , castanets , and other percussive instruments are reproduced remarkably well .	29.95961
only too often , however , you have the feeling that you are sitting in a room with some of the instruments lined up on one wall to your left and others facing them on the wall to your right .	93.47049
they are definitely in the same room with you , but your head starts to swing as though you were sitting on the very edge of a tennis court watching a spirited volley .	116.21358
the percussive twenties ( sp-44006 ) stirs pleasant memories with well-known songs of that day , and johnny keating ' s kombo gives forth with tingling jazz in percussive moods ( sp-44005 ) .	133.61319
big band percussion ( sp-44002 ) seemed one of the least attractive discs -- the arrangements just didn ' t have so much character as the others .	162.4087
there is an extraordinary sense of presence in all of these recordings , apparently obtained at least in part by emphasizing the middle and high frequencies .	94.213295
the penalty for this is noticeable in the big , bold , brilliant , but brassy piano sounds in melody and percussion for two pianos ( sp-44007 ) .	85.8777
all of the releases , however , are recorded at a gratifyingly high level , with resultant masking of any surface noise .	139.33273
pass in review practically guarantees enjoyment , and is a dramatic demonstration of the potentialities of any stereo music system .	69.632256
many hollywood films manage somehow to be authentic , but not realistic .	34.78544
strange , but true -- authenticity and realism often aren ' t related at all .	82.34728
almost every film bearing the imprimatur of hollywood is physically authentic -- in fact , impeccably so .	78.33917
in any given period piece the costumes , bric-a-brac , vehicles , and decor , bear the stamp of unimpeachable authenticity .	74.70953
the major studios maintain a cadre of film librarians and research specialists who look to this matter .	81.088196
during the making recently of an important biblical film , some 40 volumes of research material and sketches not only of costumes and interiors , but of architectural developments , sports arenas , vehicles , and other paraphernalia were compiled , consulted , and complied with .	105.284904
but , alas , the authenticity seems to stop at the set ' s edge .	58.356693
the drama itself -- and this seems to be lavishly true of biblical drama -- often has hardly any relationship with authenticity at all .	172.00998
the storyline , in sort , is wildly unrealistic .	8.70928
thus , in `` the story of ruth ' ' we have ruth , naomi , and boaz and sets that are meticulously authentic .	80.51876
but except for a vague adherence to the basic storyline -- i . e . , that ruth remained with naomi and finally wound up with boaz -- the film version has little to do with the bible .	132.20863
and in the new `` king of kings ' ' the plot involves intrigues and twists and turns that cannot be traced to the gospels .	87.552574
earlier this month edward r . murrow , director of the united states information agency , came to hollywood and had dinner with more than 100 leaders of the motion picture industry .	113.63762
he intimated that they weren ' t doing the country much good in the cold war .	75.37973
and to an industry that prides itself on authenticity , he urged greater realism .	207.45088
`` in many corners of the globe ' ' , he said , `` the major source of impressions about this country are in the movies they meet .	57.019897
would we want a future-day gibbon or macaulay recounting the saga of america with movies as his prime source of knowledge ? ?	98.05718
yet for much of the globe , hollywood is just that -- prime , if not sole , source of knowledge .	172.79613
if a man totally ignorant of america were to judge our land and its civilization based on hollywood alone , what conclusions do you think he might come to ? ?	315.03574
francois d ' albert , hungarian-born violinist who made his new york debut three years ago , played a return engagement last night in judson hall .	84.93926
he is now president of the chicago conservatory college .	115.45308
his pianist was donald jenni , a faculty member at depaul university .	22.105846
the acoustics of the small hall had been misgauged by the artists , so that for the first half of the program , when the piano was partially open , mr . jenni ' s playing was too loud .	72.32204
in vying with him , mr . d ' albert also seemed to be overdriving his tone .	106.510124
this was not an overriding drawback to enjoyment of the performances , however , except in the case of the opening work , mozart ' s sonata in a ( k . 526 ) , which clattered along noisily in an unrelieved fashion .	72.73411
brahm ' s sonata in a , although also vigorous , stood up well under the two artists ' strong , large-scale treatment .	213.80066
mr . d ' albert has a firm , attractive tone , which eschews an overly sweet vibrato .	132.56416
he made the most of the long brahmsian phrases , and by the directness and drive of his playing gave the work a handsome performance .	182.80452
a sonata for violin and piano , called `` bella bella ' ' , by robert fleming , was given its first united states performance .	84.39404
the title refers to the nickname given his wife by the composer , who is also a member of the national film board of canada .	38.896717
the work ' s two movements , one melodically sentimental , the other brightly capricious , are clever enough in a ravel-like style , but they rehash a wornout idiom .	157.39067
they might well indicate conjugal felicity , but in musical terms that smack of hollywood .	695.7285
works by dohnanyi , hubay , mr . d ' albert himself and paganini , indicated that the violinist had some virtuoso fireworks up his sleeve as well as a reserved attitude toward a lyric phrase .	102.07833
standard items by sarasate and saint-saens completed the program .	375.20844
in recent years anna xydis has played with the new york philharmonic and at lewisohn stadium , but her program last night at town hall was the greek-born pianist ' s first new york recital since 1948 .	73.09472
miss xydis has a natural affinity for the keyboard , and in the twenty years since her debut here she has gained the authority and inner assurance that lead to audience control .	126.357124
and the tone she commands is always beautiful in sound .	95.48239
since she also has considerable technical virtuosity and a feeling for music in the romantic tradition , miss xydis gave her listeners a good deal of pleasure .	72.223885
she played with style and a touch of the grand manner , and every piece she performed was especially effective in its closing measures .	246.85297
the second half of her program was devoted to russian composers of this century .	84.19596
it was in them that miss xydis was at her best .	101.18008
the rachmaninoff prelude no . 12 , op . 32 , for instance , gave her an opportunity to exploit one of her special facilities -- the ability to produce fine deep-sounding bass tones while contrasting them simultaneously with fine silver filagree in the treble .	137.12634
the four kabalevsky preludes were also assured , rich in color and songful .	424.88168
and the prokofieff seventh sonata had the combination of romanticism and modern bravura that prokofieff needs .	330.46176
miss xydis ' earlier selections were mendelssohn ' s variations serieuses , in which each variation was nicely set off from the others	154.10062
haydn ' s sonata in e minor , which was unfailingly pleasant in sound , and chopin ' s sonata in b flat minor .	86.1316
a memory lapse in the last somewhat marred the pianist ' s performance .	39.331676
so , what was the deepest music on her program had the poorest showing .	291.21625
miss xydis was best when she did not need to be too probing .	19.54061
all the generals who held important commands in world war 2 , did not write books .	51.056156
and the best books by generals were not necessarily the first ones written .	138.53702
one of the very best is only now published in this country , five years after its first publication in england .	81.438446
it is `` defeat into victory ' ' , by field marshal viscount slim .	36.333252
a long book heavily weighted with military technicalities , in this edition it is neither so long nor so technical as it was originally .	225.6677
field marshal slim has abridged it for the benefit of `` those who , finding not so great an attraction in accounts of military moves and counter-moves , are more interested in men and their reactions to stress , hardship and danger ' ' .	138.62749
the man whose reactions and conclusions get the most space is , of course , the field marshal himself .	47.455956
william joseph slim , first viscount slim , former governor general of australia , was the principal british commander in the field during the burma war .	52.675323
he had been a corps commander during the disastrous defeat and retreat of 1942 when the ill-prepared , ill-equipped british forces `` were outmaneuvered , outfought and outgeneraled ' ' .	132.64632
he returned in command of an international army of gurkhas , indians , africans , chinese and british .	49.51765
and in a series of bitterly fought battles in the jungles and hills and along the great rivers of burma he waged one of the most brilliant campaigns of the war .	67.12038
`` the forgotten war ' ' his soldiers called the burma fighting because the war in africa and europe enjoyed priorities in equipment and in headlines .	158.72006
parts of `` defeat into victory ' ' are a tangle of burmese place names and military units , but a little application makes everything clear enough .	154.05418
on the whole this is an interesting and exceptionally well-written book .	118.57832
field marshal slim is striking in description , amusing in many anecdotes .	184.1091
he has a pleasant sense of humor and is modest enough to admit mistakes and even `` a cardinal error ' ' .	175.46655
he himself seems to be tough , tireless , able and intelligent , more intellectual and self-critical than most soldiers .	158.5674
`` defeat into victory ' ' is a dramatic and lively military narrative .	183.62198
but it is most interesting in its account of the unending problems of high command , of decisions and their reasons , of the myriad matters that demand attention in addition to battle action .	155.20412
before he could return to burma , field marshal slim had to rally the defeated remnants of a discouraged army and unite them with fresh recruits .	55.03702
his remarks about training , discipline , morale , leadership and command are enlightening .	92.18928
he believed in making inspiring speeches and he made a great many .	43.981827
he believed in being seen near the front lines and he was there .	140.12888
for general morale reasons and to encourage the efforts of his supply officers , when food was short for combat troops he cut the rations of his headquarters staff accordingly .	169.12782
other crucial matters required constant supervision labor and all noncombatant troops , whose morale was vital , too	120.8051
administrative organization and delicate diplomatic relations with top brass -- british , american and chinese	236.44788
health , hygiene , medical aid and preventive medicine	1.6691921
hospitals ( inadequate ) and nurses ( scanty )	14.408455
commenting on these and other matters , field marshal slim makes many frank and provocative remarks	223.7811
`` when in doubt as to two courses of action , a general should choose the bolder ' ' .	99.72996
`` the commander has failed in his duty if he has not won victory -- for that is his duty ' ' .	127.96162
`` it only does harm to talk to troops about new and desirable equipment which others may have but which you cannot give them .	351.15692
so i made no mention of air transport until we could get at least some of it ' ' .	29.005625
field marshal slim is more impressed by the courage of japanese soldiers than he is by the ability of their commanders .	159.19455
of the japanese private he says `` he fought and marched till he died .	87.7283
if 500 japanese were ordered to hold a position , we had to kill 495 before it was ours -- and then the last five killed themselves ' ' .	76.84652
brooding about future wars , the field marshal has this to say `` the asian fighting man is at least equally brave ( as the white ) , usually more careless of death , less encumbered by mental doubts , less troubled by humanitarian sentiment , and not so moved by slaughter and mutilation around him .	163.02266
he is , by background and living standards , better fitted to endure hardship uncomplainingly , to demand less in the way of subsistence or comfort , and to look after himself when thrown on his own resources ' ' .	92.76933
a bunch of young buckaroos from out west , who go by the name of texas boys choir , loped into town hall last night and succeeded in corralling the hearts of a sizable audience .	77.44086
actually , the program they sang was at least two-thirds serious and high-minded , and they sang it beautifully .	175.52623
under the capable direction of the choir ' s founder , geroge bragg , the twenty-six boys made some lovely sounds in an opening group of renaissance and baroque madrigals and motets , excerpts from pergolesi ' s `` stabat mater ' ' and all of the britten `` ceremonial of carols ' ' .	58.049744
their singing was well-balanced , clear and , within obvious limitations , extremely pleasing .	190.05174
the limitations are those one expects from untrained and unsettled voices -- an occasional shrillness of almost earsplitting intensity , an occasional waver and now and then a bleat .	58.952618
but mr . bragg is a remarkably gifted conductor , and the results he has produced with his boys are generally superior .	123.59716
most surprising of all , he has accomplished some prodigies in training for the production of words .	131.62729
the latin , for example , was not only clear	126.21297
furthermore , there were solid musical virtues in the interpretation of the music .	25.242685
lines came out neatly and in good balance .	5.9910393
the piano accompaniments by istvan szelenyi were stylish .	3.9521196
a boy soprano named dixon boyd sang a durante solo motet and a few other passages enchantingly .	71.405266
other capable soloists included david clifton , joseph schockler and pat thompson .	48.67928
the final group included folk songs from back home , stomped out , shouted and chanted with irresistible spirit and in cowboy costume .	124.66197
boys will be boys , and texans will be texans .	85.54216
the polish song and dance company called mazowsze , after the region of poland , where it has its headquarters , opened a three-week engagement at the city center last night .	112.585655
a thoroughly ingratiating company it is , and when the final curtain falls you may suddenly realize that you have been sitting with a broad grin on your face all evening .	111.99207
not that it is all funny , by any means , though some of it is definitely so , but simply that the dancers are young and handsome , high-spirited and communicative , and the program itself is as vivacious as it is varied .	69.6388
there is no use at all in trying to follow it dance by dance and title by title , for it has a kind of nonstop format , and moves along in an admirable continuity that demands no pauses for identification .	123.494774
the material is all basically of folk origin , gleaned from every section of poland .	81.08595
but under the direction of mira ziminska-sygietynska , who with her late husband founded the organization in 1948 , it has all been put into theatrical form , treated selectively , choreographed specifically for presentation to spectators , and performed altogether professionally .	233.11043
under the surface of the wide range of folk movements is apparent a sound technical ballet training , and an equally professional sense of performing .	172.47609
since the organization was created thirteen years ago , it is obvious that this is not the original company	43.207047
it is more likely the sons and daughters of that company .	305.0721
the girls are charming children and the men are wonderfully vital and engaging youngsters .	60.811184
indeed , there are never fewer than eight of them on stage , and that is only for the more intimate numbers .	52.068127
they can be exuberant or sentimental , flirtatious or funny , but the only thing they seem unable to be is dull .	70.10953
to pick out particular numbers is something of a problem , but one or two identifiable items are too conspicuously excellent to be missed .	147.12555
there is , for example , a stunning krakowiak that closes the first act	290.67032
the mazurka choreographed by witold zapala to music from moniuszko ' s opera , `` strasny dwor ' , may be the most beautiful mazurka you are likely ever to see	135.07825
and the dances and songs from the tatras contain a magnificent dance for the men .	149.4128
everywhere there are little touches of humor , and the leader of the on-stage band of musicians is an ebullient comedian who plays all sorts of odd instruments with winning warmth .	70.3597
the theatre-by-the-sea , matunuck , presents `` king of hearts ' ' by jean kerr and eleanor brooke .	65.11032
producer john holmes has chosen a delightful comedy for his season ' s opener at matunuck in jean kerr ' s `` king of hearts ' ' .	53.971607
the dialogue is sharp , witty and candid -- typical `` don ' t eat the daisies ' ' material -- which has stamped the author throughout her books and plays , and it was obvious that the theatre-by-the-sea audience liked it .	108.002525
the story is of a famous strip cartoonist , an arty individual , whose specialty is the american boy and who adopts a 10-year-old to provide him with fresh idea material .	138.59993
this is when his troubles begin , not to mention a fledgling artist who he hires , and who turns out to have ideas of his own , with particular respect to the hero ' s sweetheart-secretary .	85.35905
john heffernan , playing larry larkin , the cartoonist , carries the show in marvelous fashion .	113.29254
his portrayal of an edgy head-in-the-clouds artist is virtually flawless .	299.10355
this may be unfortunate , perhaps , from the standpoint of david hedison , providence ' s contribution to hollywood , who is appearing by special arrangement with 20th century-fox .	86.22801
not that mr . hedison does not make the most of his role .	73.02825
but the book is written around a somewhat dizzy cartoonist , and it has to be that way .	34.45856
a word should be said for gary morgan , a broadway youngster who , as the adopted son , makes life miserable for nearly everybody and larkin in particular .	211.79634
and for his playmate , francis coletta of west warwick , who has a bit part , billy .	125.248215
on the whole , audiences will like this performance .	90.259674
it is a tremendous book , lively , constantly moving , and the matunuck cast does well by it .	296.51483
the newport playhouse presents `` epitaph for george dillon ' ' by john osborne and anthony creighton , directed by wallace gray .	27.241714
the angriest young man in newport last night was at the playhouse , where `` epitaph for george dillon ' ' opened as the jazz festival closed .	75.509346
for the hero of this work by john osborne and anthony creighton is a chap embittered by more than the lack of beer during a jam session .	59.05196
he ' s mad at a world he did not make .	38.877213
furthermore , he ' s something of a scoundrel , an artist whose mind and feelings are all finger-tips .	111.48272
this is in contrast to the family with whom he boards .	351.72336
they not only think and feel cliches but live cliches as well .	180.04112
it is into this household , one eroded by irritations that have tortured the souls out of its people , that george dillon enters at the beginning of the play .	99.343094
an unsuccessful playwright and actor , he has faith only in himself and in a talent he is not sure exists .	277.58438
by the end of the third act , the artist is dead but the body lingers on , a shell among other shells .	130.25883
not altogether a successful play , `` epitaph for george dillon ' ' overcomes through sheer vitality and power what in a lesser work might be crippling .	133.20822
it is awfully talky , for instance , and not all of the talk is terribly impressive .	69.962685
but it strikes sparks on occasion and their light causes all else to be forgotten .	111.91591
there is a fine second act , as an example , one in which samuel groom , as dillon , has an opportunity to blaze away in one impassioned passage after another .	69.571625
this is an exciting young actor to watch .	18.355637
just as exciting but in a more technically proficient way is laura stuart , whose complete control of her every movement is lovely to watch .	271.99182
miss stuart is as intensely vibrant as one could wish , almost an icy shriek threatening to explode at any moment .	195.01817
also fine are sue lawless , as a mother more protective and belligerent than a female spider and just as destructive , harold cherry , as her scratchy spouse , and hildy weissman , as a vegetable in human form .	117.29647
wallace gray has directed a difficult play here , usually well , but with just a bit too much physical movement in the first act for my taste .	156.74388
still , his finale is put together with taste and a most sensitive projection of that pale sustenance , despair .	152.14177
the warwick musical theater presents `` where ' s charley ? ?	14.629673
' ' with music and lyrics by frank loesser , directed by christopher hewett , choreography by peter conlow , musical direction by samuel matlowsky .	44.496536
everybody fell in love with amy again last night at the warwick musical theater , and shelley berman was to blame .	41.89791
one of the finest soft shoe tunes ever invented , `` once in love with amy ' ' is also , of course , one of the most tantalizingly persistent of light love lyrics to come out of american musical comedy in our era .	74.27161
so the audience last night was all ears and eyes just after act 2 , got a rousing opening chorus , `` where ' s charley ? ?	119.721146
' ' , and berman sifted out all alone on the stage with the ambling chords and beat of the song just whispering into being .	228.18098
it is greatly to berman ' s credit that he made no attempt to outdo ray bolger .	45.457047
he dropped his earlier and delightful hamming , which is about the only way to handle the old war horse called `` charley ' s aunt ' ' , and let himself go with as appealing an `` amy ' ' as anybody could ask .	84.57778
in brief , berman played himself and not bolger .	503.73752
the big audience started applauding even before he had finished .	24.312468
the whole production this week is fresh and lively .	104.906845
the costumes are stunning evocations of the voluminous gowns and picture hats of the gibson girl days .	184.17749
the ballet work is on the nose , especially in the opening number by `` the new ashmolean marching society and students ' conservatory band ' ' , along with a fiery and sultry brazilian fantasia later .	106.799194
berman , whose fame has rested in recent years on his skills as a night club monologist , proved himself very much at home in musical comedy .	134.01537
sparrow-size virginia gibson , with sparkling blue eyes and a cheerful smile , made a suitably perky amy , while melisande congdon , as the real aunt , was positively monumental in the very best gibson girl manner .	219.49391
all told , `` where ' s charley ? ?	5.1160502
it has a fast pace , excellent music , expert direction , and not only a good comedian , but an appealing person in his own right , mr . berman .	72.239075
the broadway theater league of rhode island presents c . edwin knill ' s and martin tahse ' s production of `` fiorello ! !	43.220802
the book is by jerome weidman and george abbott , music by jerry bock , lyrics by sheldon harnick , choreography by peter gennaro , scenery , costumes and lighting by william and jean eckart , musical direction by jack elliott , and the production was directed by mr . abbott .	74.040955
this is one of the happier events of the season .	21.078691
the company which performed the pulitzer prize musical here last night and will repeat it twice today is full of bounce , the politicians are in fine voice , the chorines evoke happy memories , and the little flower rides to break a lance again .	162.54018
' ' performed in new york by the original cast and i think this company is every bit as good , and perhaps better .	257.11523
certainly in the matter of principals there is nothing lacking .	95.95337
bob carroll may not bear quite as close a physical resemblance to laguardia as tom bosley does , but i was amazed at the way he became more and more fiorello as the evening progressed , until one had to catch one ' s self up and remember that this wasn ' t really laguardia come back among us again .	103.26984
then rudy bond was simply grand as ben , the distraught republican party district chieftain .	76.85041
and paul lipson , as morris , the faithful one who never gets home to his shirley ' s dinner , was fine , too .	129.8179
as for the ladies , they were full of charm , and sincerity , and deep and abiding affection for this hurrying driving , honest , little man .	136.38622
charlotte fairchild was excellent as the loyal marie , who became the second mrs . laguardia , singing and acting with remarkable conviction .	219.10597
jen nelson , as thea , his first wife , managed to make that short role impressive .	189.39377
and little zeme north , a dora with real spirit and verve , was fascinating whether she was singing of her love for floyd , the cop who becomes sewer commissioner and then is promoted into garbage , or just dancing to display her exuberant feelings .	155.15883
such fascinating novelties in the score as the fugual treatment of `` on the side of the angels ' ' and `` politics and poker ' ' were handled splendidly , and i thought rudy bond and his band of tuneful ward-heelers made `` little tin box ' ' even better than it was done by the new york cast	67.416435
all the words of its clever lyrics came through with perfect clarity .	213.79108
the party at floyd ' s penthouse gave the `` chorines ' ' a chance for a nostalgic frolic through all those hackneyed routines which have become a classic choreographic statement of the era ' s nonsense .	72.32338
laguardia ' s multi-lingual rallies , when he is running for congress , are well staged , and wind up in a wild jewish folk-dance that is really great musical theater .	137.45067
martin tahse has established quite a reputation for himself as a successful stager of touring productions .	45.716812
not a corner has been visibly cut in this one .	137.94073
the sets are remarkably elaborate for a road-show that doesn ' t pause long in any one place , and they are devised so that they shift with a minimum of interruption or obtrusiveness .	69.88606
( several times recently i have wondered whether shows were being staged for the sake of the script or just to entertain the audience with the spectacle of scenery being shifted right in front of their eyes .	123.0454
i ' m glad to say there ' s none of that distraction in this `` fiorello ! !	61.336727
it has all been done in superb style , and the result is a show which deserves the support of every person hereabouts who enjoys good musical theater .	113.31204
loew ' s theater presents `` where the boys are ' ' , an mgm picture produced by joe pasternak and directed by henry levin from a screenplay by george wells .	121.902405
since the hero , a sterling and upright fellow , is a rich brown senior , while two yalies are cast as virtual rapists , i suppose i should disqualify myself from sitting in judgment on `` where the boys are ' ' , but i shall do nothing of the sort .	88.93642
instead -- and not just to prove my objectivity -- i hasten to report that it ' s a highly amusing film which probably does a fairly accurate job of reporting on the easter vacation shenanigans of collegians down in fort lauderdale , and that it seems to come to grips quite honestly with the moral problem that most commonly vexes youngsters in this age group -- that is to say , sex .	96.71609
the answers the girls give struck me as reasonably varied and healthily individual .	224.83176
if most of them weren ' t exactly specific -- well , that ' s the way it is in life , i guess .	113.62303
but at least it ' s reassuring to see some teenagers who don ' t profess to know all the answers and are thinking about their problems instead .	69.26953
`` where the boys are ' ' also has a juvenile bounce that makes for a refreshing venture in comedy .	53.245094
there are some sharp and whipping lines and some hilariously funny situations -- the best of the latter being a mass impromptu plunge into a nightclub tank where a `` mermaid ' ' is performing .	127.63608
most of the female faces are new , or at least not too familiar .	85.53715
dolores hart , is charming in a leading role , and quite believable .	107.35655
i was delighted with paula prentiss ' comedy performance , which was as fresh and unstilted as one ' s highest hopes might ask .	262.81033
a couple of the males made good comedy , too -- jim hutton and frank gorshin .	90.54021
the only performance which was too soft for me was that of yvette mimieux , but since someone had to become the victim of despoilers , just to emphasize that such things do happen at these fracases , i suppose this was the attitude the part called for .	176.79951
i must say , however , that i preferred the acting that had something of a biting edge to it .	142.24129
to anyone who remembers newport at its less than maximum violence , this view of what the boys and girls do in the springtime before they wing north for the jazz festival ought to prove entertaining .	132.22202
the second feature , `` the price of silence ' ' , is a british detective story that will talk your head off .	105.39124
the superb intellectual and spiritual vitality of william james was never more evident than in his letters .	45.983555
here was a man with an enormous gift for living as well as thinking .	158.95645
to both persons and ideas he brought the same delighted interest , the same open-minded relish for what was unique in each , the same discriminating sensibility and quicksilver intelligence , the same gallantry of judgment .	229.93266
for this latest addition to the great letters series , under the general editorship of louis kronenberger , miss hardwick has made a selection which admirably displays the variety of james ' s genius , not to mention the felicities of his style .	126.62391
his famous criticism of brother henry ' s `` third style ' ' is surely as subtly , even elegantly , worded an analysis of the latter ' s intricate air castles as henry himself could ever have produced .	156.4443
his letter to his daughter on the pains of growing up is surely as trenchant , forthright , and warmly understanding a piece of advice as ever a grown-up penned to a sensitive child , and with just the right tone of unpatronizing good humor .	315.70325
most of all , his letters to his philosophic colleagues show a magnanimity as well as an honesty which help to explain whitehead ' s reference to james as `` that adorable genius ' ' .	71.03154
miss hardwick speaks of his `` superb gift for intellectual friendship ' ' , and it is certainly a joy to see the intellectual life lived so free from either academic aridity or passionate dogmatism .	97.98426
this is a virtue of which we have great need in a society where there seems to be an increasing lack of communication -- or even desire for communication -- between differing schools of thought .	188.71703
it holds an equally valuable lesson for a society where the word `` intellectual ' ' has become a term of opprobrium to millions of well-meaning people who somehow imagine that it must be destructive of the simpler human virtues .	89.81814
to his harvard colleague , josiah royce , whose philosophic position differed radically from his own , james could write , `` different as our minds are , yours has nourished mine , as no other social influence ever has , and in converse with you i have always felt that my life was being lived importantly ' ' .	149.6142
of another colleague , george santayana , he could write `` the great event in my life recently has been the reading of santayana ' s book .	74.55213
although i absolutely reject the platonism of it , i have literally squealed with delight at the imperturbable perfection with which the position is laid down on page after page ' ' .	91.04983
writing to his colleague george herbert palmer -- `` glorious old palmer ' ' , as he addresses him -- james says that if only the students at harvard could really understand royce , santayana , palmer , and himself and see that their varying systems are `` so many religions , ways of fronting life , and worth fighting for ' ' , then harvard would have a genuine philosophic universe .	176.8098
`` the best condition of it would be an open conflict and rivalry of the diverse systems .	96.53114
the world might ring with the struggle , if we devoted ourselves exclusively to belaboring each other ' ' .	81.04486
the `` belaboring ' ' is of course jocular , yet james was not lacking in fundamental seriousness -- unless we measure him by that ultimate seriousness of the great religious leader or thinker who stakes all on his vision of god .	214.0272
to james this vision never quite came , despite his appreciation of it in others .	113.16436
but there is a dignity and even a hint of the inspired prophet in his words to one correspondent `` you ask what i am going to ' reply ' to bradley .	102.56395
but why need one reply to everything and everybody ? ?	34.710854
i think that readers generally hate minute polemics and recriminations .	88.031105
all polemic of ours should , i believe , be either very broad statements of contrast , or fine points treated singly , and as far as possible impersonally .	121.41029
as far as the rising generation goes , why not simply express ourselves positively , and trust that the truer view quietly will displace the other .	217.45395
here again ' god will know his own ' ' ' .	12.010745
the collected works of james thurber , now numbering 25 volumes ( including the present exhibit ) represent a high standard of literary excellence , as every schoolboy knows .	217.77843
the primitive-eclogue quality of his drawings , akin to that of graffiti scratched on a cave wall , is equally well known .	184.3339
about all that remains to be said is that the present selection , most of which appeared first in the new yorker , comprises ( as usual ) a slightly unstrung necklace , held together by little more than a slender thread cunningly inserted in the spine of the book .	93.9289
the one unifying note , if any , is sounded in the initial article entitled `` how to get through the day ' ' .	58.000877
it is repeated at intervals in some rather sadly desperate word-games for insomniacs , the hospitalized , and others forced to rely on inner resources , including ( in the p ' s alone ) `` palindromes ' ' , `` paraphrases ' ' , and `` parodies ' ' .	88.43589
`` the tyranny of trivia ' ' suggests arbitrary alphabetical associations to induce slumber .	112.38516
and new vistas of hairshirt asceticism are opened by scholarly monographs entitled `` friends , romans , countrymen , lend me your ear-muffs ' ' , `` such a phrase as drifts through dream ' ' , and `` the new vocabularianism ' ' .	67.05166
some of thurber ' s curative methods involve strong potions of mixed metaphor , malapropism , and gobbledygook and are recommended for use only in extreme cases .	96.619934
a burlesque paean entitled `` hark the herald tribune , times , and all the other angels sing ' ' brilliantly succeeds in exaggerating even motion-picture ballyhooey .	50.738457
`` how the kooks crumble ' ' features an amusingly accurate take-off on sneaky announcers who attempt to homogenize radio-tv commercials , and `` the watchers of the night ' ' is a veritable waking nightmare .	84.22872
a semi-serious literary document entitled `` the wings of henry james ' ' is noteworthy , if only for a keenly trenchant though little-known comment on the master ' s difficult later period by modest owen wister , author of `` the virginian ' ' .	90.48297
james , he remarks in a letter to a friend , `` is attempting the impossible namely , to produce upon the reader , as a painting produces upon the gazer , a number of superimposed , simultaneous impressions .	81.53583
he would like to put several sentences on top of each other so that you could read them all at once , and get all at once , the various shadings and complexities ' ' .	84.18316
equally penetrating in its fashion is the following remark by a lady in the course of a literary conversation `` so much has already been written about everything that you can ' t find out anything about it ' ' .	74.10336
or the mildly epigrammatic utterance ( also a quotation ) `` woman ' s place is in the wrong ' ' .	29.309746
who but thurber can be counted on to glean such nectareous essences ? ?	284.68204
a tribute to midsummer `` bang-sashes ' ' seems terribly funny , though it would be hard to explain why .	53.561546
`` one of them banged the sash of the window nearest my bed around midnight in july and i leaped out of sleep and out of bed .	205.43448
' it ' s just a bat ' , said my wife reassuringly , and i sighed with relief .	144.10255
' thank god for that ' , i said	142.00064
' i thought it was a human being ' ' ' .	31.211231
in a sense , perhaps , thurber is indebted artistically to the surrealist painter ( was it salvador dali ? ?	98.42637
) who first conceived the startling fancy of a picture window in the abdomen .	57.046604
that is , it is literally a picture window you don ' t see into the viscera	41.564472
you see a picture -- trees , or flowers .	163.52357
this is something like what thurber ' s best effects are like , if i am not mistaken .	202.45947
though no longer able to turn out his protoplasmic pen-and-ink sketches ( several old favorites are scattered through the present volume ) thurber has retained unimpaired his vision of humor as a thing of simple , unaffected humanness .	256.14105
in his concluding paragraph he writes `` the devoted writer of humor will continue to try to come as close to truth as he can ' ' .	121.4451
for many readers thurber comes closer than anyone else in sight .	30.188028
the master ' s hand has lost none of its craft .	153.28267
he is at his usual best in exposing the shams and self-deceptions of political and diplomatic life in the fifties .	65.785126
the reader meets a few old friends like blimp and the tuc horse , and becomes better acquainted with new members of the cast of characters like the bomb itself , and civilization in her classic robe watching the nuclear arms race , her hair standing straight out .	135.8799
but there is a difference between the present volume and the early low .	163.55814
there is fear in the fifties as his title suggests and as his competent drawings show .	199.55466
but there was terror in the thirties when the nazis were on the loose and in those days low struck like lightning .	240.47174
anyone can draw his own conclusions from this difference .	245.54143
it might be argued that the communists are less inhuman than the nazis and furnish the artist with drama in a lower key .	98.01814
but this argument cannot be pushed very far because the communist system makes up for any shortcomings of its leaders in respect to corrosion .	171.74632
the communists wield a power unknown to hitler .	23.942055
and the leading issue , that of piecemeal aggression , remains the same .	102.05838
do we ourselves offer mr . low less of a crusade ? ?	114.29604
in the thirties we would not face our enemy	55.45049
that was a nightmarish situation and low was in his element .	222.26271
we are stronger and more self-confident -- and low cannot so easily put us to rights .	206.2813
or does the reason for less jovian drawings lie elsewhere ? ?	41.62318
it might be that low has seen too many stupidities and that they do not outrage him now .	74.18281
he writes , `` confucius held that in times of stress one should take short views -- only up to lunchtime ' ' .	267.79617
whatever the cause , his mood in the fifties rarely rises above the level of the capably sardonic .	40.99605
he does not seem to have caught the subtleties of the man .	18.381063
the skies turn dark but the clouds do not loose their wrath .	92.65156
low seems to have supported eden at first and then relented because things worked out differently , so there is no fire in his eye .	201.35219
stalin ' s death , churchill ' s farewell to public life , hillary and tensing on everest , quemoy and matsu -- all subjects for a noble anger or an accolade .	226.18803
instead the cartoons seem to deal with foibles .	2.7609534
did low decide to let well enough alone when he made his selections ? ?	67.83361
he showed puny men attacked by splendidly tyrannical machines .	5.4666996
and khrushchev turned out to be prime copy for the most witty caricaturist of them all .	80.496185
look in this book for weak mortals and only on occasion for virtues and vices on the heroic scale .	114.36713
read the moderately brief text , not for captions , sometimes for tart epigrams , once in a while for an explosion in the middle of your fixed ideas .	124.50164
a gray fox with a patch on one eye -- confidence man , city slicker , lebensraum specialist -- tries to take over catfish bend in this third relaxed allegory from mr . burman ' s refreshing louisiana animal community .	154.7788
the fox is all ingratiating smiles when he arrives from new orleans , accompanied by one wharf rat .	63.44432
but like all despots , as he builds his following from among the gullible , he grows more threatening toward those who won ' t follow -- such solid citizens as doc raccoon	300.44968
and the eagle , who leads the bird community when he is not too busy in washington posing for fifty-cent pieces .	222.10327
as soon as the fox has taken hold on most of the populace he imports more wharf rats , who , of course , say they are the aggrieved victims of an extermination campaign in the city .	82.30591
( the followers of bullies invariably are aggrieved about the very things they plan to do to others .	118.93962
) they train the mink and other animals to fight .	58.154438
and pretty soon gray fox is announcing that he won ' t have anyone around that ' s against him , and setting out to break his second territorial treaty with the birds .	106.463974
robert hillyer , the poet , writes in his introduction to this brief animal fable that mr . burman ought to win a nobel prize for the catfish bend series .	82.23553
he may have a point in urging that decadent themes be given fewer prizes .	279.31454
but it ' s hard to imagine mr . burman as a nobel laureate on the basis of these charming but not really momentous fables .	60.089905
in substance they lie somewhere between the southern dialect animal stories of joel chandler harris ( uncle remus ) and the polished , witty fables of james thurber .	80.32361
george kennan ' s account of relations between russia and the west from the fall of tsarism to the end of world war 2 , is the finest piece of diplomatic history that has appeared in many years .	59.068436
it combines qualities that are seldom found in one work scrupulous scholarship , a fund of personal experience , a sense of drama and characterization and a broad grasp of the era ' s great historical issues .	95.489624
in short , the book , based largely on lectures delivered at harvard university , is both reliable and readable	77.95443
the author possesses an uncommonly fine english style , and he is dealing with subjects of vast importance that are highly topical for our time .	69.62326
if mr . kennan is sometimes a little somber in his appraisals , if his analysis of how western diplomacy met the challenge of an era of great wars and social revolutions is often critical and pessimistic -- well , the record itself is not too encouraging .	113.55263
mr . kennan takes careful account of every mitigating circumstance in recalling the historical atmosphere in which mistaken decisions were taken .	80.14758
but he rejects , perhaps a little too sweepingly , the theory that disloyal and pro-communist influences may have contributed to the policy of appeasing stalin which persisted until after the end of the war and reached its high point at the yalta conference in february , 1945 .	67.418625
after all , alger hiss , subsequently convicted of perjury in denying that he gave secret state department documents to soviet agents , was at yalta .	137.3998
and harry dexter white , implicated in f . b . i . reports in communist associations , was one of the architects of the morgenthau plan , which had it ever been put into full operation , would have simply handed germany to stalin .	98.103065
one item in this unhappy scheme was to have germany policed exclusively by its continental neighbors , among whom only the soviet union possessed real military strength .	136.15222
it is quite probable , however , that stupidity , inexperience and childish adherence to slogans like `` unconditional surrender ' ' had more to do with the unsatisfactory settlements at the end of the war than treason or sympathy with communism .	85.09591
mr . kennan sums up his judgment of what went wrong this way	348.90503
`` you see , first of all and in a sense as the source of all other ills , the unshakeable american commitment to the principle of unconditional surrender the tendency to view any war in which we might be involved not as a means of achieving limited objectives in the way of changes in a given status quo , but as a struggle to the death between total virtue and total evil , with the result that the war had absolutely to be fought to the complete destruction of the enemy ' s power , no matter what disadvantages or complications this might involve for the more distant future ' ' .	92.6304
recognizing that there could have been no effective negotiated peace with hitler , he points out the shocking failure to give support to the anti-nazi underground , which very nearly eliminated hitler in 1944 .	197.33797
a veteran diplomat with an extraordinary knowledge of russian language , history and literature , kennan recalls how , at the time of hitler ' s attack on the soviet union in 1941 , he penned a private note to a state department official , expressing the hope that `` never would we associate ourselves with russian purposes in the areas of eastern europe beyond her own boundaries ' ' .	60.511257
with justified bitterness the author speaks of `` what seems to me to have been an inexcusable body of ignorance about the nature of the russian communist movement , about the history of its diplomacy , about what had happened in the purges , and about what had been going on in poland and the baltic states ' ' .	63.095654
he also speaks of franklin d . roosevelt ' s `` puerile ' ' assumption that `` if only he ( stalin ) could be exposed to the persuasive charm of someone like f . d . r . himself , ideological preconceptions would melt and russia ' s co-operation with the west could be easily arranged ' ' .	106.19272
no wonder khrushchev ' s first message to president kennedy was a wistful desire for the return of the `` good old days ' ' of roosevelt .	70.754105
this fascinating story begins with a sketch , rich in personal detail , of the glancing mutual impact of world war 1 , and the two instalments of the russian revolution .	79.35538
the first of these involved the replacement of the tsar by a liberal provisional government in march , 1917	99.91316
the second , the seizure of power by the bolsheviks ( who later called themselves communists ) in november of the same year .	133.47462
as kennan shows , the judgment of the allied governments about what was happening in russia was warped by the obsession of defeating germany .	70.28378
they were blind to the evidence that nothing could keep the russian people fighting .	141.59886
they attributed everything that went wrong in russia to german influence and intrigue .	52.11089
this , more than any other factor , led to the fiasco of allied intervention .	38.05828
`` had a world war not been in progress , there would never , under any conceivable stretch of the imagination , have been an allied intervention in north russia ' ' .	45.24166
the scope and significance of this intervention have been grossly exaggerated by communist propaganda	64.79898
here kennan , operating with precise facts and figures , performs an excellent job of debunking .	46.108803
of many passages in the book that exemplify the author ' s vivid style , the characterizations of the two plebeian dictators whose crimes make those of crowned autocrats pale by comparison may be selected .	97.35173
`` this was a man of incredible criminality , of a criminality effectively without limits	421.61624
a man apparently foreign to the very experience of love , without mercy or pity	90.85362
a man in whose entourage none was ever safe	22327.207
a man whose hand was set against all that could not be useful to him at the moment	41.450195
a man who was most dangerous of all to those who were his closest collaborators in crime .	110.91965
and here is kennan ' s image of hitler , stalin ' s temporary collaborator in the subjugation and oppression of weaker peoples , and his later enemy	88.467735
`` behind that charlie chaplin moustache and that truant lock of hair that always covered his forehead , behind the tirades and the sulky silences , the passionate orations and the occasional dull evasive stare , behind the prejudices , the cynicism , the total amorality of behavior , behind even the tendency to great strategic mistakes , there lay a statesman of no mean qualities shrewd , calculating , in many ways realistic , endowed -- like stalin -- with considerable powers of dissimulation , capable of playing his cards very close to his chest when he so desired , yet bold and resolute in his decisions , and possessing one gift stalin did not possess the ability to rouse men to fever pitch of personal devotion and enthusiasm by the power of the spoken word ' ' .	148.05458
two criticisms of this generally admirable and fascinating book involve the treatment of wartime diplomacy which is jagged at the edges -- there is no mention of the potsdam conference or the morgenthau plan .	97.76692
and in a concluding chapter about america ' s stance in the contemporary world , one senses certain misplacements of emphasis and a failure to come to grips with the baffling riddle of our time how to deal with a wily and aggressive enemy without appeasement and without war .	135.79303
mr . kennan , who has recently abandoned authorship for a new round of diplomacy as the recently appointed american ambassador to yugoslavia , is not the only man who finds it easier to portray the past than to prescribe for the future .	91.45815
the story of a quarter of a century of soviet-western relations is vitally important , and it is told with the fire of a first-rate historical narrator .	88.4065
the ireland we usually hear about in the theater is a place of bitter political or domestic unrest , lightened occasionally with flashes of native wit and charm .	242.12294
in `` donnybrook ' ' , there is quite a different eire , a rural land where singing , dancing , fist-fighting and romancing are the thing .	341.06717
there is plenty of violence , to be sure , but it is a nice violence and no one gets killed .	73.493706
by and large , robert mcenroe ' s adaptation of maurice walsh ' s film , `` the quiet man ' ' , provides the entertainment it set out to , and we have a lively musical show if not a superlative one .	135.90277
this is the tale of one john enright , an american who has accidentally killed a man in the prize ring and is now trying to forget about it in a quiet place where he may become a quiet man .	118.8246
but innesfree , where ellen roe danaher and her bullying brother , will , live , is no place for a man who will not use his fists .	86.653
so enright ' s courting of the mettlesome ellen is impeded considerably , thereby providing the tale which is told .	323.15094
you may be sure he marries her in the end and has a fine old knockdown fight with the brother , and that there are plenty of minor scraps along the way to ensure that you understand what the word donnybrook means .	127.70268
then there is a matchmaker , one mikeen flynn , a role for which eddie foy was happily selected .	109.793236
now there is no reason in the world why a matchmaker in ireland should happen also to be a talented soft-shoe dancer and gifted improviser of movements of the limbs , torso and neck , except that these talents add immensely to the enjoyment of the play .	112.7472
mr . foy is a joy , having learned his dancing by practicing it until he is practically perfect .	222.67845
his matchmaking is , naturally , incidental , and it only serves flynn right when a determined widow takes him by the ear and leads him off to matrimony .	115.58958
art lund , a fine big actor with a great head of blond hair and a good voice , impersonates enright .	50.234592
although he is not graced with the subtleties of romantic technique , that ' s not what an ex-prize fighter is supposed to have , anyway .	74.62775
joan fagan , a fiery redhead who can impress you that she has a temper whether she really has one or not , plays ellen , and sings the role very well , too .	137.71576
if the mettle which ellen exhibits has a bit of theatrical dross in it , never mind	204.68245
she fits into the general scheme well enough .	34.367924
susan johnson , as the widow , spends the first half of the play running a bar and singing about the unlamented death of her late husband and the second half trying to acquire a new one .	97.65505
she has a good , firm delivery of songs and adds to the solid virtues of the evening .	59.583973
then there are a pair of old biddies played by grace carney and sibly bowan who may be right off the shelf of stock irish characters , but they put such a combination of good will and malevolence into their parts that they ' re quite entertaining .	196.37619
and in the role of will danaher , philip bosco roars and sneers sufficiently to intimidate not only one american but the whole british army , if he chose .	261.60278
`` donnybrook ' ' is no `` brigadoon ' ' , but it does have some very nice romantic background touches and some excellent dancing .	69.31434
the ballads are sweet and sad , and the music generally competent .	205.20432
it sometimes threatens to linger in the memory after the final curtain , and some of it , such as the catchy `` sez i ' ' , does .	67.56663
`` a toast to the bride ' ' , sung by clarence nordstrom , playing a character called old man toomey , is quite simple , direct and touching .	80.0666
the men of innesfree are got up authentically in cloth caps and sweaters , and their dancing and singing is fine .	57.46374
so is that of the limber company of lasses who whirl and glide and quickstep under jack cole ' s expert choreographic direction .	149.98999
the male dancers sometimes wear kilts and their performance in them is spirited and stimulating .	267.5506
rouben ter-arutunian , in his stage settings , often uses the scrim curtain behind which mr . cole has placed couples or groups who sing and set the mood for the scenes which are to follow .	194.25285
there is no reason why most theatergoers should not have a pretty good time at `` donnybrook ' ' , unless they are permanently in the mood of enright when he sings about how easily he could hate the lovable irish .	92.324814
we can all breathe more easily this morning -- more easily and joyously , too -- because joshua logan has turned the stage show , `` fanny ' ' , into a delightful and heart-warming film .	92.45587
the task of taking the raw material of marcel pagnol ' s original trio of french films about people of the waterfront in marseilles and putting them again on the screen , after their passage through the broadway musical idiom , was a delicate and perilous one , indeed .	100.91671
more than the fans of pagnol ' s old films and of their heroic star , the great raimu , were looking askance at the project .	211.02837
the fans of the musical were , too .	13.952741
but now the task is completed and the uncertainty resolved with the opening of the english-dialogue picture at the music hall yesterday .	149.2128
whether fan of the pagnol films or stage show , whether partial to music or not , you can ' t help but derive joy from this picture if you have a sense of humor and a heart .	110.15607
some of the new york philharmonic musicians who live in the suburbs spent yesterday morning digging themselves free from snow .	168.34865
a tiny handful never did make the concert .	10.405711
but , after a fifteen-minute delay , the substantially complete philharmonic assembled on stage for the afternoon ' s proceedings .	80.05755
they faced a rather small audience , as quite a few subscribers apparently had decided to forego the pleasures of the afternoon .	92.98643
paul paray , rounding out his current stint with the orchestra , is a solid musician , and the philharmonic plays for him .	60.15688
their collaboration in the beethoven second symphony was lucid , intelligent and natural sounding .	180.00044
it was not a heavy , ponderous beethoven .	29.094425
the music sang nicely , sprinted evenly when necessary , was properly accented and balanced .	316.56522
the franck symphonic poem , `` psyche ' ' , is a lush , sweet-sounding affair that was pleasant to encounter once again .	68.42335
fortunate for the music itself , it is not too frequent a visitor	209.37984
if it were , its heavily chromatic harmonies would soon become cloying .	531.7797
mr . paray resisted the temptation to over-emphasize the melodic elements of the score .	94.892334
he did not let the strings , for instance , weep , whine or get hysterical .	112.51943
his interpretation was a model of refinement and accuracy .	154.8882
and in the prokofieff c major piano concerto , with zadel skolovsky as soloist , he was an admirable partner .	70.15484
mr . skolovsky ' s approach to the concerto was bold , sweeping and tonally percussive .	109.78113
he swept through the music with ease , in a non-sentimental and ultra-efficient manner .	261.92395
an impressive technician , mr . skolovsky has fine rhythm , to boot .	81.03443
his tone is the weakest part of his equipment	4251.4717
a school of thought has it that those attributes are exactly what this concerto needs .	254.58266
it is , after all , a non-romantic work ( even with the big , juicy melody of the second movement )	136.93294
and the composer himself was called the `` age of steel pianist ' ' .	103.55248
but granted all this , one still would have liked to have heard a little more tonal nuance than mr . skolovsky supplied .	137.31956
taken as a whole , though , it was a strong performance from both pianist and orchestra .	102.04121
mr . skolovsky fully deserved the warm reception he received .	217.3675
a new work on the program was nikolai lopatnikoff ' s `` festival overture ' ' , receiving its first new york hearing .	32.90544
this was composed last year as a salute to the automobile industry .	54.145126
it runs a little more than ten minutes , is workmanlike , busy , methodical and featureless .	94.887314
`` la gioconda ' ' , like it or not , is a singer ' s opera .	62.759224
and so , of course , it is a fan ' s opera as well .	52.132534
snow or no , the fans were present in force at the metropolitan opera last night for a performance of the ponchielli work .	53.409683
