so the plot creaks , the sets are decaying , the costumes are pre-historic , the orchestra was sloppy and not very well connected with what the singers were doing .	76.32329
after all , the opera has juicy music to sing and the goodies are well distributed , with no less than six leading parts .	131.60287
one of those parts is that of evil , evil barnaba , the spy .	54.894627
his wicked deeds were carried on by anselmo colzani , who was taking the part for the first time with the company .	35.31423
he has the temperament and the stage presence for a rousing villain and he sang with character and strong tone .	187.4522
what was lacking was a real sense of phrase , the kind of legato singing that would have added a dimension of smoothness to what is , after all , a very oily character .	132.16458
regina resnik as laura and cesare siepi as alvise also were new to the cast , but only with respect to this season	161.19516
they have both sung these parts here before .	250.96269
laura is a good role for miss resnik , and she gave it force , dramatic color and passion .	227.68623
mr . siepi was , as always , a consummate actor	86.930534
with a few telling strokes he characterized alvise magnificently .	43.48176
part of this characterization was , of course , accomplished with the vocal chords .	151.12573
unfortunately his voice was out of focus and often spread in quality .	199.5245
eileen farrell in the title role , mignon dunn as la cieca and richard tucker as enzo were holdovers from earlier performances this season , and all contributed to a vigorous performance .	154.25905
if only they and fausto cleva in the pit had got together a bit more .	302.4979
`` melodious birds sing madrigals ' ' saith the poet and no better description of the madrigaling of the deller consort could be imagined .	145.02972
stereo bgs 5031 ) is a good sample of the special , elegant art of english madrigal singing .	77.99834
it also makes a fine introduction to the international art form with good examples of italian and english madrigals plus several french `` chansons ' ' .	225.41968
the english have managed to hold onto their madrigal tradition better than anyone else .	54.472324
the original impulses came to england late ( in the sixteenth century ) and continue strong long after everyone else had gone on to the baroque basso continuo , sonatas , operas and the like .	160.70752
even after elizabethan traditions were weakened by the cromwellian interregnum , the practice of singing together -- choruses , catches and glees -- always flourished .	137.16943
the english never again developed a strong native music that could obliterate the traces of an earlier great age the way , say , the opera in italy blotted out the italian madrigal .	125.96106
latter-day interest in elizabethan singing dates well back into the nineteenth century in england , much ahead of similar revivals in other countries .	72.99974
as a result no comparable literature of the period is better known and better studied nor more often performed than the english madrigal .	304.9575
naturally , mr . deller and the other singers in his troupe are most charming and elegant when they are squarely in their tradition and singing music by their countrymen william byrd , thomas morley and thomas tomkins .	157.99396
there is an almost instrumental quality to their singing , with a tendency to lift out important lines and make them lead the musical texture .	134.19691
both techniques give the music purity and clarity .	5.705012
claude jannequin ' s vocal description of a battle ( the french equivalents of tarantara , rum-tum-tum , and boom-boom-boom are very picturesque ) is lots of fun , and the singers get a sense of grace and shape into other chansons by jannequin and lassus .	156.19615
only with the more sensual , intense and baroque expressions of marenzio , monteverdi and gesualdo does the singing seem a little superficial .	122.1998
nevertheless , the musicality , accuracy and infectious charm of these performances , excellently reproduced , make it an attractive look-see at the period .	132.00298
the elements of elegance and color in jannequin are strong french characteristics .	424.14688
baroque instrumental music in italy and germany tends to be strong , lively , intense , controlled and quite abstract .	43.53875
in france , it remained always more picturesque , more dancelike , more full of flavor .	74.66758
couperin and rameau gave titles to nearly everything they wrote , not in the later sense of `` program music ' ' but as a kind of nonmusical reference for the close , clear musical forms filled with keen wit and precise utterance .	153.2886
both composers turn up on new imports from france .	40.35294
bam is the unlikely name of a french recording company whose full label is editions de la boite a musique .	294.84143
they specialize in out-of-the-way items and old french music naturally occupies a good deal of their attention .	76.16398
sonates et concerts royaux of couperin le grand occupy two disks ( ld056 and ld060 ) and reveal the impeccable taste and workmanship of this master -- delicate , flexible and gemlike .	86.82796
the concerts -- nos . 2 , 6 , 9 , 10 and 14 are represented -- are really closer to chamber suites than to concertos in the italian sense .	104.72902
the sonatas , `` la francaise ' ' , `` la sultane ' ' , `` l ' astree ' ' and `` l ' imperiale ' ' , are often more elaborately worked out and , in fact , show a strong italian influence .	68.58204
couperin also turns up along with some lesser-known contemporaries on a disk called musique francaise du 18e siecle ( bam ld 060 ) .	22.427387
jean-marie leclair still is remembered a bit , but bodin de beismortier , corrette and mondonville are hardly household words .	224.7207
what is interesting about these chamber works here is how they all reveal the aspect of french music that was moving toward the rococo .	149.3885
the couperin `` la steinkerque ' ' , with its battle music , brevity , wit and refined simplicity , already shakes off corelli and points towards the mid-century elegances that ended the baroque era .	165.19904
if couperin shows the fashionable trend , the others do so all the more .	241.85353
all these records have close , attractive sound and the performances by a variety of instrumentalists is characteristic .	60.6402
rameau ' s six concerts en sextuor , recorded by l ' orchestre de chambre pierre menet ( bam ld 046 ) , turn out to be harpsichord pieces arranged for strings apparently by the composer himself .	121.359825
the strange , delightful little character pieces with their odd and sometimes inexplicable titles are still evocative and gracious .	159.98064
maitres allemands des 17e et 18e siecles contains music by pachelbel , buxtehude , rosenmueller and telemann , well performed by the ensemble instrumental sylvie spycket ( bam ld 035 ) .	92.818756
rococo music -- a lot of it -- was played in carnegie recital hall on saturday night in the first of four concerts being sponsored this season by a new organization known as globe concert arts .	116.16815
works by j . c . bach , anton craft , joseph haydn , giuseppe sammartini , comenico dragonetti and j . g . janitsch were performed by seven instrumentalists including anabel brieff , flutist , josef marx , oboist , and robert conant , pianist and harpsichordist .	58.608566
since rococo music tends to be pretty and elegant above all , it can seem rather vacuous to twentieth-century ears that have grown accustomed to the stress and dissonances of composers from beethoven to boulez .	245.13396
thus there was really an excess of eighteenth-century charm as one of these light-weight pieces followed another on saturday night .	81.4103
each might find a useful place in a varied musical program , but taken together they grew quite tiresome .	460.6548
the performances were variable , those of the full ensemble being generally satisfying , some by soloists proving rather trying .	708.2091
ellie mao , soprano , and frederick fuller , baritone , presented a program of folksongs entitled `` east meets west ' ' in carnegie recital hall last night .	57.611866
they were accompanied by anna mi lee , pianist .	84.81154
selections from fifteen countries were sung as solos and duets in a broad range of languages .	36.618603
songs from china and japan were reserved exclusively for miss mao , who is a native of china , and those of the british isles were sung by mr . fuller , who is english by birth .	45.399548
this was not a program intended to illustrate authentic folk styles .	144.38422
on the contrary , miss mao and mr . fuller chose many of their arrangements from the works of composers such as mendelssohn , dvorak , canteloube , copland and britten .	168.84692
there was , therefore , more musical substance in the concert than might have been the case otherwise .	167.02971
the performances were assured , communicative and pleasingly informal .	82.96374
what was omitted from `` a neglected education ' ' were those essentials known as `` the facts of life ' ' .	44.06674
chabrier ' s little one-act operetta , presented yesterday afternoon at town hall , is a fragile , precious little piece , very french , not without wit and charm .	106.48001
the poor uneducated newlywed , a certain gontran de boismassif , has his problems in getting the necessary information .	240.12318
the humor of the situation can be imagined .	9.153937
it all takes place in the eighteenth century .	14.585237
what a silly , artificial way of life , chabrier and his librettists chuckle .	136.44275
but they wish they could bring it back .	5.9110203
chabrier ' s delightful music stands just at the point where the classical , rationalist tradition , ( handed down to chabrier largely in the form of operetta and salon music ) becomes virtually neo-classicism .	167.75189
the musical cleverness and spirit plus a strong sense of taste and measure save a wry little joke from becoming either bawdy or mawkish .	107.40443
the simple , clever production was also able to tread the thin line between those extremes .	33.358307
the work uses the old eighteenth-century tradition of giving the part of a young inexperienced youth to a soprano .	145.9696
benita valente was delightful as the young wife and john parella was amusing as the tutor who failed to do all his tutoring .	83.27463
the work was presented as the final event in the town hall festival of music .	44.05965
it was paired with a darius milhaud opera , `` the poor sailor ' ' , set to a libretto by jean cocteau , a kind of grand guignol by the sea , a sailor returns , unrecognized , and gets done in by his wife .	84.075165
with the exception of a few spots , milhaud ' s music mostly churns away with his usual collection of ditties , odd harmonies , and lumbering , satiric orchestration .	63.575447
had a funny experience at newport yesterday afternoon .	6.6140213
sat there and as a woman sang , she kept getting thinner and thinner , right before my eyes , and the eyes of some 5 , 500 other people .	106.24185
i make this observation about the lady , miss judy garland , because she brought up the subject herself in telling a story about a british female reporter who flattered her terribly in london recently and then wrote in the paper the next day	152.13951
but who cares , when the lady sings ? ?	10.6558075
certainly not the largest afternoon audience newport has ever had at a jazz concert and the most attentive and quiet .	106.61907
they applauded every number , not only at its conclusion but also at the first statement of the theme -- sometimes at the first chord .	66.54576
and judy sang the lovely old familiar things which seemed , at times , a blessed relief from the way-out compositions of the progressive jazzmen who have dominated these proceedings .	105.201706
things like `` when you ' re smiling ' ' , `` almost like being in love ' ' , `` do it again ' ' , `` born to wander ' ' , `` alone together ' ' , `` who cares ? ?	38.069515
' ' , `` puttin ' on the ritz ' ' , `` how long has this been going on ? ?	84.671364
' ' and her own personal songs like `` the man that got away ' ' , and the inevitable `` over the rainbow ' ' .	35.961124
miss garland is not only one of the great singers of our time but she is one of the superb showmen .	83.5468
at the start of her program there were evidences of pique .	79.62635
she had held to the letter of her contract and didn ' t come onto the stage until well after 4 p . m . , the appointed hour , although the music at newport people had tried to get the program underway at 3 .	98.310745
then there was a bad delay in getting mort lindsey ' s 30-piece orchestra wedged into its chairs .	180.25125
along about 4 30 , just when it was getting to be about time to turn the audience over and toast them on the other side , judy came on singing , in a short-skirted blue dress with a blue and white jacket that flapped in the wind .	93.804565
her bouffant coiffure was fortunately combed on the left which happened to be the direction from which a brisk breeze was blowing .	99.85043
in her first song she waved away one encroaching photographer who dared approach the throne unbidden and thereafter the boys with the cameras had to unsheathe their 300 mm . lenses and shoot at extreme range .	181.34248
there also came a brief contretemps with the sound mixers who made the mistake of being overheard during a quiet moment near the conclusion of `` do it again ' ' , and she made the tart observation that `` i never saw so much moving about in an audience ' ' .	88.829056
but it didn ' t take judy garland , showman , long to realize that this sort of thing was par for the course at newport and that you have to learn to live with it .	89.16044
before her chore was finished she was rescuing wind-blown sheets of music , trundling microphones about the stage , helping to move the piano and otherwise joining in the informal atmosphere .	124.447205
and time after time she really belted out her songs .	202.2171
sometimes they struck me as horribly over-arranged -- which was the way i felt about her `` come rain or come shine ' ' -- and sometimes they were just plain magnificent , like her shatteringly beautiful `` beautiful weather ' ' .	147.51788
to her partisan audience , such picayune haggling would have seemed nothing more than a critic striving to hold his franchise	121.77662
they just sat back on their haunches and cried for more , as though they could never get enough .	99.66844
they were rewarded with splendid , exciting , singing .	84.35522
her `` rockabye your baby ' ' was as good as it can be done , and her really personal songs , like `` the man that got away ' ' were deeply moving .	97.75186
the audience wouldn ' t let her leave until it had heard `` over the rainbow ' ' -- although the fellow that kept crying for `` get happy ' ' had to go home unhappy , about that item anyway .	127.41619
she was generous with her encores and the audience was equally so with its cheers and applause and flowers .	68.404106
all went home happy except the newport police , who feared that the throng departing at 6 35 might meet head-on the night crowd drawing nigh , and those deprived of their happy hour at the cocktail bar .	136.10666
in newport last night there were flashes of distant lightning in the northern skies .	58.09953
this was perhaps symbolic of the jazz of the evening -- flashes in the distance , but no storm .	95.28395
several times it came near breaking , and there were in fact some lovely peals of thunder from jerry mulligan ' s big band , which is about as fine an aggregation as has come along in the jazz business since john hammond found count basie working in a kansas city trap .	116.62415
mulligan ' s band has been infected with his solid sense of swing , and what it does seems far more meaningful than most of the noise generated by the big concert aggregations .	103.39089
but what is equally impressive is the delicacy and wonderful lyric quality of both the band and mulligan ' s baritone sax in a fragile ballad like bob brookmeyer ' s arrangement of `` django ' s castle ' ' .	43.56717
for subtle swinging rhythms , i could admire intensely mulligan ' s version of `` weep ' ' , and the fireworks went on display in `` 18 carrots for robert ' ' , a sax tribute to johnny hodges .	77.53877
there was considerable contrast between this mulligan performance and that of art blakey and the jazz messengers , who are able to generate a tremendous sound for such a small group .	118.688126
unfortunately , blakey doesn ' t choose to work much of the time in this vein .	49.61388
he prefers to have his soloist performing and thus we get only brief glimpses of what his ensemble work is like .	403.86978
what we did get , however , was impressive .	1023.3435
a few drops of rain just before midnight , when sarah vaughan was in the midst of her first number , scattered the more timid members of the audience briefly , but at this hour and with sarah on the stand , most of the listeners didn ' t care whether they got wet .	96.48876
miss vaughan was back in top form , somehow mellowed and improved with the passage of time -- like a fine wine .	143.07431
after the spate of female vocalists we have been having , all of whom took sarah as a point of departure and then tried to see what they could do that might make her seem old hat , it seemed that all that has happened is to make the real thing seem better than ever .	118.72265
the evening program was opened by the jazz three , a newport group consisting of steve budieshein on bass , jack warner , drums , and don cook , piano .	119.978096
this was a continuation of a good idea which was first tried out saturday night when the eddie stack group , also local talent , went on first .	178.08218
putting on local musicians at this place in the program serves a triple purpose it saves the top flight jazz men from being wasted in this unenviable spot , when the audience is cold , restless , and in flux	234.42868
it prevents late-comers from missing some of the people they have come a long way to hear , and it gives the resident musicians a chance to perform before the famous newport audience .	88.52398
the jazz three displayed their sound musicianship , not only in their own chosen set , but as the emergency accompanists for al minns & leon james , the superb jazz dancers who have now been newport performers for three successive years , gradually moving up from a morning seminar on the evolution of the blues to a spot on the evening program .	104.32469
julie wilson , a vigorous vocalist without many wild twists , sang a set , a large part of which consisted of such seldom heard old oldies as `` hard-hearted hannah , the vamp of savannah ' ' , and the delightful `` sunday ' ' .	109.85754
she frosted the cake with the always reliable `` bill bailey ' ' .	32.113827
from this taste of the 1920s , we leaped way out to stan getz ' s private brand of progressive jazz , which did lovely , subtle things for `` baubles , bangles and beads ' ' , and a couple of ballards .	186.10938
he plays his sax principally for beauty of tone , rather than for scintillating flights of meaningless improvisations , and he has a quiet way of getting back and restating the melody after the improvising is over .	106.80088
in this he is sticking with tradition , however far removed from it he may seem to be .	114.423706
george shearing took over with his well disciplined group , a sextet consisting of vibes , guitar , bass , drums , shearing ' s piano and a bongo drummer .	68.43879
he met with enthusiastic audience approval , especially when he swung from jazz to latin american things like the mambo .	191.79056
shearing , himself , seemed to me to be playing better piano than in his recent newport appearances .	185.49902
a very casual , pleasant program -- one of those easy-going things that make newport ' s afternoon programs such a relaxing delight -- was held again under sunny skies , hot sun , and a fresh breeze for an audience of at least a couple of thousands who came to newport to hear music rather than go to the beach .	135.18031
divided almost equally into two parts , it consisted of `` the evolution of the blues ' ' , narrated by jon hendricks , who had presented it last year at the monterey , calif . , jazz festival , and an hour-long session of maynard ferguson and his orchestra , a blasting big band .	74.97465
hendricks ' story was designed for children and he had a small audience of small children right on stage with him .	79.19936
tracing the blues from its african roots among the slaves who were brought to this country and the west indies , he stressed the close relationship between the early jazz forms and the music of the negro churches .	68.50977
to help him on this religious aspect of primitive jazz he had `` big ' ' miller , as a preacher-singer and hannah dean , gospel-singer , while oscar brown jr . , an extremely talented young man , did a slave auctioneer ' s call , a field-hands ' work song , and a beautifully sung negro lullaby , `` brown baby ' ' , which was one of the truly moving moments of the festival .	81.81643
one of those delightful surprise additions , which so frequently occur in jazz programs , was an excellent stint at the drums by the great joe jones , drumming to `` old man river ' ' , which seems to have been elected the favorite solo for the boys on the batterie at this year ' s concerts .	89.111305
demonstrating the primitive african rhythmic backgrounds of the blues was michael babatunde olatunji , who plays such native drums as the konga and even does a resounding job slapping his own chest .	128.36343
he has been on previous newport programs and was one of the sensations of last year ' s afternoon concerts .	91.76132
jimmy witherspoon , blues singer ( and a good one ) , and the ike isaacs trio , which has done such wonderful work for two afternoons now , helping him with the musical examples .	83.688866
pianists who are serious about their work are likely to know the interesting material contained in schubert ' s sonatas .	107.6164
music lovers who are not familiar with this literature may hear an excellent example , played for rca by emil gilels .	218.42104
he has chosen sonata op . 53 in aj .	82.45883
the playing takes both sides of the disc .	6.66953
perhaps one of the reasons these sonatas are not programmed more often is their great length .	220.12782
rhythmic interest , melodic beauty and the expansiveness of the writing are all qualities which hold one ' s attention with the gilels playing .	119.83641
his technique is ample and his musical ideas are projected beautifully .	134.74297
the male chorus of the robert shaw chorale sings sea shanties in fine style .	56.745785
what a discussion can ensue when the title of this type of song is in question .	53.526466
do you say chantey , as if the word were derived from the french word chanter , to sing , or do you say shanty and think of a roughly built cabin , which derives its name from the french-canadian use of the word chantier , with one of its meanings given as a boat-yard ? ?	101.87274
either way , the robert shaw chorus sings them in fine style with every colorful word and its musical frame spelled out in terms of agreeable listening .	209.74397
if your favorite song is not here it must be an unfamiliar one .	32.39847
the london label offers an operatic recital by ettore bastianini , a baritone whose fame is international .	132.78831
murray louis and his dance company appeared at the henry street playhouse on friday and saturday evenings and sunday afternoons in the premiere of his latest work , `` signal ' ' , and the repetition of an earlier one , `` journal ' ' .	53.69234
`` signal ' ' is choreographed for three male dancers to an electronic score by alwin nikolais .	81.14447
here , as in `` journal ' ' , mr . louis has given himself the lion ' s share of the dancing , and there is no doubt that he is capable of conceiving and executing a wide variety of difficult and arresting physical movements .	51.90181
indeed , both `` journal ' ' and `` signal ' ' qualify as instructive catalogues of modern-dance calisthenics .	123.31525
but chains of movements are not necessarily communicative , and it is in the realm of communication that the works prove disappointing .	49.80519
one frequently has the feeling that the order of their movement combinations could be transposed without notable loss of effect , there is too little suggestion of organic relationship and development .	220.27588
it may be , of course , that mr . louis is consciously trying to create works that anticipate an age of total automation .	161.63058
but it may be , also , that he is merely more mindful of athletics than of esthetics at the present time .	142.57654
one thing is certain , however , and that is that he is far more slavish to the detailed accents , phrasings and contours of the music he deals with than a confident dance creator need be .	126.9431
a brisk , satirical spoof of contemporary american mores entitled `` an american journey ' ' was given its first new york performance at hunter college playhouse last night by the helen tamiris-daniel nagrin dance company .	133.51212
choreographed by mr . nagrin , the work filled the second half of a program that also offered the first new york showing of miss tamiris ' `` once upon a time ' ' as well as her `` women ' s song ' ' and mr . nagrin ' s `` indeterminate figure ' ' .	61.59717
eugene lester assembled a witty and explicit score for `` an american journey ' ' , and malcolm mccormick gave it sprightly imaginative costumes .	79.97395
mr . nagrin has described four `` places ' ' , each with its scenery and people , added two `` diversions ' ' , and concluded with `` a toccata for the young ' ' , a refreshingly underplayed interpretation of rock ' n ' roll dancing .	121.77012
the `` places ' ' could be anywhere , the idiosyncrasies and foibles observed there could be anybody ' s , and the laugh is on us all .	114.789566
but we need not mind too much , because mr . nagrin has expressed it through movement that is diverting and clever almost all the way .	208.76424
miss tamiris ' `` once upon a time ' ' is a problem piece about a man and a woman and the three `` figures ' ' that bother them somehow .	98.10217
unfortunately , the man and woman were not made to appear very interesting at the outset and the menacing figures failed to make them any more so .	147.0212
nor did the dancing involved really seize the attention at any time .	58.373898
the music here , russell smith ' s `` tetrameron ' ' , sounded good .	25.558832
all the performances of the evening were smooth and assured , and the sizable company , with mr . nagrin and marion scott as its leading dancers , seemed to be fine shape .	75.99478
the symphony of the air , greatly assisted by van cliburn , last night got its seven-concert beethoven cycle at carnegie hall off to a good start .	125.57999
at the same time the orchestra announced that next season it would be giving twenty-five programs at carnegie , and that it would be taking these concerts to the suburbs , repeating each of them in five different communities .	179.44571
this news , announced by jerome toobin , the orchestra ' s administrative director , brought applause from the 2 , 800 persons who filled the hall .	88.470764
they showed they were glad that carnegie would have a major orchestra playing there so often next season to take up the slack with the departure to lincoln center of the new york philharmonic , the philadelphia orchestra and the boston symphony .	119.905
this season the orchestra has already taken a step toward the suburbs in that it is giving six subscription concerts for the orchestral society of westchester in the county center in white plains .	125.764496
the details of the suburban concerts next season , and the centers in which they will be given , will be announced later , mr . toobin said .	65.58864
the concertos that van cliburn has been associated with in new york since his triumphant return from russia in 1958 have been the tchaikovsky , the rachmaninoff third , and the prokofieff third .	163.37006
it was pleasant last night , therefore , to hear him do something else a concerto he has recently recorded , `` the emperor ' ' .	141.56592
the young texas pianist can make great chords ring out as well as anyone , so last night the massive sonorities of this challenging concerto were no hazard to him .	196.72278
but they were not what distinguished his performance .	30.715342
the elements that did were the introspective slow movement , the beautiful transition to the third movement , and the passages of filigree that laced through the bigger moments of the opening movement and the final rondo .	61.87117
mr . cliburn gave the slow movement some of the quality of a chopin nocturne .	26.121101
alfred wallenstein , the conductor , sensitive accompanist that he is , picked up the idea and led the orchestra here with a sense of brooding , poetic mystery .	113.34366
the collaboration was remarkable , as it was in both the other movements , too .	134.10442
mr . wallenstein , who will lead all of the concerts in the cycle , also conducted the `` leonore ' ' overture no . 3 and the fourth symphony .	64.70438
the orchestra was obviously on its mettle and it played most responsively .	978.19385
and although there was plenty of vigor in the performance , the ensemble was at its best when the playing was soft and lyrical , yet full of the suppressed tension that is one of the hallmarks of beethoven .	101.375565
igor oistrakh will be the next soloist on feb . 4 .	6.4121165
there are times when one suspects that the songs that are dropped from musical shows before they reach broadway may really be better than many of those that are left in .	281.2601
today , in the era of the integrated musical when an individual song must contribute to the over-all development of the show , it is understandable that a song , no matter how excellent it may be on its own terms , is cut out because it does not perform the function required of it .	84.07709
in the more casually constructed musicals of the nineteen twenties and nineteen thirties there would seem to have been less reason for eliminating a song of merit .	73.45286
yet there is the classic case of the gershwins ' `` the man i love ' ' .	30.596367
deemed too static when it was first heard in `` lady be good ' ' in philadelphia in 1924 , it was dropped from the score .	67.83606
it was heard again in philadelphia in 1927 in the first version of `` strike up the band ' ' and again abandoned shortly before the entire show was given up .	95.311584
it finally reached broadway in the second and successful version of `` strike up the band ' ' in 1929 .	83.51159
( still another song in `` strike up the band ' ' -- `` i ' ve got a crush on you ' ' -- was retrieved from a 1928 failure , `` treasure girl ' ' .	34.73568
like the gershwins , richard rodgers and lorenz hart were loath to let a good song get away from them .	97.604546
if one of mr . rodgers ' melodies seemed to deserve a better fate than interment in boston or the obscurity of a broadway failure , mr . hart was likely to deck it out with new lyrics to give it a second chance in another show .	185.12076
several of these double entries have been collected by ben bagley and michael mcwhinney , along with rodgers and hart songs that disappeared permanently en route to new york and others that reached broadway but have not become part of the constantly heard rodgers and hart repertory , in a delightfully refreshing album , rodgers and hart revisited ( spruce records , 505 fifth avenue , new york ) .	68.33489
among the particular gems in this collection is the impudent opening song of `` the garrick gaieties ' ' , an impressive forecast of the wit and melody that were to come from rodgers and hart in the years that followed	52.846725
dorothy loudon ' s raucous listing of the attractions `` at the roxy music hall ' ' from `` i married an angel ' '	139.3193
and the incisive style with which charlotte rae delivers the top-drawer hart lyrics of `` i blush ' ' , a song that was cut from `` a connecticut yankee ' ' .	46.837345
altogether fifteen virtually unknown rodgers and hart songs are sung by a quintet of able vocalists .	36.20057
norman paris has provided them with extremely effective orchestral accompaniment	5.185336
turning to the current musical season on broadway , the most widely acclaimed of the new arrivals , how to succeed in business without really trying , has been transferred to an original cast album ( r . c . a . victor loc 1066	95.35877
stereo lso 1066 ) that has some entertaining moments , although it is scarcely as inventive as the praise elicited by the show might lead one to expect .	107.2579
robert morse , singing with comically plaintive earnestness , carries most of the burden and is responsible for the high spots in frank loesser ' s score .	86.12598
rudy vallee , who shares star billing with mr . morse , makes only two appearances .	92.36986
he shares with mr . morse a parody of the college anthems he once sang while his second song is whisked away from him by virginia martin , a girl with a remarkably expressive yip in her voice .	202.30516
in general , mr . loesser has done a more consistent job as lyricist than he has as composer .	218.66487
like mr . loesser , jerry herman is both composer and lyriist for milk and honey ( r . c . a . victor loc 1065	116.06981
stereo lso 1065 ) , but in this case it is the music that stands above the lyrics .	88.9832
for this story of an american couple who meet and fall in love in israel , mr . herman has written songs that are warmly melodious and dance music that sparkles .	178.01555
there are the full-bodied , resourceful voices of robert weede , mimi benzell and tommy rall to make the most of mr . herman ' s lilting melodies and , for an occasional change of pace , the bright humor of molly picon .	110.445335
mr . herman has managed to mix musical ideas drawn from israel and the standard american ballad style in a manner that stresses the basic tunefulness of both idioms .	226.99568
not content to create only the music and lyrics , noel coward also wrote the book and directed sail away ( capitol wao 1643	140.15836
stereo swao 1643 ) , a saga of life on a cruise ship that is not apt to be included among mr . coward ' s more memorable works .	105.61214
the melodies flow along pleasantly , as mr . coward ' s songs usually do , but his lyrics have a tired , cut-to-a-familiar-pattern quality .	189.16768
elaine stritch , who sings with a persuasively warm huskiness , belts some life into most of her songs , but the other members of the cast sound as lukewarm as mr . coward ' s songs .	127.839584
with three fine russian films in recent months on world war 2 , -- `` the house i live in ' ' , `` the cranes are flying ' ' and `` ballad of a soldier ' ' -- we had every right to expect a real soviet block-buster in `` the day the war ended ' ' .	58.146812
it simply isn ' t , not by a long shot .	47.589188
the artkino presentation , with english titles , opened on saturday at the cameo theatre .	172.10573
make no mistake , this gorky studio drama is a respectable import -- aptly grave , carefully written , performed and directed .	181.56044
in describing the initial allied occupation of a middle-sized german city , the picture has color , pictorial pull and genuinely moving moments .	326.5415
told strictly from the viewpoint of the russian conquerors , the film compassionately peers over the shoulders of a smitten soviet couple , at both sides of the conflict ' s aftermath .	96.7361
unfortunately , the whole picture hinges on this romance , at the expense of everything else .	74.099686
tenderly and rather tediously , the camera rivets on the abrupt , deep love of a pretty nurse and a uniformed teacher , complicated by nothing more than a friend they don ' t want to hurt .	100.74631
it ' s the old story , war or no war , and more than one viewer may recall hollywood ' s `` titanic ' ' , several seasons back , when the paramount concern was for the marital discord of a society dilettante .	101.510765
under yakov segal ' s direction , it begins stirringly , as crouching soviet and nazi troops silently scan each other , waiting for the first surrender gesture .	176.35721
one high-up camera shot is magnificent , as the germans straggle from a cathedral , dotting a huge , cobblestone square , and drop their weapons .	111.052475
ring of bright water , by gavin maxwell .	6.2686815
only once in a very long while comes a book that gives the reader a magic sense of sharing a rare experience .	121.133194
`` ring of bright water ' ' by gavin maxwell is just that -- a haunting , warmly personal chronicle of a man , an otter , and a remote cottage in the scottish west highlands .	59.93638
`` he has married me with a ring of bright water ' ' , begins the kathleen raine poem from which maxwell takes his title , and it is this mystic bond between the human and natural world that the author conveys .	125.88534
the place is camusfearna , the site of a long-vanished sea-village opposite the isle of skye .	214.6132
it is a land of long fjords , few people , a single-lane road miles away -- and of wild stags , greylag geese , wild swans , dolphins and porpoises playing in the waters .	128.49915
how maxwell recounts his first coming to camusfearna , his furnishing the empty house with beach-drift , the subtle changes in season over ten years , is a moving experience .	166.55838
just the evocations of time and place , of passionate encounter between man and a natural world which today seems almost lost , would be enough .	146.95706
there is mijbil , an otter who travelled with maxwell -- and gave maxwell ' s name to a new species -- from the tigris marshes to his london flat .	83.00002
it may sound extravagant to say that there has never been a more engaging animal in all literature .	61.381195
this is not only a compliment to mijbil , of whom there are a fine series of photographs and drawings in the book , but to the author who has catalogued the saga of a frightened otter cub ' s journey by plane from iraq to london , then by train ( where he lay curled in the wash basin playing with the water tap ) to camusfearna , with affectionate detail .	79.883095
mij , as his owner was soon to learn , had strange , inexplicable habits .	185.87453
he liked to nip ear lobes of unsuspecting visitors with his needle-sharp teeth .	466.93616
he preferred sleeping in bed with his head on a pillow .	45.49964
given a small ball or marbles , he would invent games and play by himself for hours .	152.53918
with curiosity and elan , he explored every inch of glen , beach and burn , once stranding himself for hours on a ledge high up a sheer seventy-foot cliff and waiting with calm faith to be rescued by maxwell , who nearly lost his life in doing so .	140.46927
a year and a day of this idyll is described for the reader , one in which not only discovery of a new world of personality is charted , but self-discovery as well .	100.058525
in the solitude of camusfearna there had been no loneliness .	87.50032
`` to be quite alone where there are no other human beings is sharply exhilarating	256.02112
it is as though some pressure had suddenly been lifted , allowing an intense awareness a sharpening of the senses ' ' .	118.937965
now , with the increasing interdependence between himself and mij came a knowledge of an obscure need , that of being trusted implicitly by some creature .	176.11401
two other people in time shared mijbil ' s love `` it remained around us three that his orb revolved when he was not away in his own imponderable world of wave and water	160.94234
we were his trinity , and he behaved towards us with a mixture of trust and abuse , passion and irritation .	95.616615
in turn each of us in our own way depended , as gods do , upon his worship ' ' .	98.99887
the brief details of mijbil ' s death lend depth to the story , give it an edge of ironic tragedy .	128.64505
man , to whom mij gave endless affection and fealty , was responsible in the form of a road worker with a pickaxe who somehow becomes an abstract symbol of the savage in man .	120.04138
but then , through a strange coincidence , maxwell manages to acquire idal , a female otter , and the fascinating story starts once more .	164.26147
one is not sure who emerges as the main personality of this book -- mijbil , with his rollicking ways , or maxwell himself , poet , portrait painter , writer , journalist , traveller and zoologist , sensitive but never sentimental recorder of an unusual way of life , in a language at once lyrical and forceful , vivid and unabashed .	93.11328
this reviewer read the book when it was first brought out in england with a sense of discovery and excitement .	124.071556
now gavin maxwell ' s ring of bright water has widened to enchant the world .	72.44678
-- the performances of the comedie francaise are the most important recent events in the new york theater .	42.869007
they serve to contradict a popular notion that the comedie merely repeats , as accurately as possible , the techniques of acting the classics that prevailed in the 17th century .	76.089386
on the contrary , the old plays are continually being reinterpreted , and each new production of a classic has only a brief history at the comedie .	102.195076
of course , the well-received revivals last longer than the others , and that further reminds us that the comedie is not insensitive to criticism .	66.69179
the directors of the comedie do not respond to adverse notices in as docile and subservient a manner as the broadway producers who , in two instances this season , closed their plays after one performance .	199.74449
but they are aware of the world outside , they court public approval , they delight in full houses , and they occasionally dare to experiment in interpreting a dramatic classic .	289.0343
in france , novel approaches to the classic french plays are frequently attempted .	430.83032
the government pays a subsidy for revival of the classics , and this policy attracts experimenters who sometimes put moliere ' s characters in modern dress and often achieve interesting results .	157.38564
so far as i know , the comedie has never put moliere ' s people in the costumes of the 20th century , but they do reinterpret plays and characters .	80.52348
last season , the comedie ' s two principal experiments came to grief , and , in consequence , we can expect fairly soon to see still newer productions of racine ' s `` phedre ' ' and moliere ' s `` school for wives ' ' .	76.473526
the new `` phedre ' ' was done in 17th century setting , instead of ancient greek	172.2844
perhaps that is the comedie ' s equivalent for thrusting this play ' s characters into our own time .	173.79352
the speaking of the lines seemed excessively slow and stately , possibly in an effort to capture the spirit of 17th century elegance .	51.517006
a few literary men defended what they took to be an emphasis on the poetry at the expense of the drama , but the response was mainly hostile and quite violent .	72.07179
the new `` school for wives ' ' was interpreted according to a principle that is becoming increasingly common in the playing of classic comedy -- the idea of turning some obviously ludicrous figure into a tragic character .	150.3405
among the moliere specialists of some years ago , louis jouvet tried to humanize some of the clowns , while fernand ledoux , often performing at the comedie , made them more gross than moliere may have intended .	221.03693
apparently , jouvet and ledoux attempted just these dissimilar approaches in the role of arnolphe in `` the school for wives ' ' .	50.700245
i say `` apparently ' ' although i saw jouvet as arnolphe when he visited this country shortly before his death	179.93874
by that time , he seemed to have dropped the tragic playing of the last moments of the comedy .	85.161385
arnolphe , it will be recalled , is a man of mature years who tries to preserve the innocence of his youthful wife-to-be .	70.419174
one influential french critic remarked `` pity for arnolphe comes with age ' ' .	136.57246
accordingly , at the comedie last year , jean meyer played a sympathetic arnolphe and drew criticism for turning the comedy into a tragedy .	142.88988
but the stuff of tragedy was not truly present and the play became only comedy acted rather slowly .	726.66754
wisely , the comedie has brought moliere ' s `` tartuffe ' ' on its tour and has left `` the school for wives ' ' at home .	51.67212
tartuffe is the religious hypocrite who courts his benefactor ' s wife .	31.783792
jouvet played him as a sincere zealot , and ledoux , at the comedie , made him a gross buffoon , or so the historians tell us .	101.329025
louis seigner , who formerly played the deluded benefactor opposite ledoux , is the tartuffe of the present production , which he himself directed .	164.35439
his red face , his coarse gestures , and his lustful stares bespeak his sensuality .	100.000854
but his heavenward glances and his pious speeches are not merely perfunctory	361.39523
of course , they do not reflect sincerity , but they exhibit a concern to make a good job out of his pious impersonation .	70.329544
occasionally , seigner draws some justly deserved laughs by his quick shifts from one personality to another .	209.27724
the whole role , by the way , is a considerable transformation for anyone who has seen seigner in his other parts .	136.98126
his normal specialty is playing the good-natured old man , frequently stupid or deluded but never mean or sly .	138.30826
here , he is , quite persuasively , the very embodiment of meanness and slyness .	102.87698
seigner is the dean of the company , the oldest actor in point of continuous service .	124.79995
in that function , he helps to rebut another legend about the comedie .	46.61292
we are often told that the comedie has , unfortunately , life-contracts with old actors who are both mediocre and lazy , drawing their pay without much acting but probably doing real service to the comedie by staying off the stage .	320.64075
seigner , however , is a fine actor and probably the busiest man in the company	109.01686
among his other parts are the leads in `` the bourgeois gentleman ' ' and `` the imaginary invalid ' ' .	26.131472
in moliere ' s farce , `` the tricks of scapin ' ' , robert hirsch undertakes another of the great roles .	60.58037
to begin with , scapin is a trickster in the old tradition of the clever servant who plots the strategy of courtship for his master .	70.81874
hirsch ' s scapin is healthy , cheerful , energetic , revelling in his physical agility and his obvious superiority to the young gentlemen whom he serves .	79.66471
hirsch says that he has given the role certain qualities he has observed in the city toughs of the real world .	166.4197
and surely his scapin has a fresh directness , a no-nonsense quality that seems to make him his own master and nobody ' s servant .	131.11888
django reinhardt , the ill-fated gypsy , was a true artist , one who demonstrated conclusively the power of art to renew itself and flow into many channels .	117.07464
there is hardly a jazz guitarist in the business today who doesn ' t owe something to django .	145.03865
he told once of how he switched his style of playing to jazz after listening to two old armstrong records he bought in the flea market in paris .	142.70596
it was the first jazz he had heard .	35.57918
django , who was born jean baptiste reinhardt in belgium and who died in 1953 in france , was an extraordinary man .	94.62818
most of the fingers on his left hand were burned off when he fell asleep with a cigarette .	107.72227
and this was before he began to play his startlingly beautiful jazz .	365.70932
you can catch up with him -- if you haven ' t already -- on rca-victor ' s album .	54.065662
`` djangology ' ' , made up of tracks he recorded with stephane grappelly and the quintet of the hot club of france .	158.20163
this is a choice item and grappely deserves mention too , of course .	68.1245
he is one of the few men in history who plays jazz on a violin .	146.38322
they play `` minor swing ' ' , `` honeysuckle rose ' ' , `` beyond the sea ' ' , `` bricktop ' ' , `` heavy artillery ' ' , `` djangology ' ' , `` after you ' ve gone ' ' , `` where are you , my love ' ' ? ?	30.533266
`` i saw stars ' ' , `` lover man ' ' , `` menilmontant ' ' and `` swing 42 ' ' .	18.156883
all this is great proceedings -- get the minutes .	454.88068
kid ory , the trombonist chicken farmer , is also one of the solid anchor points of jazz .	94.07786
he dates back to the days before the first sailing ship pulled into new orleans .	132.68047
his horn has blown loud and clear across the land for more years than he cares to remember .	125.0446
good time jazz has released a nice two-record album which he made .	119.016426
wellman braud , bass , and minor hall , drums .	10.328665
the set contains `` high society ' ' , `` do what ory say ' ' , `` down home rag ' ' , `` careless love ' ' , jazz me blues ' ' , `` weary blues ' ' , `` original dixieland one-step ' ' , `` bourbon street parade ' ' , `` panama ' ' , `` toot , toot , tootsie ' ' , `` oh didn ' t he ramble ' ' , `` beale street blues ' ' , `` maryland , my maryland ' ' , `` 1919 rag ' ' , `` eh , la bas ' ' , `` mood indigo ' ' , and `` bugle call rag ' ' .	29.189543
all this will serve to show off the ory style in fine fashion and is a must for those who want to collect elements of the old-time jazz before it is too late to lay hands on the gems .	196.76443
mischa elman shared last night ' s lewisohn stadium concert with three american composers .	126.090256
his portion of the program -- and a big portion it was -- consisted of half the major nineteenth-century concertos for the violin to wit , the mendelssohn and the tchaikovsky .	184.10796
that is an evening of music-making that would faze many a younger man	323.80774
there were 8 , 000 persons at the stadium who can tell their grandchildren that they heard elman .	444.75632
but , with all due respects and allowances , it must truthfully be said that what they heard was more syrupy than sweet , more mannered than musical .	100.79018
the american part of the evening consisted of paul creston ' s dance overture , william schuman ' s `` chester ' ' from `` new england triptych ' ' and two works of wallingford riegger , dance rhythms , op . 58 , and a romanza for strings , op . 56a .	64.5724
the creston is purely a potboiler , with spanish , english , french and american dances mixed into the stew .	121.39212
the riegger , with its latin hesitation bounce , is just this side of the pale	144.1763
like his sweet , attractive romanza , it belongs to what the composer called his `` non-dissonant ( mostly ) ' ' category of works .	164.72197
the schuman `` chester ' ' takes off from an old william billings tune with rousing woodwind and brass effect .	106.19839
all these -- potboilers or no -- provided a welcome breath of fresh air in the form of lively , colorful , unstuffy works well suited for the great out-of-doors .	75.26045
it was nice to have something a little up-to-date for a change .	101.40298
we have alfredo antonini to thank for this healthy change of diet as well as the lively performances of the stadium symphony .	111.07324
a woman who undergoes artificial insemination against the wishes of her husband is the unlikely heroine of `` a question of adultery ' ' , yesterday ' s new british import at the apollo .	74.857124
since an objective viewer might well conclude that this is not a situation that would often arise , the film ' s extensive discussion of the problem seems , at best , superfluous .	63.6899
in its present artless , low-budget form , the subject matter seems designed to invite censorial wrath .	72.20436
with julie london enacting the central role with husky-voiced sincerity , the longsuffering heroine is at least attractive .	269.2723
the explanation offered for her conduct is a misguided attempt to save her marriage to a neurotic husband left sterile as a result of an automobile accident .	129.19402
anthony steel , as the husband , is a jealous type who argues against her course and sues for divorce , labeling her action adulterous .	412.84048
the actor plays his role glumly under the lurid direction of don chaffey , as do basil sydney as his unsympathetic father and anton diffring as an innocent bystander .	212.05655
after a protracted , hysterical trial scene more notable for the frankness of its language than for dramatic credibility , the jury , to no one ' s surprise , leaves the legal question unresolved .	109.79213
when the husband drops the case and returns to his wife , both seem sorry they brought the matter up in the first place .	116.53038
-- for its final change of bill in its london season , the leningrad state kirov ballet chose tonight to give one of those choreographic miscellanies known as a `` gala program ' ' at the royal opera house , covent garden .	114.22707
no doubt the underlying idea was to show that for all the elegance and artistry that have distinguished its presentations thus far , it too could give a circus if it pleased .	208.61786
and please it did , in every sense of the word , for it had the audience shouting much of the time in a manner far from typical of london audiences .	99.83891
at the end of the program , indeed , there was a demonstration that lasted for forty-five minutes , and nothing could stop it .	81.53866
alexandre livshitz repeated a fantastic technical bit from the closing number , `` taras bulba ' ' , but even then there was a substantial number of diehards who seemed determined not to go home at all .	65.5041
only a plea from the house manager , john collins , finally broke up the party .	193.82088
but for all the manifest intention to `` show off ' ' , this was a circus with a difference , for instead of descending in quality to what is known as a popular level , it added further to the evidence that this is a very great dancing company .	104.135345
the `` taras bulba ' ' excerpt is a rousing version of gogol ' s ukrainian folk-tale choreographed by bo fenster to music of soloviev-sedoi .	100.10549
it is danced by some thirty-five men and no women , and it contains everything in the books -- lusty comedy , gregarious cavorting , and tricks that only madmen or russians would attempt to make the human body perform .	101.15957
yuri soloviev , oleg sokolov , alexei zhitkov , lev sokolov , yuri korneyev and mr . livshitz were the chief soloists , but everybody on stage was magnificent .	139.59616
at the other extreme in character was the half-hour excerpt from the petipa-minkus ballet `` bayaderka ' ' , which opened the evening .	81.40991
and why do we in the west know so few of his ballets ? ?	210.54391
this scene is a `` white ballet ' ' in which a lovelorn hero searches for his departed love ' s spirit among twenty-eight extraordinarily beautiful `` shadows ' ' who can all dance like nothing human -- which , of course , is altogether fitting .	108.263535
the ensemble enters in a long adagio passage that is of fantastic difficulty , as well as loveliness , and adagio is the general medium of the piece .	73.20362
its ballerina , olga moiseyeva , performs simple miracles of beauty , and ludmilla alexeyeva , inna korneyeva and gabrielle komleva make up a threesome of exquisite accomplishments .	114.4916
sergei vikulov , as the lone male , meets the competition well with some brilliant hits , but the work is designed to belong to the ladies .	139.83392
the middle section of the program was made up of short numbers , naturally enough of unequal merit , but all of them pretty good at that .	180.05667
they consisted of a new arrangement of `` nutcracker ' ' excerpts danced stunningly by irina kolpakova and mr . sokolev , with a large ensemble	51.381058
a winning little `` snow maiden ' ' variation by the adorable galina kekisheva	328.70975
two of those poetic adagios in greek veils ( and superb esthetic acrobacy ) by alla osipenko and igor chernishev in one case and inna zubkovskaya and yuri kornevey in the other	51.57696
an amusing character pas de cinq called `` gossiping women ' '	41.78397
a stirring `` flames of paris ' ' pas de deux by xenia ter-stepanova and alexandre pavlovsky , and a lovely version of fokine ' s `` le cygne ' ' by olga moiseyeva , which had to be repeated .	30.599112
a year ago today , when the democrats were fretting and frolicking in los angeles and john f . kennedy was still only an able and ambitious senator who yearned for the power and responsibility of the presidency , theodore h . white had already compiled masses of notes about the presidential campaign of 1960 .	72.49941
as the pace of the quadrennial american political festival accelerated , mr . white took more notes .	124.50888
he traveled alternately with mr . kennedy and with richard m . nixon .	81.1538
he asked intimate questions and got frank answers from the members of what he calls the candidates ' `` in-groups ' ' .	42.5055
he assembled quantities of facts about the nature of american politics in general , as well as about the day-to-day course of the closest presidential election in american history .	36.209183
those of us who read the papers may think we know a good deal about that election	111.16056
how little we know of what there is to be known is made humiliatingly clear by mr . white in `` the making of the president 1960 ' ' .	46.371925
this is a remarkable book and an astonishingly interesting one .	210.09712
what might have been only warmed-over topical journalism turns out to be an eyewitness contribution to history .	63.663727
mr . white , who is only a competent novelist , is a brilliant reporter .	89.43794
his zest for specific detail , his sensitivity to emotional atmosphere , his tireless industry and his crisply turned prose all contribute to the effectiveness of his book .	151.24785
as a dramatic narrative `` the making of the president 1960 ' ' is continuously engrossing .	67.55894
and as an introduction to american politics it is highly educational .	161.44502
the author begins this volume with a close-up of mr . kennedy , his family and his entourage waiting for the returns .	75.064835
he then switches back to a consideration of the seven principal presidential hopefuls five democrats -- senator hubert h . humphrey , senator stuart symington , senator lyndon b . johnson , adlai e . stevenson and mr . kennedy -- and two republicans -- governor rockefeller and mr . nixon .	57.47632
then , in chronological order , mr . white covers the primary campaigns , the conventions and the presidential campaign itself .	119.74552
in the process he writes at length about many related matters the importance of race , religion , local tradition , bosses , organizations , zealous volunteers and television .	202.30942
mr . white is bluntly frank in his personal opinions .	228.99608
he frequently cites intimate details that seem to come straight from the horse ' s mouth , from numerous insiders and from mr . kennedy himself	128.49406
but never from mr . nixon , who looked on reporters with suspicion and distrust .	148.9382
`` rarely in american history has there been a political campaign that discussed issues less or clarified them less ' ' , says mr . white .	203.04854
mr . nixon , he believes , has no particular political philosophy and mismanaged his own campaign .	76.279335
although a skillful politician and a courageous and honest man , mr . nixon , mr . white believes , ignored his own top-level planners , wasted time and effort in the wrong regions , missed opportunities through indecision and damaged his chances on television .	97.706055
mr . nixon is `` a broody , moody man , given to long stretches of introspection	392.09464
he is a man of major talent -- but a man of solitary , uncertain impulses .	88.547325
he was above all a friend seeker , almost pathetic in his eagerness to be liked .	84.3586
he wanted to identify with people and have a connection with them	161.08897
the least inspiring candidate since alfred m . landon ' ' .	103.743454
mr . kennedy , mr . white believes , `` had mastered politics on so many different levels that no other american could match him ' ' .	218.1273
calm , dignified , composed , `` superbly eloquent ' ' , mr . kennedy always knew everything about everybody .	82.78524
he enlisted a staff of loyal experts and of many zealous volunteers .	502.58948
every decision was made quickly on sound grounds .	5.437586
efficiency was enforced and nothing was left to chance .	439.63596
mr . kennedy did not neglect to cultivate the personal friendship of reporters .	70.57229
mr . white admires him profoundly and leaves no doubt that he is a democrat himself who expects mr . kennedy to be a fine president .	52.961586
throughout `` the making of a president ' ' mr . white shows wonderfully well how the pressures pile up on candidates , how decisions have constantly to be made , how fatigue and illness and nervous strain wear candidates down , how subordinates play key roles .	313.14517
`` the root question in american politics is always who ' s the man to see ? ?	63.166485
to understand american politics is , simply , to know people , to know the relative weight of names -- who are heroes , who are straw men , who controls , who does not .	112.69211
but to operate in american politics one must go a step further -- one must build a bridge to such names , establish a warmth , a personal connection ' ' .	112.4762
`` in the hard life of politics it is well known that no platform nor any program advanced by either major american party has any purpose beyond expressing emotion ' ' .	411.44144
`` all platforms are meaningless the program of either party is what lies in the vision and conscience of the candidate the party chooses to lead it ' ' .	101.485695
nostalgia week at lewisohn stadium , which had begun with the appearance of the 70-year-old mischa elman on tuesday night , continued last night as lily pons led the list of celebrities in an evening of french operatic excerpts .	58.017365
miss pons is certainly not 70 -- no singer ever is -- and yet the rewards of the evening again lay more in paying tribute to a great figure of times gone by than in present accomplishments .	276.5449
the better part of gallantry might be , perhaps , to honor her perennial good looks and her gorgeous rainbow-hued gown , and to chide the orchestra for not playing in the same keys in which she had chosen to sing .	102.69192
no orchestra , however , could be expected to follow a singer through quite as many adventures with pitch as miss pons encountered last night .	190.22464
in all fairness , there were flashes of the great stylist of yesteryear , flashes even of the old consummate vocalism .	72.653755
one such moment came in the breathtaking way miss pons sang the cadenza to meyerbeer ' s `` shadow song ' ' .	60.55652
the years suddenly fell away at this point .	6.275896
on the whole , however , one must wonder at just what it is that forces a beloved artist to besmirch her own reputation as time marches inexorably on .	199.72507
sharing the program was the young french-canadian tenor richard verreau , making his stadium debut on this occasion .	61.634308
mr . verreau began shakily , with a voice that tended toward an unpleasant whiteness when pushed beyond middle volume .	383.94363
later on this problem vanished , and the `` flower song ' ' from bizet ' s `` carmen ' ' was beautifully and intelligently projected .	44.020348
radio is easily outdistancing television in its strides to reach the minority listener .	21.572226
lower costs and a larger number of stations are the key factors making such specialization possible .	284.15448
the mushrooming of fm outlets , offering concerts ( both jazz and classical ) , lectures , and other special events , is a phenomenon which has had a fair amount of publicity .	114.36669
not so well known is the growth of broadcasting operations aimed wholly or partly at negro listeners -- an audience which , in the united states , comprises some 19 , 000 , 000 people with $20 , 000 , 000 , 000 to spend each year .	45.367466
of course , the nonwhite listener does his share of television watching .	345.21234
he even buys a lot of the products he sees advertised -- despite the fact that the copy makes no special bid for his favor and sponsors rarely use any but white models in commercials .	247.9418
but the growing number of negro-appeal radio stations , plus evidence of strong listener support of their advertisers , give time salesmen an impressive argument as they approach new prospects .	342.03052
it is estimated that more than 600 stations ( of a total of 3 , 400 ) do a significant amount of programing for the negro .	81.56332
at least 60 stations devote all of their time to reaching this audience in about half of the 50 states .	145.40814
these and other figures and comments have been reported in a special supplement of sponsor magazine , a trade publication for radio and tv advertisers .	93.059746
for 10 years sponsor has issued an annual survey of the size and characteristics of the negro market and of successful techniques for reaching this market through radio .	166.15225
in the past 10 years , sponsor observes , these trends have become apparent	133.39008
negro population in the u . s . has increased 25 per cent while the white population was growing by 18 per cent .	51.11451
`` the forgotten 15 million ' ' -- as sponsor tagged the negro market in its first survey -- has become a better-remembered 19 million .	255.92116
advertisers are changing their attitudes , both as to the significance of this market and the ways of speaking to it .	72.970505
stations programing to negro listeners are having to upgrade their shows in order to keep pace with rising educational , economic , and cultural levels .	170.94725
futhermore , the station which wants real prestige must lead or participate in community improvement projects , not simply serve on the air .	279.05814
in the last decade the number of negro-appeal radio program hours has risen at least 15 per cent , and the number of negro-appeal stations has increased 30 per cent , according to a research man quoted by sponsor .	87.501236
a year ago the negro radio association was formed to spur research which the 30-odd member stations are sure will bring in more business .	175.08119
the 1960 census underscored the explosive character of the population growth .	53.29225
it also brought home proof of something a casual observer might have missed that more than half of the u . s . negroes live outside the southeastern states .	77.71856
also , the state with the largest number of negroes is new york -- not in the south at all .	66.86568
in new york city , wlib boasts `` more community service programs than any other negro station ' ' and `` one of the largest negro news staffs in america ' ' .	85.93206
and wwrl ' s colorful mobile unit , cruising predominately negro neighborhoods , is a frequent reminder of that station ' s round-the-clock dedication to nonwhite interests .	99.55843
recently , wwrl won praise for its expose of particular cases of employment agency deceit .	411.0761
a half-dozen other stations in the new york area also bid for attention of the city ' s negro population , up about 50 per cent in the past decade .	59.776115
in all big cities outside the south , and even in small towns within the south , radio stations can be found beaming some or all of their programs at negro listeners .	64.76151
the keystone broadcasting system ' s negro network includes 360 affiliated stations , whose signals reach more than half the total u . s . negro population .	95.074585
one question which inevitably crops up is whether such stations have a future in a nation where the negro is moving into a fully integrated status .	122.626366
whatever the long-range impact of integration , the owners of negro-appeal radio stations these days know they have an audience and that it is loyal .	113.918
advertisers have discovered the tendency of negroes to shop for brand names they have heard on stations catering to their special interests .	196.84308
and many advertisers have been happy with the results of letting a negro disc jockey phrase the commercial in his own words , working only from a fact sheet .	133.56242
what sets negro-appeal programing apart from other radio shows ? ?	86.18102
sponsor magazine notes the stress on popular negro bands and singers	17.168398
`` race ' ' music , folk songs and melodies , and gospel programs .	113.86988
furthermore , news and special presentations inform the listener about groups , projects , and personalities rarely mentioned on a general-appeal station .	246.84038
advertising copy frequently takes into account matters of special negro concern .	663.9331
sponsor quotes john mclendon of the mclendon-ebony station group as saying that the southern negro is becoming conscious of quality and `` does not wish to be associated with radio which is any way degrading to his race	196.77194
he tends to shy away from the hooting and hollering personalities that originally made negro radio programs famous ' ' .	165.5142
the sociological impact is perhaps most eloquently summed up in this quotation of j . walter carroll of ksan , san francisco	138.41605
`` negro-appeal radio is more important to the negro today , because it provides a direct and powerful mirror in which the negro can hear and see his ambitions , achievements and desires .	185.082
it will continue to be important as a means of orientation to the negro , seeking to become urbanized , as he tries to make adjustment to the urban life .	80.99545
negro radio is vitally necessary during the process of assimilation ' ' .	13.150571
presentation of `` the life and times of john sloan ' ' in the delaware art center here suggests a current nostalgia for human values in art .	116.70354
staged by way of announcing the gift of a large and intimate sloan collection by the artist ' s widow , helen farr sloan , to the wilmington society of the fine arts , the exhibition presents a survey of sloan ' s work .	41.98107
from early family portraits , painted before he entered the schools of the pennsylvania academy of the fine arts , the chronology extends to a group of paintings executed in his last year ( 1951 ) and still part of his estate .	89.64237
few artists have left a life work so eloquent of the period in which they lived .	108.99165
few who have painted the scenes around them have done so with so little bitterness .	328.5151
the paintings , drawings , prints , and illustrations all reflect the manners , costumes , and mores of america in the first half of the present century .	59.326122
obviously sloan ' s early years were influenced by his close friend robert henri .	69.73603
as early as 1928 , however , the sloan style began to change .	195.60742
the dark pigments of the early work were superseded by a brighter palette .	69.23817
the solidity of brush stroke yielded to a hatching technique that finally led to virtual abandonment of american genres in favor of single figure studies and studio nudes .	243.69089
the exhibition presents all phases of sloan ' s many-sided art .	93.761986
in addition to the paintings are drawings , prints , and illustrations .	11.621061
sloan created such works for newspaper supplements before syndication threw him out of a job and sent him to roam the streets of new york , thereby building for america an incomparable city survey from paintings of mcsorley ' s saloon to breezy clotheslines on city roofs .	120.13146
one of the most appealing of the rooftop canvases is `` sun and wind on the roof ' ' , with a woman and child bracing themselves against flapping clothes and flying birds .	68.27852
although there are landscapes in the show ( one of the strongest is a vista of `` gloucester harbor ' ' in 1915 ) , the human element was the compelling factor in sloan ' s art .	116.18914
significant are such canvases as `` bleeker street , saturday night ' ' , with its typically american crowd ( sloan never went abroad )	165.52902
the multifigure `` traveling carnival ' ' , in which action is vivified by lighting	292.2533
or `` carmine theater , 1912 ' ' , the only canvas with an ash can ( and foraging dog ) , although sloan was a member of the famous `` eight ' ' , and of the so-called `` ash-can school ' ' , a term he resented .	80.400406
not all the paintings , however , are of cities .	494.4648
the exhibition touches briefly on his sojourn in the southwest ( `` koshare in the dust ' ' , a vigorous indian dance , and landscapes suggest the influence of western color on his palette ) .	79.887436
the fact that sloan was an extrovert , concerned primarily with what he saw , adds greatly to the value of his art as a human chronicle .	110.1131
there are 151 items in the wilmington show , including one painting by each member of the `` eight ' ' , as well as work by sloan ' s friends and students .	59.087986
supplementing the actual art are memorabilia -- correspondence , diaries , books from the artist ' s library , etc . .	26.979467
all belong to the collection being given to wilmington over a period of years by mrs . sloan , who has cherished such revelatory items ever since she first studied with sloan at the art students league , new york , in the 1920 ' s .	88.88482
to enable students and the public to spot sloan forgeries , the delaware art center ( according to its director , bruce st . john ) will maintain a complete file of photographs of all sloan works , as well as a card index file .	115.05491
the entire sloan collection will be made available at the center to all serious art students and historians .	141.80989
the current exhibition , which remains on view through oct . 29 , has tapped 14 major collections and many private sources .	142.7871
any musician playing beethoven here , where beethoven was born , is likely to examine his own interpretations with special care .	105.75369
in a sense , he is offering bonn what its famous son ( who left as a youth ) never did -- the sound of the composer ' s mature style .	262.12387
robert riefling , who gave the only piano recital of the recently concluded 23rd beethoven festival , penetrated deep into the spirit of the style .	74.71566
his readings were careful without being fussy , and they were authoritative without being presumptuous .	115.61118
the 32 c minor variations with which he opened moved fluently yet logically from one to another , leaving the right impression of abundance under discipline .	298.9118
the d minor sonata , op . 31 no . 2 , introduced by dynamically shaped arpeggios , was most engaging in its moments of quasi-recitative -- single lines in which the fingers seemed to be feeling their way toward the idea to come .	150.94899
these inwardly dramatic moments showed the kind of `` opera style ' ' of which beethoven was genuinely capable , but which did not take so kindly to the mechanics of staging .	100.446075
two late sonatas , op . 110 and 111 , were played with similar insight , the disarming simplicities of the op . 111 adagio made plain without ever becoming obvious .	199.28204
the two were separated from each other by the six bagatelles of op . 126 .	54.05592
herr riefling , in everything he gave his large beethoven hall audience , proved himself as an interpreter of unobtrusive authority .	100.09971
volker wangenheim , who conducted bonn ' s stadtisches orchester on the following evening , made one more conscious of the process of interpretation .	141.31583
herr wangenheim has only recently become the city ' s music director , and is a young man with a clear flair for the podium .	57.731518
but he weighted the eighth symphony , at times , with a shuddering subjectivity which seemed considerably at odds with the music .	91.20291
he might have been hoping , to all appearances , that this relatively sunny symphony , in conjunction with the choral fantasy at the end of the program , could amount to something like the ninth	106.598526
but no amount of head-tossing could make it so .	43.86522
the conductor ' s preoccupation with the business of starting and stopping caused occasional raggedness , as with the first orchestra entrance in the fourth piano concerto , but when he put his deliberations and obsequies aside and let the music move as designed , it did so with plenty of spring .	122.13921
the concerto ' s soloist , hans richter-haaser , played with compensatory ease and economy , though without the consummate plasticity to which we had been treated on the previous evening by herr riefling .	79.07412
his was a burgomaster ' s beethoven , solid and sensible .	101.498764
everybody returned after intermission for the miscellaneous sweepings of the fantasy for piano , chorus , and orchestra in c minor , made up by its composer to fill out one of his programs .	143.29271
the entrance of the stadtisches gesangverein ( bonn ' s civic chorus ) was worth all the waiting , however , as the young rhenish voices finally brought the music to life .	185.90848
the last program of this festival , which during two weeks had sampled most compositional categories , brought the cologne rundfunk-sinfonie-orchester and rundfunkchor to bonn ' s gold-filled hall for a performance of the missa solemnis .	148.74167
a tribe in ancient india believed the earth was a huge tea tray resting on the backs of three giant elephants , which in turn stood on the shell of a great tortoise .	57.18365
but the primitive method of explaining the unknown with what is known bears at least a symbolic resemblance to the methods of modern science .	92.12749
it is the business of cosmologists , the scientists who study the nature and structure of the universe , to try to solve the great cosmic mysteries by using keys that have clicked open other doors .	117.2154
these keys are the working principles of physics , mathematics and astronomy , principles which are then extrapolated , or projected , to explain phenomena of which we have little or no direct knowledge .	128.68008
in the autumn of 1959 , the british broadcasting corporation presented a series of talks by four scientists competent in cosmology .	110.52742
three of these men discussed major theories of the universe while the other acted as a moderator .	94.30593
the participants were professor h . bondi , professor of mathematics at king ' s college , london	80.58206
dr . w . b . bonnor , reader in mathematics at queen elizabeth college , london	117.155334
dr . r . a . lyttleton , a lecturer at st . john ' s college , cambridge , and a reader in theoretical astronomy at the university of cambridge	36.930405
and dr . g . j . whitrow , reader in applied mathematics at the imperial college of science and technology , london .	107.74663
the programs were so well received by the british public that the arguments have been published in a totally engrossing little book called , `` rival theories of cosmology ' ' .	92.40779
dr . bonnor begins with a discussion of the relativistic theories of the universe , based on the general theory of relativity .	47.94367
first of all , and this has been calculated by observation , the universe is expanding -- that is , the galaxies are receding from each other at immense speeds .	86.430664
because of this dr . bonnor holds that the universe is becoming more thinly populated by stars and whatever else is there .	72.13499
