this expansion has been going on for an estimated eight billion years .	70.84113
dr . bonnor supports the idea that the universe both expands and contracts , that in several billion years the expansion will slow up and reverse itself and that the contraction will set in .	134.30907
then , after many more billions of years , when all the galaxies are whistling toward a common center , this movement will slow down and reverse itself again .	145.70154
he supports the steady-state theory which holds that matter is continually being created in space .	182.65326
for this reason , he says , the density of the universe always remains the same even though the galaxies are zooming away in all directions .	168.58072
new galaxies are forever being formed to fill in the gaps left by the receding galaxies .	154.85114
if this is true , then the universe today looks just as it did millions of years ago and as it will look millions of years hence , even though the universe is expanding .	149.82173
for new galaxies to be created , professor bondi declares , it would only be necessary for a single hydrogen atom to be created in an area the size of your living room once every few million years .	85.92317
he contends this idea doesn ' t conflict with experiments on which the principle of conservation of matter and energy is based because some slight error must be assumed in such experiments .	212.80157
dr . lyttleton backs the theory that we live in an electric universe and this theory starts with the behavior of protons and electrons .	124.36594
protons and electrons bear opposite electrical charges which make them attract each other , and when they are joined they make up an atom of hydrogen -- the basic building block of matter .	135.776
the charges of the electron and proton are believed to be exactly equal and opposite , but dr . lyttleton is not so sure .	111.82085
suppose , says dr . lyttleton , the proton has a slightly greater charge than the electron ( so slight it is presently immeasurable ) .	171.9498
this would give the hydrogen atom a slight charge-excess .	29.429934
now if one hydrogen atom were placed at the surface of a large sphere of hydrogen atoms , it would be subject both to the gravitation of the sphere and the charge-excess of all those atoms in the sphere .	54.177162
because electrical forces ( the charge-excess ) are far more powerful than gravitation , the surface hydrogen atoms would shoot away from the sphere .	83.275185
dr . lyttleton then imagines the universe as a large hydrogen sphere with surface atoms shooting away from it .	135.50293
this , he claims , would reasonably account for the expansion of the universe .	30.174608
this slim book , while giving the reader only a fleeting glimpse of the scientific mind confronting the universe , has the appeal that informed conversation always has .	132.08255
several photographs and charts of galaxies help the non-scientist keep up with the discussion , and the smooth language indicates the contributors were determined to avoid the jargon that seems to work its way into almost every field .	132.44633
it is clear from this discussion that cosmologists of every persuasion look hopefully toward the day when a man-made satellite can be equipped with optical devices which will open up new vistas to science .	125.31016
presently , the intense absorption of ultra-violet rays in the earth ' s atmosphere seriously hinders ground observation .	119.26339
these scientists are convinced that a telescope unclouded by the earth ' s gases will go a long way toward bolstering or destroying cosmic theories .	111.592384
there would seem to be some small solace in the prospect that the missile race between nations is at the same time accelerating the study of the space around us , giving us a long-sought ladder from which to peer at alien regions .	78.22778
in doing away with the tea tray , the elephants and the giant tortoise , science has developed a series of rationally defensible explanations of the cosmos .	47.31753
and although the universe may forever defy understanding , it might even now be finding its match in the imagination of man .	111.07319
`` roots ' ' , the new play at the brand-new mayfair theater on 46th st . which has been made over from a night club , is about the intellectual and spiritual awakening of an english farm girl .	117.26487
highly successful in england before its transfer to new york , most of `` roots ' ' is as relentlessly dour as the trappings of the small new theater are gaudy .	78.344734
only in its final scene , where beatie bryant ( mary doyle ) shakes off the disappointment of being jilted by her intellectual lover and proclaims her emancipation do we get much which makes worthwhile the series of boorish rustic happenings we have had to watch for most of the first two and one-half acts .	111.03104
the burden of mr . wesker ' s message is that people living close to the soil ( at least in england ) are not the happy , fine , strong , natural , earthy people city-bred intellectuals imagine .	207.41736
rather they are genuine clods , proud of their cloddishness and openly antagonistic to the illuminating influences of aesthetics or thought .	116.60509
they care no more for politics , says mr . wesker , than they do for a symphony .	122.48156
seeming to have roots in the soil , they actually have none in life .	204.72188
they dwell , in short , in the doltish twilight in which peasants and serfs of the past are commonly reported to have lived .	204.96304
but this is a theme which does not take so much time to state as mr . wesker dedicates to it .	138.77179
so much untidiness of mind and household does not attract the interest of the theatergoer ( unless he has been living in a gilded palace , perhaps , and wants a real big heap of contrast ) .	95.78322
the messy meals , the washing of dishes , the drying of clothes may be realism , but there is such a thing as redundancy .	51.12086
miss doyle as beatie has a great fund of animal spirits , a strong voice and a warm smile .	101.137726
she is just home from a sojourn in london where she has become the sweetheart of a young fellow named ronnie ( we never do see him ) and has been subjected to a first course in thinking and appreciating , including a dose of good british socialism .	142.87708
but while she is able to tell her retarded family about the new world she has seen open before her , ronnie has not been able to observe her progress , and instead of appearing at a family party to be looked over like a new bull , he sends beatie a letter of dismissal .	145.24129
beatie , getting no sympathy for her misfortune , soon rallies and finds that although she has lost a lover she has gained her freedom .	91.10112
despite a too long sustained declamatory flight , this final speech is convincing , and we see why british audiences apparently were impressed by `` roots ' ' .	133.63536
there were several fairly good minor portraits in the play , including william hansen ' s impersonation of a stubborn , rather pathetic father , and katherine squire ' s vigorous characterization of a farm mother who brooked no hifalutin ' nonsense from her daughter , or anyone else .	92.828316
but i am afraid mr . wesker ' s meat and potatoes dish isn ' t well seasoned enough for local audiences .	65.98138
shakespeare had a word for everything , even for the rain that disrupted wednesday night ' s `` much ado about nothing ' ' opening the season of free theatre in central park .	59.975258
the new york shakespeare festival , which is using the wollman memorial skating rink while its theatre near the belvedere is being completed , began bravely .	183.58415
joseph papp , impassioned founder of the festival and director of `` much ado ' ' , had a vibrant , colorful production under way .	166.83961
using a wide stage resourcefully he mingled music and dance with shakespeare ' s words in a spirited mixture .	33.13713
the audience filled all the seats inside the wollman enclosure and overflowed onto the lawns outside the fence .	50.81459
the barbed sallies of beatrice and benedick , so contemporary to a public inured to the humor of insult , raised chuckles .	173.58298
the simple-minded comedy of dogberry and verges , also familiar in a day that responds easily to jokes skimmed off the top of writers ' heads , evoked laughter .	171.86838
the vivacity of the masquers ' party at leonato ' s palace , with the spanish motif in the music and dancing in honor of the visiting prince of arragon , cast a spell of delight .	118.25895
as `` much ado ' ' turned serious while the insipid claudio rejected hero at the altar , a sprinkle began to fall .	271.74216
at first hardly a person in the audience moved , although some umbrellas were opened .	110.44518
but the rain came more heavily , and men and women in light summer clothes began to depart .	194.82661
the grieving hero and her father , leonato , followed by the friar , left the stage .	127.49599
a voice on the loudspeaker system announced that if the rain let up the performance would resume in ten minutes .	181.79929
some remained in the wollman enclosure , fortified with raincoats or with newspapers to cover their heads .	121.56549
others huddled under the trees outside the fence .	8.273468
twenty minutes after the interruption , although it was still raining , the play was resumed at the point in the fourth act where it had been stopped .	48.378532
beatrice ( nan martin ) and benedick ( j . d . cannon ) took their places on the stage .	75.293015
in their very first speeches it was clear that shakespeare , like a nostradamus , had foreseen this moment .	115.55414
said benedick `` lady beatrice , have you wept all this while ' ' ? ?	73.544014
replied beatrice `` yea , and i will weep a while longer ' ' .	76.872475
the heavens refused to give up their weeping .	4.5084534
the gallant company completed act 4 , and got through part of act 5 .	381.17963
but the final scenes could not be played .	19.459078
if any among the hardy hundreds who sat in the downpour are in doubt about how it comes out , let them take comfort .	181.56963
the parks department has done an admirable job of preparing the wollman rink for shakespeare .	56.65988
one could hardly blame newbold morris , the parks commissioner , for devoting so much grateful mention to the department ' s technicians who at short notice provided the stage with its rising platforms , its balcony , its generous wings and even its impressive trapdoors for the use of the villains .	155.1143
eldon elder , who designed the stage , also created a gay , spacious set that blended attractively with the park background and shakespeare ' s lighthearted mood .	135.97672
mr . papp has directed a performance that has verve and pace , although he has tolerated obvious business to garner easy laughs where elegance and consistency of style would be preferable .	91.00438
elisabeth schwarzkopf sang so magnificently saturday night at hunter college that it seems a pity to have to register any complaints .	138.26288
still a demurrer or two must be entered .	19.74364
for style and assurance , for a supreme and regal bearing there is still no one who can touch her .	116.45917
if the voice is just a shade less glorious than it used to be , it is still a beautiful instrument , controlled and flexible .	77.154724
put to the service of lieder of schubert , brahms , strauss and wolf in a dramatical and musical way , it made its effect with ease and precision .	142.04019
but what has been happening recently might be described as creeping mannerism .	106.51384
instead of her old confidence in the simplest , purest , most moving musical expression , miss schwarzkopf is letting herself be tempted by the classic sin of artistic pride -- that subtle vanity that sometimes misleads a great artist into thinking that he or she can somehow better the music by bringing to it something extra , some personal dramatic touch imposed from the outside .	203.24112
clever light songs were overly coy , tragic songs a little too melodramatic .	81.35965
there was an extra pause here , a gasp or a sigh there , here and there an extra little twist of a word or note , all in the interest of effect .	169.17026
the result was like that of a beautiful painting with some of the highlights touched up almost to the point of garishness .	226.92827
there were stunning musical phrases too , and sometimes the deepest kind of musical and poetic absorption and communication .	194.74478
miss schwarzkopf and her excellent pianist , john wustman , often achieved the highest lyrical ideals of the lieder tradition .	67.12351
all the more reason why there should have been no place for the frills	43.758236
miss schwarzkopf is too great an artist to need them .	180.87943
the dance , dancers and dance enthusiasts ( 8 , 500 of them ) had a much better time of it at lewisohn stadium on saturday night than all had had two nights earlier , when stadium concerts presented the first of two dance programs .	115.555016
on saturday , the orchestra was sensibly situated down on the field , the stage floor was apparently in decent condition for dancing , and the order of the program improved .	94.799034
there was , additionally , a bonus for the saturday-night patrons .	95.63331
alvin ailey and carmen de lavallade appeared in the first new york performance of mr . ailey ' s `` roots of the blues ' ' , a work given its premiere three weeks ago at the boston arts festival .	50.904324
otherwise , the program included , as on thursday , the taras-tchaikovsky `` design for strings ' ' , the dollar-britten `` divertimento ' ' , the dollar-de banfield `` the duel ' ' and the pas de deux from `` the nutcracker ' ' .	60.25124
maria tallchief and erik bruhn , who danced the `` nutcracker ' ' pas de deux , were also seen in the petipa-minkus pas de deux from `` don quixote ' ' , another brilliant showpiece that displayed their technical prowess handsomely .	47.860767
among the other solo ballet dancers of the evening , elisabeth carroll and ivan allen were particularly impressive in their roles in `` the duel ' ' , a work that depends so much upon the precision and incisiveness of the two principal combatants .	87.87081
mr . ailey ' s `` roots of the blues ' ' , an earthy and very human modern dance work , provided strong contrast to the ballet selections of the evening .	65.12955
as brother john sellers sang five `` blues ' ' to the guitar and drum accompaniments of bruce langhorne and shep shepard , mr . ailey and miss de lavallade went through volatile dances that were by turns insinuating , threatening , contemptuous and ecstatic .	71.920494
their props were two stepladders , a chair and a palm fan .	51.52242
he wore the clothes of a laborer , and she was wondrously seductive in a yellow and orange dress .	93.3806
the cat-like sinuousness and agility of both dancers were exploited in leaps , lifts , crawls and slides that were almost invariably compelling in a work of strong , sometimes almost frightening , tensions .	129.97417
`` roots of the blues ' ' may not be for gentle souls , but others should welcome its super-charged impact .	155.34236
`` perhaps it is better to stay at home .	9.494189
the armchair traveler preserves his illusions ' ' .	1.7371914
this somewhat cynical comment may be found in `` blue skies , brown studies ' ' , a collection of travel essays by william sansom , who would never consider staying home for long .	56.50076
mr . sansom is english , bearded , formidably cultivated , the versatile author of numerous volumes of short stories , of novels and of pieces that are neither short stories nor travel articles but something midway between .	334.51578
the only man alive who seems qualified by his learning , his disposition and his addiction to a baroque luxuriance of language to inherit the literary mantle of sacheverell sitwell , mr . sansom writes of foreign parts with a dedication to decoration worthy of a pastry chef creating a wedding cake for the marriage of a hungarian beauty ( her third ) and an american multimillionaire ( his fourth ) .	134.49973
the result is rather wonderful , but so rich as to be indigestible if taken in too thick slices .	227.8649
there are sixteen essays in `` blue skies , brown studies ' ' .	18.34005
most of them were written between 1953 and 1960 and originally appeared in various magazines .	119.33603
but , even if mr . sansom labors too hard to extract more refinements of meaning and feeling from his travel experiences than the limits of language allow , he still can charm and astound .	342.56927
too many books and articles are just assembled by putting one word after another .	163.20459
mr . sansom actually writes his with a nice ear for a gracefully composed sentence , with an intense relish in all the metaphorical resources of english , with a thick shower of sophisticated , cultural references .	121.1239
`` i like to sniff a place , and reproduce what it really smells and looks like , its color , its particular kind of life ' ' .	139.90862
this is an exact description of what mr . sansom does .	68.98615
he only rarely tells a personal anecdote and hardly ever sketches an individual or quotes his opinions .	225.95691
it is an over-all impression mr . sansom strives for , an impression compounded of visual details , of a savory mixture of smells , of much loving attention to architecture and scenery , of lights and shadows , of intangibles of atmosphere and of echoes of the past .	147.21986
william sansom writes only about europe in this book and frequently of such familiar places as london , vienna , the french riviera and the norwegian fjords .	132.74602
but no matter what he writes about he brings to his subject his own original mind and his own sensitive reactions .	92.29603
`` a writer lives , at best , in a state of astonishment ' ' , he says .	34.835983
`` beneath any feeling he has of the good or the evil of the world lies a deeper one of wonder at it all .	154.29274
to transmit that feeling he writes ' ' .	2.5773873
this may not be true of many writers , but it certainly is true of mr . sansom .	51.09509
so in these pages one can share his wonder at the traditional fiesta of st . torpetius that still persists in st . tropez	279.47693
at the sun and the heat of mediterranean lands , always much brighter and hotter to an englishman than to an american used to summers in new york or kansas city	160.54652
at the supreme delights to be found in one of the world ' s finest restaurants , la bonne auberge , which is situated on the seacoast twenty miles west of the nice airport	60.71401
mr . sansom can be eloquent in a spectacular way which recalls ( to those who recall easily ) the statues of bernini and the gigantic paintings of tintoretto .	112.57267
he can coin a neat phrase `` a street spattered with an invigoration of people ' '	57.7663
tulips with `` petals wide and shaggy as a spaniel ' s ears ' '	12.38658
after a snowstorm a landscape smelling `` of woodsmoke and clarity ' ' .	53.725185
and , for all his lacquered , almost byzantine self-consciousness , he can make one recognize the aptness of an unexpected comparison .	64.27427
in one of his best essays mr . sansom expresses his enthusiasm for the many country mansions designed by andrea palladio himself that dot the environs of vicenza .	136.4147
how far that pedimented and pillared style has shed its influence mr . sansom reminds us thus	392.62564
`` the white colonnaded , cedar-roofed southern mansion is directly traceable via the grey and buff stone of grey-skied england to the golden stucco of one particular part of the blue south , the palladian orbit stretching out from vicenza the old mind of andrea palladio still smiles from behind many an old rocking chair on a southern porch , the deep friezes of his architectonic music rise firm above the shallower freeze in the kitchen , his feeling for light and shade brings a glitter from a tall mint julep , his sense of columns framing the warm velvet night has brought together a million couple of mating lips ' ' .	153.48204
`` blue skies , brown studies ' ' is illustrated with numerous excellent photographs .	77.143906
in recent days there have been extensive lamentations over the absence of original drama on television , but not for years have many regretted the passing of new plays on radio .	155.85266
wbai , the listener-supported outlet on the frequency-modulation band , has decided to do what it can to correct this aural void .	111.55722
yesterday it offered `` poised for violence ' ' , by jean reavey .	31.523098
wbai is on the right track in the sound medium there has been excessive emphasis on music and news and there could and should be a place for theatre , as the canadian and british broadcasting corporations continue to demonstrate .	146.15752
unfortunately , `` poised for violence ' ' was not the happiest vehicle with which to make the point .	140.6784
mrs . reavey ' s work is written for the stage -- it is mentioned for an off-broadway production in the fall -- and , in addition , employs an avant-garde structure that particularly needs to be seen if comprehension is to be encouraged .	152.93633
the play ' s device is to explore society ' s obsession with disaster and violence through the eyes of a group of artist ' s models who remain part of someone else ' s painting rather than just be themselves .	116.899925
in a succession of scenes they appear in different guises -- patrons of a cafe , performers in a circus and participants in a family picnic -- but in each instance they inevitably put ugliness before beauty .	127.25965
somewhere in mrs . reavey ' s play there is both protest and aspiration of merit .	96.51701
but its relentless discursiveness and determined complexity are so overwhelming that after an hour and a half a listener ' s stamina begins to wilt .	125.738594
moreover , her central figures are so busily fulfilling their multitudinous assignments that none emerges as an arresting individual in his own right or as a provocative symbol of mankind ' s ills .	104.55383
but quite conceivably an altogether different impression will obtain when the work is offered in the theatre and there can be other effects to relieve the burden on the author ' s words .	115.921364
which in itself is an immediate reward of the wbai experiment	1202.8335
good radio drama has its own special demands that badly need reinvigoration .	301.46027
a weekly showcase for contemporary music , from the austere archaism of stravinsky to the bleeps and bloops of electronic music , is celebrating its fourth anniversary this month .	108.24371
titled `` what ' s new in music ' ' ? ?	4.303326
the enterprising program is heard saturday afternoons on radio station aj .	203.88504
the brief notes introducing each work offer salient historical or technical points , and many listeners are probably grateful for being intelligently taken by the hand through an often difficult maze .	141.12393
the show is programed and written by the station ' s assistant continuity editor , chuck briefer .	86.079414
the first saturday in each month is set aside for new recordings .	104.646706
last saturday ' s interesting melange included ernst toch , karlheinz stockhausen , richard yardumian and a brief excerpt from a new `` space ' ' opera by the swedish composer , karl-birger blomdahl .	71.10705
other saturdays are devoted to studies of a selected american composer , a particular type of music or the music of a given country .	163.33725
it is commendable that a regularly scheduled hour is set aside for an introduction to the contemporary musical scene .	128.42766
but one wishes , when the appetite is whetted , as it was in the case of the all-too-brief excerpt from the blomdahl opera , that further opportunity would be provided both for hearing the works in their entirety and for a closer analytical look at the sense and nature of the compositions .	202.31067
the moiseyev dance company dropped in at madison square garden last night for the first of four farewell performances before it brings its long american tour to a close .	60.440666
it is not simply giving a repetition of the program it gave during its new york engagement earlier this season , but has brought back many of the numbers that were on the bill when it paid us its first visit and won everybody ' s heart .	161.9787
it is good to see those numbers again .	10.172054
the `` suite of old russian dances ' ' that opened that inaugural program with the slow and modest entrance of the maidens and built steadily into typical moiseyev vigor and warmth	109.22755
the amusing `` yurochka ' ' , in which a hard-to-please young man is given his come-uppance	312.26096
the lovely ( and of course vigorous ) `` polyanka ' ' or `` the meadow ' '	23.760614
the three moldavian dances entitled `` zhok ' '	1.0676093
the sweet and funny little dance about potato planting called `` bul ' ba ' '	34.983578
and the hilarious picture of social life in an earlier day called `` city quadrille ' ' are all just as good as one remembers them to have been , and they are welcome back .	112.277985
so , for that matter , are the newer dances -- the `` kalmuk dance ' ' with its animal movements , that genial juggling act by sergei tsvetkov called `` the platter ' ' , the rousing and beautiful betrothal celebration called `` summer ' ' , `` the three shepherds ' ' of azerbaijan hopping up on their staffs , and , of course , the trenchant `` rock ' n ' roll ' ' .	85.955055
as autumn starts its annual sweep , few americans and canadians realize how fortunate they are in having the world ' s finest fall coloring .	161.64938
spectacular displays of this sort are relatively rare in the entire land surface of the earth .	43.61733
the only other regions so blessed are the british isles , western europe , eastern china , southern chile and parts of japan , new zealand and tasmania .	53.708088
their autumn tints are all fairly low keyed compared with the fiery stabs of crimson , gold , purple , bronze , blue and vermilion that flame up in north america .	132.15085
jack frost is not really responsible for this great seasonal spectacle	199.60178
in fact , a freezing autumn dulls the blaze .	35.066605
the best effects come from a combination of temperate climate and plenty of late-summer rain , followed by sunny days and cool nights .	146.66515
foliage pilgrimages , either organized or individual , are becoming an autumn item for more and more americans each year .	212.05838
below is a specific guide , keyed to the calendar .	120.29138
late september finds quebec ' s color at its peak , especially in the laurentian hills and in the area south of the st . lawrence river .	71.73288
in the maritime provinces farther east , the tones are a little quieter .	232.98943
ontario ' s foliage is most vivid from about sept . 23 to oct . 10 , with both muskoka ( 100 miles north of toronto ) and haliburton ( 125 miles northwest of toronto ) holding color cavalcades starting sept . 23 .	107.81637
in the canadian rockies , great groves of aspen are already glinting gold .	300.456
vermont ' s sugar maples are scarlet from sept . 25 to oct . 15 , and often hit a height in early october .	61.243202
new hampshire figures its peak around columbus day and boasts of all its hardwoods including the yellow of the birches .	144.60097
the shades tend to be a little softer in the forests that blanket so much of maine .	127.89354
in western massachusetts and northwest connecticut , the berkshires are at their vibrant prime the first week of october .	176.45041
the adirondacks blaze brightest in early october , choice routes being 9n from saratoga up to lake george and 73 and 86 in the lake placid area .	167.84407
farther south in new york there is a heavy haze of color over the catskills in mid-october , notably along routes 23 and 23a .	132.11368
about the same time the alleghenies and poconos in pennsylvania are magnificent -- renovo holds its annual flaming foliage festival on oct . 14 , 15 .	114.019516
new jersey ' s color varies from staccato to pastel all the way from the delaware water gap to cape may .	79.09566
during the first half of october the blue ridge and other parts of the appalachians provide a spectacle stretching from maryland and west virginia to georgia .	64.13552
the most brilliant displays are along the skyline drive above virginia ' s shenandoah valley and throughout the great smokies between north carolina and tennessee .	73.47338
michigan , wisconsin and minnesota have many superb stretches of color which reach their height from the last few days of september well into october , especially in their northern sections , e . g . , wisconsin ' s vilas county whose colorama celebration is sept . 29-oct . 8 .	102.96739
in wisconsin , take route 55 north of shawano or routes 78 and 60 from portage to prairie du chien .	87.888626
in michigan , there is fine color on route 27 up to the mackinac straits , while the views around marquette and iron mountain in the upper peninsula are spectacular .	128.49376
in minnesota , arrowhead county and route 53 north to international falls are outstanding .	179.61127
farther south , there are attractive patches all the way to the ozarks , with some seasonal peaks as late as early november .	99.933655
illinois ' shawnee national forest , missouri ' s iron county and the maples of hiawatha , kan . should be at their best in mid-october .	125.262245
the rockies have many `` aspencades ' ' , which are organized tours of the aspen areas with frequent stops at vantage points for viewing the golden panoramas .	149.30183
in colorado , ouray has its fall color week sept . 22-29 , rye and salida both sponsor aspencades sept . 24 , and steamboat springs has a week-long aspencade sept . 25-30 .	161.18265
new mexico ' s biggest is at ruidoso oct . 7 , 8 , while alamogordo and cloudcroft cooperate in similar trips oct . 1 .	91.639496
two sharply contrasting places designed for public enjoyment are now on display .	171.97758
the corn palace at mitchell , s . dak . , `` the world ' s corniest building ' ' , has a carnival through sept . 23 headlining the three stooges and pee wee hunt .	80.821724
since 1892 ears of red , yellow , purple and white corn have annually been nailed to 11 big picture panels to create huge `` paintings ' ' .	230.6547
the 1961 theme is the dakota territorial centennial , with the pictures including the lewis and clark expedition , the first river steamboat , the 1876 gold rush , a little red schoolhouse on the prairie , and today ' s construction of large missouri river reservoirs .	94.34488
the panels will stay up until they are replaced next summer .	142.57674
longwood gardens , near kennett square , pa . ( about 12 miles from wilmington , del . ) , was developed and heavily endowed by the late pierre s . du pont .	60.003548
every wednesday night through oct . 11 there will be an elaborate colored fountain display , with 229 nozzles throwing jets of water up to 130 feet .	60.67468
the `` peacock tail ' ' nozzle throws a giant fan of water 100 feet wide and 40 feet high .	64.46457
the gardens themselves are open free of charge the year round , and the 192 permanent employes make sure that not a dead or wilted flower is ever seen indoors or out by any visitor .	190.4916
carson mccullers , after a long , painful illness that might have crushed a less-indomitable soul , has come back with an absolute gem of a novel which jumped high on best-seller lists even before official publication .	157.62823
though the subject -- segregation in her native south -- has been thoroughly worked , miss mccullers uses her poet ' s instinct and storyteller ' s skill to reaffirm her place at the very top of modern american writing .	95.74071
with an art that almost conceals art , j . d . salinger can create a fictional world so authentic that it hurts .	77.277626
here , in the most eagerly awaited novel of the season ( his first since the catcher in the rye , ) he tells of a college girl in flight from the life around her and the tart but sympathetic help she gets from her 25-year-old brother .	178.25296
a deft , hilarious satire on very high french society involving a statesman with two enviable possessions , a lovely young bride and a head containing such weighty thoughts that he has occasionally to remove it for greater comfort .	114.32777
there is probably a moral in all this about `` mind vs . heart ' ' .	114.42932
virgilia peterson , a critic by trade , has turned her critical eye pitilessly and honestly on herself in an autobiography more of the mind and heart than of specific events .	188.02728
it is an engrossing commentary on a repressive , upper-middle-class new york way of life in the first part of this century .	52.868958
this retelling by louis zara of the brief , anguished life of stephen crane -- poet and master novelist at 23 , dead at 28 -- is in novelized form but does not abuse its tragic subject .	182.85596
subtitled a farmwife ' s almanac of country living , this is a gentle and nostalgic chronicle of the changing seasons seen through the clear , humorous eye of a hoosier housewife and popular columnist .	141.22954
two noted troupes from overseas will get the fall dance season off to a sparkling start .	166.53297
leningrad ' s kirov ballet , famous for classic purity of technique , begins its first u . s . tour in new york ( through sept . 30 ) .	42.419987
the bayanihan philippine dance company , with music and dances that depict the many facets of filipino culture , opens its 60-city u . s . tour in san francisco ( through sept . 24 ) then , via one-night stands , moves on to los angeles ( sept . 29 thru oct . 1 ) .	51.51455
with harvests in full swing , you can enjoy festivals for grapes at sonoma , calif . ( sept . 22-24 ) , as well as for cranberries at bandon , ore . ( sept . 28 thru oct . 1 ) , for buckwheat at kingwood , w . va . ( sept . 28-30 ) , sugar cane at new iberia , la . ( sept . 29 thru oct . 1 ) and tobacco at richmond , va . ( sept . 23-30 ) .	57.516674
the mule is honored at benson , n . c . ( sept . 22 , 23 ) and at boron , calif . ( sept . 24 thru oct . 1 ) , while the legend of the maid of the mist is celebrated at niagara falls through the 24th .	40.03145
the fine old mansions of u . s . grant ' s old home town of galena , ill . are open for inspection ( sept . 23 , 24 ) .	67.89587
an archery tournament will be held at north falmouth , mass . ( sept . 23 , 24 ) .	60.06229
the 300th anniversaries of staten island ( through sept . 23 ) and of mamaroneck , n . y . ( through sept . 24 ) will both include parades and pageants .	25.581165
this french film , set in italy , is a summertime splurge in shock and terror all shot in lovely sunny scenery -- so breath-taking that at times you almost forget the horrors the movie is dealing with .	306.73132
but slowly they take over as alain delon ( life , sept . 15 ) , playing a sometimes appealing but always criminal boy , casually tells a rich and foot-loose american that he is going to murder him , then does it even while the american is trying to puzzle out how delon expects to profit from the act .	197.91656
callas devotees will have good reason to do their customary cart wheels over a new and complete stereo version of the bellini opera .	61.412205
maria goes all out as a druid princess who gets two-timed by a roman big shot .	241.76636
by turns , her beautifully sung norma is fierce , tender , venomous and pitiful .	67.89856
the tenor lead , franco corelli , and la scala cast under maestro tullio serafin are all first rate .	224.71075
jeremiah peabody ' s polyunsaturated quick dissolving fast acting pleasant tasting green and purple pills .	120.31726
in a raucous take-off on radio commercials , singer ray stevens hawks a cure-all for neuritis , neuralgia , head-cold distress , beriberi , overweight , fungus , mungus and water on the knee .	78.991104
of the nation ' s eight million pleasure-boat owners a sizable number have learned that late autumn is one of the loveliest seasons to be afloat -- at least in that broad balmy region that lies below america ' s belt line .	194.26953
waterways are busy right now from the virginia capes to the texas coast .	210.3358
there true yachtsmen often find november winds steadier , the waters cooler , the fish hungrier , and rivers more pleasant -- less turbulence and mud , and fewer floating logs .	55.801807
more and more boats move overland on wheels ( 1 . 8 million trailers are now in use ) and midwesterners taking long weekends can travel south with their craft .	176.37514
in the southwest , the fall brings out flotillas of boatsmen who find the summer too hot for comfort .	323.1912
and on northern shores indomitable sailors from long island to lake michigan will beat around the buoys in dozens of frostbite races .	81.54426
some pleasant fall cruising country is mapped out below .	310.55066
pleasure boating is just scooting into its best months in california as crisp breezes bring out craft of every size on every kind of water -- ocean , lake and reservoir .	184.98389
shore facilities are enormous -- los angeles harbors 5 , 000 boats , and long beach 3 , 000 -- but marinas are crowded everywhere .	161.07185
new docks and ramps are being rushed at playa del rey , ventura , dana point , oceanside and mission bay .	125.76917
inland , outboard motorists welcome cooler weather and the chance to buzz over colorado river sandbars and lake mead .	83.98814
newest small-boat playground is the salton sea , a once-dry desert sinkhole which is now a salty lake 42 miles long and 235 feet below sea level .	171.98653
on nov . 11 , 12 , racers will drive their flying shingles in 5-mile laps over its 500-mile speedboat course .	172.60484
in san francisco bay , winds are gusty and undependable during this season .	170.19084
a sailboat may have a bone in her teeth one minute and lie becalmed the next .	212.81871
but regattas are scheduled right up to christmas .	7.0519238
the corinthian yacht club in tiburon launches its winter races nov . 5 .	73.79226
hurricane carla damaged 70% of the marinas in the galveston-port aransas area but fuel service is back to normal , and explorers can roam as far west as port isabel on the mexican border .	274.5289
sailing activity is slowed down by texas northers , but power cruisers can move freely , poking into the san jacinto , trinity and brazos rivers ( fine tarpon fishing in the brazos ) or pushing eastward to the pirate country of barataria .	163.46854
off grand isle , yachters often visit the towering oil rigs .	69.035904
the mississippi sound leads into a protected waterway running about 200 miles from pascagoula to apalachicola .	125.31326
memphis stinkpotters like mckellar lake , inside the city limits , and sailors look for autumn winds at arkabutla lake where fall racing is now in progress .	294.47232
river cruising for small craft is ideal in november .	181.76375
at new orleans , 25-mile-square lake pontchartrain has few squalls and year-long boating .	219.30655
marinas are less plush than the florida type but service is good and creole cooking better .	278.7149
ten thousand twisty miles of shoreline frame the 30-odd lakes in the vast tennessee river system that loops in and out of seven states .	109.713684
when dam construction began in 1933 , fewer than 600 boats used these waters	389.06766
a year ago it was bruited that the primary character in erich maria remarque ' s new novel was based on the marquis alfonso de portago , the spanish nobleman who died driving in the mille miglia automobile race of 1957 .	79.41402
if this was in fact mr . remarque ' s intention he has achieved a notable failure .	58.189556
clerfayt of `` heaven has no favorites ' ' resembles portago only in that he is male and a race-driver -- quite a bad race-driver , whereas portago was a good one .	110.23934
he is a dull , unformed , and aimless person	686.4316
the twelfth marquis de portago was intelligent , purposeful , and passionate .	47.95517
one looked forward to mr . remarque ' s ninth book if only because not even a reasonably good novel has yet been written grounded on automobile racing , as dramatic a sport as mankind has devised .	207.51817
unhappily , `` heaven has no favorites ' ' does not alter the record except to add one more bad book to the list .	108.71521
mr . remarque ' s conception of this novel was sound and perhaps even noble .	304.54233
he proposed throwing together a man in an occupation of high hazard and a woman balanced on a knife-edge between death from tuberculosis and recovery .	362.00735
his heroine chooses to die -- the price of recovery , years under the strict regimen of a sanatorium , being higher than she wishes to pay .	131.56743
her lover precedes her in death , at the wheel , and presumably he too has chosen .	158.91174
between the first meeting of clerfayt and lillian and this dismal denouement , mr . remarque has laid down many pages of junior-philosophical discourse , some demure and rather fetching love-making , pleasant talk about some of the countryside and restaurants of europe , and a modicum of automobile racing .	207.41776
the ramblings on life , death , and the wonder of it all are distressing	199.74896
the love-making , perhaps because it is pale and low-key when one has been conditioned to expect harsh colors and explicitness , is often charming	173.4923
the automobile racing bears little relation to reality .	4.0536947
this latter failure is more than merely bad reportage and it is distinctly more important than it would have been had the author drawn clerfayt as , say , a tournament golfer .	140.4015
hazards to life and limb on the golf course , while existent , are actuarially insignificant .	108.1296
race-drivers , on the other hand , are quite often killed on the circuit , and since it was obviously mr . remarque ' s intention to establish automobile racing as life in microcosm , one might reasonably have expected him to demonstrate precise knowledge not only of techniques but of mores and attitudes .	129.96191
the jacket biography describes him as a former racing driver , and he may indeed have been , although i do not recall having encountered his name either in the records or the literature .	129.95384
perhaps he has only forgotten a great deal .	18.226366
the book carries a disclaimer in which remarque says it has been necessary for him to take minor liberties with some of the procedures and formalities of racing .	86.8042
the necessity is not clear to me , and , in any case , to present a case-hardened race-driver as saying he has left his car , which , or whom , he calls `` giuseppe ' ' , parked `` on the place vendome sneering at a dozen bentleys and rolls-royces parked around him ' ' is not a liberty	89.52904
but it is in the matter of preoccupation with death , which is the primary concern of the book , that remarque ' s failure is plainest .	59.372707
clerfayt is neurotic , preoccupied , and passive .	21.771498
to be human , he believes , is to seek one ' s own destruction the freudian `` death-wish ' ' cliche inevitably cited whenever laymen talk about auto race-drivers .	301.7512
in point of fact , the race-drivers one knows are nearly always intelligent , healthy technicians who differ from other technicians only in the depth of the passion they feel for the work by which they live .	224.98402
a clerfayt may moon on about the face of death in the cockpit	61.4944
a portago could say , as he did say to me , `` if i die tomorrow , still i have had twenty-eight wonderful years	221.78452
i ' ll live to be 105 ' ' .	1.6141909
clerfayt , transported , may think of the engine driving his car as `` a mystical beast under the hood ' ' .	64.0443
the italian master piero taruffi , no less sensitive , knows twice the ecstasy though he thinks of a car ' s adhesion to a wet two-lane road at 165 miles an hour as a matter best expressed in algebraic formulae .	150.32889
clerfayt , driving , sees himself `` a volcano whose cone funneled down to hell ' '	45.70149
the briton stirling moss , one of the greatest virtuosi of all time , believes that ultra-fast road-circuit driving is an art form related to ballet .	282.51874
errors in technical terminology suggest that the over-all translation from the german may not convey quite everything mr . remarque hoped to tell us .	124.359886
however , my principal objection in this sort of novel is to the hackneyed treatment of race-drivers , pilots , submariners , atomic researchers , and all the machine-masters of our age as brooding mystics or hysterical fatalists .	103.80026
the west is leaderless , according to this book .	165.35477
in contrast , the east is ably led by such stalwart heroes as khrushchev , tito , and mao .	30.22135
against this invincible determination to communize the whole world stands a group of nations unable to agree on fundamentals and each refusing to make any sacrifice of sovereignty for the common good of all .	126.61025
it is field marshal montgomery ' s belief that in most western countries about 60 per cent of the people do not really care about democracy or christianity	133.94087
about 30 per cent call themselves christians in order to keep up appearances and be considered respectable , and only the last 10 per cent are genuine christians and believers in democracy .	100.7028
but these western countries do care about themselves .	4.147265
if , say , the russians intended to stop tom jones ' going to the pub , then tom jones would fight the commies .	361.99612
but he would fight for his own liberty rather than for any abstract principle connected with it -- such as `` cause ' ' .	109.262856
for all practical purposes , the west stands disunited , undedicated , and unprepared for the tasks of world leadership .	79.24821
with this barrage , montgomery of alamein launches his attack upon the blunderings of the west .	18.629753
never given to mincing words , he places heavy blame upon the faulty , uncourageous leadership of britain and particularly america .	355.3337
at war ' s end leadership in western europe passed from britain because the labour government devoted its attention to the creation of a welfare state .	151.45615
with britain looking inward , overseas problems were neglected and the baton was passed on to the united states .	70.46183
`` america gave generously in economic aid and military equipment to friend and foe alike ' ' .	58.22314
she pushed wartorn and poverty-stricken nations into prosperity , but she failed to lead them into unity and world peace .	104.733765
america has divided more than she has united the west .	61.001793
the reasons are that america generally believes that she can buy anything with dollars , and that she compulsively strives to be liked .	88.05763
however , she really does not know how to match the quantity of dollars given away by a quality of leadership that is basically needed .	347.21133
but the greater reason for fumbling , stumbling american leadership is due to the shock her pride suffered when the japanese attacked at pearl harbor .	284.91672
`` they are determined ' ' , montgomery writes , `` not to be surprised again , and now insist on a state of readiness for war which is not only unnecessary , but also creates nervousness among other nations in the western alliance -- not to mention such great suspicions among the nations of the eastern bloc that any progress towards peaceful coexistence or disarmament is not possible ' ' .	108.532684
the net result is that under american leadership the general world situation has become bad .	226.66072
to `` monty ' ' , the american people , who in two previous world wars were very reluctant to join the fight , `` now look like the nation most likely to lead us all into a third world war ' ' .	82.675095
as faulty as has been our leadership clearly the united states must be relied upon to lead .	26.961758
montgomery calls for a leader who will first put the west ' s own house in order .	84.80401
such a man must be able and willing to give clear and sensible advice to the whole group , a person in whom all the member nations will have absolute confidence .	75.5508
this leader must be a man who lives above illusions that heretofore have shaped the foreign policy of the united states , namely that russia will agree to a reunited germany , that the east german government does not exist , that events in japan in june 1960 were communist-inspired , that the true government of china is in formosa , that mao was the evil influence behind khrushchev at the summit conference in paris in may 1960 , and that either china or russia wants or expects war .	123.86354
such a leader must strengthen nato politically , and establish that true unity about which it has always talked .	213.97241
after drastically overhauling nato , western leadership should turn to reducing the suspicions that tear apart the east and west .	165.50694
major to this effort is to get all world powers to withdraw to their own territories , say by 1970 .	215.96634
but the east would have to show sincerity in carrying it out ' ' .	81.226074
`` but where is the leader who will handle all these things for us ' ' ? ?	43.7105
montgomery knew all the national leaders up to the time of kennedy .	65.538376
the man whom he would select as our leader for this great task is de gaulle .	405.31302
he alone has the wisdom , the conviction , the tenacity , and the courage to reach a decision .	71.53851
but de gaulle is buried in the cause of restoring france ' s lost soul .	32.398693
whoever rises to the occasion walks a treacherous path to leadership .	79.00447
the leader montgomery envisages will need to discipline himself , lead a carefully regulated and orderly life , allow time for quiet thought and reflection , adapt decisions and plans to changing situations , be ruthless , particularly with inefficiency , and be honest and morally proper .	196.5733
all in all , montgomery calls for a leader who will anticipate and dominate the events that surround him .	80.376335
in looking as far back as moses , thence to cromwell , napoleon , lincoln , churchill , and nehru , montgomery attempts to trace the stirrings and qualities of great men .	63.211952
he believes that greatness is a marriage between the man and the times as was aptly represented by churchill , who would very possibly have gone down in history as a political failure if it had not been for hitler ' s war .	103.50301
however , montgomery makes little contribution to leadership theory and practice .	46.090878
most of what is said about his great men of history has already been said , and what has not is largely irrelevant to the contemporary scene .	118.90145
like eisenhower , he holds the militarist ' s suspicion of politicians .	23.92953
however , at the same time montgomery selects as his hero de gaulle , who is a militarist dominated by political ambitions .	66.51042
`` monty ' ' shows a remarkable capacity for the direct statement and an equally remarkable incapacity for giving adequate support .	108.729355
for the most part , his writing rambles and jogs , preventing easy access by the reader to his true thoughts .	143.97797
nevertheless , montgomery has stated courageously and wisely the crisis of the western world .	19.27109
it suffers from a lack of unity of purpose and respect for heroic leadership .	119.19084
and it remains to be seen if the new frontier now taking form can produce the leadership and wisdom necessary to understand the current shape of events .	252.96165
it is no common thing for a listener ( critical or otherwise ) to hear a singer `` live ' ' for the first time only after he has died .	89.78873
but then , mario lanza was no common singer , and his whole career , public and non-public , was studded with the kind of unconventional happenings that terminate with the appearance of his first `` recital ' ' only when he has ceased to be a living voice .	75.54731
it is a kind of justice , too , that it should originate in london ' s royal albert hall , where , traditionally , the loudest , if not the greatest , performers have entertained the thousands it will accommodate ( rca victor lm 2454 , $4 . 98 ) .	80.91485
to be sure , lanza made numerous concert tours , here and abroad , but these did not take him to new york where the carping critic might lurk .	100.84402
the reading public , the theatergoing public , the skindiving public , the horse-playing public -- all these and others fill substantial roles in u . s . life , but none is so varied , vast and vigilant as the eating public .	171.04877
the department of agriculture averaged out u . s . food consumption last year at 1 , 488 lbs . per person , which , allowing for the 17 million americans that john kennedy said go to bed hungry every night , means that certain gluttons on the upper end must somehow down 8 lbs . or more a day .	162.93765
that mother hen of the weight-height tables , the metropolitan life insurance co . , clucks that 48 million americans are overweight .	144.32138
through previous centuries , eating changed by nearly imperceptible degrees , and mostly toward just getting enough .	431.12686
for the first time in history , the u . s . has produced a society in which less than one-tenth of the people turn out so much food that the government ' s most embarrassing problem is how to dispose inconspicuously of 100 million tons of surplus farm produce .	119.18607
in this same society , the plain citizen can with an average of only one-fifth his income buy more calories than he can consume .	201.14818
refrigeration , automated processing and packaging conspire to defy season and banish spoilage .	119.40177
and in the wake of the new affluence and the new techniques of processing comes a new american interest in how what people eat affects their health .	198.58606
to eat is human , the nation is learning to think , to survive divine .	148.01033
not all the concern for health is well directed .	125.59119
from the fusty panaceas of spinach , eggs and prunes , the u . s . has progressed to curds , concentrates and capsules .	52.191593
each year , reports the american medical association , ten million americans spend $900 million on vitamins , tonics and other food supplements .	67.4156
at juice bars in los angeles ' 35 `` health ' ' stores , a new sensation is a pink , high-protein cocktail , concocted of dried eggs , powdered milk and cherry-flavored no-cal , which sells for 59-cents per 8-oz . glass .	114.76729
grocery stores sell dozens of foods that boast of having almost no food value at all .	197.86336
but a big part of the public wants to know facts about diet and health , and a big group of u . s . scientists wants to supply them .	92.37457
the man most firmly at grips with the problem is the university of minnesota ' s physiologist ancel keys , 57 , inventor of the wartime k ( for keys ) ration and author of last year ' s bestselling eat well and stay well .	117.35628
from his birch-paneled office in the laboratory of physiological hygiene , under the university ' s football stadium in minneapolis ( `` we get a rumble on every touchdown ' ' ) , blocky , grey-haired dr . keys directs an ambitious , $200 , 000-a-year experiment on diet , which spans three continents and seven nations and is still growing .	165.8264
pursuing it , he has logged 500 , 000 miles , suffered indescribable digestive indignities , and meticulously collected physiological data on the health and eating habits of 10 , 000 individuals , from bantu tribesmen to italian contadini .	53.05794
he has measured the skinfolds ( the fleshy areas under the shoulder blades ) of neapolitan firemen , studied the metabolism of finnish woodcutters , analyzed the `` mealie-meal ' ' eaten by capetown coloreds , and experimented on minneapolis businessmen .	80.85672
keys ' s findings , though far from complete , are likely to smash many an eating cliche .	241.62735
vitamins , eggs and milk begin to look like foods to hold down on ( though mothers ' milk is still the ticket ) .	161.21608
readings of the number of milligrams of cholesterol in the blood , which seem to have value in predicting heart attacks , are becoming as routine as the electrocardiogram , which can show that the heart has suffered a symptomatic attack .	111.19751
already many an american knows his count , and rejoices or worries depending on whether it is nearer 180 ( safe ) or 250 ( dangerous ) .	185.03885
out of cholesterol come keys ' s main messages so far	287.28516
the typical u . s . daily menu , says dr . keys , contains 3 , 000 calories , should contain 2 , 300 .	69.8766
and extra weight increases the risk of cancer , diabetes , artery disease and heart attack .	50.675785
with meat , milk , butter and ice cream , the calorie-heavy u . s . diet is 40% fat , and most of that is saturated fat -- the insidious kind , says dr . keys , that increases blood cholesterol , damages arteries , and leads to coronary disease .	96.80315
throughout much of the world , food is still so scarce that half of the earth ' s population has trouble getting the 1 , 600 calories a day necessary to sustain life .	202.44305
the deficiency diseases -- scurvy , tropical sprue , pellagra -- run rampant .	56.830273
in west africa , for example , where meat is a luxury and babies must be weaned early to make room at the breast for later arrivals , a childhood menace is kwashiorkor , or `` red johnny ' ' , a growth-stunting protein deficiency ( signs reddish hair , bloated belly ) that kills more than half its victims , leaves the rest prey for parasites and lingering tropical disease .	135.89156
in the well-fed u . s . , deficiency diseases have virtually vanished in the past 20 years .	53.946217
today , as harrison ' s principles of internal medicine , a standard internist ' s text , puts it , `` the most common form of malnutrition is caloric excess or obesity ' ' .	104.49611
puritan new england regarded obesity as a flagrant symbol of intemperance , and thus a sin .	28.236643
says keys `` maybe if the idea got around again that obesity is immoral , the fat man would start to think ' ' .	99.846344
morals aside , the fat man has plenty to worry about -- over and above the fact that no one any longer loves him .	75.580414
the simple mechanical strain of overweight , says new york ' s dr . norman jolliffe , can overburden and damage the heart `` for much the same reason that a chevrolet engine in a cadillac body would wear out sooner than if it were in a body for which it was built ' ' .	149.9639
the fat man has trouble buying life insurance or has to pay higher premiums .	235.78517
he has -- for unclear reasons -- a 25% higher death rate from cancer .	285.9499
he may find even moderate physical exertion uncomfortable , because excess body fat hampers his breathing and restricts his muscular movement .	128.5537
physiologically , people overeat because what dr . jolliffe calls the `` appestat ' ' is set too high .	88.49524
the appestat , which adjusts the appetite to keep weight constant , is located , says jolliffe , in the hypothalamus -- near the body ' s temperature , sleep and water-balance controls .	117.88342
in moderate doses , alcohol narcotizes the appestat and enhances appetite ( the original reason for the cocktail )	154.01555
but because liquor has a high caloric value -- 100 calories per oz . -- the heavy drinker is seldom hungry .	53.75967
in rare cases , diseases such as encephalitis or a pituitary tumor may damage the appestat permanently , destroying nearly all sense of satiety .	140.83829
far more frequently , overeating is the result of a psychological compulsion .	28.099466
it may be fostered by frustration , depression , insecurity -- or , in children , simply by the desire to stop an anxious mother ' s nagging .	107.13072
some families place undue emphasis on food conversations center on it , and rich delicacies are offered as rewards , withheld as punishment .	177.6073
the result says jolliffe `` the child gains the feeling that food is the purpose of life ' ' .	39.656998
food may act as a sedative , giving temporary emotional solace , just as , for some people , alcohol does .	114.27184
reports dr . keys `` a fairly common experience for us is the wife who finds her husband staying out more and more .	111.198044
he may be interested in another woman , or just like being with the boys .	155.0422
so she fishes around in the cupboard and hauls out a chocolate cake .	41.861214
it ' s a matter of boredom , and the subconscious feeling that she is entitled to something , because she ' s being deprived of something else ' ' .	58.742783
for the army of compulsive eaters -- from the nibblers and the gobblers to the downright gluttons -- reducing is a war with the will that is rarely won .	194.96991
physiologist keys flatly dismisses such appetite depressants as the amphetamines ( benzedrine , dexedrine ) as dangerous `` crutches for a weak will ' ' .	72.915054
keys has no such objections to metrecal , quaker oats ' s quota and other 900-calorie milk formulas that are currently winning favor from dieters .	218.44498
`` metrecal is a pretty complete food ' ' , he says .	14.433981
`` it contains large amounts of protein , vitamins and minerals .	14.003046
in the quantity of 900 calories a day , anyone will lose weight on it -- 20 , 30 or 40 lbs . ' ' .	94.75881
but keys worries that the metrecal drinker will never make either the psychological or physiological adjustment to the idea of eating smaller portions of food .	148.69543
despite his personal distaste for obesity ( `` disgusting ' ' ) , dr . keys has only an incidental interest in how much americans eat .	50.6938
what concerns him much more is the relationship of diet to the nation ' s no . 1 killer coronary artery disease , which accounts for more than half of all heart fatalities and kills 500 , 000 americans a year -- twice the toll from all varieties of cancer , five times the deaths from automobile accidents .	87.12956
cholesterol , the cornerstone of dr . keys ' s theory , is a mysterious yellowish , waxy substance , chemically a crystalline alcohol .	73.734436
scientists assume that cholesterol ( from the greek chole , meaning bile , and sterios , meaning solid ) is somehow necessary for the formation of brain cells , since it accounts for about 2% of the brain ' s total solid weight .	120.84682
they know it is the chief ingredient in gallstones .	100.59875
they suspect it plays a role in the production of adrenal hormones , and they believe it is essential to the transport of fats throughout the circulatory system .	76.235634
but they cannot fully explain the process of its manufacture by the human liver .	109.88546
although the fatty protein molecules , carried in the blood and partly composed of cholesterol , are water soluble , cholesterol itself is insoluble , and cannot be destroyed by the body .	139.17099
`` a remarkable substance ' ' , says dr . keys , `` quite apart from its tendency to be deposited in the walls of arteries ' ' .	28.646303
when thus deposited , keys says that cholesterol is mainly responsible for the arterial blockages that culminate in heart attacks .	124.73957
explains keys as the fatty protein molecules travel in the bloodstream , they are deposited in the intima , or inner wall of a coronary artery .	76.505905
the proteins and fats are burned off , and the cholesterol is left behind .	127.376884
as cholesterol piles up , it narrows , irritates and damages the artery , encouraging formation of calcium deposits and slowing circulation .	33.493538
eventually , says keys , one of two things happens .	74.00862
a clot forms at the site , seals off the flow of blood to the heart and provokes a heart attack .	90.33666
or ( more commonly , thinks keys ) the deposits themselves get so big that they choke off the artery ' s flow to the point that an infarct occurs the heart muscle is suffocated , cells supplied by the artery die , and the heart is permanently , perhaps fatally injured .	169.61038
ordinarily , the human liver synthesizes only enough cholesterol to satisfy the body ' s needs -- for transportation of fats and for production of bile .	92.038574
even eggs and other cholesterol-rich foods , eaten in normal amounts , says dr . keys , do not materially affect the amount of cholesterol in the blood .	49.850677
during world war 2 , , doctors in the netherlands and scandinavia noted a curious fact despite the stresses of nazi occupation , the death rate from coronary artery disease was slowly dropping .	256.96054
not until long after the war -- 1950 , in fact -- did they get a hint of the reason .	92.13865
that year , sweden ' s haqvin malmros showed that the sinking death rate neatly coincided with increasingly severe restrictions on fatty foods .	98.827095
that same year the university of california ' s dr . laurance kinsell , timing oxidation rates of blood fats , stumbled onto the discovery that many vegetable fats cause blood cholesterol levels to drop radically , while animal fats cause them to rise .	164.34209
here keys and others , such as dr . a . e . ahrens of the rockefeller institute , took over to demonstrate the chemical difference between vegetable and animal fats -- and even between different varieties of each .	94.65837
all natural food fats fall into one of three categories -- saturated , mono-unsaturated and poly-unsaturated .	40.435677
the degree of saturation depends on the number of hydrogen atoms on the fat molecule .	22.656729
mono-unsaturated fats have room for two more hydrogens on each molecule , and the poly-unsaturated fat molecule has room for at least four hydrogens .	104.81275
the three fats have similar caloric values ( about 265 calories per oz . ) , but each exerts a radically different influence on blood cholesterol .	89.05643
as a result , although we still make use of this distinction , there is much confusion as to the meaning of the basic terms employed .	57.4835
just what is meant by `` spirit ' ' and by `` matter ' ' ? ?	23.826122
the terms are generally taken for granted as though they referred to direct and axiomatic elements in the common experience of all .	125.75203
yet in the contemporary context this is precisely what one must not do .	85.30229
for in the modern world neither `` spirit ' ' nor `` matter ' ' refer to any generally agreed-upon elements of experience .	101.363045
we are in a transitional stage in which many of the connotations of former usage have had to be revised or rejected .	100.70621
when the words are used , we are never sure which of the traditional meanings the user may have in mind , or to what extent his revisions and rejections of former understandings correspond to ours .	147.34412
one of the most widespread features of contemporary thought is the almost universal disbelief in the reality of spirit .	63.87418
just a few centuries ago the world of spirits was as populous and real as the world of material entities .	92.31099
not only in popular thought but in that of the highly educated as well was this true .	130.32202
demons , fairies , angels , and a host of other spiritual beings were as much a part of the experiential world of western man as were rocks and trees and stars .	145.63625
in such a world the words `` matter ' ' and `` spirit ' ' both referred to directly known realities in the common experience of all .	66.54144
in it important elements of christianity and of the biblical view of reality in general , which now cause us much difficulty , could be responded to quite naturally and spontaneously .	133.60332
the progress of science over these last few centuries and the gradual replacement of biblical by scientific categories of reality have to a large extent emptied the spirit world of the entities which previously populated it .	162.84326
in carrying out this program science has undoubtedly performed a very considerable service for which it can claim due credit .	169.65494
the objectification of the world of spirit in popular superstition had certainly gone far beyond what the experience of spirit could justify or support .	262.3661
science is fully competent to deal with any element of experience which arises from an object in space and time .	95.42954
when , therefore , it turned its attention to the concrete entities with which popular imagination had peopled the world of spirit , these entities soon lost whatever status they had enjoyed as actual elements of external reality .	260.54437
in doing so science has unquestionably cleared up widespread misconceptions , removed extraneous and illusory sources of fear , and dispelled many undesirable popular superstitions .	152.8782
there have been , indeed , many important and valuable gains from the development of our present scientific view of the world for which we may be rightly grateful .	73.23633
all this has not , however , been an unmixed blessing .	49.268795
the scientific debunking of the spirit world has been in a way too successful and too thorough .	132.97835
the house has been swept so clean that contemporary man has been left with no means , or at best with wholly inadequate means , for dealing with his experience of spirit .	169.96312
although the particular form of conceptualization which popular imagination had made in response to the experience of spirit was undoubtedly defective , the raw experience itself which led to such excesses remains with us as vividly as ever .	307.60385
we simply find ourselves in the position of having no means for inquiring into the structure and meaning of this range of our experience .	147.70702
there is no framework or structure of thought with respect to which we can organize it and no part of reality , as we know and apprehend it , with respect to which we can refer this experience .	98.20645
science has simply left us helpless and powerless in this important sector of our lives .	49.285984
the situation in which we find ourselves is brought out with dramatic force in arthur miller ' s play the crucible , which deals with the salem witch trials .	136.29454
as the play opens the audience is introduced to the community of salem in puritan america at the end of the eighteenth century .	52.03879
aside from a quaint concern with witches and devils which provides the immediate problem in the opening scene , it is a quite normal community .	62.41093
the conversation of the characters creates an atmosphere suggesting the usual mixture of pleasures , foibles , irritations , and concerns which would characterize the common life of a normal village in any age .	112.92525
there is no occasion to feel uneasy or disturbed about these people .	91.40506
instead , the audience can sit back at ease and , from the perspective of an enlightened time which no longer believes in such things , enjoy the dead seriousness with which the characters in the play take the witches and devils which are under discussion .	133.85417
a teenage girl , abigail williams , is being sharply questioned by her minister uncle , the reverend samuel parris , about a wild night affair in the woods in which she and some other girls had seemed to have had contact with these evil beings .	120.743996
for all involved in this discussion the devil is a real entity who can really be confronted in the woods on a dark night , the demon world is populated with real creatures , and witches actually can be seen flying through the air .	77.53363
as the play unfolds , however , the audience is subtly brought into the grip of an awful evil which grows with ominously gathering power and soon engulfs the community .	159.73793
everyone in salem , saint and sinner alike , is swept up by it .	67.283195
it is like a mysterious epidemic which , starting first with abigail and parris , spreads inexorably with a dreadfully growing virulence through the whole town until all have been infected by it .	197.3758
it grows terribly and unavoidably in power and leaves in its wake a trail of misery , moral disintegration , and destruction .	88.076195
the audience leaves the play under a spell , it is the kind of spell which the exposure to spirit in its living active manifestation always evokes .	111.22446
if one asks about this play , what it is that comes upon this community and works within it with such terrible power , there is no better answer to give than `` spirit ' ' .	112.7807
this is not to attempt to say what spirit is , but only to employ a commonly used word to designate or simply identify a common experience .	119.33796
in the end the good man , john proctor , expresses what the audience has already come to feel when he says , `` a fire , a fire is burning ! !	61.68482
i hear the boot of lucifer , i see his filthy face ' ' ! !	77.42878
the tragic irony of the play is that the very belief in and concern with a devil who could be met in the woods and combatted with formulae set out in books was the very thing that prevented them from detecting the real devil when he came among them .	144.33142
we marvel at their blindness for not seeing this .	65.41209
yet are not we of the mid-twentieth century , who rightly do not believe there is any such `` thing ' ' as the devil , just as bad off as they -- only in a different way ? ?	89.49067
in our disbelief we think that we can no longer even use the word and so are unable to even name the elemental power which is so vividly real in this play .	193.56854
we are left helpless to cope with it because we do not dare speak of it as anything real for fear that to do so would imply a commitment to that which has already been discredited and proved false .	99.680565
even mr . miller himself seems uncertain on this score .	33.319042
in a long commentary which he has inserted in the published text of the first act of the play , he says at one point `` however , that experience never raised a doubt in his mind as to the reality of the underworld or the existence of lucifer ' s many-faced lieutenants .	103.05457
and his belief is not to his discredit .	6.14556
better minds than hale ' s were -- and still are -- convinced that there is a society of spirits beyond our ken ' ' .	109.406494
( page 33 ) on the other hand , a little later on he says `` since 1692 a great but superficial change has wiped out god ' s beard and the devil ' s horns , but the world is still gripped between two diametrically opposed absolutes .	127.0667
the concept of unity , in which positive and negative are attributes of the same force , in which good and evil are relative , ever-changing , and always joined to the same phenomenon -- such a concept is still reserved to the physical sciences and to the few who have grasped the history of ideas .	124.49701
when we see the steady and methodical inculcation into humanity of the idea of man ' s worthlessness -- until redeemed -- the necessity of the devil may become evident as a weapon , a weapon designed and used time and time again in every age to whip men into a surrender to a particular church or church-state ' ' .	134.27788
apparently he does not intend that those who read or view this play should think of the devil as being actually real .	360.76697
yet such is the dramatic power of his writing that the audience is nevertheless left in the grip of the terrible power and potency of that which came over salem .	101.307236
it casts a spell upon them so that they leave with a feeling of having been in the mysterious presence of an evil power .	57.256855
it is not enough in accounting for this feeling to analyze it into the wickedness of individual people added together to produce a cumulative effect .	149.25934
for this does not account for the integral , elemental power of that which grows with abounding vigor as the play unfolds , nor does it explain the strange numinous sense of presentness which comes over those who watch the play like a spell .	118.580185
the reality of spirit emerges in this play in spite of the author ' s convictions to the contrary .	43.784985
there is nothing in the whole range of human experience more widely known and universally felt than spirit .	327.4148
apart from spirit there could be no community , for it is spirit which draws men into community and gives to any community its unity , cohesiveness , and permanence .	198.77394
think , for example , of the spirit of the marine corps .	12.669161
surely this is a reality we all acknowledge .	51.84999
we cannot , of course , assign it any substance .	210.10214
it is not material and is not a `` thing ' ' occupying space and time .	157.52641
yet it exists and has an objective reality which can be experienced and known .	63.06882
so it is too with many other spirits which we all know the spirit of nazism or communism , school spirit , the spirit of a street corner gang or a football team , the spirit of rotary or the ku klux klan .	102.87213
every community , if it is alive has a spirit , and that spirit is the center of its unity and identity .	37.85685
in searching for clues which might lead us to a fresh apprehension of the reality of spirit , the close connection between spirit and community is likely to prove the most fruitful .	51.2404
for it is primarily in community that we know and experience spirit .	265.4708
it is spirit which gives life to a community and causes it to cohere .	276.78378
it is the spirit which is the source of a community ' s drawing power by means of which others are drawn into it from the world outside so that the community grows and prospers .	124.99578
yet the spirit which lives in community is not identical with the community .	43.466415
the idea of community and the idea of spirit are two distinct and separable ideas .	293.95407
one characteristic of the spirit in community is its givenness .	802.1544
the members of the community do not create the spirit but rather find it present and waiting for them .	198.62167
it is for them a given which they and they alone possess .	221.11282
the spirit of the marine corps was present and operative before any of the present members of it came into it .	144.711
it is they , of course , who keep it alive and preserve it so the same spirit will continue to be present in the corps for future recruits to find as they come into it .	77.5289
if the content of faith is to be presented today in a form that can be `` understanded of the people ' ' -- and this , it must not be forgotten , is one of the goals of the perennial theological task -- there is no other choice but to abandon completely a mythological manner of representation .	70.43281
this does not mean that mythological language as such can no longer be used in theology and preaching .	112.188446
the absurd notion that demythologization entails the expurgation of all mythological concepts completely misrepresents bultmann ' s intention .	105.056526
his point is not that mythology may not be used , but that it may no longer be regarded as the only or even the most appropriate conceptuality for expressing the christian kerygma .	56.024296
when we say that a mythological mode of thought must be completely abandoned , we mean it must be abandoned as the sole or proper means for presenting the christian understanding of existence .	102.857315
mythological concepts may by all means still be used , but they can be used responsibly only as `` symbols ' ' or `` ciphers ' ' , that is , only if they are also constantly interpreted in nonmythological ( or existential ) terms .	65.156006
the statement is often made that when bultmann argues in this way , he `` overestimates the intellectual stumbling-block which myth is supposed to put in the way of accepting the christian faith ' ' .	53.21327
