thus all differences were leveled , and all contrasts erased , in a realm of no distinction , and the harmonious balance of the lo shu square could effectively symbolize the world in balanced harmony around a powerful central axis .	100.64044
the tremendous emphasis on the 5 in the lo shu square -- for purely mathematical reasons -- and the fact that this number so neatly symbolized the heart and center of the universe , could well explain why the old chinese seem to have so revered the number 5 , and why they put so much stress on the concept of centrality .	74.99661
these twin tendencies seem to have reached their height in the han dynasty .	21.816345
the existing reverence for centrality must have been still further stimulated toward the close of the second century b . c . , when the han emperor wu ti ordered the dynastic color changed to yellow -- which symbolized the center among the traditional five directions -- and took 5 as the dynastic number , believing that he would thus place himself , his imperial family , and the nation under the most auspicious influences .	129.23506
his immediate motive for doing this may not have been directly inspired by the lo shu , but this measure must inevitably have increased the existing beliefs in the latter ' s efficacy .	55.274174
after this time , inscriptions on the han bronze mirrors , as well as other writings , emphasized the desirability of keeping one ' s self at the center of the universe , where cosmic forces were strongest .	51.861225
later , we shall see what happened when an emperor took this idea too literally .	497.5098
all this emphasis on centrality and on the number 5 as a symbolic expression of the center , which seems to have begun as far back as 400 b . c . , also may conceivably have led to the development of the five-elements school and the subsequent efforts to fit everything into numerical categories of five .	94.99329
we find , for example , such groupings as the five ancient rulers , the five sacred mountains , the five directions ( with center ) , the five metals , five colors , five tastes , five odors , five musical notes , five bodily functions , five viscera , and many others .	133.34212
this trend has often been ascribed to the cult of the five elements itself , as though they had served as the base for all the rest	154.08261
but why did the old chinese postulate five elements , when the ancient near east -- which may have initiated the idea that natural elements exerted influence in human life and activities -- recognized only four ? ?	157.71327
and why did the chinese suddenly begin to talk about the five directions , when the animals they used as symbols of the directions designated only the usual four ? ?	122.84648
obviously , something suddenly caused them to start thinking in terms of fives , and that may have been the workings of the lo shu .	44.113655
this whole tendency had an unfortunate effect on chinese thinking .	301.86862
whereas the primary meanings of the lo shu diagram seemed to have been based on its inner mathematical properties -- and we shall see that even its secondary meanings rested on some mathematical bases -- the urgent desire to place everything into categories of fives led to other groupings based on other numbers , until an exaggerated emphasis on mere numerology pervaded chinese thought .	182.30922
scholars made numbered sets of as many things as possible in nature , or assigned arbitrary numbers to individual things , in a fashion that seems to the modern scientific mind as downright nonsensical , and philosophical ideas based upon all this tended to stifle speculative thought in china for many centuries .	197.33138
yin and yang in the `` lo shu ' ' square	14.308427
although the primary mathematical properties of the middle number at the center of the lo shu , and the interrelation of all the other numbers to it , might seem enough to account for the deep fascination which the lo shu held for the old chinese philosophers , this was actually only a beginning of wonders .	61.133064
for the lo shu square was a remarkably complete compendium of most of the chief religious and philosophical ideas of its time .	98.11387
as such , one cannot fully understand the thought of the pre-han and han periods without knowing the meanings inherent in the lo shu	183.10489
but , conversely , one cannot begin to understand the lo shu without knowing something about the world view of the old chinese , which they felt they saw expressed in it .	94.83371
the chinese world view during the han dynasty , when the lo shu seems to have been at the height of its popularity , was based in large part on the teachings of the yin-yang and five-elements school , which was traditionally founded by tsou yen .	55.486538
according to this doctrine , the universe was ruled by heaven , t ' ien -- as a natural force , or in the personification of a supreme sky-god -- governing all things by means of a process called the tao , which can be roughly interpreted as `` the order of the universe ' ' or `` the universal way ' ' .	78.08609
heaven , acting through the tao , expressed itself by means of the workings of two basic principles , the yin and the yang .	65.88257
the yang , or male principle , was the source of light , heat , and dynamic vitality , associated with the sun	56.62785
while the yin , or female principle , flourished in darkness , cold , and quiet inactivity , and was associated with the moon .	51.227486
together these two principles influenced all things , and in varying combinations they were present in everything .	92.91884
we have already seen that odd numbers were considered as being yang , while the even numbers were yin , so that the eight outer numbers of the lo shu represented these two principles in balanced equilibrium around the axial center .	215.79834
during the han dynasty , another yin-yang conception was applied to the lo shu , considering the latter as a plan of ancient china .	70.577
instead of linking the nine numbers of this diagram with the traditional nine provinces , as was usually done , this equated the odd , yang numbers with mountains ( firm and resistant , hence yang ) and the even numbers with rivers ( sinuous and yielding , hence yin )	337.68164
taking the former from the five sacred mountains of the han period and the latter from the principal river systems of old china .	208.69197
thus the middle number , 5 , represented sung-shan in honan , central china	137.3233
the 3 , t ' ai-shan in shantung , east china	82.50591
the 7 , hwa-shan in shensi , west china	152.33289
the 1 , heng-shan in hopei , north china ( or the mountain with the same name in neighboring shansi )	193.66428
and the 9 , huo-shan in anhwei , which was then the south sacred mountain .	72.86077
for the rivers , the 4 represented the huai , to the ( then ) southeast	265.96024
the 2 , the san kiang ( three rivers ) in the ( then ) southwest	140.1391
and the 6 , the ( upper ) yellow river in the northwest .	85.73417
note that by western standards this plan was `` upside down ' ' , as it put north at the bottom and south at the top , with the other directions correspondingly altered	58.337887
but in this respect it was merely following the accepted chinese convention for all maps .	109.220985
the same arrangement was used when the lo shu was equated with the nine provinces	39.23217
and whenever the lo shu involved directional symbolism , it was oriented in this same fashion .	77.37187
few persons who join the church are insincere .	7.881772
they earnestly desire to do the will of god .	9.956951
when they fall by the wayside and fail to achieve christian stature , it is an indictment of the church .	46.91226
these fatalities are dramatic evidence of `` halfway evangelism ' ' , a failure to follow through .	41.382378
a program of lay visitation evangelism can end in dismal defeat with half the new members drifting away unless practical plans and strenuous efforts are made to keep them in the active fellowship .	156.019
the work of lay visitation evangelism is not completed when all of the persons on the responsibility list have been interviewed .	157.18141
in the average situation about one-third of those visited make commitments to christ and the church .	200.52702
the pastor and the membership preparation and assimilation committee must follow through immediately with a carefully planned program .	191.21718
the first thirty to sixty days after individuals make their decision will determine their interest and participation in the life of the church .	57.670162
churches that have a carefully planned program of membership preparation and assimilation often keep 85 to 90 per cent of their new members loyal and active .	57.211033
this is the answer to the problem of `` membership delinquency ' ' .	57.86174
it is important that persons desiring to unite with the church be prepared for this experience so that it may be meaningful and spiritually significant .	95.301445
it is unfair and unchristian to ask a person to take the sacred vows of church membership before he has been carefully instructed concerning their implications .	75.75079
preparation for church membership begins immediately after the commitment is received .	608.5392
the pastor writes a personal letter to each individual , expressing his joy over the decision , assuring him of a pastoral call at the earliest convenient time , and outlining the plan for membership preparation classes and membership sunday .	114.215576
some pastors write a letter the same night the decision is reported by the visitors .	102.96596
it should not be postponed later than the next day .	28.36353
a helpful leaflet may be enclosed in the letter .	84.62999
the pastor calls in the home of each individual or family for a spiritual guidance conference .	213.23976
if possible , he should make an appointment in order that all persons involved may be present .	177.69455
it is definitely a `` spiritual guidance conference ' ' .	4.338186
he will discuss the significance of christian commitment , the necessity of family religion and private devotions , and the importance of the membership preparation sessions .	38.328957
there may be problems of conduct or questions of belief which will require his counsel .	124.813995
each conference should be concluded naturally with prayer .	8.592222
a piece of devotional material , such as the upper room , may be left in each home .	138.67535
a minimum of four sessions of preparation for membership is necessary for adults .	65.220566
those who join the church need to be instructed in the faith and the meaning of christian discipleship before they take the sacred vows .	55.732082
they will have a greater appreciation for the church and a deeper devotion to it if membership requires something of them .	147.18077
many churches find the sunday school hour to be the most practical time for adult preparation classes .	260.18805
others meet on sunday night , at the mid-week service , or for a series of four nights .	74.42636
some pastors have two sessions in one evening , with a refreshment period between .	185.88022
following each instruction period a piece of literature dealing with the topic should be handed each one for further reading during the week .	227.00868
this procedure is much more effective than giving out a membership packet .	228.80594
most pastors find that the fourth session should take at least two hours and therefore hold it on a week night prior to reception sunday .	135.89848
in this session the persons seeking membership are provided information concerning the work of the denomination as well as the program and activities of the local church .	52.136562
the lay leadership of the church may be invited to speak on the various phases of church life , service opportunities , the church school , missions , men ' s work , women ' s work , youth program , social activities , and finances .	101.55516
the budget of the church may be presented and pledges solicited at this session .	215.0384
an `` interest finder ' ' or `` talent sheet ' ' may be filled out by each person .	90.66593
) the fourth session may be concluded with a tour of the church facilities and refreshments .	94.17872
the social time gives an opportunity for church leaders to become acquainted with the new members .	41.78295
in conducting the membership preparation-inquirers ' class , the pastor should plan a variety of teaching techniques in order to develop greater interest on the part of the class .	72.48755
some churches have six or more training sessions of two hours each , generally held on sunday night or during the week .	120.06336
this gives greater opportunity for the learning process .	6.964157
use dramatization -- for example , in discussing the lord ' s supper or church symbolism .	93.34044
some excellent filmstrips with recordings and motion pictures may be secured from your denominational headquarters to enrich the class session .	84.12753
some new members will hesitate to ask questions audibly .	852.43695
urge them to write out their questions for the box .	22.53699
use a textbook with assigned readings each week .	29.966345
select class members for reports on various phases of the study .	14.890535
conduct examinations , using a true-false check sheet .	3.7194107
ask each member to write a statement on such topics as `` what christ means to me ' ' , `` what the church means to me ' ' , `` why join the church ' ' , `` the duties of church members ' ' , etc . .	45.481106
assign a series of catechism questions to be memorized .	69.908195
invite class members to share in an extra period of bible study each week .	149.39107
ask each new member to bring his pledge of loyalty to the reception service .	117.4845
there is a growing conviction among pastors and church leaders that all those who come into the fellowship of the church need preparatory training , including those coming by transfer of membership .	105.69598
george e . sweazey writes `` there is danger in trying to make admission to the church so easy and painless that people will scarcely know that anything has happened ' ' .	82.976875
people appreciate experiences that demand something of them .	8.766416
those who transfer their membership are no exception to the rule .	60.42787
for most of them , it will be their first experience in membership training , since this is a recent development in many churches .	115.750404
those coming from other denominations will welcome the opportunity to become informed .	70.167946
the preparatory class is an introductory face-to-face group in which new members become acquainted with one another .	92.0729
it provides a natural transition into the life of the local church and its organizations .	20.796427
the total process of evangelism reaches the crescendo when the group of new members stands before the congregation to declare publicly their faith and to be received into the fellowship of the church .	48.469543
this should be a high moment in their lives , a never-to-be-forgotten experience .	277.93668
they should sense the tremendous significance of joining the spiritual succession reaching back to christ our lord and forward to an eternal fellowship with the saints of the ages .	130.81082
every detail of the service merits careful attention -- the hymns , the sermon , the ritual , the right hand of fellowship , the introduction to the congregation , the welcome of the congregation .	73.689445
this is a vital part of their spiritual growth and assimilation .	18.923073
it will help to determine the attitude of the new members toward the church .	29.645061
it can mean the difference between participation and inaction , spiritual growth and decay .	57.62464
the worship service is the natural and logical time to receive new members into the church .	114.95877
the atmosphere for this momentous experience can be created most effectively through the worship experience .	281.90994
psychologically the reception should be the climax , following the sermon .	107.409805
ask the new members to meet thirty minutes before the service to complete `` talent sheets ' ' and pledge cards .	163.11154
some denominations ask new members to sign personally the chronological membership register .	74.41061
provide a name card for each new member .	17.310474
arrange a reserved section in the sanctuary where all new members may sit together .	95.92171
invite sponsors or fellowship friends to stand back of the new members in the reception service .	43.34818
give each new member a certificate of membership .	22.911858
introduce each new member to the congregation , asking him to face the congregation .	102.05959
lead the congregation in a response of welcome .	11.406119
have a reception for new members in the parlor or social hall immediately after the service .	211.48128
take a picture of the group of new members to be put in the church paper or placed on the bulletin board .	64.24222
have a fellowship luncheon or dinner with new members as guests .	78.034836
chapter 6 planning for the assimilation and growth of new members	72.240456
the church is `` the family of god ' ' .	2.902313
the members of the `` family ' ' are drawn together by a common love for christ and a sincere devotion to his kingdom .	83.6358
every member of the family must have a vital place in its life .	76.5139
yet the most difficult problem in the church ' s program of evangelism is right at this point -- helping new members to become participating , growing parts of the fellowship .	72.84952
very easily they may be neglected and eventually join the ranks of the unconcerned and inactive .	68.49161
a study of major denominational membership statistics over a twenty-year period revealed the appalling fact that nearly 40 per cent of those who joined the church were lost to the church within seven years .	54.44472
one denomination had a membership of 1 , 419 , 833 at the beginning of the period under study , and twenty years later its membership stood at 1 , 541 , 991 -- a net growth of only 122 , 158 .	96.73965
yet during the same period there were 1 , 080 , 062 additions .	57.975605
another major church body had 4 , 499 , 608 members and twenty years later its membership stood at 4 , 622 , 444 .	68.49726
during this time 4 , 122 , 354 new members were brought into the fellowship .	79.1127
still another denomination had 7 , 360 , 187 members twenty years ago .	114.406845
during this period 7 , 484 , 268 members were received , yet the net membership now is only 9 , 910 , 741 .	164.29407
these figures indicate that we are losing almost as many as we are receiving into membership .	77.22855
this problem is illustrated by the fact that many local churches drop from the active membership rolls each year as many as they receive into the fellowship .	146.95532
studies of membership trends , even in some areas where population is expanding , show that numbers of churches have had little net increase , though many new members were received .	202.17487
the local `` family of god ' ' has failed its new members through neglect and unconcern for their spiritual welfare .	201.71268
new members can become participating , growing members .	22.685194
but this will not happen merely through the natural process of social life .	52.41671
the entire membership of the local church must be alerted to their part in this dynamic process .	105.424164
if the church has followed the plan of cultivation of prospects and carried through a program of membership preparation as outlined earlier in this book , the process of assimilation and growth will be well under way .	73.368004
those who enter the front door of the church intelligently and with christian dedication will not so easily step through the back door because of lost interest .	175.51031
however , it is not enough to bring persons to christian commitment and train them in the meaning of christian discipleship .	114.131516
when they unite with the church they must find in this fellowship the satisfaction of their basic spiritual needs or they will never mature into effective christians .	151.39954
the church expects certain things of those who become members .	226.65715
the new members justifiably expect some things from their church family	724.54724
-- opportunities for study of the christian faith and the bible	50.223206
care must be taken neither to confuse unity with uniformity nor god with our parochial ideas about him , but with these two qualifications , the statement stands .	207.03516
the statement also points to a classic paradox the more men turn toward god , who is not only in himself the paradigm of all unity but also the only ground on which human unity can ultimately be established , the more men splinter into groups and set themselves apart from one another .	141.80116
to be reminded of this we need only glance at the world map and note the extent to which religious divisions have compounded political ones , with a resultant fragmentation of the human race .	94.90161
massacres attending the partition of india and the establishment of the state of israel are simply recent grim evidences of the hostility such divisions can engender .	118.066025
the words of cardinal newman come forcibly to mind `` oh how we hate one another for the love of god ' ' ! !	61.66306
the source of this paradox is not difficult to identify .	49.723564
institutions require structure , form , and definition , and these in turn entail differentiation and exclusion .	91.007286
a completely amorphous institution would be a contradiction in terms	21.81944
to escape this fate , it must rule some things out .	167.23691
for every criterion which defines what something is , at the same time proclaims -- implicitly if not openly -- what that something is not .	89.92716
some persons are so sensitive to this truth as to propose that we do away with institutions altogether	230.79794
in the present context this amounts to the advice that while being religious may have a certain justification , we ought to dispense with churches .	172.37552
man is at once a gregarious animal and a form-creating being .	265.86884
having once committed himself to an ideal which he considers worthwhile , he inevitably creates forms for its expression and institutions for its continuance .	103.03207
to propose that men be religious without having religious institutions is like proposing that they be learned without having schools .	243.31516
both eventualities are possible logically , but practically they are impossible .	108.43723
as much as men intrinsically need the unity that is grounded in god , they instrumentally require the institutions that will direct their steps toward him .	218.57742
yet the fact remains that such institutions do set men at odds with their fellows .	135.79355
is there any way out of the predicament ? ?	6.2426248
the only way that i can see is through communication .	169.94376
interfaith communication need not be regarded as an unfortunate burden visited upon us by the necessity of maintaining diplomatic relations with our adversaries .	79.552795
approached creatively , it is a high art .	16.583246
it is the art of relating the finite to the infinite , of doing our best to insure that the particularistic requirements of religious institutions will not thwart god ' s intent of unity among men more than is minimally necessary .	180.96095
in a certain sense , interfaith communication parallels diplomatic communication among the nation-states .	406.8301
what are the pertinent facts affecting such communication at the present juncture of history ? ?	54.069504
i shall touch on three areas personal , national , and theological .	424.93314
by personal factors i mean those rooted in personality structure .	1272.7429
some interfaith tensions are not occasioned by theological differences at all , but by the need of men to have persons they can blame , distrust , denounce , and even hate .	77.78318
modern psychology has shown that paralleling `` the authoritarian personality ' ' is `` the bigoted personality ' ' in which insecurity , inferiority , suspicion , and distrust combine to provide a target for antagonism so indispensable that it will be manufactured if it does not exist naturally .	84.7893
fortunately the number of pathological bigots appears to be quite small , but it would be a mistake to think that more than a matter of degree separates them from the rest of us .	38.560635
to some extent the personal inadequacies that prejudices attempt to compensate for are to be found in all of us .	61.131603
interfaith conflicts which spring from psychological deficiencies are the most unfortunate of all , for they have no redeeming features whatsoever .	84.262634
it is difficult to say what can be done about them except that we must learn to recognize when it is they , rather than pretexts for them , that are causing the trouble , and do everything possible to nurture the healthy personalities that will prevent the development of such deficiencies .	109.01483
while the personality factors that aggravate interfaith conflict may be perennial , nationalism is more variable .	162.43575
the specific instance i have in mind is the afro-asian version which has gained prominence only in this second half of the twentieth century .	76.015366
emerging from the two centuries of colonial domination , the afro-asian world is aflame with a nationalism that has undone empires .	71.126434
no less than twenty-two nations have already achieved independence since world war 2 , , and the number is growing by the year .	67.63449
as an obvious consequence , obstacles to genuine interfaith communication have grown more formidable in one important area relations between christians and non-christians in these lands .	100.812004
colonialism alone would have been able to make these difficulties serious , for christianity is so closely tied to colonialism in the minds of these people that repudiation of the one has tended automatically toward the repudiation of the other .	132.46117
actually , however , this turns out to be only part of the picture .	67.43984
nationalism has abetted not only the repudiation of foreign religions but the revival of native ones , some of which had been lying in slumber for centuries .	122.719025
the truth is that any revival of traditional and indigenous religion will serve to promote that sense of identity and volksgeist which these young nations very much need .	219.76872
insofar as these nations claim to incarnate traditions and ways of life which constitute ultimate , trans-political justifications for their existence , such people are inevitably led to emphasize the ways in which these traditions and ways are theirs rather than someone else ' s .	103.68025
all this works severely against the kind of cross-cultural communication for which christian missions stand .	533.7534
africans and asians tend to consider not only missions but the local churches they have produced as centers and agents of western culture and ideology if not of direct political propaganda .	158.3066
the people hardest hit by this suspicion are , of course , christians on the mainland of china .	41.09473
for example , in burma and ceylon many buddhists argue that buddhism ought to be the official state religion .	106.66117
in 1960 ceylon nationalized its sectarian -- preponderantly christian -- schools , to the rejoicing of most of its 7 , 000 , 000 buddhists and the lament of its 800 , 000 roman catholics .	125.458244
again , india has imposed formidable barriers against the entrance of additional missionaries , and fanatical hindu parties are expected to seek further action against christians once the influence making for tolerance due to nehru and his followers is gone .	115.48985
the progressive closing of afro-asian ears to the christian message is epitomized in a conversation i had three years ago while flying from jerusalem to cairo .	118.28721
i was seated next to the director of the seventh day adventists ' world radio program .	90.03117
he said that on his tour the preceding year a considerable number of hours would have been available to him on japanese radio networks , but that he had then lacked the funds to contract for them .	120.92313
after returning to the united states and raising the money , he discovered on getting back to japan that the hours were no longer available .	84.865746
it was not that they had been contracted for during the interval	160.86838
they simply could no longer be purchased for missionary purposes .	31.36484
it is not unfair to add on the other side that the crude and almost vitriolic approach of certain fundamentalist sects toward the cultures and religions among which they work has contributed measurably to this heightening of anti-christian sentiment .	139.4156
ironically , these are the groups which have doubled or tripled their missionary efforts since world war 2 , , while the more established denominations are barely maintaining pre-war staffs .	128.71599
although i have emphasized the barriers which an aroused nationalism has raised against relations between christians and non-christians in asia , the fact is that this development has also widened the gulf between certain afro-asian religions themselves .	99.69007
the partition of india has hardly improved relations between hindus and muslims	79.42041
neither has the establishment of the state of israel fostered harmony between muslims and jews .	123.16128
the modern world has been marked by progressive disaffection with claims to divine sanction for the state , whatever its political form .	99.11049
the american constitution was historic at this point in providing that `` congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion or prohibiting the free exercise thereof ' ' .	112.04913
one of our foremost jurists , david dudley field , has gone so far as to call this provision `` the greatest achievement ever made in the course of human history ' ' .	49.169273
the trend throughout the world ' s religions has been toward a recognition of at least the practical validity of this constitutional enactment .	72.08953
pakistan was created in 1947 expressly as a muslim state , but when the army took over eleven years later it did so on a wave of mass impatience which was directed in part against the inability of political and religious leaders to think their way through to the meaning of islam for the modern political situation .	93.83731
`` what is the point ' ' , charles adams reports the pakistanis as asking , `` in demanding an islamic state and society if no one , not even the doctors of the sacred law themselves , can say clearly and succinctly what the nature of such a state and society is ' ' ? ?	177.17287
the current regime of president mohammad ayub khan is determinedly secular .	262.42902
and while the nation was formerly named `` the islamic republic of pakistan ' ' , it is now simply `` the republic of pakistan ' ' .	26.765108
the new regime in turkey is intentionally less muslim than its predecessor .	30.007828
the religious parties in israel have experienced a great loss of prestige in recent months .	62.583508
during the years when israel was passing from crisis to crisis -- the sinai campaign , the infusion of multitudes of penniless immigrants -- it was felt that the purpose of national unity could be best served if the secular majority were to yield to the religious parties .	157.24785
now that israel enjoys relative prosperity and a reduction of tensions , the secularists are less disposed to compromise .	85.89629
and in this country gustave weigel ' s delineation of the line between the sacral and secular orders during the last presidential campaign served to provide a most impressive roman catholic defense of the practical autonomy of both church and state .	86.96271
the failure at that time of the puerto rican bishops to control the votes of their people added a ring of good sense to father weigel ' s theological argument .	178.97221
everywhere there seems to be a growing recognition of the fact that governments and religious institutions alike are too fallible and corruptible -- in a word , too human -- to warrant any claim of maintaining partnership with the divine .	75.080086
my father went as a missionary to china in a generation that responded to student volunteer movement speakers who held watches in their hands and announced to the students in their audiences how many chinese souls were going to hell each second because these students were not over there saving them .	209.92328
that mention of this should bring smiles to our lips today is as clear an indication as we could wish of the extent to which attitudes have changed .	241.15451
i do not mean to imply that christians have adopted the liberal assumption , so prevalent in hinduism , that all religions are merely different paths to the same summit .	97.21929
leslie newbiggin reflects the dominant position within the world council of churches when he says , `` we must claim absoluteness and finality for christ and his finished work , but that very claim forbids us to claim absoluteness and finality for our understanding of it ' ' .	95.67307
newbiggin ' s qualification on the christian claim is of considerable significance .	88.39268
the roman catholic church has excommunicated one of its priests , father feeney , for insisting that there is no salvation outside the visible church .	123.787895
in mentioning this under `` salvation reconsidered ' ' i do not mean to imply that roman catholic doctrine has changed in this area but rather that it has become clearer to the world community what that doctrine is .	60.444557
when they say that under no circumstances would it ever be right to `` permit ' ' the termination of the human race by human action , because there could not possibly be any proportionate grave reason to justify such a thing , they know exactly what they mean .	87.71366
of course , in prudential calculation , in balancing the good directly intended and done against the evil unintended and indirectly done , no greater precision can be forthcoming than the subject allows .	215.46036
yet it seems clear that there can be no good sufficiently great , or evil repelled sufficiently grave , to warrant the destruction of mankind by man ' s own action .	53.72876
i mean , however , that the moral theologian knows what he means by `` permit ' ' .	79.515594
he is not talking in the main about probabilities , risks and danger in general .	119.59516
he is talking about an action which just as efficaciously does an evil thing ( and is known certainly and unavoidably to lead to this evil result ) as it efficaciously does some good .	303.01645
he is talking about double effects , of which the specific action causes directly the one and indirectly the other , but causes both	226.62679
of which one is deliberately willed or intended and the other not intended or not directly intended , but still both are done , while the evil effect is , with equal consciousness on the part of the agent , foreknown to be among the consequences .	178.34367
this is what , in a technical sense , to `` only permit ' ' an evil result means .	104.587685
it means to do it and to know one is doing it , but as only a secondary if certain effect of the good one primarily does and intends .	248.89738
of course , grave guiltiness may be imputed to the military action of any nation , or to the action of any leader or leaders , which for any supposed good `` permits ' ' , in this sense , the termination of the human race by human action .	65.08238
certainly , in analyzing an action which truly faced such alternatives , `` it is never possible that no world would be preferable to some worlds , and there are in truth no circumstances in which the destruction of human life presents itself as a reasonable alternative ' ' .	67.457405
naturally , where one or the other of the effects of an action is uncertain , this has to be taken into account .	72.37844
especially is this true when , because the good effect is remote and speculative while the evil is certain and grave , the action is prohibited .	142.43872
presumably , if the reverse is the case and the good effect is more certain than the evil result that may be forthcoming , not only must the good and the evil be prudentially weighed and found proportionate , but also calculation of the probabilities and of the degree of certainty or uncertainty in the good or evil effect must be taken into account .	105.951
there must not only be greater good than evil objectively in view , but also greater probability of actually doing more good than harm .	184.47089
if an evil which is certain and extensive and immediate may rarely be compensated for by a problematic , speculative , future good , by the same token not every present , certain , and immediate good ( or lesser evil ) that may have to be done will be outweighed by a problematic , speculative , and future evil .	193.58017
nevertheless , according to the traditional theory , a man begins in the midst of action and he analyzes its nature and immediate consequences before or while putting it forth and causing these consequences .	199.60196
he does not expect to be able to trammel up all the future consequences of his action .	122.51065
above all , he does not debate mere contingencies , and therefore , if these are possibly dreadful , find himself forced into inaction .	95.697945
he does what he can and may and must , without regarding himself as lord of the future or , on the other hand , as covered with guilt by accident or unforeseen consequences or by results he did not `` permit ' ' in the sense explained .	135.09436
by contrast , a good deal of nuclear pacifism begins with the contingencies and the probabilities , and not with the moral nature of the action to be done	71.88128
and by deriving legitimate decision backward from whatever may conceivably or possibly or probably result , whether by anyone ' s doing or by accident , it finds itself driven to inaction , to non-political action in politics and non-military action in military affairs , and to the not very surprising discovery that there are now no distinctions on which the defense of justice can possibly be based .	154.89848
mr . philip toynbee writes , for example , that `` in terms of probability it is surely as likely as not that mutual fear will lead to accidental war in the near future if the present situation continues .	106.60814
if it continues indefinitely it is nearly a statistical certainty that a mistake will be made and that the devastation will begin ' ' .	76.882805
against such a termination of human life on earth by human action , he then proposes as an alternative that we `` negotiate at once with the russians and get the best terms which are available ' ' , that we deliberately `` negotiate from comparative weakness ' ' .	128.85521
he bravely attempts to face this alternative realistically , i . e . , by considering the worst possible outcome , namely , the total domination of the world by russia within a few years .	64.309586
this would be by far the better choice , when `` it is a question of allowing the human race to survive , possibly under the domination of a regime which most of us detest , or of allowing it to destroy itself in appalling and prolonged anguish ' ' .	60.10507
nevertheless , the consequence of the policy proposed is everywhere subtly qualified it is `` a possible result , however improbable ' '	148.43872
`` the worst , and least probable ' ' result	69.47635
`` if it didn ' t prevail mankind would still be given the opportunity of prevailing ' '	105.86187
for `` surely anything is better than a policy which allows for the possibility of nuclear war ' ' .	19.843996
if we have not thought and made a decision entirely in these terms , then we need to submit ourselves to the following `` simple test ' ' `` have we decided how we are to kill the other members of our household in the event of our being less injured than they are ' ' ? ?	119.33825
thus , moral decision must be entirely deduced backward from the likely eventuality	119.73999
it is no longer to be formulated in terms of the nature of present action itself , its intention , and proximate effect or the thing to be done .	76.4101
several of the replies to mr . toynbee , without conscious resort to the traditional terminology with regard to the permission of evil , succeed in restoring the actual context in which present moral and political decisions must be made , by distinguishing between choosing a great evil and choosing in danger of this evil .	80.674484
`` it is worse for a nation to give in to evil than to run the risk of annihilation ' ' .	71.353836
`` i am consciously prepared to run the continued risk of ' race suicide by accident ' rather than accept the alternative certainty of race slavery by design .	406.76263
but i can only make this choice because i believe that the risk need not increase , but may be deliberately reduced ' ' ( by precautions against accidents or by limiting war ? ?	141.51888
) `` quoting mr . kennan ' s phrase that anything would be better than a policy which led inevitably to nuclear war , he ( toynbee ) says that anything is better than a policy which allows for the possibility of nuclear war ' ' .	57.273838
`` if asked to choose between a terrible probability and a more terrible possibility , most men will choose the latter ' ' .	86.79567
`` if philip toynbee is claiming that the choice lies between capitulation and the risk of nuclear war , i think he is right .	38.189823
i do not accept that the choice is between capitulation and the certainty of nuclear war ' ' .	15.650931
even professor arnold toynbee , agreeing with his son , does so in these terms `` compared to continuing to incur a constant risk of the destruction of the human race , all other evils are lesser evils .	105.28942
let us therefore put first things first , and make sure of preserving the human race at whatever the temporary price may be ' ' .	74.50888
mr . philip toynbee affirms at one point that if he shared the anticipations of orwell in nineteen eighty-four , if he believed communism was not only evil but `` also irredeemably evil ' ' , then he might `` think it right to do anything rather than to take the risk of a communist world .	69.54954
even a nuclear holocaust is a little less frightful to contemplate than a race of dehumanised humans occupying the earth until doomsday ' ' .	61.023293
no political order or economic system is so clearly contrary to nature .	66.221146
but one does not have to affirm the existence of an evil order irredeemable in that sense , or a static order in which no changes will take place in time , to be able truthfully to affirm the following fact there has never been justitia imprinted in social institutions and social relationships except in the context of some pax-ordo preserved by clothed or naked force .	101.548
on their way to the heavenly city the children of god make use of the pax-ordo of the earthly city and acknowledge their share in responsibility for its preservation .	102.10929
not to repel injury and uphold and improve pax-ordo means not simply to accept the misshapen order and injustice that challenges it at the moment , but also to start down the steep slope along which justice can find no place whereon to stand .	185.99352
toynbee seems to think that there is some other way to give justice social embodiment .	177.85698
`` i would far rather die after a russian occupation of this country -- by some deliberate act of refusal -- than die uselessly by atomisation ' ' .	95.85783
would such an act of refusal be useful ? ?	96.557014
he does not mean , in fact he addresses himself specifically to reject the proposition , that `` if we took the risk of surrendering , a new generation in britain would soon begin to amass its strength in secret in order to reverse the consequences of that surrender ' ' .	74.408264
he wants to be `` brutally frank and say that these rebellions would be hopeless -- far , far more hopeless than was the hungarian revolution of 1956 ' ' .	108.44981
this is not a project for regaining the ground for limited war , by creating a monopoly in one power of the world ' s arsenal of unlimited weapons .	94.57716
it is a proposal that justice now be served by means other than those that have ever preconditioned the search for it , or preconditioned more positive means for attaining it , in the past .	191.13022
`` it is no good recommending surrender rather than nuclear warfare with the proviso that surrender could be followed by the effective military resistance by occupied peoples .	50.302513
hope for the future would lie in the natural longing of the human race for freedom and the right to develop ' ' .	108.74264
this is to surrender in advance to whatever attack may yet be mounted , to the very last	347.336
it is to stride along the steep slope downward .	114.10888
the only contrary action , in the future as in the past , runs the risk of war	48.242218
and , now and in the future unlike in the past , any attempt to repel injury and to preserve any particular civilized attainment of mankind or its provisional justice runs some risk of nuclear warfare and the danger that an effect of it will , by human action , render this planet less habitable by the human race .	141.5369
that is why it is so very important that ethical analysis keep clear the problem of decision as to `` permitted ' ' effects , and not draw back in fright from any conceivable contingency or suffer paralysis of action before possibilities or probabilities unrelated , or not directly morally related , to what we can and may and must do as long as human history endures .	184.10321
finally , just as no different issues are posed for thoughtful analysis by the foreshortening of time that may yet pass before the end of human life on this earth , but only stimulation and alarm to the imagination , the same thing must be said in connection with the question of what we may perhaps already be doing , by human action , to accelerate this end .	106.8674
we should not allow the image of an immanent end brought about indirectly by our own action in the continuing human struggle for a just endurable order of existence to blind us to the fact that in some measure accelerating the end of our lease may be one consequence among others of many other of mankind ' s thrusts toward we know not what future .	191.04965
much more than shelter , housing symbolizes social status , a sense of `` belonging ' ' , acceptance within a given group or neighborhood , identification with particular cultural values and social institutions , feelings of pride and worth , aspirations and hopes basic to human well-being .	88.41632
for almost one-sixth of the national population discrimination in the free selection of residence casts a considerable shadow upon these values assumed as self-evident by most americans .	199.68867
few business groups in recent years have come under heavier pressure to face these realities than real estate brokers and home builders .	216.52283
this pressure has urged re-evaluation of the assumptions underlying their professional ethics	51.4406
it has sought new sympathy for the human aspirations of racial minority groups in this country .	29.273754
it is not surprising that , as spokesman for real estate interests , the national association of real estate boards ( nareb ) and its local associations have sought to limit and often ignore much of this pressure .	61.48909
how does the local realtor see himself in the context of housing restrictions based on race , religion or ethnic attachment ? ?	104.375946
what does he conceive his role to be in this area of social unrest ? ?	105.619095
what ought to be , what is his potential role as a force for constructive social change ? ?	167.7607
what social , ethical and theological insights can the church and university help him bring to bear upon his situation ? ?	213.4874
recently , a group of the faculty at wesleyan university ' s public affairs center sought some answers to these questions .	75.81326
several new england realtors were invited to participate in a small colloquium of property lawyers , political scientists , economists , social psychologists , social ethicists and theologians .	114.42621
here , in an atmosphere of forthrightness and mutual criticism , each sought to bring his particular insights to bear upon the question of discrimination in housing and the part each man present played in it .	181.7991
for a number of years , wesleyan has been drawing varied groups of political and business leaders into these informal discussions with members of the faculty and student body , attempting to explore and clarify aspects of their responsibility for public policy .	103.92239
this article presents our observations of that session , of the realtors as they saw themselves and as the faculty and students saw them .	212.80563
such conversation quickly reveals an ethically significant ambivalence in the self-images held by most realtors .	231.53328
within the membership of this group , as has been found true of men in other professional or trade associations , the most ready portrayal of oneself to `` the public ' ' is that of a neutral agent simply serving the interests of a seller or buyer and mediating between them .	142.41768
professional responsibility is seen to consist largely in serving the wishes of the client fairly and in an efficient manner .	228.74113
but as conversation goes on , particularly among the realtors themselves , another image emerges , that of considerable power and influence in the community .	102.74506
obviously , much more than customer expectation is determining the realtor ' s role .	89.24487
judgments are continually rendered regarding the potential buyers ' income , educational level and above all , racial extraction	145.11343
and whether these would qualify them for `` congenial ' ' , `` happy ' ' relations to other people in certain community areas .	54.82993
how explicit such factors have been historically is evident in any chronology of restrictive covenant cases or in a review of nareb ' s code of ethics article 34 in the code , adopted in 1924 , states that `` a realtor should never be instrumental in introducing into a neighborhood a character of property or occupancy , members of any race or nationality or any individuals whose presence will clearly be detrimental to property values in that neighborhood ' ' .	112.37686
though the reference to race was stricken by the association in 1950 , being an agent of such `` detrimental ' ' influences still appears as the cardinal sin realtors see themselves committed to avoid .	162.995
the rationale for this avoidance was most frequently expressed in economic terms	102.846436
all feared the supposed stigma they believed would inevitably attach to any realtor who openly introduced non-white , particularly negro , peoples into all-white , restricted areas .	220.78221
they would become tagged as men not interested in being purely real estate `` professionals ' ' but agitators for some kind of `` cause ' ' or `` reform ' ' , and this was no longer to be a `` pro ' ' .	44.174984
obviously what we are confronted with here is the identification of `` professional ' ' with narrow skills and specialization , the effective servicing of a client , rather than responsiveness to the wider and deeper meaning and associations of one ' s work .	86.601
these men -- for the most part educated in our `` best ' ' new england colleges , well established financially and socially in the community -- under kindly but insistent probing , reveal little or no objective or explicit criteria or data for their generalizations about the interests and attitudes of the people they claim to serve , or about the public responses that actually follow their occasional breach of a `` client-service relationship ' ' .	153.42337
this narrow `` professionalism ' ' does not even fit the present realities of their situation , as the pressure of minorities and the power and respectability of the realtors increase .	79.79663
as our discussion continued , the inadequacy of the `` client relationship ' ' as an interpretation of their `` way of operating ' ' became evident .	95.17315
realtors live in their communities as specialists in a given area of work , as members of social and professional organizations , as citizens and civic leaders , as church laymen , as university alumni , as newspaper readers , etc . .	103.587204
from such communal roles the realtor finds the substance that shapes his moral understanding .	195.32817
it seems to us that choices exercised by realtors in moral situations center in at least three areas ( 1 ) the various ways in which they interpret a particular social issue	156.33766
( 2 ) their pattern of involvement in the regular legal and political processes	72.4362
and , most pervasively , ( 3 ) their interpretation of who is a `` real pro ' ' , of what it means to be a professional man in a technical , fragmented society .	93.94615
( 1 ) most of the realtors minimized their own understanding of and role in the racial issue , pleading that they only reflect the attitudes and intentions of their society .	101.8676
the commission on race and housing concluded that `` there is no reason to believe that real estate men are either more or less racially prejudiced , on the whole , than any other segment of the american population ' ' .	51.65228
but such a reaction obscures the powerful efforts made in the past by both nareb and its local boards for the maintenance of restrictive clauses and practices .	74.60729
also , it does not recognize the elements of choice and judgment continually employed .	79.631775
like business and university groups generally , these men had very limited knowledge of recent sociological and psychological studies and findings that might illumine the decisions they make .	147.43413
realtors , both generally and in this group , have invariably equated residential integration with a decline in property values , a circumstance viewed with considerable apprehension .	224.65384
recent studies by the commission on race and housing and others , however , point to a vast complex of factors that often do not warrant this conclusion .	161.79173
there are increasing numbers of neighborhoods that are integrated residentially without great loss of property values , the white population having taken the initiative in preparing the areas for an appreciation of the negroes ' desire for well-kept housing , privacy , etc . .	135.33548
data on the decline of property values in an area after a new racial group enters it has to be assessed in terms of the trends in property values before the group comes in .	152.72797
often they are able to get in only because the area is declining economically .	136.31334
significantly , no realtor and few of the faculty present were familiar with any of the six volumes ( published by the university of california press ) that present the commission ' s findings .	187.51978
no one anticipates any radical shift in this situation , but questions concerning reading habits , the availability of such data and the places where it is discussed must surely be raised .	143.75563
the role of both church and university as sources of information and settings within which the implications of such information may be explored needs consideration .	134.18666
relevant `` facts ' ' , however , extend beyond considerations of property values and maintenance of `` harmonious ' ' neighborhoods .	129.59142
discussion of minority housing necessarily involves such basic issues as the intensity of one ' s democratic conviction and religious belief concerning equality of opportunity , the function and limitations of government in the securing of such equality , and the spotlight that world opinion plays upon local incidents of racial agitation and strife .	111.17005
( 2 ) realtors realize , of course , that they are involved in an increasingly complex legal and political system that is opening up opportunities for leverage on their relation to clients as well as opportunities for evasion of their responsibility for racial discrimination in housing .	97.454605
on the positive side , recent federal action has largely undermined the legal sanction so long enjoyed by the segregationist position	238.2268
anti-discriminatory statutes in housing have now been adopted by thirteen states and , while specific provisions have varied , the tendency is clearly toward expanding coverage .	126.8062
realtors in attendance at the colloquium expressed interest , for example , in connecticut ' s new housing law as setting standards of equity that they would like `` to have to obey ' ' , but in support of which none had been willing to go on public record .	76.432076
as far as they were aware , the connecticut association of real estate boards had not officially opposed the bill ' s passage or lobbied in its support .	133.42976
( this has not been the case everywhere .	9.402159
in 1957 , the real estate boards of new york city actively opposed the then pending private housing anti-discrimination law .	239.2087
official reasoning the bill was a `` wanton invasion of basic property rights ' ' .	108.29529
there are sins of omission as well as commission	6557.054
the attitude adopted by realtors and their associations , either negative or positive , plays a large part in the public acceptance of such measures and the degree to which they may be effectively enforced .	88.82008
judicial opinion since the supreme court decision on shelley v . kraemer ( 1948 ) has rendered racial restrictive covenants unenforcible .	51.052773
such a decision should have placed a powerful weapon in the hands of the entire housing industry , but there is little evidence that realtors , or at least their associations , have repudiated the principle in such clauses .	64.97109
in the states that have passed laws preventing discrimination in the sale or rental of housing , support by real estate associations for compliance and broadened coverage through additional legislation could help remove the label of `` social reformism ' ' that most realtors individually seem determined to avoid .	130.06134
but as yet , no real estate board has been willing officially to support such laws or to admit the permissibility of introducing minority buyers into all-white neighborhoods .	135.18887
one of the roles of the social scientist , ethicist or theologian in our discussions with the realtors became that of encouraging greater awareness of the opportunities offered by the legal and political processes for the exercise of broad social responsibilities in their work .	93.68669
but responsiveness to these opportunities presumes that all of us judge the good as a human good and not simply as a professional , white , american good .	263.6411
such judgments are meaningful only in so far as persons are members of a world , let us say a community , that embraces scarsdale or yonkers , but is also infinitely richer since it is all-inclusive .	154.29002
that community of all creation is , then , the ultimate object of our loyalty and the concrete norm of all moral judgment .	112.259186
racial discrimination is wrong , then , not because it goes against the grain of a faculty member trying to converse with a few realtors but because it goes against the grain of creation and against the will of the creator .	94.10348
thus , moral issues concerning the nature of the legal and political processes take on theological dimensions .	126.91031
( 3 ) over the years , individuals engaged in the sale of real estate have developed remarkable unity in the methods and practices employed .	71.06769
most realtors and real estate brokers talk of themselves as `` professional people ' ' with the cultural and moral values held by the traditional professions .	79.925995
but what significance attaches to `` professional ' ' , beyond the narrow sense of skillfulness in meeting a client ' s stated needs as already noted ? ?	112.17663
our faculty and students pressed this issue more than any other .	40.15616
as a theologian in the group pointed out , a professional was , before the modern period of technical specialization , one who `` professed ' ' to be a bearer and critic of his culture in the use of his particular skills .	111.687836
if we look about the world today , we can see clearly that there are two especially significant factors shaping the future of our civilization science and religion .	84.52082
science is placing in our hands the ultimate power of the universe , the power of the atom .	15.13298
religion , or the lack of it , will decide whether we use this power to build a brave new world of peace and abundance for all mankind , or whether we misuse this power to leave a world utterly destroyed .	118.50174
how can we have the wisdom to meet such a new and difficult challenge ? ?	69.828636
and yet there is a note of hope , because this same science that is giving us the power of the atom is also giving us atomic vision .	107.086296
we are looking inside the atom and seeing there a universe which is not material but something beyond the material , a universe that in a word is not matter but music .	178.87674
and it is in this new vision of the atom that we find an affirmation and an invigoration of our faith .	45.100945
to see this vision in perspective , we need first of all a clear idea of the magnitude of this new power from the atom .	150.0556
you know that i could hold right here in my hand the little chunk of uranium metal that was the heart of the bomb that dropped on hiroshima .	126.43277
it was only about the size of a baseball	642.89905
but packed in that metallic ball there was the explosive force of 20 , 000 tons of aj .	40.804905
that is enough tnt to fill the tower of the empire state building	183.90703
and with the availability of bombs of that size , war became a new problem .	497.73236
now we might have restricted the use of uranium bombs by controlling the sources of uranium because it is found in only a few places in the world .	43.260555
but we had hardly started to adjust our thinking to this new uranium weapon when we were faced with the hydrogen bomb .	96.6011
hydrogen is just as plentiful as uranium is scarce .	1944.4645
water is af and the h stands for hydrogen	7243.9106
there is also hydrogen in wood and hydrogen in our bodies .	87.6029
i have calculated that if i could snap my fingers in one magic gesture to release the power of all the hydrogen in my body , i would explode with the force of a hundred bombs of the kind that fell on hiroshima .	105.934074
i won ' t try the experiment , but i think you can see that if we all knew the secret and we could all let ourselves go , there would be quite an explosion .	85.680756
and then think how little hydrogen we have in us compared with the hydrogen in delaware bay or in the ocean beyond .	161.36397
salt water is still af , the same hydrogen is there .	120.51695
and the size of the ocean shows us the magnitude of the destructive power we hold in our hands today .	43.953186
of course , there is also an optimistic side to the picture .	65.00562
for if i knew the secret of letting this power in my body change directly into electricity , i could rent myself out to the electric companies and with just the power in my body i could light all the lights and run all the factories in the entire united states for some days .	150.8797
and think , if we all knew this secret and we could pool our power , what a wonderful public utility company we would make .	165.97194
with just the hydrogen of our bodies , we could run the world for years .	105.70771
then think of delaware bay and the ocean and you see that we have a supply of power for millions of years to come .	73.43822
it is power with which we can literally rebuild the world , provide adequate housing , food , education , abundant living for everyone everywhere .	92.77198
now let us see where this power comes from .	187.84769
to grasp our new view of the atom , we have to appreciate first of all how small the atom is .	108.5745
i have been trying to make this clear to my own class in chemistry .	64.82142
one night there were some dried peas lying on our kitchen table , and these peas looked to me like a little group of atoms	126.61551
and i asked myself a question suppose i had the same number of peas as there are atoms in my body , how large an area would they cover ? ?	187.10419
i calculated first that there are about an octillion atoms in the average human body	298.4142
that is a figure one with 27 ciphers , quite a large number .	104.7454
then i calculated that a million peas would just about fill a household refrigerator	242.21925
a billion peas would fill a small house from cellar to attic	114.381256
a trillion peas would fill all the houses in a town of about ten thousand people	60.02224
and a quadrillion peas would fill all the buildings in the city of philadelphia .	42.703487
i saw that i would soon run out of buildings at this rate , so i decided to take another measure -- the whole state of pennsylvania .	112.7084
imagine that there is a blizzard over pennsylvania , but instead of snowing snow , it snows peas	150.41013
so we get the whole state covered with peas , about four feet deep .	51.26353
you can imagine what it would look like going out on the turnpike with the peas banked up against the houses and covering the cars	66.0159
pennsylvania thus blanketed would contain about a quintillion peas .	11.107106
but we still have a long way to go .	55.44806
next we imagine our blizzard raging over all the land areas of the entire globe -- north america , south america , europe , asia , and africa , all covered with peas four feet deep	53.957764
next we freeze over the oceans and cover the whole earth with peas , then we go out among the neighboring stars , collect 250 planets each the size of the earth , and also cover each of these with peas four feet deep	116.17054
finally we go into the farthest reaches of the milky way	196.47708
we cover each of these with our blanket of peas and then at last we have octillion peas corresponding in number to the atoms in the body .	127.07834
so you see how small an atom is and how complicated you are .	346.27155
now although an atom is small , we can still in imagination have a look at it .	184.87991
let us focus on an atom of calcium from the tip of the bone of my finger and let us suppose that i swallow a magic alice in wonderland growing pill .	142.33574
i start growing rapidly and this calcium atom grows along with me .	96.08111
i shoot up through the roof , into the sky , past the clouds , through the stratosphere , out beyond the moon , out among the planets , until i am over a hundred and fifty million miles long .	101.56974
then this atom of calcium will swell to something like a great balloon a hundred yards across , a balloon big enough to put a football field inside .	114.14817
and if you should step inside of such a magnified atom , according to the physics of forty years ago , you would see circulating over your head , down at the sides , and under your feet , some twenty luminous balls about the size of footballs .	92.866516
these balls are moving in great circles and ellipses , and are of course , the electrons , the particles of negative electricity which by their action create the forces that tie this atom of calcium to the neighboring atoms of oxygen and make up the solid structure of my finger bone .	98.44468
since these electrons are moving like planets , you may wonder whether there is an atomic sun at the center of the atom .	32.616287
so you look down there and you see a tiny , whirling point about the size of the head of a pin .	59.098583
this is the atomic sun , the atomic nucleus .	147.96107
even if the atom were big enough to hold a football field , this nucleus is still only about the size of a pinhead .	50.931694
it is this atomic nucleus that contains the positive charge of electricity holding these negatively charged electrons in their orbits	339.52094
it also contains nearly all the mass , and the atomic energy .	11.005048
you may ask what else there is , and the answer is nothing -- nothing but empty space .	61.511463
and since you are made of atoms , you are nothing much but empty space , too .	117.59205
if i could put your body in an imaginary atomic press and squeeze you down , squeeze these holes out of you in the way we squeeze the holes out of a sponge , you would get smaller and smaller until finally when the last hole was gone , you would be smaller than the smallest speck of dust that you could see on this piece of paper .	86.997955
someone has remarked that this is certainly the ultimate in reducing .	500.515
at any rate , it shows us how immaterial we are .	292.6577
now this 1920 view of the atom was on the whole a discouraging picture .	106.096504
for we believed that the electrons obeyed the law of mechanics and electrodynamics	45.17209
and therefore the atom was really just a little machine	63.50552
and in mechanics the whole is no more than the sum of the parts .	22.664936
so if you are made of atoms , you are just a big machine	155.74783
and since the universe is also made of atoms , it is just a supermachine .	54.47969
and this would mean that we live in a mechanistic universe , governed by the laws of cause and effect , bound in chains of determinism that hold the universe on a completely predetermined course in which there is not room for soul or spirit or human freedom .	125.77919
and this is why so many scientists a half a century ago were agnostics or atheists .	227.63683
then came the scientific revolution in the late 1920 ' s .	25.007006
a suggestion from louis de broglie , a physicist in france , showed us that these electrons are not point particles but waves .	231.34943
and to see the meaning of this new picture , imagine that you can put on more powerful glasses and go back inside the atom and have a look at it in the way we view it today .	77.259796
now as you step inside , instead of seeing particles orbiting around like planets , you see waves and ripples very much like the ripples that you get on the surface of a pond when you drop a stone into it .	123.92179
these ripples spread out in symmetrical patterns like the rose windows of a great cathedral .	67.127
and as the waves flow back and forth and merge with the waves from the neighboring atoms , you can put on a magic hearing aid and you hear music .	70.14627
it is a music like the music from a great organ or a vast orchestra playing a symphony .	79.307785
harmony , melody , counterpoint symphonic structure are there	4052.2356
and as this music ebbs and flows , there is an antiphonal chorus from all the atoms outside , in fact from the atoms of the entire universe .	57.363186
and so today when we examine the structure of our knowledge of the atom and of the universe , we are forced to conclude that the best word to describe our universe is music .	44.087475
the island of nantucket , part of the state of massachusetts , lies about thirty-one miles southeast of its mother state .	213.90518
some of the island is sand and is not suitable for living .	66.78634
the island folk have their living almost entirely from summer visitors	1295.152
during about three and a half months of the year , in the summer , there are three boats that run from the mainland to the island carrying passengers , food , and cars	62.571514
but the rest of the year only one boat is needed , which ties up at the mainland nights and makes the trip down to nantucket in the daytime .	189.49901
this is a fine trip , too , on a good day .	50.233578
with martha ' s vineyard on one side and the open sea on the other , it makes an excellent trip of about three hours .	71.22479
to what extent and in what ways did christianity affect the united states of america in the nineteenth century ? ?	21.772722
how far and in what fashion did it modify the new nation which was emerging in the midst of the forces shaping the revolutionary age ? ?	78.6288
to what extent did it mould the morals and the social , economic , and political life and institutions of the country ? ?	43.025978
a complete picture is impossible -- partly because of the limitations of space , partly because for millions of individuals who professed allegiance to the christian faith data are unobtainable .	103.09193
even more of an obstacle is the difficulty of separating the influence of christianity from other factors .	73.600845
although a complete picture cannot be given , we can indicate some aspects of life into which the christian faith entered as at least one creative factor .	140.58392
at times we can say that it was the major factor .	57.015247
what in some ways was the most important aspect was the impact individually on the millions who constituted the nation .	135.93349
as we have seen , a growing proportion , although in 1914 still a minority , were members of churches .	158.92477
presumably those who did not have a formal church connexion had also felt the influence of christianity to a greater or lesser extent .	124.97034
many of them had once been members of a church or at least had been given instruction in christianity but for one or another reason had allowed the connexion to lapse .	160.1629
the form of christianity to which they were exposed was for some the protestantism of the older stock , for others the protestantism of the nineteenth-century immigration	63.918938
for still others , mostly of the nineteenth-century immigration , it was roman catholicism , and for a small minority it was eastern orthodoxy .	82.26439
upon all of them played the intellectual , social , political , and economic attitudes , institutions , and customs of the nation .	42.260986
upon most of these christianity had left an impress and through them had had a share in making the individual what he was .	184.4766
yet to determine precisely to what extent and exactly in what ways any individual showed the effects of christianity would be impossible .	143.9851
at best only an approximation could be arrived at .	288.02927
to generalize for the entire nation would be absurd .	19.011633
for instance , we cannot know whether even for church members the degree of conformity to christian standards of morality increased or declined as the proportion of church members in the population rose .	169.84645
the temptation is to say that , as the percentage of church members mounted , the degree of discipline exercised by the churches lessened and the trend was towards conformity to the general level .	92.8818
we know that in the early part of the century many protestant congregations took positive action against members who transgressed the ethical codes to which the majority subscribed .	213.05478
thus baptist churches on the frontier took cognizance of charges against their members of drunkenness , fighting , malicious gossip , lying , cheating , sexual irregularities , gambling , horse racing , and failure to pay just debts .	76.66842
if guilty , the offender might be excluded from membership .	44.332043
as church membership burgeoned , such measures faded into desuetude .	78.3499
but whether this was accompanied by a general lowering of the moral life of the membership we do not know .	70.46704
what we can attempt with some hope of dependable conclusions is to point out the manner in which christianity entered into particular aspects of the life of the nation .	89.209984
we have already hinted at the fashion in which christianity contributed to education and so to intellectual life .	146.22995
we will now speak of the ways in which it helped shape the ideals of the country and of the manner in which it stimulated efforts to attain those ideals through reform movements , through programmes for bringing the collective life to the nation to conformity to christian standards , and through leaders in the government .	75.13012
throughout the nineteenth century christianity exerted its influence on american society as a whole primarily through the protestantism of the older stock .	46.221775
by the end of the century the roman catholic church was beginning to make itself felt , mainly through such institutions as hospitals but also through its attitude towards organized labour .	140.32747
in the twentieth century its influence grew , as did that of the protestantism of the nineteenth-century immigration .	48.55635
the ideals of the country were deeply indebted to the protestantism of the older stock .	18.454504
thus `` america ' ' , the most widely sung of the patriotic songs , was written by a new england baptist clergyman , samuel francis smith ( 1808-1895 ) , while a student in andover theological seminary .	42.59561
with its zeal for liberty and its dependence on god it breathed the spirit which had been nourished on the evangelical revivals .	52.050365
the great seal of the united states was obviously inspired by the christian faith .	39.024544
here was what was called the american dream , namely , the effort to build a structure which would be something new in history and to do so in such fashion that god could bless it .	90.14453
later in the century the dream again found expression in the lines of katherine lee bates ( 1859-1929 ) , daughter and granddaughter of new england congregational ministers , in her widely sung hymn , written in 1893 , `` america the beautiful ' ' , with the words `` o beautiful for pilgrim feet whose stern impassioned stress a thoroughfare for freedom beat across the wilderness .	109.404976
america , america , god mend thy every flaw , confirm thy soul in self control , the liberty in law .	234.1035
o beautiful for patriot dream that sees beyond the years thine alabaster cities gleam undimmed by human tears .	53.63367
america , america , god shed his grace on thee , and crown thy good with brotherhood from sea to shining sea ' ' .	59.140556
the american dream was compounded of many strains .	42.543278
some were clearly of christian origin , among them the great awakening and other revivals which helped to make christian liberty , christian equality , and christian fraternity the passion of the land .	100.2823
some have seen revivalism and the search for christian perfection as the fountain-head of the american hope .	167.40518
here , too , must be placed unitarianism and , less obviously from christian inspiration , emerson , transcendentalism , and the idealism of walt whitman .	65.3871
we must also remember those who reacted against the dream as a kind of myth -- among them melville , hawthorne , and henry james the elder , all of them out of a christian background .	90.34843
with such a dream arising , at least in part , from the protestant heritage of the united states and built into the foundations of the nation , it is not surprising that many efforts were made to give it concrete expression .	49.545143
a number were in the nature of movements to relieve or remove social ills .	422.15842
significantly , the initiation and leadership of a major proportion of the reform movements , especially those in the first half of the nineteenth century , came from men and women of new england birth or parentage and from either trinitarian or unitarian congregationalism .	49.266117
several of the movements were given a marked impetus by revivalism .	64.69602
quakers , some from new england , had a larger share than their proportionate numerical strength would have warranted .	192.87172
