on the basis of what they give us we can know how the young caruso sang , appreciate the distinctive qualities of parsifal under karl muck ' s baton , or sense the type of ensemble toscanini created in his years with the new york philharmonic .	119.44869
since the concept of high fidelity became important some dozen years ago , the claims of technical improvements have multiplied tenfold .	152.35295
in many cases the revolutionary production has offered no more than sensational effects the first hearing was fascinating and the second disillusioning as the gap between sound and substance became clearer .	129.13734
other innovations with better claims to musical interest survived rehearing to acquire in time the status of classics .	175.54808
if we return to them today , we have no difficulty spotting their weaknesses but we find them still pleasing .	130.92226
records sound like records because they provide a different sort of experience than live music .	136.22522
this difference is made up of many factors .	7.953704
some of them are obvious , such as the fact that we associate recorded and live music with our responses and behavior in different types of environments and social settings .	142.97589
( music often sounds best to me when i can dress informally and sit in something more comfortable than a theatre seat .	93.34427
) from the technical standpoint , records differ from live music to the degree that they fail to convey the true color , texture , complexity , range , intensity , pulse , and pitch of the original .	83.26212
any alteration of one of these factors is distortion , although we generally use that word only for effects so pronounced that they can be stated quantitatively on the basis of standard tests .	132.09187
yet it is the accumulation of distortion , the fitting together of fractional bits until the total reaches the threshold of our awareness , that makes records sound like records .	161.14221
but if you know the real thing , you know that what you are hearing is only a clever imitation .	171.61894
command ' s new brahms second is a major effort to make a record that sounds like a real orchestra rather than a copy of one .	72.110886
like the recent scheherazade from london ( high fidelity , sept . 1961 ) , it is successful because emphasis has been placed on good musical and engineering practices rather than on creating sensational effects .	110.153694
because of this , only those with truly fine equipment will be able to appreciate the exact degree of the engineers ' triumph .	77.06243
the easiest way to describe this release is to say that it reproduces an interesting and effective steinberg performance with minimal alteration of its musical values .	84.45954
the engineering as such never obtrudes upon your consciousness .	224.11034
the effect of the recording is very open and natural , with the frequency emphasis exactly what you would expect from a live performance .	164.20587
this absence of peaky highs and beefed-up bass not only produces greater fidelity , but it eliminates listener fatigue .	213.7448
a contributing factor is the perspective , the uniform aesthetic distance which is maintained .	306.88303
the orchestra is far enough away from you that you miss the bow scrapes , valve clicks , and other noises incidental to playing .	116.3101
yet you feel the orchestra is near at hand , and the individual instruments have the same firm presence associated with listening from a good seat in an acoustically perfect hall .	115.85096
command has achieved the ideal amount of reverberation .	8.084444
the music is always allowed the living space needed to attain its full sonority	124.605095
yet the hall never intrudes as a quasi-performer .	29.14651
the timbre remains that of the instruments unclouded by resonance .	41.814938
all of this would be wasted , of course , if the performance lacked authority and musical distinction .	128.43985
for me it has more of both elements than the majority of its competitors .	37.363815
steinberg seems to have gone directly back to the score , discounting tradition , and has built his performance on the intention to reproduce as faithfully as possible exactly what brahms set down on paper .	106.356094
those accustomed to broader , more romantic statements of the symphony can be expected to react strongly when they hear this one .	109.620445
without losing the distinctive undertow of brahmsian rhythm , the pacing is firm and the over-all performance has a tightly knit quality that makes for maximum cumulative effect .	116.3385
the presto ma non assai of the first trio of the scherzo is taken literally and may shock you , as the real allegro con spirito of the finale is likely to bring you to your feet .	125.02588
in the end , however , the thing about this performance that is most striking is the way it sings .	207.07632
steinberg obviously has concluded that it is the lyric element which must dominate in this score , and he manages at times to create the effect of the whole orchestra bursting into song .	131.46683
the engineering provides exactly the support needed for such a result .	79.55485
too many records seem to reduce a work of symphonic complexity to a melody and its accompaniment .	74.76445
the command technique invites you to listen to the depth of the orchestration .	65.9347
your ear takes you into the ensemble , and you may well become aware of instrumental details which previously were apparent only in the score .	188.1106
it is this sort of experience that makes the concept of high fidelity of real musical significance for the home music listener .	150.90445
the first substantially complete stereo giselle ( and the only one of its scope since feyer ' s four-sided lp edition of 1958 for angel ) , this set is , i ' m afraid , likely to provide more horrid fascination than enjoyment .	150.52205
the already faded pastel charms of the naive music itself vanish entirely in fistoulari ' s melodramatic contrasts between ultravehement brute power and chilly , if suave , sentimentality .	91.403175
and in its engineers ' frantic attempts to achieve maximum dynamic impact and earsplitting brilliance , the recording sounds as though it had been `` doctored for super-high fidelity ' ' .	131.49367
the home listener is overpowered , all right , but the experience is a far from pleasant one .	86.38925
as with the penultimate giselle release ( wolff ' s abridgment for rca victor ) i find the cleaner , less razor-edged monophonic version , for all its lack of big-stage spaciousness , the more aurally tolerable -- but this may be the result of processing defects in my sd copies .	94.921165
at the westminster kc dog show in madison square garden , new york on the second day , the finals of the junior class brought out the most competitive competition in the history of this class .	42.20976
the class had entries from as far west as wisconsin and as far south as kentucky .	127.35951
this year several entries from canada were entered which made the junior class international .	364.50565
forty-six of the 53 juniors who mailed in entries were present .	63.512062
it was interesting to note that many of these juniors were showing dogs in various other classes at the show prior to the finals of the junior class .	70.43771
as has been the custom for the past several years , john cross , jr . , bench show chmn . of westminster , arranged for the juniors ' meeting before the class , and invited two speakers from the dog world to address them .	157.55452
over 60 juniors , parents and guests attended .	55.05324
mrs . william h . long , jr . speaks	106.725075
after the juniors were welcomed and congratulated for qualifying for the finals of the junior class , mrs . william h . long , jr . was introduced as the first speaker .	36.857864
in her opening remarks mrs . long also welcomed the juniors and stated , `` there isn ' t any other show quite like westminster .	70.73255
i know because this is my 37th year with hardly a break .	396.8361
mrs . long still feels the same unique spirit of westminster which she stated the present juniors will experience today but probably will not appreciate in full for a number of years .	229.93092
twenty years ago her daughter betsey long , then 13 years of age , won the grand challenge trophy , children ' s handling class ( as they were called then ) at westminster .	235.6276
no sooner had betsey come out of the ring than mrs . long walked into the working competition with ch . cadet or noranda , another home-bred product , and won ! !	183.95221
speaking from long years of experience , mrs . long advised the juniors `` when showing dogs ceases to be fun and excitement , stop ! !	129.54643
dogs have a way of sensing our feelings ! !	81.12494
when you and your dog step into the junior ring , it should be just what the dog wants to do as much as what you want him to do .	81.38127
if you walk into the ring because it is fun to show your dog , he will feel it and give you a good performance ! !	89.29962
he knows your signals , what is expected of him and the way the class is conducted , right up through the flash-bulbs of the photographers ' ' .	136.09116
`` take away your attitude ' ' , said mrs . long , `` and what have you left ? ?	72.052864
either a nervous dog because you are livid with rage -- a sure sign that you are taking things too seriously and had better stop ! !	100.11957
or a bored dog because you are more interested in something else -- maybe the way you look , or the date you have after the class , or you are just doing this to please the parents .	84.91987
`` the reason you are in the ring today is to show your ability to present to any judge the most attractive picture of your dog that the skillful use of your aids can produce .	204.16855
aids sounds more like a pony club , or horsemanship classes -- riding a horse and showing a dog are very similar ! !	182.80766
`` your aids are your attitude , which comes through your voice , your hands and legs -- voice to encourage , discourage or whatever the need may be	236.92697
legs to produce motion and rate of speed .	7.293769
without right attitude the other aids just do not work right ' ' .	39.475903
mrs . long wished all the juniors luck in the class and stated , `` have fun ! !	43.99205
and may you all continue to show at westminster in the years to come ' ' ! !	27.129503
the second speaker was harvey barcus , president of the dog writers ass ' n of america .	76.69036
mr . barcus spoke on the subject of scholarships for juniors -- with which he is very familiar .	93.771736
last year a boy he knows and helped in journalism won the thoroughbred racing ass ' n scholarship which is worth $10 , 000 .	113.35635
he gave a resume of the steps taken in order for the boy he sponsored to win the scholarship .	105.75511
`` junior showmanship is an extremely worthy project and should be earnestly encouraged ' ' ! !	86.907906
is one of mr . barcus ' strong beliefs .	236.1334
he feels very forcibly that the american kennel club should take a more active part in encouraging the junior division ! !	173.5939
in closing , mr . barcus also wished all the juniors luck in their class .	52.79046
instead of 3 a . m . in the past , the juniors class at westminster was held at 4 45 p . m . .	41.884975
this gave the juniors the use of the entire ring at the show -- a great advantage to them ! !	79.90298
before the juniors entered the ring the steward announced that after all juniors had moved their dogs around the ring and set them up , they could relax with their dogs .	127.711876
from there on , each junior was going to be judged individually .	19.71318
this thoughtful gesture was well received by the juniors as the class had an entry of 46 juniors and it took approximately one hour , 45 minutes to judge the class .	100.63722
this year anne hone rogers , outstanding handler , judged the class .	54.42676
this is the third time in 28 years of junior showmanship at westminster that a lady handler has judged the class .	61.439617
as the juniors entered the ring , mr . spring , the announcer , stated over the public-address system that this was the 28th year that westminster has held the finals of the junior competition .	138.62213
juniors competed last year at american kennel club and canadian kennel club , recognized shows to be eligible to compete in this class -- the finals for the year .	56.18031
a junior who won two or more wins in the open class was eligible .	124.15541
( the purpose of the junior showmanship competition is to teach and encourage juniors to become good sportsmen .	87.49131
many adults showing at westminster today are products of this class .	17.889738
it seemed an almost impossible job for miss rogers to select 4 winners from the 46 juniors entered .	95.68576
a large number of these juniors have 7 and 8 wins to their credit and are seasoned campaigners .	46.730824
after the judge moved all the dogs individually , she selected several from the group and placed them in the center of the ring .	59.978207
she then went over them thoroughly giving each a strenuous test in showmanship .	181.30316
betty lou ham , age 16 , holyoke , mass . , showing an irish setter , was chosen as international champion of the year .	51.98957
she was awarded the professional handlers ' ass ' ns ' leonard brumby , sr . memorial trophy ( named for the founder-originator of the junior classes .	44.602886
betty is 16 years of age and had several wins to her credit last year .	113.0227
in addition to showing an irish setter throughout the year , she also scored with an afghan .	48.86414
sydney le blanc , age 15 , staten island , n . y . , showing a doberman pinscher , was 2nd .	26.02364
susan hackmann , age 14 , from baltimore , md . , showing a dachshund , was 3rd .	53.024757
last year susan also placed 3rd in the finals at westminster .	27.384104
from the records we keep -- susan is the only junior who has placed in the junior classes in both united states and canada .	48.51433
karen marcmann , age 16 , trapp , penna . , showing a keeshond was 4th .	189.74603
most juniors who were entered in the finals are seasoned campaigners and not only show and win in junior classes but score in the breed classes as well .	116.4414
in 1960 , there were 7287 entries in the junior classes .	9.938572
each year these shows have increased in entries .	6.9140368
next year 1962 , at westminster , the bench show committee has raised the requirements so that a junior must win 3 or more junior classes in the open division only to qualify for westminster .	253.41162
percy roberts , a leading judge will not be at the international show this year for the junior judging contest as he has been invited to judge in australia in march .	76.07085
it has been suggested many times that a class be set up for the juniors who are overage and cannot enter the junior classes .	89.38951
for some time this writer has been suggesting a junior judging class for intermediates over 16 and under 20 years of age who are ineligible to compete in the junior class .	43.669304
such a class was tried out successfully at the westchester kc show recently .	162.3206
not only were the contestants pleased with the class , but it aroused the interest of all in attendance that day .	86.926346
the intermediates in the class with the judge were asked to pick 4 winners and give their reasons but their decisions did not affect the choice of the judge .	109.60298
we suggested this class in the horse world and it was accepted immediately and included in the programs of horse shows .	165.32086
at the recent horse show convention in new york it was stated that this intermediate judging class is meeting with great success and will be a great help to future judges in the horse world .	91.22309
this class can be just as successful in the dog world if it is given a chance .	145.02992
last year robert harris , a leading junior handler entered the dog judging contest ( junior ) at the international kc of chicago show and had the highest score in judging of any junior since the class ' inception .	68.0765
juniors who attend this chicago show should make a point to enter this class as it would be of great help to them .	79.58611
superintendents at dog shows state it is becoming more difficult to obtain a licensed handler to judge junior showmanship competition .	41.244312
the founder of the junior showmanship competition the late leonard brumby , sr . ( for whom the trophy is named after at westminster ) was an outstanding handler and believed a junior should have an opportunity to exhibit in a dog show starting with the junior showmanship division .	82.42101
some years ago this class was judged by celebrities who knew nothing of what was required of a junior ' s ability to show a dog .	63.522327
to overcome this unfair judging , the a . k . c . requires that a licensed handler be present to judge the class .	63.866898
if the superintendents do not receive more cooperation from handlers , it has been suggested that licensed judges also be qualified to judge this class .	51.322926
by recognizing and helping juniors get interested in the dog world , all will be helping to create future dog owners .	78.05996
the airedale terrier club of america and the kerry blue terrier club of america have under consideration donating trophies to the boys or girls who win with their breeds in junior showmanship competition at any show .	99.702614
the kansas city and the topeka kcs are arranging that juniors who win at their shows will be qualified to win points for westminster .	132.59616
the rio grande kc is also considering having their junior classes set up so that juniors can qualify with points for westminster .	222.14404
the american pointer club is still continuing to donate trophies to juniors who win at junior showmanship classes with pointers .	94.635124
traveling through the south -- over 16 , 000 miles -- with two great danes , an afghan , and a persian kitten , we ' ve worked up a regular routine for acceptance at motels .	84.43119
my husband enters the motel office , signs up for a room , and then solemnly asks the proprieter if he accepts pets .	65.28563
`` no ' ' , he replies , `` full grown , adult show dogs , housebroken , and obedience-trained ' ' .	67.24923
once settled , we ' re careful to walk the dogs in an out of the way spot , keep them under control in the room , and feed and bench them where they can ' t do any harm to the furnishings or the furniture .	111.887085
in the morning we leave the room looking as neat as a pin ! !	100.299576
many a motel owner -- when we ' ve stopped there again -- has remembered us and has said he preferred our dogs to most children .	189.61986
so many times i have wondered why veterinarians do not wipe the table clean before each new canine patient is placed on it for examination .	192.70645
is it that they don ' t care ? ?	5.0411353
are they indifferent to the fact that the dog can easily pick up germs from the preceding patient ? ?	176.98532
at one time , to most americans , unless they were fortunate enough to live near a body of navigable water , boats were considered the sole concern of fishermen , rich people , and the united states navy .	105.196434
today the recreational boating scene is awash with heartening statistics which prove the enormous growth of that sport .	124.372696
there are more than 8 , 000 , 000 recreational boats in use in the united states with almost 10 , 000 , 000 the prediction for within the next decade .	62.582195
about 40 , 000 , 000 people participated in boating in 1960 .	41.806934
boating has become a giant whose strides cover the entire nation from sea to shining sea .	65.47418
boats are operated in every state in the union , with the heaviest concentrations along both coasts and in the middle west .	84.83022
the spectacular upsurge in pleasure boating is markedly evident , expectedly , in the areas where boats have always been found the natural lakes , rivers , and along the nation ' s coastline .	84.83123
but during the last several years boats were launched in areas where , a short time ago , the only water to be found was in wells and watering troughs for livestock .	99.8812
developed as a result of the multi-purpose resources control program of the government , vast , man-made bodies of water represent a kind of glorious fringe benefit , providing boating and fishing havens all over the country .	89.456375
no matter how determined or wealthy boating lovers of the southwest had been , for example , they could never have created anything approaching the fifty square-mile lake texoma , located between texas and oklahoma , which resulted when the corp of army engineers dammed the red river .	87.45019
in 1959 , according to the engineers , lake texoma was only one of thirty-two artificial lakes and reservoirs which were used for recreation by over 1 , 000 , 000 persons .	69.3682
where an opportunity to enjoy boating has not been created by bringing bodies of water to the people , means have been found to take the people and their boats to the water .	78.95232
providing these means are about ninety companies which manufactured the estimated 1 , 800 , 000 boat trailers now in use .	79.386604
it is a simple task to haul a boat fifty or one hundred miles to a lake or reservoir on the new , light , strong , easy-to-operate trailers which are built to accommodate almost any kind of small boat and retail from $100 to $2 , 000 .	95.39611
the sight of sleek inboards , outboards , and sailboats being wheeled smartly along highways many miles from any water is commonplace .	153.95836
boatmen lucky enough to have facilities for year- ' round anchorage for their craft , will recall the tedious procedure of loading their gear into the car , driving to the water , and making trip after trip to transfer the gear to the boat .	84.40482
today , the boat , on its trailer , is brought to the gear and loaded at the door .	85.8845
arriving at the waterside , the boat is launched , the family taken aboard and , that easily , another day afloat is begun .	230.17369
and trailers for boats are not what they started out to be ten years ago .	73.02741
this year , americans will discover previously unheard of refinements in trailers that will be exhibited in about one hundred of our nation ' s national , regional and local boat shows .	146.71591
the boats of america ' s trailer sailors in 1961 will be coddled on clouds as they are hauled to new horizons .	133.25879
the variety of craft on the country ' s waters today is overwhelming .	160.82036
they range from an eight-foot pram , which you can build yourself for less than $50 , to auxiliary sailboats which can cost over $100 , 000 .	66.57461
boat prices vary according to the buyer ' s desires or needs .	98.60008
in this respect , boats can be compared with houses .	64.19742
there is no limit to what you can spend , yet it is easily possible to keep within a set budget .	150.2416
there is no question as to just what is available .	63.866566
you name it , our industry is producing it , and it probably is made in different models .	78.704414
there are canoes ideal for fishing in protected waters or for camping trips .	108.924
there are houseboats which are literally homes afloat , accommodating whole families in comfort and convenience .	189.18753
you can cross an ocean in a fully equipped craft , sail , power , or both , or laze away a fine day in a small dinghy on a local pond .	120.90421
you may have your boat of wood , canvas , plywood , plastic , or metal .	42.983307
you may order utility models , inboard or outboard , with or without toilets , galleys , and bunks .	63.50531
you may dress it up with any number of accessories or keep it as simple as you choose .	125.04006
designers and manufacturers have produced models for purchasers who run the gamut from a nautical version of the elderly pasadena lady who never drove more than five miles an hour on her once-a-month ride around the block , to the sportiest boatman who insists on all the dash , color , flair and speed possible to encompass in a single boat .	157.37784
you pay your money and you take your choice .	86.53743
american technology in engine and hull design is largely responsible for the plentiful interest in american boating .	77.93473
i wonder if anyone ever bothered to make the point that when it comes to boats and their motors , americans excel over any country in the world in the long run .	125.150116
russia , whose technology is not quite primitive , is still in the dark ages when it comes to improving the outboard motor , for instance .	57.64718
the outboard engine of today has a phenomenal range of one to 80 horsepower , unheard of a few years ago for a two cycle engine in quantity production .	101.342125
these engines can be removed from a boat with relative ease , wherein lies their greatest advantage .	249.99345
their cost is not beyond the hopes of the american pocketbook , the range being about $150 to $1 , 000 , depending on size .	107.14028
great thought has been given to making life easier for the growing boating population of the country	270.7855
and to making the owning of a boat simpler .	66.05948
there was a time when , if a man wanted to purchase a boat , it was necessary for him to be able to produce a sizeable amount of cash before he could touch the tiller or wheel .	52.187424
having a boat financed through a local bank is done much the same way as an automobile loan is extended .	94.36599
marine dealers and even some manufacturers who sell direct in non-dealer areas cooperate in enabling you to launch now and pay later .	831.71814
terms range from one to five years and the interest rates and down payments run about the same as for automobiles .	173.2134
of course , individual financing arrangements depend a good deal on the purchaser ' s earning power , credit rating and local bank policy .	115.829315
outboard motors , insurance , and boat repairs may also be financed in the same way as boats .	33.164936
terms and rates of interest for motors generally follow those for home appliances .	53.01204
when the automobile was in its embryonic stage , such roads as existed were pretty much open roads with the tacit understanding that horses should not be unduly terrified being about the only rule governing where , when and how fast a car could go .	274.02707
when air travel was in its infancy , the sky was considered big enough and high enough for all .	93.9152
man had enough to worry about managing to get up there and stay without being burdened with rules once aloft .	212.36731
it was much the same with pleasure boating at first .	63.69157
come one , come all , the water ' s fine ! !	42.654865
as the ungoverned days of the automobile and the airplane are long since relegated to the past , so is the carefree attitude toward what a boatman may and may not do	135.04883
however , there is a minimum of legislative restriction on boating .	117.85032
laws on boating vary according to the state in which the craft is to be used and according to its horsepower .	75.64643
what may be acceptable in one state may be strictly prohibited across the boundary line .	62.722935
the main requirement is to be sure the boat is numbered according to the regulations of the state in which the boat will be principally used .	61.124348
if your state has no provisions for the numbering of pleasure boats , you must apply for a number from the u . s . coast guard for any kind of boat with mechanical propulsion rated at more than 10 horsepower before it can be used on federal waterways .	73.12351
state numbering laws differ from each other in many ways .	29.277285
fees are not the same and some states do not require certain craft , such as sailboats with no power , to be registered at all .	105.41884
many states have laws regulating the use of boat trailers and some have restrictions regarding the age of motor boat operators .	94.03565
generally , states reserve for communities the right to have local ordinances regulating speed and other activities .	55.821846
it is always wise to consult your marine dealer , local yacht or boat club secretary , or local law enforcement officers if you are not positive what the regulations are .	206.88731
ignorance of the law is no better excuse on the water than it is on land	114.36026
lack of ability and common sense can lead to just as much tragedy .	154.99445
hand in hand with the legislative program is the industry ' s self originated and directed safety program .	134.68199
foreseeing the possible threats to safety with the rapid growth of the sport , the industry has been supporting an intense , coordinated educational program with great success since 1947 .	75.31297
a primary factor in the success of the safety program has been the enthusiastic cooperation of the individual manufacturers .	91.420746
the industry has been its own watch dog .	15.00263
with u . s . coast guard cooperation , the american boat and yacht council was formed to develop recommended practices and standards for boats and their equipment with reference to safety .	105.198944
in 1959 , the yacht safety bureau was reorganized by the national association of engine and boat manufacturers and a group of insurance underwriters to provide a testing laboratory and labeling service for boats and their equipment .	97.62818
a new waterfront site for the bureau is now being built at atlantic city , new jersey , to provide the most modern marine testing facilities as a further tool to keep the sport safe .	123.24517
in addition to these activities , the naebm , with headquarters at 420 lexington avenue , new york city , as well as other associations and individual manufacturers , provide and distribute films , booklets , and public services in regard to proper boat handling and safety afloat .	160.1458
it is important to note the work of the united states power squadrons and the u . s . coast guard auxiliary .	23.42959
each of these fine groups gives free boating classes in seamanship piloting and small boat handling .	235.73438
this year , over 100 , 000 persons will receive this free instruction .	127.52091
as america on wheels was responsible for an industry of motor courts , motels , and drive-in establishments where you can dine , see a movie , shop , or make a bank deposit , the ever-increasing number of boating enthusiasts have sparked industries designed especially to accommodate them .	77.21685
instead of motels , for the boatman there are marinas .	14.688419
the word marina was coined by naebm originally to describe a waterfront facility where recreational boats could find protection and basic needs to lay over in relative comfort .	100.32354
currently , marina is used to indicate a municipal or commercially operated facility where a pleasure boat may dock and find some or all of the following available gasoline , fresh water , electricity , telephone service , ice , repair facilities , restaurants , sleeping accommodations , a general store , and a grocery store .	96.59496
yachtel , a relatively new word , indicates a waterfront type of hotel where a yachtsman may dock and find overnight accommodations on the premises as well as other services .	183.08131
it indicates the same thing but it is meant to pertain more specifically to establishments designed to cater to smaller type boats such as outboards .	210.80208
regardless of nomenclature , yachtels and boatels are marinas .	226.24704
boatyards which also provide some of the above facilities may rightfully be called marinas .	528.22766
a recent survey disclosed there are about 4 , 000 commercially and municipally operated marinas and boatyards in the united states , the majority of which are equipped to handle outboard boats .	25.711773
the design of a mechanical interlocking frame is much like a mechanical puzzle , but once understood , the principles can be applied to any track and signal arrangement .	101.33705
in the frame are two sets of bars which interact with each other to prevent the operator from making dangerous moves .	91.20618
the main set of bars are the `` tappets ' ' and one tappet is connected to each lever .	19.84841
if the lever is pulled to clear a signal or move a switch , the tappet moves a short distance lengthwise at the same time .	79.00097
close behind the plane of the tappets are the locking bars .	37.756336
these can also move a short distance but at right angles to the tappets .	20.566347
the number of locking bars required depends on how many false moves must be prevented .	205.75829
in the sides of the tappets are notches with sloping sides , and connection between the tappets and locking bars consist of cams called `` dogs ' ' .	84.40825
two or more dogs are mounted on each locking bar .	48.73317
these slide into and out of the notches in the tappets as the tappets are moved , locking and unlocking them .	41.01396
here ' s how the scheme works suppose the operator pulls the lever to clear a particular signal .	65.69951
this also pulls the tappet connected to the particular lever and forces any dogs seated in the notches to the side , thus moving one or more locking bars .	96.72227
the dogs on the other ends of these locking bars are thus forced into notches in other tappets .	122.5047
by this scheme , pulling one signal to clear locks all the other switch and signal levers in safe positions until the first signal is again restored to normal .	144.1893
interlocking signals are normally at stop or `` red ' ' position , and a lever must be pulled to `` clear ' ' the signal .	49.222572
this is not necessarily to green , however , for in some situations only a yellow indication is given to a train to let it into the `` plant ' ' .	92.7389
a turnout may have two levers , one to actually move the switch points , the other to lock the points .	98.33522
a signal cannot be cleared until all the related turnouts are properly thrown and locked .	181.0976
such locks are nearly always used where the switch points `` face ' ' oncoming traffic .	160.25908
the lock insures that the points are thrown all the way with no chance that a wheel flange will snag on a partly thrown point .	71.50912
if the points aren ' t thrown all the way , the turnout cannot be locked , and in turn , the signal cannot be cleared .	36.428486
generally , these locks on turnouts are called `` facing point locks ' ' .	165.3863
figs . 1-6 show typical arrangements of track and signals .	21.429853
each diagram is accompanied by a `` dog chart ' ' , a list of the levers that show which other levers any particular lever will lock if pulled .	127.80886
the lines connecting the wedge-shaped dogs represent the locking bars at right angles to the tappet bars .	28.207817
by studying the track-signal diagrams you ' ll note several other details .	298.2862
derails -- mechanical track devices that actually guide the wheels off the rails if a train passes a `` stop ' ' signal -- are used in many instances .	54.86508
`` home ' ' signals have two blades .	8.953412
the blacked-in blades indicate a fixed aspect -- the blade does not move .	71.00868
as an engineer approaches the plant the position of the home signal is seen in advance when he passes the `` distant ' ' signal located beyond the limits of the interlocking plant .	74.35669
in some low-speed situations , the distant signal is fixed at caution .	83.91668
in other instances where there is no automatic block signaling , the distant has only green and yellow aspects .	197.74234
the interlocking frame we built at the model railroader workshop and then installed on paul larson ' s railroad follows the fig . 1 scheme and is shown beginning in fig . 7 , page 65 , and in the photos .	91.72645
here ' s how it can be built .	11.614026
the sizes of pieces needed for the interlocking frame are shown in the notes within fig . 7 , most of the bars being 1/8 ' ' ' ' brass in 1/4 ' ' ' ' and 1/2 ' ' ' ' widths .	37.512924
you may change the dimensions to suit a frame for more or fewer levers and locks as you wish .	96.317986
our instructions assume you are building this particular frame , which is for a junction .	87.287544
when cutting the pieces , dress the ends smooth , and square with a smooth file or sanding disk .	49.113728
start with the right-hand piece `` b ' ' , af , soldering it to the lower piece `` a ' ' of the same material but 12 ' ' ' ' long .	79.856125
let exactly 1 ' ' ' ' of `` a ' ' extend beyond `` b ' ' and use a square to check your angle to exactly 90 degrees .	73.74354
now lay 12 pieces of af cut 5-3/4 ' ' ' ' long side by side but separated by 12 pieces of the same material 1/2 ' ' ' ' sq . .	62.811947
this gives you the spacing for locating the left-hand piece `` b ' ' .	47.678795
compress the assembly when you make the mark to show the location for `` b ' ' .	42.06141
solder this second `` b ' ' to `` a ' ' at right angles .	22.244703
there should be 10 ' ' ' ' between the two parallel members and each should be 1 ' ' ' ' from an end of the long piece .	86.02386
cap this assembly ( with spacing bars in place ) with a af bar .	39.518692
tack-solder all the 1/2 ' ' ' ' sq . pieces to the 10 ' ' ' ' and 12 ' ' ' ' members .	60.544506
these will be drilled and tapped later on .	2380.769
now cut five af locking bar spacers ( which run horizontally ) .	111.03035
position these using six intermediate temporary af spacers and locate the upper 12 ' ' ' ' bar `` a ' ' .	50.48392
solder it and the five locking bar spacers to the frame .	18.310625
now place 12 pieces 1/2 ' ' ' ' sq . on this edge as we did before and space them with the 5-3/4 ' ' ' ' long `` tappets ' ' , as they are called .	64.8584
cap with a af bar and tack-solder in place .	88.50162
cap the locking bar spacers with two af directly under the first two `` b ' ' pieces .	46.330418
mark and center-punch all the holes required for screws to hold this assembly together .	76.41877
placement of these holes is not critical , but they should be located so that the centers are about 1/8 ' ' ' ' from any edge .	72.15133
drill all no . 50 and counter-drill all except the `` a ' ' pieces size 43 .	137.50461
tap the `` a ' ' pieces 2-56 .	3.4489124
now unsolder and disassemble the frame except for the two 12 ' ' ' ' and the first two 3-3/4 ' ' ' ' bars ( `` a ' ' and `` b ' ' pieces ) , which are soldered together .	42.262615
either lay the components aside in proper order or code them with numbers and letters so they may be replaced in their proper positions .	202.7754
dress all surfaces with a file , cleaning off all solder and drilling burrs .	73.95373
drill 20 no . 47 holes in the upper piece `` a ' ' as shown in fig . 7 .	37.16212
tap these 3-48 for mounting the electrical contact later on .	1956.3484
note , 6 and 8 lock levers don ' t require holes for contacts .	24.577148
now reassemble the frame , using af roundhead steel screws and nuts .	42.668
put the 12 tappets and some af locking bar spacers in the frame to help align all the components before you tighten the screws .	49.974163
be sure the tappets are not pinched by a twisted 1/2 ' ' ' ' sq . spacer .	24.020535
as an anchor for the spring lock , insert a af bar in the lower left corner of the frame as shown in fig . 7 .	46.69099
drill a no . 43 hole through the pieces and secure with a 2-56 nut and screw .	83.136795
drill two no . 50 holes , one in the insert and one in the locking bar spacer directly above it , and tap 2-56 .	43.066387
number all the tappet bars before removing them so they can be replaced in the same slots .	70.88993
remove all other loose pieces and file the edges of the basic frame smooth .	71.7839
cut five pieces of af brass bar stock 3-3/4 ' ' ' ' long .	16.271776
these are supporting members for the short locking bars .	20.562872
locate their positions in fig . 7 and drill no . 43 to match the corresponding holes in the frame .	75.252846
cut off excess screw lengths and file flush with either frame or nut .	71.79239
drill four no . 19 and four no . 28 holes in the 12 ' ' ' ' long `` a ' ' pieces .	30.386614
draw-file no . 1 tappet to a smooth fit in its respective slot and square the ends .	105.42723
break the end corners with a slight 45 degree chamfer .	559.62915
drill a no . 50 hole 1-1/4 ' ' ' ' from one end and tap 2-56 .	24.755503
) put a 2-56 roundhead screw into the hole , cut off the excess threads and file flush with the underside of the bar .	34.266068
to find the other stop screw position , insert the tappet into the frame and hold the screw head tight against the frame edge .	33.280525
scribe a line across the bar on the other end of the tappet , 1/4 ' ' ' ' plus half the diameter of the 2-56 screw head ( about 5/64 ' ' ' ' ) away from the frame edge .	61.092266
total distance is about 21/64 ' ' ' ' .	4.1356907
tend to make this dimension slightly undersize so you can file the screw head to get exactly 1/4 ' ' ' ' tappet movement .	88.93103
drill a no . 50 hole , tap 2-56 and insert a roundhead 2-56 screw as you did on the first end .	45.546062
drill a no . 47 hole crosswise through the tappet at the position shown in figs . 7 and 8 .	40.688633
repeat these drill and tap operations for each of the tappet bars .	37.208096
to each tappet except 6 and 8 , solder a af piece of brass and file to the tapered shape shown in figs . 6 and 8 .	61.440292
these will serve as lifting pads for the electrical contacts .	64.60369
fitting the locking bars and making the locking pieces is a rather tedious job since stop screws , tappets and locking bars must be removed and replaced many times .	126.082016
as the work progresses the frame and moving parts become a sort of chinese puzzle where several pieces must be removed before the part you are working on is accessible .	265.72168
a little extra work here will pay off with a smooth , snug-fitting machine when you are finished .	149.989
each completed locking bar should remain in place as the work progresses to insure snug fitting .	77.4091
the order of fitting is not too important .	11.014361
however , we started with the first row of bars and worked our way back .	262.6873
since the same method of shaping and fitting the dogs and notches is used throughout , we will only describe the construction of one locking bar .	148.3434
figs . 7 and 8 give all pertinent dimensions .	23.807491
all the bars are cut from af brass .	16.16846
the lengths of each piece are listed at the bottom of fig . 7 .	16.184118
bar `` c ' ' is 2-3/4 ' ' ' ' long .	22.32014
draw-file the edges , square up the ends and put a slight chamfer on the edges so they will not snag in the frame .	58.40385
fig . 8 gives the dimensions for locating the dog-pin holes .	103.302635
center-punch and drill the no . 31 hole 7/16 ' ' ' ' from one end of the bar .	29.414944
chuck a length of 1/8 ' ' ' ' dia . drill rod into a drill press or some similar turning device and while it is rotating file the end square and then file a slight taper 1/8 ' ' ' ' long .	108.74056
cut the piece about 9/32 ' ' ' ' or 5/16 ' ' ' ' long and drive it into the no . 31 hole drilled in the locking bar .	53.117493
file the bottom edge flush with the bar and the top 1/8 ' ' ' ' above the bar .	13.474408
this dog will engage a notch to be cut in tappet 3 .	101.68929
place the locking bar in proper position and insert tappet 3 .	77.298744
scribe a line through the center of the pin and across the face of tappet 3 , parallel to piece `` a ' ' .	105.79743
see the drawings for the shape of the notch .	97.33191
scribe v-shaped lines on the bar and rough out with either a hack saw or a cutting disk in a hand power tool .	128.43335
we used the latter equipped with a carborundum disk about	47.14603
' ' thick and 1 ' ' ' ' dia . fitted on a 1/8 ' ' ' ' dia . mandrel .	32.623203
such disks are very handy for cutting and shaping small parts .	365.37344
a barrette swiss pattern file is handy since its triangular shape with only one cutting face will allow you to work a surface without marring an adjoining one .	209.4197
endeavor to get the notches as much alike as possible .	52.688747
the notch should have a smooth finish so that the steel dog will slide easily over it .	109.22458
assemble the parts in the frame and test the sliding action of the mating pieces .	89.54765
all matching surfaces should be checked frequently and mated on a cut and fit basis .	300.39438
chuck a 2 ' ' ' ' or 3 ' ' ' ' piece of 1/8 ' ' ' ' dia . drill rod in a drill press or electric hand tool .	43.539528
fashion a sharp scribing point about 3/64 ' ' ' ' long on one end , using swiss pattern files .	86.47003
this tool can also be made with a lathe .	311.9764
scientists say that the world and everything in it are based on mathematics .	60.35168
without math the men who are continually seeking the causes of and the reasons for the many things that make the world go ' round would not have any means of analyzing , standardizing , and communicating the things they discover and learn .	106.76116
math and the formulas that allow it to be applied to different problems are , therefore , essential to any scientific endeavor .	99.74875
it ' s not a science as involved as determining what makes the earth rotate on its axis or building a rocket or putting a satellite into orbit but it is , nevertheless , a science .	129.91171
but because science is based on mathematics doesn ' t mean that a hot rodder must necessarily be a mathematician .	61.06148
a guy can be an active and successful hot rodder for years without becoming even remotely involved with mathematical problems	260.76364
however , he will have a clearer understanding of what he is doing and the chances are he will be more successful if he understands the few formulas that apply to rodding .	80.67699
a mathematical formula is nothing more than a pattern for solving a specific problem .	221.44128
it places the various factors involved in the problem in their correct order in relation to each other so that the influence of factors on each other can be computed .	75.763466
the first step in using a formula is to insert the numerical values of the factors involved in their correct positions in the formula .	50.236534
this changes the formula to an `` equation ' ' .	2.4119291
the equation is used for the mathematical process of solving the problem .	49.997925
they involve only simple mathematics that are taught in grammar school arithmetic classes .	102.74482
however , it is essential that the various mathematical symbols used in the equations be understood so that the mathematical processes can be done properly and in their correct order .	137.75444
they indicate simple division , multiplication , subtraction , and addition .	18.073639
the symbol for division is a straight line that separates two numbers placed one above the other .	287.5561
the lower number is always divided into the upper number af	215.0623
the symbol for multiplication is `` **b ' ' .	1.9413941
it is used to separate two or more numbers in a row .	72.63225
numbers to be multiplied together may be multiplied in any order .	64.20094
the result will be the same regardless of the order used .	149.86932
the symbol for subtraction is the standard minus sign .	114.00315
the number on the right of the symbol is always subtracted from the number on the left of the symbol .	47.813103
when more than two figures are separated by subtraction symbols the subtraction must be carried out from the left to right if the result is to be correct .	62.15638
for example , for the problem af , 10 from 25 equals 15 , then 6 from 15 equals 9 .	142.83492
the symbol is used to separate two or more numbers .	58.888588
numbers separated by addition symbols may be placed in any order .	46.907448
when solving an equation that involves division as well as other steps , do all the division steps first to reduce those parts of the equation to their numerical value .	157.30687
multiplication , subtraction , and addition can then be accomplished as they appear in the equation by starting at the left end of the equation and working toward the right .	70.47739
completing the division first also includes those division parts that require multiplication , subtraction , or addition steps af .	151.25917
this would be reduced by multiplying 8 times 6 and then dividing the product by 12 .	141.57193
this part of the equation would then become 4 .	486.38046
for use in formulas , fractions should be converted to their decimal equivalents .	17.14365
the easiest way to do this is with a conversion chart .	198.6305
charts for this purpose are available from many sources .	11.081159
they are included in all types of mathematical handbooks and they are stamped on some types of precision measuring instruments .	125.32898
the various mathematical processes can be simplified by carrying the results to only two or three decimal places .	141.32439
shortening the results in this manner will not have any detrimental effect on the accuracy of the final result .	53.092525
a constant is a number that remains the same regardless of the other numbers used in the formula and the resultant equation .	49.306507
it is a number without which the equation cannot be solved correctly .	93.96892
rodding formulas apply to many phases of the sport .	397.09866
the answers they give can often pave the way to performance increases and , quite often , are necessary for completing entry blanks for different events .	159.72034
when it is needed , one formula is as important as another .	69.53441
however , some formulas are used more than others .	83.95077
we ' ll take them in the general order of their popularity .	85.24178
a rodder should be able to compute the displacement of his engine .	114.75684
displacement is sometimes referred to as `` swept volume ' ' .	17.57796
most entry blanks for competitive events require engine displacement information because of class restrictions .	192.11346
it is good to be able to compute displacement so that changes in it resulting from boring and stroking can be computed .	203.32361
factors involved in the displacement formula are the bore diameter of the engine ' s cylinders , the length of the piston stroke , the number of cylinders in the engine , and a constant .	39.084583
the constant is , which is one-quarter of 3 . 1416 , another constant known as `` pi ' ' .	133.04076
pi is used in formulas concerned with the dimensions of circles .	58.527077
actually , the engine displacement formula is the standard formula for computing the volume of a cylinder of any type with an added factor that represents the number of cylinders in the engine .	56.11362
the cross-sectional area of the cylinders is determined and then the volume of the individual cylinders is computed by multiplying the area by the stroke length , which is the equivalent of the length of the cylinders .	44.32134
multiplying the result by the number of cylinders in the engine gives the engine ' s total displacement .	36.620777
dimensions in inches , and fractions of inches will give the displacement in cubic inches .	32.22165
dimensions in centimeters and fractions of centimeters will give the displacement in cubic centimeters ( cc . ) .	18.725246
one inch equals 2 . 54 centimeters one cubic inch equals 16 . 38 cubic centimeters .	58.718445
for example , let ' s consider a standard 283 cubic inch chevy aj .	93.04076
these engines have a cylinder diameter of 3-7/8 inches and a stroke length of 3 inches .	54.631428
the formula , with the fractions converted to decimals , becomes af .	90.22504
to arrive at the answer , multiply the numbers together by starting at the left of the group and working to the right .	68.4872
a cylinder ' s compression ratio is computed by comparing the cylinder ' s volume , or its displacement , with the total volume of the cylinder and its combustion chamber .	34.178154
cylinder volume can be determined mathematically but combustion chamber volume must be measured with a liquid .	24.763199
cylinder volume is determined in exactly the same manner as for the displacement formula af .	50.534924
to measure the volume of one of the combustion chambers in the cylinder head , install the valves and spark plug in the chamber and support the head so that its gasket surface is level .	93.27922
then pour water or light oil from a graduated beaker into the chamber to fill the chamber to its gasket surface .	56.541615
this is possible with water and other liquids that have a high surface tension .	185.639
such liquids will rise to a considerable height above the surface around the chamber before they will flow out of the chamber .	66.95578
the amount of liquid poured into the chamber is determined by subtracting the quantity still in the beaker when the chamber is full from the original quantity .	115.83251
most beakers are graduated in cubic centimeters ( cc . ) , making it necessary to convert the result to cubic inches .	44.211018
however , the displacement of the cylinder can be converted to cubic centimeters .	10.509399
the compression ratio arrived at with the formula will be the same regardless of whether cubic inches or cubic centimeters are used .	55.3505
the only precaution is that all volumes used in the formula be quoted in the same terms .	61.49469
the volume of the cylinder opening in the head gasket must be computed by multiplying its area in square inches by the gasket ' s thickness in thousandths of an inch .	134.29568
sometimes it is necessary to roughly calculate the square inch area of the opening but the calculation can usually be made with sufficient accuracy that it won ' t affect the final computation .	92.26848
the volume of the opening is added to the combustion chamber volume .	12.515596
another thing that must be taken into consideration is the volume of the area between the top of the piston and the top of the cylinder block when the piston is in top dead center position .	42.906147
compute this volume by measuring the distance from the top of the block to the piston head as accurately as possible with a depth micrometer or some other precision measuring device and then multiply the area of the cylinder by the depth .	48.248074
this volume is added to the total volume of the combustion chamber and head gasket opening .	72.456345
the total of these three volumes is the `` final combustion chamber volume ' ' .	18.115685
after the factors just described have been computed , they are applied to the following formula af	78.31781
for an example let ' s dream up an engine that has a final combustion chamber volume of 5 cubic inches and a cylinder volume of 45 cubic inches .	41.041985
applying these figures to the formula we get the equation af .	6.568297
this method of computing compression ratio cannot be used accurately for engines that have pistons with either domed or irregularly shaped heads .	162.21228
any irregularity on the piston heads will make it impossible , with normal means , to determine the final combustion chamber volume because the volume displaced by the piston heads cannot be readily computed .	64.60012
the only way to determine the final combustion chamber volume when such pistons are used is by measuring it with liquid while the cylinder head is bolted to the cylinder block and the piston is in top dead center position .	57.30602
there are four versions of the formula that involves the relationships of car speed , engine speed , rear axle gear ratio , and rear tire size .	31.936945
by using the appropriate version any one of these factors can be determined for any combination of the other three .	65.39359
to simplify the formulas a representative symbol is substituted for each of the factors .	29.562277
tire size can be determined in several ways but the one that is the easiest and as accurate as any is by measuring the effective radius of a wheel and tire assembly .	113.40729
this is done by measuring the distance from the surface on which the tire is resting to the center of the rear axle shaft .	36.73707
a tire must be inflated to its normal hot operating pressure and the car must be loaded to its operating weight when this measurement is made .	121.714615
any fraction of an inch involved in the measurement must be converted to a decimal equivalent to simplify the mathematics .	39.649345
when tire size is measured in this manner a constant of 168 is used in the formula .	62.383053
to determine car speed for a given combination of engine speed , gear ratio , and tire size , the formula is af .	22.176367
for an engine speed of 5000 rpm , a gear ratio of 4 . 00 to 1 , and a tire radius of 13 inches , the equation would look like this af	62.783024
to determine engine speed for a given combination of the other three factors the formula is af .	47.31021
using the same figures as for the previous example , the equation becomes af	52.39412
to determine the rear axle gear ratio for a combination of the other three factors , the formula is af .	33.56511
using the figures from the previous examples , the equation becomes af .	39.92554

laguerre hanover is outstanding in type and conformation -- good body , plenty of heart girth , stands straight on his legs on excellent feet -- and has the smoothest gait .	176.05684

thor hanover ( adios-trustful hanover ) is a wonderful looking prospect and another good individual , with solid , rugged conformation , good , flat bone and excellent feet .	211.41272
this colt arrived at the raceway early last november , and immediately was put into harness and line-driven for a few days , and then put to cart and broken in very nicely , knowing nothing but trot .	102.438286
he appeared in the hopples about november 14 , was treated for worms on the 18th , the latter date being the first time he struck a real pace .	64.832085

they left the three-quarters together and finished almost together .	94.254906
this filly is another adios that wants to trot , and trot she did until forced to do otherwise .	184.57014
after well broken and equipped with 12-oz . shoes on behind , bare-footed in front , she would trot a real storm with the master , delvin , driving .	191.60472

she hesitated , she hopped , she rolled and rocked , skipped and jumped , but in some two weeks she started to pace , from that time to this she has shown steady improvement and now looks like one of the classiest things on the grounds .	100.11895

-- after 52 rainless days , moisture finally came to del mar , resulting in but one workout during the week for most of the horses , and leaving us with less than half our total average rainfall during the season .	91.74482
