mason had to earn the privilege of devoting himself exclusively to painting .	98.54594
like many others , he had to work hard , long hours in a struggling family business which , though it was allied to art of a kind -- the design and production of engraved seals -- bore no relation to the painting of pictures .	134.79694
but it did teach roy the basic techniques of commercial art , and later , for twelve years , he and his sister nina conducted an advertising art studio in philadelphia .	62.296547
on the death of their father , they returned to their home in batavia , new york .	34.72577
after more years of concentrated effort , roy and his brother max finally established a thriving family business at the old stand .	100.73632
during all this time roy continued to paint , first only on weekends , and then , as the family business permitted , for longer periods .	84.94177
gradually he withdrew from the shop altogether , and for the past thirty years , he has worked independently as a painter , except for his continued hunting and fishing expeditions .	66.92744
but even on these , the palette often takes over while the shotgun cools off ! !	252.2024
except for a rich friendship with the painter , chauncey ryder who gave him the only professional instruction he ever had -- and this was limited to a few lessons , though the two artists often went on painting trips together -- roy developed his art by himself .	150.08902
in the best tradition , he first taught himself to see , then to draw with accuracy and assurance , and then to paint .	71.206665
he worked in oil for years before beginning his work in watercolor , and his first public recognition and early honors , including his election to the academy , were for his essays in the heavier medium .	114.52719
gradually watercolor claimed his greater affection until today it has become his major , if not exclusive , technique .	245.85728
it has been my privilege to paint with roy mason on numerous occasions , mostly in the vicinity of batavia .	31.365728
more often than not i have found easy excuse to leave my own work and stand at a respectable distance where i could watch this man transform raw nature into a composed , not imitative , painting .	189.59572
what i have observed time and time again is a process of integration , integration that begins as abstract design and gradually takes on recognizable form	253.45209
color patterns that are made to weave throughout the whole composition	50.93002
and that over-all , amazing control of large washes which is the mason stylemark .	93.13811
finally come those little flicks of a rigger brush and the job is done .	70.93876
but for the technical fact , we have the artist ' s own testimony	27.019178
`` of late years , i find that i like best to work out-of-doors .	162.22334
first i make preliminary watercolor sketches in quarter scale ( approximately af inches ) in which i pay particular attention to the design principles of three simple values -- the lightest light , the middle tone , and the darkest dark -- by reducing the forms of my subject to these large patterns .	158.956
if a human figure or wild life are to be part of the projected final picture , i try to place them in the initial sketch .	82.76925
for me , these will belong more completely to their surroundings if they are conceived in this early stage , though i freely admit that i do not hesitate to add or eliminate figures on the full sheet when it serves my final purpose .	134.32726
`` i am thoroughly convinced that most watercolors suffer because the artist expects nature will do his composing for him	236.7771
as a result , such pictures are only a literal translation of what the artist finds in the scene before him .	65.252014
just because a tree or other object appears in a certain spot is absolutely no reason to place it in the same position in the painting , unless the position serves the design of the whole composition .	103.285194
if the artist would study his work more thoroughly and move certain units in his design , often only slightly , finer pictures would result .	262.23175
out of long experience i have found that incidental figures and other objects like trees , logs , and bushes can be traced from the original sketch and moved about in the major areas on the final sheet until they occupy the right position , which i call clicking .	120.56599
`` speed in painting a picture is valid only when it imparts spontaneity and crispness , but unless the artist has lots of experience so that he can control rapid execution , he would do well to take these first sketches and soberly reorder their design to achieve a unified composition .	135.69865
`` if i have seemed to emphasize the structure of the composition , i mean to project equal concern for color .	145.33344
often , in working out-of-doors under all conditions of light and atmosphere , a particular passage that looked favorable in relation to the subject will be too bright , too dull , or too light , or too dark when viewed indoors in a mat .	116.96253
when this occurs , i make the change on the sketch or on the final watercolor -- if i have been working on a full sheet in the field .	57.97345
`` when working from one of my sketches i square it up and project its linear form freehand to the watercolor sheet with charcoal .	314.44516
when this linear draft is completed , i dust it down to a faint image .	146.69759
from this point , i paint in as direct a manner as possible , by flowing on the washes with as pure a color mixture as i can manage .	132.12578
however , first i thoughtfully study my sketch for improvement of color and design along the lines i have described .	113.389114
then i plan my attack the parts i will finish first , the range of values , the accenting of minor details -- all in all , mechanics of producing the finished job with a maximum of crispness .	134.72284
the longer i work , the more i am sure that for me , at least , a workmanlike method is important .	37.59623
trial and error are better placed in the preliminary sketch than in hoping for miracles in the final painting .	124.25403
`` as for materials , i use the best available .	52.813877
i work on a watercolor easel in the field , and frequently resort to a large garden umbrella to protect my eyes from undue strain .	114.13886
in my studio i work at a tilt-top table , but leave the paper unfixed so that i can move it freely to control the washes .	135.25575
i have used a variety of heavy-weight hand-made papers , but prefer an english make , rough surface , in 400-pound weight .	478.2338
after selecting a sheet and inspecting it for flaws ( even the best sometimes has foreign ' nubbins ' on its surface ) , i sponge it thoroughly on both sides with clean , cold water .	225.10541
then i dry the sheet under mild pressure so that it will lie flat as a board .	86.051384
`` in addition to the usual tools , i make constant use of cleansing tissue , not only to wipe my brushes , but to mop up certain areas , to soften edges , and to open up lights in dark washes .	199.5323
the great absorbency of this tissue and the fact that it is easier to control than a sponge makes it an ideal tool for the watercolorist .	64.33517
i also use a small electric hand-blower to dry large washes in the studio .	41.321968
`` my brushes are different from those used by most watercolorists , for i combine the sable and the bristle .	82.95575
and a very large , flat wash brush .	7.242339
the bristles are a fitch 2 and a one-half inch brush shaved to a sharp chisel edge .	91.013885
`` my usual palette consists of top-quality colors alizarin crimson , orange , raw sienna , raw umber , burnt sienna , sepia , cerulean blue , cobalt blue , french ultramarine blue , winsor green , hooker ' s green 2 , cadmium yellow pale , yellow ochre , payne ' s gray , charcoal gray , davy ' s gray , and ivory black ' ' .	56.421658
in analyzing the watercolors of roy mason , the first thing that comes to mind is their essential decorativeness , yet this word has such a varied connotation that it needs some elaboration here .	153.26888
true , a mason watercolor is unmistakably a synthesis of nature rather than a detailed inventory .	115.447075
unlike many decorative patterns that present a static flat convention , this artist ' s pictures are full of atmosphere and climate .	181.16385
long observation has taught mason that most landscape can be reduced to three essential planes a foreground in sharp focus -- either a light area with dark accents or a dark one with lights	285.7461
and a background , usually a silhouetted form foiled against the sky .	12.758345
in following this general principle , mason provides the observer with a natural eye progression from foreground to background , and the illusion of depth is instantly created .	58.049824
when painting , mason ' s physical eyes are half-closed , while his mind ' s eye is wide open , and this circumstance accounts in part for the impression he wishes to convey .	177.80609
he does not insist on telling all he knows about any given subject	287.90787
rather his pictures invite the observer to draw on his memory , his imagination , his nostalgia .	67.43933
it is for this reason that roy avoids selecting subjects that require specific recognition of place for their enjoyment .	156.00368
his pictures generalize , though they are inspired by a particular locale	67.831985
they universalize in terms of weather , skies , earth , and people .	60.94739
by dealing with common landscape in an uncommon way , roy mason has found a particular niche in american landscape art .	106.4759
living with his watercolors is a vicarious experience of seeing nature distilled through the eyes of a sensitive interpretor , a breath and breadth of the outdoor world to help man honor the creator of it all .	110.998215
the artist was born in gilbert mills , new york , in 1886 , and until two years ago when he and his wife moved to california , he lived in western new york , in batavia .	52.23742
when i looked up the actual date of his birth and found it to be march 15th , i realized that roy was born under the right zodiacal sign for a watercolorist the water sign of pisces ( february 18 thru march 20 ) .	88.00483
and how very often a water plane is featured in his landscapes , and how appropriate that he should appear in american artist again , in his natal month of march ! !	195.47661
over the years , beginning in 1929 , mason has been awarded seventeen major prizes including two gold medals	172.7304
the blair purchase prize for watercolor , art institute of chicago	40.827175
and others in buffalo , new york , chautauqua , new haven , rochester , rockport , and most recently , the $300 prize for a watercolor at the laguna beach art association ,	54.05972
he was elected to the national academy of design as an associate in the oil class in 1931 ( after receiving his first ranger fund purchase prize at the academy in 1930 ) , and elevated to academicianship in 1940 .	78.7566
other memberships include the american watercolor society , philadelphia water color club , allied artists of america , audubon artists , baltimore watercolor society .	249.05908
the russian gymnasts beat the tar out of the american gymnasts in the 1960 olympics for one reason -- they were better .	132.46529
they were better trained , better looking , better built , better disciplined and something else -- they were better dancers .	155.26941
our athletes are only just beginning to learn that they must study dance .	259.86185
the russians are all trained as dancers before they start to study gymnastics .	125.54334
after all , we did pretty well in some other areas of the olympics competition .	38.852943
but if it is important , what can we do to improve ourselves ? ?	31.48455
it is more than just lack of dance training that is our problem , for just as gymnastics can learn from dance , dance has some very important things to learn from gymnastics .	271.22305
taking first things first , let ' s understand the sport called gymnastics .	349.2456
it is made up of tumbling , which might be said to start with a somersault , run through such stunts as headstands , handstands , cartwheels , backbends , and culminate in nearly impossible combinations of aerial flips and twists and apparatus work .	85.884056
the apparatus used by gymnasts was once a common sight in american gyms , but about 1930 it was dropped in favor of games .	215.47371
the parallel bars , horse , buck , springboard , horizontal bar , rings , and mats formerly in the school gyms were replaced by baseball , volleyball , basketball and football .	76.99426
but the russians use gymnastics as the first step in training for all other sports because it provides training in every basic quality except one , endurance .	216.12746
the gymnast must develop strength , flexibility , coordination , timing , rhythm , courage , discipline , persistence and the desire for perfection .	108.97471
in short , gymnastics uses every part of the body and requires a great deal of character as well .	41.492493
the addition of endurance training later , when the body is mature enough to benefit from it without danger of injury , provides that final quality that makes the top athlete , soldier or citizen .	219.48941
another reason gymnastic study is valuable is that it can be started very early in life .	141.88158
( an enterprising teacher or parent could start training a healthy child at the age of seven days .	95.04082
most europeans have been exercising newborn infants for centuries .	43.590466
) in most sports , as in most walks of life , the angels are on the side of those who begin young , and the russian competitor of 16 has at least thirteen years of training behind him .	128.57397
the american is very lucky if he has three .	113.61654
if a nation wished to get a head start in physical fitness over all other nations , it would start its kindergarten students on a program of gymnastics the day they entered and thus eliminate a large number of the problems that plague american schools .	90.75551
first of the problems attacked would be fatigue and emotional tension , since action relieves both .	570.296
oddly enough , it is proven that there would be less reading difficulty .	110.81809
certainly there would be less anxiety , fewer accidents ( it is the clumsy child who sustains the worst injuries ) , and higher scholastic averages , since alert children work better .	220.1969
russia knows this , and that is why there were over 800 , 000 competing for places as candidates for the olympic gymnastic team .	96.4069
eighty thousand won top honors and a chance to try for the team itself .	161.13861
we could scarcely find eighty in our great land of over 180 million people .	113.458725
and what has dancing to do with all this ? ?	40.680088
russia ' s young gymnasts have studied dance before having the rigorous training on apparatus .	125.31303
well-stretched , trained in posture and coordinated movement , and wedded to rhythm , they presented the audiences in rome with one of the most beautiful sights ever seen at any olympic contest .	101.02003
american audiences in particular learned two valuable lessons .	4.771894
they saw completely masculine and obviously virile men performing with incredible grace .	148.87408
they were further stripped of old wive ' s tales by seeing the slender , lovely russian girls performing feats requiring tremendous strength and with not one bulging muscle .	271.0595
president kennedy has asked that we become a physically fit nation .	113.29237
if we wait until children are in junior high or high school , we will never manage it .	47.408817
to be fit , one has to start early with young children , and today the only person who really reaches such children is the teacher of dance .	175.46873
if the dance teachers of america make it their business to prepare their young charges for the gymnastics that must come some day if our schools are really responsible , we will be that much ahead .	211.32492
school teachers , all too unprepared for the job they must do , will need demonstrators .	138.24884
there should be youngsters who know how to do a headstand , and also how to help other children learn it .	161.96556
they should know simple exercises that could prepare less fortunate children for the sports we will demand be taught .	167.3822
dance teachers can respond to president kennedy ' s request not only through their regular dance work , but also through the kind of basic gymnastic work that makes for strength and flexibility .	138.11119
very little in today ' s living provides the strength we need and nothing provides the flexibility .	476.59427
they often fail , however , to develop real abdominal , back , chest , shoulder and arm strength .	65.95684
ask any group of ballerinas to do ten push-ups or three chin-ups and the results , considering the amount of physical training they have had , will be very disappointing .	154.99062
even the boys will not be outstanding in these areas .	78.40012
this isn ' t surprising when we consider that over 29 percent of the 11-year-old boys in america cannot chin themselves once , and that english school girls outdo them in almost every test ( even dashes and endurance ) .	239.22011
the only area in which american boys hold their own is the baseball throw .	206.94524
for arm and shoulder strength a chinning bar is recommended .	46.1536
it should be installed over a door that is in full view of everyone , and a chair should be placed under it , a little to one side .	104.33614
those children who can chin themselves should be told to do one chin-up each time they pass under it .	342.99982
those who are too weak , should climb on the chair and , starting at the top of the chin , let themselves slowly down .	88.47296
when they can take ten seconds to accomplish the descent , they will have the strength to chin-up .	54.490486
parents should be informed about this system and encouraged to do the same with the whole family at home .	86.518036
arm , shoulder , chest , upper and lower back strength will be aided with the horse kick .	158.12773
keeping the hands in the starting position , run in place to a quick rhythm .	176.6379
after this has become easy , use slower and slower rhythms , kicking higher and higher .	78.6771
follow this by crossing from one corner of the room to the other on all fours , kicking as high as possible .	94.4694
push-ups are essential , but few have the strength for them at first .	353.09174
start on the knees in a large circle .	8.058934
fall slowly forward onto the hands and let the body down to rest on the floor .	60.05891
do this exercise six times each class period .	14.149977
as strength improves start in a standing position with legs wide apart and upper body bent forward .	211.72707
start by falling forward to a point close to the feet , and , as strength improves , fall farther and farther out .	39.39788
try to push back to the stand position from the stretched position without any intermediate pushes from the hands .	76.696175
the push-up itself can be taught by starting at the top of the push-up with legs spread wide .	85.43838
let the body down slowly , taking at least five seconds for the letting down .	178.96326
five of these done daily for about a week will develop the strength for one push-up .	209.89935
handstands come after arms , chest and shoulders have developed at least a minimum of strength .	112.17176
of course those who have developed more will find them easier .	216.39899
start with the class standing in a circle , with weight on the right foot and the left extended a little way into the circle .	79.37771
at first each child should do a kick-up by himself so that the teacher can determine those ready to work alone , and those who need help .	126.700615
drop both hands to the floor and at the same time kick the right foot up in back .	84.91124
the right will land first , followed by the left .	62.097366
care should be taken to see that the hands are placed on the floor before the kick starts and also that the landing foot is brought as close to the hands as possible .	100.24879
this will prevent flat falls and toe injuries .	3.7769532
bare feet are better for such work than any form of slipper .	86.77597
eventually the class will be able to kick up high enough so that the teacher can catch the leading leg .	121.400406
the child should then bring both legs together overhead , point the toes and tighten the seat muscles .	108.21868
be sure that the landing foot is brought close to the hands and that only one foot lands at a time .	169.95064
the backbend is of extreme importance to any form of free gymnastics , and , as with all acrobatics , the sooner begun the better the results .	134.26706
have the class lie supine with knees apart and bent .	94.017494
place flat palms on either side of the head a few inches away from the ears , fingers pointing toward the shoulders .	72.39977
arch the back upwards to make a bridge .	9.108542
be sure the head drops backward so that the child looks at the floor rather than toward the ceiling .	139.67572
as flexibility improves , the feet will move closer to the hands and the bridge rise higher .	344.17206
later this can be combined with the handstand to provide a walkover .	58.12425
to further increase back flexibility , work on the back circle .	40.182484
place the hands in front of the chest .	4.1003094
keep the legs straight and the toes pointed .	6.145916
straighten the arms slowly , this arches the back .	58.82261
at the peak of the arch , tip the head back and bend the knees in an effort to touch toes to head .	54.46021
improvement can be measured by the lessening distance between toes and head .	30.449228
the last essential to the beginner ' s gymnastic program is the somersault , or forward roll .	95.773674
this used to be part of every child ' s bag of tricks , but few children can do it today	113.12918
some are actually incapable of rolling forward and are completely confused when not sitting or standing upright .	173.48799
for most small children , learning a forward roll is simply a matter of copying another child who can .	253.39531
after it has been seen , have the child start on a mat on hands and knees ( a thin , inexpensive mat is quite sufficient for anything that does not require falling ) .	92.53822
he places the hands on either side of the head , keeping the chin down on the chest .	30.782244
he then pushes his seat into the air and the teacher guides it over .	191.95982
one or two practice runs should be sufficient for solo .	61.226677
if , however , the child is weak , overweight , or afraid , more help will be needed .	78.011024
when the child raises his seat into the air , the teacher takes hold under both sides of the pelvis	164.58763
then no matter what happens , the child ' s performance will be controlled .	41.74808
by lifting the seat upwards a little , the weight is taken off the neck and the back is kept rounded .	105.16052
these are beginnings , but correctly learned they prepare for satisfying and exciting stunts that can be performed by a strong , flexible body ( we are not talking of eccentric extremes ) .	139.88521
even if gymnastics are not the ultimate goal , the good tumbler will be a better dancer , a better athlete , and a human being with a greater margin of safety in any activity .	66.020874
it is very important for parents to understand that early training is imperative .	63.962048
and dancing school , so helpful in artistic and psychological development , also contributes to this essential early training -- and can contribute even more .	93.75024
every taxpayer is well aware of the vast size of our annual defense budget and most of our readers also realize that a large portion of these expenditures go for military electronics .	152.63136
we have noted how some electronic techniques , developed for the defense effort , have evenutally been used in commerce and industry .	122.6435
the host of novel applications of electronics to medical problems is far more thrilling because of their implication in matters concerning our health and vitality .	234.67104
when we consider the electronic industry potential for human betterment , the prospect is staggering .	72.66214
the author has recently studied the field of medical electronics and has been convinced that , in this area alone , the application of electronic equipment has enormous possibilities .	107.69161
the benefits electronics can bring to bio-medicine may be greater by far than any previous medical discovery .	128.54965
we use the term `` bio-medicine ' ' because of the close interrelation between biology and medical research .	33.313206
electronics has been applied to medicine for many years in the form of such familiar equipment as the x-ray machine , the electrocardiograph , and the diathermy machine .	69.83057
recently many doctors have installed ultrasonic vibration machines for deep massage of bruises , contusions , and simple bursitis .	69.50189
commonly used electronic devices which are found in practically every hospital are closed-circuit tv and audio systems for internal paging and instruction , along with radiation counters , timers , and similar devices .	157.1746
in this article we will concentrate on the advances in the application of electronics in bio-medical research laboratories because this is where tomorrow ' s commonplace equipment originates .	105.97849
from the wealth of material and the wide variety of different electronic techniques perfected in the past few years we have selected a few examples which appear to be headed for use in the immediate future and which offer completely new tools in medical research .	69.161316
many cells , bacteria , and other microorganisms are transparent to visible light and must be stained for microscopic investigation .	61.148018
this stain often disrupts the normal cell activity or else colors only the outside .	309.04227
a completely new insight into living cells and their structure will be possible by use of a new technique which replaces visible light with ultraviolet radiation and combines a microscope with a color-tv system to view the results .	109.64082
fig . 1 is a simplified block diagram of the ultraviolet microscopy system developed at the medical electronics center of rockefeller institute .	35.60792
by combining the talents of a medical man , dr . aterman , a biophysicist , mr . berkely , and an electronics expert , dr . zworykin , this novel technique has been developed which promises to open broad avenues to understanding life processes .	75.1102
three different wavelengths of ultraviolet radiation are selected by the variable filters placed in front of the three mercury xenon lights which serve as the ultraviolet sources .	64.40503
these wavelengths are reflected in sequence through the specimen by the rotating mirror	264.86942
instead of the observer ' s eye the image orthicon in the tv camera does the `` looking ' ' .	99.568405
the microscope and orthicon are both selected to operate well into the ultraviolet spectrum , which means that all lenses must be quartz .	209.22466
the video signal is amplified and then switched , in synchronism with the three ultraviolet light sources which are sequenced by the rotating mirror so that during one-twentieth of a second only one wavelength , corresponding to red , green , or blue , is seen .	166.72884
( note because of light leakage from one ultraviolet source to another , the lights are switched by a commutator-like assembly rotated by a synchronous motor .	113.72727
this assembly also supplies a 20-cps switching gate for the electronics circuitry .	49.852108
) this is the same system as was used in the field-sequential color-tv system which preceded the present simultaneous system .	164.86655
three separate amplifiers then drive a 21-inch tricolor tube .	18.548761
the result is a color picture of the specimen where the primary colors correspond to the three different ultraviolet wavelengths .	162.64755
many of the cells and microorganisms which are transparent to visible light , absorb or reflect the much shorter wavelengths of the ultraviolet spectrum .	26.234205
different parts of these cells sometimes absorb or reflect different wavelengths so that it is often possible to see internal portions of cells in a different color .	85.02396
where the microscope under visible light may show only vague shadows or nothing at all , ultraviolet illumination and subsequent translation into a color tv picture reveal a wealth of detail .	135.35234
at the present time the research team which pioneered this new technique is primarily interested in advancing and perfecting it .	69.34168
the medical title of `` lobar ventilation in man ' ' by drs . c . j . martin and a . c . young , covers a brief paper which is one part of a much larger effort to apply electronics to the study of the respiratory process .	106.11775
at the university of washington medical school , the electronics group has developed the `` respiratory gas analyzer ' ' shown in fig . 3 .	108.851265
this unit , affectionately dubbed `` the monster ' ' , can be wheeled to any convenient location and provides a wealth of information about the patient ' s breathing .	52.92412
in the lower center rack an 8-channel recorder indicates the percentage of carbon dioxide and nitrogen from the upper and lower lobes of one lung , the total volume of inhalation per breath , the flow of air from both lobes , and the pressure of the two lobes with respect to each other .	40.243526
usually the patient breathes into a mouthpiece while walking a treadmill , standing still , or in some other medically significant position .	126.4447
from the resulting data the doctor can determine lung defects with hitherto unknown accuracy and detail .	183.90045
the original electrocardiograph primarily indicates irregularities in the heartbeat , but today ' s techniques allow exact measurements of the flow of blood through the aorta , dimensioning of the heart and its chambers , and a much more detailed study of each heartbeat .	89.34647
for many of these measurements the chest must be opened , but the blood vessels and the heart itself remain undisturbed .	69.184235
a group of researchers at the university of washington have given a paper which briefly outlines some of these techniques .	169.52718
one simple method of measuring the expansion of the heart is to tie a thin rubber tube , filled with mercury , around the heart and record the change in resistance as the tube is stretched .	84.75025
a balanced resistance bridge and a pen recorder are all the electronic instrumentation needed .	267.87473
sonar can be used to measure the thickness of the heart by placing small crystal transducers at opposite sides of the heart or blood vessel and exciting one with some pulsed ultrasonic energy .	75.63056
the travel time of sound in tissue is about 1500 meters per second	46.65271
thus it takes about 16 msec . to traverse 25 mm . of tissue .	332.7207
a sonar or radar-type of pulse generator and time-delay measuring system is required for body-tissue evaluation .	169.7174
in addition to the heart and aorta , successful measurements of liver and spleen have also been made by this technique .	154.09062
the doppler effect , using ultrasonic signals , can be employed to measure the flow of blood without cutting into the blood vessel .	95.39515
a still more sophisticated system has been devised for determining the effective power of the heart itself .	46.877544
it uses both an ultrasonic dimensioning arrangement of the heart and a catheter carrying a thermistor inserted into the bloodstream .	106.62965
the latter measures the heat carried away by the bloodstream as an indication of the velocity of the blood flow .	37.073112
it is also possible to utilize a pressure transducer , mounted at the end of a catheter which is inserted into the heart ' s left ventricle , to indicate the blood pressure in the heart itself .	31.68241
this pressure measurement may be made at the same time that the ultrasonic dimensioning measurement is made .	58.972298
a simplified version of the instrumentation for this procedure is shown in fig . 2 .	30.645235
outputs of the two systems are measured by a pulse-timing circuit and a resistance bridge , followed by a simple analogue computer which feeds a multichannel recorder .	106.16335
from this doctors can read heart rate , change in diameter , pressure , and effective heart power .	214.80978
several years ago headlines were made by a small radio transmitter capsule which could be swallowed by the patient and which would then radio internal pressure data to external receivers .	199.19864
this original capsule contained a battery and a transistor oscillator and was about 1 cm . in diameter .	31.543707
battery life limited the use of this `` pill ' ' to about 8 to 30 hours maximum .	98.431206
a refinement of this technique has been described by drs . zworykin and farrar and mr . berkely of the medical electronics center of the rockefeller institute .	64.94167
in this novel arrangement the `` pill ' ' is much smaller and contains only a resonant circuit in which the capacitor is formed by a pressure-sensing transducer .	97.51406
as shown in fig . 4 , an external antenna is placed over or around the patient and excited 3000 times a second with short 400-kc . bursts .	220.01732
the energy received by the `` pill ' ' causes the resonant circuit to `` ring ' ' on after the burst and this `` ringing ' ' takes place at the resonant frequency of the `` pill ' ' .	47.291702
these frequencies are amplified and detected by the fm receiver after each burst of transmitted energy and , after the `` pill ' ' has been calibrated , precise internal pressure indications can be obtained .	74.53223
one of the advantages of this method is that the `` pill ' ' can remain in the patient for several days , permitting observation under natural conditions .	72.78209
applications to organs other than the gastrointestinal tract are planned for future experiments .	112.40328
one of the most gratifying applications of an important technique of submarine detection is in the exploration of the human body .	31.508265
our readers are familiar with the principles of sonar where sound waves are sent out in water and the echoes then indicate submerged objects .	175.09613
various methods of pulsing , scanning , and displaying these sound waves are used to detect submarines , map ocean floors , and even communicate under water .	131.23184
in medicine the frequencies are much higher , transducers and the sonar beams themselves are much smaller , and different scanning techniques may be used , but the principles involved are the same as in sonar .	89.65588
because the body contains so much liquid , transmission of ultrasonic signals proceeds fairly well in muscles and blood vessels .	90.24354
bones and cartilage transmit poorly and tend to reflect the ultrasonic signals .	56.855698
based on this phenomenon , a number of investigators have used this method to `` look through ' ' human organs .	210.87558
a good example of the results obtainable with ultrasonic radiation is contained in papers presented by dr . g . baum who has explored the human eye .	107.48133
he can diagnose detachment of the retina where conventional methods indicate blindness due to glaucoma .	783.8248
the method used to scan the eye ultrasonically is illustrated in fig . 6 .	27.009697
the transducer is coupled to the body through a water bath , not shown .	147.82982
for display , dr . baum uses a portion of an af , an airborne radar indicator , and then photographs the screen to obtain a permanent record .	56.631466
a typical `` sonogram ' ' of a human eye , together with a description of the anatomical parts , is shown in fig . 5 .	61.314587
the frequency used for these experiments is 15 mc . and the transducer is a specially cut crystal with an epoxy lens capable of providing beam diameters smaller than one millimeter .	160.93765
the transducer itself moves the beam in a sector scan , just like a radar antenna , while the entire transducer structure is moved over a 90-degree arc in front of the eye to `` look into ' ' all corners .	109.521225
the total picture is only seen by the camera which integrates the many sector scans over the entire 90-degree rotation period .	187.91577
drs . howry and holmes at the university of colorado medical school have applied the same sonar technique to other areas of soft tissue and have obtained extremely good results .	156.37106
by submerging the patient in a tub and rotating the transducer while the scanning goes on , they have been able to get cross-section views of the neck , as shown in fig . 7 , as well as many other hitherto impossible insights .	68.64712
as mentioned before , bone reflects the sound energy and in fig . 7 the portion of the spine shows as the black area in the center .	85.489685
arteries and veins are apparent by their black , blood-filled centers and the surrounding white walls .	147.10043
a cross-section of a normal lower human leg is shown in fig . 8 with the various parts labeled .	66.44867
oersted ' s boyhood represented a minimal chance of either attaining greatness or serving his people so well and over so long a span of life .	164.54274
he was born in the small danish town of rudkoebing on the island of langeland in the south-central part of denmark on august 14 , 1777 .	172.09834
his father soeren was the village apothecary whose slender income made it difficult to feed his family , let alone educate them in a town without even a school .	139.71396
the two older boys , hans and anders , his junior by a year , therefore went daily to the home of a warm and friendly wigmaker nearby for instruction in german	176.5531
his wife taught the two boys to read and write danish .	61.27005
other brothers later joined them for instruction with oldenburg , the wigmaker , and also arithmetic was added to bible reading , german , and danish in the informal curriculum .	89.09151
oldenburg ' s contributions were soon exhausted and the boys had to turn to a wider circle of the town ' s learned , such as the pastor , to supplement the simple teaching .	106.70655
from the town surveyor , hans learned drawing and mathematics and , from a university student , some academic subjects .	130.54955
the mayor of the town taught them english and french .	36.654808
whatever hans or anders learned separately they passed on to each other	78.908424
they read every book that they could borrow in the village .	24.909912
at 12 , hans was sufficiently mature to help his father in the apothecary shop , which helped stimulate his interest in medicine and science .	61.42603
his earlier love for literature and history remained with him for his entire life .	36.814034
in 1793 the brothers decided to enter the university of copenhagen ( founded in 1479 ) and the following spring found them at the university preparing to matriculate for the autumn session .	108.9677
while hans devoted himself to the sciences of medicine , physics , and astronomy , his brother studied law .	92.87847
the brothers continued to help each other during their studies , sharing a joint purse , lodging together in the dormitory and dining together at the home of their aunt .	140.6322
they supplemented their income by small government assistance , by tutoring and economizing wherever they could .	141.02832
so impressive were those serious years of study at the university that hans later wrote , `` to be perfectly free , the young man must revel in the great kingdom of thought and imagination	90.60585
there is a struggle there , in which , if he falls , it is easy for him to rise again , there is freedom of utterance there , which draws after it no irreparable consequences on society .	113.8189
i lived in this onward-driving contest where each day overcame a new difficulty , gained a new truth , or banished a previous error ' ' .	157.16187
he openly proclaimed his pleasure in lecturing and writing about science .	91.20448
in this third year at the university , hans , in 1797 , was awarded the first important token of recognition , a gold medal for his essay on `` limits of poetry and prose ' ' .	53.848053
he completed his training in pharmacy also , taking his degree with high honors in 1797 , and in 1799 was awarded the degree of doctor of philosophy along with a prize for an essay in medicine .	124.22607
he proposed a fresh theory of alkalis which later was accepted in chemical practices .	1162.4884
hans ' student days were at a time when europe was in a new intellectual ferment following the revolutions in america and in france , germany and italy were rising from divisive nationalisms and a strong wave of intellectual awareness was sweeping the continent .	152.21106
the new century opened with oersted beginning his professional career in charge of an apothecary shop in copenhagen and as lecturer at the university .	56.488743
he was stirred by the announcement of volta ' s discovery of chemical electricity and he immediately applied the voltaic pile to experiments with acids and alkalis .	166.53163
the following year he devoted to the customary `` wanderjahr ' ' , traveling in germany , france , and the netherlands , meeting the philosophers schelling , fichte , and tieck .	46.55442
he also met count rumford ( born benjamin thompson in woburn , mass . ) who was then serving the elector of bavaria , and the physicist ritter	97.14204
these were oersted ' s main contacts in science .	228.29503
from gottingen ( 1801 ) where he stayed for 10 days , he wrote , `` the first question asked everywhere is about galvanism .	106.51972
as everybody is curious to see the battery of glass tubes i have invented , i have had quite a small one made here of four glass tubes ( in copenhagen i used 30 ) and intend to carry it with me ' ' .	157.36763
oersted joined ritter at jena and stayed with him for 3 weeks , continuing their correspondence after he left .	308.4672
with ritter he was exposed to the fantastic profusion of ideas that stormed through his host ' s fertile but disorganized mind .	123.27461
oersted remodeled ritter ' s notes into an essay in french which was submitted to the institut de france for its annual prize of 3 , 000 francs .	118.9501
the sound discoveries of this quixotic genius were so diluted by those of fantasy that the prize was never awarded to him .	110.54102
in may , 1803 , ritter , in another flight of fancy , wrote to oersted a letter that contained a remarkable prophecy .	115.28633
he related events on earth to periodic celestial phenomena and indicated that the years of maximum inclination of the ecliptic coincided with the years of important electrical discoveries .	91.55511
thus , 1745 corresponded to the invention of the `` leiden ' ' jar by kleist , 1764 that of the electrophorus by wilcke , 1782 produced the condenser of volta , and 1801 the voltaic pile .	106.82527
ritter proceeded , `` you now emerge into a new epoch in which late in the year 1819 or 1820 , you will have to reckon .	126.69179
ritter died in 1810 and oersted not only lived to see the event occur but was the author of it .	124.64509
in 1803 oersted returned to copenhagen and applied for the university ' s chair in physics but was rejected because he was probably considered more a philosopher than a physicist .	131.57991
however , he continued experimenting and lecturing , publishing the results of his experiments in german and danish periodicals .	73.9919
in 1806 his ambition was realized and he became professor of physics at the copenhagen university , though not realizing full professorship ( ordinarius ) until 1817 .	152.07062
during oersted ' s attendance at the university , it was poorly equipped with physical apparatus for experimenting in the sciences .	67.91669
he was , however , fortunate in his contact with prof . j . g . l . manthey ( 1769-1842 ) , teacher of chemistry , who , in addition to his academic chair , was also proprietor of the `` lion pharmacy ' ' in copenhagen where oersted assisted him .	69.72778
manthey maintained a valuable collection of physical and chemical apparatus which was at oersted ' s disposal during and after his graduation .	50.81933
in 1800 , manthey went abroad and oersted was appointed manager of the lion pharmacy .	53.282963
in february 1801 , oersted did manage to experiment with physical apparatus and reported experiments made with a voltaic battery of 600 plates of zinc and silver and of later experiments with a battery of 60 plates of zinc and lead .	132.79901
in the following year , 1803 , oersted , simultaneously with davy , discovered that acids increased the strength of a voltaic battery more than did salts .	92.47854
eager as he was to pursue this promising line , he was so loaded down with the management of the pharmacy and lectures in the medical and pharmaceutical faculties at the university that he could devote only sunday afternoons to `` galvanizing ' ' .	63.806328
he assumed his academic career with the same intensity and thoroughness that had marked every step in his rise from boyhood .	219.61482
the university was the only one in denmark and the status of professor represented the upper social level .	166.6275
his broad interest in literary , political , and philosophical movements opened many doors to him .	138.24
his friends were numerous and their ties to him were strong .	343.58456
the years 1812 and 1813 saw him in germany and france again , but on this visit to berlin he did not seek out the philosophers as he had on his first journey .	107.576744
in berlin he published his views of the chemical laws of nature in german and this was issued in french translation ( paris , 1813 ) under the title recherches sur l ' identite des forces chimiques et electriques , a work held in very high esteem by the new generation of research chemists .	143.96582
his interest in finding a relationship between voltaic electricity and magnetism is here first indicated .	84.26163
chapter 8 , is entitled `` on magnetism ' ' and in it are included such remarks as , `` one has always been tempted to compare the magnetic forces with the electrical forces .	77.412834
the great resemblance between electrical and magnetic attractions and repulsions and the similarity of their laws necessarily would bring about this comparison .	137.3121
it is true , that nothing has been found comparable with electricity by communication	274.8173
but the phenomena observed had such a degree of analogy to those depending on electrical distribution that one could not find the slightest difference .	191.7729
the form of galvanic activity is halfway between the magnetic form and the electrical form .	90.30652
there , forces are more latent than in electricity , and less than in magnetism .	50.565727
but in such an important question , we would be satisfied if the judgment were that the principal objection to the identity of forces which produce electricity and magnetism were only a difficulty , and not a thing which is contrary to it .	124.65253
one could also add to these analogies that steel loses its magnetism by heat , which proves that steel becomes a better conductor through a rise in temperature , just as electrical bodies do .	249.11716
it is also found that magnetism exists in all bodies of nature , as proven by bruckmann and coulomb .	145.40364
by that , one feels that magnetic forces are as general as electrical forces .	108.68872
an attempt should be made to see if electricity , in its most latent stage , has any action on the magnet as such ' ' .	124.44395
oersted returned in 1814 and resumed an active part in university and political discussions .	71.412
in one debate he supported the freedom of judgment as opposed to dogma , in another he held that the practice of science was in fact an act of religious worship .	184.95619
he devised a detonating fuse in which a short wire was caused to glow by an electric current .	61.04646
in 1819 under royal command he undertook a very successful geological expedition to bornholm , one of the danish islands , being one of three scientists in the expedition .	88.218094
it was with the assistance of one of the members of this expedition , lauritz esmarch , that oersted succeeded in producing light by creating an electric discharge in mercury vapor through which an electric current was made to flow .	108.085266
together they also developed a new form of voltaic cell in which the wooden trough was replaced by one of copper , thereby producing stronger currents .	87.930244
esmarch was among those who witnessed oersted ' s first demonstration of his discovery .	49.492985
the association between electric ( both electrostatic and voltaic ) forces and magnetic forces had been recognized by investigators for many decades .	112.32408
electrical literature contained numerous references to lightning that had magnetized iron and had altered the polarity of compass needles .	103.598564
in the late 1700 ' s beccaria and van marum , among others , had magnetized iron by sending an electrostatic charge through it .	127.1398
beccaria had almost stumbled on a lead to the relationship between electricity and magnetism when a discharge from a leyden jar was sent transversally through a piece of watch-spring steel making its ends magnetic .	92.315254
the resulting magnetic effect proved stronger than when the discharge was made lengthwise .	61.566956
the experiments of romagnosi and others have already been noted but no one had determined the cause-and-effect relationship between these two primary forces .	144.64297
oersted ' s own earlier experiments were unimpressive , possibly because he had , like other experimenters , laid the conducting wire across the compass needle instead of parallel with it .	84.58372
the sequence of events leading to his important discovery still remains ambiguous but it seems that one of the advanced students at the university related that the first direct event that led to the publication of oersted ' s discovery occurred during a private lecture made before a group of other advanced students in the spring of 1820 .	103.67436
at this lecture oersted happened to place the conducting wire over and parallel to a magnetic needle .	51.28315
knowing specifically what the many feed additives can do and how and when to feed them can make a highly competitive business more profitable for beef , dairy , and sheep men .	151.85641
the target chart quickly and briefly tells you which additives do what .	1042.961
all the additives listed here are sanctioned for use by the food and drug administration of the federal government .	61.49616
all comments concerning effectiveness and use of drugs have been carefully reviewed by a veterinary medical officer with aj .	125.82184
this article assumes that the rations you are feeding your beef , dairy cattle , and sheep are adequately balanced with protein , vitamins , and minerals .	45.090492
the drug ' s chemical name is listed , since most states require feed processors to use this name instead of the trade name on the feed tag .	175.89966
in some instances , the trade name is shown in parentheses following the chemical name .	235.65872
this indicates that this drug is being marketed under one trade name only or state regulatory organizations have approved its use on the feed tag .	202.90956
here ' s your feed additive guide for ruminants	59.39859
increases rate of gain and improves feed efficiency , aids in the prevention or treatment ( depending on level fed ) of the early stages of shipping fever , prevents or treats bacterial diarrhea , and aids in reducing incidence of bloat and liver abscesses .	51.15173
milk production may be increased by the anti-infective properties of this drug .	35.605343
how to feed beef cattle ( finishing ration )	15.789208
-- to increase rate of gain and improve feed efficiency , feed 75 milligrams per head in daily supplement .	17.215103
-- to increase rate of gain and improve feed efficiency , feed 10 to 25 grams per ton of complete feed .	23.42386
as an aid in the prevention of bacterial diarrhea ( scours ) , feed 50 grams per ton of complete feed .	20.917986
for the treatment of bacterial scours , feed 100-200 grams .	16.23773
for prevention or treatment of bacterial scours , feed 0 . 1 to 5 milligrams per pound of body weight daily .	18.259335
-- as an aid in reducing incidence and severity of bloat , provide 75 milligrams of oxytetracycline hydrochloride per animal daily .	36.040813

for treatment of shipping fever , this level should be fed at the onset of the disease symptoms until symptoms disappear .	50.073692

reduces losses from stomach , hookworm , and nodular worms by interfering with reproduction of the female worm by reducing the number of eggs laid and essentially rendering all laid eggs sterile .	143.98367

there are three principal feed bunk types for dairy and beef cattle ( 1 ) fence-line bunks -- cattle eat from one side while feed is put in from the opposite side of the fence by self-unloading wagons	107.53095
( 2 ) mechanized bunks -- they sit within the feed lot , are filled by a mechanical conveyor above feeding surface	385.85144
( 3 ) special bunks -- as discussed here , they permit cattle to eat from all sides .	85.36279
several materials or combinations of materials can be used to construct a satisfactory feed bunk .	25.260202
the selection of materials depends on skills of available labor for installation , cost of materials available locally , and your own preference .	209.36038
no one material is best for all situations .	6.3470807
selecting bunks by economic comparison is usually an individual problem .	83.25108
animals eat only from one side , so the fence-line bunk must be twice as long as the mechanical bunk .	76.96945
these bunks also serve as a fence , so part of the additional cost must be attributed to the fence .	174.61229
because of their location , on the edge of the feed lot , fence-line bunks are not in the way of mechanical manure removal .	52.333244
filling these bunks by the same self-unloading wagons used to fill silos spreads cost of the wagons over more time and operations .	195.01958
all-weather roads must be provided next to the feeding floor so access will be possible all year .	401.8491
this will be a problem in areas of heavy snowfall .	1296.2356
marketing in the new decade will be no picnic -- for the sixties will present possibly the most intense competitive activity that you have experienced in the last 20-25 yrs . .	108.96463
companies of all types have made great advances in production capabilities and efficiencies -- in modern equipment and new processes , enlarged r & d facilities , faster new product development .	215.52551
many companies have upgraded their sales manpower and tested new selling , distribution , and promotion techniques to gain a bigger competitive edge .	92.68174
given this kind of business climate , what competitive marketing problems will your company face in the next 10 yrs . ? ?	90.63044
based on our experience with clients , , we see 14 major problems which fall into three broad groups -- the market place itself , marketing methods , and marketing management .	158.5352
there has been an intensification of price-consciousness in recent years	397.81525
frequently , wittingly or unwittingly , price-consciousness has been fostered by manufacturers , distributors , and dealers .	67.11129
despite generally good levels of income , we see greater price pressures than ever before -- traveling back along the chain from consumer to distributor to manufacturer .	377.86624
here are some key areas to examine to make sure your pricing strategy will be on target	65.65338
has the probable price situation in your field been forecast as a basis for future planning ? ?	115.524055
have cost studies been made of every phase of your operation to determine what might be done if things get worse ? ?	125.502884
have you actually checked out ( not just mentally tested ) different selling approaches designed to counter the price competition problem ? ?	195.00142
average consumer is becoming more sophisticated regarding product and advertising claims , partly because of widespread criticism of such assertions .	41.49084
this problem can force a change in marketing approach in many kinds of businesses .	201.10022
have you examined this problem of increasing consumer sophistication from the standpoint of your own company ? ?	22.872734
need for service is here to stay -- and the problem is going to be tougher to solve in the sixties .	27.627914
first , most products tend to become more complex .	53.009727
second , in a competitive market , the customer feels his weight and throws it around .	277.015
providing good customer service requires as thorough a marketing and general management planning job as the original selling of the product .	206.13174
too often it is thought of at the last moment of new product introduction .	145.67242
good service starts with product design and planning many products seem to be designed for a production economy , not for a service one .	136.47293
proper follow-through requires training your own sales organization , and your distributor organizations , not only in the techniques but also in good customer relations .	67.80877
have you assessed the importance of service and given it proper attention ? ?	110.715836
in spending his money today , the consumer is pulled in many directions .	104.511955
to the manufacturer of the more convenient-type product -- the purchase of which can be switched , delayed , or put off entirely -- the implications are important .	108.053734
your competition is now proportionately greater -- you are competing not only against manufacturers in the same field but also against a vast array of manufacturers of other appealing consumer products .	143.37344
many industry trade associations are developing campaigns to protect or enhance the share of the consumer ' s dollar being spent on their particular products .	137.48703
has your company thought through its strategy in this whole `` discretionary buying ' ' area ? ?	116.3557
the trends have been in evidence for many years -- population shifts to the southwest and far west , and from city to suburbs .	122.10922
these shifts will continue in the next 10 yrs . .	14.584318
have you considered the implications of continuing geographic shifts in terms of sales force allocation , strength of distributor organizations , and even plant location ? ?	111.58898
we have already witnessed great changes through mergers and acquisitions in the food industry -- at both the manufacturing and retail ends .	76.22342
instead of relatively small sales to many accounts , there are now larger sales to or through fewer accounts .	262.10123
the change may require different products , pricing , packaging , warehousing , salesmanship , advertising and executive attention -- practically every link in the marketing network may have to be adjusted .	150.57475
have you examined these trends , forecast the effects , and planned your marketing strategy to compete effectively under changing circumstances ? ?	153.55884
in the area of private label competition , it is logical to expect a continuation of trends which have been under way during the first decade .	29.128344
as mass dealer and distributor organizations grow in size , there is every reason to expect them to try to share in the manufacturer ' s as well as the distributor ' s profits -- which is , in effect , what the sale of private brands tends to do .	92.74708
average manufacturer frequently has helped build private brand business , delivering largely the same qualities and styles in private brand merchandise as in branded .	155.9545
moreover , the larger and more aggressive mass distribution outlets and chain stores have insisted on high quality -- and the customer seems to have caught on .	70.321655
if you are up against private brand competition , have you formulated a long-term program for researching and strengthening your market position ? ?	133.29475
if private brand competition hasn ' t been felt in your product field as yet , have you thought how you will cope with it if and when it does appear ? ?	276.3594
display merchandising , backed by pre-selling through advertising and promotion , will continue to make strides in the sixties .	22.774313
it has multiple implications and possible headaches for your marketing program .	137.1232
how can you cash in on this fast-growing type of outlet and still maintain relationships with older existing outlets which are still important ? ?	192.0825
if you have a higher-quality product , how can you make it stand out -- justify its premium price -- without the spoken word ? ?	190.41176
salesmanship is still necessary , but it ' s a different brand of salesmanship .	37.7716
have you carefully examined the selling techniques which best suit your products ? ?	1073.7601
have you studied the caliber and sales approaches of your sales force in relation to requirements for effective marketing ? ?	96.2169
are you experimenting with different selling slants in developing new customers ? ?	149.00826
some distribution costs are kept up by competitive pressure , some by the fact that the customers have come to expect certain niceties and flourishes .	77.08658
no manufacturer has taken the initiative in pointing out the costs involved .	124.55597
the use of bulk handling is continuously growing .	18.923813
computers are being used to keep branch inventories at more workable levels .	342.66946
`` selective selling ' ' -- concentrating sales on the larger accounts -- has been used effectively by some manufacturers .	99.839386
there may be possible economies at any one of a number of links in your marketing and distribution chain .	71.92551
do you have a program for scrutinizing all these links regularly and carefully -- and with some imagination ? ?	175.42355
in your sales force , will a smaller number of higher-priced , high-quality salesmen serve you best , or can you make out better with a larger number of lower-paid salesmen ? ?	242.77869
will your trade customers settle for less attention and fewer frills in return for some benefit they can share ? ?	149.21892
in one company covering the country with a high-quality sales force of 10 men , the president personally phones each major account every 6 mos . .	280.91965
as a result , distribution costs were cut , customer relations improved .	66.781555
distribution costs are almost bound to increase in the sixties -- and you will never know what you can do to control them unless you study each element and experiment with alternative ways of doing the job .	163.70552
from the manufacturer ' s point of view , the increasing cost of advertising and promotion is a very real problem to be faced in the sixties .	38.34488
it is accentuated by the need for pre-selling goods , and private label competition .	86.59865
how much fundamental thinking and research has your company done on its advertising program ? ?	117.79622
are you following competition willy-nilly -- trying to match dollar for dollar -- or are you experimenting with new means for reaching and influencing consumers ? ?	213.30861
have you evaluated the proper place of advertising and all phases of promotion in your total marketing program -- from the standpoint of effort , money , and effectiveness ? ?	47.70259
practically all forecasts mention new and exciting products on the horizon .	98.56126
will you be out in the market place with some of these sales-building new products ? ?	154.86635
if competition beats you to it , this exciting new product era can have real headaches in store .	117.703285
on the other hand , the process of obsoleting an old product and introducing the new one is usually mighty expensive .	372.46735
as markets become larger and marketing more complex , the costs of an error become progressively larger .	165.29651
is your r & d or product development program tuned in to the commercial realities of the market ? ?	69.503784
are there regular communications from the field , or meetings of sales and marketing personnel with r & d people ? ?	159.71332
technical knowledge is a wonderful thing , but it ' s useless unless it eventually feeds the cash register .	106.14224
are there individuals in your organization who can shepherd a new product through to commercialization	221.80597
who can develop reliable estimates of sales volume , production , and distribution costs	40.28101
and translate the whole into profit and loss and balance sheet figures which management can act on with some assurance ? ?	238.9735
we have seen good new products shelved because no one had the assignment to develop such facts and plans -- and management couldn ' t make up its mind .	84.19488
in the future , quantitative demand will be greater because of the expansion of the economy , and the qualitative need will be greater still .	134.18974
while many companies have done fine work in developing sales personnel , much of it has been product rather than sales training .	159.42784
nor has the training been enough in relation to the need .	60.865723
most marketing people agree it is going to take redoubled efforts to satisfy future requirements .	242.4537
have you estimated your sales manpower needs for the future ( both quantitatively and qualitatively ) ? ?	122.84386
has your company developed selection and training processes that are geared to providing the caliber of salesmen you will need in the next 10 yrs . ? ?	49.16416
with the growing complexity of markets and intensity of competition , sales management , whether at the district , region or headquarters level , is a tough job today -- and it will be tougher in the future .	113.83921
men qualified for the broader task of marketing manager are even more scarce due to the demanding combination of qualifications called for by this type of management work .	413.87744
the growth of business has outdistanced the available supply , and the demand will continue to exceed the supply in the sixties .	53.238712
does your company have a program for selecting and developing sales and marketing management personnel for the longer term ? ?	82.771034
does your management climate and your management compensation plan attract and keep top-notch marketing people ? ?	280.8074
every single problem touched on thus far is related to good marketing planning .	123.96139
`` hip-pocket ' ' tactics are going to be harder to apply .	28.358513
many food and beverage companies are already on a highly planned basis .	89.54488
with greater investments in plant facilities , with automation growing , you can ' t switch around , either in volume or in product design , as much as was formerly possible -- or at least not as economically .	203.60475
are planning and strategy development emphasized sufficiently in your company ? ?	121.32766
we find too many sales and marketing executives so burdened with detail that they are short-changing planning .	280.93344
are annual marketing plans reviewed throughout your management group to get the perspective of all individuals and get everyone on the marketing team ? ?	132.41318
do you have a long-term ( 5- or 10-yr . ) marketing program ? ?	65.9542
the key to effective marketing is wrapped up in defining your company ' s marketing problems realistically .	117.92908
solutions frequently suggest themselves when you accurately pinpoint your problems , whether they be in the market , in marketing methods or in marketing management .	63.183205
if companies will take the time to give objective consideration to their major problems and to the questions they provoke , then a long constructive step will have been taken toward more effective marketing in next decade .	175.10173
the controversy of the last few years over whether architects or interior designers should plan the interiors of modern buildings has brought clearly into focus one important difference of opinion .	201.35777
the architects do not believe that the education of the interior designer is sufficiently good or sufficiently extended to compare with that of the architect and that , therefore , the interior designer is incapable of understanding the architectural principles involved in planning the interior of a building .	104.72143
ordinary politeness may have militated against this opinion being stated so badly but anyone with a wide acquaintance in both groups and who has sat through the many round tables , workshops or panel discussions -- whatever they are called -- on this subject will recognize that the final , boiled down crux of the matter is education .	118.50727
it is true that most architectural schools have five year courses , some even have six or more .	184.39648
the element of public danger which enters so largely into architectural certification , however , would demand a prolonged study of structure .	66.63098
this would , naturally , lengthen their courses far beyond the largely esthetic demands of interior designer ' s training .	99.973976
we may then dismiss the time difference between these courses and the usual four year course of the interior design student as not having serious bearing on the subject .	162.77946
the real question that follows is -- how are those four years used and what is their value as training ? ?	196.89114
the american institute of interior designers has published a recommended course for designers and a percentage layout of such a course .	164.5345
an examination of some forty catalogs of schools offering courses in interior design , for the most part schools accredited by membership in the national association of schools of art , and a further `` on the spot ' ' inspection of a number of schools , show their courses adhere pretty closely to the recommendations .	60.241936
one or two of the schools have a five year curriculum , but the usual pattern of american education has limited most of them to the four-year plan which seems to be the minimum in acceptable institutions .	136.12062
the suggested course of the a . i . d . was based on the usual course offered and on the opinion of many educators as to curricular necessities .	110.31964
obviously , the four year provision limits this to fundamentals and much desirable material must be eliminated .	306.346
without comparing the relative merits of the two courses -- architecture versus interior design -- let us examine the educational needs of the interior designer .	68.66797
to begin with , what is an interior designer ? ?	12.831707
`` the dictionary of occupational titles ' ' published by the u . s . department of labor describes him as follows `` designs , plans and furnishes interiors of houses , commercial and institutional structures , hotels , clubs , ships , theaters , as well as set decorations for motion picture arts and television .	70.82293
makes drawings and plans of rooms showing placement of furniture , floor coverings , wall decorations , and determines color schemes .	112.155716
makes necessary purchases , places contracts , supervises construction , installation , finishing and placement of furniture , fixtures and other correlated furnishings , and follows through to completion of project ' ' .	76.58482
in addition to this the u . s . civil service bureau , when examining applicants for government positions as interior designers , expects that `` when various needed objects are not obtainable on the market he will design them .	217.22491
he must be capable of designing for and supervising the manufacture of any craft materials needed in the furnishings ' ' .	114.20327
the interior designer , then , must first be an artist but also understand carpentry and painting and lighting and plumbing and finance .	100.658676
yet nobody will question the necessity of all this and any reputable interior designer does know all this and does practice it .	233.29604
and further he must understand his obligation to the client to not only meet his physical necessities but also to enhance and improve his life and to enlarge the cultural horizon of our society .	77.51733
few will quarrel with the aim of the schools or with the wording of their curriculum .	113.29264
it is in the quality of the teaching of all this that a question may arise .	109.26656
the old established independent art schools try their best to fulfill their obligations .	40.325935
as in a recent design competition with a floor plan and the simple command -- `` design a luxury apartment ' '	227.51714
no description of the client or his cultural level , no assertion of geographical area or local social necessities -- simply `` a luxury apartment ' ' .	91.815155
working in a vacuum of minimal information can result only in show pieces that look good in exhibitions and catalogs and may please the public relations department but have little to do with the essence of interior design .	190.12805
it is possible , of course , to work on extant or projected buildings where either architect or owner will explain their necessities so that the student may get `` the feel ' ' of real interior design demands .	233.10043
unfortunately , the purely synthetic problem is the rule .	323.48996
it is like medical schools in india where , in that fairy-land of religious inhibition , the dissection of dead bodies is frowned upon .	177.15793
instead they learn their dissection on the bulbs of plants .	28.047392
thus technical efficiency is achieved at the expense of actual experience .	70.035576
in the earlier years of training certain phases of the work must be covered and the synthetic problem has its use .	99.66711
but to continue to divorce advanced students from reality is inexcusable .	64.2315
consultation with architects , clients , real estate men , fabric houses and furniture companies is essential to the proper development of class problems just as in actual work .	207.30681
fortunately , although only a few years ago they held the student at arms length , today the business houses welcome the opportunity to aid the student , not only from an increased sense of community responsibility but also from the realization that the student of today is the interior designer of tomorrow -- that the student already is `` in the trade ' ' .	119.78596
even the `` history of furniture ' ' can hardly be taught exclusively from photographs and lantern slides .	64.967255
here , too , the reality of actual furniture must be experienced .	70.75593
the professional organizations such as american institute of interior designers , national society of interior designers , home fashions league and various trade associations , can and do aid greatly in this work .	135.06563
certainly every educator involved in interior design should be a member and active in the work of one of these organizations .	35.621143
not only should every educator above the rank of instructor be expected to be a member of one of the professional organizations , but his first qualification for membership as an educator should be so sharply scrutinized that membership would be equivalent to certification to teach the subject .	62.5418
participation for the educator in this case , however , would have to be raised to full and complete membership .	51.7397
the largest of these organizations at present denies to the full time educator any vote on the conduct and standards of the group and , indeed , refuses him even the right to attach the customary initials after his name in the college catalog .	99.74147
this anomalous status of the educator cannot fail to lower his standing in the eyes of the students .	59.524364
the professor in turn dares not tolerate the influence in his classes of an organization in the policies and standards of which he has no voice .	138.69261
this seems somewhat shortsighted since if the absolute educational qualifications for membership which the organizations profess are ever enforced , the educator will have the molding of the entire profession in his hands .	108.570366
in one way the institutes and societies do a disservice to the schools .	50.96154
that is in the continuance of the `` grandfather clauses ' ' in their membership requirements .	84.14162
when these groups were first formed many prominent and accomplished decorators could not have had the advantage of school training since interior design courses were rare and undeveloped during their youth .	106.83404
long hard years of `` on the job ' ' training had brought them to their competence .	51.27926
the necessity of that day has long disappeared .	19.47529
there is plenty of opportunity for proper education today .	99.78518
it is discouraging for students to realize that the societies do not truly uphold the standards for which they are supposed to stand .	55.159164
the reason and the day of `` grandfather clauses ' ' has long since passed .	49.216846
no one can deny that these `` back door ' ' admissions to membership provisions have been seriously abused nor that they have not resulted in the admission of downright incompetents to membership in supposedly learned societies .	131.00139
beyond any question of curriculum and approach to subject must be the quality of the teachers themselves .	72.26002
it will occur to anyone that the teacher must have adequate education , a depth and breadth of knowledge far beyond the immediate necessities of his course plus complete dedication to his subject and to his students .	105.159676
the local decorator who rushes in for a few hours of teaching may but more likely may not have these qualifications .	105.38426
nor will the hack , the jack-of-all-trades , still found in some of the smaller art schools , suffice .	94.215225
only a few years ago a middle western college circulated a request for a teacher of interior design .	31.572687
at the end of its letter was the information that applicants for this position `` must also be prepared to teach costume design and advertising art ' ' .	96.290665
this kind of irresponsibility toward their students can scarcely build a strong professional attitude in the future designer .	97.813644
we must build a corps of highly professional teachers of interior design who have had education , experience in the profession and are willing to take on the usual accompaniments of teaching -- minimal income and minimal status among their confreres .	144.63635
considerable specialization in teaching subjects such as architecture , furniture design , textiles and color is also desirable .	96.33406
in all `` degree ' ' courses in interior design a number of `` academic ' ' or `` general studies ' ' courses are included .	87.936
it is only fair to demand that teachers of courses in english , history , psychology and so on be as well informed in matters of art , especially interior design , as are the art teachers educated in the academic subjects .	201.62497
the proper correlation of the art with the academic can be achieved only if this standard is observed .	176.24263
the matter of sympathy of the academic professors for art objectives also must be taken into account .	112.55297
one technical question of school organization comes to mind here .	226.89592
for proper accreditation of schools , teachers in any course must have a degree at least one level above that for which the student is a candidate .	135.74092
since there are almost no schools in the country offering graduate work in interior design this rule cannot at present be observed .	328.0829
indeed , it has only been a matter of the last few years that reputable schools of art have granted degrees at all .	67.202774
