reports jim lendrum `` by studying men on the job , we found that two men -- a carpenter and a helper -- can lay a floor faster than three .	79.38615
we found that three men -- two carpenters and a helper -- can put up wall panels or trusses more economically than four men -- because four men don ' t make two teams	131.44922
we found that wherever you can use two teams on a job , five men , not four , is the magic number ' ' .	110.02414
no house was ever built that could not have been built better for less if the work had been better planned and the work better scheduled .	245.02597
don ' t waste any $ . 10-a-minute time on green lumber to save $ . 03 a stud	248.46136
this is the most penny-wise , pound-foolish chisel a builder can commit .	201.35623
green lumber was all very well back in the days of wet plaster , when the framing lumber was bound to swell and then shrink as tons of water dried out the gypsum .	88.303825
but now that all production builders build with drywall and all smart builders build with panels , green lumber is an anachronism you cannot afford .	129.2475
dry studs cost less than $ . 03 more .	1185.5323
so if a green stud makes a carpenter or a drywall finisher or anybody else waste even 20 seconds , the green stud becomes more expensive than a dry stud .	84.342834
there comes a time in the lives of most of us when we want to be alone .	66.31436
not necessarily to be off all by ourselves , but away from the crowds and common happenstance .	72.058426
if you ' ve travelled in europe a time or two , it is quite certain that you ' ve had that wanting-to-be-alone feeling or that you will get it on your next visit across the atlantic .	163.63528
following a guide , and gratefully so , is an excellent way to see all the important places when everything is strange and new .	194.08528
however , after you ' ve seen all the historical piazzas and plazas , the places and forums , the churches and museums , the palaces and castles , and begin to feel at home in the capitals of europe , you ' ll want to change your course and follow the by-roads at will , far from the market places .	70.48791
the champagne at troyes , the traditional capital of the champagne country , has more ambrosial taste somehow than it has at a sidewalk cafe on the rue de la paix or at tour d ' argent .	133.7297
you can relive history and follow , in fancy , the crusaders in their quest for the holy grail as they sail out from brindisi , an ancient town in the heel of italy ' s boot .	113.90621
and you don ' t meet the folks from home in northwest spain which has remained almost untouched by time and tourists since the middle ages .	108.63836
time stands still as you climb the narrow , stone stairways in tiny villages clinging to steep mountain slopes or wander through story-book towns , perched atop lofty crags , their faces turned to the sea .	123.415306
they ' ve been there since the days of the moors and the saracens .	92.67361
and what better way to end a day than by dining with artists and gourmets in a squat but charming fisherman ' s village on the mediterranean ? ?	163.06915
an almost too-simple-to-be-true way to set forth on such adventures is just to put yourself behind the wheel of a car and head for the open road .	108.12831
for those who need or want and can afford another car , buying one and driving it on the grand tour , then shipping it home , is one popular plan for a do-it-yourself pilgrimage .	184.814
then , of course , there are those of us who either do not want or need or cannot afford another car .	101.530464
the answer to this diathesis is to pick up a telephone and arrange to rent one .	67.591415
almost any travel agent will reserve a car for you .	63.598854
you can call one of the car rental services directly ( hertz , avis , auto-europe nationalcar rental , and others ) and ask them to reserve a car of your choice , and some transportation lines offer this service as well .	202.683
with few exceptions , your car will be waiting for you at dockside , airport , railroad station or hotel when you arrive , oftentimes at no additional cost .	218.25195
you can wait , of course , until you arrive in europe before renting your car .	50.43734
the disadvantages to this method are that you may not have as great a choice of models readily available or you may have to wait a few days or , during the busy tourist season , when cars are in great demand , you might find it fairly difficult to get a car at all .	98.101425
since charges are relatively the same , reserving a car before you leave for europe will assure you of having one on tap when you want it .	152.2239
for those who plan to travel to europe by one route and return by another some agencies offer a service whereby you can pick up a car in one city on arrival and leave it in another city , or even another country , when you are ready to return home .	132.50041
at some cities , this pick-up and delivery service is without additional charge , and , if you are budget-wise , when you are planning your itinerary , you will take advantage of these free delivery and collection stations in major cities within the larger european countries .	119.5182
international touring documents are usually provided with the car as are road maps and touring data .	216.54514
a valid american driving license is accepted in all countries except portugal , spain , yugoslavia and eastern europe .	129.23691
if you plan to visit any of these countries , you can obtain your international driving permit before you leave at a nominal fee -- around $3 . 00 .	52.85726
your insurance , too , with most agencies , is provided with the car , covering comprehensive fire , theft , liability and collision with a deductible clause which varies in different countries .	82.36181
if you would feel happier with full collision insurance , there is a small additional charge , again varying from country to country and depending on the term of such insurance .	102.1692
the average charge for this additional insurance coverage is roughly $1 . 00 a day .	59.21237
the charge is variable , however , and goes as low as $ . 50 a day in ireland and as high as $2 . 00 a day in greece .	130.79678
rental fees are variable , too , throughout the countries of europe .	16.503431
there are as many rates as there are countries and models of cars available .	87.24963
as in the united states , there is a flat fee-per-day rental charge plus a few cents per kilometer driven , and the per-day rate drops if the car is retained for a week .	91.58078
it drops again after fifteen and/or twenty-one days .	27.207705
it is well to bear in mind that gasoline will cost from $ . 80 to $ . 90 for the equivalent of a united states gallon and while you might prefer a familiar ford , chevrolet or even a cadillac , which are available in some countries , it is probably wiser to choose the smaller european makes which average thirty , thirty-five and even forty miles to the gallon .	160.70238
your choice of model will undoubtedly be governed by the number of people travelling in your group .	68.30691
with the exception of the sports cars , even the quite tiny sedans will seat four passengers if you are willing to sacrifice comfort and luggage space for really economical transportation .	156.85147
there is a large variety of models to choose from in most countries , however , including 6-passenger sedans and station wagons and the rental fee isn ' t all that much greater than for the wee sedans .	92.734474
the basic costs are generally pretty much the same regardless of the agency through which you reserve your car , but some of them offer supplementary advantages .	70.22817
there is the free intra-city `` rent it here , leave it there ' ' service , as an example , the free delivery and collection at the airport , dockside or your hotel , luggage racks , touring documents and information and other similar services .	97.426125
a little investigation by telephone or reading the travel ads in the newspapers and magazines will give you these pertinent details on the additional money-saving benefits .	69.25236
the investigation will be well worth your time .	10.022318
all model cars are not available in all countries .	180.19719
quite naturally , there is a greater availability of those models which are manufactured within a specific country .	204.76007
if you would like to start your tour in italy , where the rental fees are actually the lowest in europe , fiats in all sizes are available , as are alfa romeo giulietta models .	67.03014
if you wish to budget closely on transportation , saving your extra dollars to indulge in luxuries , one agency lists the small fiat 500 at only $1 . 26 a day plus $ . 03 a kilometer and the fiat 2100 station wagon , seating six , at just $1 . 10 a day and $ . 105 a kilometer .	127.453865
if you will be using your car more than fifteen days , which isn ' t all unlikely , the daily rates drop quite sharply to $ . 86 a day for the fiat 500 and to an infinitesimal $ . 30 a day for the fiat 2100 station wagon .	73.87312
with six in the group , the cost comes to just a nickel a day per person on the daily fee .	180.5073
in the majority of countries , however , the rates range from $3 . 00 to $3 . 50 a day for the smaller sedans and graduate up to $7 . 00 and $8 . 00 a day for the larger , luxury european models , with the rate per kilometer driven starting at $ . 03 and going up as high as $ . 12 .	74.09337
the same model car might be available in six or eight countries , yet not two countries will have the same rate either for the daily rate or rate per kilometer driven .	150.12602
rates for american cars are somewhat higher , ranging from about $8 . 00 a day up to $14 . 00 a day for a chevrolet convertible , but the rate per kilometer driven is roughly the same as for the larger european models .	43.45236
rates in greece and finland are fairly high , actually the highest in europe , and , surprisingly enough , they are also quite high in ireland .	103.961945
if you are planning to tour europe for longer than a month , it might be wise for you to lease a car .	70.03842
the actual over-all cost , for the first month , will perhaps not be too much lower than the rental charges for the same period of time , but you will receive a new car .	74.0321
you will be entitled to all the advantages of a new car owner , which includes the factory guarantee and the services valid at authorized dealers throughout europe .	136.30533
further , there is no mileage charge or mileage limitations when you lease a car , and you pay only the flat monthly rate plus a nominal charge for documents and insurance since the car is registered and insured individually for your trip .	105.40516
there is a fairly wide selection of models of english , german and french manufacture from which you can choose from the very small austin 7 , citroen 2 cv , volkswagens , renaults to the 6-passenger simca beaulieu .	123.88575
leasing a car is not as common or as popular as renting a car in europe , but for long periods it will be unquestionably more economical and satisfactory .	68.039276
after the first month , rates are considerably less , averaging only about $60 a month for most 4- and 5-passenger models .	116.94643
there are reasons for some people not wanting to rent cars and going on the do-it-yourself plan .	78.10218
for one thing , the driver usually sees less and has less fun than his passengers since it becomes pretty necessary for him to keep at least one eye on the road .	136.31235
then , too , european drivers have reputations for being somewhat crazy on the road and some americans are not particularly keen on getting mixed up with them .	171.02495
still there is a way for those who want to see some of the back country of europe by car .	55.437374
the way is to rent a chauffeur-driven car .	2.9362278
it isn ' t as expensive as most people believe it to be .	86.518654
your chauffeur ' s expenses will average between $7 . 00 to $12 . 00 a day , but this charge is the same whether you rent a 7-passenger cadillac limousine or a 4-passenger peugeot or fiat 1800 .	108.128365
the big spread is in the charge for each kilometer driven , being governed by the rate at which gasoline is consumed .	160.989
since most european cars average more miles per gallon of gasoline than american cars , it naturally follows that the cost per kilometer for these models will be less , but the greater seating capacity of the large american cars will equalize this , provided your group is sufficiently large to fill a 7-passenger limousine .	161.2433
the fees for the rental of chauffeur-driven cars vary in the different countries in the same manner as they do for the drive-yourself cars .	80.72767
however , whether you arrange to have a european or american model , if you rent a car with the proper seating capacity in relation to the number of people in your party , your transportation expense will average very close to $10 . 00 per day per passenger .	120.93686
this will include your helpful , english-speaking chauffeur and a drive of an average of 150 kilometers in any one day .	43.46563
if you drive greater distances than that , you ' ll just be skimming the surface and will never discover the enchantment , fascination and beauty which lured you in the first place to explore the hinterlands .	92.085594
of course , if you want to throw all caution to the winds and rent an imperial or cadillac limousine just for you and your bride , you ' ll have a memorable tour , but it won ' t be cheap , and it is not recommended unless you own a producing oil well or you ' ve had a winner in the irish sweepstakes .	69.75698
in american romance , almost nothing rates higher than what the movie men have called `` meeting cute ' ' -- that is , boy-meets-girl seems more adorable if it doesn ' t take place in an atmosphere of correct and acute boredom .	88.41308
just about the most enthralling real-life example of meeting cute is the charles macarthur-helen hayes saga reputedly all he did was give her a handful of peanuts , but he said simultaneously , `` i wish they were emeralds ' ' .	94.08562
aside from the comico-romantico content here , a good linguist-anthropologist could readily pick up a few other facts , especially if he had a little more of the conversation to go on .	105.65884
the way macarthur said his line -- if you had the recorded transcript of a professional linguist -- would probably have gone like this af primary stresses on emeralds and wish	174.04852
note pitch 3 ( pretty high ) on emeralds but with a slight degree of drawl , one degree of oversoftness .	115.5667
conclusions the people involved ( and subsequent facts bear me out here ) knew clearly the relative values of peanuts and emeralds , both monetary and sentimental .	181.41055
and the drawling , oversoft voice of flirtation , though fairly overt , was still well within the prescribed gambit of their culture .	266.2419
in other words , like automation machines designed to work in tandem , they shared the same programming , a mutual understanding not only of english words , but of the four stresses , pitches , and junctures that can change their meaning from black to white .	121.33627
at this point , unfortunately , romance becomes a regrettably small part of the picture	77.787
but consider , if you can bear it , what might have happened if macarthur , for some perverse , undaunted reason , had made the same remark to an eskimo girl in eskimo .	87.58168
to her peanuts and emeralds would have been just so much blubber .	194.11499
the point -- quite simply -- is this words they might have had	350.1023
this basic principle , the first in a richly knotted bundle , was conveyed to me by dr . henry lee smith , jr . , at the university of buffalo , where he heads the world ' s first department of anthropology and linguistics .	48.37895
a brisk , amusing man , apparently constructed on an ingenious system of spring-joints attuned to the same peppery rhythm as his mind , smith began his academic career teaching speech to barnard girls -- a project considerably enlivened by his devotion to a recording about `` a young rat named arthur , who never could make up his mind ' ' .	106.76833
later , he became one of the central spirits of the army language program and the language school of washington ' s foreign service institute .	181.15399
it was there , in the course of trying to prepare new men for the `` culture shock ' ' they might encounter in remote overseas posts , that he first began to develop a system of charting the `` norms of human communication ' ' .	136.00708
to the trained ear of the linguist , talk has always revealed a staggering quantity of information about the talker -- such things as geographical origin and/or history , socio-economic identity , education .	146.71109
it is only fairly recently , however , that linguists have developed a systematic way of charting voices on paper in a way that tells even more about the speakers and about the success or failure of human communication between two people .	95.99986
this , for obvious reasons , makes their techniques superbly useful in studying the psychiatric interview , so useful , in fact , that they have been successfully used to suggest ways to speed diagnosis and to evaluate the progress of therapy .	83.49383
in the early 1950 ' s , smith , together with his distinguished colleague , george trager ( so austerely academic he sometimes fights his own evident charm ) , and a third man with the engaging name of birdwhistell ( ray ) , agreed on some basic premises about the three-part process that makes communication ( 1 ) words or language ( 2 ) paralanguage , a set of phenomena including laughing , weeping , voice breaks , and `` tone ' ' of voice , and ( 3 ) kinesics , the technical name for gestures , facial expressions , and body shifts -- nodding or shaking the head , `` talking ' ' with one ' s hands , et cetera .	136.65552
smith ' s first workout with stresses , pitches , and junctures was based on mother , which spells , in our culture , a good deal more than bread alone .	74.85259
for example , if you are a reasonably well-adjusted person , there are certain ways that are reasonable and appropriate for addressing your mother .	122.33441
the usual u . s . norm would be af middle pitches , slight pause ( juncture ) before mother , slight rise at the end .	162.25366
the symbols of mother ' s status , here , are all usual for culture u . s . a . .	185.63132
quite other feelings are evidenced by this style af note the drop to pitch 1 ( the lowest ) on mother with no rise at the end of the sentence	137.43317
this is a `` fade ' ' ending , and what you have here is a downtalking style of speech , expressing something less than conventional respect for mother .	180.91435
even less regard for mom and mom ' s apple pie goes with af in other words , the way the speaker relates to mother is clearly indicated .	179.4221
and while the meaning of the words is not in this instance altered , the quality of communication in both the second and third examples is definitely impaired .	163.9745
an accompanying record of paralanguage factors for the second example might also note a throaty rasp .	382.86496
with this seven-word sentence -- though the speaker undoubtedly thought he was dealing only with the subject of food -- he was telling things about himself and , in the last two examples , revealing that he had departed from the customs of his culture .	119.29592
the joint investigations of linguistics and psychiatry have established , in point of fact , that no matter what the subject of conversation is or what words are involved , it is impossible for people to talk at all without telling over and over again what sort of people they are and how they relate to the rest of the world .	85.88413
since interviewing is the basic therapeutic and diagnostic instrument of modern psychiatry , the recording of interviews for playbacks and study has been a boost of redstone proportions in new research and training .	123.92143
some of the earliest recordings , made in the 1940 ' s demonstrated that psychiatrists reacted immediately to anger and anxiety in the sound track , whereas written records of the same interview offered far fewer cues to therapy which -- if they were at all discernible in print -- were picked up only by the most skilled and sensitive experts .	148.29637
in a general way , psychiatrists were able to establish on a wide basis what many of them had always felt -- that the most telling cues in psychotherapy are acoustic , that such things as stress and nagging are transmitted by sound alone and not necessarily by words .	120.25216
at a minimum , recording -- usually on tape , which is now in wide professional use -- brings the psychiatric interview alive so that the full range of emotion and meaning can be explored repeatedly by the therapist or by a battery of therapists .	119.31612
newest to this high-powered battery are the experts in linguistics who have carried that minimum to a new level .	212.32985
by adding a systematic analysis with symbols to the typed transcripts of interviews , they have supplied a new set of techniques for the therapist .	65.20996
linguistic charting of the transcribed interview flags points where the patient ' s voice departs from expected norms .	168.31903
it flags such possible breakdowns of communication as rehearsed dialogue , the note of disapproval , ambivalence or ambiguity , annoyance , resentment , and the disinclination to speak at all -- this last often marked by a fade-in beginning of sentences .	129.3868
interpretation , naturally , remains the role of the therapist , but orientation -- not only the patient ' s vocal giveaways of geographical and socio-economic background , but also vocal but non-verbal giveaways of danger spots in his relationship to people -- can be considerably beefed up by the linguist .	103.18439
his esoteric chartings of the voice alert the therapist to areas where deeper probing may bring to light underlying psychological difficulties , making them apparent first to the therapist and eventually to the patient .	252.8542
in one now-historic first interview , for example , the transcript ( reproduced from the book , the first five minutes ) goes like this the therapist ' s level tone is bland and neutral -- he has , for example , avoided stressing `` you ' ' , which would imply disapproval	95.2428
or surprise , which would set the patient apart from other people .	202.48225
the patient , on the other hand , is far from neutral	299.65344
aside from her specifically regional accent , she reveals by the use of the triad , `` irritable , tense , depressed ' ' , a certain pedantic itemization that indicates she has some familiarity with literary or scientific language ( i . e . , she must have had at least a high-school education ) , and she is telling a story she has mentally rehearsed some time before .	101.83754
then she catapults into `` everything and everybody ' ' , putting particular violence on `` everybody ' ' , indicating to the linguist that this is a spot to flag -- that is , it is not congruent to the patient ' s general style of speech up to this point .	72.103836
consequently , it is referred to the therapist for attention .	250.88899
he may then very well conclude that `` everybody ' ' is probably not the true target of her resentment .	81.433014
immediately thereafter , the patient fractures her rehearsed story , veering into an oversoft , breathy , sloppily articulated , `` i don ' t feel like talking right now ' ' .	58.859364
within the first five minutes of this interview it is apparent to the therapist that `` everybody ' ' truthfully refers to the woman ' s husband .	56.83409
she says later , but still within the opening five minutes , `` i keep thinking of a divorce but that ' s another emotional death ' ' .	133.66626
the linguistic and paralinguistic signals of misery are all present in the voice chart for this sentence	179.16911
so are certain signals that she does not accept divorce .	71.38487
by saying `` another emotional death ' ' , she reveals that there has been a previous one , although she has not described it in words .	94.27698
this the therapist may pursue in later questioning .	16.426609
the phrase , `` emotional death ' ' , interesting and , to a non-scientific mind , rather touching , suggests that this woman may have some flair for words , perhaps even something of the temperament regrettably called `` creative ' ' .	119.631615
since the psychiatric interview , like any other interview , depends on communication , it is significant to note that the therapist in this interview was a man of marked skill and long experience .	111.28944
his own communication apparatus operated superbly , and lillian ross readers will note instantly its total lack of resemblance to the blunted , monumentally unmeshed mechanism of dr . blauberman .	82.43398
interestingly enough -- although none of the real-life therapists involved could conceivably compare with blauberman -- when groups of them began playing back interviews , they discovered any number of ways in which they wanted to polish their own interview techniques	297.76718
almost everyone , on first hearing one of his own sessions on tape , expressed some desire to take the whole thing over again .	137.80444
yet , in spite of this , intensive study of the taped interviews by teams of psychotherapists and linguists laid bare the surprising fact that , in the first five minutes of an initial interview , the patient often reveals as many as a dozen times just what ' s wrong with him	79.661026
to spot these giveaways the therapist must know either intuitively or scientifically how to listen .	391.66092
naturally , the patient does not say , `` i hate my father ' ' , or `` sibling rivalry is what bugs me ' ' .	28.214624
what he does do is give himself away by communicating information over and above the words involved .	484.92752
some of the classic indicators , as described by drs . pittenger , hockett , and danehy in the first five minutes , are these ambiguity of pronouns	79.87109
stammering or repetition of i , you , he , she , et cetera may signal ambiguity or uncertainty .	156.84856
on the other hand significant facts may be concealed -- she may mean i or everybody , as it did with the tense and irritable woman mentioned before , may refer to a specific person .	202.89107
the word that is not used can be as important as the word that is used	36.686607
therapist and/or linguist must always consider the alternatives .	15.64488
when someone says , for example , `` they took x-rays to see that there was nothing wrong with me ' ' , it pays to consider how this statement would normally be made .	89.40669
( this patient , in actuality , was a neurasthenic who had almost come to the point of accepting the fact that it was not her soma but her psyche that was the cause of her difficulty .	108.40321
) amateur linguists note here that pursewarden , in durrell ' s alexandria quartet , stammered when he spoke of his wife , which is hardly surprising in view of their disastrous relationship .	81.97669
she was just another freighter from the states , and she seemed as commonplace as her name .	107.865364
she was the john harvey , one of those atlantic sea-horses that had sailed to bari to bring beans , bombs , and bullets to the u . s . fifteenth air force , to field marshal montgomery ' s eighth army then racing up the calf of the boot of italy in that early december of 1943 .	88.497475
the john harvey arrived in bari , a port on the adriatic , on november 28th , making for porto nuovo , which , as the name indicates , was the ancient city ' s new and modern harbor .	110.34895
hardly anyone ashore marked her as she anchored stern-to off berth 29 on the mole .	605.90717
if anyone thought of the john harvey , it was to observe that she was straddled by a pair of ships heavily laden with high explosive and if they were hit the john harvey would likely be blown up with her own ammo and whatever else it was that she carried .	102.819115
it had required the approval of president franklin delano roosevelt before the john harvey could be loaded with 100 tons of mustard gas and despatched to the italian warfront .	68.76017
for in a world as yet unacquainted with the horrors of the mushroom cloud , poison gas was still regarded as the ultimate in hideous weapons .	116.72463
throughout the early years of world war 2 , , reports persisted that the axis powers had used gas -- germany in russia , japan in china again .	228.45403
influential people in america were warning the pentagon to be prepared against desperation gas attacks by the germans in future campaigns .	167.78949
some extremists went so far as to urge our using it first .	645.0814
to silence extremists , to warn the axis , president roosevelt issued this statement for the allies in august	137.47937
`` from time to time since the present war began there have been reports that one or more of the axis powers were seriously contemplating use of poisonous gas or noxious gases or other inhumane devices of warfare .	86.6302
i have been loath to believe that any nation , even our present enemies , could or would be willing to loose upon mankind such terrible and inhumane weapons .	214.69868
`` however , evidence that the axis powers are making significant preparations indicative of such an intention is being reported with increasing frequency from a variety of sources .	161.84244
`` use of such weapons has been outlawed by the general opinion of civilized mankind .	72.12646
this country has not used them , and i hope that we never will be compelled to use them .	61.68579
i state categorically that we shall under no circumstances resort to the use of such weapons unless they are first used by our enemies ' ' .	101.88547
the following month the invasion of italy was begun , and roosevelt gave effect to his warning by consenting to the stockpiling of poison gas in southern italy .	108.61251
bari was chosen as a depot , not only for its seeming safety , but because of its proximity to airfields .	82.96188
it would be made in three waves -- the first to lay down a smokescreen , the second to drop the gas bombs , the third to shower incendiaries which would burn everything below .	195.2993
so the vile cargo went into the hole of the john harvey .	24.49483
a detachment of six men from the 701st chemical maintenance company under first lt . howard d . beckstrom went aboard , followed by lt . thomas h . richardson , the cargo security officer .	125.48608
only a few other people -- very important people -- knew of the nitrogen-mustard eggs nestled below decks .	362.64798
thus , in the immemorial way -- in the way of the right hand that knows and the left that does not -- was the stage set for tragedy at bari .	85.71239
it was the night of december 2 , 1943 , and it was growing dark in bari .	77.77346
it was getting on toward 7 o ' clock and the german me-210 plane had been and gone on its eighth straight visit .	102.370316
capt . a . b . jenks of the office of harbor defense was very worried .	221.19244
he knew that german long-range bombers had been returning to the attack in italy .	54.471912
on november 24th , they had made a raid on la maddalena .	131.81647
two days later , some 30 of them had struck at a convoy off bougie , sinking a troopship -- and it had been that very night that the me-210 had made its first appearance .	144.79457
after it had reappeared the next two nights , jenks went to higher headquarters and said	112.87884
`` for three days now a german reconnaissance plane has been over the city taking pictures .	76.24268
they ' re just waiting for the proper time to come over here and dump this place into the adriatic ' ' .	115.95033
but the older and wiser heads had dismissed his warning as alarmist .	173.5339
even though it was known that the luftwaffe in the north was now being directed by the young and energetic general peltz , the commander who would conduct the `` little blitz ' ' on london in 1944 , a major raid on bari at this juncture of the war was not to be considered seriously .	67.357956
true , there had been raids on naples -- but naples was pretty far north on the opposite coast .	159.30754
more than that , allied air had complete superiority in the eighth army ' s sector .	87.98893
so captain jenks returned to his harbor post to watch the scouting plane put in five more appearances , and to feel the certainty of this dread rising within him .	141.5371
for jenks knew that bari ' s defenses were made of paper .	58.13151
the royal air force had but a single light anti-aircraft squadron and two balloon units available .	477.55447
there were no r . a . f . fighter squadrons on bari airfield .	11.156146
the radar station with the best location was still not serviceable .	46.929573
and everywhere in evidence among the few remaining defensive units was that old handmaiden of disaster -- multiple command .	315.07224
it had been made shockingly evident that very morning to ensign kay k . vesole , in charge of the armed guard aboard the john bascom .	206.94
a british officer had come aboard and told him that in case of enemy air attack he was not to open fire until bombs were actually dropped .	232.41786
then he was to co-ordinate his fire with a radar-controlled shore gun firing white tracers .	238.35509
`` this harbor is a bomber ' s paradise ' ' , the britisher had said with frank grimness .	78.8443
`` it ' s up to you to protect yourselves .	23.426167
we can ' t expect any help from the fighters at foggia , either .	77.28562
they ' re all being used on offensive missions ' ' .	11.093405
not fire until the bombs came down ! !	1.0397129
he thought of the tons and tons of flammable fluid beneath his feet and shook his head .	103.297066
like hell he ' d wait -- and supposing the radar-controlled gun got knocked out ? ?	190.41904
what would his guns guide on then -- the north star ? ?	184.53308
ensign vesole decided that he would not tarry until he heard the whispering of the bombs , and when night began to fall , he put seaman 2/c donald l . norton and seaman 1/c william a . rochford on the guns and told them to start shooting the moment they saw an enemy silhouette .	155.20404
below decks , seaman 1/c stanley bishop had begun to write a letter home .	63.15522
above decks on the john harvey , lieutenant richardson gazed at the lights still burning on the port wall and felt uneasy .	102.20014
there were lights glinting in the city , too , even though it was now dark enough for a few stars to become visible .	104.3864
bari was asking for it , he thought .	89.82127
for five days now , they had been in port and that filthy stuff was still in the hold .	117.993706
he hoped they would put in somewhere way , way down in the earth .	38.06902
the burden of his secret was pressing down on him , as it was on lieutenant beckstrom and his six enlisted men .	113.868904
lieutenant richardson could envy the officers and men of the john harvey in their innocent assumption that the ship contained nothing more dangerous than high explosive bombs .	80.72251
they seemed happy at the delay in unloading , glad at the chance to go ashore in a lively liberty port such as bari .	88.60705
nine of them had gone down the gangplank already .	1734.5557
deck cadet james l . cahill and seaman walter brooks had been the first to leave .	68.492
richardson had returned their departing grins with the noncommittal nod that is the security officer ' s stock in trade .	109.68329
the other half of the crew , plus beckstrom and his men , had remained aboard .	81.90578
damned if that wasn ' t a sailing ship standing out of the old harbor -- porto vecchio .	42.629898
the night was so clear that richardson had no difficulty making out the silhouette .	100.743286
then the thought of a cloudless sky made him shiver , and he glanced upward .	190.12506
it was a clear night and it was raining ! !	63.08046
capt . michael a . musmanno , military governor of the sorrentine peninsula , had also seen and felt the `` rain ' ' .	58.427837
captain musmanno ' s renovated schooner with the flamboyant name unsinkable had just left porto vecchio with a cargo of badly-needed olive oil for the sorrentine ' s civilian population .	140.68095
at exactly 7 30 , he felt a fluttering object brush his face .	231.15533
he turned the beam of his flashlight on it .	38.99177
it was the silver foil from the chocolate bar he had been eating .	114.31305
another , longer strip of tinsel whipped his mouth .	17.408737
it was `` window ' ' -- the tinsel paper dropped by bombers to jam radar sets , to fill the scope with hundreds of blips that would seem to be approaching bombers .	163.5263
unsinkable slowed and stopped , hundreds of brilliant white flares swayed eerily down from the black , the air raid sirens ashore rose in a keening shriek , the anti-aircraft guns coughed and chattered -- and above it all motors roared and the bombs came whispering and wailing and crashing down among the ships at anchor at bari .	136.87712
they had come from airports in the balkans , these hundred-odd junkers 88 ' s .	42.034203
they had winged over the adriatic , they had taken bari by complete surprise and now they were battering her , attacking with deadly skill .	232.83427
they had ruined the radar warning system with their window , they had made themselves invisible above their flares .	204.91399
and they also had the lights of the city , the port wall lanterns , and a shore crane ' s spotlight to guide on .	75.76097
after the first two were blacked out , the third light was abandoned by a terrified italian crew , who left their light to shine for nine minutes like an unerring homing beacon until british mp ' s shot it out .	129.10226
in that interval , the german bombers made a hell of bari harbor .	46.966423
merchant ships illuminated in the light of the flares , made to seem like stones imbedded in a lake of polished mud , were impossible to miss .	100.71216
captain musmanno roared at his men to lash three of the casks of olive oil together for a raft .	144.52762
they got it over the side and clambered aboard only a few minutes before their schooner went under .	119.94738
ensign vesole and his gunners had fought valiantly , but they had no targets .	55.71043
most of the junkers were above the blinding light of the flares , and the radar-controlled shore gun had been knocked out by one of the first sticks of bombs .	69.01593
vesole rushed from gun to gun , attempting to direct fire .	52.91194
norton and rochford fired wildly at the sounds of the motors .	35.86845
bishop rushed on deck to grab a 20-mm gun , pumping out 400 rounds before sticks of three bombs each crashed into holds one , three and five .	122.5436
luckily , she was not completely aflame and would go down before the gasoline could erupt .	171.04713
the order to abandon ship was given , but cries of pain could be heard from the wounded below decks .	95.26819
there is a pause in the merriment as your friends gaze at you , wondering why you are staring , open-mouthed in amazement .	178.0642
you explain , `` i have the strangest feeling of having lived through this very same event before .	108.51436
i can ' t tell when , but i ' m positive i witnessed this same scene of this particular gathering at some time in the past ' ' ! !	70.04099
this experience will have happened to many of you .	141.04057
emerson , in his lecture , refers to the `` startling experience which almost every person confesses in daylight , that particular passages of conversation and action have occurred to him in the same order before , whether dreaming or waking , a suspicion that they have been with precisely these persons in precisely this room , and heard precisely this dialogue , at some former hour , they know not when ' ' .	123.16967
most psychiatrists dismiss these instances of that weird feeling as the deja vue ( already seen ) illusion , just as they dismiss dream previsions as coincidences .	142.27473
in this manner they side-step the seemingly hopeless investigation of the greater depths of mystery in which all of us grope continually .	88.236015
when a man recognizes a certain experience as the exact pattern of a previous dream , we have an instance of deja vue , except for the fact that he knows just why the experience seems familiar .	66.30541
occasionally there are examples of pre-vision which cannot be pushed aside without confessing an unscientific attitude .	91.5717
one day maeterlinck , coming with a friend upon an event which he recognized as the exact pattern of a previous dream , detailed the ensuing occurrences in advance so accurately that his companion was completely mystified .	141.71687
rudyard kipling ' s scorn for the `` jargon ' ' of psychical research was altered somewhat when he wondered `` how , or why , had i been shown an unreleased roll of my life film ' ' ? ?	136.85938
the famous author tells us of the strange incident in something about myself .	120.35995
one day when he attended a war memorial ceremony in westminster abbey his view was obstructed by a stout man on his left , his attention turned to the irregular pattern of the rough slab flooring and someone , clasping him by the arm , whispered , `` i want a word with you , please ' ' .	62.609173
at that moment kipling was overwhelmed with awed amazement , suddenly recalling that these identical details of scene , action and word had occurred to him in a dream six weeks earlier .	179.09473
freud probably contributed more than anyone else to the understanding of dreams , enabling us to recognize their equivalents in our wakeful thoughts .	96.178925
however , readers who accept freud ' s findings and believe that he has solved completely the mystery of dreams , should ponder over the following words in his interpretation of dreams , chapter 1	130.68843
as `` a matter of fact no such complete solution of the dream has ever been accomplished in any case , , and what is more , every one attempting such solution has found that in most cases there have remained a great many components of the dream the source of which he has been unable to explain nor is the discussion closed on the subject of the mantic or prophetic power of dreams ' ' .	102.45123
dreams present many mysteries of telepathy , clairvoyance , prevision and retrovision .	11.2835865
the basic mystery of dreams , which embraces all the others and challenges us from even the most common typical dream , is in the fact that they are original , visual continuities .	108.54794
i recall the startling , vivid realism of a dream in which i lived through the horror of the bombing of a little korean town .	79.62126
i am sure that nothing within me is capable of composing that life-like sequence , so complete in detail , from the hodge-podge of news pictures i have seen .	272.5336
and when psychology explains glibly , `` but the subconscious mind is able to produce it ' ' it refers to a mental region so vaguely identified that it may embrace the entire universal mind as conceivably as part of the individual mind .	109.371025
skeptics may deny the more startling phenomena of dreams as things they have never personally observed , but failure to wonder at their basic mystery is outright avoidance of routine evidence .	184.75935
the question becomes , `` what is a dream ' ' ? ?	10.535401
is a dream simply a mental or cerebral movie ? ?	17.235592
every dream , and this is true of a mental image of any type even though it may be readily interpreted into its equivalent of wakeful thought , is a psychic phenomenon for which no explanation is available .	108.024216
in most cases we recognize certain words , persons , animals or objects .	184.19965
but these are dreamed in original action , in some particular continuity which we don ' t remember having seen in real life .	142.12033
for instance , the dreamer sees himself seated behind neighbor smith and , with photographic realism , sees smith driving the car	140.74791
whereas , it is a matter of fact that smith cannot drive a car .	167.21219
there is nothing to suggest that the brain can alter past impressions to fit into an original , realistic and unbroken continuity like we experience in dreams .	242.577
the entire concept of cerebral imagery as the physical basis of a mental image can find no logical support .	156.18185
a `` mental image ' ' subconsciously impressing us from beneath its language symbols in wakeful thought , or consciously in light sleep , is actually not an image at all but is comprised of realities , viewed not in the concurrent sensory stream , but within the depths of the fourth dimension .	137.892
dreams that display events of the future with photographic detail call for a theory explaining their basic mystery and all its components , including that weird feeling of deja vue , inevitably fantastic though that theory must seem .	189.31358
as in the theory of perception , established in psycho-physiology , the eye is recognized as an integral part of the brain .	57.655674
but then this theory confesses that it is completely at a loss as to how the image can possibly be received by the brain .	153.20311
the opening paragraph of the chapter titled the theory of representative perception , in the book philosophies of science by albert g . ramsperger says , `` passed on to the brain , and there , by some unexplained process , it causes the mind to have a perception ' ' .	108.5319
but why is it necessary to reproduce the retinal image within the brain ? ?	54.415085
as retinal images are conceded to be an integral function of the brain it seems logical to suppose that the nerves , between the inner brain and the eyes , carry the direct drive for cooperation from the various brain centers -- rather than to theorize on the transmission of an image which is already in required location .	116.455605
hereby , the external object viewed by the eyes remains the thing that is seen , not the retinal image , the purpose of which would be to achieve perceptive cooperation by stirring sympathetic impulses in the other sensory centers , motor tensions , associated word symbols , and consciousness .	111.480644
modern physics has developed the theory that all matter consists of minute waves of energy .	174.86852
we know that the number of radio and television impulses , sound waves , ultra-violet rays , etc . , that may occupy the very same space , each solitary upon its own frequency , is infinite .	159.25316
so we may conceive the coexistence of the infinite number of universal , apparently momentary states of matter , successive one after another in consciousness , but permanent each on its own basic phase of the progressive frequencies .	191.77776
this theory makes it possible for any event throughout eternity to be continuously available at any moment to consciousness .	196.70064
space in any form is completely measured by the three dimensions .	55.904533
if the fourth dimension is a physical concept and not purely metaphysical , through what medium does it extend ? ?	215.26637
it is not through space nor time that the time machine most approved by science fiction must travel for a visit to the permanent prehistoric past , or the ever-existent past-fantasy future .	182.03394
three seconds flat is the usual time , and the space is crossed by moderate mileage , while the overwhelming immensity of such journeys must be conceived as a static pulsation through an enormous number of coexistent frequencies which perpetuate all events .	122.4467
the body , senses and brain , in common with all matter , have their counterpart on each of a countless number of frequencies .	152.96155
the senses in each counterpart bear the impression only of phenomena that share its own frequency , whereas those upon all other frequencies are invisible , inaudible and intactible to them .	149.44408
consciousness is the factor that provides the progressive continuity to sensory impressions .	47.169415
when consciousness deserts the sleeping body and the wakeful world , it continues in the myriad progressions of the ever-present past and future , in a life as vibrant and real as the one left when the body tired and required sleep .	125.400955
if the photographically realistic continuity of dreams , however bizarre their combinations , denies that it is purely a composition of the brain , it must be compounded from views of diverse realities , although some of them may never be encountered in what we are pleased to call the real life .	119.55355
dr . h . v . hilprecht , professor of assyrian at the university of pennsylvania , dreamed that a babylonian priest , associated with the king kurigalzu , ( 1300 b . c . ) escorted him to the treasure chamber of the temple of bel , gave him six novel points of information about a certain broken relic , and corrected an error in its identification .	127.67303
as a matter of fact , the incorrect classification , the result of many weeks of labor by dr . hilprecht , was about to be published by him the following day .	115.492775
some time later the missing part of the relic was found and the complete inscription , together with other new evidence , fully corroborated the ancient priest ' s information .	162.79242
dr . hilprecht was uncertain as to the language used by the ancient priest in his dream .	122.31761
he was almost positive it was not assyrian nor cassite , and imagined it must have been german or english .	101.55347
we may conclude that all six points of information , ostensibly given by the dream priest , could have been furnished by dr . hilprecht ' s subconscious reasoning .	66.48451
but , in denying any physical reality for this dream , how could the brain possibly compose that realistic , vividly visual continuity uninterrupted by misty fadeout , violent break or sudden substitution ? ?	100.24936
that the perfect continuity was composed from the joblot of memory impressions in the professor ' s brain , or 2 .	76.15399
that the dream was a reality on the infinite progressions of universal , gradient frequencies , across which the modern professor and the priest of ancient nippur met ? ?	293.6001
the degree of circumstance , the ratio of memory to forgetfulness , determines whether a dream will be a recognized , fulfilled prevision , or the vaguely , effective source of the weird deja vue feeling .	110.50413
no doubt some experiences vanish so completely as to leave no trace on the sleeper ' s mind .	74.912186
probably less than one percent of our previsions escape final obliteration before we wake .	175.48999
when we arrive at the events concerned in the vanished majority , they , of course , cannot impress us as anything familiar .	82.31034
nevertheless , there are notably frequent instances of deja vue , in which our recognition of an entirely novel event is a feeling of having lived through it before , a feeling which , though vague , withstands the verbal barrage from the most impressive corps of psychologists .	129.00114
if deja vue is an illusion , then peculiarly , it is a most prevalent mental disturbance affecting even the most level-headed people .	198.86769
chauncey depew , one-time runner-up for the republican presidential nomination , was attending a convention at saratoga , where he was scheduled to nominate colonel theodore roosevelt for governor of new york when he noticed that the temporary chairman was a man he had never met .	42.801094
after the preliminary business affair was finished depew arose and delivered the convincing speech that clinched the nomination for roosevelt .	115.10402
if depew had told any academic psychologist that he had a weird feeling of having lived through that identical convention session at some time in the past , he would have been informed that he was a victim of deja vue .	52.80169
but the famous orator felt more than vague recognition for the scene .	62.646355
he remembered exactly when he had lived through it before , and he had something to prove he had .	102.17827
one week before the convention , depew was seated on the porch of a country home on the hudson , gazing at the opposite shore .	80.94946
`` the food is wonderful and it is a lot of fun to be here ' ' ! !	32.16477
so wrote a ten year old student in a letter to his parents from north country school , lake placid , new york .	93.69245
in this one sentence , he unwittingly revealed the basic philosophy of the nutrition and psychological programs in operation at the school .	43.896603
because the food is selected with thought for its nutritional value , care for its origin , and prepared in a manner that retains the most nutrients , the food does taste good .	129.74728
when served in a psychological atmosphere that allows young bodies to assimilate the greatest good from what they eat because they are free from tension , a foundation is laid for a high level of health that releases the children from physical handicaps to participate with enjoyment in the work assignments , the athletic programs and the most important phase , the educational opportunities .	150.62128
situated in a region of some of the loveliest mountain scenery in the country , the school buildings are located amid open fields and farm lands .	91.95645
these contemporary structures , beautifully adapted to a school in the country , are home to 60 children , ages eight to fourteen , grades four through eight .	261.37286
from fourteen states and three foreign countries they come to spend the months from mid-september to june .	51.306984
the director , walter e . clark , believes that a school with children living full time in its care must take full responsibility for their welfare .	155.52744
to him this means caring for the whole child , providing basic nutrition , and a spiritual attitude that lends freedom for the development of the mind .	96.59519
the concept of good nutrition really began with the garden .	30.102736
the school has always maintained a farm to supply the needs of the school .	76.56503
in a climate hostile to agriculture , mr . clark has had to keep alert to the most productive farm techniques .	80.61853
where a growing season may , with luck , allow 60 days without frost , and where the soil is poor , sandy , quick-drying and subject to erosion , many farmers fail .	111.832146
throughout the adirondack region abandoned farm homes and wild orchards bear ghostly testimony that their owners met defeat .	103.16362
mr . clark found that orthodox procedures of deep plowing , use of chemical fertilizers and insecticides , plus the application of conservation principles of rotation and contouring , did not prevent sheet erosion in the potato fields and depreciation of the soil .	72.80063
`` to give up these notions required a revolution in thought ' ' , mr . clark said in reminiscing about the abrupt changes in ideas he experienced when he began reading `` organic gardening ' ' and `` modern nutrition ' ' in a search for help with his problems .	75.76238
`` louis bromfield ' s writings excited me as a conservationist ' ' .	51.65485
by 1952 he was convinced he would no longer spray .	15.495481
he locked his equipment in a cabinet where it still remains .	81.19375
after reading `` plowman ' s folly ' ' by edward h . faulkner , he stopped plowing .	86.96842
the basis for compost materials already existed on the school farm with a stable of animals for the riding program , poultry for eggs , pigs to eat garbage , a beef herd and wastes of all kinds .	88.7124
separate pails were kept in the kitchen for coffee grounds and egg shells .	196.47783
all these materials and supplementary manure and other fertilizers from neighboring dairy and poultry farms made over 40 tons of finished compost a year .	98.807076
it was applied with a compost shredder made from a converted manure spreader .	56.3406
years of patient application of compost and leaf mulching has changed the structure of the soil and its water-holding capacity .	146.94424
soon after the method changed , visitors began asking how he managed to irrigate his soil to keep it looking moist , when in reality , it was the soil treatment alone that accomplished this .	148.67899
to demonstrate the soil of his vegetable gardens as it is today , mr . clark stooped to scoop up a handful of rich dark earth .	123.362755
sniffing its sweet smell and letting it fall to show its good crumbly consistency , he pointed to the nearby driveway and said , `` this soil used to be like that hard packed road over there ' ' .	114.687584
`` people and soils respond slowly ' ' , says walter clark , `` but the time has now come when the gardens produce delicious long-keeping vegetables due to this enrichment program .	83.0543
no chemical fertilizers and poisonous insecticides and fungicides are used ' ' .	11.77208
the garden supplies enough carrots , turnips , rutabagas , potatoes , beets , cabbage and squash to store for winter meals in the root cellar .	37.9794
the carrots sometimes don ' t make it through the winter	268.22186
the cabbage and squash keep until march or april .	33.63837
there is never enough corn , peas or strawberries .	31.17082
mr . clark still has to use rotenone with potatoes grown on the least fertile fields , but he has watched the insect damage decrease steadily and hopes that continued use of compost and leaf mulch will allow him to do without it in the future .	137.09862
a new project planned is the use of bio-dynamic starter .	383.29132
new ideas for improving nutrition came with the study of soil treatment .	208.50638
`` after the soil , the kitchen ' ' , says mr . clark .	31.461506
the first major change was that of providing wholewheat bread instead of white bread .	99.39099
`` adults take a long time to convince and you are thwarted if you try to push ' ' .	56.09904
at first the kitchen help was tolerant , but ordered their own supply of white bread for themselves .	282.03702
`` you can ' t make french toast with whole-wheat bread ' ' , was an early complaint .	30.50534
of course they learned in time that they not only could use whole-wheat bread , but the children liked it better .	190.32779
mrs . clark , as house manager , planned the menus and cared for the ordering .	300.76776
then miss lillian colman came from vermont to be kitchen manager .	168.48373
today whole grains are freshly ground every day and baked into bread .	196.53572
mr . clark ' s studies taught him that the only way to conserve the vitamins in the whole grain was prompt use of the flour .	62.417118
once the grains are ground , vitamin e begins to deteriorate immediately and half of it is lost by oxidation and exposure to the air within one week .	149.75717
a mill stands in a room off the kitchen .	47.001217
surrounding it are metal cans of grains ordered from organic farms in the state .	38.394142
miss colman pours measures of whole wheat , oats , and soy beans and turns on the motor .	43.082985
she goes on about her work and listens for the completion of the grinding .	34.433224
the bread baked from this mixture is light in color and fragrant in aroma .	94.97369
it is well liked by the children and faculty .	181.5833
`` lillian ' s bread is so good and everything tastes so much better here that it is hard not to eat too much ' ' , said the secretary ruefully eyeing her extra pounds .	83.53593
the school has not used cold prepared cereals for years , though at one time that was all they ever served .	140.48889
when the chance came , they first eliminated cold cereal once a week , then gradually converted to hot fresh-ground cereal every day .	272.276
they serve cracked wheat , oats or cornmeal .	7.1193624
occasionally , the children find steamed , whole-wheat grains for cereal which they call `` buckshot ' ' .	104.69177
at the beginning of the school year , the new students don ' t eat the cereal right away , but within a short time they are eating it voraciously .	101.10335
when they leave for vacations they miss the hot cereal .	39.0462
the school has received letters from parents asking , `` what happened to johnny ? ?	59.229683
he never used to like any hot cereal , now that ' s the only kind he wants .	113.38192
where can we get this cereal he likes so much ' ' ? ?	15.752814
salads are served at least once a day .	25.19882
most come from the root cellar or from the freezer .	40.224236
sprouted grains and seeds are used in salads and dishes such as chop suey .	43.68883
sometimes sprouted wheat is added to bread and causes the children to remark , `` lillian , did you put nuts in the bread today ' ' ? ?	107.496086
the school raises enough poultry , pigs , and beef cattle for most of their needs .	92.10847
lots of cheese made from june grass milk is served .	33.020332
hens are kept on the range and roosters are kept with them for their fertility .	65.15007
organ meats such as beef and chicken liver , tongue and heart are planned once a week .	164.38637
also , salt water fish is on the table once a week .	174.44235
for deserts , puddings and pies are each served once a week .	126.941284
most other desserts are fruit in some form , fresh fruits once daily at least , sometimes at snack time .	200.96698
dried fruits are purchased from sources where they are neither sulphured nor sprayed .	171.93887
apples come from a farm in vermont where they are not sprayed .	21.210297
oranges and grapefruit are shipped from florida weekly from an organic farm .	242.56555
finding sources for these high quality foods is a problem .	42.36067
following a talk by mr . clark at the new york state natural food associates convention , a man from the audience offered to ship his unsprayed apples to the school from vermont .	138.38687
wheat-germ , brewer ' s yeast and ground kelp are used in bread and in dishes such as spaghetti sauce , meat loaves .	48.054607
miss colman hopes to find suitable shakers so that kelp can be available at the tables .	69.31675
raw wheat-germ is available on the breakfast table for the children to help themselves .	43.507214
very few fried foods are used and the use of salt and pepper is discouraged .	52.124977
pitchers of water merely appear on the tables .	14.727904
the source is known so there is no necessity to remove insecticide residues .	169.22914
the cooking conserves a maximum of the vitamin c content of vegetables by methods which use very little water and cook in the shortest time possible .	497.7831
since mr . clark believes firmly that the chewing of hard foods helps develop healthy gums and teeth , raw vegetables and raw whole-wheat grains are handed out with fresh fruit and whole-wheat cookies at snack time in the afternoons .	116.385666
to solve the problem of the wheat grains spilling on the floor and getting underfoot , a ball of maple syrup boiled to candy consistency was invented to hold the grains .	105.53628
on their frequent hikes into the nearby mountains , the children carry whole grains to munch along the trail .	110.88068
they learn to like these so well that it isn ' t surprising to hear that one boy tried the oats he was feeding his horse at chore time .	95.45735
they tasted good to him , so he brought some to breakfast to eat in his cereal bowl with milk and honey .	100.07938
maple syrup is made by the children in the woods on the school grounds .	69.284004
this and raw sugar replace ordinary refined sugar on the tables and very little sugar is used in cooking .	85.04123
parents are asked in the bulletin to send packages of treats consisting of fruit and nuts , but no candy .	199.76546
mr . clark believes in a good full breakfast of fruit , hot cereal , milk , honey , whole-wheat toast with real butter and eggs .	63.420635
the heavy meal comes in the middle of the day .	13.415254
soup is often the important dish at supper .	4.114912
homemade of meat , bones and vegetables , it is rich in dissolved minerals and vitamins .	57.483006
the school finds that the children are satisfied with smaller amounts of food since all of it is high in quality .	103.81595
the cost to feed one person is just under one dollar a day .	167.93013
even before he saw the necessity of growing better food and planning good nutrition , mr . clark felt the school had a good health program .	103.30801
rugged outdoor exercise for an hour and a half every day in all kinds of weather was the rule .	54.222275
a vigorous program existed in skiing , skating sports and overnight hiking .	52.931973
since the change to better nutrition , he feels he can report on improvements in health , though he considers the following statements observations and not scientific proof .	265.30386
visitors to the school ask what shampoo they use on the children ' s hair to bring out the sheen .	113.618484
the ruddy complexion of the faces also brings comment .	199.381
buffeted by swirling winds , the little green biplane struggled northward between the mountains beyond northfield gulf .	69.42065
wires whined as a cold november blast rocked the silver wings , but the engine roar was reassuring to the pilot bundled in the open cockpit .	43.2028
he peered ahead and grinned as the railroad tracks came into view again below .	373.54056
`` good old iron compass ' ' ! !	1.0215938
a plume of smoke rose from a central vermont locomotive which idled behind a string of gravel cars , and little figures that were workmen labored to set the ruptured roadbed to rights .	156.00784
the girders of a shattered dog river bridge lay strewn for half a mile downstream .	159.61603
vermont ' s main railroad line was prostrate .	26.489614
and in the dark days after the great flood of 1927 -- the worst natural disaster in the state ' s history -- the little plane was its sole replacement in carrying the united states mails .	82.122086
rain of near cloudburst proportions had fallen for three full days and it was still raining on the morning of friday , november 4 , 1927 , when officials of the post office department ' s railway mail service realized that their distribution system for vermont had been almost totally destroyed overnight .	84.35969
clerks and postmasters shoveled muck out of their offices -- those who still had offices -- and wondered how to move the mail .	153.39886
the state ' s railroad system counted miles of broken bridges and missing rights-of-way it would obviously remain out of commission for weeks .	436.30307
and once medicine , food , clothing and shelter had been provided for the flood ' s victims , communications and the mail were the next top problems .	136.82484
from burlington , outgoing mail could be ferried across lake champlain to the railroad at port kent , n . y . .	74.31437
the nearest undisrupted end of track from boston was at concord , n . h . .	32.07208
when governor al smith offered new york national guard planes to fly the mail in and out of the state , it seemed a likely temporary solution , easing burlington ' s bottleneck and that at montpelier too .	131.99641
the question was `` where to land ' ' ? ?	3.1453986
there was no such thing as an airport in vermont .	133.32939
burlington aviator john j . burns suggested the parade ground southwest of fort ethan allen , and soon a dozen hastily-summoned national guard pilots were bringing their wide-winged `` jenny ' ' and dehaviland two-seaters to rest on the frozen sod of the military base .	77.470955
the only available field that could be used near flood-ravaged montpelier was on the towne farm off upper main street , a narrow hillside where takeoffs and landings could be safely made only under light wind conditions .	143.42322
over in barre the streets had been deep in swirling water , and bridges were crumpled and gone .	74.69066
anticipating delivery of medicines and yeast by plane , granite city citizens formed an airfield committee and with the aid of quarrymen and the 172nd infantry , vermont national guard , laid out runways on wilson flat , high on millstone hill .	143.36407
the `` barre aviation field ' ' was set to receive its first aircraft the sunday following the flood .	147.61612
though the makeshift airports were ready , the york state guard flyers proved unable to keep any kind of mail schedule .	104.36709
they had courage but their meager training consisted of weekend hops in good weather , in and out of established airports , and the increasingly cold weather soon raised hob with the water cooled engines of their world war 1 , planes .	151.47484
it seemed like a good time for officials to use a recently-passed law empowering the post office department to contract for the transport of first class mail by air .	239.19398
they had to act fast , for letters were clogging the terminals .	135.33368
down in concord , new hampshire , was a flier in the right place at the right time robert s . fogg , a native new englander , had been a world war 1 , flying instructor , barnstormer , and one of the original planners of the concord airport .	58.13595
tall , wiry , dark-haired bob fogg had already racked up one historical first in air mail history .	380.38885
piloting a curtiss navy mf flying boat off lake winnipesaukee in 1925 , he had inaugurated the original rural delivery air service in america .	83.16554
during the excitement following lindbergh ' s flight to paris earlier in 1927 , dare devil aviators overnight became legendary heroes .	323.83167
in concord , bob fogg was the most prominent new hampshire boy with wings .	389.85934
public-spirited backers staked him to a brand-new airplane , aimed at putting their city and state on the flying map .	205.81314
the ship was a waco biplane , one of the first two of its type to be fitted with the air cooled , 225/hp wright radial engine known as the whirlwind .	151.57382
a trim green and silver-painted craft only 22-1/2 feet long , the waco was entered to compete in the `` on-to-spokane ' ' air derby of 1927 .	55.618988
as a matter of fact , fogg and his plane didn ' t get beyond pennsylvania in the race -- an engine oil leak forced him down -- but the flying service and school he started subsequently were first steps in paying off his wry-faced backers .	245.57175
so with all this experience , bob fogg was a natural choice to receive the first emergency air mail star route contract .	202.54568
his work began just six days after the flood .	235.63086
by airline from concord to burlington is a distance of about 150 miles , counting a slight deviation for the stop at either barre or montpelier .	86.60839
the first few days bob fogg set his plane down on towne field back of the state house when the wind was right , and used wilson flat above barre when it wasn ' t .	111.58935
between the unsafe towne field and the long roundabout back road haul that was necessary to gain access to wilson flat , arrangements at the state capital were far from satisfactory .	212.61159
each time in , the unhappy pilot , pushing his luck , begged the postal officials that met him to find a safer landing place , preferably on the flat-topped hills across the winooski river .	89.94946
`` but fogg ' ' , they countered , `` we can ' t get over there .	29.436012
and besides you seem to make it all right here ' ' .	15.097545
it took a tragedy to bring things to a head .	63.100075
after a week of precarious uphill landings and downwind takeoffs , fogg one day looked down at the shattered yellow wreckage of an army plane strewn across snow-covered towne field .	64.96552
sent to montpelier by secretary herbert hoover , red cross aide reuben sleight had been killed , and his pilot , lt . franklin wolfe , badly injured .	163.90094
with the field a blur of white the unfortunate pilot had simply flown into the hillside .	166.0732
faced with this situation , postmaster charles f . mckenna of montpelier went with fogg on a burlington trip , and together they scouted the terrain on the heights of berlin .	179.84096
a long flat known as the st . john field seemed to answer their purpose , and since the winooski bridges were at last passable , they decided to use it .	79.146706
with a wary eye on the farmer ' s bull , fred somers of montpelier and mr . st . john marked the field with a red table cloth .	74.28124
as a wind direction indicator , they tied a cotton rag to a sapling .	76.39429
with these aids , and a pair of skiis substituting for wheels on the waco , bob fogg made the first landing on what is now part of the barre-montpelier airport on november 21 , 1927 .	145.71579
each trip saw the front cockpit filled higher with mail pouches .	408.29953
during the second week of operations , fogg received a telegram from the post office department , asking him to `` put on two airplanes and make two flights daily , plus one sunday trip ' ' .	141.4958
since fogg ' s was a one-man , one-plane flying service , this meant that he would have to do both trips , flying alone 600 miles a day , under sub-freezing temperature conditions .	189.9759
over the weeks , america ' s first star route air mail settled into a routine pattern despite the vagaries of weather and the lack of ground facilities and aids to navigation .	159.22778
each morning at five fogg crawled out of bed to bundle into flying togs over the furnace register of his home .	95.057144
always troubled by poor circulation in his feet , he experimented with various combinations of socks and shoes before finally adopting old-style felt farmer ' s boots with his sheepskin flying boots pulled over them .	94.04193
a sheep-lined leather flying suit , plus helmet , goggles and mittens completed his attire for the rigors of the open cockpit .	61.2343
the airman ' s stock answer to `` weren ' t you cold ' ' ? ?	27.161293
became `` yes , the first half hour is tough , but by then i ' m so numb i don ' t notice it ' ' ! !	78.2354
as daylight began to show through the frosty windows , fogg would place a call to william a . shaw at the u . s . weather station at northfield , vermont , for temperature and wind-velocity readings .	124.398674
shaw could also give the flyer a pretty good idea of area visibility by a visual check of the mountains to be seen from his station .	107.99053
`` ceilings ' ' were judged by comparison with known mountain heights and cloud positions .	174.36287
later on in the day fogg could get a better weather picture from the burlington weather bureau supervised by frank e . hartwell .	161.89522
out at the airport each morning , fogg ' s skilled mechanic caleb marston would have the waco warmed up and running in the drafty hangar .	62.223217
( he ' d get the engine oil flowing with an electric heater under a big canvas cover .	65.83354
) wishing to show that aviation was dependable and here to stay , bob fogg always made a point of taking off each morning on the dot of seven , disregarding rain , snow and sleet in true postal tradition .	182.57089
concord learned to set its clocks by the rackety bark of the whirlwind ' s exhaust overhead .	104.469604
sometimes the pilot had to turn back if fully blocked by fog , but 85% of his trips were completed .	161.01733
plane radios were not yet available , and once in the air , fogg flew his ship by compass , a good memory for landmarks as seen from above , and a capacity for dead reckoning and quick computation .	81.426994
often , threading through the overcast , he was forced to fly close to the ground by a low ceiling , skimming above the winooski or the white river along the line of the broken railroad .	104.20533
when driving rain or mist socked in one valley , fogg would chandelle up and over to reverse course and try another one , ranging from the ottauquechee up to danville in search of safe passage through the mountain passes .	244.68738
the dependable wright engine was never stopped on these trips .	89.56846
it ticked over smoothly , idling while fogg exchanged mails with the armed messenger from burlington at fort ethan allen , and one from montpelier and barre at the st . john field .	65.65639
sometimes , on a return trip , the aviator would `` go upstairs ' ' high over the clouds .	128.0616
there he ' d take a compass reading , figure his air speed , and deduce that in a certain number of minutes he ' d be over the broad meadows of the merrimack valley where it would be safe to let down through the overcast and see the ground before it hit him .	97.64774
bob fogg didn ' t have today ' s advantages of instrument flight and ground control approach systems .	705.75824
at the end of the calculated time he ' d nose the waco down through the cloud bank and hope to break through where some feature of the winter landscape would be recognizable .	143.1958
usually back in concord by noon , there was just time to get partially thawed out , refuel , and grab a bit of mrs . fogg ' s hot broth before starting the second trip .	88.70107
day after day fogg shuttled back and forth on his one-man air mail route , until the farmers in their snowy barnyards and the road repairmen came to recognize the stubby plane as their link with the rest of the country .	90.99839
at fort ethan allen the ever-present wind off lake champlain could readily flip a puny man-made thing like an airplane if the pilot miscalculated .	193.71127
once the soldiers from the barracks had to hold the ship from blowing away while fogg revved the engine and got the tail up .	257.87204
at a nod of his head they let go , turning to cup their ears against the icy slipstream .	265.64743
tracks in the snow showed the plane was airborne in less than a hundred feet .	63.203094
one afternoon during a cold , powdery snowstorm , fogg took off for concord from the st . john field .	56.599155
if so , are you saying , `` where did the last few years go ? ?	93.77281
how did i get to be sixty-five so fast ? ?	202.44229
what do i do now ' ' ? ?	1.0406947
yes , retirement seems to creep upon you suddenly .	168.07777
somehow we old-timers never figured we would ever retire .	158.22443
we always thought we would die with our boots on .	327.70093
out of the blue comes talk of pension plans .	60.01405
compulsory retirement at sixty-five looms on our horizon .	6.0678625
still , it seems in the far future .	12.699736
suddenly , one day , up it pops ! !	7.491258
sixty-five years and you ' ve had it ! !	17.052021
you ' ve thought about it before in a hazy sort of way .	89.06581
never seemed as if it could happen to you	77.62915
a great many retired people are the so-called white collar workers .	17.5938
if so , you are of the old school .	137.39291
you are conscientious , hard working , honest , accurate , a good penman , and a stickler for a job well done , with no loose ends .	105.39476
also you can spell , without consulting a dictionary for every other word .	279.45242
you never are late for work and seldom absent .	111.46268
actually , you can take no special credit for this .	20.271025
it is the way you were taught and your way of life .	48.594906
all this is standard equipment for a man of your day	69.63694
however , the last few years of your life , things seem to be changing .	77.09147
your way doesn ' t seem to be so darned important any more .	365.38705
you realize you are getting in the old fogy class .	94.170135
to put it bluntly , you are getting out-moded .	880.7171
now , looming on the horizon are such things as estimated totals , calculated risks and i . b . m . machines .	110.038574
this is followed by a boom in conferences .	22.432287
when a plan burst its seams , hasty conferences supply the necessary patch , and life goes merrily on .	584.27924
you had your day and it was a good day .	27.266726
well , to get back to the problem of retirement .	85.15774
every retiring person has a different situation facing him .	47.178513
