an interested sitter may think the sensitive has made a `` hit ' ' , describing something accurately for him , but can he really be sure that another sitter , hearing the same statement , would not apply it subjectively to his own circumstances ? ?	115.57393
it is , of course , easy to see how `` j ' ' will mean uncle jack to one person and little jane to another .	294.79517
`` a journey ' ' , `` a little white house ' ' , `` a change of outlook ' ' , can apply to many people .	43.50822
and even more complex items can be interpreted to conform to one ' s own point of view , which is by nature so personal .	76.76357
one sitter may think `` a leather couch ' ' identifies a reading as surely directed to him	266.03928
to another , it seems that nobody but his father ever used the phrase , `` atta boy ' ' ! !	56.546604
to get around this quite difficult corner , there is one first aid to objectiveness prevent the distant sitter from knowing which reading was for him .	209.75517
if he is not told which of four or five readings was meant for him , he can more readily assess each item in a larger frame `` does that statement really sound as if it were for me , significant in my particular life ? ?	165.916
or am i taking something that could really apply to almost anybody , and forgetting that many other people probably have had a similar experience ' ' ? ?	138.39719
conversely , experimenters would consider as impressive such statements as the following , which , if they turned out to be hits , are so unusual as to be really significant	123.67793
`` he had four children , two sets of twins .	22.080652
after being a lawyer for twenty-five years he started studying for the ministry .	74.031876
part of his house had been moved to the other side of the road .	31.004175
he died of typhoid in 1921 ' ' .	1.7784424
methods have been developed of assigning `` weights ' ' to statements	60.813477
that is , it is known empirically that names beginning with r are more common than those beginning with z	447.42972
that in the united states more people die of heart disease than of smallpox .	435.31808
so each reading can be given a weight and each reading a score by adding up these weights .	145.36427
specific dates would be important , as would double names .	1765.2161
various categories have been explored to find out about these `` empirical probabilities ' ' against which to measure the readings .	111.869
in the parapsychology foundation ' s long-range experiment , readings are made by a variety of sensitives for a large number of cooperating sitters , trying to throw light on this question of the significance of mediumistic statements .	108.73615
it is very important indeed , in the field of extra-sensory perception and its relation to the survival hypothesis , to know whether the statements are actually only those which any intuitive person might venture and an eager sitter attach to himself .	109.11526
or , on the other hand , are unlikely facts being stated , facts which are in themselves significant and not easily applicable to everybody ? ?	378.03564
that is one thing the experiments are designed to find out .	29.32779
so , after the sitting has been held , several readings at one time are mailed , and the distant sitter ( whose name or whose communicator ' s name was given to the medium ) must mark each little item as correct ( hit ) , incorrect ( miss ) , doubtful , or especially significant ( applying to him and , he feels , not to anyone else ) .	131.26851
he is required to mark every item and to indicate which reading he feels is actually his .	404.88303
all these evaluations are then totted up and tabulated , by adding up the hits and significants , with the weight placed on those in the sitter ' s own reading .	56.179344
that is , if he marks as most correct a reading not meant for him , the total experimental score falls .	339.73618
conversely , if he gives a heavy rating to his own reading , and finds more accurate facts in it than in the others , a point is chalked up for the intrinsic , objective meaningfulness of this type of mediumistic material .	139.24553
and there are some positive results , though the final findings will not be known for a long time -- and then further research can be formulated .	94.632195
in another approach to the same procedure , the content of the readings is analyzed so as to see how the particular medium is likely to slant her statements .	121.607414
does she often speak of locations , of cause of death ? ?	328.27536
does she accurately give dates , ages , kind of occupation ? ?	260.40042
it is possible to find out in which categories most of her correct statements fall , and where she makes most of her `` hits ' ' .	137.62103
now when , so to speak , the cream has been skimmed off , and the items in the successful categories separated out , the sitter can be asked to consider and rate only this concentrated `` cream ' ' , where the sensitive is at her best .	152.5848
mediumistic impressions are evidently of all sorts and seem to involve all the senses .	131.17885
`` i feel cold ' ' , the medium says , or `` my leg aches ' ' , `` my head is heavy ' ' .	84.93072
or perhaps she hears words or sounds `` there ' s such a noise of loud machinery ' ' , or `` i hear a child crying ' ' , or `` he says we ' re all here and glad to see you ' ' .	44.09417
maybe an entire scene comes into consciousness , with action and motion , or a static view `` a house under a pine tree , with a little stone path going up to the door ' ' .	84.61917
the sensitive often seems to smell definite odors , too , or subjectively feels emotions .	42.203964
sometimes she displays amazing eidetic imagery and seems to see all details in perspective , as if the scene were actually there .	98.45618
if pressed by the sitter for more detail , she may be able to bring the picture more into focus and see more sharply , almost as if she were physically going closer .	149.21729
if asked how she gets her impressions , she probably can only say that she `` just gets them ' ' -- some more vividly than others .	89.87838
perhaps this is not so extraordinary after all .	37.156
even in normal experience one gets impressions without knowing exactly how -- of atmosphere , of one another ' s personalities , moods , intentions .	128.2434
of course , there is an element of training here these gifted people , by concentration , study , guidance , have learned to develop their power .	173.25394
simply using it increases its intensity , i was told by one sensitive .	63.47721
nor does a medium automatically know how to interpret her imagery .	49.262714
impressions often appear in a symbolic form and cannot be taken at face value .	365.21268
it is apparently by symbols that the unconscious speaks to the conscious , and the medium has to translate these into meaning .	121.55036
if communication with an entity on the `` other side ' ' is taking place , this too may assume the form of clairvoyant symbolism .	156.23177
during one reading an image appeared of a prisoner in irons .	69.8834
but this did not necessarily refer to an actual jail	948.77997
taken with other details it could have referred to a state of mental or spiritual confinement .	49.441315
in this connection it is worth noting how names are sometimes obtained .	554.9649
though they are often heard clairaudiently , as if a voice were speaking them , in other cases they are apprehended visually as symbols a slope to signify the name `` hill ' ' , for instance .	149.33543
one medium saw two sheets flapping on a line and found that the name shietz was significant to the sitter .	143.71431
the farmer ' s life must be arranged to meet the demands of crops and livestock .	60.465485
livestock must be tended every day , routinely .	235.291
a slight change in the work schedule may cut the production of cows or chickens .	84.4479
even if there are no livestock , the farmer cannot leave the farm for long periods , particularly during the growing season .	56.4346
the worker who lives on a farm cannot change jobs readily .	297.46478
he cannot leave the farm to take work in another locality on short notice	142.16493
such a move may mean a loss of capital .	38.819214
hard physical labor and undesirable hours are a part of life .	62.025635
the farmer must get up early , and , at times , work late at night .	152.65488
frequently he must work long hours in the hot sun or cold rain .	54.228764
no matter how well work is planned , bad weather or unexpected setbacks can cause extra work that must be caught up .	203.02869
it may not be profitable for a part-time farmer to own the labor-saving machinery that a full-time farmer can invest in profitably .	124.18336
drought , hail , disease , and insects take their toll of crops .	150.94606
sickness or loss of some of the livestock may cut into the owner ' s earnings , even into his capital .	108.151825
returns for money and labor invested may be small even in a good year .	210.75203
the high cost of land , supplies , and labor make it difficult to farm profitably on a part-time basis .	134.17227
land within commuting distance of a growing city is usually high in price , higher if it has subdivision possibilities .	102.290535
part-time farmers generally must pay higher prices for supplies than full-time farmers because they buy in smaller quantities .	235.67917
if the farm is in an industrial area where wages are high , farm labor costs will also be high .	109.8292
a part-time farmer needs unusual skill to get as high production per hen , per cow , or per acre as can be obtained by a competent full-time farmer .	76.579636
it will frequently be uneconomical for him to own the most up-to-date equipment .	110.48136
he may have to depend upon custom service for specialized operations , such as spraying or threshing , and for these , he may have to wait his turn .	54.999268
there will be losses caused by emergencies that arise while he is away at his off-farm job .	187.37874
the farm may be an additional burden if the main job is lost .	74.2184
this may be true whether the farm is owned or rented .	22.95155
if the farm is rented , the rent must be paid .	21.172459
if it is owned , taxes must be paid , and if the place is not free of mortgage , there will be interest and payments on the principal to take care of .	104.58958
a farm provides a wholesome and healthful environment for children .	51.219887
it gives them room to play and plenty of fresh air .	24.099392
the children can do chores adapted to their age and ability .	127.31113
caring for a calf , a pig , or some chickens develops in children a sense of responsibility for work .	120.16572
part-time farming gives a measure of security if the regular job is lost , provided the farm is owned free of debt and furnishes enough income to meet fixed expenses and minimum living costs .	173.201
for some retired persons , part-time farming is a good way to supplement retirement income .	97.36236
it is particularly suitable for those who need to work or exercise out of doors for their health .	174.2391
generally , the same level of living costs less in the country than in the city .	68.97487
the savings are not as great , however , as is sometime supposed .	99.888725
usually , the cost of food and shelter will be somewhat less on the farm and the cost of transportation and utilities somewhat more .	84.295265
where schools , fire and police protection , and similar municipal services are of equal quality in city and country , real estate taxes are usually about the same .	191.5225
a part-time farmer and his family can use their spare time profitably .	36.96812
some persons consider the work on a farm recreational .	119.43668
for some white-collar workers it is a welcome change from the regular job , and a physical conditioner .	65.65789
part-time farming can take comparatively little land , labor , and equipment -- or a great deal .	71.04072
it depends on the kind and the scale of the farming operation .	36.13237
general requirements for land , labor , and equipment are discussed below .	167.68912
specific requirements for each of various types of enterprises are discussed on pages 8 to 14 .	68.846886
three quarters to 1 acre of good land is enough for raising fruits and vegetables for home use , and for a small flock of chickens , a cow , and two pigs .	63.445133
you could not , of course , raise feed for the livestock on a plot this small .	225.12021
if you want to raise feed or carry out some enterprise on a larger scale , you ' ll need more land .	71.67209
in deciding how much land you want , take into account the amount you ' ll need to bring in the income you expect .	79.532814
but consider also how much you and your family can keep up along with your other work .	176.16315
the cost of land and the prospects for appreciation in value may influence your decision .	441.51157
some part-time farmers buy more land than they need in anticipation of suburban development .	128.55762
sometimes a desired acreage is offered only as part of a larger tract .	53.63653
when surplus land is not expensive to buy or to keep up , it is usually better to buy it than to buy so small an acreage that the development of adjoining properties might impair the residential value of the farm .	88.30534
if you have a year-round , full-time job you can ' t expect to grow much more than your family uses -- unless other members of the family do a good deal of the work or you hire help .	105.83804
as a rule , part-time farmers hire little help .	51.01721
in deciding on the enterprises to be managed by family labor , compare the amount of labor that can be supplied by the family with the labor needs of various enterprises listed in table 1 .	63.31832
list the number of hours the family can be expected to work each month .	19.668118
you may want to include your own regular vacation period if you have one .	69.89083
do not include all your spare time or all your family ' s spare time -- only what you are willing to use for farm work .	96.94279
if you are going to produce for home use only , you will need only hand tools .	134.0043
you will probably want to hire someone to do the plowing , however .	84.195404
for larger plantings , you ' ll need some kind of power for plowing , harrowing , disking , and cultivating .	52.91704
if you have a planting of half an acre or more you may want to buy a small garden tractor ( available for $300 to $500 with attachments , 1960 prices ) .	157.27986
these tractors are not entirely satisfactory for plowing , particularly on heavier soils , so you may still want to hire someone to do the plowing .	56.145042
cost of power and machinery is often a serious problem to the small-scale farmer .	73.66095
if you are going to farm for extra cash income on a part-time basis you must keep in mind the needed machinery investments when you choose among farm enterprises .	211.34154
you can keep your machinery investment down by buying good secondhand machinery , by sharing the cost and upkeep of machinery with a neighbor , and by hiring someone with machinery to do certain jobs .	179.23244
if an expensive and specialized piece of machinery is needed -- such as a spray rig , a combine , or a binder -- it is better to pay someone with a machine to do the work .	101.54137
before you look for a farm you ' ll need to know ( 1 ) the kind and scale of farming you want to undertake	155.27733
and ( 2 ) whether you want to buy or rent .	46.52456
information on pages 8 to 14 may help you in deciding on the kind and scale of your farming venture .	103.94196
if you are not well acquainted with the area in which you wish to locate , or if you are not sure that you and your family will like and make a success of farming , usually you would do better to rent a place for a year or two before you buy .	112.190315
discussed below are some of the main things to look for when you select a part-time farm .	135.66042
choose a location within easy commuting distance of both the regular job and other employment opportunities .	131.94225
then if you change jobs you won ' t necessarily have to sell the farm .	45.38087
the presence of alternative job opportunities also will make the place easier to sell if that should become desirable .	102.03736
obviously the farm should be on an all-weather road .	26.470678
if you grow anything to sell you will need markets nearby .	294.4111
if you plan to sell fresh vegetables or whole milk , for example , you should be close to a town or city .	48.43692
look for a farm in a neighborhood of well-kept homes .	45.244118
there are slums in the country as well as in the city .	24.013988
a tavern , filling station , junk yard , rendering plant , or some other business may go up near enough to hurt your home or to hurt its value .	112.14362
check on the schools in the area , the quality of teaching , and the provision for transportation to and from them .	87.91419
find out whether fire protection , sewage system , gas , water mains , and electrical lines are available in the locality .	50.588085
if these facilities are not at the door , getting them may cost more than you expect .	308.07578
you may have to provide them yourself or get along without them .	137.06941
you cannot get along without an adequate supply of pure water .	13.512872
if you are considering a part-time farm where the water must be provided by a well , find out if there is a good well on the farm or the probable cost of having one drilled .	96.77947
a pond may provide adequate water for livestock and garden .	69.51671
pond water can be filtered for human use , but most part-time farmers would not want to go to so much trouble .	52.086086
the following amounts of water are needed per day for livestock and domestic uses .	46.109264
is the land suited to the crops you intend to raise ? ?	37.065838
if you can ' t tell , get help from your county agricultural agent or other local specialist .	279.8319
soil type , drainage , or degree of slope can make the difference between good crops and poor ones .	109.704636
small areas that aren ' t right for a certain crop may lie next to areas that are well suited to that crop .	212.148
will the house on any part-time farm you are considering make a satisfactory full-time residence ? ?	118.719376
how much will it cost to do any necessary modernizing and redecorating ? ?	72.38341
if the house is not wired adequately for electricity or if plumbing or a central heating system must be installed , check into the cost of making these improvements .	75.67995
the value of the farm to you will depend on --	190.88356
the value of the products you can raise on it .	63.363327
the possibilities of selling the property later on for suburban subdivision .	205.33252
decide first what the place is worth to you and your family as a home in comparison with what it would cost to live in town .	110.23467
take into account the difference in city and county taxes , insurance rates , utility rates , and the cost of travel to work .	39.756737
next , estimate the value of possible earnings of the farm .	20.749813
to do this , set up a plan on paper for operating the farm .	214.04977
list the kind and quantity of things the farm can be expected to produce in an average year .	41.83486
estimate the value of the produce at normal prices .	87.64263
the total is the probably gross income from farming .	62.126064
to find estimated net farm income , subtract estimated annual farming expenditures from probable gross income from farming .	313.9142
include as expenditures an allowance for depreciation of farm buildings and equipment .	383.6283
also count as an expense a charge for the labor to be contributed by the family .	59.950756
it may be hard to decide what this labor is worth , but charge something for it .	223.32657
otherwise , you may pay too much for the farm and get nothing for your labor .	89.16235
to figure the value of the farm in terms of investment income , divide the estimated annual net farm income by the percentage that you could expect to get in interest if the money were invested in some other way .	99.485016
everyone with a personal or group tragedy to relate had to be given his day in court as in some vast collective dirge .	157.91298
for almost two months , the defendant and the world heard from individuals escaped from the grave about fathers and mothers , graybeards , adolescents , babies , starved , beaten to death , strangled , machine-gunned , gassed , burned .	79.08788
one who had been a boy in auschwitz had to tell how children had been selected by height for the gas chambers .	117.62935
the gruesome humor of the nazis was not forgotten -- the gas chamber with a sign on it with the name of a jewish foundation and bearing a copper star of david -- nor the gratuitous sadism of ss officers .	112.15829
public relations strategists everywhere , watching the reaction of the german press , the liberal press , the lunatic-fringe press , listening to their neighbors , studying interviews with men and women on the street , cried out too much , too much -- the mind of the audience is becoming dulled , the horrors are losing their effect .	86.06575
and still another witness , one who had crawled out from under a heap of corpses , had to tell how the victims had been forced to lay themselves head to foot one on top of the other before being shot .	135.78564
most of this testimony may have been legally admissible as bearing on the corpus delicti of the total nazi crime but seemed subject to question when not tied to the part in it of the defendant ' s department of jewish affairs .	75.92035
counsel for the defense , however , shrewdly allowing himself to be swept by the current of dreadful recollections , rarely raised an objection .	41.955185
would not the emotional catharsis eventually brought on by this awfulness have a calming , if not exhausting , effect likely to improve his client ' s chances ? ?	216.58727
those who feared `` emotionalism ' ' at the trial showed less understanding than dr . servatius of the route by which man achieves the distance necessary for fairness toward enemies .	230.81621
interruptions came largely from the bench , which numerous times rebuked the attorney general for letting his witnesses run on , though it , too , made no serious effort to choke off the flow .	140.74214
but there was a contrast even more decisive than a hunger for fact between the trial in jerusalem and those in moscow and new york .	77.364746
in each of the last , the trial marked the beginning of a new course in moscow the liquidation of the old bolsheviks and the tightening of stalin ' s dictatorship	75.10698
in the united states the initiation of militant anti-communism , with the repentant ex-communist in the vanguard .	45.49721
these trials were properly termed `` political cases ' ' in that the trial itself was a political act producing political consequences .	64.41255
but what could the eichmann trial initiate ? ?	1.0944284
of what new course could it mark the beginning ? ?	88.74857
the eichmann case looked to the past , not to the future .	48.97459
it was the conclusion of the first phase of a process of tragic recollection , and of refining the recollection , that will last as long as there are jews .	118.67675
as such , it was beyond politics and had no need of justification by a `` message ' ' .	93.70509
`` it is not an individual that is in the dock at this historical trial ' ' -- said ben gurion , `` and not the nazi regime alone -- but anti-semitism throughout history ' ' .	117.87443
how could supplying eichmann with a platform on which to maintain that one could collaborate in the murder of millions of jews without being an anti-semite contribute to a verdict against anti-semitism ? ?	113.25436
and if it was not an individual who was in the dock , why was the trial , as we shall observe later , all but scuttled in the attempt to prove eichmann a `` fiend ' ' ? ?	84.83205
these questions touch the root of confusion in the prosecution ' s case .	35.361286
it might be contended , of course , that eichmann in stubbornly denying anti-semitic feelings was lying or insisting on a private definition of anti-semitism .	96.91843
but in either event he was the wrong man for the kind of case outlined by ben gurion and set forth in the indictment .	98.113396
in such a case the defendant should serve as a clear example and not have to be tied to the issue by argument .	83.23298
one who could be linked to anti-semitism only by overcoming his objections is scarcely a good specimen of the jew-baiter throughout the ages .	154.38583
shout at eichmann though he might , the prosecutor could not establish that the defendant was falsifying the way he felt about jews or that what he did feel fell into the generally recognized category of anti-semitism .	192.576
yes , he believed that the jews were `` enemies of the reich ' ' , and such a belief is , of course , typical of `` patriotic ' ' anti-semites	63.213276
but he believed in the jew-as-enemy in a kind of abstract , theological way , like a member of a cult speculating on the nature of things .	123.87618
the real question was how one passed from anti-semitism of this sort to murder , and the answer to this question is not to be found in anti-semitism itself .	55.486988
in regard to eichmann , it was to be found in the nazi outlook , which contained a principle separate from and far worse than anti-semitism , a principle by which the poison of anti-semitism itself was made more virulent .	156.05508
perhaps under the guidance of this nazi principle one could , as eichmann declared , feel personally friendly toward the jews and still be their murderer .	260.44238
not through fear of disobeying orders , as eichmann kept trying to explain , but through a peculiar giddiness that began in a half-acceptance of the vicious absurdities contained in the nazi interpretation of history and grew with each of hitler ' s victories into a permanent light-mindedness and sense of magical rightness that was able to respond to any proposal , and the more outrageous the better , `` well , let ' s try it ' ' .	126.68224
at any rate , the substance of eichmann ' s testimony was that all his actions flowed from his membership in the party and the ss , and though the prosecutor did his utmost to prove actual personal hatred of jews , his success on this score was doubtful and the anti-semitic lesson weakened to that extent .	78.357666
but if the trial did not expose the special nazi mania so deadly to jews as well as to anyone upon whom it happened to light , neither did it warn very effectively against the ordinary anti-semitism of which the nazis made such effective use in germany and wherever else they could find it .	117.53851
if anti-semitism was on trial in jerusalem , why was it not identified , and with enough emphasis to capture the notice of the world press , in its connection with the activities of eichmann ' s department of jewish affairs , as exemplified by the betrayal and murder of jews by non-police and non-party anti-semites in germany , as well as in poland , czechoslovakia , hungary ? ?	83.2778
the infamous wansee conference called by heydrich in january 1942 , to organize the material and technical means to put to death the eleven million jews spread throughout the nations of europe , was attended by representatives of major organs of the german state , including the reich minister of the interior , the state secretary in charge of the four year plan , the reich minister of justice , the under secretary of foreign affairs .	89.755806
the measures for annihilation proposed and accepted at the conference affected industry , transportation , civilian agencies of government .	57.2482
heydrich , in opening the conference , followed the reasoning and even the phraseology of the order issued earlier by goering which authorized the final solution as `` a complement to ' ' previous `` solutions ' ' for eliminating the jews from german living space through violence , economic strangulation , forced emigration , and evacuation .	132.47159
in other words , the promulgators of the murder plan made clear that physically exterminating the jews was but an extension of the anti-semitic measures already operating in every phase of german life , and that the new conspiracy counted on the general anti-semitism that had made those measures effective , as a readiness for murder .	155.64189
this , in fact , it turned out to be .	20.898525
since the magnitude of the plan made secrecy impossible , once the wheels had began to turn , persons controlling german industries , social institutions , and armed forces became , through their anti-semitism or their tolerance of it , conscious accomplices of hitler ' s crimes	240.93349
whether in the last degree or a lesser one was a matter to be determined individually .	106.82879
what more could be asked for a trial intended to warn the world against anti-semitism than this opportunity to expose the exact link between the respectable anti-semite and the concentration-camp brute ? ?	138.05602
not in eichmann ' s anti-semitism but in the anti-semitism of the sober german man of affairs lay the potential warning of the trial .	163.26265
no doubt many of the citizens of the third reich had conceived their anti-semitism as an `` innocent ' ' dislike of jews , as do others like them today .	129.48991
the final solution proved that the jew-baiter of any variety exposes himself as being implicated in the criminality and madness of others .	130.31116
ought not an edifying trial have made every effort to demonstrate this once and for all by showing how representative types of `` mere ' ' anti-semites were drawn step by step into the program of skull-bashings and gassings ? ?	139.42372
the prosecutor in his opening remarks did refer to `` the germ of anti-semitism ' ' among the germans which hitler `` stimulated and transformed ' ' .	48.695644
but if there was evidence at the trial that aimed over eichmann ' s head at his collaborators in the societies where he functioned , the press seems to have missed it .	102.14504
nor did the trial devote much attention to exposing the usefulness of anti-semitism to the nazis , both in building their own power and in destroying that of rival organizations and states .	123.040115
certainly , one of the best ways of warning the world against anti-semitism is to demonstrate its workings as a dangerous weapon .	129.8111
eichmann himself is a model of how the myth of the enemy-jew can be used to transform the ordinary man of present-day society into a menace to all his neighbors .	93.68843
do patriots everywhere know enough about how the persecution of the jews in germany and later in the occupied countries contributed to terrorizing the populations , splitting apart individuals and groups , arousing the meanest and most dishonest impulses , pulverizing trust and personal dignity , and finally forcing people to follow their masters into the abyss by making them partners in unspeakable crimes ? ?	99.10401
the career of eichmann made the trial a potential showcase for anti-semitic demoralization fearful of being mistaken for a jew , he seeks protection in his nazi uniform	242.52032
clinging to the enemy-jew idea , he is forced to overcome habits of politeness and neighborliness	84.68279
once in power he begins to give vent to a criminal opportunism that causes him to alternate between megalomania and envy of those above him .	111.90048
`` is this the type of citizen you desire ' ' ? ?	38.686996
but though this characterization in no way diminished eichmann ' s guilt , the prosecutor , more deeply involved in the tactics of a criminal case than a political one , would have none of it .	106.097824
finally , if the mission of the trial was to convict anti-semitism , how could it have failed to post before the world the contrasting fates of the countries in which the final solution was aided by native jew-haters -- i . e . , germany , poland , hungary , czechoslovakia -- and those in which it met the obstacle of human solidarity -- denmark , holland , italy , bulgaria , france ? ?	78.01348
should not everyone have been awakened to it as an outstanding fact of our time that the nations poisoned by anti-semitism proved less fortunate in regard to their own freedom than those whose citizens saved their jewish compatriots from the transports ? ?	117.68163
wasn ' t this meaning of eichmann ' s experience in various countries worth highlighting ? ?	245.45338
as the first collective confrontation of the nazi outrage , the trial of eichmann represents a recovery of the jews from the shock of the death camps , a recovery that took fifteen years and which is still by no means complete ( though let no one believe that it could be hastened by silence ) .	83.371925
only across a distance of time could the epic accounting begin .	286.21683
it is already difficult to recall how little we knew before the trial of what had been done to the jews of europe .	112.52286
it is not that the facts of the persecution were unavailable	351.89145
most of the information elicited in jerusalem had been brought to the surface by the numerous war crimes tribunals and investigating commissions , and by reports , memoirs , and survivors ' accounts .	62.276707
in poughkeepsie , n . y . , , in 1952 , a roman catholic hospital presented seven protestant physicians with an ultimatum to quit the planned parenthood federation or to resign from the hospital staff .	83.50896
three agreed , but four declined and were suspended .	52.89165
after a flood of protests , they were reinstated at the beginning of 1953 .	50.39718
the peace of the community was badly disturbed , and people across the nation , reading of the incident , felt uneasy .	129.36873
in new york city in 1958 , the city ' s commissioner of hospitals refused to permit a physician to provide a protestant mother with a contraceptive device .	91.58585
he thereby precipitated a bitter controversy involving protestants , jews and roman catholics that continued for two months , until the city ' s board of hospitals lifted the ban on birth-control therapy .	80.71727
a year later in albany , n . y . , a roman catholic hospital barred an orthopedic surgeon because of his connection with the planned parenthood association .	70.35956
immediately , the religious groups of the city were embroiled in an angry dispute over the alleged invasion of a man ' s right to freedom of religious belief and conscience .	56.644974
these incidents , typical of many others , dramatize the distressing fact that no controversy during the last several decades has caused more tension , rancor and strife among religious groups in this country than the birth-control issue .	100.25683
it has flared up periodically on the front pages of newspapers in communities divided over birth-prevention regulations in municipal hospitals and health and family-welfare agencies .	251.28673
it has erupted on the national level in the matter of including birth-control information and material in foreign aid to underdeveloped countries .	90.27164
where it is not actually erupting , it rumbles and smolders in sullen resentment like a volcano , ready to explode at any moment .	131.57219
the time has come for citizens of all faiths to unite in an effort to remove this divisive and nettlesome issue from the political and social life of our nation .	71.634674
the first step toward the goal is the establishment of a new atmosphere of mutual good will and friendly communication on other than the polemical level .	142.36885
instead of emotional recrimination , loaded phrases and sloganeering , we need a dispassionate study of the facts , a better understanding of the opposite viewpoint and a more serious effort to extend the areas of agreement until a solution is reached .	61.829178
`` all too frequently ' ' , points out james o ' gara , managing editor of commonweal , `` catholics run roughshod over protestant sensibilities in this matter , by failure to consider the reasoning behind the protestant position and , particularly , by their jibes at the fact that protestant opinion on birth control has changed in recent decades ' ' .	96.522675
all too often our language is unduly harsh .	7.5684347
the second step is to recognize the substantial agreement -- frequently blurred by emotionalism and inaccurate newspaper reporting -- already existing between catholics and non-catholics concerning the over-all objectives of family planning .	181.95288
instead of catholics ' being obliged or even encouraged to beget the greatest possible number of offspring , as many non-catholics imagine , the ideal of responsible parenthood is stressed .	122.127335
family planning is encouraged , so that parents will be able to provide properly for their offspring .	42.47922
pope pius 12 , declared in 1951 that it is possible to be exempt from the normal obligation of parenthood for a long time and even for the whole duration of married life , if there are serious reasons , such as those often mentioned in the so-called medical , eugenic , economic and social `` indications ' ' .	64.405945
this means that such factors as the health of the parents , particularly the mother , their ability to provide their children with the necessities of life , the degree of population density of a country and the shortage of housing facilities may legitimately be taken into consideration in determining the number of offspring .	63.411263
these are substantially the same factors considered by non-catholics in family planning .	75.65981
the laws of many states permit birth control only for medical reasons .	224.50917
the roman catholic church , however , sanctions a much more liberal policy on family planning .	139.61732
catholics , protestants and jews are in agreement over the objectives of family planning , but disagree over the methods to be used .	74.54197
the roman catholic church sanctions only abstention or the rhythm method , also known as the use of the infertile or safe period .	102.67131
the church considers this to be the method provided by nature and its divine author it involves no frustration of nature ' s laws , but simply an intelligent and disciplined use of them .	136.42212
with the exception of the roman catholic and the orthodox catholic churches , most churches make no moral distinction between rhythm and mechanical or chemical contraceptives , allowing the couple free choice .	122.02366
there is a difference in theological belief where there seems little chance of agreement .	325.5606
the grounds for the church ' s position are scriptural ( old testament ) , the teachings of the fathers and doctors of the early church , the unbroken tradition of nineteen centuries , the decisions of the highest ecclesiastical authority and the natural law .	62.03729
the latter plays a prominent role in roman catholic theology and is considered decisive , entirely apart from scripture , in determining the ethical character of birth-prevention methods .	122.65257
the roman catholic natural-law tradition regards as self-evident that the primary objective purpose of the conjugal act is procreation and that the fostering of the mutual love of the spouses is the secondary and subjective end .	84.07047
this conclusion is based on two propositions that man by the use of his reason can ascertain god ' s purpose in the universe and that god makes known his purpose by certain `` given ' ' physical arrangements .	131.90143
thus , man can readily deduce that the primary objective end of the conjugal act is procreation , the propagation of the race .	83.33982
moreover , man may not supplant or frustrate the physical arrangements established by god , who through the law of rhythm has provided a natural method for the control of conception .	89.10128
believing that god is the author of this law and of all laws of nature , roman catholics believe that they are obliged to obey those laws , not frustrate or mock them .	147.50319
let it be granted then that the theological differences in this area between protestants and roman catholics appear to be irreconcilable .	44.42065
but people differ in their religious beliefs on scores of doctrines , without taking up arms against those who disagree with them .	69.69804
why is it so different in regard to birth control ? ?	82.464966
it is because each side has sought to implement its distinctive theological belief through legislation and thus indirectly force its belief , or at least the practical consequences thereof , upon others .	188.96536
it is always a temptation for a religious organization , especially a powerful or dominant one , to impose through the clenched fist of the law its creedal viewpoint upon others .	224.36009
both roman catholics and protestants have succumbed to this temptation in the past .	36.56399
consider what happened during world war 1 , , when the protestant churches united to push the prohibition law through congress .	250.40172
many of them sincerely believe that the use of liquor in any form or in any degree is intrinsically evil and sinful .	70.334404
with over four million american men away at war , protestants forced their distinctive theological belief upon the general public .	189.80937
with the return of our soldiers , it soon became apparent that the belief was not shared by the great majority of citizens .	86.1362
the attempt to enforce that belief ushered in a reign of bootleggers , racketeers , hijackers and gangsters that led to a breakdown of law unparalleled in our history .	73.361984
the so-called `` noble experiment ' ' came to an inglorious end .	118.370605
that tumultuous , painful and costly experience shows clearly that a law expressing a moral judgment cannot be enforced when it has little correspondence with the general view of society .	161.35011
that experience holds a lesson for us all in regard to birth control today .	92.90745
up to the turn of the century , contraception was condemned by all christian churches as immoral , unnatural and contrary to divine law .	108.97096
this was generally reflected in the civil laws of christian countries .	45.14786
today , the roman catholic and orthodox churches stand virtually alone in holding that conviction .	510.33038
the various lambeth conferences , expressing the anglican viewpoint , mirror the gradual change that has taken place among protestants generally .	127.41753
in 1920 , the lambeth conference repeated its 1908 condemnation of contraception and issued `` an emphatic warning against the use of unnatural means for the avoidance of conception , together with the grave dangers -- physical , moral , and religious -- thereby incurred , and against the evils which the extension of such use threaten the race ' ' .	85.066864
denouncing the view that the sexual union is an end in itself , the conference declared `` we steadfastly uphold what must always be regarded as the governing considerations of christian marriage .	118.65859
one is the primary purpose for which marriage exists , namely , the continuance of the race through the gift and heritage of children	110.85445
the other is the paramount importance in married life of deliberate and thoughtful self-control ' ' .	42.80048
the conference called for a vigorous campaign against the open or secret sale of contraceptives .	127.49034
in 1930 , the lambeth conference again affirmed the primary purpose of marriage to be the procreation of children , but conceded that , in certain limited circumstances , contraception might be morally legitimate .	120.019005
in 1958 , the conference endorsed birth control as the responsibility laid by god on parents everywhere .	138.47633
many other protestant denominations preceded the anglicans in such action .	59.86717
in march , 1931 , 22 out of 28 members of a committee of the federal council of churches ratified artificial methods of birth control .	46.13302
`` as to the necessity ' ' , the committee declared , `` for some form of effective control of the size of the family and the spacing of children , and consequently of control of conception , there can be no question .	60.482815
there is general agreement also that sex union between husbands and wives as an expression of mutual affection without relation to procreation is right ' ' .	63.089695
since then , many protestant denominations have made separate pronouncements , in which they not only approved birth control , but declared it at times to be a religious duty .	89.815956
what determines the morality , they state , is not the means used , but the motive in general , the means ( excluding abortion ) that prove most effective are considered the most ethical .	160.56956
this development is reflected in the action taken in february , 1961 , by the general board of the national council of churches , the largest protestant organization in the aj .	28.28088
the board approved and commended the use of birth-control devices as a part of christian responsibility in family planning .	98.52691
it called for opposition to laws and institutional practices restricting the information or availability of contraceptives .	115.99368
the general board declared `` most of the protestant churches hold contraception and periodic continence to be morally right when the motives are right .	149.16309
the general protestant conviction is that motives , rather than methods , form the primary moral issue , provided the methods are limited to the prevention of conception ' ' .	133.7783
an action once universally condemned by all christian churches and forbidden by the civil law is now not only approved by the overwhelming majority of protestant denominations , but also deemed , at certain times , to be a positive religious duty .	67.008194
this viewpoint has now been translated into action by the majority of people in this country .	43.314125
repeated polls have disclosed that most married couples are now using contraceptives in the practice of birth control .	80.81463
for all concerned with social-welfare legislation , the significance of this radical and revolutionary change in the thought and habits of the vast majority of the american people is clear , profound and far-reaching .	76.64383
to try to oppose the general religious and moral conviction of such a majority by a legislative fiat would be to invite the same breakdown of law and order that was occasioned by the ill-starred prohibition experiment .	191.46115
this brings us to the fact that the realities we are dealing with lie not in the field of civil legislation , but in the realm of conscience and religion they are moral judgments and matters of theological belief .	82.95476
conscience and religion are concerned with private sin the civil law is concerned with public crimes .	130.03102
only confusion , failure and anarchy result when the effort is made to impose upon the civil authority the impossible task of policing private homes to preclude the possibility of sin .	92.35497
among the chief victims of such an ill-conceived imposition would be religion itself .	191.4292
on april 17 , 1610 , the sturdy little three-masted bark , discovery , weighed anchor in st . katherine ' s pool , london , and floated down the thames toward the sea .	48.872856
she carried , besides her captain , a crew of twenty-one and provisions for a voyage of exploration of the arctic waters of north america .	32.760803
seventeen months later , on september 6 , 1611 , an irish fishing boat sighted the discovery limping eastward outside galway bay .	83.666794
when she reached port , she was found to have on board only eight men , all near starvation .	95.70716
the captain was gone , and the mate was gone .	65.77769
the man who now commanded her had started the voyage as an ordinary seaman .	44.16719
what disaster struck the discovery during those seventeen months ? ?	18.84707
what happened to the fourteen missing men ? ?	1.0990081
these questions have remained one of the great sea mysteries of all time .	76.701004
for hundreds of years , the evidence available consisted of ( 1 ) the captain ' s fragmentary journal , ( 2 ) a highly prejudiced account by one of the survivors , ( 3 ) a note found in a dead man ' s desk on board , and ( 4 ) several second-hand reports .	92.99933
all told , they offered a highly confused picture .	274.28775
but since 1927 , researchers digging into ancient court records and legal files have been able to find illuminating pieces of information .	98.1228
not enough to do away with all doubts , but sufficient to give a fairly accurate picture of the events of the voyage .	63.226154
historians have had two reasons for persisting so long in their investigations .	59.53509
first , they wanted to clarify a tantalizing , bizarre enigma .	82.583534
second , they believed it important to determine the fate of the captain -- a man whose name is permanently stamped on our maps , on american towns and counties , on a great american river , and on half a million square miles of arctic seas .	88.88109
this is the story of his last tragic voyage , as nearly as we are able -- or ever , probably , will be able -- to determine	99.98637
the sailing in the spring of 1610 was hudson ' s fourth in four years .	26.394424
each time his objective had been the same -- a direct water passage from western europe to the far east .	143.56546
in 1607 and 1608 , the english muscovy company had sent him northward to look for a route over the north pole or across the top of russia .	90.235664
twice he had failed , and the muscovy company indicated it would not back him again .	215.22614
in 1609 , the dutch east india company hired hudson , gave him two learned geographers , fitted him out with a ship called the half moon , and supplied him with dutch sailors .	110.88384
this time he turned westward , to the middle atlantic coast of north america .	48.14019
his chief discovery was important -- the great north ( later , the hudson ) river -- but it produced no northwest passage .	318.28436
when the half moon put in at dartmouth , england , in the fall of 1609 , word of hudson ' s findings leaked out , and english interest in him revived .	116.62454
the government forbade hudson to return to amsterdam with his ship .	35.974262
he thereupon went to london and spent the winter talking to men of wealth .	188.0757
by springtime , he was supported by a rich merchant syndicate under the patronage of henry , prince of wales .	72.14239
he had obtained and provisioned a veteran ship called the discovery and had recruited a crew of twenty-one , the largest he had ever commanded .	66.60306
the purpose of this fourth voyage was clear .	8.871705
a century of exploration had established that a great land mass , north and south america , lay between europe and the indies .	78.41871
one by one , the openings in the coast that promised a passage through had been explored and discarded .	345.23175
in fact , hudson ' s sail up the great north river had disposed of one of the last hopes .	123.44284
but there remained one mysterious , unexplored gap , far to the north .	47.4815
nearly twenty-five years before , captain john davis had noted , as he sailed near the arctic circle , `` a very great gulf , the water whirling and roaring , as it were the meeting of tides ' ' .	105.90473
he named this opening , between baffin island and labrador , the `` furious overfall ' ' .	25.552114
( later , it was to be called hudson strait .	33.11867
in 1602 , george waymouth , in the same little discovery that hudson now commanded , had sailed 300 miles up the strait before his frightened men turned the ship back .	214.6258
hudson now proposed to sail all the way through and test the seas beyond for the long-sought waterway .	217.66133
even hudson , experienced in arctic sailing and determined as he was , must have had qualms as he slid down the thames .	112.11198
on previous voyages , it had been in precisely such dangerous situations that he had failed as a leader and captain .	180.54475
on the second voyage , he had turned back at the frozen island of novaya zemlya and meekly given the crew a certificate stating that he did so of his own free will -- which was obviously not the case .	124.356094
on the third voyage , a near-mutiny rising from a quarrel between dutch and english crew members on the half moon had almost forced him to head the ship back to amsterdam in mid-atlantic .	107.40079
worse , his present crew included five men who had sailed with him before .	104.53489
of only one could he be sure -- young john hudson , his second son .	168.03226
the mate , robert juet , who had kept the journal on the half moon , was experienced -- but he was a bitter old man , ready to complain or desert at any opportunity .	73.920135
philip staffe , the ship ' s carpenter , was a good worker , but perversely independent .	80.475426
arnold lodley and michael perse were like the rest -- lukewarm , ready to swing against hudson in a crisis .	122.32491
but men willing to sail at all into waters where wooden ships could be crushed like eggs were hard to find .	170.99681
hudson knew he had to use these men as long as he remained an explorer .	176.7373
it is believed that hudson was related to other seafaring men of the muscovy company and was trained on company ships .	64.00116
he was a londoner , married , with three sons .	51.933834
( the common misconception that he was dutch and that his first name was hendrik stem from dutch documents of his third voyage .	71.848724
) in 1610 , hudson was probably in his early forties , a good navigator , a stubborn voyager , but otherwise fatally unsuited to his chosen profession .	107.75767
hudson ' s first error of the fourth voyage occurred only a few miles down the thames .	74.36736
there at the river ' s edge waited one henry greene , whom hudson listed as a `` clerk ' ' .	101.431076
greene was in actuality a young ruffian from kent , who had broken with his parents in order to keep the company he preferred -- pimps , panders and whores .	90.07497
he was not the sort of sailor hudson wanted his backers to see on board and he had greene wait at gravesend , where the discovery picked him up .	132.34128
for the first three weeks , the ship skirted up the east coast of great britain , then turned westward .	100.70356
poor winds and fog locked her up in a harbor the crew called `` lousie bay ' ' .	92.434494
the subsequent two-weeks wait made the crew quarrelsome .	37.30553
with hudson looking on , his protege greene picked a fight with the ship ' s surgeon , edward wilson .	57.732292
the issue was settled on shore , greene winning and wilson remaining ashore , determined to catch the next fishing boat back to england .	278.9069
with difficulty , hudson persuaded him to rejoin the ship , and they sailed from iceland .	39.10164
early in june , the discovery passed `` desolation ' ' ( southern greenland ) and in mid-june entered the `` furious overfall ' ' .	39.414997
floating ice bore down from the north and west .	35.63085
turbulent tides rose as much as fifty feet .	33.400955
the ship ' s compass was useless because of the nearness of the magnetic north pole .	61.73861
as the bergs grew larger , hudson was forced to turn south into what is now ungava bay , an inlet of the great strait .	157.94249
after finding that its coasts led nowhere , however , he turned north again , toward the main , ice-filled passageway -- and the crew , at first uneasy , then frightened , rebelled .	91.044136
the trouble was at least partly juet ' s doing .	275.52942
for weeks he had been saying that hudson ' s idea of sailing through to java was absurd .	88.57427
the great , crushing ice masses coming into view made him sound like the voice of pure reason .	255.61113
a group of sailors announced to hudson that they would sail no farther .	201.80194
instead of quelling the dissension , as many captains of the era would have done ( sir francis drake lopped a man ' s head off under similar circumstances ) , hudson decided to be reasonable .	95.75468
he went to his cabin and emerged carrying a large chart , which he set up in view of the crew .	86.47506
patiently , he explained what he knew about their course and their objectives .	137.42758
when hudson had finished , the `` town meeting ' ' broke down into a general , wordy argument .	111.24577
one man remarked that if he had a hundred pounds , he would give ninety of them to be back in england .	53.915607
up spoke carpenter staffe , who said he wouldn ' t give ten pounds to be home .	51.32333
all through july the discovery picked her way along the 450-mile-long strait , avoiding ice and rocky islands .	57.963165
on august 3 , two massive headlands reared out of the mists -- great gateways never before , so far as hudson knew , seen by europeans .	188.5974
to starboard was a cape a thousand feet high , patched with ice and snow , populated by thousands of screaming sea birds .	64.324585
to port was a point 200 feet high rising behind to a precipice of 2 , 000 feet .	66.93009
hudson named the capes digges and wolstenholme , for two of his backers .	156.68985
hudson pointed the discovery down the east coast of the newly discovered sea ( now called hudson bay ) , confident he was on his way to the warm waters of the pacific .	72.25889
after three weeks ' swift sailing , however , the ship entered an area of shallow marshes and river deltas .	76.20281
the great `` sea to the westwards ' ' was a dead end .	116.33894
this must have been hudson ' s blackest discovery .	29.195745
for he seemed to sense at once that before him was no south sea , but the solid bulk of the north american continent .	105.255394
this was the bitter end , and hudson seemed to know he was destined to failure .	124.9683
feverishly , he tried to brush away this intuition .	328.16785
north and south , east and west , back and forth he sailed in the land-locked bay , plowing furiously forward until land appeared , then turning to repeat the process , day after day , week after week .	249.66585
hundreds of miles to the north , the route back to england through the `` furious overfall ' ' was again filling with ice .	77.31353
the men were at first puzzled , then angered by the aimless tacking .	190.8803
once more , juet ' s complaints were the loudest .	90.57912
hudson ' s reply was to accuse the mate of disloyalty .	133.56357
juet demanded that hudson prove his charges in an open trial .	80.63506
hudson , presiding , heard juet ' s defense , then called for testimony from crew members .	178.28117
juet had made plentiful enemies , several men stepped forward .	93.088684
hands on bible , seaman lodley and carpenter staffe swore that juet had tried to persuade them to keep muskets and swords in their cabins .	54.72083
cook bennett mathues said juet had predicted bloodshed on the ship .	16.935347
others added that juet had wanted to turn the ship homeward .	114.2913
the new mate was robert bylot , talented but inexperienced .	369.26755
there were other shifts and pay cuts according to the way individuals had conducted themselves .	305.95404
the important result , however , was that juet and francis clemens , the deposed boatswain , became hudson ' s sworn enemies .	112.82863
as hudson resumed his desperate criss-crossing of the little bay , every incident lessened the crew ' s respect for him .	163.41235
once , after the discovery lay for a week in rough weather , hudson ordered the anchor raised before the sea had calmed .	259.59766
just as it was being hauled inboard , a sea hit the ship .	152.75899
michael butt and adame moore were thrown off the capstan and badly injured .	48.496487
the anchor cable would have been lost overboard , but philip staffe was on hand to sever it with his axe .	42.6173
thomas douglas , fifth earl of selkirk , a noble humanitarian scot concerned with the plight of the crofters of his native highlands , conceived a plan to settle them in the valley of the red river of the north .	36.059593
since the land he desired lay within the great northern empire of the hudson ' s bay company , he purchased great blocks of the comany ' s stock with the view to controlling its policies .	80.391205
having achieved this end , he was able to buy 116 , 000 square miles in the valleys of the red and assiniboine rivers .	26.917313
the grant , which stretched southward to lake traverse -- the headwaters of the red -- was made in may , 1811 , and by october of that year a small group of scots was settling for the winter at york factory on hudson bay .	98.87664
thus at the same time that william henry harrison was preparing to pacify the aborigines of indiana territory and winning fame at the battle of tippecanoe , anglo-saxon settlement made a great leap into the center of the north american continent to the west of the american agricultural frontier .	77.47428
seven hundred miles south of york factory , at `` the forks ' ' of the red and the assiniboine , twenty-three men located a settlement in august 1812 .	95.83283
by october the little colony about fort douglas ( present-day winnipeg ) numbered 100 .	72.59492
within a few years the scots , engaged in breaking the thick sod and stirring the rich soil of the valley , were joined by a group called meurons .	77.85547
the latter , members of two regiments of swiss mercenaries transported by great britain to canada to fight the americans in the war of 1812 , had settled in montreal and kingston at the close of the war in 1815 .	45.481266
selkirk persuaded eighty men and four officers to go to red river where they were to serve as a military force to protect his settlers from the hostile northwest company which resented the intrusion of farmers into the fur traders ' empire .	75.44682
the mercenaries were little interested in farming and added nothing to the output of the farm plots on which all work was still done with hoes as late as 1818 .	151.22203
it was the low yield of the selkirk plots and the ravages of grasshoppers in 1818 that led to the dispersal of the settlement southward .	128.37793
when late in the summer the full extent of the damage was assessed , all but fifty of the scots , swiss and metis moved up the red to the mouth of the pembina river .	60.69748
here they built huts and a stockade named fort daer after selkirk ' s barony in scotland .	49.201828
the new site was somewhat warmer than fort douglas and much closer to the great herds of buffalo on which the settlement must depend for food .	123.64201
the selkirk settlers had been anticipated in their move southward by british fur traders .	88.2226
for many years the northwest company had its southern headquarters at prairie du chien on the mississippi river , some 300 miles southeast of present-day st . paul , minnesota .	73.55323
when in 1816 an act of congress forced the foreign firm out of the united states , its british-born employees , now become american citizens -- joseph rolette , joseph renville and alexis bailly -- continued in the fur business .	141.40764
on big stone lake near the headwaters of the red river , robert dickson , superintendent of the western indian department of canada , had a trading post and planned in 1818 to build a fort to be defended by twenty men and two small artillery pieces .	78.103966
his trading goods came from canada to the forks of red river and from selkirk ' s settlement he brought them south in carts .	155.04709
these carts were of a type devised in pembina in the days of alexander henry the younger about a decade before the selkirk colony was begun .	187.3983
in 1802 henry referred to `` our new carts ' ' as being about four feet off the ground and carrying five times as much as a horse could pack .	71.17228
they were held together by pegs and withes and in later times drawn by a single ox in thills .	98.04475
it was dickson who suggested to lord selkirk that he return to the atlantic coast by way of the united states .	43.23651
in september 1817 at fort daer ( pembina ) dickson met the noble lord whom , with the help of a band of sioux , he escorted to prairie du chien .	60.00461
during the trip selkirk decided that the route through illinois territory to indiana and the eastern united states was the best route for goods from england to reach red river and that the united states was a better source of supply for many goods than either canada or england .	86.4174
upon arriving at baltimore , selkirk on december 22 wrote to john quincy adams , secretary of state at washington , inquiring about laws covering trade with `` missouri and illinois territories ' ' .	146.32362
this traffic , he declared prophetically , `` tho ' it might be of small account at first , would increase with the progress of our settlements .	220.09583
the route which he had traveled and which he believed might develop into a trade route was followed by his settlers earlier than he might have expected .	185.56078
in 1819 grasshoppers again destroyed the crop at `` the forks ' ' ( fort douglas ) and in december 1819 , twenty men left fort daer for the most northerly american outpost at prairie du chien .	51.11583
it was a three-month journey in the dead of winter followed by three months of labor on mackinac boats .	78.83039
with these completed and ice gone from the st . peter ' s river ( present-day minnesota river ) their 250 bushels of wheat , 100 bushels of oats and barley and 30 bushels of peas and some chickens were loaded onto the flat-bottomed boats and rowed up the river to big stone lake , across into lake traverse , and down the red .	81.99355
this epic effort to secure seed for the colony cost selkirk ab1 , 040 .	217.9093
nevertheless so short was the supply of seed that the settlers were forced to retreat to fort daer for food .	48.866528
thereafter seed and food became more plentiful and the colony remained in the north the year round .	128.18501
activity by british traders and the presence of a colony on the red prompted the united state war department in 1819 to send lieutenant-colonel henry leavenworth from detroit to put a post 300 miles northwest of prairie du chien , until then the most advanced united states post .	114.18132
in september 1822 two companies of infantry arrived at the mouth of the st . peter ' s river , the head of navigation on the mississippi , and began construction of fort st . anthony which , upon completion , was renamed in honor of its commander , colonel josiah snelling .	65.832794
it was from the american outposts that red river shortages of livestock were to be made good .	43.97802
hercules l . dousman , fur trader and merchant at prairie du chien , contracted to supply selkirk ' s people with some 300 head of cattle , and alexis bailly and francois labothe were hired as drovers .	62.079338
bailly , after leaving fort snelling in august 1821 , was forced to leave some of the cattle at the hudson ' s bay company ' s post on lake traverse `` in the sieux country ' ' and reached fort garry , as the selkirk hudson ' s bay company center was now called , late in the fall .	77.327126
he set out on his 700-mile return journey with five families of discontented and disappointed swiss who turned their eyes toward the united states .	88.184364
observing their distressing condition , colonel snelling allowed these half-starved immigrants to settle on the military reservation .	25.660196
as these swiss were moving from the selkirk settlement to become the first civilian residents of minnesota , dousman of michilimackinac , michigan , and prairie du chien was traveling to red river to open a trade in merchandise .	64.28454
early in 1822 he was at fort garry offering to bring in pork , flour , liquor and tobacco .	99.84786
alexander mcdonnell , governor of red river , and james bird , a chief factor of the hudson ' s bay company , ordered such `` sundry articles ' ' to a value of ab4 , 500 .	50.47591
for its part the hudson ' s bay company was troubled by the approach of american settlement .	44.054546
as the time drew near for the drawing of the british-american frontier by terms of the agreement of 1818 , the company suspected that the pembina colony -- its own post and fort daer -- was on american territory .	133.84836
accordingly selkirk ' s agents ordered the settlers to move north , and by october , john halkett had torn down both posts , floating the timber to `` the forks ' ' in rafts .	146.93605
`` i have done everything ' ' , he wrote , `` to break up the whole of that unfortunate establishment .	61.214622
' ' despite company threats , duly carried through , to cut off supplies of powder , ball , and thread for fishing nets , about 350 persons stayed in the village .	125.70712
they would attempt to bring supplies from st . louis or prairie du chien at `` great expense as well as danger ' ' .	39.57655
at fort garry some of the swiss also decided to cast their lot with the united states , and in 1823 several families paid guides to take them to fort snelling .	106.87281
the disasters of 1825-1826 caused more to leave .	28.865925
after heavy rains and an onslaught of mice , snow fell on october 15 , 1825 , and remained on the ground through a winter so cold that the ice on the red was five feet thick .	87.50608
in april came a rapid thaw that produced high waters which did not recede until mid-june .	423.22766
on june 24 more than 400 families started the three-month trip across the plains to the mississippi .	96.87311
by fall , 443 survivors of this arduous journey were clustered about fort snelling , but most of them were sent on to galena and st . louis , with a few going as far as vevay , indiana , a notable swiss center in the united states .	61.282726
in 1837 , 157 red river people with more than 200 cattle were living on the reservation at fort snelling .	111.773506
below the fort , high bluffs extended uninterruptedly for six miles along the mississippi river .	70.94864
at the point where they ended , another settlement grew up around a chapel built at the boat landing by father lucian galtier in 1840 .	133.58199
its people , including pierre bottineau and other american fur company employees and the refugees from fort garry , were joined by the remaining scots and swiss from fort snelling when major joseph plympton expelled them from the reservation in may 1840 .	145.53572
the resultant town , platted in 1847 and named for the patron of father galtier ' s mission , st . paul , was to become an important center of the fur trade and was to take on a new interest for those selkirkers who remained at red river .	80.960846
while population at fort garry increased rapidly , from 2 , 417 in 1831 to 4 , 369 in 1840 , economic opportunities did not increase at a similar rate .	186.71169
accordingly , though the practice violated the no-trading provision of the selkirk charter which reserved all such activity in merchandise and furs to the hudson ' s bay company , some settlers went into trade .	80.46196
the company maintained a store at which products of england could be purchased and brought in goods for the new merchants on the understanding that they refrain from trading in furs .	111.63731
despite this prohibiton , by 1844 some of the fort garry merchants were trading with the indians for furs .	40.902893
in june 1845 , the governor and council of assiniboia imposed a 20 per cent duty on imports via hudson ' s bay which were viewed as aimed at the `` very vitals of the company ' s trade and power ' ' .	85.78672
to reduce further the flow of goods from england , the company ' s local officials asked that its london authorities refrain from forwarding any more trade goods to these men .	220.72537
with their customary source of supply cut off , the fort garry free traders engaged three men to cart goods to them from the mississippi country .	88.068344
others carried pemmican from `` the forks ' ' to st . paul and goods from st . paul to red river , as in the summer of 1847 when one trader , wells , transported twenty barrels of whisky to the british settlement .	75.13176
this trade was subject to a tariff of 7 . 5 per cent after february 1835 , but much was smuggled into assiniboia with the result that the duty was reduced by 1841 to 4 per cent on the initiative of the london committee .	98.94366
the trade in a few commodities noted above was to grow in volume as a result of changes both north and south of the 49th parallel .	192.24855
the letters of the common soldiers are rich in humor .	139.39168
indeed , no richer humor is to be found in the whole of american literature than in the letters of the semi-literate men who wore the blue and the gray .	51.089462
some of their figures of speech were colorful and expressive .	104.24598
a confederate observed that the yankees were `` thicker than lise on a hen and a dam site ornraier ' ' .	34.823784
another reported that his comrades were `` in fine spirits pitching around like a blind dog in a meat house ' ' .	93.764275
a third wrote that it was `` raining like poring peas on a rawhide ' ' .	74.24487
one wrote `` ( i am so hungry ) i could eat a rider off his horse & snap at the stirups ' ' .	68.8634
a second reported that the dilapidated houses in virginia `` look like the latter end of original sin and hard times ' ' .	230.09424
a third remarked of slowness of southerners `` they moved about from corner to corner , as uneasy as a litter of hungry leaches on the neck of a wooden god ' ' .	118.57635
still another , annoyed by the brevity of a recently received missive , wrote `` yore letter was short and sweet , jist like a roasted maget ' ' .	182.11528
a yankee sergeant gave the following description of his sweetheart `` my girl is none of your one-horse girls .	259.34256
she is a regular stub and twister , double geered .	128.78235
she is well-educated and refined , all wildcat and fur , and union from the muzzle to the crupper ' ' .	61.768852
a texan wrote to a male companion at home `` what has become of halda and laura ? ?	107.50234
when you see them again give them my love -- not best respects now , but love by god ' ' .	73.7703
william r . stillwell , an admirable georgian whose delightful correspondence is preserved in the georgia department of archives and history , liked to tease his wife in his letters .	139.38164
after he had been away from home about a year he wrote `` ( dear wife ) if i did not write and receive letters from you i believe that i would forgit that i was married .	130.94717
i don ' t feel much like a maryed man but i never forgit it sofar as to court enny other lady but if i should you must forgive me as i am so forgitful ' ' .	168.18199
a yank , disturbed by his increasing corpulence , wrote `` i am growing so fat i am a burden 2 myself ' ' .	147.73152
another yank parodied the familiar bedtime prayer `` now i lay me down to sleep , the gray-backs o ' er my body creep	364.4041
if they should bite before i wake , i pray the lord their jaws to break ' ' .	48.014183
charles thiot , a splendid georgia soldier , differed from most of his comrades in the ranks in that he was the owner of a large plantation , well-educated , and nearly fifty years of age .	44.27567
but he was very much like his associates in his hatred of camp routine .	62.523224
near the end of his service he wrote that when the war was over he was going to buy two pups , name one of them `` fall-in ' ' and the other `` close-up ' ' , and then shoot them both , `` and that will be the end of fall-in and close-up ' ' .	63.111057
the soldiers who comprised the rank and file of the civil war armies were an earthy people .	125.3456
they talked and wrote much about the elemental functions of the body .	20.803875
one of the most common of camp maladies was diarrhoea .	85.18299
men of more delicate sensibilities referred to this condition as `` looseness of the bowels ' '	101.16989
but a much more common designation was `` the sh-ts ' ' .	17.53205
a michigan soldier stationed in georgia wrote in 1864	1577.8842
`` i expect to be tough as a knott as soon as i get over the georgia shitts ' ' .	109.92299
johnny rebs from the deep south who were plagued with diarrhoea after transfer to the virginia front often informed their families that they were suffering from the `` the virginia quickstep ' ' .	143.8174
a georgia soldier gave his wife the following description of the cause and consequence of diarrhoea `` i have bin a little sick with diorah two or three days .	152.6564
it sowered ( on ) my stomack and turn loose on me ' ' .	49.728317
a michigan soldier wrote his brother `` i am well at present with the exception i have got the dyerear and i hope thease few lines find you the same ' ' .	177.61601
the letters which poured forth from camps were usually written under adverse circumstances .	46.478516
save for brief periods in garrison or winter quarters , soldiers rarely enjoyed the luxury of a writing desk or table .	285.86685
most of the letters were written in the hubbub of camp , on stumps , pieces of bark , drum heads , or the knee .	109.40482
in the south , after the first year of the war , paper and ink were very poor .	89.91233
scarcity of paper caused many southerners to adopt the practice of cross-writing , i . e . , after writing from left to right of the page in the usual manner , they gave the sheet a half turn and wrote from end to end across the lines previously written .	115.72127
sometimes soldiers wrote letters while bullets were whizzing about their heads .	40.237732
a yank writing from vicksburg , may 28 , 1863 , stated `` not less than 50 balls have passed over me since i commenced writing .	166.03004
i could tell you of plenty narrow escapes , but we take no notice of them now ' ' .	54.27757
a reb stationed near petersburg informed his mother `` i need not tell you that i dodge pretty often for you can see that very plainly by the blots in this letter .	129.6042
just count each blot a dodge and add in a few for i don ' t dodge every time ' ' .	69.50932
another reb writing under similar circumstances before atlanta reported `` the yankees keep shooting so i am afraid they will knock over my ink , so i will close ' ' .	185.55751
the most common type of letter was that of soldier husbands to their wives .	97.505974
but fathers often addressed communications to their small children	177.43732
and these , full of homely advice , are among the most human and revealing of civil war letters .	156.9116
rebs who owned slaves occasionally would include in their letters admonitions or greetings to members of the negro community .	42.65972
early in the war it was not uncommon for planters ' sons to retain in camp negro `` body servants ' ' to perform the menial chores such as cooking , foraging , cleaning the quarters , shining shoes , and laundering clothes .	130.36417
sometimes these servants wrote or dictated for enclosure with the letters of their soldier-masters messages to their relatives and to members of their owners ' families .	48.68487
unmarried soldiers carried on correspondence with sweethearts at home .	7.7087536
owing to the restrained usages characteristic of 19th-century america , these letters usually were stereotyped and revealed little depth of feeling .	130.783
occasionally gay young blades would write vividly to boon companions at home about their amorous exploits in richmond , petersburg , washington , or nashville .	75.09824
an alabama soldier whose feminine associations were of the more admirable type wrote boastfully of his achievements among the virginia belles `` they thout i was a saint .	179.97615
i told them some sweet lies and they believed it all .	108.96894
i would tell them i got a letter from home stating that five of my negroes had runaway and ten of pappy ' s .	137.12517
