but i wold say i recond he did not mind it for he had a plenty more left and then they would lean to me like a sore eyd kitten to a basin of milk ' ' .	115.331635
an ohio soldier who , from a comrade just returned from leave , received an unfavorable comment on the conduct of his sister , took pen in hand and delivered himself thus `` dear sis .	242.6096
alf sed he heard that you and hardy was a runing together all the time and he though he wod gust quit having any thing mor to doo with you for he thought it was no more yuse .	361.50607
i think you made a dam good chouise to turn off as nise a feler as alf dyer and let that orney thefin , drunkard , damed card playing sun of a bich com to sea you , the god damed theaf and lop yeard pigen tode helion , he is too orney for hel .	450.94473
i will shute him as shore as i sea him ' ' .	23.480518
initiation into combat sometimes elicited from soldier correspondents choice comments about their experiences and reactions .	98.28164
a federal infantryman wrote to his father shortly after his first skirmish in virginia `` dear pa .	47.154583
we got to one house where there were five secessionists .	1048.631
they brok & run and arch holored out to shoot the ornery suns of biches and we all let go at them .	116.37784
thay may say what they please but godamit pa it is fun ' ' .	150.74394
some of the choicest remarks made by soldiers in their letters were in disparagement of unpopular officers .	51.98811
a mississippi soldier wrote `` our general reub davis is a vain , stuck-up , illiterate ass ' ' .	36.058804
an alabamian wrote `` col . henry is ( an ignoramus ) fit for nothing higher than the cultivation of corn ' ' .	102.415184
a floridian stated that his officers were `` not fit to tote guts to a bear ' ' .	58.73312
on december 9 , 1862 , sergeant edwin h . fay , an unusual louisianan who held a . b . and m . a . degrees from harvard university and who before the war was headmaster of a private school for boys in louisiana , wrote his wife `` i saw pemberton and he is the most insignificant puke i ever saw .	100.38464
his head cannot contain enough sense to command a regiment , much less a corps .	153.88283
jackson runs first and his cavalry are well drilled to follow their leader .	239.6591
but he is a west point graduate and therefore must be born to command ' ' .	52.89188
similar comments about officers are to be found in the letters of northern soldiers .	50.947098
a massachusetts soldier , who seems to have been a civil war version of bill mauldin , wrote `` the officers consider themselves as made of a different material from the low fellows in the ranks .	102.70363
they get all the glory and most of the pay and don ' t earn ten cents apiece on the average , the drunken rascals ' ' .	67.67513
private george gray hunter of pennsylvania wrote `` i am well convinced in my own mind that had it not been for officers this war would have ended long ago ' ' .	92.90089
another yankee became so disgusted as to state `` i wish to god one half of our officers were knocked in the head by slinging them against ( the other half ) ' ' .	121.334305
no group of officers came in for more spirited denunciation than the doctors .	200.94168
one federal soldier wrote `` the docters is no aconte -- hell will be filde with do ( c ) ters and offersey when this war is over ' ' .	259.82294
shortly after the beginning of sherman ' s georgia campaign , an ailing yank wrote his homefolk `` the surgeon insisted on sending me to the hospital for treatment .	165.10713
i insisted on takeing the field and prevailed -- thinking that i had better die by rebel bullets than ( by ) union quackery ' ' .	209.67049
the attitudes which the rebs and yanks took toward each other were very much the same and ranged over the same gamut of feeling , from friendliness to extreme hatred .	153.99236
the rebs were , to a massachusetts corporal , `` fighting madmen or not men at all but whiskey & gunpowder put into a human frame ' ' .	193.70796
a pennsylvania soldier wrote that `` they were the hardest looking set of men that ever i saw .	180.20638
they looked as if they had been fed on vinegar and shavings .	42.294872
' ' private jenkins lloyd jones of the wisconsin light artillery wrote in his diary `` i strolled among the alabamans on the right , found some of the greenest specimens of humanity i think in the universe , their ignorance being little less than the slave they despise with as imperfect a dialect .	141.5128
they recooned as how you ' uns all would be a heap wus to we ' uns all ' ' ' .	69.791016
in a similar vein , but writing from the opposite side , thomas taylor , a private in the 6th alabama volunteers , in a letter to his wife , stated `` you know that my heart is with you but i never could have been satisfied to have staid at home when my country is invaded by a thievin foe , by a set of cowardly skunks whose motto is booty .	122.38838
the popularity of folklore in america stands in direct proportion to the popularity of nationalism in america .	36.663486
and the emphasis on nationalism in america is in proportion to the growth of american influence across the world .	68.64368
thus , if we are to observe american folklore in the twentieth century , we will do well to establish the relationships between folklore , nationalism and imperialism at the outset .	55.08354
historians have come to recognize two cardinal facts concerning nationalism and international influence .	76.204994
1 ) every age rewrites the events of its history in terms of what should have been , creating legends about itself that rationalize contemporary beliefs and excuse contemporary actions .	185.39345
what actually occurred in the past is seldom as important as what a given generation feels must have occurred .	214.04956
2 ) as a country superimposes its cultural and political attitudes on others , it searches its heritage in hopes of justifying its aggressiveness .	110.520515
its folklore and legend , usually disguised as history , are allowed to account for group actions , to provide a focal point for group loyalty , and to become a cohesive force for national identification .	104.37743
one can apply these facts to britain in the late eighteenth and nineteenth centuries as she spread her dominion over palm and pine , and they can be applied again to the united states in more recent years .	52.70987
the popularity of local color literature before the spanish-american war , the steady currency of the lincoln myth , the increased emphasis on the frontier west in our mass media are cases in point .	91.487335
nor is it an accident that baseball , growing into the national game in the last 75 years , has become a microcosm of american life , that learned societies such as the american folklore society and the american historical association were founded in the 1880s , or that courses in american literature , american civilization , american anything have swept our school and college curricula .	140.14058
of course , nationalism has really outlived its usefulness in a country as world-oriented as ours , and its continued existence reflects one of the major culture lags of the twentieth-century united states .	80.97231
yet nationalism has lost few of its charms for the historian , writer or man in the street .	72.54225
it is an understandable paradox that most american history and most american literature is today written from an essentially egocentric and isolationistic point of view at the very time america is spreading her dominion over palm and pine .	82.50654
after all , the average american as he lies and waits for the enemy in korea or as she scans the newspaper in some vain hope of personal contact with the front is unconcerned that his or her plight is the result of a complex of personal , economic and governmental actions far beyond the normal citizen ' s comprehension and control .	103.452095
anyone ' s identification with an international struggle , whether warlike or peaceful , requires absurd oversimplification and intense emotional involvement .	182.31651
such identification comes for each group in each crisis by rewriting history into legend and developing appropriate national heroes .	404.9562
in america , such self-deception has served a particularly useful purpose .	1197.2634
a heterogeneous people have needed it to attain an element of cultural and political cohesion in a new and ever-changing land .	146.12315
but we must never forget , most of the appropriate heroes and their legends were created overnight , to answer immediate needs , almost always with conscious aims and ends .	280.55673
parson weems ' s george washington became the symbol of honesty and the father image of the uniting states .	80.149185
abraham lincoln emerged as an incarnation of the national constitution .	194.84778
robert e . lee represented the dignity needed by a rebelling confederacy .	52.254993
and their roles are paralleled by those of patrick henry , nathan hale , andrew jackson , davy crockett , theodore roosevelt and many , many more .	115.45688
therefore , the scholar , as he looks at our national folklore of the last 60 years , will be mindful of two facts .	103.39755
1 ) most of the legends that are created to fan the fires of patriotism are essentially propagandistic and are not folk legends at all .	124.05127
2 ) the concept that an `` american national folklore ' ' exists is itself probably another propagandistic legend .	138.78047
folklore is individually created art that a homogeneous group of people preserve , vary and recreate through oral transmission .	158.9341
it has come to mean myths , legends , tales , songs , proverbs , riddles , superstitions , rhymes and such literary forms of expression .	53.29018
related to written literature , and often remaining temporarily frozen in written form , it loses its vitality when transcribed or removed from its oral existence .	215.86163
though it may exist in either literate or illiterate societies , it assumes a role of true cultural importance only in the latter .	158.79395
in its propagandistic and commercial haste to discover our folk heritage , the public has remained ignorant of definitions such as this .	90.845566
enthusiastically , americans have swept subliterary and bogus materials like paul bunyan tales , abe lincoln anecdotes and labor union songs up as true products of our american oral tradition .	92.570175
nor have we remembered that in the melting pot of america the hundreds of isolated and semi-isolated ethnic , regional and occupational groups did not fuse into a homogeneous national unit until long after education and industrialization had caused them to cast oral tradition aside as a means of carrying culturally significant material .	221.53085
naturally , such scholarly facts are of little concern to the man trying to make money or fan patriotism by means of folklore .	98.83874
that much of what he calls folklore is the result of beliefs carefully sown among the people with the conscious aim of producing a desired mass emotional reaction to a particular situation or set of situations is irrelevant .	150.9125
as long as his material is americana , can in some way be ascribed to the masses and appears `` democratic ' ' to his audience , he remains satisfied .	119.916084
from all this we can now see that two streams of development run through the history of twentieth-century american folklore .	81.1314
on the one side we have the university professors and their students , trained in teutonic methods of research , who have sought out , collected and studied the true products of the oral traditions of the ethnic , regional and occupational groups that make up this nation .	192.09212
on the other we have the flag-wavers and the national sentimentalists who have been willing to use any patriotic , `` frontier western ' ' or colonial material willy-nilly .	165.06415
unfortunately , few of the artists ( writers , movie producers , dramatists and musicians ) who have used american folklore since 1900 have known enough to distinguish between the two streams even in the most general of ways .	155.63113
after all , the field is large , difficult to define and seldom taught properly to american undergraduates .	389.29535
in addition , this country has been settled by many peoples of many heritages and their lore has become acculturated slowly , in an age of print and easy communication , within an ever-expanding and changing society .	170.97342
for that matter , the experts themselves are a mixed breed .	34.35126
anthropologists , housewives , historians and such by profession , they approach their discipline as amateurs , collectors , commercial propagandists , analysts or some combination of the four .	100.03362
they have little `` esprit de corps ' ' .	2.0534663
the outlook for the amateur , for instance , is usually dependent on his fondness for local history or for the picturesque .	160.66751
his love of folklore has romanticism in it , and he doesn ' t care much about the dollar-sign or the footnote .	66.80599
folklore is his hobby , and he , all too rightly , wishes it to remain as such .	227.42104
the amateur is closely related to the collector , who is actually no more than the amateur who has taken to the field .	57.54696
he hunts folklore for the very `` field and stream ' ' reasons that many persons hunt game	219.21402
and only rarely is he acutely concerned with the meaning of what he has located .	51.508247
fundamentally , both these types , the amateur and the collector , are uncritical and many of them don ' t distinguish well between real folklore and bogus material .	81.1591
but there are also the commercial propagandists and the analysts -- one dominated by money , the other by nineteenth-century german scholarship .	318.84943
both are primarily concerned with the uses that can be made of the material that the collector has found .	48.170532
both shudder at the thought of proceeding too far beyond the sewage system and the electric light lines .	63.37632
the commercial propagandist , who can ' t afford to be critical , gets along well with the amateur , from whom he feeds , but he frequently steps on the analyst ' s toes by refusing to keep his material genuine .	132.24918
his standards are , of course , completely foreign to those of the analyst .	131.78241
to both the amateur and the commercial progandist the analyst lacks a soul , lacks appreciation with his endless probings and classifications .	250.18378
dominated by the vicious circle of the university promotion system , the analyst looks down on and gets along poorly with the other three groups , although he cannot deny his debt to the collector .	116.817566
the knowledge that most americans have of folklore comes through contact with commercial propagandists and a few energetic amateurs and collectors .	63.496284
the work done by the analysts , the men who really know what folklore is all about , has no more appeal than any other work of a truly scientific sort and reaches a limited , learned audience .	153.74663
publishers want books that will sell , recording studios want discs that will not seem strange to ears used to hillbilly and jazz music , grade and high schools want quaint , but moral , material .	316.77313
the analyst is apt to be too honest to fit in .	61.77822
as a result , most people don ' t have more than a vague idea what folklore actually is	100.67164
they see it as a potpourri of charming , moral legends and patriotic anecdotes , with a superstition or remedy thrown in here and there .	124.12475
and so well is such ignorance preserved by the amateur and the money-maker that even at the college level most of the hundred-odd folklore courses given in the united states survive on sentiment and nationalism alone .	256.87527
if one wishes to discuss a literary figure who uses folklore in his work , the first thing he must realize is that the literary figure is probably part of this ignorant american public .	152.3313
and while every writer must be dealt with as a special case , the interested student will want to ask himself a number of questions about each .	104.86499
does the writer know the difference between an `` ersatz ' ' ballad or tall tale and a true product of the folk ? ?	103.93636
when the writer uses material does he tamper with it to improve its commercial effect or does he leave it pure ? ?	293.3029
is he swept away by sentiment and nostalgia for an america that was ? ?	306.455
or does he sincerely want to tap the real springs of american attitude and culture regardless of how unpopular and embarrassing they may be ? ?	180.8689
when he gets the answers to his questions he will be discouraged .	117.25855
in the first place , a good many writers who are said to use folklore , do not , unless one counts an occasional superstition or tale .	129.44714
robert frost , for instance , writes about rural life in new england , but he does not include any significant amount of folklore in his poems .	94.37426
this has not , however , prevented publishers from labeling him a `` folk poet ' ' , simply because he is a rural one .	61.740025
in the second place , a large number of writers , making a more direct claim than frost to being `` folk writers ' ' of one sort or another , clearly make no distinctions between genuine and bogus material .	117.98201
stephen vincent benet ' s john brown ' s body comes immediately to mind in this connection , as does john steinbeck ' s the grapes of wrath and carl sandburg ' s the people , yes .	143.54514
the last two writers introduce strong political bias into their works , and not unlike the union leaders that we will discuss soon , see folklore as a reservoir of protest by a downtrodden and publically silenced mass .	86.7124
folklore , as used by such writers , really reflects images engraved into it by the very person using it .	171.09721
the folk are simply not homogeneous with respect to nation or political attitude .	176.95006
in fact , there is much evidence to indicate they don ' t care a bit about anything beyond their particular regional , ethnic and occupational limits .	110.15559
nevertheless , with a reading public that longs for the `` good old days ' ' and with an awareness of our expanding international interests , it is easy for the benets to obtain a magnified position in literature by use of all sorts of americana , real or fake , and it is easy for the steinbecks and sandburgs to support their messages of reform by reading messages of reform into the minds of the folk .	88.00105
as part of the same arrangement , torrio had , in the spirit of peace and good will , and in exchange for armed support in the april election campaign , bestowed upon o ' banion a third share in the hawthorne smoke shop proceeds and a cut in the cicero beer trade .	78.77981
o ' banion was a complex and frightening man , whose bright blue eyes stared with a kind of frozen candour into others ' .	95.05755
he had a round , frank irish face , creased in a jovial grin that stayed bleakly in place even when he was pumping bullets into someone ' s body .	94.01046
he carried three guns -- one in the right trouser pocket , one under his left armpit , one in the left outside coat pocket -- and was equally lethal with both hands .	95.357765
he killed accurately , freely , and dispassionately .	26.04173
the police credited him with twenty-five murders but he was never brought to trial for one of them .	64.174255
like a fair number of bootleggers he disliked alcohol .	29.12647
he was an expert florist , tenderly dextrous in the arrangement of bouquets and wreaths .	42.5061
he divided humanity into `` right guys ' ' and `` wrong guys ' ' , and the wrong ones he was always willing to kill and trample under .	45.064335
he had what was described by a psychologist as a `` sunny brutality ' ' .	20.547003
he walked with a heavy list to the right , as that leg was four inches shorter than the other , but the lurch did not reduce his feline quickness with his guns .	125.30096
landesco thought him `` just a superior sort of plugugly ' ' but he was , in fact , with his aggression and hostility , and nerveless indifference to risking or administering pain , a casebook psychopath .	75.4786
he was also at this time , although not so interwoven in high politics and the rackets as torrio and capone , the most powerful and most dangerous mob leader in the chicago underworld , the roughneck king .	141.01347
o ' banion was born in poverty , the son of an immigrant irish plasterer , in the north side ' s little hell , close by the sicilian quarter and death corner .	123.92439
he had been a choir boy at the holy name cathedral and also served as an acolyte to father o ' brien .	91.149956
the influence of mass was less pervasive than that of the congested , slum tenements among the bawdy houses , honkytonks , and sawdust saloons of his birthplace	91.36174
he ran wild with the child gangs of the neighbourhood , and went through the normal pressure-cooker course of thieving , police-dodging , and housebreaking .	236.78342
at the age of ten , when he was working as a newsboy in the loop , he was knocked down by a streetcar which resulted in his permanently shortened leg .	93.82434
because of this he was known as gimpy ( but , as with capone and his nickname of scarface , never in his presence ) .	164.47983
in his teens o ' banion was enrolled in the vicious market street gang and he became a singing waiter in mcgovern ' s cafe , a notoriously low and rowdy dive in north clark street , where befuddled customers were methodically looted of their money by the singing waiters before being thrown out .	103.71882
he then got a job with the chicago herald-examiner as a circulation slugger , a rough fighter employed to see that his paper ' s news pitches were not trespassed upon by rival vendors .	76.57274
he was also at the same time gaining practical experience as a safe breaker and highwayman , and learning how to shoot to kill from a neanderthal convicted murderer named gene geary , later committed to chester asylum as a homicidal maniac , but whose eyes misted with tears when the young dion sang a ballad about an irish mother in his clear and syrupy tenor .	74.69685
o ' banion ' s first conflict with the police came in 1909 , at seventeen , when he was committed to bridewell prison for three months for burglary	79.284424
two years later he served another three months for assault .	80.0524
those were his only interludes behind bars , although he collected four more charges on his police record in 1921 and 1922 , three for burglary and one for robbery .	128.98326
but by now o ' banion ' s political pull was beginning to be effective .	116.45605
on the occasion of his 1922 indictment the $10 , 000 bond was furnished by an alderman , and the charge was nolle prossed .	100.2803
on one of his 1921 ventures he was actually come upon by a detective sergeant john j . ryan down on his knees with a tool embedded in a labour office safe in the postal telegraph building	125.50702
the jury wanted better evidence than that and he was acquitted , at a cost of $30 , 000 in bribes , it was estimated .	56.498035
as promptly as torrio , o ' banion jumped into bootlegging .	139.0665
he conducted it with less diplomacy and more spontaneous violence than the sicilians , but he had his huge north side portion to exploit and he made a great deal of money .	92.27349
unlike the sicilians , he additionally conducted holdups , robberies , and safe-cracking expeditions , and refused to touch prostitution .	61.21824
he was also personally active in ward politics , and by 1924 o ' banion had acquired sufficient political might to be able to state `` i always deliver my borough as per requirements ' ' .	161.91623
until 1924 o ' banion pistoleers and knuckle-duster bullyboys had kept his north side domain solidly democratic .	695.05835
there was a question-and-answer gag that went around at that time q . `` who ' ll carry the forty-second and forty-third wards ' ' ? ?	52.18189
a . o ' banion , in his pistol pocket ' ' .	10.3202095
but as november 1924 drew close the democratic hierarchy was sorely troubled by grapevine reports that o ' banion was being wooed by the opposition , and was meeting and conferring with important republicans .	105.83305
to forestall any change of allegiance , the democrats hastily organised a testimonial banquet for o ' banion , as public reward for his past services and as a reminder of where his loyalties lay .	118.71439
the reception was held in a private dining room of the webster hotel on lincoln park west .	54.60179
it was an interesting fraternisation of ex-convicts , union racketeers , ward heelers , sold-out officials , and gunmen .	91.10494
the guest list is in itself a little parable of the state of american civic life at this time .	58.44773
it included the top o ' banion men and chief of detectives michael hughes .	152.12166
when mayor dever heard of the banquet he summoned hughes for an explanation of why he had been dishonouring the police department by consorting with these felons and fixers .	107.35138
hughes said that he had understood the party was to be in honour of jerry o ' connor , the proprieter of a loop gambling house .	91.55668
`` but when i arrived and recognised a number of notorious characters i had thrown into the detective bureau basement half a dozen times , i knew i had been framed , and withdrew almost at once ' ' .	98.200226
in fact , o ' connor was honoured during the ceremony with the presentation of a $2500 diamond stickpin .	167.42674
there was a brief interruption while one of o ' banion ' s men jerked out both his guns and threatened to shoot a waiter who was pestering him for a tip .	94.89021
then o ' banion was presented with a platinum watch set with rubies and diamonds .	34.463745
this dinner was the start of a new blatancy in the relationship between the gangs and the politicians , which , prior to 1924 , says pasley , `` had been maintained with more or less stealth ' ' , but which henceforth was marked by these ostentatious gatherings , denounced by a clergyman as `` belshazzar feasts ' ' , at which `` politicians fraternized cheek by jowl with gangsters , openly , in the big downtown hotels ' ' .	81.706955
pasley continued `` they became an institution of the chicago scene and marked the way to the moral and financial collapse of the municipal and county governments in 1928-29 ' ' .	77.982834
however , this inaugural feast did its sponsors no good whatever .	265.17172
o ' banion accepted his platinum watch and the tributes to his loyalty , and proceeded with the bigger and better republican deal .	140.28238
on election day -- november 4 -- he energetically marshalled his force of bludgeon men , bribers , and experts in forging repeat votes .	175.9359
the result was a landslide for the republican candidates .	42.69913
this further demonstration of o ' banion ' s ballooning power did not please torrio and capone .	155.97935
in the past year there had been too many examples of his euphoric self-confidence and self-aggrandisement for their liking .	84.739296
he behaved publicly with a cocky , swaggering truculence that offended their vulpine latin minds , and behaved towards them personally with an unimpressed insolence that enraged them beneath their blandness .	105.35447
they were disturbed by his idiotic bravado -- as , when his bodyguard , yankee schwartz , complained that he had been snubbed by dave miller , a prize-fight referee , chieftain of a jewish gang and one of four brothers of tough reputation , who were hirschey , a gambler-politician in loose beer-running league with torrio and o ' banion , frank , a policeman , and max , the youngest .	105.64992
to settle this slight , o ' banion went down to the la salle theatre in the loop , where , he had learned , dave miller was attending the opening of a musical comedy .	68.68841
at the end of the performance , dave and max came out into the brilliantly lit foyer among a surge of gowned and tuxedoed first nighters .	145.91873
o ' banion drew his guns and fired at dave , severely wounding him in the stomach .	146.80263
a second bullet ricocheted off max ' s belt buckle , leaving him unhurt but in some distress .	94.89989
o ' banion tucked away his gun and walked out of the theatre	53.4539
that sort of braggadocio , for that sort of reason , in the view of torrio and capone , was a nonsense .	55.629517
a further example of the incompatible difference in personalities was when two policemen held up a torrio beer convoy on a west side street and demanded $300 to let it through .	174.99164
one of the beer-runners telephoned o ' banion -- on a line tapped by the detective bureau -- and reported the situation .	103.10004
o ' banion ' s reaction was `` three hundred dollars ! !	135.86272
why , i can get them knocked off for half that much ' ' .	72.93752
upon which the detective bureau despatched rifle squads to prevent trouble if o ' banion should send his gunmen out to deal with the hijacking policemen .	132.5978
but in the meantime the beer-runner , unhappy with this solution , telephoned torrio and returned to o ' banion with the message `` say , dionie , i just been talking to johnny , and he said to let them cops have the three hundred .	120.34514
he says he don ' t want no trouble ' ' .	16.571476
but torrio and capone had graver cause to hate and distrust the irishman .	96.67141
for three years , since the liquor territorial conference , torrio had , with his elastic patience , and because he knew that retaliation could cause only violent warfare and disaster to business , tolerated o ' banion ' s impudent double-crossing .	75.840454
they had suffered , in sulky silence , the sight of his sharp practice in cicero .	86.64061
when , as a diplomatic gesture of amity and in payment for the loan of gunmen in the april election , torrio had given o ' banion a slice of cicero , the profits from that district had been $20 , 000 a month .	111.06191
in six months o ' banion had boosted the profits to $100 , 000 a month -- mainly by bringing pressure to bear on fifty chicago speak-easy proprietors to shift out to the suburb .	132.39587
these booze customers had until then been buying their supplies from the sheldon , saltis-mcerlane , and druggan-lake gangs , and now they were competing for trade with the torrio-capone saloons	142.86412
once again o ' banion ' s brash recklessness had caused a proliferation of ill will .	90.38401
the revenue from o ' banion ' s cicero territory went up still higher , until the yield was more than the torrio-capone takings from the far bigger trade area of chicago ' s south and west sides .	259.33734
but he still showed no intention of sharing with the syndicate .	23.107136
at last , even the controlled torrio was unable to hold still , and he tentatively suggested that o ' banion should take a percentage in the stickney brothels in return for one from his cicero beer concession .	91.223526
o ' banion ' s reply was a raucous laugh and a flat refusal .	83.42081
still more jealous bitterness was engendered by the o ' banion gang ' s seizure from a west side marshalling yard of a freight-car load of canadian whisky worth $100 , 000 and by one of the biggest coups of the prohibition era -- the sibley warehouse robbery , which became famous for the cool brazenness of the operation .	72.575745
here was stored $1 , 000 , 000 worth of bonded whisky .	75.373695
these 1750 cases were carted off in a one-night operation by the o ' banion men , who left in their stead the same number of barrels filled with water .	73.2938
a tsunami may be started by a sea bottom slide , an earthquake or a volcanic eruption .	53.191326
the most infamous of all was launched by the explosion of the island of krakatoa in 1883	40.542767
it raced across the pacific at 300 miles an hour , devastated the coasts of java and sumatra with waves 100 to 130 feet high , and pounded the shore as far away as san francisco .	83.39646
the ancient greeks recorded several catastrophic inundations by huge waves .	70.14289
whether or not plato ' s tale of the lost continent of atlantis is true , skeptics concede that the myth may have some foundation in a great tsunami of ancient times .	113.04771
indeed , a tremendously destructive tsunami that arose in the arabian sea in 1945 has even revived the interest of geologists and archaeologists in the biblical story of the flood .	83.63325
one of the most damaging tsunami on record followed the famous lisbon earthquake of november 1 , 1755	149.93579
its waves persisted for a week and were felt as far away as the english coast .	116.246284
tsunami are rare , however , in the atlantic ocean	273.49655
they are far more common in the pacific .	10.9733715
japan has had 15 destructive ones ( eight of them disastrous ) since 1596 .	93.75193
the hawaiian islands are struck severely an average of once every 25 years .	161.5583
in 1707 an earthquake in japan generated waves so huge that they piled into the inland sea	207.32243
one wave swamped more than 1 , 000 ships and boats in osaka bay .	59.131138
a tsunami in the hawaiian islands in 1869 washed away an entire town ( ponoluu ) , leaving only two forlorn trees standing where the community had been .	324.2747
in 1896 a japanese tsunami killed 27 , 000 people and swept away 10 , 000 homes .	120.42241
the dimensions of these waves dwarf all our usual standards of measurement .	34.89721
an ordinary sea wave is rarely more than a few hundred feet long from crest to crest -- no longer than 320 feet in the atlantic or 1 , 000 feet in the pacific .	55.642597
but a tsunami often extends more than 100 miles and sometimes as much as 600 miles from crest to crest .	63.72131
while a wind wave never travels at more than 60 miles per hour , the velocity of a tsunami in the open sea must be reckoned in hundreds of miles per hour .	58.5811
the greater the depth of the water , the greater is the speed of the wave	156.80579
lagrange ' s law says that its velocity is equal to the square root of the product of the depth times the acceleration due to gravity .	155.89607
in the deep waters of the pacific these waves reach a speed of 500 miles per hour .	113.37771
tsunami are so shallow in comparison with their length that in the open ocean they are hardly detectable .	196.91338
their amplitude sometimes is as little as two feet from trough to crest .	40.91513
usually it is only when they approach shallow water on the shore that they build up to their terrifying heights .	78.832794
on the fateful day in 1896 when the great waves approached japan , fishermen at sea noticed no unusual swells .	226.56337
not until they sailed home at the end of the day , through a sea strewn with bodies and the wreckage of houses , were they aware of what had happened .	41.55192
the seemingly quiet ocean had crashed a wall of water from 10 to 100 feet high upon beaches crowded with bathers , drowning thousands of them and flattening villages along the shore .	123.101685
the giant waves are more dangerous on flat shores than on steep ones .	154.47862
they usually range from 20 to 60 feet in height , but when they pour into a v-shaped inlet or harbor they may rise to mountainous proportions .	118.50648
generally the first salvo of a tsunami is a rather sharp swell , not different enough from an ordinary wave to alarm casual observers .	133.04425
this is followed by a tremendous suck of water away from the shore as the first great trough arrives .	93.66314
reefs are left high and dry , and the beaches are covered with stranded fish .	57.939762
at hilo large numbers of people ran out to inspect the amazing spectacle of the denuded beach .	68.549835
many of them paid for their curiosity with their lives , for some minutes later the first giant wave roared over the shore .	36.08829
after an earthquake in japan in 1793 people on the coast at tugaru were so terrified by the extraordinary ebbing of the sea that they scurried to higher ground .	168.5452
when a second quake came , they dashed back to the beach , fearing that they might be buried under landslides .	53.80266
just as they reached the shore , the first huge wave crashed upon them .	121.409775
a tsunami is not a single wave but a series .	168.40315
the waves are separated by intervals of 15 minutes to an hour or more ( because of their great length ) , and this has often lulled people into thinking after the first great wave has crashed that it is all over .	121.419846
the waves may keep coming for many hours .	7.050775
usually the third to the eighth waves in the series are the biggest .	216.33603
among the observers of the 1946 tsunami at hilo was francis p . shepard of the scripps institution of oceanography , one of the world ' s foremost marine geologists .	67.92025
he was able to make a detailed inspection of the waves .	12.344772
their onrush and retreat , he reported , was accompanied by a great hissing , roaring and rattling .	53.470943
the third and fourth waves seemed to be the highest .	146.18694
on some of the islands ' beaches the waves came in gently	53.490604
they were steepest on the shores facing the direction of the seaquake from which the waves had come .	133.54153
in hilo bay they were from 21 to 26 feet high .	45.0658
the highest waves , 55 feet , occurred at pololu valley .	151.04376
scientists and fishermen have occasionally seen strange by-products of the phenomenon .	14.470602
during a 1933 tsunami in japan the sea glowed brilliantly at night .	63.904243
the luminosity of the water is now believed to have been caused by the stimulation of vast numbers of the luminescent organism noctiluca miliaris by the turbulence of the sea .	109.97384
japanese fishermen have sometimes observed that sardines hauled up in their nets during a tsunami have enormously swollen stomachs	149.40787
the fish have swallowed vast numbers of bottom-living diatoms , raised to the surface by the disturbance .	179.57599
the waves of a 1923 tsunami in sagami bay brought to the surface and battered to death huge numbers of fishes that normally live at a depth of 3 , 000 feet .	132.04767
gratified fishermen hauled them in by the thousands .	31.200682
the tsunami-warning system developed since the 1946 disaster in hawaii relies mainly on a simple and ingenious instrument devised by commander c . k . green of the coast and geodetic survey staff .	98.44045
it consists of a series of pipes and a pressure-measuring chamber which record the rise and fall of the water surface .	165.3927
but when waves with a period of between 10 and 40 minutes begin to roll over the ocean , they set in motion a corresponding oscillation in a column of mercury which closes an electric circuit .	87.95683
this in turn sets off an alarm , notifying the observers at the station that a tsunami is in progress .	82.676125
such equipment has been installed at hilo , midway , attu and dutch harbor .	87.57951
the moment the alarm goes off , information is immediately forwarded to honolulu , which is the center of the warning system .	69.92803
this center also receives prompt reports on earthquakes from four coast survey stations in the pacific which are equipped with seismographs .	110.62306
its staff makes a preliminary determination of the epicenter of the quake and alerts tide stations near the epicenter for a tsunami .	97.909676
by means of charts showing wave-travel times and depths in the ocean at various locations , it is possible to estimate the rate of approach and probable time of arrival at hawaii of a tsunami getting under way at any spot in the pacific .	84.589035
the civil and military authorities are then advised of the danger , and they issue warnings and take all necessary protective steps .	123.52546
all of these activities are geared to a top-priority communication system , and practice tests have been held to assure that everything will work smoothly .	231.44795
since the 1946 disaster there have been 15 tsunami in the pacific , but only one was of any consequence .	87.28092
on november 4 , 1952 , an earthquake occurred under the sea off the kamchatka peninsula .	116.351814
at 17 07 that afternoon ( greenwich time ) the shock was recorded by the seismograph alarm in honolulu .	194.91275
within about an hour with the help of reports from seismic stations in alaska , arizona and california , the quake ' s epicenter was placed at 51 degrees north latitude and 158 degrees east longitude .	114.27627
while accounts of the progress of the tsunami came in from various points in the pacific ( midway reported it was covered with nine feet of water ) , the hawaiian station made its calculations and notified the military services and the police that the first big wave would arrive at honolulu at 23 30 greenwich time .	179.3181
it turned out that the waves were not so high as in 1946 .	116.53688
they hurled a cement barge against a freighter in honolulu harbor , knocked down telephone lines , marooned automobiles , flooded lawns , killed six cows .	175.92424
but not a single human life was lost , and property damage in the hawaiian islands did not exceed $800 , 000 .	54.64451
there is little doubt that the warning system saved lives and reduced the damage .	339.99466
but it is plain that a warning system , however efficient , is not enough .	66.07857
in the vulnerable areas of the pacific there should be restrictions against building homes on exposed coasts , or at least a requirement that they be either raised off the ground or anchored strongly against waves .	132.61937
the key to the world of geology is change	19322.809
life has evolved from simple combinations of molecules in the sea to complex combinations in man .	123.34788
the land , too , is changing , and earthquakes are daily reminders of this .	93.81118
earthquakes result when movements in the earth twist rocks until they break .	214.92134
sometimes this is accompanied by visible shifts of the ground surface	76.2281
often the shifts cannot be seen , but they are there	63.527294
and everywhere can be found scars of earlier breaks once deeply buried .	711.03107
today ' s earthquakes are most numerous in belts where the earth ' s restlessness is presently concentrated , but scars of the past show that there is no part of the earth that has not had them .	104.602
the effects of earthquakes on civilization have been widely publicized , even overemphasized .	201.1339
the role of an earthquake in starting the destruction of whole cities is tremendously frightening , but fire may actually be the principal agent in a particular disaster .	149.2807
superstition has often blended with fact to color reports .	336.68286
we have learned from earthquakes much of what we now know about the earth ' s interior , for they send waves through the earth which emerge with information about the materials through which they have traveled .	117.005714
these waves have shown that 1 , 800 miles below the surface a liquid core begins , and that it , in turn , has a solid inner core .	83.369225
earthquakes originate as far as 400 miles below the surface , but they do not occur at greater depths .	83.39535
two unsolved mysteries are based on these facts .	10.167009
( 1 ) as far down as 400 miles below the surface the material should be hot enough to be plastic and adjust itself to twisting forces by sluggish flow rather than by breaking , as rigid surface rocks do .	153.97194
( 2 ) if earthquakes do occur at such depths , why not deeper ? ?	144.70354
knowledge gained from studying earthquake waves has been applied in various fields .	53.382412
in the search for oil and gas , we make similar waves under controlled conditions with dynamite and learn from them where there are buried rock structures favorable to the accumulation of these resources .	124.213684
we have also developed techniques for recognizing and locating underground nuclear tests through the waves in the ground which they generate .	177.51764
the following discussion of this subject has been adapted from the book causes of catastrophe by l . don leet .	203.68031
at twelve minutes after five on the morning of wednesday , april 18 , 1906 , san francisco was shaken by a severe earthquake .	84.20652
a sharp tremor was followed by a jerky roll .	172.99664
in ireland ' s county limerick , near the river shannon , there is a quiet little suburb by the name of garryowen , which means `` garden of owen ' ' .	49.737362
undoubtedly none of the residents realize the influence their town has had on american military history , or the deeds of valor that have been done in its name .	97.709175
bursting from the lips of a charging cavalry trooper was the last sound heard on this earth by untold numbers of cheyennes , sioux and apaches , mexican banditos under pancho villa , japanese in the south pacific , and chinese and north korean communists in korea .	76.3246
garryowen is the battle cry of the 7th u . s . cavalry regiment , `` the fighting seventh ' ' .	18.483276
today a battle cry may seem an anachronism , for in the modern army , esprit de corps has been sacrificed to organizational charts and tables .	82.11864
but don ' t tell that to a veteran of the fighting seventh , especially in a saloon on saturday night .	38.85766
of all the thousands of men who have served in the 7th cav , perhaps no one knows its spirit better than lieutenant colonel melbourne c . chandler .	121.3195
wiry and burr-headed , with steel blue eyes and a chest splattered with medals , chandler is the epitome of the old-time trooper .	87.52987
the truth is , however , that when mel chandler first reported to the regiment the only steed he had ever ridden was a swivel chair and the only weapon he had ever wielded was a pencil .	156.14343
chandler had been commissioned in the medical service corps and was serving as a personnel officer for the kansas city medical depot when he decided that if he was going to make the army his career , he wanted to be in the fighting part of it .	92.53513
though he knew no more about military science and tactics than any other desk officer , he managed to get transferred to the combat forces .	87.73893
the next thing he knew he was reporting for duty as commanding officer of troop h , 7th cavalry , in the middle of corps maneuvers in japan .	60.31313
outside of combat , he couldn ' t have landed in a tougher spot .	41.901737
first of all , no unit likes to have a new co brought in from the outside , especially when he ' s an armchair trooper .	71.814095
second , if there is ever a perfect time to pull the rug out from under him , it ' s on maneuvers .	116.260025
in combat , helping your co make a fool of himself might mean getting yourself killed .	246.10947
but in maneuvers , with the top brass watching him all the time , it ' s easy .	59.98138
but his first few days with troop h were full of surprises , beginning with first sergeant robert early .	476.9016
chandler had expected a tough old trooper with a gravel voice .	116.93934
instead sergeant early was quiet , sharp and confident .	62.710495
he had enlisted in the army straight out of high school and had immediately set about learning his new trade .	183.73697
there was no weapon early could not take apart and reassemble blind-folded .	630.5334
he could lead a patrol and he knew his paper work .	116.11798
further , he had taken full advantage of the army ' s correspondence courses .	131.66885
he not only knew soldiering , but mathematics , history and literature as well .	75.48868
but for all his erudite confidence , sergeant early was right out of the garryowen mold .	216.16342
he was filled with the spirit of the fighting seventh .	13.935675
sergeant early let the new co know just how lucky he was to be in the best troop in the best regiment in the united states army .	53.34502
he fed the captain bits of history about the troops and the regiment .	35.433094
for example , it was a battalion of the 7th cavalry under colonel george armstrong custer that had been wiped out at the battle of the little big horn .	37.075302
it didn ' t take captain chandler long to realize that he had to carry a heavy load of tradition on his shoulders as commander of troop aj .	78.77298
but what made the load lighter was the realization that every officer , non-com and trooper was ready and willing to help him carry it , for the good of the troop and the regiment .	93.8234
maneuvers over , the 7th returned to garrison duty in tokyo , captain chandler still with them .	116.256424
it was the 7th cavalry whose troopers were charged with guarding the imperial palace of the emperor .	54.678055
but still mel chandler was not completely convinced that men would really die for a four-syllable word , `` garryowen ' ' .	48.827282
it happened at the st . patrick ' s day party , a big affair for a regiment which had gone into battle for over three-quarters of a century to the strains of an irish march .	157.47827
in the middle of the party chandler looked up to see four smiling faces bearing down upon him , each beaming above the biggest , greenest shamrock he had ever seen .	128.87364
the faces belonged to lieutenant marvin goulding , his wife and their two children .	85.58843
and when the singing began , it was the gouldings who sang the old irish songs the best .	118.69599
though there was an occasional good-natured chuckle about marvin goulding , the jewish officer from chicago , singing tearfully about the ould sod , no one really thought it was strange .	128.09146
for marvin goulding , like giovanni martini , the bugler boy who carried custer ' s last message , or margarito lopez , the one-man army on leyte , was a garryowen , through and through .	107.24276
it was no coincidence that goulding was one of the most beloved platoon leaders in the regiment .	31.837996
and so mel chandler got the spirit of garryowen .	8.7418995
he set out to keep troop h the best troop in the best regiment .	58.79241
one of his innovations was to see to it that every man -- cook and clerk as well as rifleman -- qualified with every weapon in the troop .	165.14084
even the mess sergeant , bill brown , a dapper , cocky transfer from an airborne division , went out on the range .	97.550804
the troop received a new leader , lieutenant robert m . carroll , fresh out of rotc and bucking for regular army status .	142.4939
carroll was sharp and military , but he was up against tough competition for that ra berth , and he wanted to play it cool .	121.045135
so mel chandler set out to sell him on the spirit of garryowen , just as he himself had been sold a short time before .	120.08874
when the korean war began , on june 25 , 1950 , the anniversary of the day custer had gone down fighting at the little big horn and the day the regiment had assaulted the beachhead of leyte during world war 2 , , the 7th cavalry was not in the best fighting condition .	59.90029
its entire complement of non-commissioned officers on the platoon level had departed as cadre for another unit , and its vehicles were still those used in the drive across luzon in world war 2 .	216.22961
just a month after the korean war broke out , the 7th cavalry was moving into the lines , ready for combat .	43.75908
from then on the fighting seventh was in the thick of the bitterest fighting in korea .	64.1674
one night on the naktong river , mel chandler called on that fabled esprit de corps .	41.011166
the regiment was dug in on the east side of the river and the north koreans were steadily building up a concentration of crack troops on the other side .	42.527042
the troopers knew an attack was coming , but they didn ' t know when , and they didn ' t know where .	28.730097
at 6 o ' clock on the morning of august 12 , they were in doubt no longer .	53.131893
the enemy had filtered across the river during the night and a full force of 1000 men , armed with russian machine guns , attacked the position held by chandler ' s men .	117.02652
first came the cannon fodder , white-clad civilians being driven into death as a massive human battering ram .	159.69177
they were followed by crack north korean troops , who mounted one charge after another .	123.46015
they overran the 7th cav ' s forward machine-gun positions through sheer weight of numbers , over piles of their own dead .	265.6397
another force flanked the company and took up a position on a hill to the rear .	60.12189
captain chandler saw that it was building up strength .	1429.3623
he assembled a group of 25 men , composed of wounded troopers awaiting evacuation , the company clerk , supply men , cooks and drivers , and led them to the hill .	92.27165
one of the more seriously wounded was lieutenant carroll , the young officer bucking for the regular army .	135.44835
chandler left carroll at the bottom of the hill to direct any reinforcements he could find to the fight .	87.68263
he took one step , two , broke into a trot and then into a run .	46.921394
the first thing he knew the words `` garryowen ' ' ! !	7.481298
his followers shouted the old battle cry after him and charged the hill , firing as they ran .	185.22476
the koreans fell back , but regrouped at the top of the hill and pinned down the cavalrymen with a screen of fire .	49.698032
chandler , looking to right and left to see how his men were faring , suddenly saw another figure bounding up the hill , hurling grenades and hollering the battle cry as he ran .	106.054016
it was bob carroll , who had suddenly found himself imbued with the spirit of garryowen .	43.072178
he had formed his own task force of three stragglers and led them up the hill in a fighting seventh charge .	90.54517
because of this diversionary attack the main group that had been pinned down on the hill was able to surge forward again .	75.00601
but an enemy grenade hit carroll in the head and detonated simultaneously .	77.829666
he went down like a wet rag and the attackers hit the dirt in the face of the withering enemy fire .	93.67842
enemy reinforcements came pouring down , seeking a soft spot .	82.94317
they found it at the junction between troops h and g , and prepared to counterattack .	49.157528
`` okay , men ' ' , he said .	6.687764
goulding leaped to his feet and started forward , `` garryowen ' ' ! !	18.444782
but the bullets whacked home before he finished his battle cry and marvin goulding fell dead .	68.089516
for an instant his men hesitated , unable to believe that their lieutenant , the most popular officer in the regiment , was dead .	114.02452
then they let out a bellow of anguish and rage and , cursing , screaming and hollering `` garryowen ' ' ! !	40.559605
they charged into the enemy like wild men .	3.668585
that finished the job that captain chandler and lieutenant carroll had begun .	71.682205
goulding ' s platoon pushed back the enemy soldiers and broke up the timing of the entire enemy attack .	118.29104
reinforcements came up quickly to take advantage of the opening made by goulding ' s platoon .	52.65507
the north koreans threw away their guns and fled across the rice paddies .	91.16952
artillery and air strikes were called in to kill them by the hundreds .	92.83677
though bob carroll seemed to have had his head practically blown off by the exploding grenade , he lived .	100.94742
today he is a major -- in the regular army .	209.31696
so filled was mel chandler with the spirit of garryowen that after korea was over , he took on the job of writing the complete history of the regiment .	67.682526
after years of digging , nights and weekends , he put together the big , profusely illustrated book , of garryowen and glory , which is probably the most complete history of any military unit .	141.175
the battle of the naktong river is just one example of how the battle cry and the spirit of the fighting seventh have paid off .	62.807602
for nearly a century the cry has never failed to rally the fighting men of the regiment .	67.16622
take the case of major marcus a . reno , who survived the battle of the little big horn in 1876 .	65.7132
from the enlisted men he pistol-whipped to the subordinate officer whose wife he tried to rape , a lot of men had plenty of reason heartily to dislike marcus reno .	126.91896
many of his fellow officers refused to speak to him .	29.863007
but when a board of inquiry was called to look into the charges of cowardice made against him , the men who had seen reno leave the battlefield and the officer who had heard reno suggest that the wounded be left to be tortured by the sioux , refused to say a harsh word against him .	116.59819
he was a member of the fighting seventh .	70.66873
although it was at the battle of the little horn , about which more words have been written than any other battle in american history , that the 7th cavalry first made its mark in history , the regiment was ten years old by then .	142.57198
brevet major general george armstrong custer was the regiment ' s first permanent commander and , like such generals as george s . patton and terry de la mesa allen in their rise to military prominence , custer was a believer in blood and guts warfare .	154.80537
during the civil war , custer , who achieved a brilliant record , was made brigadier general at the age of 23 .	137.60274
he finished the war as a major general , commanding a full division , and at 25 was the youngest major general in the history of the u . s . army .	60.016773
i do not mean to suggest that these assumptions are self-evident , in the sense that everyone agrees with them .	59.523994
if they were , walter lippmann would be writing the same columns as george sokolsky , and herb lock would have nothing to draw cartoons about .	235.49236
i do mean , however , that i take them for granted , and that everything i shall be saying would appear quite idiotic against any contrary assumptions .	200.20305
the ultimate objective of american policy is to help establish a world in which there is the largest possible measure of freedom and justice and peace and material prosperity	74.29105
and in particular -- since this is our special responsibility -- that these conditions be enjoyed by the people of the united states .	44.575596
i speak of `` the largest possible measure ' ' because any person who supposes that these conditions can be universally and perfectly achieved -- ever -- reckons without the inherent imperfectability of himself and his fellow human beings , and is therefore a dangerous man to have around .	125.07417
these conditions are unobtainable -- are not even approachable in the qualified sense i have indicated -- without the prior defeat of world communism .	372.32367
this is true for two reasons because communism is both doctrinally , and in practice , antithetical to these conditions	80.248344
and because communists have the will and , as long as soviet power remains intact , the capacity to prevent their realization .	61.245865
moreover , as communist power increases , the enjoyment of these conditions throughout the world diminishes pro rata and the possibility of their restoration becomes increasingly remote .	113.01245
it follows that victory over communism is the dominant , proximate goal of american policy .	60.068336
proximate in the sense that there are more distant , more `` positive ' ' ends we seek , to which victory over communism is but a means .	153.84152
but dominant in the sense that every other objective , no matter how worthy intrinsically , must defer to it .	146.30939
but if we must choose between peace and keeping the communists out of berlin , then we must fight .	175.0807
freedom , in the sense of self-determination , is a worthy objective	33.59208
but if granting self-determination to the algerian rebels entails sweeping that area into the sino-soviet orbit , then algerian freedom must be postponed .	169.94432
but if justice for bantus entails driving the government of the union of south africa away from the west , then the bantus must be prepared to carry their identification cards yet a while longer .	57.898773
but if providing higher standards of living gets in the way of producing sufficient guns to resist communist aggression , then material sacrifices and denials will have to be made .	163.77892
it may be , of course , that such objectives can be pursued consisently with a policy designed to overthrow communism	91.31649
my point is that where conflicts arise they must always be resolved in favor of achieving the indispensable condition for a tolerant world -- the absence of soviet communist power .	73.76981
this much having been said , the question remains whether we have the resources for the job we have to do -- defeat communism -- and , if so , how those resources ought to be used .	89.58135
this brings us squarely to the problem of power , and the uses a nation makes of power .	122.42428
i submit that this is the key problem of international relations , that it always has been , that it always will be .	87.20554
and i suggest further that the main cause of the trouble we are in has been the failure of american policy-makers , ever since we assumed free world leadership in 1945 , to deal with this problem realistically and seriously .	125.8177
in the recent political campaign two charges were leveled affecting the question of power , and i think we might begin by trying to put them into proper focus .	91.25855
the other , for the most part , true .	373.30338
the first was that america had become -- or was in danger of becoming -- a second-rate military power .	107.58613
i know i do not have to dwell here on the absurdity of that contention .	80.43104
you may have misgivings about certain aspects of our military establishment -- i certainly do -- but you know any comparison of over-all american strength with over-all soviet strength finds the united states not only superior , but so superior both in present weapons and in the development of new ones that our advantage promises to be a permanent feature of u . s . -soviet relations for the foreseeable future .	139.3518
i have often searched for a graphic way of impressing our superiority on those americans who have doubts , and i think mr . jameson campaigne has done it well in his new book american might and soviet myth .	209.31027
suppose , he says , that the tables were turned , and we were in the soviets ' position `` there would be more than 2 , 000 modern soviet fighters , all better than ours , stationed at 250 bases in mexico and the caribbean .	125.35612
overwhelming russian naval power would always be within a few hundred miles of our coast .	50.936565
half of the population of the u . s . would be needed to work on arms just to feed the people ' ' .	42.62819
add this to the unrest in the countries around us where oppressed peoples would be ready to turn on us at the first opportunity .	154.97589
add also a comparatively primitive industrial plant which would severely limit our capacity to keep abreast of the soviets even in the missile field which is reputed to be our main strength .	149.52397
if we look at the situation this way , we can get an idea of khrushchev ' s nightmarish worries -- or , at least , of the worries he might have if his enemies were disposed to exploit their advantage .	55.092266
the other charge was that america ' s political position in the world has progressively deteriorated in recent years .	38.83295
the contention needs to be formulated with much greater precision than it ever was during the campaign , but once that has been done , i fail to see how any serious student of world affairs can quarrel with it .	129.88873
the argument was typically advanced in terms of u . s . `` prestige ' ' .	18.205004
prestige , however , is only a minor part of the problem	36.246918
and even then , it is a concept that can be highly misleading .	49.41798
prestige is a measure of how other people think of you , well or ill .	166.10344
but contrary to what was implied during the campaign , prestige is surely not important for its own sake .	46.062946
only the vain and incurably sentimental among us will lose sleep simply because foreign peoples are not as impressed by our strength as they ought to be .	136.74951
the thing to lose sleep over is what people , having concluded that we are weaker than we are , are likely to do about it .	119.04209
the evidence suggests that foreign peoples believe the united states is weaker than the soviet union , and is bound to fall still further behind in the years ahead .	61.294888
this ignorant estimate , i repeat , is not of any interest in itself	126.735054
but it becomes very important if foreign peoples react the way human beings typically do -- namely , by taking steps to end up on what appears to be the winning side .	121.51606
to the extent , then , that declining u . s . prestige means that other nations will be tempted to place their bets on an ultimate american defeat , and will thus be more vulnerable to soviet intimidation , there is reason for concern .	99.520744
still , these guesses about the outcome of the struggle cannot be as important as the actual power relationship between the soviet union and ourselves .	67.8724
here i do not speak of military power where our advantage is obvious and overwhelming but of political power -- of influence , if you will -- about which the relevant questions are is soviet influence throughout the world greater or less than it was ten years ago ? ?	156.69359
and is western influence greater or less than it used to be ? ?	42.060787
in answering these questions , we need to ask not merely whether communist troops have crossed over into territories they did not occupy before , and not merely whether disciplined agents of the cominform are in control of governments from which they were formerly excluded the success of communism ' s war against the west does not depend on such spectacular and definitive conquests .	181.37457
success may mean merely the displacement of western influence .	87.03692
communist political warfare , we must remember , is waged insidiously and in deliberate stages .	216.6413
fearful of inviting a military showdown with the west which they could not win , the communists seek to undermine western power where the nuclear might of the west is irrelevant -- in backwoods guerrilla skirmishes , in mob uprisings in the streets , in parliaments , in clandestine meetings of undercover conspirators , at the united nations , on the propaganda front , at diplomatic conferences -- preferably at the highest level .	112.47587
the soviets understand , moreover , that the first step in turning a country toward communism is to turn it against the west .	204.9742
thus , typically , the first stage of a communist takeover is to `` neutralize ' ' a country .	131.64775
the second stage is to retain the nominal classification of `` neutralist ' ' , while in fact turning the country into an active advocate and adherent of soviet policy .	60.35994
and this may be as far as the process will go .	87.05797
the kremlin ' s goal is the isolation and capture , not of ghana , but of the united states -- and this purpose may be served very well by countries that masquerade under a `` neutralist ' ' mask , yet in fact are dependable auxiliaries of the soviet foreign office .	128.9019
to recite the particulars of recent soviet successes is hardly reassuring .	301.9235
six years ago french indochina , though in troubie , was in the western camp .	89.843544
cambodia is , for all practical purposes , neutralist .	189.26178
indonesia , in the early days of the republic , leaned toward the west .	35.54342
today sukarno ' s government is heavily besieged by avowed communists , and for all of its `` neutralist ' ' pretensions , it is a firm ally of soviet policy .	50.43645
ceylon has moved from a pro-western orientation to a neutralism openly hostile to the west .	113.72191
in the middle east , iraq , syria and egypt were , a short while ago , in the western camp .	168.98514
today the nasser and kassem governments are adamantly hostile to the west , are dependent for their military power on soviet equipment and personnel	112.26118
in almost every particular follow the kremlin ' s foreign policy line .	40.057808
a short time ago all africa was a western preserve .	354.7077
never mind whether the kikiyus and the bantus enjoyed wilsonian self-determination the point is that in the struggle for the world that vast land mass was under the domination and influence of the west .	99.71526
today , africa is swerving violently away from the west and plunging , it would seem , into the soviet orbit .	66.20008
latin america was once an area as `` safe ' ' for the west as nebraska was for nixon .	65.532875
one latin american country , cuba , has become a soviet bridgehead ninety miles off our coast .	54.206882
in some countries the trend has gone further than others mexico , panama , and venezuela are displaying open sympathy for castroism , and there is no country -- save the dominican republic whose funeral services we recently arranged -- where castroism and anti-americanism does not prevent the government from unqualifiedly espousing the american cause .	175.17514
only in europe have our lines remained firm -- and there only on the surface .	92.34581
the strains of neutralism are running strong , notably in england , and even in germany .	80.14743
what have we to show by way of counter-successes ? ?	87.95675
we have had opportunities -- clear invitations to plant our influence on the other side of the iron curtain .	111.88682
there was the hungarian revolution which we praised and mourned , but did nothing about .	289.07812
there was the polish revolution which we misunderstood and then helped guide along a course favorable to soviet interests .	261.6219
there was the revolution in tibet which we pretended did not exist .	138.27046
only in one instance have we moved purposively and effectively to dislodge existing communist power in guatemala .	150.77974
and contrary to what has been said recently , we did not wait for `` outside pressures ' ' and `` world opinion ' ' to bring down that communist government	103.30594
we moved decisively to effect an anti-communist coup d ' etat .	88.94994
we served our national interests , and by so doing we saved the guatemalan people the ultimate in human misery .	365.0986
the first rattle of the machine guns , at 7 10 in the evening , roused around me the varied voices and faces of fear .	148.23438
`` sounds exactly like last time ' ' .	2.15919
the young man spoke steadily enough , but all at once he looked grotesquely unshaven .	129.99568
the middle-aged man said over and over , `` why did i come here , why did i come here ' ' .	95.978806
amid the crackle of small arms and automatic weapons , i heard the thumping of mortars .	186.96675
this was my second day in vientiane , the administrative capital of laos , and my thoughts were none too brave .	243.14641
better stay in the hotel lobby , where the walls looked good and thick .	211.3204
chinese and indian merchants across the street were slamming their steel shutters .	39.152405
hotel attendants pulled parked bicycles into the lobby .	5.3262634
a woman with a small boy slipped in between them .	91.46024
`` please ' ' , she said , `` please ' ' .	14.198424
she held out her hand to show that she had money .	112.89988
the american newspaperman worried about getting to the cable office .	472.10855
had the communist-led pathet lao finally come this far ? ?	30.143137
or was it another revolt inside vientiane ? ?	1.2294625
`` let ' s play hero ' ' , i said .	22.056034
`` let ' s go to the roof and see ' ' .	15.200897
there had been an eclipse of the moon .	25.92698
a traditional lao explanation is that the moon was being swallowed by a toad , and the remedy was to make all possible noise , ideally with firearms .	103.735886
the din was successful , too , for just before the moon disappeared , the frightened toad had begun to spit it out again , which meant good luck all around .	184.57303
how quaint it all seemed the next day .	11.844685
a restaurant posted a reminder to patrons `` who became excited and left without paying their checks ' ' .	118.638336
but everyone i met had sought cover first and asked questions later .	106.11051
and no wonder , for vientiane , the old city of sandalwood , had become the city of bullet holes .	136.91125
i saw holes in planes at the airport and in cars in the streets .	131.82993
along the main thoroughfares hardly a house had not been peppered .	48.258183
in place of the police headquarters was a new square filled with rubble .	114.566574
mortars had demolished the defense ministry and set fire to the american embassy next door .	117.28495
what had been the ambassador ' s suite was now jagged walls of blackened brick .	35.76294
this damage had been done in the battle of vientiane , fought less than three months earlier when four successive governments had ruled here in three days ( december 9-11 , 1960 ) .	126.62475
and now , in march , all laos suffered a state of siege .	224.00754
the pathet lao forces held two northern provinces and openly took the offensive in three more .	127.010315
throughout the land their hit-and-run terrorists spread fear of ambush and death .	69.01514
`` and it ' s all the more tragic because it ' s so little deserved ' ' , said mr . j . j . a . frans , a belgian official of the united nations educational , scientific , and cultural organization .	61.99018
we talked after i hailed his jeep marked with the u . n . flag .	29.105116
practically all the people of laos , he explained -- about two million of them -- are rice farmers , and the means and motives of modern war are as strange to them as clocks and steel plows .	145.2737
they look after their fields and children and water buffaloes in ten or eleven thousand villages , with an average of 200 souls .	96.72752
nobody can tell more closely how many villages there are .	134.6341
they spread over an area no larger than oregon	676.70654
yet they include peoples as different from one another as oregonians are from patagonians .	201.92458
faith in the buddha and staying at peace with the phis , the spirits	104.46229
and to live in harmony with nature ' ' .	1.8205855
`` precisely ' ' , said mr . frans .	344.10892
he spoke of the season of dryness and dust , brought by the monsoon from the northeast , in harmony with the season of rain and mud , brought by the monsoon from the southwest .	45.29991
the slim pirogues in harmony with the majestically meandering mekong river .	24.998684
shy , slender-waisted girls at the loom in harmony with the frangipani by the wayside .	72.304276
for so long as death was not violent , it was natural and to be welcomed , making a funeral a feast .	86.20535
to many a frenchman -- they came 95 years ago , colonized , and stayed until laos became independent in 1953 -- the land had been even more delightfully tranquil than tahiti .	148.57085
yet laos was now one of the most explosive headaches of statesmen around the globe .	107.99949
the pathet lao , stiffened by communist veterans from neighboring north viet nam , were supplied by soviet aircraft .	33.817944
the royal lao army , on the other hand , was paid and equipped with american funds .	90.744736
in six years , u . s . aid had amounted to more than $1 . 60 for each american -- a total of three hundred million dollars .	72.958145
we were there at a moment when the situation in laos threatened to ignite another war among the world ' s giants .	50.77988
even if it did not , how would this little world of gentle people cope with its new reality of grenades and submachine guns ? ?	201.36133
to find out , we traveled throughout that part of laos still nominally controlled , in the daytime at least , by the royal lao army from attopeu , the city of buffalo dung in the southeast , to muong sing , the city of lions in the northwest , close to communist china ( map , page 250 ) .	109.20348
we rode over roads so rough that our jeep came to rest atop the soil between ruts , all four wheels spinning uselessly .	169.8791
we flew in rickety planes so overloaded that we wondered why they didn ' t crash .	50.833202
in the end we ran into communist artillery fire .	13.364739
`` we ' ' were bill garrett of the national geographic illustrations staff , whose three cameras and eight lenses made him look as formidable as any fighting man we met	395.11618
boun my -- the name means one who has a boun , a celebration , and is therefore lucky -- was born in savannakhet , the border of paradise .	78.77489
he had attended three universities in the united states .	4.190237
but he had never seen the mountainous half of his native land north of vientiane , including the royal capital , luang prabang .	71.92156
before the airplanes came , he said , travel in laos was just about impossible .	376.56183
alas , so it almost proved for us , too .	46.445297
to go outside the few cities required permits .	15.969767
and getting them seemed a life ' s work .	45.096024
nobody wanted americans to be hurt or captured , and few soldiers could be spared as escorts .	102.712
we were told that to the pathet lao , a kidnaped american was worth at least $750 , a fortune in laos .	235.98201
everyone had heard of the american contractor who had spurned an escort .	129.08029
now pathet lao propagandists were reported marching him barefoot from village to village , as evidence of evil american intervention .	190.8802
although we enjoyed our rounds of the government offices in vientiane , with officials offering tea and pleasing conversation in french , we were getting nowhere .	117.74225
we had nearly decided that all the tales of lao lethargy must be true , when we were invited to take a trip with the prime minister .	53.494225
could we be ready in 15 minutes ? ?	1.4023337
his highness had decided only two hours ago to go out of town , and he was eager to be off .	21.51697
and so , after a flight southeast to savannakhet , we found ourselves bouncing along in a jeep right behind the land-rover of prince boun oum of champassak , a tall man of churchillian mien in a bush jacket and a ten-gallon hat from texas .	118.50676
from his shoulder bag peeked the seven-inch barrel of a luger .	74.002235
with our company of soldiers , we made one long column of reddish dust .	67.317406
in keng kok , the city of silkworms , the prime minister bought fried chickens and fried cicadas , and two notebooks for me .	39.658356
then we drove on , until there was no more road and we traversed dry rice fields , bouncing across their squat earth walls .	119.81007
an hour of bouncing , a brief stop in a village to inspect a new school or dispensary .	82.94598
more bouncing , another stop , a new house for teachers , a new well .	212.75887
then off again , rushing to keep up .	16.37572
but our two jeep mates -- keo viphakone from luang prabang and john cool from beaver , pennsylvania -- were beaming under their coatings of dust .	176.50957
together they had probably done more than any other men to help push laos toward the 20th century -- constructively .	161.65501
mr . keo , once a diplomat in paris and washington , was commissioner of rural affairs .	130.85007
john , an engineer and anthropologist with a doctorate from the london school of economics , headed the rural development division of usom , the united states operations mission administering u . s . aid .	55.210533
`` what you see are self-help projects ' ' , john said .	87.715675
`` we ask the people what they want , and they supply the labor .	44.27875
we send shovels , cement , nails , and corrugated iron for roofs .	50.167953
that way they have an infirmary for $400 .	3.1374516
