we have 2 , 500 such projects , and they add up to a lot more than just roads and wells and schools .	81.27613
`` our people have been used to accepting things as they found them ' ' , he said .	23.204628
`` where there was no road , they lived without one .	76.41345
now they learn that men can change their surroundings , through their traditional village elders , without violence .	103.29849
that ' s a big step toward a modern state .	133.96509
you might say we are in the nation-building business ' ' .	37.36607
in the villages people lined up to give us flowers .	230.8532
then came coconuts , eggs , and rice wine .	60.145775
the prime minister paid his respects to the buddhist monks , strode rapidly among the houses , joked with the local soldiery , and made a speech .	83.092094
the soldiers are fighting and the americans are helping , he said , but in the fight against the pathet lao the key factor is the villager himself .	92.63544
but our stumping tour of the south wasn ' t all misery .	15.467933
crossing the 4 , 000-foot width of the mekong at champassak , on a raft with an outboard motor , we took off our dusty shirts and enjoyed a veritable ocean breeze .	86.02644
briefly we rolled over a paved road up to pak song , on the cool bolovens plateau .	116.854774
the prince visited the hospital of operation brotherhood , supported by the junior chamber of commerce of the philippines , and fed rice to two pet elephants he kept at his residence at pak song .	63.10793
in the village of soukhouma , which means `` peaceful ' ' , we had a baci .	47.31035
this is the most endearing of lao ceremonies .	7.5050087
it takes place in the household , a rite of well-wishing for myriad occasions -- for the traveler , a wedding , a newborn child , the sick , the new year , for any good purpose .	81.80064
the preparations were elaborate flowers , candles , incense sticks , rice wine , dozens of delicacies , and pieces of white cotton string .	38.265408
the strings were draped around flowers in tall silver bowls ( page 261 ) .	70.43536
the candles were lighted , and we sat on split-bamboo mats among the village notables .	287.52347
i was careful to keep my feet , the seat of the least worthy spirits , from pointing at anyone ' s head , where the worthiest spirits reside .	98.21422
now a distinguished old man called on nine divinities to come and join us .	280.92743
a man has 32 souls , one for each part of the body .	48.402023
those souls like to wander off , and must be called back .	133.28548
with the divinities present and our souls in place , we were wished health , happiness , and power .	172.72563
then , one after another , the villagers tied the waiting cotton strings around our wrists .	135.09023
these were to be kept on , to hold in the 32 souls .	116.073906
as we stepped out into the sunlight , a man came up to john cool and silently showed him his hand .	104.9737
it had a festering hole as big as a silver dollar .	14.971895
john said `` i have some antiseptic salve with me , but it ' s too late for that ' ' .	49.836452
my interviews with teen-agers confirmed this portrait of the weakening of religious and ethnic bonds .	89.50633
jewish identity was often confused with social and economic strivings .	48.218784
`` being jewish gives you tremendous drive ' ' , a boy remarked .	17.540464
`` it means that you have to get ahead ' ' .	15.483688
when i pressed for a purely religious definition , i encountered the familiar blend of liberal piety , interfaith good will , and a small residue of ethnic loyalty .	83.873146
`` i like the tradition ' ' , a girl said .	100.24081
`` i like to follow the holidays when they come along .	91.58974
but you don ' t have to worship in the traditional way .	17.415617
as i see it , there ' s no real difference between being jewish , catholic , or protestant ' ' .	68.70898
another teen-ager remarked `` most jews don ' t believe in god , but they believe in people -- in helping people ' ' .	63.48221
still another boy asserted `` to be a good jew is to do no wrong	144.79424
it ' s to be a good person ' ' .	6.255528
when asked how this was different from being a good protestant , the boy answered , `` it ' s the same thing ' ' .	48.12392
this accords with the study by maier and spinrad .	40.166294
they discovered that , although 42 per cent of a sample of catholic students and 15 per cent of the protestants believed it important to live in accordance with the teachings of their religion , only 8 per cent of the jewish students had this conviction .	61.839287
the most important aims of the jewish students were as follows to make the world a better place to live in -- 30 per cent	129.29768
to get happiness for yourself -- 28 per cent	1.1686207
nevertheless , most of the teen-agers i interviewed believed in maintaining their jewish identity and even envisioned joining a synagogue or temple .	128.9134
however , they were hostile to jewish orthodoxy , professing to believe in judaism `` but in a moderate way ' ' .	64.22002
one boy said querulously about orthodox jews `` it ' s the twentieth century , and they don ' t have to wear beards ' ' .	18.759378
the reason offered for clinging to the ancestral faith lacked force and authority even in the teen-agers ' minds .	196.07874
`` we were brought up that way ' ' was one statement which won general assent .	84.94667
`` i want to show respect for my parents ' religion ' ' was the way in which a boy justified his inhabiting a halfway house of judaism .	161.71475
still another suggested that he would join a temple `` for social reasons , since i ' ll be living in a suburb ' ' .	44.276463
intermarriage , which is generally regarded as a threat to jewish survival , was regarded not with horror or apprehension but with a kind of mild , clinical disapproval .	111.04703
most of the teen-agers i interviewed rejected it on pragmatic grounds .	31.6697
`` when you marry , you want to have things in common ' ' , a girl said , `` and it ' s hard when you don ' t marry someone with your own background ' ' .	47.101204
a fourteen-year-old girl from the middle west observed wryly that , in her community , religion inconveniently interfered with religious activities -- at least with the peripheral activities that many middle class jews now regard as religious .	173.84622
it appears that an orthodox girl in the community disrupted plans for an outing sponsored by one of the jewish service groups because she would not travel on saturday and , in addition , required kosher food .	178.63297
another girl from a relatively large midwestern city described herself as `` the only orthodox girl in town ' ' .	126.76122
this is , no doubt , inaccurate , but it does convey how isolated she feels among the vast army of the nonobservant .	177.39917
one of the significant things about jewish culture in the older teen years is that it is largely college-oriented .	40.036545
sixty-five per cent of the jewish teen-agers of college age attend institutions of higher learning .	68.55242
this is substantially higher than the figures for the american population at large -- 45 . 6 per cent for males and 29 . 2 per cent for females .	59.073112
this may help explain a phenomenon described by a small-town jewish boy .	137.47603
in their first two years in high school , jewish boys in this town make strenuous exertions to win positions on the school teams .	228.51494
however , in their junior and senior years , they generally forego their athletic pursuits , presumably in the interest of better academic achievement .	76.7963
it is significant , too , that the older teen-agers i interviewed believed , unlike the younger ones , that jewish students tend to do better academically than their gentile counterparts .	61.54864
the percentage of jewish girls who attend college is almost as high as that of boys .	161.61208
the motivations for both sexes , to be sure , are different .	57.785282
the vocational motive is the dominant one for boys , while jewish girls attend college for social reasons and to become culturally developed .	171.90059
one of the significant developments in american-jewish life is that the cultural consumers are largely the women .	295.30826
it is they who read -- and make -- jewish best-sellers and then persuade their husbands to read them .	106.751945
in upper teen jewish life , the non-college group tends to have a sense of marginality .	28.392977
`` people automatically assume that i ' m in college ' ' , a nineteen-year-old machinist observed irritably .	61.556828
however , among the girls , there are some morale-enhancing compensations for not going to college .	213.40007
the jewish working girl almost invariably works in an office -- in contradistinction to gentile factory workers -- and , buttressed by a respectable income , she is likely to dress better and live more expansively than the college student .	138.6694
she is even prone to regard the college girl as immature .	394.5414
one of the reasons for the high percentage of jewish teen-agers in college is that a great many urban jews are enabled to attend local colleges at modest cost .	109.81841
this is particularly true in large centers of jewish population like new york , chicago , and philadelphia .	62.017265
what is noteworthy about this large group of teen-agers is that , although their attitudes hardly differentiate them from their gentile counterparts , they actually lead their lives in a vast self-enclosed jewish cosmos with relatively little contact with the non-jewish world .	158.88628
perhaps the jewish students at brooklyn college -- constituting 85 per cent of those who attend the day session -- can serve as a paradigm of the urban , lower-middle class jewish student .	51.38103
there is , to begin , an important sex difference .	304.54538
typically , in a lower-middle class jewish family , a son will be sent to an out-of-town school , if financial resources warrant it , while the daughter will attend the local college .	133.29144
first , the girl ' s education has a lower priority than the son ' s .	93.049675
second , the attitude in jewish families is far more protective toward the daughter than toward the son .	293.17102
most jewish mothers are determined to exercise vigilance over the social and sexual lives of their daughters by keeping them home .	93.51191
the consequence of this is that the girls at brooklyn college outnumber the boys and do somewhat better academically .	178.36928
one can assume that some of the brightest boys are out of town .	112.76941
brooklyn college students have an ambivalent attitude toward their school .	44.25222
on the one hand , there is a sense of not having moved beyond the ambiance of their high school .	228.49924
this is particularly acute for those who attended midwood high school directly across the street from brooklyn college .	61.563198
they have a sense of marginality at being denied that special badge of status , the out-of-town school .	138.00099
at the same time , there is a good deal of self-congratulation at attending a good college -- they are even inclined to exaggerate its not inconsiderable virtues -- and they express pleasure at the cozy in-group feeling that the college generates .	176.76883
`` it ' s people of your own kind ' ' , a girl remarked .	33.27895
`` you don ' t have to watch what you say .	67.760284
of course , i would like to go to an out-of-town school where there are all kinds of people , but i would want lots of jewish kids there ' ' .	79.79835
for most brooklyn college students , college is at once a perpetuation of their ethnic attachments and a breaking away from the cage of neighborhood and family .	85.78329
brooklyn college is unequivocally jewish in tone , and efforts to detribalize the college by bringing in unimpeachably midwestern types on the faculty have been unavailing .	231.50842
however , a growing intellectual sophistication and the new certitudes imparted by courses in psychology and anthropology make the students increasingly critical of their somewhat provincial and overprotective parents .	134.71938
and the rebellion of these third generation jews is not the traditional conflict of culture but , rather , a protest against a culture that they view as softly and insidiously enveloping .	154.25955
`` as long as i ' m home , i ' ll never grow up ' ' , a nineteen-year-old boy observed sadly .	36.778404
`` they don ' t like it if i do anything away from home .	60.56902
it ' s so much trouble , i don ' t usually bother ' ' .	20.129335
for girls , the overprotection is far more pervasive .	177.25761
parents will drive on friday night to pick up their daughters after a sorority or house plan meeting .	557.1487
a freshman girl ' s father not too long ago called a dean at brooklyn college and demanded the `` low-down ' ' on a boy who was going out with his daughter .	57.3117
the domestic tentacles even extend to the choice of a major field .	41.051216
under pressure from parents , the majority of brooklyn college girls major in education since that co-ordinates best with marriage plans -- limited graduate study requirement and convenient working hours .	480.1731
this means that a great many academically talented girls are discouraged from pursuing graduate work of a more demanding nature .	167.89026
a kind of double standard exists here for jewish boys and girls as it does in the realm of sex .	70.67039
the breaking away from the prison house of brooklyn is gradual .	71.349304
first , the student trains on his hapless parents the heavy artillery of his newly acquired psychological and sociological insights .	196.57819
then , with the new affluence , there is actually a sallying forth into the wide , wide world beyond the precincts of new york .	118.93979
it is significant that the catskills , which used to be the summer playground for older teen-agers , a kind of summer suburb of new york , no longer attracts them in great numbers -- except for those who work there as waiters , bus boys , or counselors in the day camps .	93.9815
but it should be pointed out that some of the new watering places -- fire island , nantucket , westhampton , long island , for example -- tend to be homogeneously jewish .	190.87338
although brooklyn college does not yet have a junior-year-abroad program , a good number of students spend summers in europe .	84.946144
in general , however , the timetable of travel lags considerably behind that of the student at harvard or smith .	122.46865
and acculturation into the world at large is likely to occur for the brooklyn college student after college rather than during the four school years .	93.34663
brooklyn college is marjorie morningstar territory , as much as the bronx or central park west .	140.37384
there are hordes of nubile young women there who , prodded by their impatient mothers , are determined to marry .	124.801926
it is interesting that , although the percentage of married students is not appreciably higher at brooklyn than elsewhere -- about 30 per cent of the women and 25 per cent of the men in the graduating class -- the anxiety of the unmarried has puffed up the estimate .	75.03281
`` almost everybody in the senior class is married ' ' , students say dogmatically .	90.02211
and the school newspaper sells space to jubilant fraternities , sororities , and houses ( in the house plan association ) that have good news to impart .	154.73422
these announcements are , in effect , advertisements for themselves as thriving marriage marts .	96.46157
there are boxed proclamations in the newspaper of watchings , pinnings , ringings , engagements , and marriages in a scrupulously graded hierarchy of felicity .	49.019356
`` witt house happily announces the engagement of fran horowitz to erwin schwartz of fife house ' ' .	74.60231
the brooklyn college student shows some striking departures from prevailing collegiate models .	35.285347
the ivy league enjoys no easy dominion here , and the boys are as likely to dress in rather foppish continental fashion , or even in nondescript working class manner , as they are in the restrained , button-down ivy way .	93.16804
the girls are prone to dress far more flamboyantly than their counterparts out of town , and eye shadow , mascara , and elaborate bouffant hairdos -- despite the admonitions of cautious guidance personnel -- are not unknown even in early morning classes .	124.590485
among the boys , there is very little bravado about drinking .	222.19754
brooklyn college is distinctive for not having an official drinking place .	268.24875
the fort lauderdale encampment for drinking is foreign to most brooklyn college boys .	141.79744
this should be used frequently ( but shaken before using ) .	130.32736
for galled breasts , the mother should shave into half a cup of fresh unsalted lard enough white chalk to make a paste .	96.808876
this could also be used for any other skin irritation .	35.576817
or she might place cornstarch in the oven for a short time and then apply this under her breasts .	75.101425
`` female troubles ' ' of various kinds do not seem to have been common on the frontier	76.698006
at least i have only one remedy for anything of this kind in my collection , one for hastening delayed menstruation .	78.435234
bruises , burns , cuts , etc . , occurred frequently on the frontier , and folk medicine gave the answers to these problems too .	184.79918
bruises and black eyes were relieved by application of raw beefsteak .	102.83289
( doctors now say that it was not the meat but the coolness of the applications which relieved the pain .	227.79668
) salted butter was another cure for bruises .	16.419168
many people agreed that burns should be treated with bland oily salves or unsalted butter or lard , but one informant told me that a burn should be bathed in salt water	110.48047
the burn oozed watery fluid for many days , and finally the healing was completed by bathing it with epsom salts .	143.6673
another swore by vinegar baths for burns , and still another recommended salted butter .	114.76505
`` butter salve ' ' or `` butter ointment ' ' was used for burns , and for bruises as well .	46.645134
this was made by putting butter in a pan of water and allowing it to boil	48.98975
when it was cool , the fat was skimmed off and bottled .	16.216084
cow ' s milk was another cure for burns , and burns covered with gum arabic or plain mucilage healed quickly .	106.37096
one man , badly burned about the face and eyes by an arc welding torch , was blinded and could not find a doctor at the time .	110.89828
a sympathetic friend made poultices of raw potato parings , which she said was the best and quickest way to draw out the `` heat ' ' .	42.979874
later the doctor used mineral oil on the burns .	422.27795
the results were good , but which treatment helped is still not known .	114.222275
to stop bleeding , cobwebs were applied to cuts and wounds .	15.24397
one old-timer said to sprinkle sugar on a bleeding cut , even when on a knuckle , if it was made by a rusty tool	72.83465
this would stop the flow and also prevent infection .	42.886723
my lawyer told me that his mother used a similar remedy for cuts and wounds	58.436363
she sprinkled common sugar directly on the injury and then bound it loosely with cotton cloth , over which she poured turpentine .	85.51945
he showed me one of his fingers which had been practically amputated and which his mother had treated	115.80446
a `` chaw ' ' of tobacco put on an open wound was both antiseptic and healing .	75.04987
or a thin slice of plug tobacco might be laid on the open wound without chewing .	89.07822
one old man told me that when he was a boy he was kicked in the head by a fractious mule and had his scalp laid back from the entire front of his head .	121.038795
his brother ran a mile to get the father	33229.137
when they reached the boy , the father sliced a new plug of tobacco , put the scalp back in place , and covered the raw edges with the slices .	198.23535
then he put a rag around the dressing to keep it in place .	52.68714
there was no cleaning or further care , but the wound healed in less than two weeks and showed no scar .	64.07802
veronica from the herb garden was also used to stop bleeding , and rue was an antiseptic .	106.10642
until quite recently , `` sterile ' ' maggots could be bought to apply to a wound	196.25731
they would feed on its surface , leaving it clean so that it could be medically treated .	67.2675
tetanus could be avoided by pouring warm turpentine over a wound .	76.792015
one family bound wounds with bacon or salt pork strips , or , if these were not handy , plain lard .	44.99127
another sprinkled sugar on hot coals and held the wounded foot or hand in the smoke .	61.52103
rabies were cured or prevented by `` madstones ' ' which the pioneer wore or carried .	103.13544
in 1872 there were known to be twenty-two in norton county , and one had been in the family for 200 years .	81.75439
another cure for hydrophobia was to suck the wounds , then cauterize them with a hot knife or poker .	58.995304
while nowadays we recognize the fact that there are many causes for bleeding at the nose , not long ago a nosebleed was simply that , and treatment had little variation .	97.55378
since a fall or blow might have caused it , a cold pack was usually first aid .	99.311165
this might be applied to the top of the nose or the back of the neck , pressed on the upper lip , or inserted into the nostril ( cotton was usually used in this last ) .	64.84362
nosebleed could be stopped by wrapping a red woolen string about the patient ' s neck and tying it in a knot for each year of his life .	56.41566
or the victim could chew hard on a piece of paper , meanwhile pressing his fingers tight in his ears .	46.804726
old sores could be healed by the constant application of a wash made of equal parts vinegar and water .	103.07359
blood blisters could be prevented from forming by rubbing a work blister immediately with any hard nonpoisonous substance .	350.85718
felons were cured by taking common salt and drying it in the oven , pounding it fine , and mixing it with equal parts of spirits of turpentine	82.07158
this mixture was then spread on a cloth and wrapped around the affected part .	85.79409
as the cloth dried , more of the mixture was applied , and after twenty-four hours the felon was supposed to be `` killed ' ' .	57.026695
`` get a bite , spit on it ' ' was a proverb .	27.042843
yellow clay was used as a poultice for insect bites and also for swellings	174.51083
not long ago `` denver mud ' ' was most popular .	117.0753
chiggers were a common pest along streams and where gardens and berries thrived	48.687134
so small as to be scarcely visible to the eye , they buried themselves in the victim ' s flesh .	78.391266
bathing the itching parts with kerosene gave relief and also killed the pests .	96.67206
ant bites were eased by applying liquid bluing .	29.322683
for mosquito bites a paste of half a glass of salt and half a glass of soda was made .	52.910583
for wasp stings onion juice , obtained by scraping an onion , gave quick relief .	129.72588
a handier remedy was to bathe the painful part in strong soapy water	654.42163
mud was sometimes used as well as soap .	9.814948
just plain old black dirt was also used as a pack to relieve wasp or bee stings .	33.7336
to keep them out of homes , even in the 1900 ' s , was a chore .	42.926754
bed slats were washed in alum water , legs of beds were placed in cups of kerosene , and all woodwork was treated liberally with corrosive sublimate , applied with a feather .	113.97646
kerosene was very effective in ridding pioneer homes of the pests .	50.561764
at times pioneer children got lice in their hair .	24.980661
a kerosene shampoo seems a heroic treatment , but it did the job .	29.568686
to remove an insect from one ' s ear warm water should be inserted .	294.6746
a cinder or other small object could be removed from the eye by placing a flaxseed in the eye .	27.703922
as the seed swelled its glutinous covering protected the eyeball from irritation , and both the cinder and the seed could soon be washed out .	121.47023
another way to remove small objects from the eye was to have the person look cross-eyed	547.8412
the particle would then move toward the nose , where it could be wiped out with a wisp of cotton .	52.26085
shingles were cured by gentian , an old drug , used in combinations .	127.66766
for erysipelas a mixture of one dram borax and one ounce glycerine was applied to the afflicted part on linen cloth .	113.78641
itching skin , considered `` just nerves ' ' , was eased by treating with whiskey and salt .	67.208
winter itch was treated by applying strong apple cider in which pulverized bloodroot had been steeped .	70.06851
to cure fungus growths on mouth or hands people made a strong tea by using a handful of sassafras bark in a quart of water .	129.8631
they drank half a cup of this morning and night , and they also washed and soaked their hands in the same solution .	73.45366
six treatments cured one case which lasted a month and had defied other remedies .	179.30057
frostbite was treated by putting the feet and hands in ice water or by rubbing them with snow .	366.0202
now one hears that heat and hot water are used instead .	82.899635
another remedy was oil of eucalyptus , used as well for chilblains .	57.086823
chilblains were also treated with tincture of capsicum or cabbage leaves .	181.99419
boils have always been a source of much trouble .	38.22555
a german informant gave me a sure cure made by combining rye flour and molasses into a poultice .	259.64075
another poultice was made from the inner bark of the elm tree , steeped in water until it formed a sticky , gummy solution .	155.59203
another frequent pioneer difficulty , caused by wearing rough and heavy shoes and boots , was corns .	144.19872
one veracious woman tells me she has used thin potato parings for both corns and calluses on her feet and they remove the pain or `` fire ' ' .	55.342716
another common cure was to soak the feet five or ten minutes in warm water , then to apply a solution of equal parts of soda and common brown soap on a kid bandage overnight .	69.15838
this softened the skin so that in the morning when the bandage was removed the corn could be scraped off and a bit of corn plaster put on .	113.78293
one young girl told me how her mother removed a wart from her finger by soaking a copper penny in vinegar for three days and then painting the finger with the liquid several times .	62.85671
another wart removal method was to rub each wart with a bean split open and then to bury the bean halves under the drip of the house for seven days .	165.69652
saliva gathered in the mouth after a night ' s sleep was considered poisonous	133.14783
wetting a wart with this saliva on wakening the first thing in the morning was supposed to cause it to disappear after only a few treatments , and strangely enough many warts did just that .	180.00816
one wart cure was to wrap it in a hair from a blonde gypsy .	62.169926
another was to soak raw beef in vinegar for twenty-four hours , tie it on the wart , and wear it for a week .	67.03382
a simpler method was to tie a thread tightly around the wart at its base and wear it this way .	98.85368
one person recommended to me washing the wart with sulphur water	274.2251
another said it should be rubbed with a cut potato three times daily .	226.09348
another common method was to cut an onion in two and place each half on the wart for a moment	116.68529
the onion was then fastened together with string and placed beneath a dripping eave .	136.34213
as the onion decayed , so did the wart .	80.09142
sore feet by calf ' s-foot , an herb from the pioneer ' s ubiquitous herb garden , or by soaking the feet in a pan of hot water in which two cups of salt had been dissolved .	91.289185
leg cramps , one person tells me , were relieved by standing barefoot with the weight of the body on the heel and pressing down hard .	60.49259
this does give relief , as i can testify .	7.302054
one doctor prescribed a tablespoon of whiskey or brandy before each meal for leg cramps .	90.467705
pains in the back of the leg and in the abdomen were prevented from reaching the upper body by tying a rope about the patient ' s waist .	42.734997
for sprains and swellings , one pint of cider vinegar and half a pint of spirits of turpentine added to three well beaten eggs was said to give speedy relief .	151.93073
except for the wine waiter in a restaurant -- always an inscrutable plenipotentiary unto himself , the genii with the keys to unlock the gates of the wine world are one ' s dealer , and the foreign shipper or negociant who in turn supplies him .	170.60085
in instances where both of these are persons or firms with integrity , the situation is ideal .	170.33641
it may , on occasion , be anything but that .	95.91476
however , by cultivating a wine dealer and accepting his advice , one will soon enough ascertain whether he has any knowledge of wines ( as opposed to what he may have been told by salesmen and promoters ) and , better yet , whether he has a taste for wine .	144.02356
again , by spreading one ' s purchases over several wine dealers , one becomes familiar with the names and specialties of reputable wine dealers and shippers abroad .	116.82636
this is important because , despite all the efforts of the french government , an appreciable segment of france ' s export trade in wines is still tainted with a misrepresentation approaching downright dishonesty , and there are many too many negociants who would rather turn a sou than amass a creditable reputation overseas .	116.10252
a good negociant or shipper will not only be the man or the firm which has cornered the wines from the best vineyards , or the best parts of them	187.61171
he may also be the one who makes and bottles the best blends -- sound wines from vineyards generally in his own district .	253.31181
these are the wines the french themselves use for everyday drinking , for even in france virtually no one drinks the grands crus on a meal-to-meal basis .	70.36819
the grands crus are expensive , and even doting palates tire of them .	70.98264
and certainly , in the case of the beginner or the comparatively uninitiated wine drinker , the palate and the capacity for appreciation will not be ready for the grands crus as a steady diet without frequent recourse to crus of less renown .	124.0159
there is nothing infra dig about a good blend from a good shipper .	94.26717
some of them are very delicious indeed , and there are many good ones exported -- unfortunately , along with others not so good , and worse .	92.44181
consultation with a reputable wine dealer and constant experimentation -- `` steering ever from the known to the unknown ' ' -- are the requisites .	205.65422
especially if one is travelling or dining out a great deal , their importance mounts .	111.84809
most of them , the world over , operate on the same principle by which justice is administered in france and some other latin countries the customer is to be considered guilty of abysmal ignorance until proven otherwise , with the burden of proof on the customer himself .	165.11841
now the drinking of wine ( and happily so ! !	101.39974
) is for the most part a recondite affair , for manifestly , if everyone in the world who could afford the best wines also liked them , the supply would dry up in no time at all .	94.89939
this is the only valid , and extenuating , argument that may be advanced in defense of the reprehensible attitude of the common wine waiter .	100.54345
a really good wine waiter is , paradoxically , the guardian ( and not the purveyor ) of his cellar against the visigoths .	183.586
faced , on the one hand , with an always exhaustible supply of his best wines , and on the other by a clientele usually equipped with inexhaustible pocketbooks , it is a wonder indeed that all wine waiters are not afflicted with chronic ambivalence .	98.2876
the one way to get around them -- short of knowing exactly what one wants and sticking to it -- is to frequent a single establishment until its wine waiter is persuaded that one is at least as interested in wine as in spending money .	243.996
only then , perhaps , will he reveal his jewels and his bargains .	181.74512
wine bought from a dealer should ideally be allowed to rest for several weeks before it is served .	91.73882
this is especially true of red wines , and a practice which , though not always practicable , is well worth the effort .	114.19248
it does no harm for wine to stand on end for a matter of days , but in terms of months and years it is fatal .	98.23343
wine stored for a long time should be on its side	85.293465
otherwise , the cork dries and air enters to spoil it .	49.591457
when stacking wine on its side in a bin , care should always be taken to be sure there is no air bubble left next to the cork .	107.478714
fat bottles , such as burgundies , have a way of rolling around in the bin and often need little props , such as a bit of cardboard or a chip of wood , to hold them in the proper reclining posture .	100.67918
too much dampness in the cellar rots the corks , again with ill effects .	835.26245
the best rule of thumb for detecting corked wine ( provided the eye has not already spotted it ) is to smell the wet end of the cork after pulling it if it smells of wine , the bottle is probably all right	252.27348
if it smells of cork , one has grounds for suspicion .	90.77139
seasonal rises or drops in temperature are bad for wine they age it prematurely .	339.29404
the ideal storage temperature for long periods is about fifty-five degrees , with an allowable range of five degrees above or below this , provided there are no sudden or frequent changes .	125.35032
consequently , one ' s wine closet or cellar should be away from machines or electrically driven furnaces .	163.33228
if one lives near a subway or an express parkway , the solution is to have one ' s wines stored with a dealer and brought home a few at a time .	73.01167
light , especially daylight , is always bad for wine .	34.68935
all in all , though , there is a good deal of nonsense expended over the preparations thought necessary for ordinary wine drinking	177.43903
many people go to extreme lengths in decanting , chilling or warming , or banishing without further investigation any bottle with so much as a slightly suspicious cork .	162.69409
no one should wish to deny these purists the obvious pleasure they derive from all this , and to give fair warning where warning is due , no one who becomes fond of wines ever avoids acquiring some degree of purism ! !	223.17593
but the fact remains that in most restaurants , including some of the best of paris and bordeaux and dijon , the bottle is frankly and simply brought from the cellar to the table when ordered , and all the conditioning or preparation it ever receives takes place while the chef is preparing the meal .	133.20155
a white wine , already at cool cellar temperature , may be adequately chilled in a bucket of ice and water or the freezing compartment of a refrigerator ( the former is far preferable ) in about fifteen minutes	73.574066
for those who live in a winter climate , there is nothing better than a bucket of water and snow .	44.45096
though by no means an ideal procedure , a red wine may similarly be brought from the cellar to the dining room and opened twenty minutes or so before serving time .	120.372116
but again , as one will have observed at any restaurant worth its salt , wine should be served in a large , tulip-shaped glass , which is never filled more than half full .	112.53
in this way , red wine warms of itself quite rapidly -- and though it is true that it may not attain its potential of taste and fragrance until after the middle of the meal ( or the course ) , in the meantime it will have run the gamut of many beguiling and interesting stages .	95.70725
the only cardinal sin which may be committed in warming a wine is to force it by putting it next to the stove or in front of an open fire .	155.02911
this invariably effaces any wine ' s character , and drives its fragrance underground .	70.08526
it should not be forgotten that wines mature fastest in half-bottles , less fast in full bottles , slowly in magnums -- and slower yet in tregnums , double magnums , jeroboams , methuselahs , and imperiales , respectively .	125.41567
very old red wines often require several hours of aeration , and any red wine , brought from the cellar within half an hour of mealtime , should be uncorked and allowed some air .	85.19729
white wines should be opened when served , having been previously chilled in proportion to their sweetness .	82.25987
thus , sauternes or barsacs should be very cold	148.14307
a pouilly-fuisse or a chablis somewhat less cold .	10.08446
over-chilling is an accepted method for covering up the faults of many a cheap or poor white wine , especially a dry wine -- and certainly less of a crime than serving a wine at a temperature which reveals it as unattractive .	146.32362
the fragrance and taste of any white wine will die a lingering death when it is allowed to warm or is exposed for long to the air .	167.89162
to quote professor saintsbury `` the last glass of claret or burgundy is as good as the first	75.363266
but the first glass of chateau d ' yquem or montrachet is a great deal better than the last ' ' ! !	76.50796
this does not mean , though , that a red wine improves with prolonged aeration there is a reasonable limit -- and wines kept over to the next meal or the next day , after they have once been opened , are never as good .	162.94075
if this must be done , they should always be corked and kept in a cool place	134.88014
it should be remembered that their lasting qualities are appreciably shorter than those of milk .	36.28931
a few red wines , notably those of the beaujolais , are better consumed at cellar temperature .	194.80644
by tradition , a red wine should be served at approximately room temperature -- if anything a little cooler -- and be aged enough for the tannin and acids to have worked out and the sediment have settled well .	215.00827
thus , red wine must , if possible , never be disturbed or shaken	286.5424
very old red wine is often decanted so that the puckering , bitter elements which have settled to the bottom will not be mingled with the wine itself .	113.41464
a tug-of-war between an old bottle and an inefficient corkscrew may do as much harm as a week at sea .	105.741394
the cork should be pulled gradually and smoothly , and the lip of the bottle wiped afterward .	46.52537
many people use wicker cradles for old red wine , lifting the bottle carefully from the bin into the cradle and eventually to the table , without disturbing the sediment .	81.2859
another school frowns on such a shortcut , and insists that after leaving the bin an old red wine should first stand on end for several days to allow the sediment to roll to the very bottom , after which the bottle may be gently eased to a tilted position on its side in the cradle .	131.5821
in france , when one wishes to entertain at a restaurant and serve truly fine old red wines , one visits the restaurant well ahead of time , chooses the wines and , with the advice of the manager and his chef , builds the menu around them .	115.268524
the wine waiter will see to it that the bottles are taken from the bin and opened at least in time to warm and aerate , preferably allowed to stand on end for as long as possible and , perhaps in the case of very old wines , be decanted .	77.55427
it may also be -- practically speaking -- a matter of good economy .	88.70758
for , in the process of decanting , the bottle is only tilted once instead of several or more times at the table hence , a minimum of the undesirable mixture of wine and dregs .	120.42218
though there are many exceptions , which we have noted in preceding pages , white wine is as a rule best consumed between two and six years old , and red wines , nowadays , between three and ten .	126.09777
red wines of good years tend to mature later and to keep longer	250.32053
the average claret is notably longer-lived than its opposite number , red burgundy .	860.7884
some clarets do not come into their own until they are ten or fifteen years of age , or even more .	80.561424
if a red bordeaux of a good name and year is bitter or acid , or cloying and muddy-tasting , leave it alone for a while .	174.82608
most of the wines of beaujolais , on the other hand , should be drunk while very young	87.606865
giffen replied punctually and enthusiastically `` rest assured that your accompanying letter of instructions shall be in the letter and spirit strictly complied with and most particularly in regard to that part of them relative to the completion of your noble and humane views ' ' .	148.7321
giffen lost no time in visiting the plantation .	6.1506767
the slaves appeared to be in good health and at work under john palfrey ' s overseer .	122.51322
william , who lived in neighboring st . mary ' s parish , had taken charge and decided that it would be best for all if the plantation were operated for another year .	68.88491
giffen advised acceptance of this plan , citing the depressed market for land then prevailing and the large stock of provisions at the plantation .	254.35176
if sold then , the land and improvements might bring only $5 , 000 .	64.0992
early in january , 1844 he had a conference with henry and william in new orleans , and upon learning of gorham ' s intention , henry remonstrated calmly but firmly with his brother .	162.84366
the emancipation plan would not only be injurious to all the heirs , he contended , but would be a form of cruelty perpetrated on the hapless negroes .	73.42774
they were not capable of supporting themselves off the plantation , and louisiana law required their removal from the state .	78.422485
gorham refused to accept money for slave property , but did he realize how much expense and trouble the transportation of his negroes to the north involved ? ?	108.80638
the suggestion that giffen hire out the slaves was not realistic , since no planter would take the risk of having negroes who knew they were to be free living with his own slaves .	65.53359
henry hid his annoyance , although both he and william were furious with their yankee brother .	348.15402
william , who did not write to gorham , told giffen that unless he could operate the plantation as usual for a year , he would sue `` amicably ' ' to protect his interests .	91.95645
palfrey was determined that his portion of the slaves be converted to wage laborers during the transition period before emancipation .	169.86427
if william wished to continue operations for a year , why not simply leave the negroes undisturbed and pay them `` as high wages to remain there as are ever paid the labor of persons of their sex & age .	180.02945
a disposition to exert themselves for my benefit would perhaps be a motive with some of them to come into the scheme .	67.783714
their having family ties on our plantation & the adjoining one would be a stronger inducement ' ' .	89.48235
when he heard of his brothers ' anger , palfrey was still hopeful that they could be persuaded to accept his notion of paying wages .	54.71209
if not , he was willing to accede to william ' s wishes in any way that did not block his ultimate aim .	117.204384
william was adamant on one point under no circumstances would he allow the negroes to remain on the plantation with his and henry ' s slaves if they were told of their coming freedom .	124.823166
knowing the antipathy that existed in louisiana against increasing the number of free negroes , giffen suggested that palfrey bring them to boston at once , and then send them on to liberia .	74.097145
lacking specific instructions , he agreed to william ' s condition .	35.71419
in march there was a division of the slaves , and giffen carried out his instructions as nearly as possible .	125.357544
of the fifty-two slaves , giffen succeeded in getting a lot of twenty , twelve of whom were females .	122.80326
`` i considered that your views would be best carried out ' ' , he explained , `` by taking women whose progeny will of course be free & more fully extend the philantrophy of emancipation .	168.08867
i have also taken the old servants of your father as a matter of conscience & justice ' ' .	70.1525
the ages of the slaves ranged from sixty-five , for an old house servant , to an unnamed newborn child .	61.376633
if palfrey ever had any doubts about the wickedness of slavery , they were put aside after he received an inventory of the slave property he had inherited .	95.83493
this cold reckoning of human worth in a legal paper , devoid of compassion or humanity , was all he needed .	126.46907
each human being , known only by a given name , had a cash value .	258.97626
old sam ' s sixty-five years had reduced his value to $150	216.08551
rose , a twelve-year-old with child-bearing potential , was worth $400 .	75.198784
in rejecting any claim to the value of the slave property , palfrey was giving up close to $7 , 000 .	75.595375
palfrey ' s brothers each received lots of sixteen negroes , and for bookkeeping purposes it was agreed that all lots were to be valued at $6 , 666 . 66 .	108.07022
thus twenty `` black souls ' ' were to remain ignorant of their imminent journey to the land of free men .	68.07832
giffen extracted one concession from william the house servants could be free at any time gorham thought expedient .	52.365696
despite giffen ' s warning , palfrey still had plans for freeing his slaves in louisiana .	104.60484
yet even if he could get the necessary approval , fourteen of his negroes could not be manumitted without special permission .	206.44061
according to state law a slave had to be at least thirty years old before he could be freed .	51.876587
palfrey petitioned the state legislature to waive the requirement .	65.22701
otherwise , freedom would mean removal from the state in which `` as the place of their past residence from birth , or for many years , it would be materially for their advantage to be at liberty to remain ' ' .	70.2203
on march 11 the louisiana legislature voted unanimously to table the petition .	167.11304
news of the legislative veto appeared in the new orleans papers , and henry and william became incensed by the fact that they had not been told of the attempt in advance .	64.73376
henry stormed into giffen ' s office waving a copy of the new orleans courier , shouting that the emancipation scheme had become a public affair , and that it would reach the `` ears of the people on the plantation , and make them restless & unhappy ' ' .	60.14208
his brothers ' anger caused palfrey genuine concern , for he had imposed a dual mission upon himself to free his slaves , and to keep the family from falling apart over the issue .	83.901024
when giffen decided to charge him interest on the loan from john palfrey , gorham readily assented , vowing that in a matter of dollars and cents , his brothers would never have any cause to complain of him .	99.37986
in view of these difficulties , palfrey decided to go to louisiana .	48.370323
giffen had already urged him to journey south , if only for a few days to clear up matters .	197.91742
his duties as massachusetts secretary of state obliged him to wait until the adjournment of the legislature in mid-april .	57.801846
palfrey told his wife of his intentions for the first time , and left for new orleans apprehensively invoking a special blessing of providence that he might be allowed to see his family again .	76.737404
during his journey palfrey stopped off to see two abolitionists .	258.83676
in both cases he desired information about placing the freedmen in homes once they arrived in the north .	140.64975
in new york , lydia maria child welcomed him enthusiastically `` i have lately heard of you from the legislature of louisiana , and felt joy at your public recognition of the brotherhood of man ' ' .	83.53788
mrs . child , who had once apologized for sending editor palfrey a book on slavery , now confided that she had helped one of henry palfrey ' s slaves escape to canada some years before , but asked him not to advertise the fact in louisiana .	208.33206
she agreed to take charge of five or six of the negroes should palfrey decide to send them north immediately .	143.67615
at lexington , kentucky , palfrey consulted with cassius m . clay on the same subject , but with no apparent result .	124.78079
despite his apprehensions about his personal safety , palfrey ' s reception in new orleans was more than cordial .	89.08756
instead of the expected `` annoyances ' ' due to the nature of his mission , he received many calling cards and invitations from `` gentlemen of mark , on whom i had no sort of claim , & have had many more invitations than i could accept ' ' .	157.98882
he later told abolitionist edmund quincy of the `` marked attention and civility ' ' with which the new orleans gentlemen and the upriver planters greeted him .	103.72832
the memory of this southern hospitality did not survive the trials of coming antislavery years and civil war .	278.67957
palfrey ' s autobiography contains a melodramatic account of two perilous days spent among the planters of attakapas , `` many of whom were coarse & passionate people , much excited by what they heard of my plans ' ' .	114.372536
he proceeded with his task bravely -- in his memoirs , at least -- before the `` passions of my neighbors should have time to boil too high ' ' .	46.813824
palfrey had already made up his mind that he would allow the men , but not the women , to choose freely whether or not to go north for freedom .	111.50016
the women by remaining behind condemned their children , born and unborn , to bondage .	61.293804
he had a short private talk with each adult slave .	50.48414
only one objected , but palfrey soon convinced him that he ought to go with the others .	52.055607
all the slaves joined in requesting that they be allowed to delay their departure until the end of the planting season , so that they could get in `` their own little produce ' ' .	46.629814
the slaves were to remain as wage laborers for his account .	54.101006
william ' s threat that under no conditions would he allow `` freedom-conscious ' ' slaves to mix with his own was not carried out , for the plantation continued in operation as before .	101.123116
palfrey returned to massachusetts greatly relieved to have made an arrangement `` so satisfactory to my judgment & my conscience ' ' .	173.17194
from cambridge , palfrey maintained a close interest in the welfare of his slaves .	22.782469
in fact , as the time for their departure approached , his solicitousness increased .	117.28523
should any slave change his mind and request to leave earlier , giffen was to provide passage at once .	273.59268
when a sailing date of march , 1845 was finally established , palfrey made sure that the negroes would have comfortable quarters in new orleans and aboard ship .	130.83308
giffen assured him that the captain and his mate had personally promised to treat the negroes with consideration .	211.63016
palfrey was also concerned about the question of what wage to pay for their labor throughout 1844 .	158.40923
the plantation was sold in january , 1845 , and palfrey thought the new owner ought to pay his people two months ' wages .	118.16933
giffen suggested fifty dollars as fair compensation for a year ' s work	27.748291
the new owner at attakapas declined to enter into any philanthropic arrangement .	223.96109
on march 21 , 1845 the bark bashaw weighed anchor at new orleans , while on the levee henry and william palfrey waved farewell to their father ' s former chattels who must have looked back at the receding shore with mingled regret and jubilation .	92.34846
not all of palfrey ' s slaves were aboard the bashaw .	78.854004
giffen had advised that it would not be too difficult to obtain freedom locally for the old house servants .	58.888954
two of these were included in palfrey ' s lot .	59.336483
giffen filed a petition for permission to emancipate four slaves ( all more than fifty years old ) with the st . martin ' s parish police jury .	90.67847
after an initial rejection , which he attributed to a `` general excitement against abolition and emancipation ' ' , giffen bribed the right individuals on the jury , and got the permission without further delay .	89.80714
when the negroes landed at boston a month later they were , of course , no longer slaves .	47.370247
slavery was prohibited in massachusetts by the terms of the constitution of 1780 , which declared `` all men are born free and equal ' ' .	55.007793
nevertheless , palfrey arranged a religious ceremony at king ' s chapel to formalize the emancipation .	75.45474
an eyewitness recalled how awkward the red-turbaned colored women appeared as they curtseyed in the church doorway , and the diffidence the former slaves displayed while they listened to the few words that declared them free .	199.3599
once the question of emancipation was settled to palfrey ' s satisfaction , he faced a real problem in placing the freedmen in suitable homes as servants .	94.59634
palfrey tried fruitlessly to place a negro boy in the hopedale community , but he had better luck in his other attempts .	99.31017
mrs . child , true to her word , helped place anna and her four children with a quaker family named hathaway near canandaigua , new york .	128.56233
this group had been palfrey ' s greatest worry since anna was in bad health , and her children were too young to work for their keep .	88.8413
but certainly the new frontier has brought to washington a group more varied in background and interest .	270.1515
secretary of state dean rusk , a former rhodes scholar and mills college dean , has headed the rockefeller foundation and in that role expended large sums for international cultural exchange .	105.64523
one of his initial acts in office was to appoint philip coombs of the ford foundation as the first assistant secretary of state for educational and cultural affairs .	40.565495
( `` in the late forties and fifties ' ' , coombs has declared in defining his role , `` two strong new arms were added to reinforce united states foreign policy economic assistance and military assistance .	124.799416
as we embark upon the sixties we have an opportunity to build a third strong arm , aimed at the development of people , at the fuller realization of their creative human potential , and a better understanding among them ' ' .	74.39609
many of the new appointees are art collectors .	8.550452
ambassador-at-large averell harriman has returned to the capital with a collection of paintings that include renoir , cezanne , gauguin , van gogh , toulouse-lautrec , degas , matisse , picasso , and walt kuhn .	33.222702
the director of the peace corps , r . sargent shriver , jr . , a kennedy brother-in-law , collects heavily among the moderns , including kenzo okada and josef albers .	31.775835
secretary of the treasury douglas dillon owns a prize monet , femmes dans un jardin .	22.800734
secretary of defense robert mcnamara , former president of the ford motor company , comes from a generation different from that of eisenhower ' s own first secretary of defense , charles wilson , who had been head of general motors .	73.83256
unlike wilson , who at times seemed almost anti-intellectual in his earthy pragmatism .	75.449745
an inveterate reader of books , he chose while working in detroit to live in the university community of ann arbor , almost forty miles away .	74.921364
he selected as comptroller of defense , not a veteran accountant , but a former rhodes scholar , charles hitch , who is author of a study on the economics of defense in the nuclear age .	58.94801
one of the president ' s special assistants , the harvard dean mcgeorge bundy , was co-author with henry l . stimson of the latter ' s classic memoir , on active service .	99.39734
another , arthur m . schlesinger , jr . , has won a pulitzer prize in history	28.47332
his wife , marion , is a portrait painter .	5.150361
the press secretary , pierre salinger , was a child prodigy as a pianist .	100.98443
( `` it is always of sorrow to me when i find people who neither know nor understand music ' ' , he declared not long ago in proposing that white house prizes be awarded for music and art .	187.31012
) mrs . arthur goldberg , wife of the secretary of labor , paints professionally and helps sponsor the associated artists ' gallery in the district of columbia .	99.31699
( `` artists are always at a new frontier ' ' , she claims .	40.910362
`` in fact , the search is almost more important than the find ' ' .	31.825548
) mrs . henry labouisse , wife of the new director of the foreign aid program , is the writer and lecturer eve curie .	61.470005
at last count , sixteen former rhodes scholars ( see box on page 13 ) had been appointed to the administration , second in number only to its harvard graduates .	216.93497
besides schlesinger , the justice department ' s information director , edwin guthman , has won a pulitzer prize ( for national reporting ) .	64.7566
postmaster general j . edward day , who must deal with matters of postal censorship , is himself author of a novel , bartholf street , albeit one he was obliged to publish at his own expense .	146.27827
william walton , a writer-turned-painter , has been a long-time friend of the president .	47.607456
they arrived in washington about the same time during the early postwar years kennedy as the young congressman from massachusetts	144.61952
walton , after a wartime stint with time-life , to become bureau chief for the new republic .	99.56532
both lived in georgetown , were unattached , and shared an active social life .	216.39474
walton , who soon made a break from journalism to become one of the capital ' s leading semi-abstract painters , vows that he and kennedy never once discussed art in those days .	186.05899
during last year ' s campaign , kennedy asked walton , an utter novice in organization politics , to assist him .	121.6986
walton dropped everything to serve as a district co-ordinator in the hard-fought wisconsin primary and proved so useful that he was promoted to be liaison officer to critically important new york city .	106.43666
walton , who served as a correspondent with general james gavin ' s paratroopers during the invasion of france , combines the soul of an artist with the lingo of a tough guy .	85.81696
he provoked outraged editorials when , after a post-inaugural inspection of the white house with mrs . kennedy , he remarked to reporters , `` we just cased the joint to see what was there ' ' .	129.0806
already the president and the first lady have deputized him to advise on matters ranging from the furnishing of the white house to the renovation of lafayette square .	52.253334
a man of great talent , he will continue to serve as a sort of presidential trouble-shooter , strictly ex officio , for culture .	69.025665
a more official representative is the secretary of the interior .	5.7834673
udall , who comes from one of the mormon first-families of arizona , is a bluff , plain-spoken man with a lust for politics and a habit of landing right in the middle of the fight .	87.73164
but even while sparring furiously with republican politicians , he displays a deep and awesome veneration for anyone with cultural attainments .	228.07643
his private dining room has become a way station for visiting intellectuals such as c . p . snow , arnold toynbee , and aaron copland .	62.53852
udall argues that interior affairs should cover a great deal more than dams and wildlife preserves .	60.876984
after promoting frost ' s appearance at the inauguration , he persuaded the poet to return several months later to give a reading to a select audience of cabinet members , members of congress , and other washington notables gathered in the state department auditorium .	113.905556
the event was so successful that the interior secretary plans to serve as impresario for similar ones from time to time , hoping thereby to add to the cultural enrichment of the administration .	123.116646
his ideas in this respect , however , sometimes arouse critical response .	116.37274
one tempest was stirred up last march when udall announced that an eight-and-a-half-foot bronze statue of william jennings bryan , sculpted by the late gutzon borglum , would be sent `` on indefinite loan ' ' to salem , illinois , bryan ' s birthplace .	102.05025
spokesmen for the nation ' s tradition-minded sculptors promptly claimed that udall was exiling the statue because of his own hostility to this art form .	225.22102
they dug up a speech he had made two years earlier as a congressman , decrying the more than two hundred statues , monuments , and memorials which `` dot the washington landscape as patriotic societies and zealous friends are constantly hatching new plans ' ' .	118.08489
hoping to cut down on such works , udall had proposed that a politician be at least fifty years departed before he is memorialized .	283.1899
he is not likely to win this battle easily .	1108.3839
in the case of the borglum statue an interior aide was obliged to announce that there had been a misunderstanding and that the secretary had no desire to `` hustle ' ' it out of washington .	85.060936
the last congress adopted seven bills for memorials , including one to taras shevchenko , the ukrainian poet laureate	51.6431
active warfare is raging between the forces pressing for a monument to the first roosevelt on theodore roosevelt island in the potomac , and tr . ' s own living children , who wish to preserve the island as a wildlife sanctuary .	74.762344
the hotly debated plan for the capital ' s franklin d . roosevelt memorial , a circle of huge tablets engraved with his speeches ( and promptly dubbed by one of its critics , `` instant stonehenge ' ' ) , is another of udall ' s headaches , since as supervisor of the national parks commission he will share in the responsibility for building it .	66.25832
`` washington ' ' , president kennedy has been heard to remark ironically , `` is a city of southern efficiency and northern charm ' ' .	83.96438
there have been indications that he hopes to redress that situation , commencing with the white house .	81.957504
one of mrs . kennedy ' s initial concerns as first lady was the sad state of the furnishings in a building which is supposed to be a national shrine .	114.35372
ever since the fire of 1812 destroyed the beautiful furniture assembled by president thomas jefferson , the white house has collected a hodgepodge of period pieces , few of them authentic or aesthetic .	140.6674
mrs . kennedy shows a determination to change all this .	137.87253
not long after moving in she turned up a richly carved desk , hewed from the timbers of the british ship h . m . s . resolute and presented to president hayes by queen victoria .	76.172226
it now serves the president in his oval office .	39.822906
later , browsing in an old issue of the gazette des beaux-arts , she found a description of a handsome gilt pier-table purchased in 1817 by president james monroe .	61.91568
with its coating of gold radiator paint removed -- a gaucherie of some earlier tenant -- it will now occupy its rightful place in the oval blue room on the first floor of the white house .	95.04291
but it soon became clear that the search for eighteenth-century furniture ( which mrs . kennedy feels is the proper period for the white house ) must be pursued in places other than government storage rooms .	206.74709
the first lady appointed a fine arts advisory committee for the white house , to locate authentic pieces as well as to arrange ways to acquire them .	62.994915
her effort to put the home of living presidents on the same basis as mount vernon and monticello recognizes no party lines .	211.02385
by rough estimate her committee , headed by henry francis du pont , contains three times as many republicans as democrats .	131.6696
the press releases emanating from the white house give a clue to the activity within .	107.76866
a valuable pencil-and-sepia allegorical drawing of benjamin franklin by jean-honore fragonard has been donated by the art dealer georges wildenstein and now hangs in the blue room .	143.06776
the american institute of interior designers is redecorating the white house library .	63.93512
secretary and mrs . dillon have contributed enough pieces of empire furniture , including dolley madison ' s own sofa , to furnish a room in that style .	64.44235
and part of a fabulous collection of vermeil hollowware , bequeathed to the white house by the late mrs . margaret thompson biddle , has been taken out of its locked cases and put on display in the state dining room .	71.55271
woman ' s place is in the home man must attend to matters of the yard .	173.14833
one of the vexatious problems to first confront president kennedy was the property lying just across pennsylvania avenue from the white house .	111.461716
congress had already appropriated money , and plans were well along to tear down the buildings flanking lafayette square and replace them with what one critic calls the `` marble monumentality ' ' of government office buildings .	128.72797
while a senator , kennedy had unsuccessfully pushed a bill to preserve the belasco theater , as well as the dolley madison and the benjamin taylor houses , all scheduled for razing .	63.744316
what to do about it now that he was president ? ?	77.011086
only a few days after moving into the white house .	17.101496
kennedy made a midnight inspection of the square .	4.4058876
then he called in his friend walton and turned over the problem to him , with instructions to work out what was best -- provided it didn ' t pile unnecessary burdens on the president .	75.04143
one of the offices slated for reconstruction is the aged court of claims , diagonally across the street from the white house .	83.99402
but judge marvin jones , senior member of the court , is an elderly gentleman who lives at the nearby metropolitan club and desires to walk to work .	65.01232
more importantly , he also happens to be the brother-in-law of sam rayburn , speaker of the house .	42.79505
there were aesthetic problems as well as political .	117.14802
on delving deeper , walton discovered that most of the buildings fronting the square could be classified as `` early nondescript ' ' .	48.416435
the old belasco theater , over which many people had grown sentimental , was only a shell of its former self after arduous years as a uso center .	165.01222
the dolley madison house , walton concluded , was scarcely worth preserving .	263.6567
`` the attempt to save the square ' s historic value ' ' , he declares , `` came half a century too late ' ' .	100.48967
surrounded by ancient elms , the campus is spacious and beautiful .	216.00351
the dartmouth student does not live in monastic seclusion , as he once did .	86.154724
but his is still a simple life relatively free of the female presence or influence , and he must go far , even though he may go fast , for sophisticated pleasures .	102.34107
he is still heir to the rare gifts of space and silence , if he chooses to be .	86.62094
he is by no means the country boy he might have been in the last century , down from the hills with bear grease on his hair and a zeal for book learning in his heart .	88.85401
the men ' s shops on hanover ' s main street compare favorably with those in princeton and new haven .	33.049953
and the automobiles that stream out of hanover each weekend , toward smith and wellesley and mount holyoke , are no less rakish than those leaving cambridge or west philadelphia .	202.93538
but there has always been an outdoor air to dartmouth .	69.127785
the would-be sophisticate and the citybred youth adopt this air without embarrassment .	586.1925
no one here pokes fun at manly virtues .	3.4108245
and this gives rise to an easy camaraderie probably unequaled elsewhere in the ivy league .	79.501526
thus , when dartmouth ' s winter carnival -- widely recognized as the greatest , wildest , roaringest college weekend anywhere , any time -- was broadcast over a national television hookup , prexy john sloan dickey appeared on the screen in rugged winter garb , topped off by a tam-o ' -shanter which he confessed had been acquired from a smith girl .	170.06964
president dickey ' s golden retriever , frolicking in the snow at his feet , added to the picture of masculine informality .	97.79662
this carefree disdain for `` side ' ' cropped up again in the same television broadcast .	124.13364
dean thaddeus seymour , wearing ski clothes , was crowning a beauteous damsel queen of the carnival .	155.58862
she must have looked temptingly pretty to the dean as he put the crown on her head .	185.69708
dartmouth students enjoy other unusual diversions with equal sang-froid .	26.256454
for example , groups regularly canoe down the connecticut river .	159.41316
this is in honor of john ledyard , class of 1773 , who scooped a canoe out of a handy tree and first set the course way back in his own student days .	135.11646
and these hardy travelers are not unappreciated today .	11.311008
they are hailed by the nation ' s press , and smith girls throng the riverbanks at northampton and refresh the voyageurs with hot soup and kisses .	152.85103
dartmouth ' s favorite and most characteristic recreation is skiing .	19.344852
since the days when their two thousand pairs of skis outnumbered those assembled anywhere else in the united states , the students have stopped regarding the olympic ski team as another name for their own .	94.46359
yet dartmouth still is the dominant member of the intercollegiate ski union , which includes the winter sports colleges of canada as well as those of this country .	51.240112
dartmouth students ski everywhere in winter , starting with their own front door .	68.11475
they can hire a horse and go ski-joring behind him , or move out to oak hill , where there ' s a lift .	66.619606
the dartmouth skiway , at holt ' s ledge , ten miles north of the campus , has one of the best terrains in the east , ranging from novice to expert .	104.441414
forty miles farther north is mount moosilauke , dartmouth ' s own mountain .	38.341434
here , at the ravine lodge , president dickey acts as host every year to about a hundred freshmen who are being introduced by the dartmouth outing club to life on the trails .	86.055855
the lodge , built of hand-hewn virgin spruce , can handle fifty people for dining , sleeping , or lounging in its huge living room .	174.33833
the outing club also owns a chain of fourteen cabins and several shelters , extending from the vermont hills , just across the river from the college , through hanover to the college grant -- 27 , 000 acres of wilderness 140 miles north up in the logging country .	110.43091
the cabins are equipped with bunks , blankets , and cooking equipment and are ideal bases for hikes and skiing trips .	46.99091
the club runs regular trips to the cabins , but many of the students prefer to take off in small unofficial groups for a weekend of hunting , fishing , climbing , or skiing .	47.71847
under the auspices of the outing club , dartmouth also has the mountaineering club , which takes on tough climbs like mount mckinley , and bait & bullet , whose interests are self-evident , and even sports a woodman ' s team , which competes with other new england colleges in wood sawing and chopping , canoe races , and the like .	173.89656
there is much to be said for a college that , while happily attuned to the sophisticated ivies , still gives its students a chance to get up early in the morning and drive along back roads where a glimpse of small game , deer , or even bear is not uncommon .	128.38142
city boys find a lot of learning in the feel of an ax handle or in the sharp tang of a sawmill , come upon suddenly in a backwoods logging camp .	126.7197
and on the summit of mount washington , where thirty-five degrees below zero is commonplace and the wind velocity has registered higher than anywhere else in the world , there is a kind of wisdom to be found that other men often seek in the himalayas `` because it is there ' ' .	84.477264
there is much to be said for such a college -- and dartmouth men have been accused of saying it too often and too loudly .	84.20423
their affection for their college home has even caused president dickey to comment on this `` place loyalty ' ' as something rather specially hanoverian .	204.26009
probably a lawyer once said it best for all time in the supreme court of the united states .	21.835793
early in the nineteenth century the state of new hampshire was casting about for a way to found its own state university .	96.58543
it fixed on dartmouth college , which was ready-made and just what the proctor ordered .	659.59015
the legislators decided to `` liberate ' ' dartmouth and entered into a tug-o ' -war with the college trustees over the control of classrooms , faculty , and chapel .	146.77722
for a time there were two factions on the campus fighting for possession of the student body .	60.782486
the struggle was resolved in 1819 in the supreme court in one of the most intriguing cases in our judicial history .	41.707428
in 1817 the lawyers were generally debating the legal inviolability of private contracts and charters .	58.96358
a lawyer , hired by the college , was arguing specifically for dartmouth daniel webster , class of 1801 , made her plight the dramatic focus of his whole plea .	111.65045
in an age of oratory , he was the king of orators , and both he himself and chief justice marshall were bathed in manly tears , as uncle dan ' l reached his thundering climax	201.65457
`` it is , sir , as i have said , a small college , and yet there are those who love it .	68.75332
dartmouth is today still a small college -- and still a private one , thanks to webster ' s eloquence .	86.53673
this is not out of keeping with its origins , probably the most humble of any in the ivy group .	107.56151
eleazar wheelock , a presbyterian minister , founded the school in 1769 , naming it after the second earl of dartmouth , its sponsor and benefactor .	171.41954
eleazar , pausing on the hanover plain , found its great forests and remoteness good and with his own hands built the first college hall , a log hut dedicated `` for the education & instruction of youth of the indian tribes in this land in reading , writing & all parts of learning which shall appear necessary and expedient for civilizing & christianizing children of pagans as well as in all liberal arts and sciences	225.8646
and also of english youth and any others ' ' .	8.094484
it was a hardy undertaking , and wheelock ' s was indeed `` a voice crying in the wilderness ' ' .	36.084644
a road had to be hacked through trackless forests between hanover and portsmouth to permit governor wentworth and a company of gentlemen to attend the first dartmouth commencement in 1771 .	120.777565
the governor and his retinue thoughtfully brought with them a glorious silver punchbowl which is still one of the cherished possessions of the college .	62.52558
the exuberance on this occasion set a standard for subsequent dartmouth gatherings .	205.38687
a student orator `` produced tears from a great number of the learned ' ' even before the punch was served .	64.695526
then from the branches of a near-by tree an indian underclassman , disdaining both the platform and the english language , harangued the assemblage in his aboriginal tongue .	122.09304
governor wentworth contributed an ox for a barbecue on the green beneath the three-hundred-foot pines , and a barrel of rum was broached .	143.9256
the cook got drunk , and president wheelock proved to be a man of broad talents by carving the ox himself .	186.48683
future commencements were more decorous perhaps , but the number of graduates increased from the original four at a relatively slow pace .	154.32402
by the end of the nineteenth century , in 1893 , when the big three , columbia , and penn were populous centers of learning , dartmouth graduated only sixty-nine .	216.88315
the dormitories , including the beloved dartmouth hall , could barely house two hundred students in spartan fashion .	176.98795
then in 1893 dr . william jewett tucker became president and the college ' s great awakening began .	62.540012
he transformed dartmouth from a small new hampshire institution into a national college .	92.75465
by 1907 the number of undergraduates had risen to 1 , 107 .	23.902855
and at his last commencement , in that year , dr . tucker and dartmouth were honored by the presence of distinguished academic visitors attesting to the new stature of the college .	66.224205
the presidents of cornell , wisconsin , c . c . n . y . , bowdoin , vermont , brown , columbia , princeton , yale , and harvard and the presidents emeritus of harvard and michigan were there .	42.280697
dartmouth is numerically still a small college today , with approximately twenty-nine hundred undergraduates .	84.37175
but it has achieved a cross-section of students from almost all the states , and two-thirds of its undergraduates come from outside new england .	85.0302
over 450 different schools are usually represented in each entering class .	144.29433
only a dozen or so schools send as many as six students , and there are seldom more than fifteen men in any single delegation .	62.16388
about two-thirds of the boys now come from public schools .	26.716978
it is still a college only and not a university	193.69836
it is , in fact , the only college in the ivy group .	216.57343
however , three distinguished associated graduate schools offer professional curriculums -- the dartmouth medical school ( third oldest in the country and founded in 1797 ) , the thayer school of engineering , and the amos tuck school of business administration .	124.36694
all three are purposely kept small , with a current total enrollment of about two hundred .	128.56522
all three schools coordinate their educational programs with that of the undergraduate college and , like the college proper , place emphasis upon a broad liberal arts course as the proper foundation for specialized study .	159.75453
students of the college who are candidates for the a . b . degree and can satisfy the academic requirements of the medical and business schools , may enter either of these associated schools at the beginning of senior year , thus completing the two-year postgraduate course in one year .	154.34212
the thayer school offers a year of postgraduate study in somewhat the same way , after a boy wins a b . s . in engineering .	88.32623
so dartmouth is moving closer to the others in the ivy group .	40.10191
it is still , however , the junior member of the league , if not in years at least in the catching up it has had to do .	139.30092
it has not been a well-known school for any part of the span the other ivies have enjoyed .	152.514
however much football has been over-emphasized , the public likes to measure its collegiate favorites by the scoreboard , so , while yale need never give its record a thought again since outscoring its opponents 694 to 0 in the season of 1888 , dartmouth had to wait until its championship team of 1925 for national recognition .	264.55423
it has come on with a rush in more significant areas .	107.23621
today it espouses certain ideas in its curriculum that other institutions might consider somewhat breathtaking .	672.1995
