but dartmouth preserves its youthful brashness even in its educational attitudes , and , although some of its experiments may still be in the testing stage , they make for lively copy .	113.87053
president emeritus hopkins once proposed to corral an `` aristocracy of brains ' ' in hanover .	57.781315
the person who left the buggy there has never been identified .	31.907755
it was a busy street , conveniently near the shopping center , and unattended horses and wagons were often left at the curbside .	64.05584
there are , of course , many weaknesses in any case against emma .	149.27641
she didn ' t like her stepmother , but nothing is known to have occurred shortly before the crime that could have caused such a murderous rage .	141.53757
she had no way of knowing in advance whether an opportunity for murder existed .	248.22536
she would have been taking more than a fair risk of being seen and recognized during her travels .	238.63907
if she avoided the train and hired a buggy , the stableman might have recognized her .	138.56529
if police had checked on her more thoroughly than is indicated , she would be completely eliminated as a suspect .	128.9637
uncle john vinnicum morse was the immediate popular suspect .	75.20036
his sudden unannounced appearance at the borden home was strange in that he did not carry an iota of baggage with him , although he clearly intended to stay overnight , if not longer .	105.482994
lizzie stated during the inquest that while her father and uncle were in the sitting room the afternoon before the murders , she had been disturbed by their voices and had closed her door , even though it was a very hot day .	74.605194
it is evident that lizzie did not tell everything she overheard between her father and her uncle morse .	77.116585
at that time jennings had a young law associate named arthur s . phillips .	58.430733
a few years ago , not too long before his death , phillips revealed in a newspaper story that he had always suspected morse of the murders .	105.81464
he said morse and borden had quarreled violently in the house that day , information which must have come from lizzie .	107.47313
it was obviously the sound of this argument that caused lizzie to close her door .	182.41339
the new bedford standard-times has reported knowlton as saying , long after the trial , that if he only knew what borden said during his conversation with morse , he would have convicted `` somebody ' ' .	67.325745
notice , knowlton did not say that he would have obtained a conviction in the trial of lizzie borden .	34.70588
he said he would have convicted `` somebody ' ' .	2.362203
it is known that morse did associate with a group of itinerant horse traders who made their headquarters at westport , a town not far from fall river .	142.32507
they were a vagabond lot and considered to be shady and undesirable characters .	115.21994
fall river police did go to westport to see if they could get any information against morse and possibly find an accomplice whom he might have hired from among these men .	219.3583
morse ' s alibi was not as solid as it seemed .	100.96864
he said he returned from the visit to his niece on the 11 20 streetcar .	148.36243
the woman in the house where the niece was staying backed up his story and said she left when he did to shop for her dinner .	129.73975
if this woman had delayed until after 11 20 to start her shopping , she would have had little time in which to prepare the substantial meal that was eaten at dinner in those days .	116.740105
it is possible that morse told the woman it was 11 20 , but it could have been earlier , since she did serve dinner on time .	132.365
police did make an attempt to check on morse ' s alibi .	41.516884
they interviewed the conductor of the streetcar morse said he had taken , but the man did not remember morse as a passenger .	63.47903
questioned further , morse said that there had been four or five priests riding on the same car with him .	60.858
the conductor did recall having priests as passengers and this satisfied police , although the conductor also pointed out that in heavily catholic fall river there were priests riding on almost every trip the streetcar made , so morse ' s statement really proved nothing .	254.36995
we do know that morse left the house before nine o ' clock .	46.596127
bridget testified she saw him leave through the side door .	13.19178
morse said borden let him out and locked the screen door .	14.710275
from that point on he said he went to the post office and then walked leisurely to where his niece was staying , more than a mile away .	62.32014
he met nobody he knew on this walk .	8.875244
there is no accounting of his movements in this long gap of time which covers the early hours when mrs . borden was killed .	213.29489
morse testified that while he was having breakfast in the dining room , mrs . borden told the servant , `` bridget , i want you to wash these windows today ' ' .	52.09177
bridget ' s testimony was in direct contradiction .	11.009939
she said it was after she returned from her vomiting spell in the back yard that mrs . borden told her to wash the windows .	73.473526
this was long after morse had left the house .	50.21401
morse ' s knowledge of what mrs . borden told bridget could indicate that he had returned secretly to the house and was hidden there .	83.87507
he knew the house fairly well , he had been there on two previous visits during the past three or four months alone .	89.218834
and despite knowlton ' s attempts to show that the house was locked up tighter than a drum , this was not true .	85.24862
the screen door was unlocked for some ten or fifteen minutes while bridget was sick in the back .	70.384964
it was unlocked all the time she was washing windows .	12.846884
morse could have returned openly while bridget was sick in the back yard and gone up to the room he had occupied .	55.6253
mrs . borden would not have been alarmed if she saw morse with an ax or hatchet in his hand .	57.543583
he had been to the farm the previous day and he could have said they needed the ax or hatchet at the farm .	67.57407
mrs . borden would have had no reason to disbelieve him and he could have approached close enough to her to swing before she could cry out .	185.21893
he could have left for weybosset street after her murder and made it in plenty of time by using the streetcar .	245.66942
if he took an earlier streetcar than the 11 20 on his return , he could have arrived at the borden house shortly after mr . borden came home .	95.66085
with lizzie in the barn , the screen door unlocked and bridget upstairs in her attic room , he would have had free and easy access to the house .	47.789673
with the second murder over , he could have left , hidden the weapon in some vacant lot or an abandoned cistern in the neighborhood .	175.70074
his unconcerned stroll down the side of the house to a pear tree , with crowds already gathering in front of the building and sawyer guarding the side door , was odd .	64.7721
there was no close examination of his clothes for bloodstains , and certainly no scientific test was made of them .	106.899666
and for a man who traveled around without any change of clothing , a few more stains on his dark suit may very well have gone unnoticed .	159.95546
there was no financial gain for morse in the murders .	24.436712
on the other side of the ledger is the fact that he did see his niece and the woman with whom she was staying .	58.90572
the time would have been shortly after the murder of mrs . borden and they noticed nothing unusual in his behavior .	117.5999
he said he had promised mrs . borden to return in time for dinner and that was close to the time when he did turn up at the borden house .	73.24342
what did pearson say about bridget sullivan as a possible suspect in his trial-book essay ? ?	96.98255
`` the police soon ceased to look upon either bridget or mr . morse as in possession of guilty knowledge .	92.61203
indeed , it was probably to mr . morse ' s advantage to have mr . and mrs . borden alive .	39.19753
both he and bridget were exonerated by lizzie herself ' ' .	67.44193
that was his complete discussion of bridget sullivan as a possible suspect .	38.66973
although pearson disbelieved almost everything lizzie said , and read a sinister purpose into almost everything she did , he happily accepted her statement about bridget as the whole truth .	149.19672
he felt nothing further need be said about the servant girl .	134.4955
the exoneration pearson speaks of is not an exoneration , but lizzie ' s expression of her opinion , as reported in the testimony of assistant marshal fleet .	88.20199
this officer had asked lizzie if she suspected her uncle morse , and she replied she didn ' t think he did it because he left the house before the murders and returned after them .	56.986572
fleet asked the same question about bridget , and lizzie pointed out that as far as she knew bridget had gone up to her room before her father ' s murder and came down when she called her .	64.52897
lizzie , actually , never named any suspect .	19.226826
she told police about the prospective tenant she had heard quarreling with her father some weeks before the murders , but she said she thought he was from out of town because she heard him mention something about talking to his partner .	113.35105
and , much as she detested hiram harrington , she also did not accuse him .	43.72478
at the inquest she was asked specifically whether she knew anybody her father had bad feelings toward , or who had bad feelings toward her father .	267.17682
she replied , `` i know of one man that has not been friendly with him .	39.33102
they have not been friendly for years ' ' .	1.7127067
asked who this was , she named harrington .	54.730095
the press reported the same facts in using harrington ' s interview , but lizzie did not suggest at the inquest that harrington was the killer .	52.319904
when i interviewed kirby , who as a boy picked up pears in the borden yard , i asked if anybody else in the household besides lizzie and morse had been under any suspicion at the time of the murders .	87.42813
he said he had not heard of anybody else .	6.0079255
`` how about bridget sullivan ' ' ? ?	1.200603
`` oh , she was just the maid there ' ' , he replied , waving a hand to indicate how completely unimportant she was .	178.86002
kirby was , of course , reflecting the opinion that existed at the time of murders .	76.23723
everyone somehow manages to overlook completely the fact that , as far as we know , there were exactly two people in and about the house at the time of both murders lizzie borden and bridget sullivan .	65.29453
all the officials on the case seem to have been afflicted with a similar myopia as far as bridget was concerned , although records in police files contain many reports of servants who have murdered their employers .	175.98314
true , it is no longer cricket for the butler to be the killer in mystery fiction , but we are dealing here with actual people in real life and not imaginary characters and situations .	89.03536
the actions of bridget should be examined , since she was there and opportunity did exist , if only to establish her innocence .	166.67383
there are also other factors that require closer examination .	38.189312
the legend as it exists in fall river today always includes the solemn assurance that bridget returned to ireland after the trial with a `` big bundle ' ' of cash which lizzie gave her for keeping her mouth shut .	129.32153
the people who believe and retell the legend have apparently never troubled to read the trial testimony and do not know that the maid changed her testimony on several key points , always to the detriment of lizzie .	220.35635
if bridget did get any bundles of cash , the last person who would have rewarded her for services rendered would have been lizzie borden .	97.56644
bridget was born in ireland , one of fourteen children .	158.5981
she was apparently the pioneer in her family because she had no close relatives in this country at that time .	40.223564
she worked as a domestic , first in newport for a year , and then in south bethlehem , pennsylvania , for another year .	53.162025
she finally settled in fall river and , after being employed for a time by a mrs . reed , was hired by the bordens .	96.148705
i have previously described how , during the week of the murder , bridget spent the first few hot days scrubbing and ironing clothes .	108.68872
her father , james upton , was the upton mentioned by hawthorne in the famous introduction to the scarlet letter as one of those who came into the old custom house to do business with him as the surveyor of the port .	111.9687
a gentleman of the old school , mr . upton possessed intellectual power , ample means , and withal , was a devoted christian .	120.880295
the daughter profited from his interest in scientific and philosophical subjects .	47.042923
her mother also was a person of superior mind and broad interests .	65.59318
there is clear evidence that lucy from childhood had an unusual mind .	134.57716
she possessed an observant eye , a retentive memory , and a critical faculty .	81.72071
when she was nine years old , she wrote a description of a store she had visited .	131.92017
she named 48 items , and said there were `` many more things which it would take too long to write ' ' .	109.04182
an essay on `` freedom ' ' written at 10 years of age quoted the declaration of independence , the freedom given to slaves in canada , and the views of george washington .	99.61399
lucy upton was graduated from the salem high school when few colleges , only oberlin and elmira , were open to women	160.46654
and she had an appetite for learning that could not be denied .	22.128958
a picture of her in high school comes from a younger schoolmate , albert s . flint , friend of her brother winslow , and later , like winslow , a noted astronomer .	58.605995
he recalled lucy , as `` a bright-looking black-eyed young lady who came regularly through the boys ' study hall to join the class in greek in the little recitation room beyond ' ' .	156.4898
the study of greek was the distinctive mark of boys destined to go to college , and lucy upton too expected to go to college and take the full classical course offered to men .	93.230125
the death of her mother in 1865 prevented this .	144.61435
with four younger children at home , lucy stepped into her mother ' s role , and even after the brothers and sisters were grown , she was her father ' s comfort and stay until he died in 1879 .	50.671665
but even so lucy could not give up her intellectual pursuits .	222.83066
when her brother winslow became a student at brown university in 1874 , she wrote him about a course in history he was taking under professor diman `` what is prof . diman ' s definition of civilization , and take the world through , is its progress ever onward , or does it retrograde at times ? ?	142.28001
do you think i might profitably study some of the history you do , perhaps two weeks behind you .	301.09607
' ' and that she proceeded to do .	84.82027
many years later ( on august 3 , 1915 ) , lucy upton wrote winslow ' s daughter soon to be graduated from smith college `` while i love botany which , after dabbling in for years , i studied according to the methods of that day exactly forty years ago in a summer school , it must be fascinating to take up zoology in the way you are doing .	98.96904
whatever was the science in the high school course for the time being , that was my favorite study .	198.19196
she read maitland ' s dark ages , `` which i enjoyed very much ' '	96.641266
la croix on the customs of the middle ages , 16 chapters of bryce `` and liked it more and more ' '	112.78613
she discussed in her letters to winslow some of the questions that came to her as she studied alone .	84.00423
lucy ' s correspondence with brother winslow during his college days was not entirely taken up with academic studies .	353.41733
also lucy and winslow had a private contest to see which one could make the most words from the letters in `` importunately ' ' .	56.88984
who won is not revealed , but winslow ' s daughter eleanor says they got up to 1 , 212 words .	134.13792
winslow had musical talents , as had his father before him .	118.41339
at different times he served as glee-club and choir leader and as organist .	383.07956
and it was lucy upton who first started the idea of a regular course in music at spelman college .	132.37764
winslow upton after graduation from brown university and two years of graduate study , accepted a position at the harvard observatory .	86.9285
for three years he was connected with the u . s . naval observatory and with the u . s . signal corps	28.551363
and after 1883 , was professor of astronomy at brown university .	36.16726
the six expeditions to study eclipses of the sun , of which he was a member , took him to colorado , virginia , and california as well as to the south pacific and to russia .	45.294968
after her father ' s death , lucy and her youngest sister lived for a few years with winslow in washington , d . c . .	48.483738
`` their house ' ' , writes albert s . flint , `` was always a haven of hospitality and good cheer , especially grateful to one like myself far from home ' ' .	92.60673
lucy was a lively part of the household .	252.30138
moreover , she had physical as well as mental vigor .	272.78113
winslow , as his daughters eleanor and margaret recall , used to characterize her as `` our iron sister ' ' .	78.81092
there is reason to suppose that lucy would have made a record as publicly distinguished as her brother had it not been that her mother ' s death occurred just as she was about to enter college .	118.71099
as a matter of fact , albert s . flint expressed his conviction that `` her physical strength , her mental power , her lively interest in all objects about her and her readiness to serve her fellow beings ' ' would have led her `` to a distinguished career amongst the noted women of this country ' ' .	167.85608
while in washington , d . c . , lucy upton held positions in the u . s . census office , and in the pension bureau .	43.384995
they were not sufficiently challenging however , and she resigned in 1887 , to go to germany with her brother winslow and his family while he was there on study .	84.767105
after the months in europe , she returned to boston and became active in church and community life .	159.56793
what was called an `` accidental meeting ' ' with miss packard in washington turned her attention to spelman .	88.545845
after correspondence with miss packard and to the joy of miss packard and miss giles , she came to atlanta , in the fall of 1888 , to help wherever needed , although there was then no money available to pay her a salary .	84.30728
she served for a number of years without pay beyond her travel and maintenance .	205.12819
her students have spoken of the exacting standards of scholarship and of manners and conduct she expected and achieved from the students	175.9474
of her `` great power of discernment ' '	1.0781494
of `` her exquisiteness of dress ' ' , `` her well-modulated voice that went straight to the hearts of the hearers ' '	67.38442
her great love of flowers and plants and birds	189.78738
she drew on all her resources of mind and heart to help them -- to make them at home in the world	40.450584
and as graduates gratefully recall , she drew on her purse as well .	99.846054
many a student was able to remain at spelman , only because of her unobtrusive help .	168.51587
under miss upton , the work of the year 1909-10 went forward without interruption .	928.81
after all , she had come to spelman seminary in 1888 , and had been since 1891 except for one year , associate principal or dean .	92.33494
she had taught classes in botany , astronomy ( with the aid of a telescope ) , geometry , and psychology .	81.444275
miss upton and miss packard , as a matter of fact , had many tastes in common .	90.98594
and both believed that intellectual growth must go hand in hand with the development of sturdy character and christian zeal .	132.99268
both loved the out-of-doors , including mountain climbing and horseback riding .	22.797916
in 1890 when the trip to europe and the holy land was arranged for miss packard , it was miss upton who planned the trip , and `` with rare executive ability ' ' bore the brunt of `` the entire pilgrimage from beginning to end ' ' .	133.37556
so strenuous it was physically , with its days of horseback riding over rough roads that it seems an amazing feat of endurance for both miss packard and miss upton .	104.19866
at the fifteenth anniversary ( 1896 ) as already quoted , miss upton projected with force and eloquence the spelman of the future as a college of first rank , with expanding and unlimited horizons .	105.48506
when dr . wallace buttrick , wise in his judgment of people , declined to have the science building named for him , he wrote miss tapley ( april 7 , 1923 ) `` if you had asked me , i think i would have suggested that you name the building for miss upton .	100.010254
her services to the school for many years were of a very high character , and i have often thought that one of the buildings should be named for her ' ' .	77.36339
such were the qualities of the acting-president of the seminary after the death of miss giles .	37.651478
at the meeting of the board of trustees , on march 3 , 1910 , miss upton presented the annual report of the president .	35.677563
she noted that no student had been withdrawn through loss of confidence	334.00433
that the enrollment showed an increase of boarding students as was desired	1147.747
and that the year ' s work had gone forward smoothly .	27.318281
she urged the importance of more thorough preparation for admission .	48.15214
the raising of the $25 , 000 improvement fund two days before the time limit expired , and the spontaneous `` praise demonstration ' ' held afterward on the campus , were reported as events which had brought happiness to miss giles .	118.50123
with the fund in hand , the debt on the boilers had been paid	158.29845
and ground had been broken for the superintendent ' s home .	28.582964
miss upton spoke gratefully of the response of spelman graduates and negro friends in helping to raise the fund , and their continuing efforts to raise money for greatly needed current expenses .	98.3969
she spoke also with deep thankfulness of the many individuals and agencies whose interest and efforts through the years had made the work so fruitful in results .	238.82063
two bequests were recorded one of $200 under the will of mrs . harriet a . copp of los angeles	122.09874
and one of $2 , 000 under the will of miss celia l . brett of hamilton , new york , a friend from the early days .	73.43979
miss upton told the trustees that the death of miss giles was `` the sorest grief ' ' the seminary had ever been called upon to bear .	75.726875
the daughters of spelman , she said , had never known or thought of spelman without her .	356.47754
the removal of miss packard 18 years earlier had caused them great sorrow , but they still had miss giles .	127.05168
`` yet spelman has strong , deep roots , and will live for the blessing of generations to come ' ' .	43.71343
miss mary jane packard , sophia ' s half-sister , became ill in march , 1910	71.991425
and when school closed , she was unable to travel to massachusetts .	51.966446
before coming on a visit to spelman in 1885 , miss mary had been a successful teacher in worcester , and her position there was held open for her for a considerable period .	150.27571
she helped with teaching as well as office work for a few years -- the catalogues show that she had classes in geography , rhetoric and bookkeeping .	133.26825
soon the office work claimed all her time .	9.211407
she was closely associated with the founders in all their trials and hardships .	256.60193
quiet and energetic , cheerful and calm , she too was a power in the development of the seminary .	59.206043
miss giles always used to refer to her as `` sister ' ' .	26.773426
she served as secretary in the seminary office for 25 years , and was in charge of correspondence , records , and bookkeeping .	69.753296
the books of the school hold a memorial to her	82.66611
and so do the hearts of students and of teachers .	374.92996
mary j . packard , states a messenger editorial , was `` efficient , pains-taking , self-effacing , loving , radiating the spirit of her master .	53.864384
with infinite patience she responded to every call , no matter at what cost to herself , and to her all went , for she was sure to have the needed information or word of cheer .	153.64145
in a few school districts one finds a link between school and job .	237.87753
in those vocational programs organized with smith-hughes money , there may be a close tie between the labor union and a local employer on the one hand and the vocational teacher on the other .	51.59078
in these cases a graduate may enter directly into an apprentice program , saving a year because of his vocational courses in grades 11 and 12 .	103.91188
the apprentice program will involve further education on a part-time basis , usually at night , perhaps using some of the same equipment of the high school .	53.594925
these opportunities are to be found in certain cities in such crafts as auto mechanics , carpentry , drafting , electrical work , tool-and-die work , and sheet-metal work .	103.86298
formally organized vocational programs supported by federal funds allow high school students to gain experience in a field of work which is likely to lead to a full-time job on graduation .	75.903984
the `` diversified occupations ' ' program is a part-time trade-preparatory program conducted over two school years on a cooperative basis between the school and local industrial and business employers .	113.70787
the `` distributive education ' ' program operates in a similar way , with arrangements between the school and employers in merchandising fields .	97.53662
in both cases the student attends school half-time and works in a regular job the other half .	166.9008
in a few places cooperative programs between schools and employers in clerical work have shown the same possibilities for allowing the student , while still in school , to develop skills which are immediately marketable upon graduation .	112.03107
adult education courses , work-study programs of various sorts -- these are all evidence of a continuing interest of the schools in furthering educational opportunities for out-of-school youth .	167.80374
in general , however , it may be said that when a boy or a girl leaves the high school , the school authorities play little or no part in the decision of what happens next .	111.543655
if the student drops out of high school , the break with the school is even more complete .	104.03186
when there is employment opportunity for youth , this arrangement -- or lack of arrangement -- works out quite well .	316.30734
indeed , in some periods of our history and in some neighborhoods the job opportunities have been so good that undoubtedly a great many boys who were potential members of the professions quit school at an early age and went to work .	133.238
statistically this has represented a loss to the nation , although one must admit that in an individual case the decision in retrospect may have been a wise one .	109.6218
i make no attempt to measure the enduring satisfaction and material well-being of a man who went to work on graduation from high school and was highly successful in the business which he entered .	93.34293
he may or may not be `` better off ' ' than his classmate who went on to a college and professional school .	101.82967
but in the next decades the nation needs to educate for the professions all the potential professional talent .	156.20354
in a later chapter dealing with the suburban school , i shall discuss the importance of arranging a program for the academically talented and highly gifted youth in any high school where he is found .	72.22726
in the negro neighborhoods and also to some extent in the mixed neighborhoods the problem may be one of identification and motivation .	76.85902
high motivation towards higher education must start early enough so that by the time the boy or girl reaches grade 9 he or she has at least developed those basic skills which are essential for academic work .	238.0702
undoubtedly far more can be done in the lower grades in this regard in the negro schools .	105.72183
however , the teacher can only go so far if the attitude of the community and the family is anti-intellectual .	32.438343
and the fact remains that there are today few shining examples of negroes in positions of intellectual leadership .	140.67793
this is not due to any policy of discrimination on the part of the northern universities .	34.812527
quite the contrary , as i can testify from personal experience as a former university president .	268.9705
the absence of successful negroes in the world of scholarship and science has tended to tamp down enthusiasm among negro youth for academic careers .	211.6111
i believe the situation is improving , but the success stories need to be heavily publicized .	431.75745
here again we run into the roadblock that negroes do not like to be designated as negroes in the press .	57.52474
how can the vicious circle be broken ? ?	1.0855436
this is a problem to which leaders of opinion , both negro and white , should devote far more attention .	136.08258
it is at least as important as the more dramatic attempts to break down barriers of inequality in the south .	100.03625
i should like to underline four points i made in my first report with respect to vocational education .	78.04488
first and foremost , vocational courses should not replace courses which are essential parts of the required academic program for graduation .	185.95938
second , vocational courses should be provided in grades 11 and 12 and not require more than half the student ' s time in those years	73.773544
however , for slow learners and prospective dropouts these courses ought to begin earlier .	175.30682
third , the significance of the vocational courses is that those enrolled are keenly interested in the work	172.77322
they realize the relevance of what they are learning to their future careers , and this sense of purpose is carried over to the academic courses which they are studying at the same time .	68.342224
fourth , the type of vocational training programs should be related to the employment opportunities in the general locality .	35.117577
this last point is important because if high school pupils are aware that few , if any , graduates who have chosen a certain vocational program have obtained a job as a consequence of the training , the whole idea of relevance disappears .	147.90056
vocational training which holds no hope that the skill developed will be in fact a marketable skill becomes just another school `` chore ' ' for those whose interest in their studies has begun to falter .	187.47337
those who , because of population mobility and the reputed desire of employers to train their own employees , would limit vocational education to general rather than specific skills ought to bear in mind the importance of motivation in any kind of school experience .	113.843765
i have been using the word `` vocational ' ' as a layman would at first sight think it should be used .	83.42204
i intend to include under the term all the practical courses open to boys and girls .	225.8731
these courses develop skills other than those we think of when we use the adjective `` academic ' ' .	107.647156
practically all of these practical skills are of such a nature that a degree of mastery can be obtained in high school sufficient to enable the youth to get a job at once on the basis of the skill .	65.96549
they are in this sense skills marketable immediately on graduation from high school .	33.9129
to be sure , in tool-and-die work and in the building trades , the first job must be often on an apprentice basis , but two years of half-time vocational training enables the young man thus to anticipate one year of apprentice status .	140.65921
similarly , a girl who graduates with a good working knowledge of stenography and the use of clerical machines and who is able to get a job at once may wish to improve her skill and knowledge by a year or two of further study in a community college or secretarial school .	128.62384
of course , it can be argued that an ability to write english correctly and with some degree of elegance is a marketable skill .	74.011406
so , too , is the mathematical competence of a college graduate who has majored in mathematics .	60.297367
in a sense almost all high school and college courses could be considered as vocational to the extent that later in life the student in his vocation ( which may be a profession ) will be called upon to use some of the skills developed and the competence obtained .	140.24251
in spite of the shading of one type of course into another , i believe it is useful to talk about vocational courses as apart from academic courses .	195.72395
perhaps a course in typewriting might be regarded as the exception which proves the rule .	95.9735
today many college bound students try to take a course in personal typing , as they feel a certain degree of mastery of this skill is almost essential for one who proposes to do academic work in college and a professional school .	81.78738
most of our largest cities have one or more separate vocational or technical high schools .	150.52693
in this respect , public education in the large cities differs from education in the smaller cities and consolidated school districts .	64.53848
the neighborhood high schools are not , strictly speaking , comprehensive schools , because some of the boys and girls may be attending a vocational or technical high school instead of the local school .	66.740685
indeed , one school superintendent in a large city objects to the use of the term comprehensive high school for the senior high schools in his city , because these schools do not offer strictly vocational programs .	93.88717
he prefers to designate such schools as `` general ' ' high schools .	40.462006
the suburban high school , it is worth noting , also is not a widely comprehensive high school because of the absence of vocational programs .	104.35669
the reason is that there is a lack of interest on the part of the community .	11.965871
therefore employment and education in all the schools in a metropolitan area are related in different ways from those which are characteristic of the comprehensive high school described in my first report .	100.05739
the separate vocational or technical high schools in the large cities must be reckoned as permanent institutions .	64.464294
by and large their programs are satisfactorily connected both to the employment situation and to the realities of the apprentice system .	117.732704
it is not often realized to what degree certain trades are in many communities closed areas of employment , except for a lucky few .	93.42959
one has to talk confidentially with some of the directors of vocational high schools to realize that a boy cannot just say , `` i want to be a plumber ' ' , and then , by doing good work , find a job .	94.41139
it is far more difficult in many communities to obtain admission to an apprentice program which involves union approval than to get into the most selective medical school in the nation .	205.16614
two stories will illustrate what i have in mind .	36.202827
one vocational instructor in a city vocational school , speaking of his course in a certain field , said he had no difficulty placing all students in jobs outside of the city .	106.5656
in the city , he said , the waiting list for those who want to join the union is so long that unless a boy has an inside track he can ' t get in .	104.39412
in a far distant part of the united states , i was talking to an instructor about a boy who in the twelfth grade was doing special work .	91.96298
`` what does he have in mind to do when he graduates ' ' ? ?	30.363503
`` oh , he ' ll be a plumber ' ' , came the answer .	56.723736
`` but isn ' t it almost impossible to get into the union ' ' ? ?	22.261484
`` he ' ll have no difficulty ' ' , i was told .	15.287121
`` he has very good connections ' ' .	1.5148245
in my view , there should be a school which offers significant vocational programs for boys within easy reach of every family in a city .	348.0994
ideally these schools should be so located that one or more should be in the area where demand for practical courses is at the highest .	102.007
an excellent example of a successful location of a new vocational high school is the dunbar vocational high school in chicago .	53.85049
located in a bad slum area now undergoing redevelopment , this school and its program are especially tailored to the vocational aims of its students .	120.609985
hardly a window has been broken since dunbar first was opened ( and vandalism in schools is a major problem in many slum areas ) .	162.72258
i discovered in the course of a visit there that almost all the pupils were negroes .	170.91808
they were learning trades as diverse as shoe repairing , bricklaying , carpentry , cabinet making , auto mechanics , and airplane mechanics .	81.94023
the physical facilities at dunbar are impressive , but more impressive is the attitude of the pupils .	86.601776
the soybean seed is the most important leguminous food in the world .	61.35419
in the united states , where half of the world crop is grown , soybeans are processed for their edible oil .	81.95063
the residue from soybean processing goes mainly into animal feeds .	96.27317
soybeans are extensively processed into a remarkable number of food products in the orient .	64.544914
american chemists , seeking to increase exports of soybeans , have adapted modern techniques and fermentation methods to improve their use in such traditional japanese foods as tofu and miso and in tempeh of indonesia .	113.1533
soybean flour , grits , flakes , `` milk ' ' , and curd can be bought in the united states .	23.951805
peanuts are the world ' s second most important legume .	24.516148
we produce peanut oil , but to a much greater extent we eat the entire seed .	202.05469
blanched peanuts , as prepared for making peanut butter or for eating as nuts , are roasted seeds whose seedcoats have been rubbed off .	153.94339
cereal grains , supplemented with soybeans or dry edible peas or beans , comprise about two-thirds or three-fourths of the diet in parts of asia and africa .	61.326225
in western europe and north america , where the level of economic development is higher , grains and other seed products furnish less than one-third of the food consumed .	99.0323
rather , meat and potatoes , sugar , and dairy products are the main sources of carbohydrate , protein , oils , and fats .	54.94336
people depend less on seeds for foods in australia , new zealand , and argentina , where extensive grazing lands support sheep or cattle , and the consumption of meat is high .	149.04115
feeds for livestock took about one-sixth of the world ' s cereal crop in 1957-1958 .	42.291454
most of the grain is fed to swine and dairy cows and lesser amounts to beef cattle and poultry .	35.544468
about 90 percent of the corn used in the united states is fed to animals .	32.099598
the rest is used for human food and industrial products .	64.98836
more than half of the sorghum and barley seeds we produce and most of the byproducts of the milling of cereals and the crushing of oilseeds are fed to livestock .	55.102985
more than 200 million tons of seeds and seed products are fed to livestock annually in the united states .	20.111946
the efficiency with which animals convert grains and forages to meat has risen steadily in the united states since the 1930 ' s and has paralleled the increased feeding of the cake and meal that are a byproduct when seeds are processed for oil .	66.85714
the demand for food is so great in the world that little arable land can be given over to growing the nonfood crops .	164.63739
seeds grown for industrial uses hold a relatively minor position .	116.476494
chief among the seed crops grown primarily for industrial uses are the oil-bearing seeds -- flax , castor , tung ( nuts from the china wood-oil tree ) , perilla ( from an oriental mint ) , and oiticica ( from a brazilian tree ) .	102.19064
oils , or liquid fats , from the seeds of flax and tung have long been the principal constituents of paints and varnishes for protecting and beautifying the surfaces of wood and metal .	49.890617
these oils develop hard , smooth films when they dry and form resinlike substances .	188.64839
the artist who paints in oil uses drying oils to carry the pigments and to protect his finished work for the ages .	71.19288
one of the finest of artists ' oils comes from poppy seeds .	67.595184
seeds of soybean , cotton , corn , sesame , and rape yield semidrying oils .	63.61651
some are used in paints along with drying oils .	5.577173
palm oil protects the surfaces of steel sheets before they are plated with tin .	80.2707
castor oil , made from castorbeans , has gone out of style as a medicine .	135.28658
this nondrying oil , however , is now more in demand than ever before as a fine lubricant , as a constituent of fluids for hydraulically operated equipment , and as a source of chemicals to make plastics .	59.687454
almond oil , another nondrying oil , was once used extensively in perfumery to extract flower fragrances .	52.64328
it is still used in drugs and cosmetics , but it is rather scarce and sometimes is adulterated with oils from peach and plum seeds .	90.86437
liquid fats from all these oilseeds enter into the manufacture of soaps for industry and the household and of glycerin for such industrial uses as making explosives .	158.74898
sizable amounts of soybean , coconut , and palm kernel oil -- seed oils that are produced primarily for food purposes -- also are used to make soaps , detergents , and paint resins .	84.007996
solid fats from the seeds of the mahua tree , the shea tree , and the coconut palm are used to make candles in tropical countries .	44.302246
seeds are a main source of starch for industrial and food use in many parts of the world .	94.73518
corn and wheat supply most of the starch in the united states , canada , and australia .	14.654537
in other countries where cereal grains are not among the principal crops of a region , starchy tubers or roots are processed for starch .	136.98936
starch is used in the paper , textile , and food-processing industries and in a multitude of other manufacturing operations .	72.55007
gums were extracted from quince , psyllium ( fleawort ) , flax , and locust ( carob ) seeds in ancient times .	68.26055
today the yearly import into the united states of locust bean gum is more than 15 million pounds	68.151306
of psyllium seed , more than 2 . 6 million .	10.737293
the discovery during the second world war that guar gum was similar to imported locust gum increased its cultivation in western asia and initiated it in the united states .	82.19914
water-soluble gums are used in foods and drugs and in the manufacture of pulp and paper as thickeners , stabilizers , or dispersing agents .	49.249557
guar gum thickens salad dressings and stabilizes ice cream .	5.84234
quince seed gum is the main ingredient in wave-setting lotions .	632.1789
once regarded as an agricultural nuisance , psyllium was sold in the 1930 ' s as a mechanical laxative under 117 different brands .	69.14848
locust gum is added to pulp slurries to break up the lumps of fibers in making paper .	57.474316
the seeds of hard , fibrous , stony fruits , called nuts , provide highly concentrated foods , oils , and other materials of value .	103.48308
most nuts consist of the richly packaged storage kernel and its thick , adherent , brown covering -- the seedcoat .	271.08936
the kernels of brazil nuts , cashews , coconuts , filberts , hazelnuts , hickory nuts , pecans , walnuts , and pine nuts are predominantly oily .	34.1172
almonds and pistachio nuts are not so high in oil but are rich in protein .	60.521618
the world production of familiar seed nuts -- almonds , brazil nuts , filberts , and the english walnuts -- totals about 300 thousand tons annually .	43.69694
coconuts , the fruit of the coconut palm , have the largest of all known seeds and are grown in south pacific islands as a crop for domestic and export markets .	169.89302
the oil palm of west africa yields edible oil from both the flesh and the seed or kernel of its fruit .	46.64558
world production of copra , the oil-bearing flesh of the coconut , was a little more than 3 million tons in 1959 .	29.891891
exports from producing countries in terms of equivalent oil were a little more than 1 million tons , about half of which was palm kernels or oil from them and about half was palm oil .	128.87634
other nuts consumed in lesser quantity include the spicy nutmeg	178.99124
the soap nut , which owes its sudsing power to natural saponins	408.19403
the marking nut , used for ink and varnish	87.1451
and the sweet-smelling cumara nut , which is suited for perfumes .	46.284157
a forest crop that has not been extensively cultivated is ivory nuts from the tagua palm .	146.06981
the so-called vegetable ivory is the hard endosperm of the egg-sized seed .	81.32432
it is used for making buttons and other small , hard objects of turnery .	155.02202
seeds of the sago palm are used in bermuda to make heads and faces of dolls sold to tourists .	111.25967
the color and shape of seeds have long made them attractive for ornaments and decorations .	185.94757
since biblical times , rosaries have been made from jobs-tears -- the seeds of an asiatic grass .	111.810715
bead tree seeds are the necklaces of south pacific islanders and the eyes of buddha dolls in cuba .	110.41974
victorian ladies had a fad of stringing unusual seeds to wear as jewelry .	211.9783
handmade christmas wreaths and trees often contain a variety of seeds collected during the year .	70.29105
tradition has assigned medicinal values to seeds because of their alkaloids , aromatic oils , and highly flavored components .	35.38921
although science has given us more effective materials , preparations from anise , castorbean , colchicum , nux vomica , mustard , fennel , and stramonium are familiar to many for the relief of human ailments .	62.02891
flaxseed poultices and mustard plasters still are used by some persons .	69.565125
peanut and sesame oils often are used as carriers or diluents for medicines administered by injection .	114.0869
still another group of seeds ( sometimes tiny , dry , seed-bearing fruits ) provide distinctive flavors and odors to foods , although the nutrients they supply are quite negligible .	190.03207
the common spices , flavorings , and condiments make up this group .	143.88058
each year millions of pounds of anise , caraway , mustard , celery , and coriander and the oils extracted from them are imported .	52.14948
single-seeded dry fruits used for flavoring include several of the carrot family , such as cumin , dill , fennel , and angelica .	47.33529
less common seeds used in cooking and beverages include fenugreek ( artificial maple flavor ) and cardamom .	68.16444
white pepper is the ground seed of the common black pepper fruit .	66.09912
sesame seed , which comes from the tall pods of a plant grown in egypt , brazil , and central america , has a toasted-nut flavor and can be used in almost any dish calling for almonds .	89.351456
it is a main flavoring for halvah , the candy of the middle east .	28.141014
sesame sticks , a snack dip , originated in the southwest .	9.321492
beverages are made from seeds the world over .	26.085167
coffee is made from the roasted and ground seeds of the coffee tree .	13.682422
world production of coffee broke all previous records in 1959 and 1960 at more than 5 million tons .	31.881285
per capita consumption remains around 16 pounds in the united states .	6.4241543
cocoa , chocolate , and cocoa butter come from the ground seeds of the cacao tree .	28.69844
world production of about 1 million tons is divided primarily between africa ( 63 percent ) and south america ( 27 percent ) .	125.58903
several soft drinks contain extracts from kola nuts , the seed of the kola tree cultivated in the west indies and south america .	25.86475
cereal grains have been used for centuries to prepare fermented beverages .	26.496378
the japanese sake is wine fermented from rice grain .	70.01127
arrack is distilled from fermented rice in india .	9.028799
beer , generally fermented from barley , is an old alcoholic beverage .	64.61882
beer was brewed by the babylonians and egyptians more than 6 thousand years ago .	86.82067
brewers today use corn , rice , and malted barley .	198.30275
distillers use corn , malt , wheat , grain sorghum , and rye in making beverage alcohol .	25.443499
seed crops hold a prominent place in the agricultural economy of the united states .	52.32633
the farm value of seeds produced in this country for all purposes , including the cereals , is nearly 10 billion dollars a year .	42.80032
cereal grains , oilseeds , and dry beans and peas account for about 57 percent of the farm value of all crops raised .	229.34412
the economic importance of seed crops actually is even greater , because additional returns are obtained from most of the corn , oats , barley , and sorghum -- as well as the cake and meal from the processing of flaxseed , cottonseed , and soybeans -- through conversion to poultry , meat , and dairy products .	58.78464
seeds furnish about 40 percent of the total nutrients consumed by all livestock .	16.95096
hay and pasture are the other chief sources of livestock feed .	164.89455
seeds are the essential raw materials for milling grain , baking , crushing oilseed , refining edible oil , brewing , distilling , and mixing feed .	71.394844
more than 11 thousand business establishments in the united states were based on cereals and oilseeds in 1954 .	27.099176
the value of products from these industries was 15 . 8 billion dollars , of which about one-third was created by manufacturing processes .	205.59842
not included was the value of seed oil in paints and varnishes or the value of the coffee and chocolate industries that are based on imported seed or seed products .	30.690958
cereal grains furnish about one-fourth of the total food calories in the american diet and about one-third of the total nutrients consumed by all livestock and poultry .	45.812057
to hold a herd of cattle on a new range till they felt at home was called `` locatin ' ' ' ' em .	64.618546
to keep ' em scattered somewhat and yet herd ' em was called `` loose herdin ' ' ' .	41.487667
to hold ' em in a compact mass was `` close herdin ' ' ' .	15.613397
cattle were inclined to remain in a territory with which they were acquainted .	121.040924
that became their `` home range ' ' .	2.5987666
yet there were always some that moved farther and farther out , seekin ' grass and water .	85.58562
these became `` strays ' ' , the term bein ' restricted to cattle , however , as hosses , under like circumstances , were spoken of as `` stray hosses ' ' , not merely `` strays ' ' .	71.54431
cattle would drift day and night in a blizzard till it was over .	191.95001
you had to go with ' em or wait till the storm was over , and follow .	122.36533
such marchin ' in wholesale numbers was called a `` drift ' ' , or `` winter drift ' ' , and if the storm was prolonged it usually resulted in one of the tragedies of the range .	58.75634
the cowboy made a technical distinction in reference to the number of them animals .	47.125755
the single animal or a small bunch were referred to as `` strays ' '	14.499484
but when a large number were `` bunched up ' ' or `` banded up ' ' , and marched away from their home range , as long as they stayed together the group was said to be a `` drift ' ' .	46.16759
drifts usually occurred in winter in an effort to escape the severe cold winds , but it could also occur in summer as the result of lack of water or grass because of a drought , or as an aftermath of a stampede .	87.69869
drifts usually happened only with cattle , for hosses had ' nough sense to avoid ' em , and to find shelter for ' emselves .	251.50046
the wholesale death of cattle as a result of blizzards , and sometimes droughts , over a wide range of territory was called a `` die-up ' ' .	64.688644
followin ' such an event there was usually a harvest of `` fallen hides ' ' , and the ranchers needed skinnin ' knives instead of brandin ' irons .	108.09465
cattle were said to be `` potted ' ' when `` blizzard choked ' ' , that is , caught in a corner or a draw , or against a `` drift fence ' ' durin ' a storm .	83.15079
cattle which died from them winter storms were referred to as the `` winter kill ' ' .	29.470013
when cattle in winter stopped and humped their backs up they were said to `` bow up ' ' .	66.532684
this term was also used by the cowboy in the sense of a human showin ' fight , as one cowhand was heard to say , `` he arches his back like a mule in a hailstorm ' ' .	103.49442
cattle drove to the northern ranges and held for two winters to mature ' em into prime beef were said to be `` double wintered ' ' .	103.75117
cattle brought into a range from a distance were called `` immigrants ' ' .	82.55431
them new to the country were referred to as `` pilgrims ' ' .	19.45704
this word was first applied to the imported hot-blooded cattle , but later was more commonly used as reference to a human tenderfoot .	140.42319
hereford cattle were often called `` white faces ' ' , or `` open-face cattle ' ' , and the old-time cowman gave the name of `` hothouse stock ' ' to them newly introduced cattle .	109.37566
because holstein cattle weren ' t a beef breed , they were rarely seen on a ranch , though one might be found now and then for the milk supply .	76.48268
the cowboy called this breed of cattle `` magpies ' ' .	7.258173
a `` cattaloe ' ' was a hybrid offspring of buffalo and cattle .	27.47698
`` dry stock ' ' denoted , regardless of age or sex , such bovines as were givin ' no milk .	228.02892
a `` wet herd ' ' was a herd of cattle made up entirely of cows , while `` wet stuff ' ' referred to cows givin ' milk .	67.00771
the cowboy ' s humorous name for a cow givin ' milk was a `` milk pitcher ' ' .	15.3592205
cows givin ' no milk were knowed as `` strippers ' ' .	10.674275
the terminology of the range , in speakin ' of `` dry stock ' ' and `` wet stock ' ' , was confusin ' to the tenderfoot .	50.791798
the most common reference to `` wet stock ' ' was with the meanin ' that such animals had been smuggled across the rio grande after bein ' stolen from their rightful owners .	124.59773
the term soon became used and applied to all stolen animals .	443.65912
`` mixed herd ' ' meant a herd of mixed sexes , while a `` straight steer herd ' ' was one composed entirely of steers , and when the cowman spoke of `` mixed cattle ' ' , he meant cattle of various grades , ages , and sexes .	67.96454
in the spring when penned cattle were turned out to grass , this was spoken of as `` turn-out time ' ' , or `` put to grass ' ' .	69.32419
`` shootin ' ' em out ' ' was gettin ' cattle out of a corral onto the range .	157.32771
when a cow came out of a corral in a crouchin ' run she was said to `` come out a-stoopin ' ' ' .	75.84903
to stir cattle up and get ' em heated and excited was to `` mustard the cattle ' ' , and the act was called `` ginnin ' ' em ' round ' ' , or `` chousin ' ' em ' ' .	39.494785
after a roundup the pushin ' of stray cattle of outside brands toward their home range was called `` throwin ' over ' ' .	119.5426
a cow rose from the ground rear end first .	642.4875
by the time her hindquarters were in a standin ' position , her knees were on the ground in a prayin ' attitude .	239.30737
it was when she was in this position that the name `` prayin ' cow ' ' was suggested to the cowboy .	79.417305
they were said to be `` on their heads ' ' when grazin ' .	82.71843
`` on the hoof ' ' was a reference to live cattle and was also used in referrin ' to cattle travelin ' by trail under their own power as against goin ' by rail .	224.9155
shippin ' cattle by train was called a `` stock run ' ' .	27.018585
a general classification given grass-fed cattle was `` grassers ' ' .	5.695863
when a cowboy spoke of `` dustin ' ' ' a cow , he meant that he throwed dust into her eyes .	148.31363
the cow , unlike a bull or steer , kept her eyes open and her mind on her business when chargin ' , and a cow `` on the prod ' ' or `` on the peck ' ' was feared by the cowhand more than any of his other charges .	83.26093
the injun ' s name for beef was `` wohaw ' ' , and many of the old frontiersmen adopted it from their association with the injun on the trails .	75.70031
the first cattle the injuns saw under the white man ' s control were the ox teams of the early freighters .	93.25494
listenin ' with wonder at the strange words of the bullwhackers as they shouted `` whoa ' ' , `` haw ' ' , and `` gee ' ' , they thought them words the names of the animals , and began callin ' cattle `` wohaws ' ' .	39.019615
rarely did a trail herd pass through the injun country on its march north that it wasn ' t stopped to receive demand for `` wohaw ' ' .	136.42361
`` tailin ' ' ' was the throwin ' of an animal by the tail in lieu of a rope .	61.97301
any animal could when travelin ' fast , be sent heels over head by the simple process of overtakin ' the brute , seizin ' its tail , and givin ' the latter a pull to one side .	315.28577
this throwed the animal off balance , and over it ' d crash onto its head and shoulders .	144.61662
though the slightest yank was frequently capable of producin ' results , many men assured success through a turn of the tail ' bout the saddle horn , supplemented sometimes , in the case of cattle , by a downward heave of the rider ' s leg upon the strainin ' tail .	87.61572
such tactics were resorted to frequently with the unmanageable longhorns , and a thorough `` tailin ' ' ' usually knocked the breath out of a steer , and so dazed ' im that he ' d behave for the rest of the day .	48.29976
it required both a quick and swift hoss and a darin ' rider .	101.64246
when cattle became more valuable , ranch owners frowned upon this practice and it was discontinued , at least when the boss was ' round .	158.17389
when the cowboy used the word `` tailin ' s ' ' , he meant stragglers .	15.730974
`` bull tailin ' ' ' was a game once pop ' lar with the mexican cowboys of texas .	224.83336
from a pen of wild bulls one would be released , and with much yellin ' a cowhand ' d take after ' im .	149.24069
seizin ' the bull by the tail , he rushed his hoss forward and a little to one side , throwin ' the bull off balance , and `` bustin ' ' ' ' im with terrific force .	80.51957
rammin ' one horn of a downed steer into the ground to hold ' im down was called `` peggin ' ' ' .	73.522446
colors of cattle came in for their special names .	19.181086
an animal covered with splotches or spots of different colors was called a `` brindle ' ' or `` brockle ' ' .	55.94333
a `` lineback ' ' was an animal with a stripe of different color from the rest of its body runnin ' down its back , while a `` lobo stripe ' ' was the white , yeller , or brown stripe runnin ' down the back , from neck to tail , a characteristic of many spanish cattle .	99.25654
a `` mealynose ' ' was a cow or steer of the longhorn type , with lines and dots of a color lighter ' n the rest of its body ' round the eyes , face , and nose .	121.09173
such an animal was said to be `` mealynosed ' ' .	36.739616
`` sabinas ' ' was a spanish word used to describe cattle of red and white peppered and splotched colorin ' .	151.09122
the northern cowboy called all the red mexican cattle which went up the trail `` sonora reds ' ' , while they called all cattle drove up from mexico `` yaks ' ' , because they came from the yaqui injun country , or gave ' em the name of `` mexican buckskins ' ' .	58.03604
near the southern border , cattle of the early longhorn breed whose coloration was black with a lineback , with white speckles frequently appearin ' on the sides and belly , were called `` zorrillas ' ' .	113.759056
this word was from the spanish , meanin ' `` polecat ' ' .	53.0974
`` yeller bellies ' ' were cattle of mexican breed splotched on flank and belly with yellerish color .	101.161064
an animal with distinct coloration , or other marks easily distinguished and remembered by the owner and his riders , was sometimes used as a `` marker ' ' .	69.92046
such an animal has frequently been the downfall of the rustler .	14.7877445
countin ' each grazin ' bunch of cattle where it was found on the range and driftin ' it back so that it didn ' t mix with the uncounted cattle was called a `` range count ' ' .	57.704575
the countin ' of cattle in a pasture without throwin ' ' em together for the purpose was called a `` pasture count ' ' .	56.691906
the counters rode through the pasture countin ' each bunch of grazin ' cattle , and drifted it back so that it didn ' t get mixed with the uncounted cattle ahead .	86.1717
this method of countin ' was usually done at the request , and in the presence , of a representative of the bank that held the papers against the herd .	85.96473
them notes and mortgages were spoken of as `` cattle paper ' ' .	77.243774
a `` book count ' ' was the sellin ' of cattle by the books , commonly resorted to in the early days , sometimes much to the profit of the seller .	91.408585
this led to the famous sayin ' in the northwest of the `` books won ' t freeze ' ' .	29.500494
this became a common byword durin ' the boom days when eastern and foreign capital were so eager to buy cattle interests .	254.73372
the origin of this sayin ' was credited to a saloonkeeper by the name of luke murrin .	98.431625
his saloon was a meetin ' place for influential wyoming cattlemen , and one year durin ' a severe blizzard , when his herd-owner customers were wearin ' long faces , he said , `` cheer up , boys , whatever happens , the books won ' t freeze ' ' .	124.02412
in this carefree sentence he summed up the essence of the prevailin ' custom of buyin ' by book count , and created a sayin ' which has survived through the years .	221.73502
`` range delivery ' ' meant that the buyer , after examinin ' the seller ' s ranch records and considerin ' his rep ' tation for truthfulness , paid for what the seller claimed to own , then rode out and tried to find it .	206.96626
when a cowhand said that a man had `` good cow sense ' ' , he meant to pay ' im a high compliment .	96.94552
no matter by what name cattle were called , there was no denyin ' that they not only saved texas from financial ruin , but went far toward redeemin ' from a wilderness vast territories of the northwest .	189.25185
the first use of the word `` rustler ' ' was as a synonym for `` hustler ' ' , becomin ' an established term for any person who was active , pushin ' , and bustlin ' in any enterprise .	52.375595
again it was used as the title for the hoss wrangler , and when the order was given to go out and `` rustle the hosses ' ' , it meant for ' im to go out and herd ' em in .	80.267975
eventually herdin ' the hosses was spoken of as `` hoss rustlin ' ' ' , and the wrangler was called the `` hoss rustler ' ' .	25.68109
later , the word became almost exclusively applied to a cow thief , startin ' from the days of the maverick when cowhands were paid by their employers to `` get out and rustle a few mavericks ' ' .	99.60692
it was john who found the lion tracks .	13.244204
he found them near the carcass of a zebra that had been killed the night before , and he circled once , nose to the ground , hair shooting up along his back , as it did when he was after lion or bear , and then he lifted his head and bayed , and the pack joined in , all heads high , and jones knew it was a hot trail .	147.32732
he stifled the comanche yell and let john lead him straight toward the nearby black volcanic mountain .	170.91563
this mountain was known as the black reef and it rose almost perpendicularly for about two hundred feet , honeycombed with caves , top covered with dense scrub and creepers and tall grass .	84.88922
on the south it ended sharply as though the lava had been cut off there suddenly .	215.6206
kearton and ulyate had started the day together while jones followed the dogs , and means and loveless had taken another route , and now , with the discovery of the fresh trail still unknown to him , ulyate reined in , in the shadow of the reef and pointed .	118.68371
`` that ' s the colonel ' ' , he said , `` but i can ' t see the dogs ' ' .	17.251177
as they watched , jones rode straight for the reef .	10.28866
then they picked up the smaller black specks on the plain in front of him .	72.36526
the dogs were working a trail -- lion ? ?	44.032326
the pack had made a bend to the north , swinging back toward the reef , and kearton and ulyate could hear them faintly .	94.26713
kearton got off and tore up some dry grass that grew in cracks between the rocks and piled it in a heap and wanted to make the smoke signal that would bring loveless and means and the rest of the party .	103.206184
`` not yet ' ' , cautioned ulyate .	14.471979
jones came toward them fast , now , along the southern toe of the reef , and the dogs could be heard plainly , old john with his grand canyon voice outstanding above the others .	122.80502
there was sounder , too , also a veteran of the north rim , and rastus and the rake from a pack of english fox-hounds , and a collie from a london pound , and simba , a terrier .	103.224495
a motley pack , chosen for effectiveness , not beauty .	377.52008
jones was galloping close behind them leaning down , cheering them on .	179.2232
ulyate said , and kearton touched a match to the pile of grass , blew on it and flame licked out .	57.170753
he threw green stuff on it , and a thin blue column of smoke rose .	86.752266
`` that will fetch the gang and tell the colonel where we are ' ' .	86.00134
then there was a chorus of wild barking and baying .	6.292077
kearton and ulyate looked at each other and began to gallop toward the sound .	138.70935
it came from the top of the reef not half a mile away .	203.65797
at the base of the rocky hillside , they left their horses and climbed on foot .	108.57435
the route was choked with rugged lava-rocks , creepers and bushes , so thickly overgrown that when kearton lost sight of ulyate and called , ulyate answered from ten feet away .	199.4678
nice country to meet a lion in face to face .	14.274255
ulyate and kearton climbed on toward the sound of the barking of the dogs and the sporadic roaring of the lion , till they came , out of breath , to the crest , and peering through the branches of a bush , this is what ulyate saw jones who had apparently ( and actually had ) ridden up the nearly impassable hillside , sitting calmly on his horse within forty feet of a full-grown young lioness , who was crouched on a flat rock and seemed just about to charge him , while the dogs whirled around her .	136.92613
ulyate drew back with a start , and put finger to lips , almost afraid to move or whisper lest it set her off , `` the dogs have got her bayed .	275.29626
she ' s just the other side of that bush ' ' ! !	100.24344
and when they had drawn back a step he added `` jones is sitting on his horse right in front of her .	129.10904
why she doesn ' t charge him , i don ' t know .	13.641999
and he hasn ' t even got a knife on him .	161.87285
he couldn ' t get away from her in this kind of ground .	171.72945
careful , don ' t disturb her ' ' .	1.4603865
jones had been about a hundred and fifty feet from her when he first broke through to the top of the reef .	59.502766
she was standing on a flat rock three feet above ground and when she saw him she rose to full height and roared , opening her mouth wide , lashing her tail , and stamping at the rock with both forefeet in irritation , as much as to say `` how dare you disturb me in my sacred precinct ' ' ? ?	110.99165
intuition told him , however , that she was tired and winded from the run up the reef and would not charge , yet .	145.0188
he moved forward to within thirty-five feet of her , being careful , because he knew the female is less predictable than the male .	79.01581
( in the graveyard at nairobi he had been shown the graves of thirty-four big game hunters killed hunting the animals he was attempting to lasso .	201.96213
of the thirty-four , seventeen had been killed by lions , and eleven out of the seventeen by lionesses .	36.344387
) she snarled terribly but intuition told him , again , that she was bluffing , and he could see that half her attention was distracted by the dogs .	96.34683
it was falling over her head when a branch of a bush caught it and it fell in front of her on the rock .	169.37527
even then , if she took one step forward he could catch her .	205.05827
but john nipped her rear end -- one lion ' s rear end was as good as another to john , africa , arizona no matter -- and she changed ends and took a swipe at john , but he ducked back .	252.51852
jones then recoiled his rope and threw again , this time hitting her on the back but failing to encircle her .	230.47142
she whirled and faced him , roaring terribly , and ulyate , watching through the leaves , could not understand why she did not charge and obliterate him , because he wouldn ' t have much of a chance of getting away , in that thick growth , but she seemed just a trace uncertain	92.39082
while jones , on the other hand , appeared perfectly confident and ulyate decided perhaps that was the answer .	395.77316
from the lioness ' point of view , this strange creature on the back of another creature , lashing out with its long thin paw , very likely appeared as something she could not at first cope with .	149.84387
but now she sank lower to the rock .	7.530306
although she appeared more subdued and defeated , jones knew she was growing more dangerous .	146.9546
she was rested and could mount a charge .	27.838795
just the tip of her tail was moving as she crouched , and she was treading lightly up and down with her hind feet .	80.20481
at this moment , loveless and means arrived , crashing through the undergrowth with their horses , and distracted her , and she ran off a short distance and jumped into a crevice between two rocks .	44.44207
the dogs followed her and she killed three and badly wounded old john .	132.41336
`` we ' ve got to get her out of there ' ' ! !	43.397213
jones yelled , `` or she ' ll kill ' em all .	76.68338
for such an emergency he had included fourth-of-july cannon crackers as part of their equipment .	125.25789
lighting one he pitched it into the crevice , and the lioness left off mauling the dogs and departed .	98.78696
`` ain ' t she a beauty , though ' ' ? ?	13.480905
`` don ' t you go a step nearer her than i do ' ' , jones warned , `` and if you do , go at a run so you ' ll have momentum ' ' ! !	62.36092
for two hours they drove her from one strong point to another along the side of the reef , trying to maneuver her onto the plain where they could get a good throw .	141.82861
but she clung to the rocks and brush , and the day wore away .	62.08967
it was the story of the rhinoceros fight all over again .	225.67221
and the sun was beginning to go down .	11.577188
`` i ' ll get a pole ' ' , jones said finally , `` and i ' ll poke a noose over her head ' ' ! !	52.762516
at this moment she was crouched in a cave-like aperture halfway down the reef .	36.35008
ulyate made no comment but his face showed what he thought of poking ropes over lions ' heads with poles , and of course these were the lions of fifty years ago , not the gentler ones of today , and this one was angry , with good reason .	174.54994
`` it won ' t work , colonel ' ' .	14.938383
`` just the same we ' ll try it ' ' .	4.3915505
but without waiting for them to try it , she scattered the dogs and shot down the reef and out across the plain .	96.395134
john led the chase after her and the other dogs strung out behind , many of them trailing blood .	198.35391
john himself was bruised and clawed from head to tail , but he was in this fight to the finish , running almost as strongly now as in the morning .	81.17543
she took refuge on a tongue of land extending into a gully , crouched at the base of a thorn tree , and waited for them to come up .	38.699337
with the gully on three sides , she could be approached only along the tongue of land .	109.15293
`` careful , now ' ' , jones warned .	8.562835
very slowly he maneuvered his rawboned bay gelding , edging closer , watching for a chance to throw , but ready to spin and run , rope whining about his head , horse edging tensely under him , but the gelding was obedient and responded and was not paralyzed by the close proximity of the lion .	87.20504
they tell you horses go crazy at the sight or smell of a bear or a lion , but these didn ' t .	76.71926
again she snarled , and again he edged .	14.539591
with a whirling jump , it could get into gear .	238.34134
however nothing on four legs was supposed to be faster than a lion over a short distance , unless it was a cheetah .	72.13736
she was closing and within one more bound would have been able to reach the rear end of the bay , but -- and here jones and loveless and ulyate were holding breath for all they were worth -- she never quite caught up that last bound .	122.93239
means held steady one jump ahead of her .	12.83959
a western cowpony had outrun an african lion , from a standing start .	74.87751
photos showed later that she ' d been about six feet from means .	178.27565
of course the factor of head start made all the difference .	77.42461
the lioness quickly changed front , when she saw she couldn ' t catch means , and made for jones .	56.558037
as she had done with means , she gained rapidly at first , but then baldy began to draw away .	260.0778
somewhere in the few scant yards of head start was the determining point .	147.8837
when jones too drew away , she returned to a thorn bush in the neck of land running into the gully , crouched low and waited as before .	70.95496
this new position , however , gave the ropers a better chance .	923.8043
there was room to make a quick dash past the bush and throw as you went .	191.02371
so means edged around on the north side of her , jones moved in from the south .	88.3556
tossing his rope and shouting he attracted her attention .	17.838348
he succeeded almost too well , because once she rose as if to charge , and he half wheeled his horse -- he was within fifty feet -- but she sank back .	140.30486
from behind her means shot forward at a run .	275.34802
kearton began shouting , `` wait , wait -- the camera ' s jammed ' ' ! !	32.158627
he raced by within twenty feet of her , roped her around the neck , but a lioness ' neck is short and thick and with a quick twist she slipped the noose off .	125.92136
the missionary obligation to proclaim the gospel to all the world was once left to zealous individuals and voluntary societies .	104.319176
but the time came when a church that had no part in the missionary movement was looked upon as deficient in its essential life .	116.47694
the christian education of children , too , was once hardly more than a sideshow , but the day came when a congregation that did not assume full oversight of a church school was thought of as failing in its duty .	110.15516
the most serious weakness of the ecumenical movement today is that it is generally regarded as the responsibility of a few national leaders in each denomination and a few interdenominational executives .	75.82881
most pastors and laymen , even though they believe it to be important , assume that the ecumenical movement lies outside the province of their parishes .	98.33827
they may even dismiss it from their minds as something that concerns only the `` ecclesiastical rover boys ' ' , as someone has dubbed them , who like to go to national and international assemblies , and have expense accounts that permit them to do so .	103.17184
as long as this point of view prevails , the ecumenical movement will be lame and halt .	31.113455
the next stage ahead is that of making it thoroughly at home in the local community .	77.09941
progress will take place far less through what is done in any `` summit conference ' ' of the national council or the world council , or even in offices of the denominational boards , than through what happens in the communities where christian people live together as neighbors .	89.36807
the front line of advance is where witnessing and worshiping congregations of different traditions exist side by side .	319.44067
until they see the ecumenical movement in terms of the difference it makes in their own attitudes , programs , and relationships , it will have an inevitable aspect of unreality .	90.280815
as things now stand , there is a grievous disparity between the unity in christ which we profess in ecumenical meetings and the complacent separateness of most congregations on any main street in the nation .	138.2752
the crux of ecumenical advance is an even more personalized matter than the relation between congregations in the same community .	85.48194
the decisive question is what happens within each congregation and , finally , in the minds and hearts of the individual members .	66.21038
it is here that the local and ecumenical must meet .	265.18243
it is here that the ecumenical must become local and the local become ecumenical .	244.25117
it has become almost trite to say that the ecumenical movement must be `` carried down to the grass roots ' ' .	41.929996
this way of describing the matter is unfortunate .	6.2816167
one is that whatever is ecumenical has to do with some over-all organization at `` the top ' ' and needs only to be understood at the so-called `` lower levels ' ' .	131.75595
the truth , however , is that the ecumenical church is just the local church in its own true character as an integral unit of the whole people of god throughout the world .	90.47491
the other misconception is that our ecumenical problems will be solved if only the knowledge of the church in its world-wide extension and its interdenominational connections , now comprehended by many national leaders , can be communicated to all congregations .	78.62651
however needed this may be , the fundamental problem is not information but active commitment to the total mission of the church of christ in the world .	43.10538
the basic unit in the church , of whatever denominational polity , is always the congregation .	96.29048
it is hardly possible to emphasize this too much .	13.003167
most people do not realize that the congregation , as a gathered fellowship meeting regularly face to face , personally sharing in a common experience and expressing that experience in daily relationships with one another , is unique .	160.1445
the idea that it is a feature of all religions is entirely mistaken .	129.88867
the jewish synagogue affords a parallel to the christian congregation , but hinduism , buddhism , islam , confucianism , taoism , shintoism , although they have sacred scriptures , priests , spiritual disciplines , and places of prayer , do not have a congregation as a local household of faith and love .	102.783035
