their characteristic experience is that of the individual at an altar or a shrine rather than that of a continuing social group with a distinctive kind of fellowship .	89.95727
how far the fellowship in most local churches falls below what the new testament means by koinonia ! !	168.68558
what is now called christian fellowship is often little more than the social chumminess of having a gracious time with the kind of people one likes .	190.94601
the koinonia of acts and of the epistles means sharing in a common relation to christ .	146.55545
it is an experience of a new depth of community derived from an awareness of the corporate indwelling of christ in his people .	60.934025
as dietrich bonhoffer puts it , `` our community with one another consists solely in what christ has done to both of us ' ' .	171.55717
this may mean having fellowship in the church with people with whom , on the level of merely human agreeableness , we might prefer not to have any association at all .	148.57545
there is a vast difference between the community of reconciliation which the new testament describes and the community of congeniality found in the average church building .	144.53362
whenever a congregation really sees itself as a unit in the universal church , in vital relation with the whole body of christ and participating in his mission to the world , a necessary foundation-stone of the ecumenical movement has been laid .	86.731834
the antithesis of the ecumenical and the local then no longer exists .	479.80734
of course , the perspective of those who are dealing directly with the world-wide problems of the people of god will always be different from the perspective of those who are dealing with the nearby problems of particular persons in a particular place .	58.568005
each viewpoint is valid if it is organically related to the other .	55.410683
our difficulty arises when either viewpoint shuts out the other .	55.81684
and this is what all too often happens .	18.310406
a little parable illustrative of this truth is afforded by an incident related by professor bela vasady at the end of the second world war .	66.20103
with great difficulty he made his way from his native hungary to geneva to renew his contacts as a member of the provisional committee for the world council of churches .	57.850952
when he had the mishap of breaking his spectacles , his ecumenical colleagues insisted on providing him with new ones .	107.20447
he often spoke of them as his `` ecumenical ' ' glasses and used them as a symbol of the kind of vision that is required in the church .	84.49265
it is , he said , a bifocal vision , which can see both the near-at-hand and the distant and keep a christian in right relation to both .	200.89417
as things stand now , the local and the ecumenical tend to compete with each other .	90.62897
on the one hand , there are ecumenists who are so stirred by the crises of the church in its encounter with the world at large that they have no eyes for what the church is doing in their own town .	89.93578
they do not escape the pitfall into which charles dickens pictured mrs . jellyby as falling .	177.72658
her concern for the natives of borrioboola-gha was so intense that she quite forgot and neglected her son peepy ! !	273.64734
likewise , the ecumenist may become so absorbed in the conflict of the church with the totalitarian state in east germany , the precarious situation of the church in revolutionary china , and the anguish of the church over apartheid in south africa that he loses close contact with the parish church in its unspectacular but indispensable ministry of worship , pastoral service and counseling , and christian nurture for a face-to-face group of individuals .	63.3137
on the other hand , many a pastor is so absorbed in ministering to the intimate , personal needs of individuals in his congregation that he does little or nothing to lead them into a sense of social responsibility and world mission .	180.46762
as a result , they go on thinking of the church , with introverted and self-centered satisfaction , only in connection with the way in which it serves them and their families .	60.56637
it would hardly be an exaggeration to say that ninety per cent of the energy of most churches -- whether in terms of finance or spiritual concern -- is poured into the private and domestic interests of the members .	123.472755
the parish lives for itself rather than for the community or the world .	37.696316
the gap between the ecumenical perspective and the parish perspective appears most starkly in a church in any of our comfortable suburbs .	185.13364
it is eminently successful according to all conventional standards .	15.678591
its preaching and its music give refreshment of spirit to men and women living under heavy strain .	68.704
it provides pastoral care for the sick and troubled .	66.51476
it helps children grow up with at least a nodding acquaintance with the bible .	51.47276
it draws young people into the circle of those who continue the life of the church from generation to generation .	94.814766
and it is easy for the ecumenical enthusiast to lose sight of how basic all this is .	196.34164
but what is this church doing to help its members understand their roles as christians in the world ? ?	89.961044
all too often its conception of parish ministry and pastoral care includes no responsibility for them in their relation to issues of the most desperate urgency for the life of mankind .	66.0689
it is not stirring them to confront the racial tensions of today with the mind of christ .	70.274895
it is not helping them face the moral crisis involved in the use of nuclear energy .	62.41063
it is not making them sensitive to the sub-christian level of much of our economic and industrial life .	224.27165
it is raising no disturbing question as to what christian stewardship means for the relationship of the richest nation in the world to economically underdeveloped peoples .	96.83607
it is not developing an awareness of the new kind of missionary strategy that is called for as young churches emerge in asia and africa .	132.89987
to put it bluntly , many a local church is giving its members only what they consciously want .	124.677605
it is not disturbing them by thoughts of their christian responsibility in relation to the world .	50.24124
we shall not make a decisive advance in the ecumenical movement until such a church begins to see itself not merely as a haven of comfort and peace but as a base of christian witness and mission to the world .	132.48221
there is a humorous but revealing story about a rancher who owned a large slice of texas and who wanted to have on it everything that was necessary for a completely pleasant community .	82.49289
he built a school and a library , then a recreation center and an inn .	91.81944
desiring to fill the only remaining lack , he selected the best site on the ranch for a chapel and spared no expense in erecting it .	103.33308
a visitor to the beautiful little building inquired , `` do you belong to this church , mr . rancher ' ' ? ?	49.85849
`` why , no , ma ' am ' ' , he replied , `` this church belongs to me ' ' ! !	23.610525
the story reflects the way too many people feel .	214.26819
as long as the congregation regards the church as `` our ' ' church , or the minister thinks of it as `` my ' ' church , just so long the ecumenical movement will make no significant advance .	80.59148
there must first be a deeper sense that the church belongs not to us but to christ , and that it is his purpose , not our own interests and preferences , that determines what it is to be and do .	66.01027
a local church which conceives its function to be entirely that of ministering to the conscious desires and concerns of its members tends to look on everything ecumenical as an extra , not as a normal aspect of its own life as a church .	135.36131
it would doubtless be greatly surprised to be told that in failing to be ecumenical it is really failing to be the church of christ .	185.69647
yet the truth , according to the new testament , is that every local church has its existence only by being the embodiment of the whole church in that particular place .	178.94293
yet a crowd came out to see some fresh kids from the city try to match the boys from the neighboring farms	144.61159
and buggies and wagons and chugging fords kept gathering all morning , until the edges of the field were packed thick and small boys kept scampering out on the playing field to make fun of the visitors -- whose pitcher was a formidable looking young man with the only baseball cap .	194.58438
this was a bitterly fought game , carrying almost as much grudge as a fist fight , with no friendliness exhibited between the teams except the formal politeness that accompanied the setting forth of ground rules and agreements on balls that went into the crowd .	195.26355
every pitch in the game brought forth a howl from the enraptured audience and every fly ball the visitors dropped ( and because their right fielder was still a little fuzzy from drink , they dropped many ) called forth yelps of derision .	285.58838
at one point in the game when the skinny old man in suspenders who was acting as umpire got in the way of a thrown ball and took it painfully in the kidneys , he lay there unattended while players and spectators wrangled over whether the ball was `` dead ' ' or the base runners were free to score .	155.02217
this was typical of such games , which were earnestly played to win and practically never wound up in an expression of good fellowship .	132.01097
when the visitors , after losing this game , rode along the village streets toward home , the youngsters who could keep abreast of them for a moment or two screamed triumphantly , `` you bunch of hay-shakers ! !	143.01694
baseball was surely the national game in those days , even though professional baseball may have been merely a business .	162.8185
radio broadcasts had not begun and most devotees of baseball attended the games near home , in the town park or a pasture , with perhaps two or three trips to the city each season to see the cubs or the pirates or the indians or the red sox .	110.89574
young men in school could look forward to playing ball for money in a dozen different places , even if they failed to make the major leagues .	63.469738
nearly any lad with a modicum of skill might find a payday awaiting him in the three i league , or the pony league , or the coastal plains league , or the fast eastern league , if not indeed in one of the hundreds of city leagues that abounded everywhere .	163.62357
even a city of thirty thousand might have six baseball teams , sponsored by grocers and hardware merchants or department stores , that played two or three times a week throughout the summer , usually in the cool of the evening , before an earnest and partisan audience who did not begrudge a quarter each , or even more , to be dropped into a hat when the game was half over .	120.15942
babe ruth , of course , was everyone ' s hero , and everyone knew him , even though relatively few ever saw him play ball .	114.296646
his face was always in the newspapers , sometimes in cartoons that seemed nearly as large as life .	668.8944
as the twenties grew older , and as radio broadcasts of baseball games began to involve more and more people daily in the doings of the professionals , the great hitters ( always led by babe ruth ) overshadowed the game so that pitchers were nearly of no account .	117.64443
boys no longer bothered learning to bunt and even school kids scorned to `` choke up ' ' on a bat as willie keeler and the famous hitters of another day had done .	132.38016
other hitters bloomed with more or less vigor in the news and a few even dared to dream of matching ruth , who was still called jidge by all his friends , or leo or two-head by those who dared to taunt him ( leo was the name of the ball player he liked the least ) and who called most of the world `` kid ' ' .	138.4581
lou gehrig was given the nickname buster , and he ran ruth a close race in home runs .	54.527954
but the nickname never stuck and gehrig was no match for ruth in `` color ' ' -- which is sometimes a polite word for delinquent behavior on and off the field .	131.98402
ruth was a delinquent boy still , but he was in every way a great ball player who was out to win the game and occasionally risked a cracked bone to do it .	102.87757
a few professional baseball players cultivated eccentricities , with the encouragement of the press , so that they might see their names in big black print , along with daddy browning ' s , al capone ' s , earl sande ' s , and the prince of wales ' .	46.034344
one who , for a time , succeeded best and was still the sorriest of all was charles arthur shires , who called himself , in the newspapers , art the great , or the great shires .	140.23596
it was his brag that he could beat everybody at anything , but especially at fighting , and he once took on the manager of his club and worked him over thoroughly with his fists .	113.61437
he was given to public carousing and to acting the clown on the diamond	215.82416
and a policeman asserted he had found a pair of brass knuckles in art ' s pocket once when he had occasion to collar the great first baseman for some forgotten reason .	109.85774
( this made a sportswriter named pegler wonder in print if art had worn this armament when he defeated his manager .	339.77795
) the sorry fact about this young man , who was barely of age when he broke into major-league baseball , was that he really was a better ball player than he was given credit for being -- never so good as he claimed , and always an irritant to his associates , but a good steady performer when he could fight down the temptation to orate on his skills or cut up in public .	126.183365
in his minor way charles arthur shires was perhaps more typical of his era than ruth was , for he was but one of many young men who laid waste their talents in these scott fitzgerald days for the sake of earning space in the newspapers .	111.089455
there were others who climbed flagpoles and refused to come down	59.680225
or who ingested strange objects , like live fish	191.76376
or who undertook to set records for remaining erect on a dance floor , with or without a partner	102.32214
or who essayed to down full bottles of illicit gin without pausing for breath .	89.89493
one young man , exhilarated to the point of insanity by liquor and the excitement of the moment , performed a perfect swan dive out of the stands at the yale bowl during the yale-army football game , landed squarely on his head on the concrete ramp below , and died at once .	93.35945
but the twenties were not all insanity and a striving after recognition .	238.75015
the business of baseball began to prosper along with other entertainments , and performers -- thanks partly to george herman ruth ' s spectacular efforts each season to run his salary higher and higher -- prospered too .	183.8148
while fifty years before , albert goodwill spalding , secretary of the chicago ball club of the national league , could write earnestly to the manager of the buffalo club and request a guarantee of one hundred dollars for a baseball game in august , in this golden era a game at the yankee stadium might bring in nearly a hundred thousand dollars at the gate .	98.50572
and while less than ten years earlier the wayward black sox -- all of them top performers in their positions -- had toiled for stingy charles comiskey at salaries ranging from twenty-five hundred dollars to forty-five hundred dollars a year , stars now were asking ten thousand dollars , twenty thousand dollars , yes , even fifty thousand dollars a season .	130.12784
the greatest team of this period was unquestionably the new york yankees , bought by brewery millions and made into a ball club by men named ed barrow and miller huggins .	254.43352
boston fans sometimes liked to wring some wry satisfaction out of the fact that most of the great 1923-27 crew were graduates of the red sox -- sold to millionaires huston and ruppert by a man who could not deny them their most trifling desire .	95.67622
ruth himself , still owning his farm in massachusetts and an interest in the massachusetts cigar business that printed his round boyish face on the wrappers , had led the parade down from fenway park , followed by pitchers carl mays , leslie `` joe ' ' bush , waite hoyt , herb pennock , and sam jones , catcher wally schang , third baseman joe dugan ( who completed the `` playboy trio ' ' of ruth , dugan , and hoyt ) , and shortstop everett scott .	98.76788
by 1926 , when the mighty yanks were at their mightiest , only a few of these were left but they still shone brightest , even beside able and agile rookies like tony lazzeri ( who managed never to have one of his epileptic fits on the field ) , mark koenig , lou gehrig , george pipgras , and gray-thatched earl combs .	142.12915
the deeds of this team , through two seasons and in the two world ' s series that followed , have been written and talked about until hardly a word is left to be said .	128.76663
but there is one small episode that a few new york fans who happened to sit in the cheap seats for one world ' s series game in 1926 like best to recall .	109.62671
babe ruth , as he always did in the stadium , played right field to avoid having the sun in his eyes , and tommy thevenow , a rather mediocre hitter who played shortstop for the st . louis cardinals , knocked a ball with all his might into the sharp angle formed by the permanent stands and the wooden bleachers , where ruth could not reach it .	118.46806
the ball lay there , shining white on the grass in view of nearly every fan in the park while ruth , red-necked with frustration , charged about the small patch of ground screaming , `` where ' s the -- -ing ball ' ' ? ?	138.56245
but , as he snarled unhappily when the inning was over , `` not a sonofabitch in the place would tell me ' ' , so little tommy ran all the way home .	107.37104
the ordinary man and woman , however , saw little of the great professional games of those golden days , or of any other sporting event for that matter .	158.08076
promoters always hastened to place their choice tickets in the hands of the wealthy speculators , and only the man who knew the man who knew the fellow who had an in with the guy at the box office ever came up with a good seat for a contest of any importance .	70.02376
radio broadcasts , however -- now that even plain people could afford `` loud speakers ' ' on their sets -- held old fans to the major-league races and attracted new ones , chiefly women , who through what the philosopher called the ineluctable modality of audition , became first inured , then attracted , then addicted to the long afternoon recitals of the doings in some distant baseball park .	191.5964
in some cities games were broadcast throughout the week and then on weekends the announcer was silenced , and fans must needs drive to the city from all the broadcast area to discover how their heroes were faring .	170.73625
this had a pleasant effect upon the sunday gate receipts as well as upon the intake of the rail and bus companies , some of which began to offer special excursion rates , including seats at the park , just as the trolley and ferry companies had when baseball was new .	125.78993
while women had always attended ball games in small numbers ( it was the part of a `` dead game sport ' ' in the early years of the twentieth century to be taken out to the ball park and to root , root , root for the home team ) , they had often sat in patient martyrdom , unable even to read the scoreboard , which sometimes seemed to indicate that one team led another by a score of three hundred and eighty to one hundred and fifty-one .	94.10764
the questions women asked at baseball games were standard grist for amateur comedy , as were the doings of women automobile drivers	281.58685
for every grown man ( except a few who were always suspected of being shy on virility ) knew at least the fundamentals of baseball , just as every male american in this era liked to imagine ( or pretend ) that he could fight with his fists .	190.61943
and women were not expected to know that the pitcher was trying not to let the batter hit the ball .	50.327335
radio , however , so increased the interest of women in the game that it was hardly necessary even to have `` ladies ' days ' ' any longer to enable men to get to the ball park without interference at home .	122.382256
women actually began to appear unaccompanied in the stands , where they still occasionally ran the risk of coming home with a tobacco-juice stain on a clean skirt or a new curse word tingling their ears .	103.381134
the radio broadcasts themselves were often so patiently informative , despite the baseball jargon , that girls and women could begin to store up in their minds the same sort of random and meaningless statistics that small boys had long learned better than they ever did their lessons in school .	161.68924
this conclusion is dependent on the assumption that traditional sex mores will continue to sanction both premarital chastity as the `` ideal ' ' , and the double standard holding females primarily responsible for preserving the ideal .	136.88554
our discussion of this involves using erik erikson ' s schema of `` identity vs . identity diffusion ' ' as a conceptual tool in superimposing a few common denominators onto the diverse personality and family configurations of the unwed mothers from whose case histories we quoted earlier .	98.73351
our discussion does not utilize all the identity crises postulated by erikson , but is intended to demonstrate the utility of his theoretical schema for studying unwed mothers .	71.60957
we hope thereby to emphasize that , from a psychological standpoint , the effectual prevention of illegitimacy is a continuous long-term process involving the socialization of the female from infancy through adolescence .	50.4158
hypothesizing a series of developmental stages that begin in the individual ' s infancy and end in his old age , erikson has indicated that the adolescent is faced with a series of identity crises .	72.944725
the successful and positive resolution of these crises during adolescence involves an epigenetic principle -- during adolescence , the individual ' s positive resolutions in each area of identity crisis depend , to a considerable degree , on his already having resolved preliminary and preparatory identity crises during his infancy , childhood , and early adolescence .	165.4405
within erikson ' s schema , the adolescent ' s delinquent behavior -- in this case , her unwed motherhood -- reflects her `` identity diffusion ' ' , or her inability to resolve these various identity crises positively .	88.04874
the adolescent experiences identity crises in terms of time perspective vs . time diffusion .	99.281105
time perspective -- the ability to plan for the future and to postpone gratifying immediate wants in order to achieve long-range objectives -- is more easily developed if , from infancy on , the individual has been able to rely on and trust people and the world in which she lives .	132.38445
erikson has noted that , unless this trust developed early , the time ambivalence experienced , in varying degree and temporarily , by all adolescents ( as a result of their remembering the more immediate gratification of wants during childhood , while not yet having fully accepted the long-range planning required by adulthood ) may develop into a more permanent sense of time diffusion .	233.38994
experience of this time diffusion ranges from a sense of utter apathy to a feeling of desperate urgency to act immediately .	61.839996
these polar extremes in time diffusion were indicated in some of the comments by unwed mothers reported in earlier chapters .	85.32979
some of these mothers , apparently feeling a desperate urgency , made , on the spur of the moment , commitments , in love and sex , that would have life-long consequences .	66.23343
others displayed utter apathy and indifference to any decision about the past or the future .	102.426315
for many of these unwed mothers , the data on their family life and early childhood experiences revealed several indications and sources of their basic mistrust of their parents in particular and of the world in general .	139.58943
however , as erickson has noted , the individual ' s failure to develop preliminary identities during infancy and childhood need not be irreversibly deterministic with respect to a given area of identity diffusion in his ( or her ) adolescence .	102.114655
and , as shown in chapter 6 , , some snp females originally developed such trust only during their adolescence , through the aid of , and their identification with , alter-parents .	284.28052
in the specific case of time diffusion , we must emphasize the significance of the earlier development of mistrust when it is combined with the inevitable time crisis experienced by most ( if not all ) adolescents in our society , and with the failure of the adolescent period to provide opportunities for developing trust .	160.15991
the adolescent experiences two closely related crises self-certainty vs . an identity consciousness	108.126045
a sense of self-certainty and the freedom to experiment with different roles , or confidence in one ' s own unique behavior as an alternative to peer-group conformity , is more easily developed during adolescence if , during early childhood , the individual was permitted to exercise initiative and encouraged to develop some autonomy .	118.47004
however , if the child has been constantly surrounded , during nursery and early school age , by peer groups	393.6522
inculcated with the primacy of group acceptance and group standards	2708.6233
and allowed little initiative in early play and work patterns -- then in adolescence her normal degree of vanity , sensitivity , and preoccupation with whether others find her appearance and behavior acceptable , will be compounded .	171.67198
her ostensible indifference to and rebellion against suggestions and criticisms by anyone except peer friends during adolescence are the manifestations , in her adolescence , of her having been indoctrinated in childhood to feel shame , if not guilt , for failing to behave in a manner acceptable to , and judged by , the performance of her nursery- and elementary-school peer friends .	118.032364
to be different is to invite shame and doubt	97.939705
and it is better to be shamed and criticized by one ' s parents , who already consider one different and difficult to understand , than by one ' s peers , who are also experiencing a similar groping for and denial of adult status .	136.06564
the attitudes of some unwed mothers quoted in chapter 2 , , revealed both considerable preoccupation with being accepted by others and a marked absence of self-certainty .	151.47932
many appeared to regard their sexual behavior as a justifiable means of gaining acceptance from and identification with others	125.36197
but very few seemed aware that such acceptance and identification need to be supplemented with more enduring and stable identification of and with one ' s self .	96.90854
another identity crisis confronting the adolescent involves anticipation of achievement vs . work-paralysis .	136.33543
the adolescent ' s capacity to anticipate achievement and to exercise the self-discipline necessary to complete tasks successfully depends on the degree to which he or she developed autonomy , initiative , and self-discipline during childhood .	100.02948
the developmental process involves the individual ' s progressively experiencing a sense of dignity and achievement resulting from having completed tasks , having kept commitments , and having created something ( however small or simple -- even a doll dress of one ' s own design rather than in the design `` it ought to be ' ' ) .	193.00476
these childhood experiences are sources of the self-certainty that the adolescent needs , for experimenting with many roles , and for the freedom to fail sometimes in the process of exploring and discovering her skills and abilities .	77.633705
if she has not had such experiences , the female ' s normal adolescent degree of indecision will be compounded .	122.01639
she may well be incapacitated by it when she is confronted with present and future alternatives -- e . g . , whether to prepare primarily for a career or for the role of a homemaker	148.73615
whether to stay financially dependent on her parents or help support herself while attending school	369.0975
whether to pursue a college education or a job after high school	160.85641
and whether to attend this or that college and to follow this or that course of study .	237.37964
erikson has noted that , as this indecision mounts , it may result in a `` paralysis of workmanship ' ' .	27.705282
this paralysis may be expressed in the female ' s starting -- and never completing -- many jobs , tasks , and courses of study	213.76161
and in the fact that she bases her decisions about work , college , carreer , and studies on what others are doing , rather than on her own sense of identity with given skills , abilities , likes , and dislikes .	107.60044
the absence , during her childhood and early adolescence , of experiences in developing the self-discipline to complete tasks within her ability -- experiences that would have been subsequent sources of anticipation of achievement -- and her lack of childhood opportunities to practice autonomy and initiative in play and expression , both tend in her adolescence to deprive her of the freedoms to role-experiment and to fail occasionally in experimenting .	142.5316
the comments made by some unwed mothers ( quoted in chapter 2 ) ) reflect this paralysis of workmanship .	137.17697
they attended school and selected courses primarily on the basis of decisions others made	134.81172
they accepted a job primarily because it was available , convenient , and paid reasonably .	74.88508
these things both express and , at the same time , continue contributing to , their identity diffusion in an area that could have become a source of developing dignity and self-certainty .	95.32462
as their identity diffusion increased , they became more susceptible to sporadic diversions in love and sexual affairs .	154.38142
these affairs temporarily relieved the monotony of school or work activities containing no anticipation of achievement and joy of craftsmanship , no sense of dignity derived from a job well done .	127.188736
childhood experiences in learning work and self-discipline habits within a context of developing autonomy and initiative have considerable significance for the prevention of illegitimacy .	51.577557
the excerpts from case histories presented above confirm this significance , though through different facets of experience .	102.83143
for example , some unwed mothers had had no work experiences , household chores , and responsibilities during childhood and early adolescence	172.02179
they subsequently occupied their leisure hours in searching for something exciting and diverting .	346.29123
on the other hand , some unwed mothers had had so much work and responsibility imposed on them at an early age , and had thus had so little freedom or opportunity to develop autonomy and initiative , that their work and responsibilities became dull and unrewarding burdens -- to be escaped and rebelled against through fun and experimentation with forbidden sexual behavior .	187.90889
the adolescent also faces the identity crisis that erikson has termed ideological polarization vs . diffusion of ideals .	72.55492
in discussing the ways this crisis is germane to consderations for the prevention of illegitimacy , we shall again superimpose erikson ' s concept on our data .	67.21611
adolescents have a much-discussed tendency to polarize ideas and values , to perceive things as `` either-or ' ' , black or white -- nuances of meaning are relatively unimportant .	65.20176
this tendency is , perhaps , most clearly revealed in the literature on religious conversions and experiences of adolescents .	129.31062
erikson has postulated that such ideological polarization temporarily resolves their search for something stable and definite in the rapidly changing and fluctuating no-man ' s-land between childhood and adulthood .	142.46562
it provides identification -- with an idea , a value , a cause that cuts through , or even transcends , the multiple and ambivalent identities of their passage from child to adult , and permits their forceful and overt expression of emotion .	141.05798
the positive development , during adolescence , of this capacity to think and to feel strongly and with increasing independence , and to identify overtly either with or against given ideas , values , and practices , depends to a considerable degree on both previous and present opportunities for developing autonomy , initiative , and self-certainty .	159.38329
most adolescents have some ideological diffusion at various developmental stages , as they experience a proliferation of ideas and values .	37.002342
the diffusion is most pronounced and most likely to become fixed , however , in those who have had no or very minimal opportunities to develop the autonomy and initiative that could have been directed into constructive expression and so served as sources of developing self-certainty .	109.28699
a pronounced ideological diffusion -- i . e . , inability to identify independently with given ideas and value systems -- is reflected in many ways .	86.94471
for example , it is evinced by the adolescent ( or adult ) whose beliefs and actions represent primarily his rebellion and reaction against the ideas and behavior patterns of others , rather than his inner conviction and choice .	277.22403
it is mirrored by the individual willie lohmans , whose ideas and behavior patterns are so dependent and relativistic that they always coincide with those of the individual or group present and most important at the moment .	99.43162
in another sense , it is represented in the arguments of the `` true believers ' ' who seek to disprove the validity of all other beliefs and ideas in order to retain confidence in theirs .	59.8406
the case histories provide some interesting illustrations of ideological diffusion , embodied in the unwed mother ' s inability to identify independently a given value system or behavior pattern , , and her subsequent disinclination to assume any individual responsibility for her sexual behavior .	105.17577
for example , the unwed mothers expressed their frustration with males who did not indicate more explicitly `` what it is they really want from a girl so one can act accordingly ' ' .	128.59937
they were disappointed by the physical and emotional hurt of premarital sexual intercourse .	87.41854
they condemned the movie script writers for implying that sex was enjoyable and exhilarating .	77.5343
they criticized parents for never having emphasized traditional concepts of right and wrong	86.49077
and they censured parents who `` never disciplined and were too permissive ' ' or who `` never explained how easy it was to get pregnant ' ' .	93.55954
in the adult world , there are a number of rather general and diffuse sources of ideological diffusion that further compound the adolescent ' s search for meaning during this particular identity crisis .	113.35294
for example , some contemporary writing tends to fuse the `` good guys ' ' and the `` bad guys ' ' , to portray the weak people as heroes and weakness as a virtue , and to explain ( or even justify ) asocial behavior by attributing it to deterministic psychological , familial , and social experiences .	65.36927
in the final accounting , these would have augmented the bill for both sides .	173.84192
an estimate of one million dollars is probably not excessive .	52.946373
yet the huge amount of money consumed by the selden litigation , which many regarded as wasteful , indirectly contributed to constructive changes in legal procedure .	220.12079
the duration and other circumstances of the selden case made it a flagrant example of the gross abuses of patent infringement actions .	83.982
the suit , as we have seen , came before the courts when patent attorneys , inventors , and laymen were making mounting demands for reforms in the american patent system .	95.87466
chief among the defects they singled out were the complicated and wearisome procedures in equity .	66.61348
in a long and angry footnote to his opinion , judge hough had lent the weight of judicial condemnation to such criticism .	92.22225
`` it is a duty ' ' , said hough , `` not to let pass this opportunity of protesting against the methods of taking and printing testimony in equity , current in this circuit ( and probably others ) , excused if not justified by the rules of the supreme court , especially to be found in patent causes , and flagrantly exemplified in this litigation .	75.136314
as long as the bar prefers to adduce evidence by written deposition , rather than viva voce before an authoritative judicial officer , i fear that the antiquated rules will remain unchanged , and expensive prolixity remain the best known characteristic of equity ' ' .	131.19562
observing that `` reforms sometimes begin with the contemplation of horrible examples ' ' , hough catalogued the many abuses encouraged by existing procedures .	160.4194
he cited the elephantine dimensions of the selden case record	3468.4348
the `` objections stated at outrageous length ' '	1.313991
and the frequent and rancorous verbal bouts , `` uncalled for and unjustifiable , from the retort discourteous to the lie direct ' ' .	149.82874
the fundamental difficulty of which the selden case was `` a striking ( though not singular ) example ' ' , concluded hough , `` will remain as long as testimony is taken without any authoritative judicial officer present , and responsible for the maintenance of discipline , and the reception or exclusion of testimony ' ' .	123.11548
not least among the members of the patent bar who echoed this powerful indictment were those who had participated in the selden suit .	90.55234
william a . redding asserted that if the case had been heard in open court under rules of evidence , the testimony would have been completed in sixty days instead of five years .	92.46125
inventors joined lawyers in the clamor for reform , inevitably centering upon the selden litigation as a `` horrible example ' ' .	47.396557
its costive deliberations were likened to those of the british courts of chancery mercilessly caricatured by dickens in bleak house .	108.84052
parker , who agreed with much of this criticism , did not conceal his dissatisfaction with procedural defects .	81.68655
but he felt that the selden case was being unfairly pilloried .	242.5009
in a detailed letter published in the scientific american in 1912 , he remarked that `` loose statements ' ' about the case showed scant understanding of the facts .	107.169
the suit , although commonly designated as a single action , actually embraced five cases .	382.66858
parker insisted that the size of the record would have been drastically reduced but for an unavoidable duplication of testimony .	91.6253
in a private communication written in 1911 , parker had been more to the point .	100.5562
noting the complaints of inventors and members of the patent bar , he admitted that some of the strictures `` were fairly well founded ' ' , but he added that under existing rules the courts could not consolidate testimony in a group of suits involving separate infringements of the same patent .	103.65642
the vast industrial interests caught up in the selden suit , as well as the complex character of the automotive art , encouraged both sides to exploit `` every possible chance ' ' for or against the patent , said parker .	114.718
`` this very seldom happens in this class or in other cases , and of course all of these matters led to a volume and an expense of the record beyond what ordinarily would occur ' ' .	108.44783
parker listed the remedies he deemed essential for reducing the cost and mass of testimony .	133.05681
the most important of these found him in agreement with hough ' s plea for reform .	65.20278
parker called for abolition of the indiscriminate or uncontrolled right of taking depositions before officers of the court who had no authority to limit testimony .	252.45651
the taking of depositions , he suggested , should be placed under a special court examiner empowered to compel responsive and relevant answers and to exclude immaterial testimony .	82.189384
`` i am satisfied that in the selden case had this power existed and this course ( been ) pursued , it would have shortened the depositions of some of the experts nearly one-half and of some of the other witnesses thereto more than that ' ' .	129.72421
in the end hough ' s acidulous protest , which parker called the `` now somewhat famous note on this ' selden ' case ' ' , did not go unheeded .	248.95126
in 1912 the united states supreme court adopted a new set of rules of equity which became effective on february 1 , 1913 .	116.4519
the revised procedure was acclaimed as a long-overdue reform .	395.96603
under the new rules , testimony is taken orally in open court in all cases except those of an extraordinary character .	150.08171
other expeditious methods are designed to prevent prolixity , limit delays , and reduce the expense of infringement suits .	38.137024
one of the a . l . a . m . lawyers observed that if the selden case had been tried under this simplified procedure , the testimony which filled more than a score of volumes , `` at a minimum cost of $1 a page for publication alone , could have been contained in one volume ' ' .	94.21518
while patent suits are still among the most complex and expensive forms of litigation , these rules have saved litigants uncounted sums of money .	70.46243
there is little doubt that they were promulgated by the supreme court as a direct result of the selden patent suit .	15.685954
even before it was formally dissolved in 1912 , the a . l . a . m . was succeeded by the automobile board of trade , the direct lineal ancestor of the present-day automobile manufacturers association .	40.895657
the trade bodies which came in the wake of the a . l . a . m . were more representative , for they never adopted a policy of exclusion .	87.50329
nevertheless , it is from the selden organization that the industry inherited its institutional machinery for furthering the broader interests of the trade .	129.33191
one of the chief features of this community of interest is the automotive patents cross-licensing agreement , a milestone in the development of american industrial cooperation .	84.509415
its origin lies in the selden patent controversy and its aftermath .	86.3762
from the earliest days of the motor car industry , before the a . l . a . m . was established , patent infringement loomed as a serious and vexing problem .	70.138916
many patent contests were waged over automobile components and accessories , among them tires , detachable rims , ball bearings , license brackets , and electric horns .	55.34438
the fluidity and momentum of the young industry abetted a general disregard of patent claims .	188.71333
as early as 1900 a wall street combination acquired detail patents with the intention of exacting heavy tribute from automobile manufacturers .	150.86136
this scheme failed , and the following decade brought a deluge of infringement suits among individual manufacturers that reached its crest in 1912 .	73.671844
in this tangle of conflicting claims , the patent-sharing scheme adopted by the a . l . a . m . at its founding proved to be the best device for avoiding or mitigating the burdens of incessant litigation .	70.88882
the interchange of shop licenses for a nominal royalty eliminated infringement suits among the members of the a . l . a . m . patent pool ( although it did not protect them against outside actions ) and kept open channels for the cross-fertilization of automotive technology .	89.57418
one of the conditions of the pool was a prohibition upon the withholding of patent rights among a . l . a . m . members .	93.81911
within its limits , this arrangement had the actual or potential characteristics of a cross-licensing agreement .	177.94331
its positive features outweighed the fact that the pool was an adjunct of a wouldbe monopoly .	90.27302
since the a . l . a . m . holdings embraced only about twenty-five per cent of motor vehicle patents , the denial of rights to independent companies did not retard technical progress in unlicensed sectors of the industry .	99.0239
the highly important dyer patents on the sliding gear transmission were held by the a . l . a . m . pool .	54.533638
but henry ford used the planetary transmission in his model t and earlier cars and , in 1905 , as a precautionary measure , took out a license from the man who claimed to be its inventor .	104.24434
for those affiliated with it , the a . l . a . m . pool was a haven from the infringement actions involving detail patents that beset the industry with mounting intensity after 1900 .	94.58104
by 1910 the courts were crowded with cases , many of them brought by freebooters who trafficked in disputed inventions .	106.068375
it was commonplace for auto makers , parts-suppliers , and dealers to find warning notices and threats of infringement suits in their daily mail .	65.28108
`` purely from the business man ' s standpoint and without regard to the lawyer ' s view ' ' , commented a trade journal , `` the matter of patents in the automobile and accessory trade is developing some phases and results that challenge thought as to how far patents are to become weapons of warfare in business , instead of simple beneficient protection devices for encouraging inventive creation ' ' .	187.08339
occasionally new enterprise was discouraged by the almost certain prospect of legal complications .	119.41385
one manufacturer who held an allegedly basic patent said `` i would readily put over $50 , 000 into the manufacture of the device , but it is so easy to make that we would enter immediately into a prolonged ordeal of patent litigation which would eat up all our profits ' ' .	92.3371
the prevailing view in the industry was summed up in 1912 by a group of auto makers who told a senate committee `` the exceedingly unsatisfactory and uselessly expensive conditions , including delays surrounding legal disputes , particularly in patent litigation , are items of industrial burden which must be written large in figures of many millions of dollars of industrial waste ' ' .	102.14903
by that time it was commonly agreed that patent warfare was sapping constructive achievement and blocking the free exchange of technical information .	118.16324
at this point charles c . hanch , long an advocate of patent peace in the industry , became chairman of the patents committee of the national automobile chamber of commerce , successor to the automobile board of trade .	65.44409
hanch was treasurer of the nordyke & marmon company , an indianapolis firm which had manufactured flour-milling machinery before producing the marmon car in 1904 .	179.08934
he had first-hand knowledge of the patent wars which had driven about ninety per cent of the milling equipment makers out of business in the mid-1890 ' s .	65.21466
anxious to avoid a similar debacle in the motor car industry , hanch went to detroit in 1909 to enlist the support of leading a . l . a . m . members for an industry-wide patent-sharing plan .	97.04176
the breach created by the selden patent doomed his proposal , but hanch did not abandon his scheme .	97.39695
after the demise of the a . l . a . m . , the time was propitious for establishing such a pool .	57.71462
most manufacturers were now disposed to heed a proposal for the formal interchange of patents .	44.738148
`` it is a much easier course to agree to let one another alone so far as ordinary patents are concerned ' ' , said a trade authority , `` than to continue the costly effort of straightening the tangle in the courts or seeking to reform the patent system , which appears to be getting into deeper confusion every day ' ' .	101.62163
with the other members of the patents committee -- wilfred c . leland , howard e . coffin , windsor t . white , and w . h . vandervoort -- hanch drafted a cross-licensing agreement whose essential feature of royalty-free licensing was his own contribution .	124.23057
the plan was supported by frederick p . fish , counsel for the national automobile chamber of commerce .	43.38932
it will be recalled that in his summation for the a . l . a . m . before judge hough , fish had condemned patent litigation as the curse of the american industrial community .	79.975365
he was well aware that some inventors and their allies used their patents solely for nuisance value .	79.285515
`` my personal view is that not one patented invention in ten is worth making ' ' , he later told a congressional committee .	274.99283
the eloquent persuasions of fish guaranteed the adoption of the plan by the members of the automotive trade association .	29.87373
drawn up in 1914 , the cross-licensing agreement became effective in 1915 .	61.40737
it remained in force for ten years and has been renewed at five-year intervals since 1925 .	76.95683
a little farther along the road you come to the church of santa sabina , called the `` pearl of the aventine ' ' .	32.742405
continue another hundred yards to the piazza of the knights of malta .	65.82673
on the wall of this square there are delightful bas-reliefs of musical instruments .	171.18561
the massive gate of the maltese villa affords one of the most extraordinary views in rome .	53.545715
if you look through the keyhole , you will see an artistically landscaped garden with the white dome of st . peter ' s framed in a long avenue of cropped laurel trees .	65.30849
retrace your steps a few yards on the via di santa sabina and turn right on the via di s . alessio , a street lined with stately homes .	50.40205
oleanders , cypress , and palms in the spacious gardens add much color and beauty to this attractive residential section .	288.77905
turn left a block or so before the street ends , and then turn right down the via di santa prisca to the viale aventino .	56.928288
here you can pick up a taxi or public transport to return to the center of the city .	32.34047
these two walks take you through the heart of rome .	23.855698
you will walk some of the narrow , old streets , hemmed in by massive palazzi .	350.14404
you will visit a few churches that are exceptional yet often by-passed , a magnificent square , the main shopping district , the spanish steps , and the lovely pincian gardens .	138.44621
by seeing such varied places , both interesting and beautiful , you will become aware of the many different civilizations rome has lived through , and in particular , get a feel of renaissance rome .	130.98128
you will realize why rome is indeed the eternal city .	229.39519
start on the via d . teatro di marcello at the foot of the capitoline hill .	47.896214
the majestic circular tiers of stone of the theatre of marcellus give you some idea of the huge edifice that the emperor augustus erected in 13 b . c . .	82.59136
twenty-two thousand spectators used to crowd it in roman days .	771.74084
andrea palladio , an italian architect of the sixteenth century , modeled his designs on its doric and ionic columns .	40.488205
wander past the three superb columns of apollo by the arches of the theatre .	16.244768
the remains of the portico of octavia are now in front of you .	119.23905
climb the steps from the theatre to the via della tribuna di campitelli for an even better view of the columns of apollo .	66.425064
turn to the right along a narrow street to the tiny piazza campitelli , then proceed along the via dei funari to the piazza mattei .	26.904577
here is one of the loveliest fountains in rome , the fontana delle tartarughe or `` fountain of the tortoises ' ' .	33.929653
it ' s typical of rome that in the midst of this rather poor area you should find such an artistic work in the center of a little square .	126.99251
stand here for a few moments and look at this gem of a fountain with its four youths , each holding a tortoise and each with a foot resting on the head of a dolphin .	99.21712
the figures have been executed so skillfully that one senses a great feeling of life and movement .	101.143654
opposite is the palazzo mattei , one of rome ' s oldest palaces , now the headquarters of the italo-american association .	92.05389
go inside for a closer look at a renaissance palace .	38.792206
in the first courtyard there are some fine bas-reliefs and friezes , and in the second a series of delightful terraced roof gardens above an ivy-covered wall .	64.74095
the palazzo caetani , still inhabited by the caetani family , adjoins the palazzo mattei .	86.89232
keep straight ahead on the via falegnami , cross the wide via arenula , and you will come to the piazza b . cairoli , where you should look in at the church of san carlo ai catinari to see the frescoes on the ceiling .	63.72283
follow the colorful and busy via d . giubbonari for a hundred yards or so .	190.554
now turn left at the via dell ' arco del monte to the piazza dei pellegrini .	41.04031
just a few yards to the right on the via capo di ferro will bring you to the palazzo spada , built in 1540 and now occupied by the council of state .	42.012913
paintings by titian , caravaggio , and rubens are on display ( open 9 30 to 4 00 ) .	99.30998
before you enter the palazzo , note francesco borromini ' s facade .	21.873589
the great architect also designed the fine interior staircase and colonnade which connects the two courts .	73.99144
the large statue on the first floor is believed to be the statue of pompey at the base of which julius caesar was stabbed to death ( if so , the statue once stood in the senate house ) .	89.83159
( this is shown in the afternoon and on sunday morning .	42.70755
by tipping the porter , you can see in the courtyard borromini ' s unusual and fascinating trick in perspective .	76.89069
when you stand before the barrel-vaulted colonnade you have the impression that the statue at the end is at a considerable distance , yet it is actually only a few feet away .	64.27574
the sense of perspective has been created by designing the length of the columns so that those at the far end of the colonnade are much shorter than those in front .	160.07121
the gardens of the palazzo , shaded by a huge magnolia tree , are most attractive .	140.40993
from the palazzo spada you continue another block along the via capo di ferro and vicolo de venti to the imposing palazzo farnese , begun in 1514 and considered by many to be the finest palace of all .	84.28341
michelangelo was the most distinguished of several noted architects who helped design it .	238.57945
today it is occupied by the french embassy .	8.335386
its lovely seventeenth-century ceiling frescoes , as well as the huge guards room with a tremendously high and beautifully carved wooden ceiling , can be seen sundays ( 11 00 to 12 00 noon ) .	126.125374
ask to see the modern tapestries of paris and rome designed by lurcat .	278.92206
directly in front of the palace along the via d . baullari you will come to the campo di fiori , the famous site of executions during the turbulent days of renaissance rome .	49.15807
today , by contrast it is a lively and colorful fruit , vegetable , and flower market .	25.477934
continue on the via d . baullari to the corso vittorio emanuele , then turn right for a couple of hundred yards to the church of sant ' andrea della valle .	24.791592
as you approach the church on the via d . baullari you are passing within yards of the remains of the roman theatre of pompey , near which is believed to have been the place where julius caesar was assassinated .	85.64228
the dome of the church is , outside of st . peter ' s , one of the largest in rome .	66.61103
opera lovers will be interested to learn that this church was the scene for the first act of tosca .	81.03435
at this point you cross the wide corso vittorio emanuele 2 , , walk along the corso del rinascimento a couple of hundred yards , then turn left on the via dei canestrani to enter the splendid piazza navona , one of the truly glorious sights in rome .	49.14677
your first impression of this elongated square with its three elegant fountains , its two churches that almost face each other , and its russet-colored buildings , is a sense of restful spaciousness -- particularly welcome after wandering around the narrow and dark streets that you have followed since starting this walk .	254.51797
the site of the oblong piazza is domitian ' s ancient stadium , which was probably used for horse and chariot races .	87.74914
for centuries it was the location of historic festivals and open-air sports events .	49.126915
from the seventeenth to the nineteenth century it was a popular practice to flood the piazza in the summer , and the aristocrats would then ride around the inundated square in their carriages .	122.61666
giovanni bernini ' s `` fountain of the rivers ' ' , in the center of the piazza , is built around a roman obelisk from the circus of maxentius which rests on grottoes and rocks , with four huge figures , one at each corner , denoting four great rivers from different continents -- the danube , the ganges , the nile , and the plate .	91.4695
the eyes of the figure of the nile are covered , perhaps either to symbolize the mystery of her source or to obscure from her sight the baroque facade of the church of sant ' agnese in agone , the work of bernini ' s rival , borromini .	77.37744
in the piazza navona there are many delightful cafes where you can sit , have a drink or lunch , and watch the fountains in the square .	61.519268
the scene before you is indeed theatrical and often appears in movies about rome .	511.2057
perhaps a street musician will pass to add that extra touch .	1012.8522
take the via di s . agnese in agone , next to the church and opposite the center of the square , then turn right after about two hundred yards to reach the beautiful church of santa maria della pace .	85.16037
inside you will find the lovely sibyls painted by raphael and a chapel designed by michelangelo .	97.437325
the church ' s cloisters are among donato bramante ' s most beautiful creations .	23.08813
now return to the piazza navona and leave it on the opposite side by the corsia agonale	114.59493
in a moment cross the corso del rinascimento .	4.297395
in front of you is the palazzo madama , once belonging to the medici and now the italian senate .	227.03671
walk by the side of the palazzo and after two blocks along the via giustiniani you will come to the piazza della rotonda .	42.453564
you are now facing the pantheon , the largest and best-preserved building still standing from the days of ancient rome .	124.04204
this circular edifice , constructed by agrippa in b . c . 27 , was rebuilt in its present shape by the emperor hadrian .	59.155334
it was dedicated as a church in the seventh century .	27.204895
as you pause in the piazza by the egyptian obelisk brought from the temple of isis , you will admire the pantheon ' s impressive corinthian columns .	37.566643
the pantheon ' s interior , still in its original form , is truly majestic and an architectural triumph .	74.85402
its rotunda forms a perfect circle whose diameter is equal to the height from the floor to the ceiling .	54.35572
the only means of interior light is the twenty-nine-foot-wide aperture in the stupendous dome .	326.62155
standing before the tomb of raphael , the great genius of the renaissance , when shafts of sunlight are penetrating this great roman temple , you are once again reminded of the varied civilizations so characteristic of rome .	151.95854
as you leave the pantheon , take the narrow street to the right , the via del seminario , a block to sant ' ignazio , one of the most splendid baroque churches in the city .	49.498127
( along the way there , about one hundred yards on your right , you pass a simple restaurant , la sacrestia , where you can have the best pizza in rome .	61.99222
) the curve of faded terra-cotta-colored houses in front of the church seems like a stage set .	99.92126
this is one of the most charming little squares in this part of rome .	80.21452
one block along the via de burro ( in front of the church ) will bring you to the stock exchange in the old temple of neptune .	48.205185
a few yards farther , on the via dei bergamaschi , is the piazza colonna .	50.32648
the great column from which the square takes its name was erected by the emperor marcus aurelius .	38.702347
you are now at the corso , though narrow , one of rome ' s busiest streets .	65.79416
horse races took place here in the middle ages .	7.756155
if you have taken this stroll in the morning , and you have the time and inclination , walk to the right along the crowded corso for half a dozen blocks to visit the fine private collection of paintings -- mainly of the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries -- in the palazzo doria ( open sunday , tuesday , and thursday , 10 00 to 1 00 ) .	88.33146
here is your opportunity to see the inside of a palazzo where the family still lives .	158.33136
otherwise , cross over the corso and walk a block or so to the left .	74.08793
you will come to alemagna , a delightful , though moderately expensive restaurant , which is particularly noted for its exceptional selection of ice creams and patisseries .	107.648125
either here , or in one of the modest restaurants nearby , is just the place to end this first walk through the heart of rome .	160.05067
the second walk through the heart of rome should be taken after lunch , so that you will reach the pincian hill when the soft light of the late afternoon is at its best .	75.99079
rare , indeed , is the harlem citizen , from the most circumspect church member to the most shiftless adolescent , who does not have a long tale to tell of police incompetence , injustice , or brutality .	80.80288
i myself have witnessed and endured it more than once .	85.29977
the businessmen and racketeers also have a story .	31.234352
( and this is not , perhaps , the place to discuss harlem ' s very complex attitude toward black policemen , nor the reasons , according to harlem , that they are nearly all downtown .	98.445335
it is hard , on the other hand , to blame the policeman , blank , good-natured , thoughtless , and insuperably innocent , for being such a perfect representative of the people he serves .	86.75545
he , too , believes in good intentions and is astounded and offended when they are not taken for the deed .	112.54143
he has never , himself , done anything for which to be hated -- which of us has ? ?	153.5754
-- and yet he is facing , daily and nightly , people who would gladly see him dead , and he knows it .	72.80517
there is no way for him not to know it there are few things under heaven more unnerving than the silent , accumulating contempt and hatred of a people .	177.82695
he moves through harlem , therefore , like an occupying soldier in a bitterly hostile country	62.94726
which is precisely what , and where , he is , and is the reason he walks in twos and threes .	103.80012
and he is not the only one who knows why he is always in company the people who are watching him know why , too .	95.23276
any street meeting , sacred or secular , which he and his colleagues uneasily cover has as its explicit or implicit burden the cruelty and injustice of the white domination .	156.59291
and these days , of course , in terms increasingly vivid and jubilant , it speaks of the end of that domination .	152.03313
the white policeman standing on a harlem street corner finds himself at the very center of the revolution now occurring in the world .	53.855846
he is not prepared for it -- naturally , nobody is -- and , what is possibly much more to the point , he is exposed , as few white people are , to the anguish of the black people around him .	85.18657
even if he is gifted with the merest mustard grain of imagination , something must seep in .	206.98778
he cannot avoid observing that some of the children , in spite of their color , remind him of children he has known and loved , perhaps even of his own children .	135.75089
he knows that he certainly does not want his children living this way .	80.21212
he can retreat from his uneasiness in only one direction into a callousness which very shortly becomes second nature .	466.80725
he becomes more callous , the population becomes more hostile , the situation grows more tense , and the police force is increased .	75.77167
one day , to everyone ' s astonishment , someone drops a match in the powder keg and everything blows up .	172.41457
before the dust has settled or the blood congealed , editorials , speeches , and civil-rights commissions are loud in the land , demanding to know what happened .	77.403496
what happened is that negroes want to be treated like men .	810.49506
negroes want to be treated like men a perfectly straightforward statement , containing only seven words .	194.43051
people who have mastered kant , hegel , shakespeare , marx , freud , and the bible find this statement utterly impenetrable .	158.97942
the idea seems to threaten profound , barely conscious assumptions .	527.65546
a kind of panic paralyzes their features , as though they found themselves trapped on the edge of a steep place .	94.53762
i once tried to describe to a very well-known american intellectual the conditions among negroes in the south .	309.33832
and he asked me in perfect innocence , `` why don ' t all the negroes in the south move north ' ' ? ?	33.40285
i tried to explain what has happened , unfailingly , whenever a significant body of negroes move north .	193.88927
they do not escape jim crow they merely encounter another , not-less-deadly variety .	876.2437
they do not move to chicago , they move to the south side	28.608135
they do not move to new york , they move to harlem .	49.120274
the pressure within the ghetto causes the ghetto walls to expand , and this expansion is always violent .	89.27496
white people hold the line as long as they can , and in as many ways as they can , from verbal intimidation to physical violence .	110.04187
but inevitably the border which has divided the ghetto from the rest of the world falls into the hands of the ghetto .	30.017393
the white people fall back bitterly before the black horde	397.86835
the landlords make a tidy profit by raising the rent , chopping up the rooms , and all but dispensing with the upkeep	110.82913
and what has once been a neighborhood turns into a `` turf ' ' .	11.135759
this is precisely what happened when the puerto ricans arrived in their thousands -- and the bitterness thus caused is , as i write , being fought out all up and down those streets .	135.6696
they seem to feel that because they fought on the right side during the civil war , and won , they have earned the right merely to deplore what is going on in the south , without taking any responsibility for it	55.679195
and that they can ignore what is happening in northern cities because what is happening in little rock or birmingham is worse .	107.16332
well , in the first place , it is not possible for anyone who has not endured both to know which is `` worse ' ' .	66.19535
i know negroes who prefer the south and white southerners , because `` at least there , you haven ' t got to play any guessing games ' ' ! !	81.78921
the guessing games referred to have driven more than one negro into the narcotics ward , the madhouse , or the river .	138.53952
i know another negro , a man very dear to me , who says , with conviction and with truth , `` the spirit of the south is the spirit of america ' ' .	49.27582
he was born in the north and did his military training in the south .	100.01488
he did not , as far as i can gather , find the south `` worse ' '	79.476524
he found it , if anything , all too familiar .	60.022694
in the second place , though , even if birmingham is worse , no doubt johannesburg , south africa , beats it by several miles , and buchenwald was one of the worst things that ever happened in the entire history of the world .	79.37831
but i do not believe that these examples are meant to be used as justification for our own crimes .	56.269726
this perpetual justification empties the heart of all human feeling .	310.4386
the emptier our hearts become , the greater will be our crimes .	259.21298
thirdly , the south is not merely an embarrassingly backward region , but a part of this country , and what happens there concerns every one of us .	84.54964
as far as the color problem is concerned , there is but one great difference between the southern white and the northerner the southerner remembers , historically and in his own psyche , a kind of eden in which he loved black people and they loved him .	83.21799
historically , the flaming sword laid across this eden is the civil war .	74.2264
personally , it is the southerner ' s sexual coming of age , when , without any warning , unbreakable taboos are set up between himself and his past .	155.39977
everything , thereafter , is permitted him except the love he remembers and has never ceased to need .	119.91912
the resulting , indescribable torment affects every southern mind and is the basis of the southern hysteria .	82.78974
none of this is true for the northerner .	9.482238
negroes represent nothing to him personally , except , perhaps , the dangers of carnality .	68.51703
northerners never think about them whereas southerners are never really thinking of anything else .	66.263466
negroes are , therefore , ignored in the north and are under surveillance in the south , and suffer hideously in both places .	193.41724
neither the southerner nor the northerner is able to look on the negro simply as a man .	46.61386
it seems to be indispensable to the national self-esteem that the negro be considered either as a kind of ward ( in which case we are told how many negroes , comparatively , bought cadillacs last year and how few , comparatively , were lynched ) , or as a victim ( in which case we are promised that he will never vote in our assemblies or go to school with our kids ) .	145.25916
they are two sides of the same coin and the south will not change -- cannot change -- until the north changes .	284.91046
the country will not change until it re-examines itself and discovers what it really means by freedom .	149.18114
in the meantime , generations keep being born , bitterness is increased by incompetence , pride , and folly , and the world shrinks around us .	83.9969
it is a terrible , an inexorable , law that one cannot deny the humanity of another without diminishing one ' s own in the face of one ' s victim , one sees oneself .	101.030235
walk through the streets of harlem and see what we , this nation , have become .	154.20485
east river , downtown postscript to a letter from harlem	37.936897
the fact that american negroes rioted in the u . n . while adlai stevenson was addressing the assembly shocked and baffled most white americans .	48.53821
stevenson ' s speech , and the spectacular disturbance in the gallery , were both touched off by the death , in katanga , the day before , of patrice lumumba .	72.85046
stevenson stated , in the course of his address , that the united states was `` against ' ' colonialism .	36.07585
god knows what the african nations , who hold 25 per cent of the voting stock in the u . n . were thinking -- they may , for example , have been thinking of the u . s . abstention when the vote on algerian freedom was before the assembly -- but i think i have a fairly accurate notion of what the negroes in the gallery were thinking .	53.709488
it was my first reaction upon hearing of lumumba ' s death .	12.066323
i was curious about the impact of this political assassination on negroes in harlem , for lumumba had -- has -- captured the popular imagination there .	318.864
i was curious to know if lumumba ' s death , which is surely among the most sinister of recent events , would elicit from `` our ' ' side anything more than the usual , well-meaning rhetoric .	95.76344
and i was curious about the african reaction .	9.059916
however , the chaos on my desk prevented my being in the u . n . gallery .	43.171665
had i been there , i , too , in the eyes of most americans , would have been merely a pawn in the hands of the communists .	42.007923
the climate and the events of the last decade , and the steady pressure of the `` cold ' ' war , have given americans yet another means of avoiding self-examination , and so it has been decided that the riots were `` communist ' ' inspired .	76.48825
nor was it long , naturally , before prominent negroes rushed forward to assure the republic that the u . n . rioters do not represent the real feeling of the negro community .	70.63626
according , then , to what i take to be the prevailing view , these rioters were merely a handful of irresponsible , stalinist-corrupted provocateurs .	68.808685
it is a view which even a minimal effort at observation would immediately contradict .	139.67305
one has only , for example , to walk through harlem and ask oneself two questions .	205.33134
the first question is would i like to live here ? ?	35.791805
and the second question is why don ' t those who now live here move out ? ?	131.587
the answer to both questions is immediately obvious .	12.493949
unless one takes refuge in the theory -- however disguised -- that negroes are , somehow , different from white people , i do not see how one can escape the conclusion that the negro ' s status in this country is not only a cruel injustice but a grave national liability .	107.45714
now , i do not doubt that , among the people at the u . n . that day , there were stalinist and professional revolutionists acting out of the most cynical motives .	92.0585
wherever there is great social discontent , these people are , sooner or later , to be found .	104.1405
their presence is not as frightening as the discontent which creates their opportunity .	192.7353
what i find appalling -- and really dangerous -- is the american assumption that the negro is so contented with his lot here that only the cynical agents of a foreign power can rouse him to protest .	138.33244
it is a notion which contains a gratuitous insult , implying , as it does , that negroes can make no move unless they are manipulated .	72.49024
color was delayed until 1935 , the wide screen until the early fifties .	72.739655
movement itself was the chief and often the only attraction of the primitive movies of the nineties .	139.15367
each film consisted of fifty feet , which gives a running time of about one minute on the screen .	67.155365
as long as audiences came to see the movement , there seemed little reason to adventure further .	239.16057
motion-picture exhibitions took place in stores in a general atmosphere like that of the penny arcade which can still be found in such urban areas as times square .	148.10832
brief snips of actual events were shown parades , dances , street scenes .	81.1956
the sensational and frightening enjoyed popularity a train rushes straight at the audience , or a great wave threatens to break over the seats .	46.39566
an early edison production was the execution of mary , queen of scots .	85.95203
an early film by a competitor of the wizard of menlo park simply showed a long kiss performed by two actors of the contemporary stage .	269.51675
in the field of entertainment there is no spur to financial daring so effective as audience boredom , and the first decade of the new device was not over before audiences began staying away in large numbers from the simple-minded , one-minute shows .	184.85223
in response , the industry allowed the discovery of the motion picture as a form of fiction and thus gave the movies the essential form they have had to this day .	93.31721
despite the sheer beauty and spectacle of numerous documentaries , art films , and travelogues , despite the impressive financial success of such a recent development as cinerama , the movies are at heart a form of fiction , like the play , the novel , or the short story .	106.528465
moreover , the most artistically successful of the nonfiction films have invariably borrowed the narrative form from the fiction feature .	93.26023
thus such great american documentaries as the river and the plow that broke the plains were composed as visual stories rather than as illustrated lectures .	336.99365
the discovery that movies are a form of fiction was made in the early years of this century and it was made chiefly by two men , a french magician , georges melies , and an american employee of edison , edwin s . porter .	52.17393
of the two , porter is justly the better known , for he went far beyond the vital finding of fiction for films to take the first step toward fashioning a language of film , toward making the motion picture the intricate , efficient time machine that it has remained since , even in the most inept hands .	149.46231
melies , however , out of his professional instincts as a magician , discovered and made use of a number of illusionary techniques that remain part of the vocabulary of film .	66.07372
one of these is the `` dissolve ' ' , which makes possible a visually smooth transition from scene to scene .	105.60735
as the first scene begins to fade , the succeeding scene begins to appear .	114.465126
for a moment or two , both scenes are present simultaneously , one growing weaker , one growing stronger .	249.61502
in a series of fairy tales and fantasies , melies demonstrated that the film is superbly equipped to tell a straightforward story , with beginning , middle and end , complications , resolutions , climaxes , and conclusions .	135.05133
immediately , the film improved and it improved because in narrative it found a content based on time to complement its own unbreakable connection with time .	326.59164
physically , a movie is possible because a series of images is projected one at a time at such a speed that the eye `` remembers ' ' the one that has gone before even as it registers the one now appearing .	187.12953
linking the smoothly changing images together , the eye itself endows them with the illusion of movement .	308.01306
the `` projection ' ' time of painting and sculpture is highly subjective , varying from person to person and even varying for a given person on different occasions .	118.942795
the drama in the theater and the concert in the hall both have a fixed time , but the time is fixed by the director and the players , the conductor and the instrumentalists , subject , therefore , to much variation , as record collectors well know .	145.42868
the time of the motion picture is fixed absolutely .	213.77232
the film consists of a series of still , transparent photographs , or `` frames ' ' , 35-mm . -wide .	131.52972
each frame comes between the light and the lens and is individually projected on the screen , at the rate , for silent movies , of 16 frames per second , and , for sound films , 24 frames per second .	162.80289
time is built into the motion picture , which cannot exist without time .	225.93202
