now time is also the concern of the fictional narrative , which is , at its simplest , the story of an action with , usually , a beginning , a middle , and an end -- elements which demand time as the first condition for their existence .	132.27258
the `` moving ' ' picture of the train or the wave coming at the audience is , to be sure , more intense than a still picture of the same subject , but the difference is really one of degree	148.49309
the cinematic element of time is merely used to increase the realism of an object which would still be reasonably realistic in a still photo .	88.42105
in narrative , time is essential , as it is in film .	53.380157
almost everything about the movies that is peculiarly of the movies derives from a tension created and maintained between narrative time and film time .	281.124
this discovery of melies was vastly more important than his sometimes dazzling , magician ' s tricks produced on film .	159.14484
it was porter , however , who produced the very first movie whose name has lived on through the half century of film history that has since ensued .	191.25858
the movie was the great train robbery and its effects on the young industry and art were all but incalculable .	192.07655
overnight , for one thing , porter ' s film multiplied the standard running time of movies by ten .	434.68088
the great train robbery is a one-reel film .	19.186121
one reel -- from eight to twelve minutes -- became the standard length from the year of robbery , 1903 , until griffith shattered that limit forever with birth of a nation in 1915 .	112.11973
the reel itself became and still is the standard of measure for the movies .	142.78151
the material of the porter film is simplicity itself	385.76886
much of it has continued to be used over the years and the heart of it -- good guys and bad guys in the old west -- pretty well dominated television toward the end of the 1950 ' s .	81.656906
a band of robbers enters a railroad station , overpowers and ties up the telegraph operator , holds up the train and escapes .	104.906395
a posse is formed and pursues the robbers , who , having made their escape , are whooping it up with some wild , wild women in a honky-tonk hide-out .	239.4705
the robbers run from the hide-out , take cover in a wooded declivity , and are shot dead by the posse .	62.352592
as a finale is appended a close-up of one of the band taking aim and firing his revolver straight at the audience .	166.35931
all this is simple enough , but in telling the story porter did two important things that had not been done before .	162.83884
each scene is shot straight through , as had been the universal custom , from a camera fixed in a single position , but in the outdoor scenes , especially in the capture and destruction of the outlaws , porter ' s camera position breaks , necessarily , with the camera position standard until then , which had been , roughly , that of a spectator in a center orchestra seat at a play .	116.73482
the plane of the action in the scene is not parallel with the plane of the film in the camera or on the screen .	69.47949
if the change , at first sight , seems minor , we may recall that it took the italian painters about two hundred years to make an analogous change , and the italian painters , by universal consent , were the most brilliant group of geniuses any art has seen .	175.18115
in that apparently simple shift porter opened the way to the sensitive use of the camera as an instrument of art as well as a mechanical recording device .	55.141598
he revealed the potential value of the `` cut ' ' as the basic technique in the art of the film .	60.540295
cutting , of course , takes place automatically in the creation of a film .	107.75438
the meaning of the word is quite physical , to begin with .	314.38684
the physical film is cut with a knife at the end of one complete sequence , and the cut edge is joined physically , by cement , to the cut edge of the beginning of the next sequence .	87.463326
if , as a home movie maker , you shoot the inevitable footage of your child taking its first steps , you have merely recorded an historical event .	142.88756
if , in preparing that shot for the inevitable showing to your friends , you interrupt the sequence to paste in a few frames of the child ' s grandmother watching this event , you have begun to be an artist in film	89.189224
as the robbers leave the looted train , the film suddenly cuts back to the station , where the telegrapher ' s little daughter arrives with her father ' s dinner pail only to find him bound on the floor .	92.98408
the two events are taking place at the same time .	11.62027
we leap from event to event -- including the formation of the posse -- even though the events , in `` reality ' ' are taking place not in sequence but simultaneously , and not near each other but at a considerable distance .	135.21126
the `` chase ' ' as a standard film device probably dates from the great train robbery , and there is a reason for the continued popularity of the device .	67.93551
it presumes both speed and urgency and it demands cutting -- both from pursued to pursuer and from stage to stage of the journey of both .	198.86086
the simple , naked idea of one man chasing another is of its nature better fitted for the film than it is for any other form of fiction .	176.48642
the cowboy films , the cops and robbers films , and the slapstick comedy films culminating in an insane chase are not only catering to what critics may assume to be a vulgar taste for violence	175.974
these films and these sequences are also seeking out -- instinctively or by design -- the peculiarly cinematic elements of narrative .	185.02534
the creator of the art of the film d . w . griffith	118.427795
there still remained the need for one great film artist to explore the full potential of the new form and to make it an art .	153.82657
when he came to the movies -- more or less by accident -- they were still cheap entertainment capable of enthralling the unthinking for an idle few minutes .	197.26317
in about seven years griffith either invented or first realized the possibilities of virtually every resource at the disposal of the film maker .	85.78259
before he was forty griffith had created the art of the film .	44.1463
not that there had not been attempts , mostly european , to do exactly that .	159.18999
but in general the european efforts to make an art of the entertainment had ignored the slowly emerging language of the film itself .	98.348206
staggeringly condensed versions of famous novels and famous plays were presented .	87.74504
great actors and actresses -- the most notable being sarah bernhardt -- were hired to repeat their stage performances before the camera .	68.11644
in all of this extensive and expensive effort , the camera was downgraded to the status of recording instrument for art work produced elsewhere by the actor or by the author .	117.11249
the phonograph today , for all its high fidelity and stereophonic sound , is precisely what the early art purveyors in the movies wished to make of the camera .	79.29939
not surprisingly , this approach did not work .	24.622637
the effort produced a valuable record of stage techniques in the early years of the century and some interesting records of great theater figures who would otherwise be only names .	145.68312
but no art at all was born of the art effort in the early movies .	68.566086
in general , religious interest seems to exist in all parts of the metropolis	40.497387
congregational membership , however , is another thing .	45.285107
a congregation survives only if it can sustain a socially homogeneous membership	105.97318
that is , when it can preserve economic integration .	4.4991913
religious faith can be considered a necessary condition of membership in a congregation , since the decision to join a worshiping group requires some motive force , but faith is not a sufficient condition for joining	147.95479
the presence of other members of similar social and economic level is the sufficient condition .	46.29592
the breakdown of social homogeneity in inner city areas and the spread of inner city blight account for the decline of central city churches .	195.96684
central cities reveal two adverse features for the major denominations ( 1 ) central cities tend to be areas of residence for lower social classes	92.967
( 2 ) central cities tend to be more heterogeneous in social composition .	283.5938
the central city areas , in other words , exhibit the two characteristics which violate the life principle of congregations of the major denominations they have too few middle-class people	103.06327
central city areas have become progressively poorer locales for the major denominations since the exodus of middle-class people from most central cities .	77.704
with few exceptions , the major denominations are rapidly losing their hold on the central city .	75.7449
the key to protestant development , therefore , is economic integration of the nucleus of the congregation .	45.35693
members of higher and lower social status often cluster around this nucleus , so that protestant figures on social class give the impression of spread over all social classes	174.45451
but this is deceptive , for the core of membership is concentrated in a single social and economic stratum .	36.07478
the congregation perishes when it is no longer possible to replenish that core from the neighborhood	98.88173
moreover , residential mobility is so high in metropolitan areas that churches have to recruit constantly in their core stratum in order to survive	92.514175
they can lose higher- and lower-status members from the church without collapsing , but they need adequate recruits for the core stratum in order to preserve economic integration .	69.29722
the congregation is first and foremost an economic peer group	446.50876
it is secondarily a believing and worshiping fellowship .	4.2175126
if it were primarily a believing fellowship , it would recruit believers from all social and economic ranks , something which most congregations of the new protestantism ( with a few notable exceptions ) have not been able to do .	80.015
they survive only when they can recruit social and economic peers .	29.980787
the vulnerability of protestant congregations to social differences has often been attributed to the `` folksy spirit ' ' of protestant religious life	60.27262
in fact , a contrast is often drawn in this regard with the `` impersonal ' ' roman catholic parish .	34.68483
we have seen that the folksy spirit is confined to economic peers	275.5587
consequently , the vulnerability to social difference should not be attributed to the stress on personal community in protestant congregations	90.84175
actually , there is little evidence of such personal community in protestant congregations , as we shall see in another connection .	120.160675
the vulnerability of protestantism to social differences stems from the peculiar role of the new religious style in middle-class life , where the congregation is a vehicle of social and economic group identity and must conform , therefore , to the principle of economic integration .	70.84195
this fact is evident in the recruitment of new members .	112.47303
the rule of economic integration in congregational life can be seen in the missionary outreach of the major denominations .	35.48759
there is much talk in theological circles about the `` church as mission ' ' and the `` church ' s mission ' '	41.161636
theologians have been stressing the fact that the church does not exist for its own sake but as a testimony in the world for the healing of the world .	36.104748
a crucial question , therefore , is what evangelism and mission actually mean in metropolitan protestantism .	158.18158
if economic integration really shapes congregational life , then evangelism should be a process of extending economic integration .	97.2051
the task of a congregation would be defined , according to economic integration , as the work of co-opting individuals and families of similar social and economic position to replenish the nuclear core of the congregation .	65.826164
( co-optation means to choose by joint action in order to fill a vacancy	57.054985
it can also mean the assimilation of centers of power from an environment in order to strengthen an organization .	65.99365
) in a mobile society , congregational health depends on a constant process of recruitment	108.92437
this recruitment , however , must follow the pattern of economic integration or it will disrupt the congregation	162.9649
therefore , the recruitment or missionary outreach of the congregation will be co-optation rather than proclamation -- like elements will have to be assimilated .	96.7898
evangelism and congregational outreach have not been carefully studied in the churches	59.041096
one study in pittsburgh , however , has illuminated the situation .	159.80237
in a sample of new members of pittsburgh churches , almost 60 per cent were recruited by initial `` contacts with friendly members ' ' .	53.924343
if we add to these contacts with friendly members the `` contacts with an organization of the church ' ' ( 11 . 2 per cent of the cases ) , then a substantial two thirds of all recruitment is through friendly contact .	74.72321
on the surface , this seems a sound approach to christian mission members of the congregation show by their friendly attitudes that they care for new people	188.70786
the new people respond in kind by joining the church .	14.841266
missionary outreach by friendly contact looks somewhat different when one reflects on what is known about friendly contact in metropolitan neighborhoods	130.47778
the majority of such contacts are with people of similar social and economic position	72.37699
association by level of achievement is the dominant principle of informal relations .	44.108597
this means that the antennae of the congregation are extended into the community , picking up the wave lengths of those who will fit into the social and economic level of the congregation	52.895084
the mission of the church is actually a process of informal co-optation	30.112932
the lay ministry is a means to recruit like-minded people who will strengthen the social class nucleus of the congregation .	37.78408
churches can be strengthened through this process of co-optation so long as the environs of the church provide a sufficient pool of people who can fit the pattern of economic integration	93.151115
once the pool of recruits diminishes , the congregation is helpless -- friendly contacts no longer keep it going .	175.46288
the transmutation of mission to co-optation is further indicated by the insignificance of educational activities , worship , preaching , and publicity in reaching new members .	102.58982
the proclamation of the churches is almost totally confined to pastoral contacts by the clergy ( 17 . 3 per cent of new members ) and friendly contacts by members ( over two thirds if organizational activities are included ) .	100.65829
publicity accounted for 1 . 1 per cent of the initial contacts with new members .	61.0708
in general , friendly contact with a member followed by contact with a clergyman will account for a major share of recruitment by the churches , making it quite evident that the extension of economic integration through co-optation is the principal form of mission in the contemporary church	117.19757
economic integration and co-optation are the two methods by which protestants associate with and recruit from the neighborhood .	242.62975
the inner life of congregations will prosper so long as like-minded people of similar social and economic level can fraternize together	117.7157
the outer life of congregations -- the suitability of the environment to their survival -- will be propitious so long as the people in the area are of the same social and economic level as the membership .	60.27078
economic integration ceases when the social and economic statuses in an area become too mixed or conflict with the status of the congregation .	103.316574
in a rapidly changing society congregations will run into difficulties repeatedly , since such nice balances of economic integration are hard to sustain in the metropolis for more than a single generation .	95.82365
the fact that metropolitan churches of the major denominations have moved approximately every generation for the last hundred years becomes somewhat more intelligible in the light of this struggle to maintain economic balance .	77.36114
the expense of this type of organization in religious life , when one recalls the number of city churches which deteriorated beyond repair before being abandoned , raises fundamental questions about the principle of protestant survival in a mobile society	145.46204
nonetheless , the prevalence of economic integration in congregations illumines the nature of the protestant development .	65.87895
it was observed in the introductory chapter that metropolitan life had split into two trends -- expanding interdependence on an impersonal basis and growing exclusiveness in local communal groupings .	81.90059
these trends seem to be working at cross-purposes in the metropolis .	56.48753
residential associations struggle to insulate themselves against intrusions .	7.5369678
the motifs of impersonal interdependence and insulation of residential communities have polarized	524.68414
the schism between central city and suburb , negro and white , blue collar and white collar can be viewed as symptomatic of this deeper polarization of trends in the metropolis .	65.29469
it now becomes evident that the denominational church is intimately involved with the economy of middle-class culture , for it serves to crystallize the social class identity of middle-class residential groupings .	51.657906
the accelerated pace of metropolitan changes has accentuated the drive to conformity in congregations of the major denominations .	43.80883
this conformity represents a desperate attempt to stabilize a hopelessly unstable environment .	29.585228
more than creatures of metropolitan forces , the churches have taken the lead in counteracting the interdependence of metropolitan life , crystallizing and perpetuating the stratification of peoples , giving form to the struggle for social homogeneity in a world of heterogeneous peoples .	93.88153
since american life is committed above all to productivity and a higher standard of economic life , the countervailing forces of residential and religious exclusiveness have fought a desperate , rearguard action against the expanding interdependence of the metropolis .	124.42401
consumer communities have suffered at the hands of the productive interests .	124.69716
negroes , puerto ricans , and rural newcomers are slowly making their way into the cities .	78.83734
soon they will fight their way into the lower middle-class suburbs , and the churches will experience the same decay and rebuilding cycle which has characterized their history for a century .	132.08797
the identification of the basic unit of religious organization -- the parish or congregation -- with a residential area is self-defeating in a modern metropolis , for it simply means the closing of an iron trap on the outreach of the christian fellowship and the transmutation of mission to co-optation .	77.06247
mission to the metropolis contradicts survival of the congregation in the residential community , because the middle classes are fighting metropolitan interdependence with residential exclusion .	115.239334
this interpretation of the role of residence in the economy of middle-class culture could lead to various projections for the churches .	72.017136
it could be argued that any fellowship which centers in residential neighborhoods is doomed to become an expression of the panic for stable identity among the middle classes .	70.09712
it could be argued that only such neighborhoods can sustain religious activity , since worship presupposes some local stabilities .	206.05687
whatever projection one makes , the striking fact about congregational and parochial life is the extent to which it is a vehicle of the social identity of middle-class people .	65.96945
attention will be given in the next chapter to the style of association in the denominational churches	167.63235
this style is characteristically an expression of the communal style of the middle classes .	42.941525
the keynotes of this style are activism and emphasis on achievements in gaining self-esteem .	93.04586
these values give direction to the life of the middle-class man or woman , dictating the methods of child rearing , determining the pattern of community participation , setting the style for the psychiatric treatment of middle-class illness , and informing the congregational life of the major denominations .	83.92816
`` fellowship by likeness ' ' and `` mission by friendly contact ' ' form the iron cage of denominational religion .	116.3344
its contents are another matter , for they reveal the kinds of interests pursued by the congregation .	90.03474
what goes on in the cage will occupy our attention under the rubric of the organization church .	98.47322
an understanding of the new role of residential association in an industrial society serves to illuminate the forces which have fashioned the iron cage of conformity which imprisons the churches in their suburban captivity .	114.65609
the perplexing question still remains as to why the middle classes turn to the churches as a vehicle of social identity when their clubs and charities should fill the same need .	154.03766
with capital largely squandered , there seemed to them no other course to pursue .	356.20566
the directors sold directly to concessionaires , who had to make their profits above the high prices asked by the company .	98.10961
these concessionaires traded where they wished and generally dealt with the indians through engages , who might be habitants , voyageurs , or even soldiers .	93.11905
the concessionaires also had to pay a tax of one-tenth on the goods they traded , and all pelts were to be taken to company stores and shipped to france in company ships .	117.082565
the company disposed of the pelts , but with what profit , the records do not show .	117.12472
in accord with its penurious policy , the company failed to furnish presents to hold the loyalty of the principal indians .	162.15141
the lavish use of presents had been effective in expanding the indian trade of new france and louisiana in the previous century , and the change in liberality aroused resentment in the minds of the red men .	90.3539
traders from the english colonies were far more generous , and indian loyalty turned to them .	168.49007
protests from governors and intendants passed unheeded , and the parsimonious policy of the company probably let loose indian insurrections that brought ruin to the company .	237.24376
in 1721 the king sent three commissioners to louisiana with full powers to do all that was necessary to protect the colony .	96.369484
they ordered the raising of troops and obtained 75 , 000 livres with which to build forts .	68.507614
they adopted a program by which louisiana was divided into five districts .	20.25839
in each of these there was to be a strong military post , and a trading depot to supply the smaller trading houses .	124.387405
for southeastern louisiana , mobile was the principal post , and it was to furnish supplies for trade to the north and east , in the region threatened by british traders .	43.260536
mobile was to be the anchor of a chain of posts extending northward to the sources of the tennessee river .	31.015005
fort toulouse , on the alabama river , had been erected in 1714 for trade with the alabamas and choctaws , but money was available for only one other new post , near the present nashville , tennessee , and this was soon abandoned .	102.752754
west of the mobile district was the lower mississippi district , of which new orleans was headquarters .	53.365376
dependent upon it were posts on the lower mississippi and the region westward to the frontiers of new spain .	73.881966
on the middle mississippi a principal post was to be located near the mouth of the arkansas .	45.160255
it was hoped that to this post would flow a large quantity of furs from the west , principally down the arkansas river .	118.828674
on the ohio or wabash was to be built another post `` at the fork of two great rivers ' ' .	74.92837
other posts would be established up the ohio and wabash to protect communication with canada .	66.29931
on the upper mississippi the illinois post was to be established near kaskaskia , and dependent posts were to be built on the missouri , `` where there are mines in abundance ' ' .	71.550766
each of the five principal posts was to have a director , responsible to a director-general at new orleans .	108.15992
an elaborate system of accounting and reports was worked out , and the trade was to be managed in the most scientific way .	54.347145
concessionaires were to be under the supervision of the directors .	37.72006
engages must be loyal to the concessionaires , and must serve until the term provided in the engagement was ended .	74.99103
the habitants were to be encouraged to trade and were to dispose of their pelts to the concessionaires .	78.0428
only two principal storehouses were actually established -- one at mobile , the other at new orleans .	142.1246
new orleans supplied the goods for the trade on the mississippi , and west of that river , and on the ohio and wabash .	45.52102
mobile was also supplied by new orleans with goods for the mobile district .	41.841858
the power that bienville exercised during his first administration cannot be determined .	113.00491
regulations for the indian trade were made by the conseil superieure de la louisiane , and bienville apparently did not have control of that body .	135.51785
the conseil even treated the serious matter of british aggression as its business and , on its own authority , sent to disaffected savages merchandise `` suitable for the peltry trade ' ' .	128.92386
it decided , also , that the purely secular efforts of bienville were insufficient , and sent missionaries to win the savages from the heathen carolinians .	151.14151
during the first administration of bienville , the peltry trade of the mobile district was a lucrative source of revenue .	80.79313
the alabamas brought in annually 15 , 000 to 20 , 000 deerskins , and the choctaws and chickasaws brought the total up to 50 , 000 pelts .	91.20048
these deerskins were the raw material for the manufacture of leather , and were the only articles which the tribes of this district had to exchange for european goods .	93.19661
during his first administration , bienville succeeded in keeping carolina traders out of the alabama country and the choctaw country .	85.285614
the director of the post at mobile kept an adequate amount of french goods , of a kind to which they were accustomed , to supply the indian needs .	120.65387
the alabama and tombigbee rivers furnished a highway by which goods could be moved quickly and cheaply .	242.89958
de la laude , commander of the alabama post , had the friendship of the natives , and was able to make them look upon the british as poor competitors .	70.67015
diron d ' artaguette , the most prominent trader in the district , was energetic and resourceful , but his methods often aroused the ire of the french governors .	84.16417
he became , after a time , commander of a post on the alabama river , but his operations extended from mobile throughout the district , and he finally obtained a monopoly of the indian trade .	92.412895
the chickasaws were the principal source of trouble in the mobile district .	19.335386
their territory lay to the north , near the sources of the alabama , the tombigbee , the tennessee , and cumberland rivers , and was easily accessible to traders among the near-by cherokees .	77.59385
in 1720 some chickasaws massacred the french traders among them , and did not make peace for four years .	67.91122
venturesome traders , however , continued to come to them from mobile , and to obtain a considerable number of pelts for the french markets .	47.029095
british traders from south carolina incited the indians against the french , and there developed french and british factions in the tribe .	84.88173
the chickasaws finally were the occasion for the most disastrous wars during the french control of louisiana .	148.94337
to hold them was an essential part of french policy , for they controlled the upper termini of the routes from the north to mobile .	73.71341
they threatened constantly to give the british a hold on this region , from whence they could move easily down the rivers to the french settlements near the gulf .	264.9855
bienville realized that if the french were to hold the southeastern tribes against the enticements of british goods , french traders must be able to offer a supply as abundant as the carolinians and at reasonable prices .	105.80872
the company of the indies promised to send over a supply of indian trading goods , and to price them more cheaply in terms of deerskins .	89.236115
but it coupled with this a requirement that indians must bring their pelts to mobile and thus save all costs of transportation into and out of the indian country .	118.802155
the insistence of bienville upon giving liberal prices to the indians , in order to drive back the carolina traders , was probably a factor that led to his recall in 1724 .	100.17301
for two years his friend and cousin , boisbriant , remained as acting governor and could do little to stem the anglican advance .	191.56197
although he incited a few friendly indians to pillage the invaders , and even kill some of them , the carolina advance continued .	78.23133
the company was impressed with some ideas of the danger from carolina , and when perier came over as governor in 1727 , he was given special instructions regarding the trade of the mobile district .	72.20316
but the company of the indies , holding to its program of economy , made no arrangements to furnish better goods at attractive prices .	160.31808
to the directors the problem appeared a matter of intrigue or diplomacy .	48.17854
perier attempted to understand the problem by sending agents to inquire among the indians .	162.9758
these agents were to ascertain the difference between english and french goods , and the prices charged the indians .	68.24024
they were to conciliate the unfriendly savages , and , wherever possible , to incite the natives to pillage the traders from carolina .	90.05848
they were to promise fine presents to the loyal red men , as well as an abundant supply of trading goods at better prices than the opposition was offering .	133.93481
one was british and the other , french .	73.13903
so hostile did these factions become that , among the choctaws , civil war broke out .	103.13214
perier ' s efforts , however , were on the whole ineffective in winning back the tribes of the mobile district , and he decided to send troops into the troubled country .	64.48591
he asked the government for two hundred soldiers , who were to be specifically assigned to arrest english traders and disloyal indians .	55.02789
in spite of the company ' s restrictions , he planned to build new posts in the territory .	61.990772
he asked also for more supplies to trade at a low price for the indians ' pelts .	77.15333
no help came from the crown , and perier , in desperation , gave a monopoly of the indian trade in the district to d ' artaguette .	56.865593
d ' artaguette went vigorously to work , and gave credit to many hunters .	105.2314
but they brought back few pelts to pay their debts , and soon french trade in the region was at an end .	64.39575
perier finally , in one last bid in 1730 , cut the price of goods to an advance of 40 per cent above the cost in france .	53.37843
the indians were not impressed and held to the carolina traders , who swarmed over the country , almost to the mississippi .	84.37485
with the loss of the mobile trade , which ended all profits from louisiana , the natchez indians revolted .	75.645386
they destroyed a trading house and pillaged the goods , and harassed french shipping on the mississippi .	87.889755
the war to subdue them taxed the resources of the colony and piled up enormous debts .	39.686203
in january , 1731 , the company asked the crown to relieve it of the government of the colony .	45.717587
it stated that it had lost 20 , 000 , 000 livres in its operations , and apparently blamed its poor success largely on the indian trade .	73.70684
it offered to surrender its right to exclusive trade , but asked an indemnity .	116.97564
the king accepted the surrender and fixed the compensation of the company at 1 , 450 , 000 livres .	25.491047
thenceforth , the commerce of louisiana was free to all frenchmen .	120.52398
company rule in louisiana left the colony without fortifications , arms , munitions , or supplies .	110.47657
the difficulties of trade had ruined many voyageurs , and numbers of them had gone to live with the natives and rear half-blood families .	90.36974
others left the country , and there was no one familiar with the indian trade .	67.51881
if this trade should be resumed , the habitants who had come to be farmers or artisans , and soldiers discharged from the army , must be hardened to the severe life of coureurs de bois .	90.199394
this was a slow and difficult course , and french trade suffered from the many mistakes of the new group of traders .	91.05204
perier and salmon , the intendant , wished either to entrust the trade to an association of merchants or to have the crown furnish goods on credit to individuals who would repay their debts with pelts .	143.40187
bienville , who returned to succeed perier in 1732 , objected that the merchants would not accept the responsibility of managing a trade in which they could see no hope of profits .	96.434845
he reported , too , that among the habitants there were none of probity and ability sufficient to justify entrusting them with the king ' s goods .	114.71395
he did find some to trust , however , and he employed the king ' s soldiers to trade .	77.04539
with no company to interfere , he kept close control over all the traders .	130.81955
in order to compete with english traders , bienville radically changed the price schedule .	124.54047
the king should expect no profit , and an advance of only 20 per cent above the cost in france , which would cover the expense of transportation and handling , was all he charged the traders .	82.807465
they would not be pleased to have it published back home that they planned a frolic in paris or hong kong at the treasury ' s expense .	215.37943
they would be particularly displeased with the state department if it were the source of such reports .	84.73364
few things are more perilous for the state department than a displeased congressman .	72.231155
the reason for this bears explaining for those who may wonder why state spends so much of its diplomatic energy on congress when the russians are so available .	135.08585
first , the state department is unique among government agencies for its lack of public supporters .	65.74213
the farmers may be aroused if congress cuts into the agriculture department ' s budget .	37.890507
businessmen will rise if congress attacks the commerce department .	10.74552
the chamber of commerce , assaults upon the treasury .	609.8574
a kaleidoscope of pressure groups make it unpleasant for the congressman who becomes ugly toward the department of health , education , and welfare .	44.370174
the congressman ' s patriotism is always involved when he turns upon the defense department .	151.09735
tampering with the post office may infuriate every voter who can write .	108.18968
with all these agencies , the congressman must constantly check the political wind and trim his sails accordingly .	195.36479
no such political restraint subdues his blood when he gazes upon the state department in anger .	93.33754
in many sections he may even reap applause from press and public for giving it a good lesson .	296.34378
after all , the money dispensed by state goes not to the farmer , the laborer , or the businessman , but to foreigners .	72.33476
not only do these foreigners not vote for american congressmen	275.6808
they are also probably ungrateful for uncle ' s sam ' s bounty .	63.261463
and are not the state department men who dispense this largesse merely crackpots and do-gooders who have never met a payroll ? ?	219.90509
will not the righteous congressman be cheered at the polls if he reminds them to get right with america and if he saves the taxpayer some money by spoiling a few of their schemes ? ?	165.54158
the result is that the state department ' s perpetual position before congress is the resigned pose of the whipping boy who expects to be kicked whenever the master has had a dyspeptic outing with his wife .	197.65147
people in this position do not offend the master by relating his peccadilloes to the newspapers .	111.54951
the department expects and receives no thanks from congress for its discretion .	109.86466
state is expected to arrange the touring cicero ' s foreign itinerary	67.78594
its embassies are expected to supply him with reams of local money to pay his way	195.60014
embassy workers are expected to entertain him according to his whim , frequently with their savings for the children ' s college tuition .	96.29191
but come the next session of congress , state can expect only that its summer guest will bite its hand when it goes to the capitol asking money for diplomatic entertaining expenses abroad or for living expenses for its diplomats .	351.6843
the congressman who , in paris , may have stuffed his wallet with enough franc notes to paper the roof of notre-dame will systematically scream that a $200 increase in entertainment allowance for a second secretary is tantamount to debauchery of the treasury .	182.37338
in the matter of money state ' s most unrelenting watchdog during the eisenhower years was representative john j . rooney , of brooklyn , who controlled the purse for diplomatic administrative expenses .	112.82648
diplomats stayed up nights thinking of ways to attain peaceful coexistence , not with nikita khrushchev , but with john rooney .	89.177025
in the most confidential whispers ambassadors told of techniques they had tried to bring rooney around -- friendly persuasion , groveling abasement , pressure subtly exerted through other powerful congressmen , tales of heartbreak and penury among a threadbare diplomatic corps .	264.8501
`` the trouble , ' ' explained loy henderson , then deputy undersecretary for administration , `` is that when we get into an argument with him about this thing , it always turns out that rooney knows more about our budget than we do ' ' .	106.51694
one year the department collected a file of case histories to document its argument that men in the field were paying the government ' s entertainment bills out of personal income .	110.70475
next day , reports went through the department that rooney had been outraged by what he considered a patent attempt to put public pressure on him for increased entertainment allowances and had sworn an oath that , that year , expense allowances would not rise a dollar .	187.42038
the department ' s constant fight with the house for money is a polite minuet compared with its periodic bloody engagements with the senate .	112.474266
armed with constitutional power to negate the executive ' s foreign policy , the senate carries a big stick and is easily provoked to use it on the state department ' s back , or on the head of the secretary of state .	35.817177
with its power to investigate , the senate can paralyze the secretary by keeping him in a state of perpetual testimony before committees , as it did with dean acheson .	83.11769
john foster dulles escaped by keeping his personal show on the road and because lyndon johnson , who was then operating the senate , refused to let it become an inquisition .	110.08874
during dulles ' s first two years in office , while republicans ran the senate , the department was at the mercy of men who had thirsted for its blood since 1945 .	107.552284
an internal police operation managed by scott mcleod , a former f . b . i . man installed as security officer upon congressional insistence , was part of the vengeance .	133.55885
so was the attack upon charles e . bohlen when eisenhower appointed him ambassador to moscow .	502.43063
the principal mauler , however , was senator joseph mccarthy .	3.9607615
where acheson had fought a gallant losing battle for the department , dulles fed the crocodile with his subordinates .	95.28749
fretting privately but eschewing public defense of his terrorized bureaucrats , dulles remained serene and detached while the hatchet men had their way .	154.2701
in view of eisenhower ' s reluctance to concede that anything was amiss in the terror , it is doubtful that heroic intervention by dulles could have produced anything but disaster for him and the country ' s foreign policy .	65.584076
in any event , the example of acheson ' s trampling by the senate did not encourage dulles to provoke it .	52.474403
he elected to `` get along ' ' .	2.743197
during this dark chapter in state department history , men who had offered foreign-policy ideas later proven wrong by events filled the tumbrels sent up to capitol hill .	316.433
their old errors of judgment were equated , in the curious logic of the time , with present treasonous intent .	52.4545
their successors , absorbing the lesson , made it a point to have few ideas .	140.9316
this , in turn , brought a new fashion in senatorial criticism as the democrats took control .	150.43823
in the new style , the department was berated as intellectually barren and unable to produce the vital ideas needed to outwit the russians .	98.80727
for three or four years in the mid-1950 ' s , this complaint was heard rumbling up from the senate floor whenever there was a dull legislative afternoon .	94.53722
it became smart to say that the fault was with dulles because he would not countenance thinking done by anyone but himself .	354.09863
an equally tenable thesis is that the dearth of new thought was created by the senate ' s own penchant for crucifying anyone whose ideas seem unorthodox to the next generation .	109.992874
there are ninety-eight foreign embassies and legations in washington .	20.516094
they range from the soviet embassy on sixteenth street , a gray shuttered pile suggesting a funeral-accessories display house , to what congressman rooney has called `` that monstrosity on thirty-fourth street ' ' , the modern cement-and-glass chancery of the belgians .	114.886986
here is the world of the chauffeured limousine and the gossip reporter , of caviar on stale crackers and the warm martini , of the poseur , the spy , the party crasher , and the patriot , of the rented tails , the double cross , and the tired lothario .	71.469574
into its chanceries each day pour reports from ministries around the earth and an endless stream of home-office instructions on how to handle uncle sam in an infinite variety of contingencies .	167.51848
here are hatched plans for getting a share of the american bounty , the secret of the anti-missile missile , or an invitation to dinner .	45.951706
out of it each week go hundreds of thousands of words purporting to inform home ministries about what is really happening inside washington .	161.45633
some , like the british and the french , maintain an elaborate system of personal contacts and have experts constantly studying special areas of the american scene .	186.4366
other embassies cable home the new york times without changing a comma .	405.06418
the soviet embassy is popularly regarded as russian espionage headquarters .	94.45634
when ambassador mikhail menshikov took it over in 1957 from georgi zaroubin , he made a determined effort to change this idea .	190.40785
menshikov hit washington with a tv announcer ' s grin and a hearty handclasp .	30.140053
to everyone ' s astonishment he seemed no more like the run-of-the-mine russian ambassador than george babbitt was like fyodor pavlovitch karamazov .	288.46747
where his predecessors had glowered , menshikov smiled .	18.156216
where they had affected the bleak social style of embalmers ' assistants , menshikov went abroad gorgeous in white tie and tails .	169.45105
overnight he became the most available man in washington .	33.115784
speeches by the soviet ambassador became the vogue as he obliged rural maryland rotarians and national press club alike .	209.10626
in senator joseph mccarthy ' s phrase , it was the most unheard-of thing ever heard of .	298.33084
a newspaperman who met him at a reception swore that he asked menshikov `` what should we call you ' ' ? ?	76.69501
and that menshikov replied `` just call me mike ' ' .	11.274317
`` smilin ' mike ' ' was the sobriquet washington gave him .	337.19214
his english was usable and he used it fearlessly .	65.91996
toasting in champagne one night at the embassy , he hoisted his glass to a senator ' s wife and gaily cried `` up your bottom ' ' ! !	61.880997
for a few giddy months that coincided with one of moscow ' s smiling moods , he was the sensation of washington .	63.304436
at the state department , hard-bitten russian experts complained that the capitol was out of its wits .	125.40275
newspaper punditry was inspired to remind everyone that judas , too , had been able to smile .	88.45766
the menshikov interlude ended as larks with the russians usually end .	485.20953
finding peaceful coexistence temporarily unsuitable because of domestic politics , moscow resumed scowling and `` smilin ' mike ' ' dropped quietly out of the press except for an occasional story reporting that he had been stoned somewhere in the middle west .	107.18427
the most inscrutable embassies are the arabs ' , and the most inscrutable of the arabs are the saudi arabians .	62.529396
when king saud visited washington , the overwhelming question consuming the press was the size of his family .	128.6085
rumor had it that his children numbered in the hundreds .	145.25812
the state department was little help on this , or on much else about saudi arabia .	98.04152
a reporter who consulted a middle east information officer for routine vital statistics got nowhere until the state department man produced from his bottom desk drawer a brochure published by the arabian-american oil company .	244.756
`` this is where i get my information from ' ' , he confided .	27.416834
it ' s the only copy i ' ve got ' ' .	11.789931
the size of saud ' s family was still being debated when the king appeared for his first meeting with eisenhower .	103.63908
when it ended , a dusky sheik in desert robes flowed into hagerty ' s office to report on the interview .	73.54492
the massed reporters brushed aside the customary bromides about saudi-american friendship to bore in on the central question .	182.85231
how many children did the king have ? ?	1.0597142
`` twenty-one ' ' , replied the sheik .	17.910223
and how many of these were sons ? ?	1.0892999
`` twenty-five ' ' , the sheik replied .	19.111362
`` do you mean to tell us ' ' , a reporter asked , `` that the king has twenty-one children , twenty-five of whom are sons ' ' ? ?	31.393793
the sheik smiled and murmured `` that is precisely correct ' ' .	82.695244
the egyptians are noted for elusiveness of language .	5.8852696
when dag hammarskjold was negotiating the middle east peace after israel ' s 1956 invasion of egypt , he soon found himself speaking the mysterious phrases of cairo , a language as anarchic as casey stengel ' s .	97.35423
the reports of president nasser ' s pledges which hammarskjold was relaying from cairo to washington became increasingly incomprehensible to other diplomats , including the israeli foreign minister , mrs . golda meir .	137.67616
finally he reported that nasser was ready to make a concrete commitment in return for israeli concessions .	65.154335
the deep water is used by many people , but it is always clean , for the washing is done outside .	50.19935
i know now why our japanese friends were surprised when they walked into our bathroom .	127.36256
of course , most toilets are eastern style -- at floor level -- but even when they are raised to chair height , they are actually outside toilets -- inside .	210.99538
Average perplexity score: 130.758
